list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

hom.sense: The fifth letter of the alphabet: called jiymN, which is one of the names of letters of the fem. gender, but which it is allowable to make masc.: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]: and of the number of the letters termed maHoquwrap, and Huruwfu Alqaloqalapi, because it cannot be uttered in a case of pause without a strong compression, and a strong sound: and it is also one of those termed Xajoriy-ap, from AlX-ajoru, which is the place of opening of the mouth. (TA.)

It is sometimes substituted for I, when the latter letter is doubled, (Ḳ,) or is so substituted by some of the Arabs; (AA, Ṣ;) as in fuqayomij-N, for fuqayomiI-N; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and mur-ij-N, for mur-iI-N. (AA, Ṣ.) An Arab of the desert recited to Khalaf El-Aḥmar,
xaAliI EuwayofN waOabuw Ealij-i
AlomuToEimaAni Al-aHoma biQloEaXij-i
[My maternal uncle is 'Oweyf, and Aboo-'Alijj, who feed with flesh-meat at nightfall]; meaning EaliI- and EaXiI-. (Ṣ.) It is also sometimes substituted for a single I. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) AZ gives the following ex.:
yaA rab-i Uino kunota qabilota Huj-atijo
falaA yazaAlu XaAHijN yaOotiyka bijo
[O my Lord, if Thou accept my plea, a brayer (or mule) shall not cease to bring me to Thee (i. e. to thy temple)]; (Ṣ;) meaning Huj-atiI (Ḳ) [and biI]. Oamosajato and OamosajaA are also mentioned as occurring in a verse, for Oamosato and OamosaI [because originally Oamosayato and OamosaIa]. (Ṣ.) But all these substitutions are abominable, (Ṣ, Ibn-ʼOsfoor,) and only allowable in cases of poetical necessity. (Ibn-ʼOsfoor.) It is further said that some of the Arabs, among whom were the tribe of Ḳuḍáʼah, changed I, when occurring immediately after E, into j; and said, for raAEK, [originally raAEiIN,] raAEijN: this is what is termed EajoEajapN: Fr attributes the substitution of j for I to the tribe of Teiyi, and some of the tribe of Asad. (TA.)
Some of the Arabs also changed it into I; saying XayarapN for XajarapN, and javoyaAvN for javojaAvN, and yaS-aSa for jaS-aSa. (AZ, Ṣ in art. yS.)
[As a numeral, j denotes Three; and, as such, is generally written without the dot, but thus H, or thus H, to distinguish it from H, which denotes eight.]

entry.sense: juWojuWN The breast (Sador, Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán,” Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of a human being, (TA,) and of a bird, and ‡ of a ship: (Ṣ, TA:) or the sternum, or breast-bone: or the middle of the breast: or the part where the heads of the bones of the breast come together; as in the Nh and M: (TA:) pl. jaMjiYu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) An Arab is related to have said, maA OaToyaba juwcaAba AlOaruz-i bijaMjiYi AlUiwaz-i [How delicious is jwcAb of rice (i. e. rice prepared with sugar and flesh-meat) with the breasts of geese!]. (TA.) And you say, Xaq-ati Als-afiynapu bijuWojuWihaA ‡ [The ship clave the water with her breast]. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. jaOaba, aor. _a {yajoOabu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaOobN, (Ṣ,) He gained, earned, or acquired, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) wealth, or property: (Ḳ:) but [SM says,] I have not seen that any of the leading lexicologists has mentioned this addition of wealth, or property. (TA. [See, however, jaO-LbN, below.]) The rájiz (Ru-beh Ibn-El-ʼAjjáj, TA) says,
waQll-ehu raAEiI EamaliI wajaOobiI
[And God is mindful of my work and my earning]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also He sold jaOobi, i. e. magorap [red ochre]; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and so jabaOa. (IAạr, TA.)

jaOobN Thick, gross, big, or bulky: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or strong: (A:) applied to an ass, (A, Ḳ,) or to a wild ass: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also jaAbN, without C: (Ṣ:) pl. juWuwbN. (TA.) Accord. to the Ḳ [and the A], it signifies also Whatever is rude, or coarse; thick, gross, big, or bulky: (kul-u jaAfK galiyZK:) but in the L, we find kaAhilN jaOobN galiyZN [meaning that jaOobN applied to the part of the back termed kAhl signifies thick, or big]: and xaloqN jaOobN as meaning a thick, gross, big, or bulky, make. (TA.)
[Hence,] AljaOobu The lion. (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

And jaOobapu AlmidoraI, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or, accord. to AO (Ṣ) and the Mj (TA) and Sh, (TA in art. jwb q. v.,) without C, (Ṣ, TA,) A doe-gazelle having her horn just come forth; because the horn when it first comes forth is thick, and afterwards becomes slender; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) thus showing her to be young: (Ṣ:) or a doe-gazelle, and a cow, strong in the horn. (A.) [See also art. jwb.]
You say also, fulaAnN Xaxotu AlMli jaOobu AlS-abori † Such a one is slender in body, or person, [but] great in patience. (Ṣ.)
The navel. (Ḳ.)
Red ochre; syn. magorap [read by Golius mEzp]; (Mj, Ḳ;) with and without C, (Mj, TA.)

entry.sense: jaOobapu AlbaToni, (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ,) as also jaboOapu AlbaToni, (Ibn-Buzurj, TA,) i. q. maOonapu AlbaToni, (Ḳ,) i. e. The part of the belly that is between the navel and the pubes. (TA.)
juWobapN: see what next follows.
juWuwbapN (Ḳ) and juWobapN↓ (Ḳ accord. to some copies, but not in others nor in the TA) A grinning, and frowning, or contracting, of the face; or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (Ḳ.)
jaO-LbN A gainer, an earner, or an acquirer, of wealth, or property. (TA voce jaw-aAbN.)

[jaAvaliyqN an arabicized word, from the Greek καθολικὸς, The catholicos; i. e.] the primate of the Christians in the country of El-Islám, [residing] in the [chief] city of El-Islám: under him is the biToriyq [or biToriyk, or baTorak, i. e. patriarch] of Antioch: then, under him, is the maToraAn [or metropolitan]; under whom is the Ousoquf- [or bishop], in every province: then, the qis-iys [or priest]: then, the Xam-aAs [or deacon]: (Ḳ:) accord. to Ṣgh, a judge, or ruler: in the Tekmileh, a wise man, or sage. (TA.) j and q do not occur in any one word, unless it is arabicized or a word imitative of a sound: (Ṣ and Ḳ * at the beginning of the section in which this word is mentioned:) accord. to El-Jawáleeḳee, they do not occur in any Arabic word unless separated, as in jalawobaqN and jaranodaqN: accord. to Lth, they occur in many words, most of which are arabicized. (TA ib.)

1. jaOara, aor. _a {yajoOaru}, inf. n. juWaArN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and jaOor (Ḳ,) He, (a bull, Ṣ and Ḳ, or a calf, A,) and jaOorato she, (a cow, Ḳ,) lowed. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) juWaArN is like xuwaArN; and is substituted for the latter in a reading of the Ḳur vii. 146 and xx. 90. (Akh, Ṣ.)

Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. ns. as above, (Ḳ,) He (a man praying, A and TA) raised his voice in prayer, or supplication: (Th, Ḳ:) he cried out: (Es-Suddee, TA:) he cried out, calling for aid, or succour; humbled, or abased, himself, and raised his voice: (A:) he humbled, or abased, himself, with earnest supplication; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) AilaI Qll-ehi to God; (Ṣ;) and cried out, or called, for aid, or succour. (Ḳ.)
[Accord. to Ḳatádeh, yajoOaruwna in the Ḳur xxiii. 66 signifies yaxoraEuwna, as written in the TA; but this is app. a mistranscription for yajozaEuwna, They manifest grief and agitation;, &c.]
Also ‡ It (a plant) grew tall; (A, Ḳ;) like as one says, SaAHati AlX-ajarapu. (A.) And jaOarati AlOaroDu ‡ The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall. (A, Ḳ.)
jaOorN, applied to herbage, (Az, A, Ḳ,) ‡ Fresh, juicy, or sappy: (Ḳ,* TA:) or tall, and fullgrown: (Az, TA:) and abundant. (A, Ḳ.)

gayovN jaOorN, (Ḳ,) and juWarN↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and, accord. to Aṣ, juWaArN↓, (TA voce jawar-N,) as also jiwar-N, (Ḳ,) ‡ A copious rain; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) that makes the plants, or herbage, to grow tall: (A:) or the second, a rain that makes a sound, or noise. (TA.)
juW-rN: see jaOorN.
juWaArN: see jaOorN.
huwa jaO-rN biAll-ayoli [He is one who cries out, calling for aid, or succour; who humbles, or abases, himself, and raises his voice; much, or often, by night]. (A, TA.)
1. jaOaXato nafosuhu, aor. _a {yajoOaXu}, His soul rose, or heaved, by reason of grief or fear; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of jaAXato, aor. tajiyXu. (TA.)
Also, both of these, His (a coward's) soul purposed flight: or was frightened. (TA in art. jyX.)
jaOaXa Uilayohi, aor. _a {yajoOaXu}, He came, came forward, or advanced, towards him. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jaOoXN The return to its place, (ruwaAE, Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the fright, (rawoE, as in a copy of the A, [which latter is agreeable with explanations of the verb given above,]) of the heart, when in a state of commotion on an occasion of fright. (Lth, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

The soul (nafos) of a man: (IDrd, A, Ḳ:) or his heart: or firmness, or constancy, of heart: or strength of heart when one hears a thing and knows not what it is: (TA:) sometimes, [jaAXN,] without C: (Ḳ:) pl. juWuwXN (Ḳ) and jiYaAXN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN raAbiTu AljaOoXi Such a one restrains his soul, or himself, from flight, by reason of his courage; (Ṣ A;*) is strong in heart; as also rabiyTu AljaOoXi: (Ṣ in art. rbT:) or both signify is courageous. (Ḳ in art. rbT, q. v.) And waAhiI AljaOoXi [Infirm, or weak, in soul, or heart]. (A, TA.) And rabaTa licelika AlOamori jaOoXFA, (A,) or jaAXFA only, [without C,] (ISk, TA,) see art. rbT. And rabaTa jaOoXuhu His heart became strong. (Ḳ in art. rbT q. v.)
See also juWoXuwXN.

entry.sense: juWoXN: see what follows.

hom.sense: juWoXuwXN The breast, or chest; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also jaOoXN↓ and juWoXN↓: (A:) or its Hayozuwm, q. v. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

The forepart (Sador) of the night; accord. to which explanation it is tropical: or what is between the beginning and the third thereof: or a while thereof: (TA:) or a portion thereof; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) and of people. (Ḳ.)
Also A thick, or gross, or coarse, man. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jayoOalu The DabuE [or female hyena]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a name thereof, of the measure fayoEalu, determinate without Al (Ṣ,) imperfectly decl.; (Ḳ;) as also jayoOalapu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to Ks; (Ṣ;) and jayalu, without C, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the I not being changed into A as in naAbN and the like because the C, though literally suppressed, is considered as though meant to be retained, and because the I is considered as though meant to be quiescent; (Aboo-ʼAlee the grammarian, Ṣ, TA;) and AljayoOalu, (Ḳ,) like the first, but with Al. (TA.)
Also, AljayoOalu, accord. to Ibn-Es-Seed, The wolf: but MF deems this strange. (TA.)
jayoOalapu: see above.
jaAmN: see art. jwm.
jaAmuwsN: see art. jys.

juWonapN A receptacle of the kind termed safaT, covered with skin, for the perfumes of the seller of perfumes; as also juwnapN: originally with C: pl. like SuradN [i. e. juwanN: thus in the TA, without C]. (Ḳ.) See also art. jwn.
jaAhN: see art. jwh.
jaAwarosN: see art. jrs.
3. jaAMniI: see 3 in art. jyO.

hom.sense: 1. jab-ahu, aor. _u {yajobubu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. jab-N (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jibaAbN, (A, Ḳ, MF,) He cut it; or cut it off; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Ajtbahu↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)

jab-a xuSaAhu, inf. n. jab-N and jibaAbN, He cut off entirely, or extirpated, his testicles; (TA;) [as also Aijotab-ahaA↓; for] jab-N (A, Ḳ) and jibaAbN and AijotibaAbN (TA) signify the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, (A, Ḳ, TA,) of the testicle, (Ḳ, TA,) or of the genitals: (A:) [or] jibaAbN signifies [or signifies also, as inf. n. of jub-a,] the having the testicles, (Ṣ, TA,) or genitals, (Mṣb,) entirely cut off. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA.) You say also, jababotuhu, meaning I cut off entirely, or extirpated, his genitals; (Mṣb;) [or his testicles; or his penis; as is implied in the TA:] and jub-a, inf. n. jab-N, (Mgh, TA,) [or jibaAbN,] he had his penis and his testicles [or either of these] cut off entirely, or extirpated. (Mgh, TA.*)
jab-a Als-anaAma,, aor. _u {yajobubu}, inf. n. jab-N; and Ajtb-hu↓; He cut off the hump of the camel: accord. to Lth, jab-N signifies the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, of the hump. (TA.)

jab-a Aln-axola, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) [aor. _u {yajobubu},] inf. n. jab-N, (A, Ḳ,) or jibaAbN, (Ṣ, TA,) or jabaAbN, (A,) or both the second and last, (Mṣb, [the first is disallowed by MF,]) He fecundated the palmtrees [with the pollen of the male tree]. (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA.) You say, jaMCa zamanu AljibaAbi, (Ṣ,) or AljabaAbi, with fet-ḥ, (A,) or both, (Mṣb,) [The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees came].

jab-a Alqawoma, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yajobubu}, (TA,) inf. n. jab-N, (Ḳ,) He surpassed, or overcome, the people, or company of men; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) accord. to some, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, or in beauty, and in any or every manner. (TA.) And jab-ati Aln-isaMCa She surpassed the [other] women in her beauty. (TA.) The saying
jab-ato nisaMCa AlEaAlamiyna biAls-ababo
[She overcame the women of the whole world by means of the string] relates to a woman who measured round her hinder parts with a string, and then threw it to the women of the tribe, that they might do with it the like; but they found it to be much exceeding their measures. (TA.) See 3, in three places.
See also 2.

2. tajobiybN The reaching of the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl, in a horse, to the knee and the hock: (Ṣ:) or the rising of the whiteness to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu. (Ḳ.) You say of a horse, fiyhi tajobiybN [In him is a rising of the tHjyl to the knee and the hock]: and in this case, the horse is said to be mujab-abN: and the subst. is jababN↓ [meaning a whiteness of the legs rising to the knee and the hock]. (Ṣ.) [See mujab-abN.]

The act of shrinking [from a thing]; or the being averse [from it]; or the act of withdrawing; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) outwardly or inwardly. (TA.) You say of a man, jab-aba facahaba [He shrank, or was averse, or withdrew, and went away]. (Ṣ.) And jay-aba Aln-aAsu Eano TaAEapi Qll-ehi The people forsook, or relinquished, the obeying of God. (TA from a trad.)

The act of fleeing. (Ḳ.) You say of a man, jbab He fled. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wanaHonu UicaA jab-abotumu Eano nisaAYikumo
kamaA jab-abato mino Einodi OawolaAdihaA AlHumuro
[And we, when ye flee from your women, like as the wild asses have fled from the presence of their young ones]. (TA.) And jab-a↓, said of a man, [if not a mistranscription for jab-aba,] signifies He went quickly, fleeing from a thing. (TA.)
The act of satisfying with water (Ḳ, TA) the earth, (Aljabuwb, TA,) or cattle. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. jibaAb The act of vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, &c., (Ḳ,) as, for instance, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, and in lineage: (TA:) and mujaAb-apN the vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, (Ḳ,) &c., (TA,) and in food: (Ḳ:) but [SM says,] I know not whence this addition, respecting food, is derived. (TA. [See, however, what follows, from the A.]) You say, jaAb-aniI fajababotuhu↓ He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, and I overcame him. (TA.) And jaAb-ati AlmaroOapu SaAHibatahaA fajab-atohaA↓ HusonFA The woman vied, or contended for superiority, with her fellow, and surpassed her in beauty. (TA.) And jaAb-ahu fiI AlqiraI fajab-ahu↓ He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in the entertainment of guests, and he overcame him therein. (A.)
4. Ajb- It (camels' milk) had, or produced, what is termed jubaAb [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
5. tjb-b He clad himself with a jub-ap [q. v.]. (MA.) [And so, app., Ajtb-↓, explained by Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, as signifying He put on a vest, or tunic.]

hom.sense: 8: see 1, in three places:
and see also 5.

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. jabojaba He dealt, or trafficked, in jabaAjib [pl. of jubojubapN, q. v.]. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. tajabojaba i. q. Ait-aXaqa; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e. He prepared what is called jubojubap: (TA:) or he put what is called xaloE into a jubojubap [q. v.]. (AZ, TA.)

hom.sense: jub-N A well: (A, Ḳ:) or a well not cased with stone or the like: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a well containing much water: or a deep well: (A, Ḳ:) or of some other description: (A:) or a well in a good situation with respect to pasture: or one that people have found; not one that they have dug: (Ḳ:) or a well that is not deep: (Lth, TA:) or a well that is wide, or ample: (El-Kilábeeyeh, TA:) or a well that is cut through rock, or smooth rock, or stones, or smooth stones, or hard and smooth and large stones: (Aboo-Ḥabeeb, TA:) of the masc. gender; (Mṣb, TA;) [not fem. like biYorN;] or masc. and fem.: (Fr, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajobaAbN (Mṣb, Ḳ.) and [of mult.] jibaAbN and jibabapN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
A well that is dug wherein a grape - vine is planted; like as one is dug for the shoot of a palm - tree: pl. jibaAbN. (ISh, TA.)
The inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, whether cased with stone or the like or not. (Sh, TA.)

The juron of a well [app. meaning A hollowed stone, or stone basin, for water, placed at the mouth of a well: or, perhaps, a hollowed stone placed over the mouth; for many a well has such a stone, forming a kind of parapet]. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.)

[A kind of leathern bag;] a mazaAdap of which one part is sewed to another, (Ḳ, TA,) wherein they used to prepare the beverage termed nabiyc, until, by use, it acquired strength for that purpose; mentioned in a trad., forbidding the use of it; and also called majobuwbapN↓. (TA.)

The spathe, or envelope, of the spadix, or flowers, of the palmtree; also called juf-N: the former word was unknown to AʼObeyd: both occur, accord. to different readings, in a trad., where it is said that a charm contrived to bewitch Moḥammad was put into the jub-, or juf-, of a TaloEap: accord. to Sh, (TA,) it means the inside of a TaloEap [which latter here app. signifies, as it does in some other instances, the spathe, not the spadix, of a palmtree]; (Ḳ, TA;) in like manner as the inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, is called jub-: the pl. is jibaAbN. (TA.) Hence the well-known prov., jibaAbN falaA taEan-a OaborFA [They are merely envelopes of the flowers of palm-trees; therefore weary not thyself to effect fecundation]; applied to a man in whom is little or no good; meaning he is like the spathes of the palm-tree in which are no flowers; therefore weary not thyself by attempting to make him good; laA taEan-a being for laA tataEan-a. (MF.)

jub-apN A well-known garment [or coat], (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of the kind of those called muqaT-aEaAt: (TA:) accord. to ʼIyáḍ, a garment cut out and sewed: accord. to Ibn-Hajar and others, a double garment quilted with cotton; or, sometimes, if of wool, a single garment, not quilted with anything: (MF:) [most probably not so much resembling the modern garment more generally known by the same name (for a description and representation of which see my “Modern Egyptians,” ch. i.,) as a kind of jub-ap still worn in Northern Africa, described in this Lexicon voce midoraEapN: accord. to Golius, “tunica ex panno gossipino, cui pallium seu toga imponitur, cum subductitio panno et intercedente gossipio punctim consuta: Italis consona voce giuppa: si ita cum gossipio consuta non sit, dur-aAEapN tunica illa gossipina dicitur:”] pl. jubabN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jibaAbN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

I. q. diroEN [A coat of mail; or any coat of defence]: (Ḳ:) pl. jubabN. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,
lanaA jubabN waOaromaAHN TiwaAlN
bihin-a numaArisu AlHaroba AlX-aTuwnaA
[We have coats of mail, or of defence, and long spears: with them we ply distant war]. (TA.)
The part of a spear-head into which the shaft enters: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the vaEolab is the part of the spear-shaft that enters into the head. (TA.)

[In the TA, jub-apu Alr-umoHi is also explained as meaning mA dxl mn AlsnAn fyh The part of the spearhead that enters into the shaft: but it seems that mn has been inserted here by a mistake of the copyist; and that the true meaning intended is the part of the spear-shaft into which the head enters; though in general the shaft enters into the head.]
The part in which is the muXaAXap [q. v.] of a horn. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.)
The HijaAj [or bone that surrounds the cavity (see art. Hj)] of the eye. (Ḳ.)

The contents (HaXow) of the solid hoof: or the horny box (qaron) of the solid hoof: or the joint between the sAq [which seems to mean here, as it does in many other instances, the hind shank,] and the thigh: (Ḳ:) or the shank-joint of a horse or the like (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi [commonly applied, as in the Ṣ and Ḳ voce rusog, to the upper extremity of the pastern, i. e. the fetlock-joint, which seems to be the meaning intended in this instance,]) in the ciraAE [which here app. means the fore leg, not the arm]: or, accord. to Aṣ, the part where the wZyf [or shank] is set into the hoof: (Ṣ:) or the part of the rsg [or pastern], of a horse, where the wZyf [or shank] joins upon the HawoXab [which seems here to mean the upper pasternbone]: or, as AO says, the part where a horse's wZyf joins to the upper part of the HwXb: or, as he says in another place, the place where each tibia and hind shank, of a horse, meet; [the hockjoint;] expl. by mltqI sAqyh wwZyfI rjlyh: and the place of junction of any two bones, except in the back-bone. (TA.)
Accord. to Lth, Whiteness of the bTAnyp [a word which I have not found anywhere but in this instance] of a horse or similar beast, extending to the hairs that surround the hoof. (TA.)

jababN A cutting off of the hump of a camel: (Ḳ:) or a cutting in the hump of a camel: (TA:) [or the state of having the hump cut off; as seems to be indicated in the Ṣ:] or an erosion of the hump of a camel, by the saddle, so that it does not grow large. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: jubabN Butter, or what is produced by churning, of camels' milk; like as zubod is what is produced by churning of cows' or sheep's or goats' milk: (Mṣb in art. zbd:) what rises upon the surface, (T, Ṣ,) or what has collected together [or coagulated], (Ḳ,) of the milk of camels, resembling zubod, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which camels' milk has not: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) when a camel shakes about a skin of camels' milk, suspended to him, what is termed jbAb collects at the mouth of the skin. (T.)

jabuwbN The earth, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) in general; (Lḥ;) sometimes written jabuwbu, as a proper name, without the article, and imperfectly decl., like XaEuwbu: (TA:) so called because it is cut, i. e. dug; or because it cuts, i. e. dissunders, the bodies of those buried in it: (Suh, TA:) and hence jab-aAnN↓ and jab-aAnapN↓, signifying a burial-ground; from Aljab-u and Aljabuwbu; accord. to Kh; but others derive these two words from jbn: (TA:) or rugged land: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or hard or rugged land, composed of rock, not of soil: (IAạr, TA:) or earth, or dust: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or the surface of the earth; (ISh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) whether plain or rugged or mountainous: (ISh:) a word without a pl.: (Ṣ:) also coarse, or big, lumps or clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud; plucked from the surface of the ground: (TA:) or crumbled clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud: (IAạr, TA:) and with p {jabuwbapN}, a lump, or clod, of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud. (Ḳ.)
jibaAbiI-N: see what next follows.
jub-iI-N [app. a contraction of jubabiI-N], or jibaAbiI-N↓ A seller of jibaAb [pl. of jub-apN, q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
jabojabapN: see what next follows, in two places.

jubojubapN, (Ṣ,) or jabojabapN↓, (A,) or both, (Ḳ,) and jabaAjibu [which is the pl.], (L, TA,) The stomach of a ruminant animal * (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) in which xaloE [q. v.] is put, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e., (TA,) in which is put flesh-meat cut in pieces; (Ḳ, TA;) or in which is put flesh-meat to be used as provision in travelling; (TA;) or in which melted grease (Ṣ, Ḳ) is collected (Ṣ) or put: (Ḳ:) or the skin of the side of a camel, cut out in a round form, in which is prepared flesh-meat, (Ḳ, TA,) such as is called waXiyqap, (TA,) which is flesh-meat that is boiled once, and then cut into strips, and dried, or salted and sun-dried; the most lasting of all provision [of the kind]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the first and second both signify tripe; in Persian, Xknbh or UiXokanobah. (MA.) A coward is likened to a jbjbp in which xlE is put; because of his turgidness and his little profitableness. (TA.)
Also, the first, A vessel, or receptacle, made of skin, in which water is given to camels, and in which one macerates habiyd [i. e. colocynths, or the pulp thereof, or the seeds thereof]. (TA.)
And A basket, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of small size, (TA,) made of skins, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in which dust, or earth, is removed: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Ḳṭ, it is [jabojabapN↓,] with fet-ḥ: (TA:) pl. jabaAjibu. (Ṣ.)
And A drum: pl. jabaAjibu [which is explained in the Ḳ as meaning “a drum” instead of “drums”]: as in the saying, Duribato EalaI baAbihi AljabaAjibu [The drums were beaten at his door]. (A.)
jubojubiI-N A tripe-seller. (Golius from Meyd. [See jubojubapN.])
jubojubiy-apN Food made with tripe; in Persian, Xikanobaho waA; (Golius from Meyd;) in Turkish, suxotuw XwrbAsI. (MA.)

Oajab-u A camel having his hump cut off: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having his hump cut off: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having his hump eroded by the saddle, so that it does not grow large: (Ḳ:) or having no hump: (A, TA:) fem. jab-aMCu. (A, Ḳ.)

And [hence,]the fem., ‡ A woman not having [prominent] buttocks: (Ḳ:) or i. q. rasoHaMCu [i. e. having small buttocks sticking together; or having little flesh in her posteriors and things]: (ISh, TA:) or whose bosom and breasts have not become large: (Ḳ:) or whose breast has not become large: (Sh, TA:) or small in the breast; from the same epithet applied to a she-camel; (A;) for a woman having small breasts is like the camel that has no hump: (TA:) or having no thighs; (Ḳ;) i. e. having lean thighs; as though having no thighs. (TA.) Also, the masc., † A pubes having little flesh. (TA.)
[Hence, also,] AlOajab-u i. q. Alfaroju [as meaning The pudendum muliebre]; (Ḳ;) from the same word as applied to a camel [having no hump]. (TA.)
majab-apu The middle, or main part, (jaAd-p,) of a road. (Ṣ.)

mujab-abN A horse in which the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl reaches to the knee and the hock; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] in which the whiteness [of the lower part of the leg] reaches to the knee and the hock or the knees and the hocks: (TA:) or in which the tHjyl reaches to his knees: (Lth, TA:) or in which the whiteness rises to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu; (Ḳ, TA;) or more than this, [perhaps a mistake of a copyist for less than this,] so as not to reach to the knees: or in which the whiteness reaches to the hairs that surround his hoof. (TA.)
biYorN mujab-abapN Aljawofi A well having in the middle a part wider than the rest, hollowed out like a cupola. (Fr, TA.)
majobuwbN Having the genitals, (Mṣb,) or the testicles (Ṣ,* Mgh, TA) and the penis, (Mgh,) cut off entirely, or extirpated: (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or having the penis cut off. (TA.)
majobuwbapN: see jub-u.

1. jabaOa and jabiYa, aor. _a {yajobaOu}, He restrained, or withheld, himself; refrained, forbore, or abstained; or turned back, or reverted. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, jabaOa Eanohu, and jabiYa, meaning He restrained, or withheld, himself,, &c., from him, or it; and regarded him, or it, with reverence, veneration, dread, awe, or fear: (TA:) [or,] accord. to AZ, jabaOotu Eani Alr-ajuli, inf. n. jaboCN and jubuwoCN, [to which Golius adds jubuWN and jibaMCN, but, I suspect, from incorrect MSS.,] means I drew, or held, or hung, back from the man; or remained behind him; or shrank from him; or shrank from him and hid myself: and he cites (from Nuseyb Ibn-Mihjen, TA)
fahalo Oana Uil-a mivolu say-iqapi AlEidaI
Uini Qsotaqodamato naHorN waUino jabaOato EaqorN
[And am I otherwise than like the beasts driven away by the enemy? If they go before, slaughter befalls them; and if they remain behind, hocking]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, maA jabaOa Eano XatomiI He did not draw back from reviling me; did not desist, or abstain, therefrom. (TA.)
It (a sword) recoiled, or reverted, without penetrating, or without effect: (Ḳ:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.)

It (the sight, or the eye,) recoiled, or reverted: (Ḳ:) or so the former verb [only]; and disliked, or disapproved, or hated, the thing [that was before it]. (TA.) You say, jabaOato EayoniI Eani AlX-aIoCi My eye recoiled, or reverted, from the thing. (Ṣ.) And of a woman of displeasing aspect you say, Uin-a AlEayoni latajobaOu EanohaA [Verily the eye recoils from her with dislike]. (Aṣ, TA.)
He disliked, disapproved, or hated: (Ḳ:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) You say, jabaOa AlX-aIoCa He disliked,, &c., the thing. (TA.)
He inclined his neck: (Ḳ:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.)
He hid himself; (Ḳ, TA;) [app. from fear;] as, for instance, a Dab- [q. v.] in its hole. (TA.)

He, or it, came, or went, forth, or out: (Ḳ:) [or so the former verb only.] You say of a serpent, jabaOa Ealayohi It came forth upon him from its hole (Ṣ, TA) so as to frighten him; and in like manner one says of a hyena, and a Dab-, and a jerboa. (TA.) And jabaOa EalaI Alqawomi He came forth unexpectedly upon the people, or company of men. (TA.) And jabaOa AljaraAdu The locusts invaded, or came suddenly upon, the country. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. OajobaOato said of a land, (Ṣ,) or AjbO said of a place, (Ḳ,) It abounded with [the kind of truffles called] kamoOap, (Ṣ,) or kamoC, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or [rather] jibaOap [a pl. or quasi-pl. n. of jaboC. (So in other copies of the Ḳ.)]
AjbO He hid a thing. (Ḳ.) And hence, He hid his camels from the collector of the poor-rate. (IAạr, TA.)

He sold seed-produce before it showed itself to be in a good state, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or before it came to maturity. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., mano OajobaI faqado OarobaI [He who sells seed-produce before it shows itself to be in a good state, or before it has come to maturity, practices the like of usury]: (Ṣ, TA:) originally with C, (Ṣ,) which is suppressed for the purpose of assimilation [to ArbI]. (TA.) [See 4 in art. jbw and jbI.]
AjbO EalaI Alqawomi He overlooked the people, or company of men; or commanded, or had, a view of them; or came in sight of them; syn. OaXorafa. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaboCN sing. of jibaOapN, like as faqoEN is of fiqaEapN, and garodN of giradapN: (Ṣ:) or i. q. kamoOapN: (Ḳ:) or n. un. of jaboOapN↓, which is a coll. gen. n., like kamoOapN: (MF and TA, voce qaEobN:) [J says,] jibaOapN signifies Red kamoOap [or truffles]: or, accord. to El-Aḥmar, those [truffles] that incline to redness; kamoOapN signifying those that incline to dust-colour and blackness; and fiqaEapN, the white; and banaAtu Oawobara, the small: (Ṣ:) accord. to AḤn, jaboOapN↓ signifies a white thing resembling a kamoC, of which no use is made: but accord. to IAạr, the black kamoOap; which, he says, are the best of kmOp: (TA:) the pl. of jaboCN is OajobuWN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (Ṣ,) and jibaOapN, [as mentioned above,] or, accord. to Sb, this is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and jabaON↓, (Ḳ,) or this also is a quasi-pl. n. (TA.)
I. q. OakamapN [q. v., i. e. A hill, or mound,, &c.]: pls. as above. (Ḳ.)
A hollow, or cavity, (T, Ḳ,) in a mountain, (TA,) in which the water (T, Ḳ) of the rain (TA) stagnates, (T,) or collects: (Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
jabaON: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: jaboOapN: see jaboCN, in two places.
Also A shoemaker's board, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) on which he cuts his leather; also called qurozuwmN. (Ṣ.)
And The place where the false ribs of the camel end, and thence as far as the navel and udder. (Ḳ.)
And The part of the belly called the maOonapN thereof; as also jaOobapN; (Ibn-Buzurj, TA;) i. e. the part between the navel and the pubes. (TA in art. jOb.)

entry.sense:
jub-aON (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jub-aMCN↓ (Sb, Ḳ) Fearful, or cowardly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. with p {jub-aOapN]: and therefore the pl. is formed by the addition of w and n. (Sb, TA.)
Mafrook Ibn-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee says,
famaA Oana mino rayobi Almanuwni bijub-aOK
walaA OanaA mino sayobi AlUilehi biMyisi
[But I am not fearful of the vicissitudes of fortune, nor despairing of the favour of God]. (Ṣ, TA.)
jub-aMCN: see what next precedes.
jaAbiYN The locust, or locusts: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because of the coming forth thereof [suddenly or unexpectedly: see 1, last two sentences]: (Ṣ, TA:) as also jaAbK [q. v.]. (TA.)
OaroDN majobaOapN A land abounding with [the truffles called] jibaOap. (Ṣ.)

Aljibotu, not a pure Arabic word, because it comprises the letters H and t without any of the letters of the kind called cawolaqiI- [which are r and l and n]; (Ṣ;) The idol: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or idols: (Ksh in iv. 54:) or the name of a certain idol, (Bḍ and Jel on that verse,) belonging to Kureysh; as also AlT-aAguwtu: (Jel:) and that which is worshipped instead, or to the exclusion, of God; whatever it be: (Ksh, Bḍ, Ḳ:) said to be originally Aljibosu, i. e., (Bḍ,) he, or that, wherein is no good: (Bḍ, Ḳ:) and the diviner: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the enchanter: (Ṣ, Ḳ, Kull:) and the like thereof: (Ṣ:) or the Devil; Satan: (Kull:) and enchantment. (Esh-Shaabee, Ḳ.) Accord. to Esh-Shaabee, yuWominuwna biAljiboti waAlT-aAguwti, in the Ḳur [iv. 54], means They believe in enchantment and the Devil: or, accord. to I’Ab, by Aljbt is meant Hoyeí Ibn-Akhtab; and by AlTAgwt, Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf: (TA:) or the words relate to these two men, Jews, who, in order to induce Kureysh to join with them in a league against Moḥammad, prostrated themselves to the gods of Kureysh: (Ksh, Bḍ:) or to certain Jews, who said that the worship of idols is more pleasing to God than that to which Moḥammad invited. (Bḍ.) It is said in a trad. that what are termed AlT-iyarapu and AlEiyaAfapu and AlT-aroqu are mina Aljiboti [app. meaning of things wherein is no good: or kinds of divination: or from the Devil]. (Ṣ.)

1. jabacahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. _i {yajobicu}, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jabocN, (T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) i. q. jacabahu (T,* Ṣ, A, Mgh,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ,*, &c.) i. e. He drew it;, &c.: (T, TA:) formed by transposition from the latter; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A;) accord. to some: (Mṣb:) or it is a dial. var. of the latter; (M, L, Ḳ, &c.;) of the dial. of Temeem; (T, Mṣb;) not formed from the latter by transposition, (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, IJ, M, L, Ḳ,) for both are equally conjugated: (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, IJ, L, Mṣb:) and AijotibaAcN [inf. n. of Ajtbc↓] signifies the same as jabocN. (Ḳ.) jabacaniI rajulN mino xalofiI, meaning A man pulled me from behind me, occurs in a trad. (L.)
You say also, jabacatohu and jacabatohu, meaning, ‡ She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage. (T and TA in art. jcb.)
7. AinojibaAcN [inf. n. of Anjbc] i. q. AinojicaAbN, (Ḳ,) meaning Quick going or journeying or travelling. (TA.)
8: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. jabara, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yajoburu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jaborN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and jubuwrN, (M, Ḳ,) which latter, accord. to MF, is an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the trans. verb also, (TA,) and jibaArapN, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) He set a bone; reduced it from a fractured state; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) as also jb-r↓, (A, IAmb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓, (Ibn-Talhah, MF, TA,) but this is extremely strange, and not found in the lexicons of celebrity, (MF,) and not heard by AO; (TA;) [and Ajtbr↓.] One says also, jb-r↓ yadahu, (A, IAmb,) or jabarahaA, (Mṣb,) He (a bone-setter) set his arm, or reduced it from a fractured state: (A:) or put upon it the jabiyrap [or splints]. (Mṣb.)

Hence, (TA,) jabara, (AAF, M, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. jaborN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and jubuwrN [but respecting this latter see above] and jibaArapN; (Ḳ;) and jb-r↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓; (Ibn-Talhah, MF, TA; [but respecting this form see above;]) and Ajtbr↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He restored a man from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (AAF, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.:) or he benefited a poor man; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him: (M, Ḳ:) but the former is the more appropriate explanation: (AAF, TA:) and this signification is tropical; (IDrst, MF, TA;) the poor man being likened to one who has a broken bone, and his restoration to wealth, or competence, being likened to the setting of the bone; wherefore he is called faqiyrN, as though the vertebræ of his back were broken: (IDrst, TA:) in the A it is mentioned as proper, not tropical; but the author of the A afterwards mentions jabarotu fulaAnFA as tropical in the sense of naEaXotuhu ‡ [I recovered such a one from his embarrassment,, &c.; repaired his broken fortune, or his condition]. (TA.) One says also, jabarotu faAqapa Alr-ajuli ‡ [I repaired the broken fortune of the man;] I restored the man to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency. (AHeyth, TA.) And jabarotu Alyatiyma † [I put the affairs of the orphan into a right, or good, state: or] I gave to the orphan. (Mṣb.) And jabara ‡ He restored anything to a sound, right, or good, state. (IDrst, TA.) And jabarahu Qll-ehu † [May God render him sound, and strong]: said in relation to a child. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. zrE.) And jabarotu niSaAba Alz-akaApi bikacaA † I made the amount of the property equal to that which renders it incumbent on the possessor to pay the poor-rate, by [adding] such a thing: the name of that thing is jbrAn [app. juboraAnN↓]: and the person who does this is termed jaAbirN↓. (Mṣb.)

jabara also signifies He compelled, or constrained, another. (B.) You say, jabarahu EalaI AlOamori, (Lḥ, Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoburu}, inf. n. jaborN and jubuwrN, (Mṣb,) a chaste form of the verb, of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Az, TA,) or of the Benoo-Temeem and of many of the people of El-Ḥijáz, (Mṣb,) or of Temeem alone; (Lḥ, TA;) [but said in the Mgh to be of weak authority;] and Ajbrhu↓; (Th, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) both these forms of the verb mentioned by AZ, Fr, AʼObeyd, and others, (Mṣb,) but the latter is the form used by the generality of the Arabs, (Lḥ, TA,) and by the grammarians [in general]; (TA;) He compelled him, against his will, to do the thing: (Lḥ, Th, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) UijobaArN↓ originally signifying the inciting, urging, or inducing, another to restore a thing to a sound, right, or good, state. (B.) And Ajbrhu↓ EalaI AlHukomi He (a judge) compelled him to submit to, or to perform, the sentence. (L.)

Also jabara, [aor. _u {yajoburu},] inf. n. jubuwrN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaborN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter, accord. to MF [and the Mgh], is an inf. n. of the trans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the intrans. verb also; (TA;) and Anjbr↓, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Ajtbr↓, (T, Ṣ,) and tjb-r↓; (Ḳ;) It (a bone) became set, or reduced from a fractured state. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And [hence,] the first of these verbs, with the same inf. ns.; (Ḳ;) and Ajtbr↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and Anjbr↓, and tjb-r↓, and Astjbr↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He (a poor man, Ḳ, and an orphan, TA) became restored from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or received a benefit, or benefits: (Ḳ:) Ajtbr↓ is syn. with AntEX ‡ [he recovered, or became recovered, from his embarrassment,, &c.]. (A.) [And † It (anything) became restored to a sound, right, or good, state.] El-ʼAjjáj has used jabara transitively and intransitively in the same sentence, saying,
qado jabara Ald-iyna AlUilaAhu fajabaro
[† God hath restored the religion to a sound, right, or good, state, and it hath become restored thereto]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to some, the second verb is corroborative of the first; the meaning being, God hath desired, or purposed, to restore the religion,, &c., and hath completed its restoration. (B.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in five places.
Ajbrhu also signifies He imputed to him [the tenet of] Aljabor; (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ;*) he called him a jabariI-: (L:) like as Akfrhu signifies “he imputed to him infidelity.” (Ṣ.)

5. tjb-r: see 1, latter part, in two places. Also ‡ What had gone from him (a man) returned to him: (Ḳ:) or some of his property that had gone from him returned to him. (T, TA.) † He (a sick man) became in a good state. (Ḳ.) † It (a plant, TA, and a tree, Ḳ) became green, and put forth leaves (Ḳ, TA) and fresh green twigs, when dry: produced fresh shoots in its dry parts: (TA:) it (herbage) became somewhat restored to a good state after having been eaten: (Ḳ,* TA:) or grew after having been eaten. (Ṣ.)
He (a man, Ṣ) magnified himself; behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
† He (a man) obtained wealth, or property: (Ḳ:) but Lḥ explains it as meaning, intransitively, he obtained wealth, or property. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, latter part, in two places.

8: see 1, in five places. You say also, OaSaAbatohu muSiybapN laA yajotabiruhaA [† A calamity befell him from which he will not recover]; i. e. laA majobara↓ minohaA [† there is no recovering from it]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 10: see 1, latter part.
Astjbrhu ‡ He exerted himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to him, taking care of him, or putting his affairs into a right, or proper, state. (A.)

jaborN, in computation, † The addition of something for the purpose of reparation. (TA.) [Hence, Aljaboru † Algebra; more commonly called Aljaboru waAlmuqaAbalapu perfective addition and compensative subtraction; or restoration and compensation; because of the frequency of these operations in the reduction of equations.]

The contr. of qadarN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is the assertion that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit acts of disobedience; (Mṣb;) the virtual denial that actions proceed from man, and attributing them to God; the sect that hold the tenet thus termed asserting that man, with respect to his actions, is like the feather suspended in the air; whereas qadarN signifies the “virtual attributing of optional, or voluntary, actions to man; asserting that man creates his own optional, or voluntary, actions:” (IbrD:) AʼObeyd says that it is a post-classical term. (Ṣ.)

A king; (AA, T, M, Ḳ;) of uncertain derivation: (M:) and a slave, or servant: (AʼObeyd, Kr, Ḳ, &c.:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) and a man: (AA, AʼObeyd, Ḳ, &c.:) [see jaboraYiylu:] and a young man: and [a] courageous [man]. (Ḳ.)

[Also, app., Aloes-wood: Aljaboru is explained in the Ḳ as signifying AlEuwdu, which means wood in general, as well as aloes-wood in particular; and to this is added in the TA, AlcI yujobaru bihi, as though the meaning were the wood with which one sets bones; but I think that yujobaru is a mistranscription for yujam-aru; and that the meaning is aloes-wood with which one fumigates.]

entry.sense: jabariI-N or jaboriI-N: see jabariy-apN.
jabaruw-apN and jaboruw-apN and jabaruwtN, &c.: see what next follows.

hom.sense: jabariy-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaboriy-apN and jiboriy-apN and jibiriy-apN and jiboriyaMCu↓ (Ḳ) and jabariy-aMCu↓ (Aboo-Naṣr, TA) and jabaruw-apN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaboruw-apN↓ (Ḳ) and jabaruwtN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, one of the forms most known, of the measure faEaluwtN, like malakuwtN and rahabuwtN and ragabuwtN and raHamuwtN, said to be the only other words of this measure, though, as MF says, this requires consideration, TA) and juboruwtN↓ (Ḳ) and jaboraWuwtN↓ (Et-Tedmuree, TA) and jabaruwtaI↓ (Ḳ, like raHamuwtaI, [&c.], TA) and jab-uwrapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jab-uwrN↓ (Lḥ, Kr) and jub-uwrN↓ (Lḥ, TA) and jubuwrapN↓ and tajobaArN↓, (Ḳ,) all inf. ns., (TA,) [or simple substs.,] meaning The quality denoted by the epithet jab-aArN; (Ḳ;) i. e. self-magnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence; or proud, haughty, or insolent, behaviour; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;), &c. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence, maA kaAnato nubuw-apN Uil-aA tanaAsaxahaA mulokN jabariy-apF [There has been no prophetic office but a kingly office has succeeded in its place through some one's selfmagnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence]; i. e., but kings have magnified themselves, or behaved proudly or haughtily or insolently, after it. (A, TA.)

Aljabariy-apu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Aljaboriy-apu, (Th, Mṣb,) or the latter is a mispronunciation, or is the correct form, (Ḳ,) and the former is so pronounced in order to assimilate it to Alqadariy-apu; (Mṣb, Ḳ;*) the latter is the pronunciation of the scholastic theologians of the persuasion of EshSháfi'ee (El-Háfidh in the “Tabseer,” B) in old times, but the term used in the conventional language of the modern scholastic theologians is Almujobarapu↓; (B;) and Aljbry-p, also, is a post-classical term; (TA;) The contr. of Alqadariy-apu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the sect who hold the tenet termed jaborN [q. v.]; (Mṣb;) a sect of those who follow their own natural desires, whose founder was El-Hoseyn Ibn-Moḥammad En-Nejjár El-Basree, who assert that man has no power; that [what are termed] voluntary motions are of the same predicament as a tremour; though this does not oblige them to deny the imposition of duties; (Lb, TA;) a sect who assert that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit sins: (AHeyth, TA:) n. un. jabariI-N↓ or jaboriI-N. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: jaboraAlu and jiboraAlu: see jaboraYiylu.
juboraAnN: see 1.
jiboriylu and jaboriylu, &c.: see jaboraYiylu.
jiboriynu and jaboriynu: see jaboraYiylu.
jiboriyaMCu and jabariy-aMCu: see jabariy-apN.

jaboraYiylu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) imperfectly decl., because having the quality of a proper name and that of a foreign word, or being a compound regarded as forming a single word, as some say, (TA,) originally Syriac, or Hebrew, [גַּבְרִיאֵל,] (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee],) A proper name of an angel; (TA;) [Gabriel: and also, of a man:] signifying the servant of God: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or (rather, TA) the man of God: (AʼObeyd, TA:) being said to be composed of jaborN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) signifying “servant,” or “slave,” (Mṣb, TA,) or rather “man,” (TA,) and UiylN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) signifying “God:” (Mṣb, TA:) or both together signify the servant of the Compassionate: or the servant of the Mighty, or Glorious: (TA:) this form of the word is of the dialects of Keys and Temeem: (TA:) and there are other dial. vars.; namely, jaborayiylu↓, without C, and jaboraAYiylu ↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, and jaboraYilu ↓, and jaboraAYiylu ↓, (Ḳ,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jaboraAYilu ↓, (Ḳ,) and jaboraAyilu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jiboriylu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, which is the form most known and most chaste, and is of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, TA,) and jaboriylu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ, reckoned of weak authority by Fr, because the measure faE-iyl [or faEoliyl] does not exist in the language, for as to samowiyl, mentioned by Esh-Shiháb as against the objection of Fr, it is of the measure faEowiyl, MF, TA,) and jaborayolu↓, and jaboraAlu↓, and jiboraAlu↓, (Ḳ,) and jiboriynu↓, and jaboriynu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jaboraAYiynu↓. (Es-Suyootee, MF.)
jaborayiylu: see jaboraYiylu.
jaboraAYilu and jaboraAyilu: see jaboraYiylu.
jaboraAYiylu and jaboraAyiylu: see jaboraYiylu.
jaboraAYiyna: see jaboraYiylu.

hom.sense: jubaArN A thing of which no account, or for which no revenge or retaliation or mulct, is taken. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) You say, cahaba damahu jubaArFA His blood went unrevenged, unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct. (Ṣ, A.) And juroHN jubaArN A wound for which is no retaliation, nor any expiatory mulct. (A, TA.) And HarobN jubaArN A war in which is no retaliation, (Ḳ, TA,) nor any expiatory mulct. (TA.) And AlmaEodinu jubaArN [The mine is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if the mine fall in upon him who is working in it, and he perish, his hirer is not to be punished for it. (Ṣ and Mṣb from a trad.) And AlbiYoru jubaArN [The well is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if a man fall into an ancient well, and perish, his blood is not to be expiated by a mulct: (TA:) or, as some say, it relates to a hired man's descending into a well to cleanse it, or to take forth something from it, if he fall into it and die. (TA in art. bOr.) And jurHu AlEajumaMCi jubaArN The wound of the speechless beast, if it get loose and wound a man or other thing while loose, is a thing for which no retaliation or expiatory mulct is exacted. (T, A,* Mṣb.*)
Clear, or quit, of a thing: so in the saying, OanaA minohu xalaAwapN wujubaArN [I am clear, or quit, of it]. (Ḳ. [See also faAlijN.])
A torrent. (Ḳ.)

Anything that corrupts, or mars, and destroys; (so accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, and the TA;) as the torrent, &c.: (TA:) or anything that is corrupted, or marred, and destroyed. (So accord. to other copies of the Ḳ.)
Tuesday; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) an ancient name thereof, (Ṣ,) used in the Time of Ignorance; (TA;) as also jibaArN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jibaArN: see what next precedes.

jibaArapN and jabiyrapN↓ Splints; pieces of wood with which bones are set, or reduced from a fractured state: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or bones which are put upon a diseased part of the person, to reduce it to a sound state: pl. jabaAYiru. (Mṣb.)
Also, both words, A wide bracelet; syn. yaAraqN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a bracelet (siwaAr) of gold or silver: pl. jabaAYirapN [or jabaAYiru, as above?]. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
jubuwrapN: see jabariy-apN.
jabiyrapN: see jibaArapN.

jab-aArN One who magnifies himself, or behaves proudly or haughtily or insolently, and does not hold any one to have any claim upon him, or to deserve anything of him: (Ḳ:) one who slays when in anger: (Ṣ, A:) one who slays unjustly: (Ḳ:) imperious, or domineering, by absolute force and power; overbearing; tyrannical; a tyrant: (TA:) any one who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; who is bold, or audacious, and immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient, or rebel-lious; or who exalts himself and is inordinate in infidelity; or who is extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing; or who is refractory, or averse from obedience; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also jib-iyrN↓: (Ḳ:) or this latter signifies one who magnifies himself much, or behaves very proudly or haughtily or insolently: (Ṣ:) and the former, one who proudly, haughtily, or insolently, disdains the service of God: (Lḥ, TA:) fem. with p {jab-aArapN}: pl. masc. jab-aAruwna and jabaAbirapN. (A, TA.)

Aljab-aArN [A name of] God; so called because of his magnifying Himself [above every other being], (Ḳ,) and his highness: (TA:) meaning the Compeller of his creatures to do whatsoever He willeth: (Bḍ and Jel in lix. 23:) or the Compeller of his creatures to obey the commands and prohibitions which He pleaseth to impose upon them: (Mṣb, TA:) accord. to Fr, from Oajobara, and the only instance known to him of an epithet of the measure faE-aAlN from a verb of the measure OafoEala except dar-aAkN [q. v.] from Oadoraka: (Az, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, from jabara as syn. with Oajobara: (Mṣb:) it is also explained as meaning the Supreme; the High above his creatures: (Az, TA:) or the Unattainable; and hence applied to the palm-tree [of which the branches cannot be reached by the hand]: (IAmb, TA:) or it may signify ‡ the Restorer of the poor to wealth or competence or sufficiency. (Az, TA.) [God is also called] jab-aAru Alquluwbi EalaI fiTaraAtihaA † The Establisher of hearts according to their natural constitutions which He hath given them in the mothers' wombs, disposing them to know Him and to confess Him, both the unfortunate of them and the fortunate. (TA from a trad. of ʼAlee.)
Also ‡ A name of AljawozaMCu [the constel-lation Orion]; (A, Ḳ;) because it is [represented] in the form of a crowned king upon a throne. (A.)
ciraAEu Aljab-aAri † The cubit of the king: (A, TA:) or the long cubit: or, as Ḳṭ thinks, by Aljb-Ar is here meant a certain foreign king whose fore arm was of full length. (TA.)
qalobN jab-aArN ‡ A heart that receives not admonition: (A:) or that admits not compassion. (Ḳ.)

jab-aArN, (Seer, Ḳ,) without p, (Seer, TA,) applied to a palm-tree (naxolapN), signifies ‡ Tall and young; (Seer, Ḳ, TA;) as also jub-aArN↓: (Ḳ:) or is applied to palmtrees collectively (naxolN), and signifies tall, and above the reach of the hand; (T, Ṣ;) and the epithet applied to a single palm-tree is with p; (Ṣ, A;) in this sense; meaning less than saHuwqN: (A:) or, with p {jab-aArapN}, it signifies a young palm-tree, that has attained its utmost height and has borne fruit: (M:) or that has been ascended [for the purpose of cutting off its fruit], and retains its excellence, surpassing therein other palm-trees. (AḤn, TA.)
Also, hence, as Az thinks, (TA,) ‡ Huge, tall, and strong; a giant. (T, A,* Ḳ.)
And, with p {jab-aArapN}, (Ṣ, A,) and also without p {jab-aArN}, (A,) applied to a she-camel, ‡ Great (Ṣ, A) and fat. (Ṣ.)
jub-aArN: see jab-aArN.
jab-uwrN and jub-uwrN: see jabariy-apN.
jib-iyrN: see jab-aArN.
jab-uwrapN: see jabariy-apN.

jaAbirN, (Ṣ,) and jaAbiru bonu Hab-apa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) names of ‡ Bread; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Oabuw jaAbirK is a surname thereof; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so Oum-u jaAbirK: which last also signifies the ear of corn: (T in art. Am:) and i. q. Alhariysapu [grain, or wheat, bruised, or brayed, and then cooked]. (Ḥar p. 227.)

fulaAnN jaAbirN liI i. q. musotajobirN↓ ‡ [Such a one exerts himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to me, taking care of me, or putting my affairs into a right, or proper, state]. (A.)
See also 1.
tajobaArN: see jabariy-apN.
majobarN [an inf. n. of 1]: see 8.
Almujobarapu: see jabariy-apN.
mujab-irN One who sets bones, or reduces them from a fractured state; a bone-setter. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
majobuwrapN A woman possessed by a jinnee, or genie; syn. majonuwnapN; but this is held to be of weak authority. (Mgh.)
Almutajab-iru The lion. (Ḳ.)
musotajobirN: see jaAbirN.
jaboraYiylu and its vars.: see art. jbr.
jibosN [Gypsum;] i. q. jiS-N, or jaS-N, (Ḳ,) with which one builds. (Kr, TA.*)
majobasapN or mujab-asapN: see jab-aAsapN.

hom.sense: 1. jabalahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajobulu} (Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yajobilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jabolN, (KL.) He (God) created him. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL.) So in the phrase, jabalahu EalaI kacaA, (Mṣb,) or ElI AlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ,) He (God) created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to such a thing, or to the thing; adapted him, or disposed him, by nature thereto. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., jubilati Alquluwbu EalaI Hub-i mano OaHosana UilayohaA wabugoDi mano OasaMCa UilayohaA [Hearts are created with a disposition to the love of him who does good to them, and the hatred of him who does evil to them]. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) i. q. jabarahu [evidently as meaning He compelled him, against his will, EalaI AlOamori to do the thing; for he who is created with a disposition to do a thing is as though he were compelled to do it]; and so Ajblhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. UijobaAlN. (TA.)
jabila † He (a man) became like a mountain (jabal) in bigness, thickness, coarseness, or roughness. (TA.)
jabila Hadiyduhumo (Ḳ, TA; in the CK, jabala; and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, without any vowels;) † Their iron was, or became, blunt, such as would not penetrate. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 3. jAbl He (a man) alighted, or descended and abode, or sojourned, or settled, in a mountain. (AA, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajbl He came, or went, or betook himself, to the mountain. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
‡ He (a digger) reached a hard place, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or stone, (Mgh,) in his digging. (TA. [AlHaAfir, meaning “the digger,” Golius seems to have misunderstood as meaning “the hoof” of a horse.])
[Hence,] ‡ He (a poet) experienced difficulty in diction, (Ḳ, TA,) so that he said nothing original, nor anything in the way of repetition. (TA.)
And Talaba HaAjapF faOajobala † He sought a thing that he wanted, and failed of attaining it. (TA.)
And saOalonaAhumo faOajobaluwA ‡ We asked them, and they refused, and did not give. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, TA.)
And OajobaluwA ‡ Their iron became blunt, so that it would not penetrate. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Ajblhu ‡ He found him to be a jabal, i. e. a niggard: (Ḳ, TA:) it is considered as implying fixedness. (TA.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 5. tjb-lwA They entered a mountain: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to the O, you say, tjb-l Alqawomu AljibaAla, meaning, the people, or company of men, entered the mountains. (TA.)

hom.sense: jabolN † Big, thick, coarse, or rough; (TA;) as also jabilN ↓, applied to a thing (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) of any kind: (Ḳ:) or this latter is applied to an arrow, signifying † coarsely, roughly, or rudely, pared. (Ḳ.) You say rajulN jabolu Alr-aOosi, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jabalu AlrOs,]) and Alwajohi, (TA,) ‡ A man having a big, thick, coarse, or rough, head, and face; (TA;) having little sweetness. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also jabiylN.] And rajulN mijobaAlN↓ † A big, thick, coarse, or rough, and heavy, man. (Ḥam p. 818.) And AimoraOapN jabolapN (Ḳ [in one place in the CK jabalapN and jibolapN, but only jabolapN accord. to the TA,]) and mijobaAlN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) ‡ A woman big, thick, coarse, or rough, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in make; (Ṣ;) large in make. (TA.) And xiloqapN jabolapN † A big, thick, coarse, or rough, make. (Ḥam p. 821.) And naAqapN jabolapu Als-anaAmi ‡ A she-camel having an increasing hump. (TA.) And sayofN jabolN and mijobaAlN↓ † A sword not made thin. (TA.)
Also (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, jabal,]) A court [of a house]; syn. saAHapN. (Ḳ.)
jubolN: see jibolN:
and jibil-N.
Also Dry trees. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jibolN Much; or numerous; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jubolN↓ (Ḳ.) So in the phrases maAlN jibolN [Much property; or numerous cattle]; and HaI-N jibolN A numerous tribe. (Ṣ.)
See also jibil-N, in two places.

jabalN [A mountain: or] any of the mountains (OawotaAd [lit. “pegs,” or “stakes,” a term applied to the mountains because they are supposed to make the earth firm, or fast,]) of the earth, that is great and long; (Mgh, Ḳ;) or, as some say, only such as is long; (Mṣb;) such as is isolated being called OakamapN, or qun-apN: (Ḳ:) [and also applied to a rocky tract; any rocky elevation, however little elevated:] and sometimes it means stone; [or rock;] such, for instance, as is reached by the digger: and hence it is applied to Es-Safà and El-Marweh: (Mgh:) pl. [of mult.] jibaAlN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of pauc., Mṣb) OajobulN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajobaAlN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] † A man who does not remove from his place: you say of such a one, huwa jabalN. (TA.)
‡ A niggard. (Ḳ, TA.) [See 4.]
‡ The lord, or chief, of a people, or company of men: and their learned man. (Fr, Ḳ, TA.)
Abonapu Aljabal † The serpent: (Ḳ:) because it keeps to the jabal. (TA.)
† Calamity, or misfortune. (Ḳ.)
† The bow that is made from the tree called naboE; (Ḳ, TA;) because this is one of the trees of the jabal. (TA.)
† The echo. (Ḥar p. 472.)
jabulN: see jibil-N.
jabilN: see jabolN.

Also, applied to the iron head, or blade, of an arrow, or of a spear, or of a sword, &c., ‡ Blunt; that will not penetrate into a thing: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,* TA:) and so, with p {jabilapN}, applied to a faOos. (TA.)
jubulN: see jibil-N.

hom.sense: jabolapN (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK jabalapN,]) and jibolapN↓ The face: or the baXarap [or external skin] thereof: or the part thereof that is turned towards one. (Ḳ.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or the former, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or blemish. (Ḳ.)
And Strength. (Ḳ.)
And Hardness of the earth, or ground. (Lth, Ḳ.)
See also jubolapN:
and see jibolapN.
A camel's hump; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jabolapN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also jibil-N:
and see jibil-apN, in two places.
jibolapN: see jibil-apN.
Also The origin, or stock, (Ḳ, TA,) of any created thing; (TA;) and so jubul-apN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
The fundamental nature, or composition, of a mountain. (TA.)
vawobN jay-idu Aljibolapi ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, good in respect of the thread (Ḳ, TA) and the weaving. (TA.)
rajulN cuw jibolapK † A big, thick, coarse, or rough, man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jibil-N, in two places:
and see jabolapN.

entry.sense: jabalapN: see jibil-apN.
jubul-N: see what next follows.

jibil-N and jubul-N↓ and jibolN↓ [accord. to the CK like EadolN, but correctly like EidolN,] and jubolN↓ and jubulN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to different readings of the instance occurring in the Ḳur xxxvi. 62, the first being the reading of the people of El-Medeeneh, (Ṣ,) [and the most common,] A great company of men; as also jibil-apN↓ and jabiylN↓: (Ḳ:) or [simply] a company of men; (Ṣ;) as also jabulN↓, accord. to Kh; (Ṣgh, TA;) and so jabolapN↓ and jubolapN↓ and jibil-apN↓: which last three signify also the same as Oum-apN [a nation, or people,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) it is said [by some] that jibil-N is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of jibil-apN↓ meaning a numerous company: (TA:) jibalapN is pl. of jibolN↓: one says, qabaHa Qll-ehu jibalatakumo [May God remove far from prosperity, or success,] your companies: (Fr, TA:) and jibalN is pl. of jibolapN↓. (Bḍ in xxxvi. 62.)

hom.sense: See also jibolapN:
and see what next follows, in two places.

jibil-apN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jubul-apN↓ and jabiylapN↓ (Ṣgh, MF) and jibolapN↓ (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) and jubolapN↓ and jabolapN↓ and jabalapN↓, (Ḳ,) but this last, accord. to MF, is unknown, (TA,) Nature; or natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; idiosyncrasy; syn. xiloqapN (AA, Ṣ, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and TabiyEapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and gariyzapN; all these signifying the same: (Mṣb:) pl. of the first jibil-aAtN. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxvi. 184], waAljibil-apa AlOaw-aliyna, (Ṣ,) meaning Alxaliyqapa, (Jel,) or cawiI Aljibil-api, i. e. And the preceding created beings: (Bḍ:) El-Ḥasan read with damm [i. e. Aljubul-apa↓ or Aljvbolapa↓]. (Ṣ.)
See also jibil-N, in three places:
and see jubul-apN.

entry.sense: jabaliI-N Of, or relating to, a mountain or mountains; contr. of suholiI-N. (The Lexicons, &c. passim.)

jibil-I-N Natural; i. e. of, or relating to, the natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; like TabiyEiI-N; i. e. essential; resulting from the Creator's ordering of the natural disposition in the body. (Mṣb.)

jibaAlN ‡ The body, with, or without, the members; syn. jasadN and badanN; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to a mountain in bigness [?]. (TA.) One says, OaHosana Qll-ehu jibaAlahu, meaning, ‡ [May God render beautiful] his body (jasadahu): and [render good] his created xuluq [or mind, with its qualities and attributes: but I rather think that xuluq is here a mistranscription for xaloq, meaning make]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

hom.sense: jabiylN: see jibil-N.
jabiylu Alwajohi ‡ A man having a bad, or an ugly, face. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also jabolN.]

entry.sense: jabiylapN: see jibil-apN.
mijobaAlN: see jabolN, in three places.
majobuwlN, applied to a man, † Great, large, or big, (Ḳ, TA,) in make; as though he were a mountain. (TA.)

1. jabuna, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajobunu}, inf. n. jubonN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jubunN (Ḳ) and jabaAnapN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and jabana, (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajobunu}; (Mṣb, TA;) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed jabaAn (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jabiyn; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. cowardly, (Ḳ,) or weak hearted. (Mṣb.) And jabuna Eanohu He held back, or refrained, from him, or it, through cowardice. (TA in art. Ers.)
2. jbanhu, inf. n. tajobiynN, He attributed to him cowardice (jubon). (Ṣ.) And huwa yujab-anu, inf. n. as above, He is accused of cowardice. (Ḳ.)
4. Ajbnhu He found him to be such as is termed jabaAn; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. a coward, or cowardly, (Ḳ,) or weak-hearted: (Mṣb:) or he reckoned him a coward; (M, Ḳ;) as also Ajtbnhu↓. (Ḳ.)
5. tjb-n It (milk) became like jubon [i. e. cheese]. (Ḳ.)
And hence, perhaps, (TA,) † He (a man) became thick, gross, coarse, or big. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 8. Ajtbnhu He made cheese of it; i. e. of milk. (T, Ḳ.)
See also 4.

jubonN and jubunN↓ and jubun-N↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the first of which is the most approved, and the last the most rare, and said by some to be used only in a case of necessity in poetry, (Lth, Mṣb,) [Cheese;] a certain thing that is eaten, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) well known: (Ḳ:) n. un. jubonapN, (TA,) a word having a more particular signification than jubonN, (Ṣ,) meaning a qurS [or round, flattened, loaf] thereof, (Mgh,) [or a cheese, or piece of cheese,] as also jubunapN (TA) and jubun-apN. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also jubonN and jubunN↓, [inf. ns. of jabuna, used as simple substs., Cowardice; weak-heartedness;] the quality denoted by jabaAnN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: jubunN: see jubonN, in two places.
jubun-N: see jubonN.
juboniI-N A seller of jubon [i. e. cheese]. (TA.)
And a rel. n. from suwqu Aljuboni [The cheesemarket] in Damascus. (Ḳ.)

jabaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) an epithet from jabana, (Ṣ,) applied to a man and to a woman, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the latter case like HaSaAnN and razaAnN, (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, Ṣ,) and with p {jabaAnapN} also applied to a woman; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and jabynN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from jabuna, (Ṣ,) applied to a man and to a woman; and jab-aAnN↓; (Ḳ;) A coward; or cowardly; i. e. wont to dread things, so as not to venture upon them boldly, (Ḳ, TA,) by night or by day; (TA;) weak-hearted: (Mṣb:) jabaAnN is contr. of XujaAEN: (Mṣb in art. XjE:)
pl. masc. jubanaMCu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [properly of jabiynN] and fem. jabaAnaAtN. (Lth, Mṣb, TA.) huwa jabaAnu Alkalobi [He is one whose dog is cowardly,] means ‡ he is extremely generous: (Ḳ, TA:) because, by reason of guests' coming to him, his dog does not growl. (TA.) And you say, fulaAnN XujaAEu Alqalobi jabaAnu Alwajohi ‡ [app. meaning Such a one is courageous in heart, mild in face]. (TA. [Expl. by AjnI Alwjh, which seems to be a mistranscription.])

hom.sense: jabiynN: see jabaAnN.

Also The part above the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof; the two being called jabiynaAni: (Ṣ:) the side of the forehead, [so Bḍ in xxxvii. 103,] from the part over against the place where the hair falls off, to the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof: so say Az and IF and others: the forehead (Aljabotap) is between the jabiynaAni: (Mṣb:) or the jabiynaAni are the two borders of the forehead, on either side thereof, in the part between the two eyebrows (fiymaA bayona AlHaAjibayoni [so in the copies of the Ḳ, a mistake for fymA yaliI AlHAjbyn in the part next to the two eyebrows]), rising to the place where the growth of the hair terminates: (Ḳ:) or between the place where the growth of the hair terminates and the eyebrows: (TA:) or the jbyn is the borders (in the T, the border, TA) of the forehead, between the two temples, uniting with the naASiyap [or place where the hair grows in the fore part of the head, or the hair of that part]: (Ḳ, TA:) and it sometimes occurs as meaning the forehead: (MF, TA:) [see an ex. voce tariba, where it is used in this last sense, and is fem., perhaps because syn. with jabohap, for] Lḥ says that it is always masc.: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jubunN and [of pauc.] OajobinapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajobunN. (Ḳ.)
jab-aAnN: see jabaAnN.
Also One who keeps, or guards, the produce of land in the desert. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jab-aAnapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jab-aAnN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more common, (Mṣb,) A place of prayer, (Mṣb,) or common place of prayer, (Mgh,) in a SaHoraMC [or desert tract]. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

A burial-ground: (Ḳ:) this is sometimes called jb-Anp because the place of prayer is generally in the burial-ground: (Mṣb:) accord. to Kh, these two words, in this sense, are from Aljab-u and Aljabuwbu; but others derive them from jbn. (TA in art. jb.)
A [desert tract such as is termed] SaHoraMC. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A place that produces much herbage: and level, elevated land: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or the latter, level, elevated land, that produces much herbage: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) accord. to ISh, it is smooth, without trees; but it may have in it hills, and a tract abounding with trees: and sometimes the jb-Anp is level, without hills and without any tract abounding with trees; but it is not in sand nor in mountains, though it may be in [high grounds such as are termed] qifaAf [pl. of quf-N] and in [what are termed] XaqaAYiq [pl. of XaqiyqapN]. (TA.)
jab-AniI-N A dweller in the jab-aAn, meaning SaHoraMC. (TA.)

Oajobanu [More, and most, cowardly, or weakhearted]. (TA.) You say Oajobanu mino SaAfirK, i. e. [More cowardly] than a whistling bird: (Ṣ in art. Sfr:) or, as some say, than a thief. (TA in that art. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 326.])

majobanapN [A cause of cowardice, or weak-heartedness]. One says, Alwaladu majobanapN maboxalapN [Children are a cause of cowardice and a cause of niggardliness]; because one loves continuance of life, and property, on account of them. (Ṣ, TA.)

1. jabahahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajobahu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jabohN, (Ḥam p. 355,) He slapped, (Ṣ,) or struck, (Ḳ,) or hit, (Mṣb,) or struck him on, (Ḥam ubi suprà,) his jabohap [or forehead]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà.)

And [hence], (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He turned him back (Ḳ, TA) from the thing that he wanted: (TA:) or ‡ he met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, a thing disliked, or hated: (Ḳ, TA, TḲ:) or ‡ he encountered him, or confronted him, with speech in which was roughness: (JK, M, TA:) or ‡ he encountered him with that which he disliked, or hated; or he accused him thereof to his face; (M, TA, and Ḥam ubi suprà;) or so jabahahu biAlmakoruwhi. (Ṣ, TA.)

jabaha AlmaMCa, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (JK, Ṣ,) ‡ He came to the water, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) when there was at it no apparatus for drawing, (Ṣ,) i. e. no pulley, &c., (JK, TA,) or having no means of drawing, so that he only looked at the surface of the water. (Z, Ḳ.) [See also jabiyhapN.]
jabaha Alqawoma ‡ It (winter) came upon the people unprepared for it. (A, Ḳ.)

2. tajobiyhN The mounting a fornicator, or an adulterer, upon an ass, and turning his face towards the tail; whence the trad. of the Jews respecting the adulterer, yuHum-amu wayujab-ahu wyujoladu [He shall have his face blackened with charcoal, and be mounted on an ass with his face towards the tail, and be flogged]: (Mgh:) or the mounting two fornicators, or adulterers, upon an ass, and turning the backs of their heads towards each other, (JK, Mgh,) and parading them round about; thus accord. to the Tekmileh: (Mgh:) or the blackening [with charcoal] the faces of two fornicators, or adulterers, (Oano yuHam-ara in the Ḳ being a mistake for Oano yuHum-ama, i. e. yusaw-ada, TA,) and mounting them upon a camel or an ass, and turning their faces in contrary directions: accord. to analogy, it should mean turning their faces towards each other; for it is from Aljabotapu: tajobiyhN also signifies the bending, inclining, lowering, or hanging down, the head towards the ground: and it may be hence; (i. e. it may be hence that it is applied to him who is mounted on a beast in the manner described above; TA;) because he to whom this is done bends down his head in shame and confusion: or it may be from jabahahu meaning “he did to him a thing disliked, or hated.” (Ḳ.)
8. AijotibaAhN The deeming [one] rude, coarse, unkind, hard, or churlish. (JK.)
And The fearing [a person or thing]. (JK.)
And Ajtbhhu He disliked, or hated, and feared, it, or him; namely, a country, or town, and a man. (JK.)
He disapproved it, or disliked it, and did not find it wholesome; namely, water, (En-Nawádir, Ḳ,), &c. (Ḳ.)
jabahN Largeness, (Ṣ,) or width (JK, M, Ḳ) and beauty, (M, Ḳ,) of the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or protuberance, or prominence, thereof. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jabohapN [The forehead;] the part of the face which is the place of prostration: (Aṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the even part that is between the eyebrows and the naASiyap [or place where the hair grows in the fore part of the head]: (Kh, JK, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so of a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and of others: (Ṣ:) [or,] of a horse, the part that is below the ears and above the eyes: (TA:) pl. jibaAhN. (Mṣb, TA.)

Also † The moon (Ḳ, TA) itself: but [it rather seems to mean the upper part of the disc of the moon; for] it is said in the M that a certain unknown poet has metaphorically assigned a jbhp to the moon. (TA.)
Also jabohapN, ‡ The chief of a people, or company of men; (JK, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) like as one says the wajoh thereof. (Mgh, TA.)

‡ The generous and manly, or manly and noble, persons of a people, or company of men: or men exerting themselves in the case of a bloodwit or a debt or other obligation, (Ḳ, TA,) or in repairing the condition of a poor man, (TA,) and who come not to any one but he is ashamed to turn them back, (Ḳ, TA,) or who are seldom or never turned back by anyone: so, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, in a trad. in which it is said that there shall be no poor-rate in the case of the jbhp. (TA.)

‡ A company, or collected number, of men, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and of horses: (JK, Mṣb:) or, of horses, the best: (TA:) and [simply] horses; (Lth, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) a word having no sing., or n. un.: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) having this last meaning in the trad. above mentioned; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) because horses are the best of beasts. (Mgh.)

‡ Abjectness, or ignominy; (JK, M, Ḳ, TA;) and a state of annoyance, or molestation: (Z, TA:) thought by ISd to be from jabahahu meaning “he encountered him with that which he disliked or hated,” or “he accused him thereof to his face;” because the doing this causes one to experience abjectness, or ignominy. (TA.) It is said to have this meaning in a trad., in which it is said, faUin-a Qll-eha qado OaraAHakumo mina Aljabohapi wAls-aj-api wAlbaj-api, i. e. For God hath relieved you from abjectness, or ignominy,, &c., and milk diluted with water, and blood drawn from a vein [of a camel], which the Arabs used to eat:
or in this trad., (TA,) Aljabotahapu is the name of a certain idol (ISd, Ḳ, TA) that was worshipped in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) and Alsj-p and Albj-p were two idols. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. sj.)

entry.sense: waradonaA maMCF lahu jabiyhapN We came to a water that was salt, so that the drinking thereof did not take away the thirst of our cattle: (ISk, JK, Ṣ:) or that was altered for the worse in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing, though still drinkable; or covered with the green substance called TuHolub and with leaves: or that was deep in the bottom, difficult to give to drink. (ISk, Ṣ.) [See also 1, last meaning but one.]
jub-ahN i. q. jub-aON, (Ḳ,) i. e. A fearful, or cowardly, man. (TA.)
jaAbihN, applied to a gazelle, (JK,) or to a bird or a wild animal, (Ḳ,) That meets one with its face or forehead; and such is of evil omen: (Ḳ:) contr. of qaEiydN. (JK.)
Coming to water: so in a saying cited and explained in art. Acn, conj. 2. (IAạr, TA.)

Oajobahu, applied to a man, Large, (Ṣ,) or wide (JK, M, Ḳ) and beautiful, (M, Ḳ,) in the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or protuberant, or prominent, therein: (M, Ḳ:) applied to a horse, having a protuberant, or prominent, forehead, rising beyond the bone of the nose: (TA:) fem. jabohaMCu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) of which the dim. is jubayohaMCu. (Ṣ.)
AlOajobahu The lion; (Ḳ;) because of the width of his jabohap. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: jbw / jbI
dictScrap.label:
jbw and jbI
[The words belonging to the former of these two arts. cannot well be classed by themselves, being intimately connected with those of the latter, which are the more numerous and common, and from which they are generally easily distinguishable.]

hom.sense: 1. jabaI, (Ḳ,) first pers. jabayotu, (Ks, Ṣ, Er-Rághib,) aor. _i; (Ḳ;) and jabaI, aor. _a, (Ḳ,) said by MF to be unknown, and also, because neither the second nor the third radical is a faucial letter, unreasonable, but mentioned by Sb, though held by him to be of weak authority, and mentioned also by IAạr, as extr., like OabaI, aor. yaOobaI; (TA;) and jabaA, (TA,) first pers. jabawotu, (Ks, Ṣ, TA,) aor. _u; (TA;) inf. n. [of the first and second] jaboIN (Sh, Ḳ) and [probably of the last only] jabFA and jibFA and jubFA and [of the last, but whether in the first or the second of the senses here following is not shown,] jibowapN; (Ḳ; [or this last has a different application, explained below;]) He collected water in a trough or tank for beasts, &c. (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ, Er-Rághib.)

And (hence, metaphorically, Er-Rághib, TA) the first of these verbs, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, Er-Rághib,) and the second, (Ḳ,) and the third; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) inf. n. (of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) jibaAyapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, Er-Rághib) and (of the last, Ṣ, Mṣb) jibaAwapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jabowN (TA) [and probably jibowapN also, which see above]; ‡ He collected the [tax called] xaraAj, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, Er-Rághib,) and [other] property. (Mṣb, TA.) The last of these verbs is said in the Ṣ to be originally with C, though pronounced without C; but IB says that this is not the case, and that it has not been heard with C. (TA.) You say also, jabaAhu Alqawoma † [He collected it from the people, or company of men]; (M, Ḳ,* TA;) and jabaI minohumo † [He collected from them]. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

Also jabaA [or jabaI], (TA,) first pers. jabayotu, (Zj, TA,) † He appropriated a thing purely to himself, exclusively of any partner; chose it, or took it in preference, for himself. (Zj, TA.) And hence, (Zj, TA,) AjtbAhu↓ † He chose it, or selected it, (Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ) linafosihi for himself. (TA.)
And jabaI and jabaA, [originally jabaOa,] He returned, receded, retreated, or went back. (TA.)

2. jb-I, inf. n. tajobiyapN, He placed his hands upon his knees, (Ḳ, TA,) in prayer; (TA;) or upon the ground: or he fell prostrate; or fell upon his face: (Ḳ:) or he lowered his body and his hands, and raised his buttocks: (Ḥam p. 801:) [or] tjbyp signifies a man's standing [with the hands upon the knees] in the manner of the raAkiE: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) accord. to AʼObeyd, what is thus termed is of two kinds: one is the placing the hands upon the knees, while standing: the other, the prostrating oneself, or falling upon the face, lying down; which is sujuwdN: (Ṣ:) or the bending down, and placing the hands upon the knees; because it is a bringing-together of the limbs. (Mgh.)
jb-Ahu, inf. n. as above, meaning He gave to him, is vulgar. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AjbI in the trad. mano OajobaI faqado OarobaI is originally OajobaOa [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) accord. to IAth, it is a corruption of the relater, or the C is suppressed to assimilate the verb to ArbI (TA.) The inf. n., UijobaMCN, is variously explained, as follows: (TA:) The selling seed-produce before it shows itself to be in a good state: (AʼObeyd, Th, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a man's hiding his camels from the collector of the poor-rate: (IAạr, AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) and i. q. EiynapN; i. e. the selling to a man a commodity for a certain price to be paid at a certain period, then buying it of him with ready money for a less price than that for which it was sold. (TA.)
8. AijotibaMCN † The drawing forth property from the places in which it is known, or presumed, or accustomed, to be. (TA.)
† The collecting in the way of choice, or selection. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

Also † God's particular, or peculiar, distinguishing of men by abundant bounty, from which various blessings result to them without their labour; as happens to prophets and some others. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also AjtbAhu, † He forged it: and he extemporized it. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [vii. 202], qaAluwA lawolaA QjotabayotahaA † They say, Wherefore hast thou not forged it, (Fr, TA,) or produced it, (Th, TA,) or invented it, (Jel,) or put it together by forgery, (Bḍ,) of thyself? (Fr, Th, Bḍ, Jel, TA:) or wherefore hast thou not sought it, or demanded it, of God? (Bḍ.)

hom.sense:
jabFA, or jabFI, (as in different copies of the Ḳ,) written with A and with I, (TA,) The camel-waterer's going in advance of the camels a day before their coming to the water, and collecting for them water in the drinking-trough, and then bringing them to it (IAạr, Ḳ, TA) on the morrow. (IAạr, TA.) [App. an inf. n., of which, in this sense, the verb is not mentioned.] So in the verse,
biAlr-ayovi maA OarowayotuhaA laA biAlEajalo
wabiAljabaA OarowayotuhaA laA biAlqabalo
[Slowly I satisfied their thirst; not hastily: and by going in advance of them a day, and collecting for them water in the trough, and bringing them to it on the morrow, I satisfied their thirst; not by pouring the water into the trough while they were drinking, without having prepared any for them beforehand]. (IAạr, TA.)
A wateringtrough (Ḳ, TA) in which water is collected: (TA:) or the station of the drawer of water, upon the [upper part of the] casing. (Ḳ.)
The place where a well is dug: (Ḳ:) in this sense, and in the next, also written jabFI (TA.)

The brink, or margin, of a well. (A boo-Leylà, Ḳ.) The earth that is around a well, that is seen from afar; (Ṣ;) originally jabaON: (TA:) what is around a well: (Ḳ:) and what is around a wateringtrough: (TA:) pl. OajobaMCN. (Ḳ.)
jabaA meaning A gift without compensation is a vulgar word. (TA.)
