entry.sense: jibFA Water collected (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) in a trough, (T, Ḳ,) being drawn from a well, (T, TA,) for camels; (Ṣ;) [like jabFA;] as also jibowapN↓, (Ḳ, TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ, but omitted in the CK,) or jabowapN↓, (so in two copies of the Ṣ,) and jubowapN↓ also, (so in a copy of the Ṣ, [see jabFA,]) and jabaAwapN↓, (Ḳ, TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) and jabaAwapN↓, (Ḳ, TA, and so in another copy of the Ṣ, but omitted in the CK,) and jibaMCapN↓: (TA as from the Ḳ, but not in the CK: [perhaps a mistranscription for jibaAyapN↓:]) but accord. to IAmb, jibFA is pl. of jiboyapN↓. (TA.)
jabowapN; see jibFA.
jubowapN: see jabFA and jibFA.

hom.sense: jibowapN: see jibFA.

entry.sense: jiboyapN: see what next precedes:
and see jibFA.
jibaMCapN: see jibFA.
jabaAwapN and jibaAwapN: see jibFA.
jibaAyapN: see jibFA.
† The tax called UitaAwap [or xaraAj]. (TA in art. Atw.) [Originally an inf. n.]
jabaAyaA [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Wells which are dug, and in which the shoots of grape-vines are set. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
jaAbK A collector of water for camels: belonging to arts. jbw and jbI. (TA.)

† The locust (Ḳ) that collects everything by eating it; as also jaAbiYN [q. v.]. (TA.) The Arabs say, UicaA jaMCati Als-anapu jaMCa maEahaA AljaAbiI waAljaAniI, i. e. † [When the year of drought comes,] the locust and the wolf [come with it]. (IAạr, TA.)

jaAbiyapN A watering-trough, (Ṣ,) or large wateringtrough, (Ḳ,) in which water is collected (Ṣ) for camels: (TA:) or a watering-trough that collects water: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. jawaAbK. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 12], wajafaAnK kaAljawaAbiI [And bowls like watering-troughs, or great wateringtroughs]. (Ṣ.)
† A company of men. (Ḳ,* TA.)
luWoluWapN mujab-aApN A hollowed pearl: (Ibn-Wahb, TA:) the latter word thought by El-Khaṭṭábee to be formed by transposition from mujaw-bapN. (TA.)

hom.sense: jav-a said of a collector of honey, He took the honey with its jav- and its maHaAriyn, i. e., the bees that had died in it. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. Ainojav-a (M, L, TA) and Aujotuv-a↓ (M, A, L, TA) It was, or became, pulled up, or out: properly, its whole juv-ap [or body] was taken; said of a tree: (TA in explanation of the latter:) it was, or became, cut, or cut off; (A, L;) or cut off from its root; (L;) pulled up, or out, by the root; uprooted, or eradicated: said of a tree. (A.)
8: see 1 and 7.

jav-N, so in the Ṣ [and L] and other lexicons, but in the Ḳ it is implied that it is juv-N↓, (TA,) Bees' wax: or any particles, of the wings of the bees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of their bodies, (Ṣ,) intermixed with the honey: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or] the xiroXaMC of honey; (Ḳ;) i. e. the young bees, or the wings, that are upon honey; as in the M and L, &c.: (TA:) or the bees that have died in the honey. (IAạr, TA.)
Also Dead locusts. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: juv-N: see jav-N.

Also Elevated ground (Ṣ, TA, but not in all the copies of the former) such as has a form visible from a distance: (TA:) or ground that is elevated so as to be like a small [hill of the kind called]Oakamap. (Ḳ.)
The envelope of fruit; (Ḳ;) [or of the spadix of a palm-tree;] like juf-N; the v being a substitute for f. (TA.)

entry.sense: juv-apN The body, or corporeal form or figure, (XaxoS.) of a man, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [absolutely, or] sitting, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) or sleeping, [by which is meant, as in many other instances, lying down,] (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or reclining, or lying on the side: (TA:) that of a man standing erect being termed TalalN (Mṣb) or qaAmapN; (TA;) and XxS applying in common to what is termed jvap and what is termed Tll, in relation to a man: (Mṣb:) or jvap is used only in relation to a man upon a horse's or camel's saddle, wearing a turban: so says IDrd on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb El-Akhfash; but he adds that this has not been heard from any other: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] juvavN (A, TA) and [of pauc.] OajovaAvN; the latter as though formed from juv-N, without regard to the augmentative letter [p]; or it may be pl. of juvavN, and thus a pl. pl. (TA.)

Also A body; [a corpse;] syn. jasadN; as in the saying, in a trad., Aall-hum-a jaAfi AlOaroDa Eano juv-atihi [O God, remove the earth from his body, or corpse: i. e., let it not press against his sides in the grave]. (TA.)
[And The body of a tree: see 7.]

javiyvN [a coll. gen. n.] Young palm-trees, or shoots of palm-trees, that are cut off from the mother-trees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted: n. un. with p {javiyvapN}: it is thus called until it yields fruit; when it is called naxalapN: (Ṣ:) or what are planted, of the shoots of palm-trees; (AḤn, Ḳ;) not what are set, of the stones: (AḤn, TA:) or shoots of palm-trees when they are first pulled off from the mother-trees: (Aṣ, TA: [as also qavayvN:]) or, with p {javiyvapN}, it signifies a palm-tree produced from a date-stone, for which a hole is dug, and which is transplanted with the earth adhering to its root: (AA, TA:) or what falls in succession from [app. a mistake for at] the roots, or lower parts, of palm-trees. (Abu-lKhattáb, TA.)
And Grapes that fall at the roots, or lower parts, of the vine. (ISd, TA.)
mijav-apN and mijovaAvN↓ A thing with which javiyv [q. v.] are uprooted: (M, Ḳ:) an iron implement with which young palm-trees, or shoots of palmtrees, are pulled up or off. (Ṣ.)
mijovaAvN: see what next precedes.
XajarapN mujotav-apN A tree [pulled up or out, by the root: or] that has no root in the ground. (A.)

baHoru Almujotav-i The fourteenth metre of verse; as though it were cut off from the xafiyf; (TA;) the metre consisting of
musotafoEiluno faAEilaAtuno faAEilaAtuno
(Ḳ. [So originally; but in usage, the last of the three feet is cut off. Accord. to the TA, the first foot is properly written musotafoEi luno, as in some copies of the Ḳ.])

1. javula, aor. _u {yajovulu}; (Lth, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and javila, aor. _a {yajovalu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. juvuwlapN and javaAlapN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) both of the former verb; (Mṣb, TA;) [but both mentioned in the Ṣ as simple substs.;] It was, or became, such as is termed javolN, explained below. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 4. AijovaOal-a He (a bird) ruffled his feathers (Ṣ, Ḳ) by reason of the cold. (TA.)
† He (a man) became angry, and prepared himself for fighting. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† It (a plant, or herbage,) became tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (Z, Ḳ:) or became tall (Aihotaz-a, q. v.), and such as might be grasped with the hand. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (the plumage of a bird) became ruffled. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: javolN (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and javiylN↓ (Ḳ) A thing, (Mṣb,) or hair, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ‡ trees (XajarN), (Ḳ, TA,) much, or abundant, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and thick, or abundant, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and thick, or coarse, or rough, (Mṣb,) or tangled, or luxuriant and dense, (Ḳ,) and soft: (TA:) or thick, or coarse, or rough, and short: or dense and black: (Ḳ:) or the blackest hair: or the thickest, or coarsest, or roughest: (Lth, TA:) or anything large, big, or bulky, and dense, and tangled, or luxuriant. (Ḳ.) You say liHoyapN An abundant, thick, or coarse, or rough, beard. (Mṣb:) or a thick, or dense, beard. (TA.) And naASiyapN javolapN A horse's forelock moderate in respect of quantity and length: such is approved. (Ṣ.) And XajarapN javolapN ‡ A many-leaved, big, tree. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
javolN A species of ant, large and black; as also jafolN: (IDrd, TA:) or javolapN signifies a black ant: (Ṣ:) or a large and: and javolN is its pl. [or coll. gen. n.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: javaylN: see javolN.
juvaAlapN Leaves that have become gradually scattered, or strewn. (Ḳ.)
mujovaYil-N Brood, or wide. (Ḳ.)
Standing erect. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. javama, aor. _i {yajovimu} (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yajovumu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. juvuwmN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and javomN, (Ḳ,) said of a bird, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a hare, and sometimes of a gazelle, (Mṣb,) or of a [young gazelle such as is termed] xaXof, (Ḳ,) and of a camel, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a jerboa, (Ḳ,) and a man, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He clave to the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or kept to his place, not quitting it: (Ḳ:) or fell upon his breast: (Mṣb,* Ḳ:) juvuwmN in the case of a bird and a hare is like buruwkN in the case of a camel: (Mṣb:) or in the case of a bird it is like juluwsN in the case of a man [so that the verb means he sat]. (Mgh.)
Also, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajovimu}, (TA,) said of seed-produce, It rose a little from the ground. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Also, (AḤn, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajovumu}, (AḤn, TA,) inf. n. juvuwmN, said of a raceme of a palm-tree, Its unripe, or ripening, dates became somewhat large: (AḤn, Ḳ:*) or it became large, and kept its place. (T, TA.)
Also, inf. n. juvuwmN, said of the night, † It became half spent. (Th, Ḳ, TA.)
javama also signifies He collected clay, or mould, and earth, or dust, and ashes. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. jv-m, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. tajoviymN, (KL,) [He made a bird, and a hare, and the like, to cleave to the ground, then to be shot at, or cast at, and so killed: see mujav-apN:] he kept, or held, a bird confined, that it might [be shot at, or cast at, and] die: (KL:) he turned an animal on his side to be slaughtered. (Golius, as from the KL, but not in my copy of that work.)
5. tjv-m He (a bird) mounted his female for the purpose of copulation. (TA.)
javomN Seed-produce rising a little from the ground; as also javamN↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)
A raceme of a palm-tree having its unripe, or ripening, dates becoming somewhat large. (Ḳ,* TA.)
javamN: see the next preceding paragraph.
juvamN: see jav-aAmapN:
and juvaAmN.
javomapN: see juvuwmN.
juvomapN Clay, or mould, and earth, or dust, and ashes, collected. (Ḳ.)
javamapN: see juvuwmN.
juvamapN: see jav-aAmapN:
and juvaAmN.

juvomaAnN The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jisomN: and i. q. XaxoSN [app. as meaning a person; not, as J seems to have held, a corporeal, or material, form or thing or substance, such as is seen from a distance; see jisomN]: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aṣ, it has the latter meaning, i. q. XaxoSN; and jusomaAnN has the former meaning, that of jisomN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and jasadN: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to AZ, juvomaAnN is syn. with jusomaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. jasadN. (Ṣ.) One says, maA OaHosana juvomaAna Alr-ajuli and jusomaAnahu, meaning [How goodly, or beautiful, is] the body, or person, of the man! (AZ, Ṣ.) J cites, as an ex. of this word in the sense of XxS, from a verse of Bishr,
sanaAmN kajuvomaAni Albaniy-ipi OatolaEaA
observing that by Albny-p is meant the Kaabeh: but IB says that the right reading, as found in his poetry, is Albaliy-api, and OatolaEu; and that the meaning is, A [long] hump like the jvmAn [or body] of the she-camel that is placed [and confined without food or water until she dies] at the grave of a dead man. (TA.) One says also, jaMCanaA bivariydK kajuvomaAni AlmaMCi [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth and piled up, like the body of the bird of the kind called qaTFA]. (Ṣ.)

juvomaAniy-apu AlmaMCi, as used in the saying of El-Farajeeyeh, (Ḳ,) so in the copies of the Ḳ, [or El-Faraheeyeh, accord. to the CK,] but correctly of El-Farezdaḳ, (TA,)
wabaAtato bijuvomaAniy-api AlmaMCi niybuhaA
UilaI caAti raHolK kaQlomaMtimi Hus-araA
means The water itself: or the middle thereof: or the place where it collected. (Ḳ TA.) [The poet says, And her aged she-camels passed the night in the water, &c., … like the companies of mourning women having the head, or the face, &c., uncovered: but what is meant by AlI cAt rHl, unless it be with one having a saddle upon her, UilaI being sometimes used in the sense of maEa I am unable to conjecture. In the CK, nayobahA and kAlmeAvimi are erroneously put for niybuhaA and kaAlmaMtimi.]

juvaAmN Incubus, or nightmare; (T, Ḳ;) what comes upon a man when he is sleeping; (T, TA;) what comes upon a man in the night, preventing him from speaking; i. q. nayodulaAnN; (IAạr, TA;) as also jaAvuwmN↓ (T, Ḳ) and jav-aAmapN↓ and juvamN↓ and juvamapN↓. (T, TA.)
javuwmN: see jaAvimN.
Hence, † A hare. (TA.)

hom.sense: juvuwmN pl. of jAvimN [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: jav-aAmN: see jaAvimN.
jav-aAmapN: see jaAvimN.

Hence, ‡ A man who keeps to the region of cities, towns, villages, or cultivated land, and does not travel: (Mṣb:) a man who sleeps much, and does not travel; as also juvamapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juvamN↓ and jaAvuwmN↓: (Ḳ:) [see also jaAvimapN:] stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; or not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs: and a forbearing, or clement, personage, chief, or man of rank or quality. (Ḳ.)
See also juvaAmN.

jaAvimN A bird, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a hare, and sometimes a gazelle, (Mṣb,) or a [young gazelle such as is termed] xiXof, (Ḳ,) and a camel, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a jerboa, and a man, (Ḳ,) cleaving to the ground: or keeping to his place, not quitting it: (Ḳ:) or falling upon his breast: (Mṣb,* Ḳ:) as also javuwmN↓: (Ḳ:) [or the latter] and jav-aAmN↓ doing so much, or often: and jav-aAmapN↓ doing so very much, or very often: (Mṣb:) and the first, also, sitting upon his legs like a bird: pl. juvuwmN (TA) [and juv-amN, accord. to Freytag]. faOaSobaHuwA fiI daArihimo jaAvimiyna, in the Ḳur [vii. 76, &c.], means [And they became, in their abode,] bodies cast upon the ground: (TA:) or extinct, or motionless; and dead. (Bḍ.)
Aljuvvwmu ‡ The stars composing the constellation of the Scorpion; also called Alburuku: see barokN. (L and TA in art. brk.)
jaAvimapN One who does not quit his house, or tent. (Lth, TA.) [See also jav-aAmapN.]
jaAvuwumN: see jav-aAmapN:
and juvaAmN.

[majovamN and majovimN A place where a bird, &c., cleaves to the ground: or to which it keeps: or where it falls upon its breast. And particularly,] The seat, or form, of a hare: (TA:) [pl. majaAvimu.]

mujav-amapN A bird, and a hare, and the like, that is confined or set up, to be killed; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh;) that is made to cleave to the ground (tujav-amu), and then shot at, or cast at, until it is killed; (Ṣ, Mgh;) which manner of killing is forbidden: (Ṣ:) or any animal that is set up and shot at, or cast at, and [so] killed: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or a sheep, or goat, that is shot at with arrows: (ʼIkrimeh, Mgh:) or a sheep, or goat, that is stoned (Sh, Mgh, TA) until it dies, and is then eaten. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. javaA and javaI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) EalaI rukobatayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _u and _i, inf. n. juvuw-u and juviI-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He sat upon his knees; (Ḳ, TA;) for the purpose of contention or disputation, or the like: (TA:) or jvA [and jvI] he kneeled; put himself in a kneeling posture; which is the mode of sitting of him who is contending or disputing: (AZ, Ḥar p. 512:) [or he put down his knees upon the ground and raised his buttocks; i. e. he kneeled with his body and thighs erect, or nearly so: see jaAvK:] and javaA lirukobatihi he fell [upon his knee]; and javawoA lilr-ukabi [they fell upon the knees, and sank backwards so as to rest the body upon the keels or upon the left foot bent sideways beneath; for] juvuw-N is the manner of sitting of the mutaXah-id [in prayer]: (Ḥam p. 287:) or javaA, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. javowN and juvuwN, (TA,) he stood upon the extremities of his toes; (Ḳ;) like jacaA; from which AO reckons it to be formed by substitution [of v for c]; but IJ says that they are two dial. vars. (TA.) Aboo-Thumámeh says,
OuxaASimuhumo mar-aPF qaAYimFA
waOajovuw UicaA maA javawoA lilr-ukabo
[I contending, or disputing, with them one time standing, and falling upon my knees when they fell upon their knees]. (Ḥam p. 287.)
javawotu, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. javowN; (TA;) and javayotu, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. javoIN; (TA;) I collected camels, and sheep or goats. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. jaAvayotu rukobatiI UilaI rukobatihi, (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) or jaAvayotuhu rukobatiI UilaI rukobatihi, (so in other copies of the Ṣ,) [I sat, or sat with him, with my knee to his knee, each of us sitting upon his knees, in contending or disputing: see 1]: and jaAvayotuhu alone, (Ṣ voce HaADarotuhu,) [signifies the same,] inf. n. mujaAvaApN (Ḳ and TA voce muHaAaDrapN) [and jivaMCN: see also 6].
4. AjvAhu (Ṣ, Ḳ) He made him to sit upon his knees: [see 1:] or he made him to stand upon the extremities of his toes. (Ḳ.)

6. tajaAvawoA EalaI Alr-ukab [They sat together upon their knees], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in contending or disputing; inf. n. mujaAvaApN and jivaMCN, which are [properly inf. ns. of 3, but are] thus used as inf. ns. of a verb to which they do not conform. (TA.)
Alt-ajaAviI fiI UiXaAlapi AlHajari is like Alt-ajaAci I [The vying, one with another, in lifting the stone, for trial of strength]. (TA.)

hom.sense: juvFA, or juvFI, [pl. of juvowapN, q. v.]

[Also] A company, or congregated body, of men; (TA;) or so javowapN↓ (Bḍ in xlv. 27) [or juvowapN↓]: and companies, or congregated bodies, thereof. (TA.) It has the former meaning in a trad., where it is said, yaSiyruwna yawoma AlqiyaAmapi juvFA kul-u Oum-apK tatobaEu nabiy-ahaA [They shall become, on the day of resurrection, a company, or congregated body, each people following its prophet: or here the pl. meaning is more reasonable]: and the latter in the trad., fulaAnN mino juvaI jahan-ama [Such a one is of the companies, or congregated bodies, of Hell, or Hellfire], accord. to one recital: otherwise, mino juviI-i↓ jahan-ama of those that sit upon the knees therein. (TA.)
AljuvaA is also said to have been A certain idol, to which sacrifices were performed. (TA.)

entry.sense: javowapN: see what next follows, in two places:
and see juvFA.

hom.sense: juvowapN and jivowapN↓ and javowapN↓ Stones collected together: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the stones of earth collected together like the [mound over a] grave: and the first, a hillock: or a heap of earth: (TA:) or collected earth: (Ḥam p. 399:) or a quantity collected of earth, &c.: (Ḥam p. 381:) and (hence, Ḥam p. 381) a grave: (TA, Ḥam pp. 381 and 399:) pl. juvFA, (TA, Ḥam p. 399,) or juvoI. (Ḥam ib.) It is said in a trad., raOayotu qubuwra AlX-uhadaMCi juvFA I saw the tombs of the martyrs [to be] collections of earth. (TA.) And juvaI AlHarami ( pl. of juvowapN, TA) and jivaI AlHarami (pl. of jivowapN↓, TA) signify What are collected, in the sacred territory, of the stones of the jimaAr [or pebbles cast at Minè]: (Ṣ:) or this is a mistake; (Ḳ;) pointed out by Ṣgh in the TṢ: (TA:) the meaning is, what are collected together of the stones that are set [in heaps] at the limits of the sacred territory: or the OanoSaAb [or stones set up around the Kaabeh] upon which victims were slain in sacrifice. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also i. q. jacowapN [A live coal; or piece of fire;, &c.]: (Ḳ:) or so javowapN↓ and javowapN↓: (TA:) or jvwpN mino naArK: (Fr, TA:) asserted by Yaạḳoob to be formed by substitution [of v for c]. (TA.)
And The middle [of a thing]. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA: but omitted in the CK and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.)
And The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jasadN: (Ḳ:) or so juvowapN: pl. juvFI. (Sh, TA.)
And juvowapN, A great, or large, man. (ISh, TA.)
See also juvFA.

entry.sense: jivowapN: see juvowapN, in three places.

hom.sense: [And hence, perhaps,] Incubus, or nightmare. (TA. [But in this sense it is written in the TA jvA, without C, and without any syll. sign.])
Also i. q. jazaMCN [Requital, or compensation]. (Ḳ.)
And Quantity, measure, size, bulk, or extent; and amount, sum, or number, (Ḳ, TA,) as, for instance, of a people, or company of men. (TA.)

entry.sense: juvaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAvK Sitting upon his knees: or standing upon the extremities of his toes: (Ḳ:) and [simply] sitting: or [kneeling with his body and thighs erect, or nearly so; i. e.] putting down his knees [upon the ground] and raising his buttocks: (TA:) [see also 1, of which it is the part. n.:] pl. juviIN and jiviI-N; (Ḳ;) or these may be pls., like bukI-N and bkIN, pls. of baAk; or inf. ns. used as epithets [as is indicated in the Ṣ]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say qawomN juviI-N [A company of men sitting upon their knees]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) like as you say jalasa juluwsFA and qawomN juluwsN. (Ṣ.) And hence, in the Ḳur [xix. 73], wanacaru AlZ-aAlimiyna fiyhaA juviy-FA, and jiviy-FA also, with kesr to the j because of the kesr of the letter following it, [And we will leave the wrongdoers therein, sitting upon their knees.] (Ṣ.) And fulaAnN mino juviI-i jahan-ama: see juvFA. (TA.) And, in the Ḳur [xlv. 27], wataraI kul-a Oum-apK jaAviyapF (TA) And thou shalt see every people sitting upon the knees, (Bḍ, Jel,) in an upright posture, not at ease: (Bḍ:) or congregated; (Bḍ, Jel;) from javowapN signifying “a company,” or “congregated body.” (Bḍ.) Whence, (TA,) suwrapu AljaAviyapi The [forty-fifth] chapter, of the Ḳur-án, next after that called Ald-uxaAn. (Ṣ, TA.)
[AljaAviI, or AljaAviI EalaI rukobatayohi, † The constellation Hercules.]
[majovFI A place of sitting upon the knees.]
R. Q. 1. jaHojaHa He mentioned a jaHojaAH [or chief,, &c.] of his people. (TA.)
jaHojaHato She gave birth to a jHjAj. (TA.) And jHjHt biwaladihaA She brought forth her child a jHjAH. (A.)
jaHojaHN: see the following paragraph.
Also A low, an ignoble, a vile, a mean, or a sordid, man; possessing no manly qualities. (AA, T, Ḳ.) [Thus it bears two contr. significations.]

jaHojaAHN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and jaHojaHN↓ (Ḳ) A chief, lord, master, or man of rank or quality or distinction: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or one who is liberal, bountiful, or munificent; or one who is noble, or generous: (TA:) and one who hastens [to render aid] in cases of evil: (A:) pl. (of the former, Ṣ, A, TA, [or of the latter accord. to analogy,]) jaHaAjiHu (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and (of the same, A, TA) jaHaAjiHapN (A, Ḳ) and jaHaAjiyHu: (Ḳ:) it is said in the Ṣ that these two are pls. of the first pl.; the p in the former of them being substituted for the I in the latter of them, which is rejected; for one of these two letters must be retained, but both cannot be together: this assertion in the Ṣ, however, is well refuted by MF. (TA.)

hom.sense: Also jaHadahu, He found him to be niggardly, or avaricious: (Ḳ:) or he found him to possess little good; i. e., to be either niggardly or poor. (TA.)

jaHida, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoHadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaHadN, (Ṣ,) He (a man) was, or became, niggardly, or avaricious; (Ṣ;) possessed little good; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AjHd↓: (Ṣ:) or his property became dissipated or dispersed, and passed away; and so ↓the latter verb. (AA, TA.)
It (anything, TA) was, or became, little in quantity, or scanty. (Ḳ, TA.)
It (a person's life, TA) was, or became, strait, and difficult. (Ḳ,* TA.)
It (a plant) was, or became, scanty; (Ṣ;) did not grow tall. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jaHidati AlOaroDu The land became dry, and of no good. (L.)
jaHada EaAmunaA [Our year was, or became, one of little rain: see jaHidN]. (A.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.
4: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: jaHodN and juHodN↓ and jaHadN↓ Paucity, or scantiness, of good; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which means both niggardliness and poverty: (A:) straitness of the means of subsistence; as also juHuwdN↓. (TA.) One says, nakadFA lahu wajaHadFA↓ (Ṣ) and nukodFA lahu wajuHodFA↓ (L in art. nkd) [May God decree straitness, or difficulty, to him, and poverty]: a form of imprecation. (TA.)
jaHodN as an epithet, fem. with p {jaHodapN}: see jaHodN, in three places.

entry.sense: juHodN: see jaHodN, in four places.
jaHadN: see jajodN, in four places.

jaHidN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jajodN↓ and OajoHadu↓ (Ḳ) A man niggardly, or avaricious; (Ṣ;) possessing little good. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] OaroDN jaHodapN↓ Dry land, in which is no good. (L.) And EaAmN jaHidN, (Ṣ,) or jaHodN↓, (A,) A year in which is little rain. (Ṣ.)
Also jaHidN, A thick and short horse: fem. with p {jaHidapN}: pl. jiHaAdN. (Ḳ.)
juHuwdN: see jaHodN.
jaH-aAdN (applied to a man, TA) Slow in emitting his seminal fluid; syn. baTIoCu AlUinozaAli. (Ḳ.)
OajoHadu: see jaHidN.

hom.sense: 1. jaHara, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoHaru}; (Ḳ;) and AnjHr↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tjH-r↓, (Ḳ,) and AstjHr↓, (A,) said of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab-, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a jerboa, and of a serpent, (Mṣb,) [&c., (see juHorN,)] It entered its burrow, or hole; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) betook itself to it for refuge; or resorted to it. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] jaHarato Eayonuhu [and tjH-rt↓ or AnjHrt↓ (see jaHoraMCu)] ‡ His eye sank, or became depressed, in his head. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
jaHarati AlX-amosu liloguyuwbi † [The sun set, or became near to setting]. (TA.)
And jaHarati AlX-amosu † The sun rose high, (Ḳ,) so that the shade receded and contracted. (TA.)
Hajara said of a man, † He retreated, or retired; remained behind; or held back. (Ṣ, TA.)
jaHara Alr-abiyEu ‡ The [rain called] rbyE withheld itself: (A:) [or] the [season called] rbyE did not give us rain. (Ḳ.)
And jaHara Ean-aA Alxayoru † Good, or prosperity, kept back from us, (Ḳ,* TA,) and did not betide us. (TA.)
See also 4.

4. AjiHrhu He made it (a [lizard of the kind called] Dab- [&c.]) to enter its burrow, or hole; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;)
as also jaHarahu↓: (Ḳ:) and it (rain) constrained it (a Daba [&c.]) to enter its burrow, or hole. (A,* TA.)
[Hence,] OajoHarahumu AlfazaEu ‡ [Fright drove them into their dwellings]. (A.)
AjHrt Als-anapu ‡ Drought, or dearth, brought the people into strait, or narrow, circumstances. (A.)
And AjHrhu UilaI kacaA † He constrained him, or compelled him, to have recourse to, or to betake himself to, or to do, such a thing. (Ḳ,* TA.)
AjHr Alqawomu ‡ The people, or company of men, entered upon a time of drought, (Ḳ,) and difficulty. (TA.)
AjHrt Aln-ujuwmu ‡ The stars (i. e. the stars of winter, TA) occasioned no rain. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1; in two places.
7: see 1; in two places.
8. AjtHr linafosihi juHorFA It [a Dab-, &c.] made for itself a burrow, or hole. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A deep-bottomed cavern. (Ḳ.)

juHorN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juHoraAnN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) The burrow, or hole, (M, Ḳ,) of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab-, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, MF,) and ‡ of a jerboa, and ‡ of a serpent, (Mgh, Mṣb, MF,*) and † of any venomous reptile or the like, and wild beast, (M, Ḳ,) or of any creature that is not of a large size; (TA;) and [the den] of a hyena: (Ḳ in art. wjr:) pl. [of mult.] of the former, jiHarapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ [in the CK jaHarapN]) and [of pauc.] OajoHaArN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] the former, (A,) or ↓the latter, or both, (IAth, TA,) ‡ The vulva of a woman; the pudendum muliebre: and ‡ the anus. (IAth, TA.)

You say, HaS-iniI juHoraki ‡ [Protect thou (O woman) thy pudendum]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., (by ʼÁïsheh, A,) UicaA HaADati AlmaroOapu Haruma AljuHoraAnu↓ (Ṣ, TA) ‡ When a woman has the menstrual discharge, the vulva is forbidden: (TA:) or, (accord. to one reading, TA,) Haruma AljuHoraAn, i. e. both (A) the vulva and the anus (TA) are forbidden; (A, TA;) one having been forbidden before. (TA.)
[Hence likewise,] the former signifies also † A hole, or aperture, (vaEolabN,) whence rainwater flows. (Ḳ and TA in art. vElb.)

jaHorapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaHarapN (Ḳ) † A severe, hard, or distressful, year; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one of drought, dearth, or unfruitfulness, (Ḳ,) and of little rain; because it drives the people into the tents, or houses. (TA.)

EayonN jaHoraMCu i. q. mutajaH-irapN↓ or munojaHirapN↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) i. e. ‡ An eye deep, or depressed, in its socket. (TA.) It occurs in a trad., in a description of Ed-Dejjál; but Az says that [in this instance] it is correctly jaxoraMC, with x. (TA.)
juHoraAnN: see juHorN, in three places.

jaAHirN [Entering a burrow, or hole: and also] † remaining behind, not having come up to others; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a horse or the like, &c. (TA.) [jawaAHiru is its pl., signifying] Entering into burrows, or holes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and hiding-places: (Ṣ:) entering secretly into [their] habitations: (KL:) and also † remaining behind; applied to wild animals, &c. (TA.)
majoHarN, (Ḳ,) pl. majaAHiru, (Ṣ, A,) ‡ A hidingplace; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a place of refuge. (Ḳ.)
EayonN mutajaH-irapN or munojaHirapN: see jaHoraMCu.

1. jaHaXahu, (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,*) aor. _a {yajoHaXu}, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaHoXN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It scratched it, or the like, (namely the skin, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, or a man's side, Ks,) so as to abrade the surface, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or so as to abrade the skin; (Ks;) syn. saHajahu, (Ks, Ḳ,) and qaXarahu: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or i. q. xadaXahu: or it signifies more than this last: (Ks, Ḳ:) or less than this last: (Lth, Ḳ:) and it (an arrow) made a mark upon it; [or grazed it;] namely, a wall. (Mgh.) You say, OaSaAbahu XaIoCN fajaHaXa wajohahu [A thing struck him, and abraded the surface of the skin of his face]: and bihi jaHoXN [in him, or it, is an abrasion of the skin]: (Ṣ, TA:) or jaHoXN is not in the face, nor [anywhere] in the body [except in the side]. (L, TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting Moḥammad, saqaTa mino farasK fajuHiXa Xiq-ahu He fell from a horse, and the skin of his side was scratched, or lacerated, or abraded. (Mgh,* TA.) [See also majoHuwXN.]

jaHoXN A young ass; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) domestic and wild: or before it becomes big: (TA:) or from the time when it is brought forth until it becomes big from sucking: when it has completed the year, it is called tawolabN: (Aṣ:) [or the latter is applied to a wild ass of that age:] pl. [of pauc.] OajoHaAXN (so in a copy of the Ṣ) and [of mult.] jiHaAXN and jiHoXaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juHuwXN (Mṣb) and jiHaXapN: (Aṣ, TA:) [dim. juHayoXN:] and fem. jaHoXapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., AljaHoXa lam-aA bac-aka AlOaEoyaAru, (A, TA,) i. e., Seek thou, or pursue thou, the young ass when the full-grown asses outstrip thee: applied to him who seeks much, and it escapes him; so one says to him, Seek thou less than that. (TA.) [Meyd gives faAtaka in the place of bac-aka.]
Also ‡ A mare's colt; (A, Ḳ;) as being likened to a young ass. (TA.)

And ‡ A gazelle; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) in the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) or a young gazelle; (A, TA;) in that dial.; occurring in a poem of Aboo-Dhu-eyb; but accord. to one relation, the word there is xXof. (TA.)

hom.sense: jaHiyXN The side, (Ḳ, TA,) of a man: (TA:) and a lateral, or an adjacent, part, or place, or tract. (Sh, Ḳ.) You say, OuSiyba jaHiyXuhu His side was hit, or hurt. (TA.) And nazala fulaAnN AljaHiyXa Such a one alighted in the adjacent part or tract. (TA.)

A man who retires to a distance, apart from others: (Ṣ:) who alights apart from others, and does not mix with them: (IDrd, Ḳ:) who lives alone, with none to incommode him in his house. (AḤn.) You say, nazala fulaAnN jaHiyXFA Such a one alighted alone; apart from others. (TA.)

entry.sense: juHayoXN [dim. of jaHoXN]. You say, huwa juHayoXu waHodihi ‡ He is one who follows his own opinion only, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) who has his gain to himself exclusively, (TA,) and does not consult others, nor mix with them; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Euyayoru waHodihi; [q. v.;] meaning dispraise; (Ṣ, A, TA;) the man being thereby likened to a [little] young ass. (TA.)
bayotN jaAHiXN [A tent] apart from the tribe. (TA.)
majoHuwXN One whose side (jaHiyXuhu, TA) is hit, or hurt. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jaHaZato Eayonuhu, aor. _a {yajoHaZu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. juHuwZN (T, Ṣ, TA) and jiHaAZN, (M, TA,) His eyeball, the globe of his eye, was prominent (T, M, Ḳ, TA) and apparent: (TA:) or was large (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and prominent; (Ṣ, TA;) as though a large pearl came forth from the eyelids. (Jm, TA.)

jaHaZa Uilayohi Eamalahu ‡ He looked into, or examined, his deed, and saw the evil that he had done: (Ḳ:) and it may mean he looked into his face, and reminded him of the evil of his deed. (Az, TA.) The Arabs also say, laOajoHaZan-a Uilayoka Oavara yadika, meaning † I will assuredly show thee the evil of the effect of thy hand. (Az, TA)

entry.sense: 2. jH-Z, inf. n. tajoHiyZN, He looked sharply, or intently. (Ḳ.)
jaHZtAni: see ejaAHiZataAni.
jiHaAZN: see jaAHiZN.
jiHaAZN The part [which is next below, or around, the eye, and] which is called the maHojir of the eye. (IDrd, Az, L, Ḳ.)
And, (Az, Ḳ,) in one copy [of the work of IDrd, i. e. the Jm,] (Az,) The edge of the gland of the penis. (Az, Ḳ.)
jiHaAZAni: see jaAHiZataAni.
jiHaAZataAni: see jaAHiZataAni.

jaAHiZN A man having the eyeball, or globe of the eye, prominent and apparent; (TA;) or large and prominent; (Ṣ, TA;) as also jaHoZamN↓, in which the m is augmentative. (Ṣ, TA.) And jaAHZu AlEayonayoni A man whose blacks of his eyes are prominent. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN jaAHiZN UilaI-a biEayonihi, and mujaH-iZN↓, meaning Such a one is looking at me intently. (T, TA in art. znr.) And juH-aZN and juHuZN, [which are pls. of jaAHiZN,] applied to men, signify Raising the eyes, and looking fixedly; or stretching and raising the sight; or opening the eyes and not moving the eyelids. (L, TA.)

jaAHiZataAni, (so in copies of the Ṣ, and in the L,) or jiHaAZataAni↓, (so in a copy of the Ṣ, and so accord. to a copy of the KL, in which the sing. is written jiHaAZapN, though Golius, on the authority of that work, writes it jaHaAZapN,) or jaHaAZaAni↓, accord. to Lth, (TA,) or jaHZtAni↓, (as written in one copy of the Ṣ,) The two blacks of the eye [or rather of the two eyes]. (Lth, Ṣ, L, TA.)
mujaH-iZN: see jaAHiZN.

hom.sense: 1. jaHafahu, aor. _a {yajoHafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaHofN, (TA,) He, or it, stripped off, scraped off, or otherwise removed, its superficial part; (Ḳ;) [and so AjtHfhu↓; for you say,] AjtHf Als-ayolu AlwaAdiI The torrent stripped off [or swept away] the superficial parts of the valley. (TA.)

He, or it, took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, or the greater part of it, or much of it; or swept it away: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, vehemently. (TA.) And mujaAHafapN [an inf. n. of jAHf↓] signifies The taking a thing, taking it away, removing it, or sweeping it away. (TA.)
It (a bucket) took it and bore it away; namely, water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He collected it, lanafosh for himself. (Ḳ.)
He laded it out with his hand or with a ladle, namely, food, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and beverage, (TA,) lahu for him. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
He threw it (a thing, IDrd) by kicking it with his foot. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
jaHafa Alkurapa (Ḳ) and AjtHfhA↓ (TA) He snatched away the ball (Ḳ, TA) from the ground. (TA in explanation of the former. See also jaHofapN.)
[The inf. n.] jaHofN also signifies The act of eating (AA, Ṣ, TA) what is called variyd, (Ṣ,* TA,) or butter with dates, or with dried dates. (AA, Ṣ.)
And The act of striking, or smiting, with the sword. (AA, Ṣ, TA.)
And The act of ejecting, or expelling. (KL.)
And The doing damage, or an injury. (KL. [See also 4.])
And jaHafa maEahu He inclined with him, (Ḳ, TA,) EalaI gayorihi against another: and in like manner, jaHafa lahu [he inclined to him]. (TA.)
jaHifa He (a man) was affected with the flux of the belly termed juHaAf. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. jAHf, inf. n. mujaAHafapN: see 1.

jAHfhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies He pushed, or pressed, against, or upon, him, or it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so jAHf bihi: (TA:) and clave to him, or it: (Ḥam p. 62:) and jiHaAfN [which is also an inf. n. of the same verb] signifies the pushing, or pressing, one against another, or one upon another, in war: and the striving, struggling, contending, or conflicting, in an affair. (AA, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Ahnaf, Uin-amaA OanaA bayona tamiymK kaEulobapi Alr-aAEiI yujaAHifuwna bihaA yawoma Alwirodi, i. e. [I am, among Temeem, only like the milkingvessel of the pastor,] upon which they press, or crowd, together [on the day of coming to water]. (TA.)
He was, or became, near to him, or it. (Ṣ, IF, Ḳ.) So in the phrase jAHf Alc-anoba [He was, or became, near to committing the crime, or sin, or act of disobedience]. (IF, TA.) [See also 4.]
jAHf Eanohu He repelled from him. (TA.)
[The inf. n.] jiHaAfN also signifies The act of fighting, or combating: (Ḳ:) and slaying. (TA.)
And A bucket's striking against the mouth of the well, so that its water pours out, and sometimes it becomes rent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

4. AjHf bihi, (inf. n. UijoHaAfN, Mṣb,) He, or it, took away, carried away, or removed, him, or it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said, in this sense, of a torrent: (Mṣb:) and extirpated him, or it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) said of a torrent, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and of time, or fortune, and of a calamity. (TA.) See also 1.

He, or it, did damage, or an injury, to him. (KL,* MA.) [See also 1.] It is said by one of the sages, mano Mvara Ald-unoyaA OajoHafa biMxiratihi [He who prefers the enjoyments of the present life mars his enjoyments of the life to come]. (TA.) And you say, OajoHafato bihi AlfaAqahu Want reduced him to poverty, (Ḳ, TA,) and caused his property to pass away. (TA.) And OajoHafati Als-anapu The year was, or became, one of drought, and dearth, or sterility. (Mṣb.) [Accord. to Fei,] UijoHaAfN is met. used as meaning ‡ The making to suffer excessive loss or detriment. (Mṣb.) [It is also used as a simple subst., meaning Damage, harm, or injury: pl. UijoHaAfaAtN.]
He imposed upon him, or tasked him with, (namely, his slave, Mṣb,) that which he was unable to do. (Mṣb, TA.)
[Hence, perhaps, † He strained it, or wrested it; namely, a word, or an expression.]
He approached him, or it; was, or became, near to him, or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 3.]

He approached it, or drew near to it, (namely, a road,) but did not enter it. (TA.) And AjHf bihimo, said of an enemy, and of a torrent, or rain, He, or it, approached them, or drew near to them, but missed them. (TA.)
He was near to falling short of accomplishing it, namely, an affair, or of doing what was requisite therein; or was near to being remiss therein. (TA.)

6. tjAHfwA They reached, or hit, one another with staves, (Ḳ, TA,) in the O, with bows, (TA,) and swords, (Ḳ, TA,) in fighting. (TA.) Hence the phrase, in a trad., UicaA tajaAHafato qurayXN Almuloka bayonahumo, i. e., When Kureysh shall contend together in fight for dominion. (TA.)
tjAHfwA Alkurapa bayonahumo They contended together in snatching away the ball (taxaATafuwhaA) with the goff-sticks, (Ḳ,* TA,) after rolling it along. (TA.)
8. AjtHfhu: see 1, in three places.
Also He seized it, took it, or carried it off, by force. (Ḳ, TA.)
He took it up, namely, the food called varyd, with the three fingers. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
He exhausted it, namely, the water of a well, (Ḳ, TA,) with the hand or with a vessel. (TA.)
jaHofN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: jaHofapN A portion of clarified butter. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph.
An affection resembling magaS [or pain and griping] in the belly, (Ḳ, TA,) arising from indigestion. (TA.) [See also jaHaAfN.]

entry.sense: The water that is exhausted from a well: or, that remains in the well after the exhausting [of the rest]. (Ḳ.)
A small quantity of the food called variyd, in a vessel, not filling it. (Ḳ.)
The quantity that is laded out at once, of food: or a handful: (IAạr, Ḳ:) pl. juHafN. (TA.)

A portion of scattered herbage in the qawoz (a mistake for qaron, meaning the most elevated part, TA) of a desert, (Ḳ, TA,) resembling waters on all its sides, such as that the seeker of water knows not which of the waters is the nearest to the extremity thereof. (TA.)
juHaAfN That carries away everything; applied to a torrent; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaAHifN↓; (TA;) and to death. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Death [itself]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A flux of the belly, arising from indigestion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a pain that attacks in consequence of eating flesh-meat without bread. (TA.) [See also jaHofapN.]
jaHuwfN A bucket (dalowN) that takes and bears away water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Food of the kind called variyd remaining in the middle of a bowl. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
jaAHifN: see juHaAfN
mar-a AlX-aIoCu muDir-FA wamujoHifFA The thing passed by approaching, or coming near. (Ṣ.)

sanapN mujoHifapN A year that renders the cattle lean: or a year that destroys people, or impoverishes them, or injures them, (tujoHifu bihimo,) by slaughter, or by marring, or destroying, the cattle. (TA.)
And mujoHifapN, alone, A calamity; (Ḳ;) because it extirminates people. (TA.)
majoHuwfN A man affected with the flux of the belly termed juHaAfN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. jaHofalahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaHofalapN, (TA,) He prostrated him on the ground; threw him down: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and sometimes they said, jaEofalahu. (Ṣ.)
He reproved, chid, or reproached, him for his deed; or did so severely. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. 2. tajaHofaluwA They congregated; collected themselves together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jaHofalN An army: (Ṣ:) or a numerous army. (Ḳ.) MF holds it to be formed, with an augmentative l, from AljaHofu, meaning “the taking,” or “carrying,” a thing “away.” (TA.)
A great man: (Ḳ:) or a man of great estimation or dignity. (Ṣ.)
A generous, noble, or high-born, chief or lord. (Ḳ.)
Great in the sides. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaHofalapN The lip (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a solid-hoofed animal, (Sudot;,) [i. e.,] of a horse, a mule, and an ass: (Ḳ:) and metaphorically applied to that of a man, which is properly termed XafapN: (TA:) not, as some assert, peculiarly the upper lip: (MF:) pl. jaHaAfilu. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) jaHofalataAni, (TA,) Two callosities (raqomataAni) in the two arms of the horse, (Ḳ,) resembling two marks made with a hot iron, facing each other, in the inner side of each arm. (TA.)
jaHanofalN (with an augmentative n Ṣ) Thicklipped. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. jHumati Aln-aAru, aor. _u {yajoHumu}, inf. n. juHuwmN; and jaHimat, aor. _a {yajoHamu}, inf. n. jaHomN and jaHamN [accord. to the CK juHomN] and juHuwmN; The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; (Ḳ, TA;) and had many live coals, and much flame: (TA in explanation of the latter verb; and so the former or the latter is explained in a copy of the Ṣ, in which it is imperfectly written:) or the former signifies it became great: (TA:) and AjHmt↓ it became vehement; said of fire, and also of war. (Ḥam p. 810.)
jaHama, aor. _a {yajoHamu}, He kindled fire; made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame. (Ḳ.)

4. AjHm Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf.n. OijoHaAmN, (TA,) He refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; like AHjm: (Ṣ:) but the former is a rare dial. var. (Ḥar p. 95.) Both these verbs bear contr. significations; being used as meaning He advanced, or went forward: and also he receded, or drew back. (MF.)
AjHm fulaAnFA He, or it, was near to destroying, or killing, such a one. (Ḳ.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 5. tjHum He burned with vehemence of desire, or covetousnsss, and niggardliness; (Ḳ;) as also tjAHm↓: from jaAHimu AlHarobi. (TA.)

Hence, also, (TA,) i. q. taDaAyaqa [app. meaning He became straitened in disposition]. (Ḳ.) You say also, huwa yatajaAHamu↓ EalayonaA, i. e., yataDaAyaqu [app., He becomes straitened in disposition against us]: a phrase mentioned by El-Mundhiree on the authority of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.)
6: see 5, in two places.

jaHomapN The burning, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire; (Ḥam p. 77;) as also jaAHimN↓: (TA:) or vehemence of burning or blazing or flaming: (Bḍ in xxxvii. 95:) or it is an epithet applied to fire because of its redness [or as meaning red]. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)
See also jaHiymN.
juHomapN: see jaHiymN.

jaHiymN A fire burning, or blazing, or flaming, vehemently; (Ḳ;) as also jaAHimN↓: (Ḥam p. 810:) and any fire having one part above another; as also jaHomapN↓ and juHomapN↓; (Ḳ;) of which last the pl. is juHamN: (TA:) or having many live coals, and flaming much: (so in a copy of the Ṣ:) and any great fire in a pit or the like; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from the saying in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 95], qaAluwA QbonuwA lahu bunoyaAnFA faOaloquwhu fiI AljaHiymi [They said, Build ye for him a building, and cast him into the great fire therein]. (Ṣ.) And AljaHiymu is one of the names of The fire [of Hell]; (Ṣ, TA;) from which may God preserve us. (TA.) See also jaAHimN.
jaH-aAmN Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: (Ḳ:) from jaAHimu AlHarobi, meaning “the straitness, and vehemence, of war.” (TA.)

jaAHimN: see jaHiymN. Also Live coals (jamorN) vehemently burning or blazing or flaming. (Ḳ.) And a place vehemently hot; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaHiymN↓. (Ḳ.) El-Aạshà says, Almawotu jaAHimN [app. meaning † Death is like a burning, or fiercelyburning, fire]. (Ṣ.) See also jaHomapN.

jaAHimu Aljarobi The main part [or the thick] of the war or battle: (Ḳ:) or the straitness thereof: (TA:) and the vehemence of the fight or slaughter, in the scene thereof. (Ḳ.) You say, AiSoTalaI bijaAHimi AlHarobi ‡ [He warmed himself with the heat, or vehemence, of the battle]. (TA.)
AljaAHimapu Fire: (TA:) or, [as an epithet,] fire burning, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming. (Ḥam p. 77.)

hom.sense: 1. jad-ahu, aor. _u {yajodudu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. jad-N, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut it, or cut it off. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh.) You say of a weaver, jad-a vawobFA He cut off a piece of cloth [sufficient for a garment or the like, from the web]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And jad-a Aln-axola, (Ṣ, Mgh, L,) aor, _u, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. jad-N (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and jadaAdN (Lḥ, Mgh, L) and jidaAdN; (Lḥ, L; [in the L, the last two forms are mentioned as inf. ns., and the former of them is mentioned as inf. n. in the Mgh; but in the Ḳ, they are only mentioned as syn. with jad-N; and in the Ṣ, it seems to be implied that they are simple substs., or quasi-inf. ns.;]) i. q. Saramahu; (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;*) [like jac-ahu and jaz-ahu;] i.e., He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees. (Mgh, L. [See also jadaAdN.]) And jud-ato OaxolaAfu Aln-aAqapi The she-camel's teats were cut off by some accident that befell her: (Aṣ, TA:) or, in consequence of injury occasioned to her by the SiraAr [q. v.]. (Ṣ.) And tajodiydN [inf. n. of jd-d↓] signifies The cutting off the teat of a camel. (KL.) You say also, jud-a vadoyaA Oum-ika May thy mother's breasts be cut off: a form of imprecation against a man; and implying a wish for his separation. (Aṣ, L, from a trad.)
See also 5.

jad-a,, aor. _i {yajodidu}, inf. n. jid-apN, It (a garment, TA, or a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) was new; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [as though newly cut off from the web;] from jad-a as signifying “he cut,” or “cut off.” (L.) [See also 5.]

jad-a, like taEiba, (Mṣb,) see. pers. jadidNta, [like its syn. HaZiZota,] (L, Mṣb,) aor. yajad-u; (Mṣb;) or jud-a, with damm, (Mgh,) see. pers. judidota, (Ṣ,) [aor. yujad-u;] inf. n. jad-N; (Ṣ,* Mgh, L, Mṣb;) He was, or became, fortunate, or possessed of good fortune, (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb,) or of good worldly fortune; (TA;) he advanced in the world, or in worldly circumstances; (Mgh;) biAlOamori by the affair, or event, whether good or evil; (L;) or biAlX-aIoCi by the thing. (Mṣb.) And humo yujad-uwna bihimo, as also yuHaZ-uwna bhm, They become possessed of good fortune, and riches, or competence, or sufficiency. (Ibn-Buzurj, L.) [You say also, jad-a jad-uhu ‡: so in a copy of the A: probably a mistranscription for jad-a jid-uhu, which see below: if not, meaning His fortune became good; or his good fortune increased in goodness: or, perhaps, his dignity became great; from what next follows].

jad- fiI EayoniI, (Ṣ, A,) or fiI Euyuwni Aln-aAsi, and Suduwrihimo, (Mgh,) aor. _i {yajodidu}, inf. n. jad-N, (Ṣ,) He was, or became, great, or of great dignity or estimation, in my eye, or in the eyes of men, and their minds. (Ṣ, A, Mgh.) It is said in a trad. of Anas, kaAna Alr-ajulu min-aA UicaA qaraOa Albaqarapa waMla EimoraAna jad-a fiynaA, i. e., [A man of us, when he recited the chapter of the Cow and that of the Family of ʼImrán (the second and third chapters of the Ḳur-án),] used to be great in our eyes. (Ṣ.)

jad-a fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or fiI Oamorihi, (L,) or fiI kalaAmihi, (Mṣb,) aor. _i {yajodidu} (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. jid-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or jad-N, (L, Mṣb,) jid-N being a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and Ajd-↓ fiyhi; (L, Ḳ;) He was serious, or in earnest, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the affair, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or in his affair, (L,) or in his speech; (Mṣb;) syn. Haq-aqa; (L;) contr. of hazala. (L, Mṣb. [In the Ṣ and A and Ḳ, the inf. n. is said to signify the contr. of hazolN; and in the Ḳ, it is also said to be syn. with taHoqiyqN.])

And jad-a fiI AlOamori, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajodidu} and _u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jid-N, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is jad-N; (Mṣb;) and Ajd-↓ fiyhi; (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) signify also He strove, laboured, or toiled; exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, diligently, studiously, sedulously, earnestly, or with energy; was diligent, or studious; took pains, or extraordinary pains; in the affair. (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And jad-afiI Als-ayori He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in going, or journeying, or in his course, or pace; ‡ he hastened therein: and in like manner, Ajd-↓ Als-ayora † he hastened his course, or pace. (L.) And jad-a jid-uhu, [meaning His labour, or exertion, or energy, was, or became, great, or extraordinary: or] meaning AizodaAda jid-uhu jid-FA [his labour, &c., increased in labour,, &c.]: or it may mean what was not [his] jid-, became jid-; wherefore, i. e. because it would be so eventually, it is here so called. (Ḥam p. 33.) [See also jad-a jad-uhu, above.]

jad-a bihi AlOamoru (A, L) ‡ The affair, or event, distressed, or afflicted, him. (L.) So in the saying of Aboo-Sahm,
OaxaAlidu laA yaroDaI Eani AlEabodi rab-uhu
UicaA jad-a biAlX-ayoxi AlEuquwqu AlmuSam-imu
[O Khálid, his Lord will not approve of the servant, or man, (meaning the son,) when cutting, or biting, disobedience to a parent distresses the old man]. (L.)
jad-a, aor, _i, inf. n. jad-N and jid-N, It (a house, or tent, bayot) dripped, or let fall drops. (Ḳ.)
2. jd-d, inf. n. tajodiydN: see 1.
See also 4, in three places.
tjdyd also signifies The making [or weaving] stripes of different colours in a garment. (KL.)

entry.sense: 3. jAd-hu fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) inf. n. mujaAd-apN, (L,) i. q. HaAq-ahN (Ṣ, L) or HaAqaqahu (Ḳ) [He contended with him respecting a thing, each of them asserting his right therein: so accord. to explanations of HAq-hu in the lexicons: but I think that the meaning intended here is, he acted seriously, or in earnest, with him in the affair; and this is confirmed by its being immediately added in the TA, after HAqqh, “and Oajad-a” signifies “Haq-aqa, as above mentioned:” see jad-afiI AlOamori expl. by Haq-aqa as contr. of hazala]. Also He exerted his full effort, or endeavour, or energy, with him in the affair. (So accord. to an explanation of the inf. n., mjAdap, in the KL.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajd- Aln-axolu The palm-trees attained to the time for the cutting off of the fruit. (Ṣ, A,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[Hence, perhaps,] Oajad-ato qaruniI minohu I (myself, TA) relinquished, or forsook, him, or it. (Ḳ.)

Ajd-hu, and Astjd-hu↓, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and jd-dhu↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He made it new; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ,) or a garment: (A, TA:) or he put it on, or wore it, new; namely, a garment. (TA.) One says to him who puts on a new garment, Oaboli waOajid-a waQHomadi AlkaAsiI [Wear out, and make, or put on, new, and praise the Clother, meaning God]. (Ṣ.) And you say, bahiIa bayotu fulaAnK faOajad-a bayotFA mino XaEarK [The tent of such a one was, or became, rent, or pierced with holes; therefore he made a new tent of haircloth]. (Ṣ.) And jd-d↓ AlOamora, and Ajd-hu, and Astjd-hu↓, He originated, or innovated, the thing, or affair; or did it newly, or for the first time (Mṣb.) And jd-d↓ AlwuDuwoCa ‡ [He renewed the ablution termed wDwC], and AlEahoda ‡ [the compact, or contract, or covenant,, &c.]. (TA.)

Ajd- fulaAnN Oamorahu bicelika Such a one established, or settled, firmly his affair, or case, thereby, or therein: so says Aṣ, and he cites the following verse:
Oajad-a bihaA OamorFA waOayoqana Oan-ahu
lahaA Oawo liOuxoraI kaAlT-aHiyna turaAbuhaA
[He established, or settled, firmly his case thereby, or therein, and knew certainly that he was for it, (app. meaning a war, or battle, Harob, which is fem.,) or for another whereof the dust would be like flour]: Aboo-Naṣr says, It has been related to me that he said, Ajda bhA AmrFA means Ajd- Oamorahu bihaA; [and so this phrase is explained in the Ḳ;] but the former explanation I heard from himself: (L:) or this phrase means Oajad-a Oamoruhu bihaA [so in two copies of the Ṣ, app., † his affair, or case, became easy, or practicable, thereby, like ground termed jadad, which is easy to walk, or travel, upon; see the next sentence]; Amr being put in the accus. case as a specificative, like EayonFA in the phrase qarirotu bihi EayonFA, meaning qar-ato bihi EayoniI. (Ṣ.)

Ajd- also signifies It (a road) was, or became, what is termed jadad [i. e. hard, or level,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Ajd-t laka AlOaroDu The ground hath become to thee free from soft places, and clear to thy view. (TA.)

Also He walked along, or traversed, what is termed jadad. (Ḳ.) And Ajd- Alqawomu The people, or company of men, came to what is so termed: (Ṣ:) and ascended upon the surface (jadiyd) of the ground: or went upon sand such as is termed jadad. (TA.)
See also 1, in three places.

entry.sense: 5. tjd-d [originally It became cut, or cut off.]
[And hence,] It (an udder) lost, or became devoid of, its milk: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] jud-a↓, aor. yujad-u, inf. n. jadadN, it, (a breast, and an udder,) became dry. (AHeyth, TA.)

Hence also, [It was newly made; as though newly cut off from the web;] said of a garment: (TA:) and it (a thing, Ṣ, A) became new: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and it (a thing, or an affair,) originated; was originated, or innovated; or was done newly, or for the first time: and sometimes Astjd-↓ is used intransitively [in the same senses]. (Mṣb.) [Also † It (an action, as, for instance, ablution, and a compact, or the like,) was renewed. See jad-ada as syn. with Oajad-a.]

hom.sense: 10: see 4, in two places:
and see also 5.

jad-N Fortune, or particularly good fortune, syn. HaZ-N, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) and baxotN, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) in the world, or in wordly circumstances; (TA;) advance in the world, or in worldly circumstances: (Mgh:) pl. [of mult.] juduwdN (Ṣ) and [of pauc.] OajodaAdN and Oajud-N. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN cuw jad-K fiI kacaA Such a one is possessed of good fortune in such a thing. (L.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the day of resurrection, waUicaA OaSoHaAbu Aljad-i maHobuwsuwna And lo, the people who were possessed of good fortune and riches in the world were imprisoned. (L.) And in a prayer, (L,) laA yanofaEu caA Aljad-i minoka Aljad-u The good worldly fortune of him who is possessed of such fortune will not profit him, (Mgh, L,) in the world to come, (L,) in lieu of Thee; (Mgh, L;*) i. e., of obedience to Thee: (Mgh, and Mughnee in art. mino:) or in lieu of the good fortune that cometh from Thee: or, as some say, will not defend him from Thee. (Mughnee ubi suprà. [See also another explanation below.]) Hence, Oajad-aka laA tafoEalo [or Oajad-ika]; and, accord. to some, wajad-ika: see jid-N.

One's lot in life; and the means of subsistence that one receives from the bounty of God. (L, Ḳ.) One says, lifulaAnK fiI hecaA AlOamori jad-N Such a one has in this thing, or state of affairs, means of subsistence. (AʼObeyd, L.)

Richness; competence, or sufficiency; or the state of being in no need, or of having no wants, or of having few wants. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.) lA ynfE cA Aljd- mnk Aljd-, [explained above, is said to mean] Riches,, &c., will not profit the possessor thereof with Thee; for nothing will profit him but acting in obedience to Thee: mnk here signifies Einodaka. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Greatness, or majesty; (Mujáhid, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to some, specially of God: (TA:) so in the Ḳur lxxii. 3: (Ṣ, TA:) or his freedom from all wants or the like; syn. ginFI. (Ṣ.) Hence, taEaAlaI jad-uka, (Mgh, TA,) in a trad. respecting prayer, (TA,) Exalted be thy greatness, or majesty. (Mgh,* TA.)
See also Oajad-aka, as an interrogative phrase, voce jid-N.

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and majoduwdN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and jadiydN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jad-iy-N↓, (Ṣ,) and jud-N↓, and jud-iy-N↓, the last two with damm, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, Fortunate; or possessed of good fortune; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) or possessed of good worldly fortune: (TA:) or possessing great fortune, or great good fortune: (Ḳ:) [the words here given from the Ṣ are there coupled with synonyms of the same form, thus; jadiydN↓ HaZiyZN, and majoduwdq↓ maHoZuwZN, and jad-N HaZ-u, and jad-iy-N↓ HaZ-iI-N; on the authority of ISk:] jud-N↓, with damm, as an epithet applied to a man, is said by Sb to be syn. with majoduwdN; and its pl. is jud-uwna only. (L.)

Also jad-u, A grandfather; the father's father, and the mother's father: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and † a higher ascendant; an ancestor: (Mṣb:) and jad-apN↓ a grandmother; the father's mother, and the mother's mother: (Ḳ:) [and † a female ancestor:] pl. of the former, OajodaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] and juduwdN and juduwdapN: (Ḳ:) and of the latter, jad-aAtN. (TA.) Hence, accord. to some, wajad-ika laA tafoEalo: see jid-N.
See also jud-apN:
and see jadiydN.
jud-N: see jad-N, in two places.
See also jud-apN.
Also The side (jaAnib) of anything. (Ḳ.)

And A well in a place where is much herbage, or pasture: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a well abounding with water; (Ḳ;) [and] so judojudN↓; (KL;) but AʼObeyd says that this is not known: (L:) and, contr., a well containing little water: a scanty water, or water little in quantity: a water at the extremity of a [desert such as is called] falaAp: (Ḳ:) an old water: (Th, Ḳ:) an old well: (KL:) pl. (in all these senses, TA) OajodaAdN. (Mṣb, TA.)

jid-N [accord. to some an inf. n., but accord. to others a simple subst., (see jad-a,)] Seriousness, or earnestness, contr. of hazolN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in speech. (Mṣb.) Hence, valaAvN jid-uhun-a jid-N wahazoluhun-a jid-N [There are three things in relation to which what is serious is serious and what is jesting is serious]: a saying of Moḥammad, whereby he forbade a man's divorcing and emancipating and marrying and then retracting, saying “I was jesting;” as was customary in the time of paganism. (Mṣb.) Oajid-aka and Oajad-aka↓ signify the same; (Ṣ;) but the former is the more chaste; (TA;) jid- and jad- being thus used only as prefixed nouns: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Aṣ says that the meaning is, Oabijid-K minoka hecaA [Does this proceed from thee in seriousness, or in earnest?]; and that jid- is put in the accus. case because of the rejection of the [prep.] b: AA says that the meaning is, maA laka Oajid-FA minoka [What aileth thee? Doth it proceed from thee in seriousness, or in earnest?]; and that jd- is put in the accus. case as an inf. n.: Th says that the phrase as it occurs in poetry is Oajid-aka, with kesr: (Ṣ:) but when it occurs with wa [in the place of Oa, or with Oa in the sense of wa, as a particle denoting an oath,]
it is wajad-ika↓ [or Oajad-ika], with fet-ḥ: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) yon say, wajad-ika laA tafoEalo, (Ḳ, in the CK wajad-aka,) meaning, By thy grandfather, do not [such a thing]: or by thy fortune, or good fortune, do not: (TA:) also, when you say, Oajid-aka laA tafoEalo, [or Oajid-ika, for Oa (q. v.) is substituted for a particle of swearing, as in Oall-ehi laOafoEalan-a,] the meaning is, I adjure thee by thy truth, (Lth, Ḳ,) and by thy seriousness, or earnestness, (Lth, TA,) do not: and when you say, Oajad-aka↓ laA tafoEalo, [or Oajad-ika,] the meaning is, I adjure thee by thy fortune, or good fortune, do not: (Lth, Ḳ:) Aboo-ʼAlee Esh-Shalowbeenee asserts that it implies the signification of an oath. (MF.) In the phrase Ajd-k lA tafoEalu, AAF says, we may consider lA tfEl as put in the place of a denotative of state; or the phrase may be originally Ajd-k Oano laA tafoEala, An being suppressed, and its government annulled: [therefore it may be rendered, in the former case, Is it with seriousness on thy part, thou doing such a thing? and in the latter case, Is it with seriousness on thy part that thou will not do such a thing? i. e. dost thou mean seriously that thou will not do it? or in this case, Ajd-k may be used as a form of adjuration in one of the senses explained above, and laA tafoEalu may mean, that thou do not such a thing; or Ajd-k may mean wajad-aka, (explained above, and so in the three exs. below,) and laA tafoEalu, thou wilt not do it:] and, as AḤei says, there is here a nice point, which is this; that the noun [meaning the pronoun] to which jd- is prefixed should agree in person with the verb which follows it; so that one should say, Ajd-iI laA Oukorimuka, and Ajd-ka laA tafoEalu, and Ajd-hu laA yazuwrunaA; because jd- is an inf. n. corroborating the proposition that follows it. (MF.)

Also, [and in this case, likewise, accord. to some an inf. n., but accord. to others a simple subst., (see, again, jad-a,)] A striving, labour, or toil; exertion of one's self, or of one's power or efforts or endeavours or ability; vigorousness, strenuousness, laboriousness, diligence, studiousness, sedulousness, earnestness, or energy; painstaking, or extraordinary painstaking; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) in affairs, (Ṣ,) or in an affair. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, jid-FA [meaning In a great, or an extraordinary, degree; greatly, much, exceedingly, or extraordinarily; very; very greatly, or very much; extremely]; as in the phrase, (Mṣb,) fulaAnN muHosinN jid-FA [Such a one is beneficent in a great, or an extraordinary, degree; very, exceedingly, or extremely, beneficent]: you should not say jad-FA. (Ṣ, Mṣb.* [In my copy of the Mṣb, it is mHsn jd-A bAlftH: but the context shows that there is an omission here, and that, after jd-A, we should read, as in the Ṣ, walaA taqulo jad-FA.]) jid-FA [in a phrase of this kind] is put in the accus. case as an inf. n. [of which the verb is understood; so that, in the ex. given above, the proper meaning is, yajid-u fiI AlUiHosaAni jid-FA striving in beneficence with a great striving]; because it is not from the same root as the preceding word, nor is it identical with it [in meaning]. (L.) You say also, fiI hecaA xaTarN jid-a EaZiymK, meaning EaZiymN jid-FA [† In this is a very, or an extremely, great danger, or risk]. (Ṣ.) And hecA AlEaAlimu jid-a AlEaAlimi This is the learned man, the extremely [or the very] learned man. (L.) And hecaA EaAlimN jid-a EaAlimK This is a learned man, an extremely [or a very] learned man. (L,* Ḳ.)
Also ‡ Haste. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA.) So in the phrase fulaAnN EalaI jid-i OamorK ‡ Such a one is in haste in an affair. (Ṣ, L, TA.)
See also jud-apN:
and see jadiydN.

entry.sense: jad-apN: see jad-N, near the end of the paragraph.

jud-apN The bank, or side, or a river; as also jid-apN and jid-N↓ (IAth, L, Ḳ) and jud-N↓ (IAth, Mgh, L) and jad-N↓, (Mgh, L, Ḳ,) accord. to some, but correctly jud-N; so called because cut off from the river, or because cut by the water, in like manner as it is called saAHilN because it is abraded by the water: (Mgh:) or the part of a river that is near the land; as also jid-apN↓: (L:) and the shore of the sea: (MF:) accord. to Aṣ, jd-p is an arabicized word from the Nabathean kd-. (L.)

The stripe, or streak, that is on the back of the ass, differing from his general colour. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.) And ‡ A streak (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in anything, (TA,) as in a mountain, (Fr, Ṣ,) differing in colour from the rest of the mountain, (Ṣ,) white and black and red; (Fr, TA;) as also in the sky: (A, TA:) pl. judadN, (Fr, Ṣ,) occurring in the Ḳur xxxv. 25; (Ṣ;) where some read jududN, pl. of jdydp↓ [app. jadiydapN], which is syn. with jud-apN; and some, jadadN [q. v.]. (Bḍ.)
A sign, or mark, syn. EalaAmapN, (Th, Ḳ,) of, or in, anything. (Th, TA.)

A beaten way, marked with lines [cut by the feet of the men and beasts that have travelled along it]: (Az, L:) or a road, or way: pl. judadN: (Mṣb:) and juduwdN, also, [app. another pl. of jud-apN,] signifies paths, or tracks, forming lines upon the ground. (Az, L.) See also jaAd-apN.

[Hence, app., but accord. to the Ṣ from the same word as signifying “a streak,”] rakiba jud-apF mina AlOamori, (Ṣ, A, TA,) or jud-apa AlOamori, (Ḳ,) ‡ He set upon a way, or manner, of performing the affair: (A:) or he formed an opinion respecting the affair, or case. (Zj, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
See also jid-apN.
jid-apN: see jud-apN, in two places:
and see jadiydN.
Also A rag; or piece torn off from a garment; and so jud-apN↓: thus in the saying, maA Ealayohi jid-apN and jud-apN [There is not upon him a rag]. (Ḳ.)
A collar upon the neck of a dog: (Th, L, Ḳ:) pl. judadN [like luHFI pl. of liHoyapN, or perhaps a mistake for jidadN]. (L.)

jadadN Hard ground: (Ṣ:) or hard level ground: (Ḥar p. 522:) [see also jadojadN:] or rough level ground: (Ḳ:) or rough ground: or level ground: (TA:) or a level and spacious tract of land; a tract such as is called SaHoraMC, and such as is called faDaMC, containing no soft place in which the feet sink, nor any mountain, nor any [hill such as is called] Oakamap; sometimes wide, and sometimes of little width: (ISh:) [and] a conspicuous road: (Bḍ in xxxv. 25:) pl. OajodaAdN. (ISh.) It is said in a prov., mano salaka Aljadada Oamina AlEivaAra [He who walks along hard, or hard and level, ground is secure from stumbling]; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning, he who pursues the course marked out by common consent is secure from stumbling. (TA.) And makaAnN jadadN occurs in a trad., meaning Level ground. (TA.)
See also jadiydN.
Also Sand that is thin, or fine, (Ḳ, TA,) and sloping down. (TA.)
And A thing resembling a siloEap [or ganglion] in the neck of a camel. (Ḳ.)

jadaAdN and jidaAdN↓ The cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (Ṣ,* A,* L, Mṣb,* Ḳ.*) You say, hecaA zamanu AljadaAdi and AljidaAdi [This is the time, or season, of the cutting off of the fruit of the palmtrees]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.*) Some say that jdAd signifies particularly [as above,] the cutting off [of the fruit] of palm-trees; and jcAc, the cutting off of all fruits, in a general sense: others say that they signify the same. (TA.)

Also The time, or season, of the cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (Ṣ,* L.) You say jadaAdN and jidaAdN, like SaraAmN and SiraAmN, and qaTaAfN and qiTaAfN; (Ks, Ṣ;) whence it seems as though the measures faEaAlN and fiEaAlN were uniformly applicable to every noun signifying the time of the action; such nouns being likened to OawaAnN and UiwaAnN. (Ṣ.)
jidaAdN: see jadaAdN, and jaAd-N.

jaduwdN, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or jaduwdapN, (L,) Having little milk, (ISk, Ṣ,) or not from any imperfection; (L;) applied to a ewe, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but not to a she-goat; the epithet maSuwrN being used in the latter case: (ISk, Ṣ:) or a ewe or she-goat having no milk; as also jad-aMCu↓: (A:) pl. jadaAYidu (Ṣ, L) and jidaAdN. (L.)
Also A fat she-ass: pl. jidaAdN. (AZ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
jadiydN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, [i. e. majoduwdN↓,] Cut, or cut off. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) A poet says,
OabiI Hub-iI sulayomaI Oano yabiydaA
waOamosaI HaboluhaA xalaqFA jadiydaA
[My love of Suleymà hath refused to perish; but her cord (i. e. her tie of affection to me) hath become worn out and cut]: (Ṣ:) [as jdyd signifies “new” more commonly than “cut,”] this verse appears as though it involved a contradiction. (MF.)

Applied to a garment, or a piece of cloth [sufficient for a garment or the like], Newly cut off [from the web] by the weaver: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so (without p, Ṣ) applied to a miloHafap; (Ṣ, A;) thus applied to a fem. n. because syn. with majoduwdapN↓; (Ṣ, ISd;) or, accord. to Sb, because by mlHfp in this case is meant UizaAr, and for a like reason in like cases; (Ḥam p. 555;) but one also says jadiydapN; (ISd;) and accord. to some, jdyd is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, and therefore the p is regularly affixed to it: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) the pl. is jududN (Mbr, Th, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and judadN; (AZ, AʼObeyd, Mbr;) but the former is the more common. (TA.)

And hence, (L,) applied to a garment, (L, TA,) or a thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) New; contr. of qadiymN, (Mṣb,) or contr. of xalaqN; (Ṣ, L;) from jid-apN as contr. of bilFI: (Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] Oajid-apN and [of mult.] jududN and judadN. (L.) You say, OaSobaHato xalaquhumo jududFA, a phrase mentioned by Lḥ, meaning xuloqaAnuhumo jududFA [i. e. Their old worn-out garments became replaced by new]: or jududFA may be here put for jadiydFA. (L.)

And hence, (TA,) AljadiydaAni and AlOajad-aAni↓ The night and the day; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because they never become impaired by time. (TA.) You say, laA OafoEaluhu maA Qxotalafa AljadiydaAni and AlOajad-aAni↓ [I will not do it while the day and the night succeed each other]: (Ṣ:) or maA kar-a AljadiydaAni and AlOajad-aAni [while the day and the night return time after time: i. e., ever]. (A.)
Hence likewise, jadiydN also signifies A thing of which one has had no knowledge. (L.)

And hence, (L,) Aljadiydu signifies Death: (Ḳ:) or is applied as an epithet to death, in the dial. of Hudheyl. (L.) Accord. to Akh and El-Mugháfis El-Báhilee, jadiydu Almawoti means The commencement of death. (L.)
Also The face, or surface, of the earth, or ground; [as though it were cut;] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so jadadN↓, and jid-apN↓, and jad-N↓, (Ḳ,) and jid-N↓. (TA.)
See also jad-N, in two places.

entry.sense: judaAdapN What is cut off from the roots, or eradicated, of, or from, palm-trees, &c. (Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: jadiydapN The kind of pad, or stuffed thing, (rifaAdapN,) and the felt, stuck, or attached, beneath the two boards of a horse's saddle: there are two such things, called jadiydataAni: (Ṣ:) or the jdydtAn consist of the felt that is stuck, or attached, in the inner side of a horse's and of a camel's saddle: (L:) but jdydp thus applied is a post-classical word: the [classical] Arabs say jadoyapN, (Ṣ,) or, as in J's own handwriting, jadiy-apN. (So in the margin of a copy of the Ṣ.)
See also jud-apN.

entry.sense: jad-iI-N: see jad-N, in two places.
jud-iI-N: see jad-N.
jadojadN Hard level ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [see also jadadN:] smooth ground: and rough ground: (TA:) a smooth tract such as is called fayof. (AA, TA.)

hom.sense: judojudN [The cricket;] i. q. Sar-aAru All-ayoli, (Ṣ, M,) a small flying thing, (Ḳ,) that leaps, or springs, or bounds, much, (Ṣ, M,) and creaks by night, (TA,) and bears a resemblance to the jaraAd [or locust]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and a certain insect like the junodab, (M, L, Ḳ,) except that it is generally blackish, and short, but in some instances inclining to white; also called SaroSarN: (M, L:) or i. q. SadFI and junodabN: (El-'Adebbes:) pl. jadaAjidu. (Ṣ.) Accord. to IAạr, A certain insect that clings to a skin, or hide, and eats it. (TA.)
See also jud-N.
jaAd-N act. part. n. of jad-a; (Mgh, L;) Cutting, or cutting off. (Mgh.)

OajaAd-u Oanota Oamo haAzilN Art thou serious or jesting? (A.) It is said in a trad., laA yaOoxucan-a OaHadukumo mataAEa Oaxiyhi laAEibFA jaAd-FA [By no means shall any one of you take the property of his brother in play and in earnest]; by which is meant taking a thing without meaning to steal it, but meaning to vex and anger the owner, so that the taker is in play with respect to theft, but in earnest in annoying. (TA in art. lEb.)

fulaAnN jaAd-N Such a one is striving, labouring, or toiling; exerting himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability;, &c. (TA.) And fulaAnN jaAd-N mujid-N↓, thus with the two similar words together, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L,) signifies the same [in an intensive degree]. (L, TA.)

jaAd-u miAYapi wasoqK Land, or palm-trees, of which the produce, cut therefrom, is a hundred camel-loads: jaAd-N being here used in the sense of majoduwdN↓. (L.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr, nahala EaAYiXapa jidaAda↓ EiXoriyna wasoqFA, meaning He gave to ʼÁïsheh palm-trees of which the quantity of the dates cut therefrom was a hundred camel-loads; but the phrase heard from the Arabs is jaAd-a EiXoriyna: the former is like the saying hecihi Ald-araAhimu Darobu AlOamiyri; and the latter, like EiyXapN raADiyapN. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: jaAd-apN The main part of a road; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) its middle: (Mgh, Mṣb, and M voce jarajap:) or its even part: or the beaten track, or part along which one walks, or travels; the conspicuous part thereof: or a main road that comprises other roads, or tracks, and upon which one must pass: (TA:) or a road, or way, absolutely; as also jud-apN↓: (Zj, MF:) or a road leading to water: (AḤn, TA:) it is so called because it is marked with tracks, forming lines: (T, TA:) pl. jawaAd-N, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) occurring in poetry without teshdeed, but disapproved by Aṣ. (L.) fulaAnN EalaI AljaAd-api means † Such a one is following the right course of action or the like. (Mgh.) You say also, huwa EalaI jaAd-api AlHaq-i † [He is on the road, or main road, of truth]: not, however, EalaI jaAd-api AlbaATili, but ElI mazal-api AlbaATili, and mazolaqatihi, and maholakatihi. (MF.)

hom.sense: Oajad-u [Having some part, or parts, cut, or cut off: fem. jad-aMCu].
[Hence,] jad-aMCu A ewe, or she-goat, or she-camel, (TA,) having her ear cut off. (Ḳ, TA.)
A ewe, or she-goat, having her teats cut off; (Sh, TA;) as also mujad-adapN↓ [q. v.], applied to a she-camel: (Aṣ, TA:) or having her udder cut off. (Khálid, TA.)

[And hence,] † A milch animal (TA [in the Ṣ app. restricted to a ewe]) whose milk has passed away, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of some fault, or imperfection: (ISk, Ṣ:) see also jaduwdN: or a ewe, or she-camel, or she-ass, having little milk; having a dry udder: or having dry teats, being hurt by the SiraAr [q. v.]: (L:) and Oajad-u † a breast that has become dry. (AHeyth.)
† A woman small in the breast: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having short breasts. (TA from a trad.)
† A desert, (falaAp, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or land, (OaroD, A,) in which is no water: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) a desert (mafaAzap) that is dry. (TA.)
EaAmN Oajad-u and sanapN jad-aMCu † A year of drought, and of dryness o the earth. (TA.)
AlOajad-aAni: see jadiydN, in two places.
Oajad-u also signifies More [and most] easy to walk or ride upon, and more [and most] plain or level; applied to a road. (TA.)
And More [and most] fortunate; applied to a man. (ISd, A, L.)
mujad-adapN AlOaxolaAfi A she-camel having her teats cut off in consequence of injury occasioned to her by the SiraAr [q. v.]. (Ṣ.) See also Oajad-u.
And mujad-adN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC having stripes of different colours. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: mujid-N: see jaAd-N.

Uin-ahaA lmjd-p biAlr-ajuli, a phrase mentioned by Aṣ, said of a she-camel, meaning, Verily she is quick in her pace with the man: but Az says, I know not whether he said mijad-apN↓ or mujid-apN: the former would be from jad-a; and the latter, from Oajad-a. (L.)
mijad-apN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: See also jad-N, in two places.

1. jaduba, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajodubu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. juduwbapN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a place, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, or a country, or region, Mṣb,) was, or became, affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jadiba, (A,) inf. n. jadabN; (KL;) or jadaba; (Ḳ;) and Ajdb↓; (A, Ḳ;) or jadibat, aor. _a {yajodabu}; and Oajodabat↓; both said of the earth or land (AlOaroD): (Mṣb:) and Oajodabati↓ AlbilaAdu the countries, or regions, were affected with drought, and the prices became high [therein]. (TA.)

jadabahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajodibu} (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yajodubu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jadobN, (Mṣb,) He found fault with it; dispraised it; expressed disapprobation of it. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So in the saying (Ṣ, A) relating to ʼOmar, (A, TA,) in a trad., (Ṣ,) jadaba Als-amara baEoda AlEiXaMCi (Ṣ) or baEoda AlEatamapi (A) [He expressed disapprobation of night-discourse after nightfall, or after the first third of the night reckoned from the disappearance of the redness of the twilight].

entry.sense:
3. jaAdabati AlUibilu AlEaAma, (ISk, Ṣ, A, TA,) inf. n. mujaAdabapN, (TA,) The camels experienced, or have experienced, drought, and barrenness, or dryness of the earth, this year, and have become in such a state as not to eat anything but dry and black herbage, dry vumaAm [or panic grass]: (ISk, Ṣ, TA:)
or have not met with, or found, anything but what was bad, by reason of drought, and barrenness, or dryness of the earth, this year. (A.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in three places.
Oajodabati Als-anapu The year became one of drought, barrenness, or dearth; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (A,* TA.)
Ajdb Alqawomu The people, or company of men, experienced drought, barrenness, or death; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] nazalonaA bibaniI fulaAnK faOajodabonaA ‡ We alighted as guests at the abode of the sons of such a one, and found not entertainment with them, though they were in the enjoyment of plenty: (A:) [or] nazalonaA fulaAnFA faOajodabonaAhu † we alighted as guests at the abode of such a one, and [found that] he did not entertain us. (TA.) [The latter, if correct, is from what next follows.]
Ajdb AlOaroDa He found the land to be affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. maA Oatajad-abu Oano OaSoHabaka † I do not deem it disagreeable, or unsuitable, to accompany thee; syn. maA Oasotawoximu. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
jadobN Drought, barrenness, or dearth; contr. of xiSobN; (Ṣ;) i. q. maHolN, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. drought, or suspension of rain, and dryness of the earth; (Mṣb;) dryness and barrenness of the earth: (Ḥar p. 576:) and jidab-N↓ is a name, or subst., for AljadobN, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning AlmaHolu; as in the saying of the rájiz, cited by Sb,
laqado xaXiytu Oano OaraI jidab-aA
fiI EaAminaA baEoda maA OaxoSab-aA
[Verily I feared to see drought, or barrenness,, &c., in this our year, after it had been abundant in herbage]; jidab-aA being used for AljadobaA; or, accord. to one reading, it is jadobab-aA↓, with a doubled b added; the change being made for the sake of the metre. (M, TA. [Respecting OaxoSab-aA, see 4 in art. xSb.])

Also A place, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or a country, or region, (Mṣb,) affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; and so jadiybN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaduwbN↓ and majoduwbN↓, (Ḳ,) the last derived from judiba though this verb has not been used, (TA,) and mujodibN↓, (M, A,) of which the pl. is majaAdiybu. (A.) You say also OaroDN jadobN [in which jdb is an inf. n. (though app. obsolete as such) and therefore applicable to a fem. subst.] (ISd, TA) and jadobapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jadibapN↓ (A, Mṣb) and jadiybN↓ (Mṣb) and jaduwbN↓ (Lḥ, M, Mṣb) and mujodibapN↓, of which last the pl. is majaAdiybu, (Mṣb,) A land affected with drought,, &c.: (Ṣ, M, A, &c.:) and OaroDuwna juduwbN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as though to each part were applied the term jadobN [used as a subst.] from which is formed the pl. juduwbN, (TA,) and jadobN, (Ḳ,) which is here an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore applicable to a pl. subst.], (TA,) lands affected with drought,, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And falaApN jadobaMCu↓ [fem. of Oajodabu] (M, Ḳ) A desert affected with drought,, &c.; (Ḳ;) in which is neither little nor much, neither pasture nor herbage. (M, TA.) And fulaAnN jadiybu↓ AljanaAbi Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought,, &c. (Ṣ. [But this phrase is generally used tropically, as meaning † Such a one is ungenerous or illiberal or inhospitable. See art. jnb.]) And sanapN jadobapN (Ḳ in art. jrz) and EaAmN jaduwbN↓ (M, TA) [A year of drought,, &c.]. See also OajaAdibu, in two places.
Also i. q. EayobN [A vice, fault, defect,, &c.]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a signification which may be either proper or tropical. (Er-Rághib, MF.)

entry.sense: OaroDN jadibapN: see jadobN.
Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jadabaAtK: see jacabaAt, in art. jcb.
jidab-N and jadobab-N: see jadobN.
jaduwbN: see jadobN, in three places.
jadiybN: see jadobN, in three places.

jaAdibN Finding fault, dispraising, expressing disapprobation: whence the saying of Dhu-rRummeh,
fayaA laka mino xad-K OasiylK w manoTiqK
raxiymK wamino xaloqK taEal-ala jaAdibuho
meaning [O thou smooth and even cheek, and gentle speech, and make] whereof he who dispraises it occupies himself vainly, finding no defect in it. (Ṣ, TA.)

It is also said [as in the Ḳ, &c.] to signify Lying; and the author of the ʼEyn says that it has no verb belonging to it [in this sense]; but this is a mistranscription [for xaAdibN]: AZ says that jaAdibN, with j, has the signification here first given. (M, TA.)
