junodabN and junodubN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and jinodabN, like dirohamN, (Sb, M, Ḳ,) the last of which is of weakest authority, because of a rare measure, whereof it has been said that there are only four examples: (TA:) in all of them the n is said by some to be radical; but others, with more reason, hold it to be augmentative: (MF:) Sb says that it is augmentative: (Ṣ:) A species of locust, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known: (Ḳ:) or the male locust: or small locust: or, accord. to Seer, i. q. SadFI [a kind of cricket], that creaks by night, and hops and flies: [but see SadFI:] or, accord. to the M, it is smaller than the SdI, and is found in the deserts: pl. janaAdibu. (TA.) Sr- Aljndb [i. e. Sar-a Aljunodabu The jndb creaked] is a saying of the Arabs, used as a proverb; alluding to a difficult affair by which a person is troubled in mind; originating from the fact that the jndb, when its feet are scorched by the heated ground, does not keep them steadily upon it, and a creaking sound is consequently heard, produced by its legs. (TA.)
Oum-u junodabK The sand; because the locust [or jndb] deposits its eggs therein: and the walker therein falls into evil [or encounters difficulty]. (TA.)

[Hence it signifies also] Misfortune: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and perfidy, or faithlessness, or treachery: (M, Ḳ:) and wrong, or injury: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and evil conduct, or ill treatment. (Ṣ.) You say, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI Oum-i junodabK Such a one fell into misfortune: or into perfidy. (TA.) And waqaEuwA fiI Oum-i junodabK They suffered wrong, or injury. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And waqaEa Alqawomu junodabK The people, or company of men, committed wrong, or injury, and slew him who was not a slayer: (TA:) [as though they came with violence upon sand in which eggs of the jndb were deposited, and so destroyed the eggs, which had occasioned them no harm.] And rakiba Oum-a junodabK He committed wrong, or injury. (TA.)
[Oajodabu i. q. jadobN as syn. with jadiybN: fem. jadoyaMCu. Hence,] falaApN jadoyaMCu: see jadobN.
[Hence also,] sanapN jadobaMCu A year of much snow. (L in art. Xhb.)

Oajodabu is [also] said in the M to be [used as] a subst. applied to what is termed mujodib [i. e. as syn. with the latter word used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; app. meaning A place, or the like, affected with drought,, &c.]. (TA.)
[Also, as a comparative and superlative epithet, meaning More, and most, affected with drought,, &c.; contr. of OaxoSabu.]

OajaAdibu, in a trad., where it is said, wakaAnato fiyhi OajaAdibu Oamosakati AlmaMCi, (Ḳ,* TA,) or wkAnt fiyhaA, (TA,) [And there were in it AjAdb that retained the water], is said to be pl. of OajodubN, which is pl. of jadobN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) like as OakaAlibu is pl. of OakolubN, which is pl. of kalobN; (TA;) and signifies hard parts of the ground, that retain water, and do not imbibe it quickly; or, as some say, land having no plants or herbage, from jadobN↓ meaning “drought”, &c.: the word is thus written in the two Saheehs, of El-Bukháree and Muslim: (IAth, TA:) but some say that it is an anomalous pl. of jadobN, like as maHaAsinu is of HusonN: and there are other readings; namely, OajaAcibu and OaHaAdibu and OaHaAzibu and OajaAridu, pl. of Oajoradu, and UixaAcaAtN, pl. of UixaAcapN. (MF, TA.)
mujodibN, and its fem. with p {mujodibapN}: see jadobN.
mijodaAbN Land scarely ever, or never, abundant in herbage, or in the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; scarcely ever, or never, fruitful, or plentiful. (Ḳ.)
majoduwbN: see jadobN.
8. Ajtdv He made, or prepared, a jadav, i. e., a grave, or sepulchre; or did so for himself. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

1. jadaHa, aor. _a {yajodaHu}, inf. n. jadoHN, He mixed anything. (L.) jadaHa Als-awiyqu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) wanaHowahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and jd-Hhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN; (L;) and AjtdHhu↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and AjdHhu↓; (Ḳ;) He stirred about the swyq [or meal made of parched barley or wheat], and the like, with water, [or milk, (see what follows,) or clarified butter, or fat of a sheep's tail, &c., (see lat-a,)] until the whole became of a uniform consistence: (L:) or he stirred it about with a mijodaH: (A, L:) or he stirred about the swyq in milk, and the like, with a mjdH, until it became mixed: (Lth, TA:) or he beat and mixed the swyq with a mjdH: (Mgh:) i. q. lat-ahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and jd-Hhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN, he mixed it; in the Ḳ, laTaxahu; but the right reading is xalaTahu, as in the L and other lexicons: (TA:) and AjtdHhu↓ he drank it (Xrbh [but this is perhaps a mistranscription for Darabahu he beat it]) with the mjdH. (L, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
4: see 1.
AHdH AlUibila He branded the camels on their thighs with the mark called mijodaH. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1, in two places.
AlmujodaHu: see the next paragraph.

mijodaHN The instrument with which sawiyq is stirred about with water, &c.; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.;) which is a piece of wood the end whereof has several sides; (Ṣ, L;) or a piece of wood at the head of which are two cross pieces of wood; (A, Mgh, L;) and sometimes having three prongs: (IAth, TA:) pl. majaAdiHu. (L.)
It is sometimes used tropically, as relating to evil, or mischief. (L.) [Thus it means ‡ A stirrer-up of evil or mischief; or a thing that stirs up, or whereby one stirs up, evil or mischief.]

Also † Any one of the majaAdiyHu Als-amaMCi [or stirrers-up of the sky, or of rain]; (L;) these being the OanowaMCN [or stars, or asterisms, which, by their auroral settings or risings, were believed by the Pagan Arabs to bring rain, &c.]; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) of those AnwAC that seldom or never failed [to bring rain], accord. to the Arabs: (Mgh:) the I in the pl. is added to give fulness to the sound of the kesreh; for the regular pl. is majaAdiHu, and the sing. of mjAdyH should by rule be mijodaAHN. (A, IAth, Mgh.) One says, Arosalati Als-amaMCa majaAdiyHuhaA (L) or majaAdiyHu Algayovi (A) † [Its stirrers-up, or the stirrers-up of rain, or the stars or asterisms which were the bringers of it, sent forth rain]. It is related of ʼOmar, that he ascended the pulpit to pray for rain, and, having only offered a prayer for forgiveness, descended; whereupon it was said to him, “Thou hast not prayed for rain;” and he replied, laqadi Qsotasoqayotu bimajaAdiyHi Als-amaMCi † [I have indeed prayed for rain by words which are the stirrers-up of rain]; making the prayer for forgiveness to be a prayer for rain, in allusion to a passage in the Ḳur, lxxi. 9 and 10; and meaning thereby to deny the efficacy of the AnwAC. (A,* Mgh,* L.) AlmijodaHu, also pronounced AlmujodaHu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) thus pronounced by El-Umawee, (Ṣ,) is moreover the name of † A particular star or asterism, one of those which the Pagan Arabs asserted to be bringers of rain: (L:) said to be Ald-abaraAnu [the Hyades; or the five chief stars thereof; or the brightest star thereof, a of Taurus]; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) [which is called by this name of AldbrAn] because it rises latterly [with respect to the Pleiades], (Ṣ,) or because it follows (yadoburu, i. e. yatobaEu,) the Pleiades: (T in art. dbr:) [whence] it is also called HaAdiI Aln-ujuwmi [“the urger of the stars,” properly, “with singing”], (Ṣ,) or HaAdiI Aln-ajomi [“the urger of the asterism,” meaning, “of the Pleiades”], and taAliI Aln-ajomi [“the follower of the asterism,” or, “of the Pleiades”], (Ḳzw,) and Alt-aAliI and Alt-aAbiEu [“the follower”]: (Sh:) or it is a small star or asterism, between AldbrAn and Alv-uray-aA [or the Pleiades]: (IAạr, Ḳ:) [perhaps meaning the four stars that are the chief stars of the Hyades exclusively of a Tauri:] or three stars, (Mgh, TA,) like the three stones upon which a cooking-pot rests, (TA,) likened to a three-pronged mijodaH; (Mgh, TA;) on the [auroral] rising of which, heat is expected: (TA:) the Arabs regarded it as one of the AnwAC which [by their auroral setting] foretokened rain. (IAth.) AlmijodaHaAni is a name by which some of the Arabs called † The two wings of AljawozaMC [or Orion]. (Sh, TA.)
mijodaHN also signifies † A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the thighs of camels. (Ḳ.)
mujad-aHN Beverage, or wine, (XaraAb,) stirred about: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, blood, when it is stirred about in the body of a gored animal by the goring horn. (L.)

majoduwHN Blood drawn from a vein, used in times of dearth, or drought, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the Time of Ignorance: (Ṣ:) or blood which was mixed with something else, and eaten in times of dearth: (TA:) or a kind of food of the Pagan Arabs, being blood obtained by opening a vein of a she-camel, which blood was received in a vessel, and drunk. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jadara, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoduru}, (TA,) He made a jidaAr [app. here meaning a wall of enclosure]; syn. Haw-aTa: (Ḳ:) or he built a jdAr: and he founded it. (Ḥam p. 818.)
He concealed himself by means of a jidAr [or wall]. (Th, Ḳ.)

judira, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. jadorN; (TA;) and jadara, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoduru}, inf. n. jadorN; (Lḥ, TA;) and jud-ira↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which last some disallow, because this form denotes repetition, and the verb signifies the having a disease that befalls but once in a man's life; (MF;) He (a man, Ṣ, or a child, A) had, or became attacked by, judariI- [or small-pox]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [And jadara AljudariI-u The small-pox came forth, or broke out; as in the TḲ: for its inf. n.] jadorN signifies the coming forth, or breaking out, of the judariI-. (Ḳ.)

jadura, aor. _u {yajoduru}, inf. n. jadaArapN, He, or it, was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (Ḳ.) You say, jadura bihi [and lahu] He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt,, &c., for it. (A.) [And jadura Oano yafoEala kacaA He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt,, &c., for doing such a thing. See jadiyrN.]
jadarahu He made, or called, (jaEala,) him, or it, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (Ḳ.)
2. jad-ara binaMCahu: see 8.
jud-ira: see 1.

entry.sense: 4. maA Oajodarahu biAlxayori [and liloxayori] How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, is he for what is good! or how worthy is he of what is good! (A.) And maA Oajodarahu Oano yafoEala celika, and Oajodiro bihi, How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet,, &c., is he for doing that! or how worthy is he to do that! (TA.) The usage of jadura, signifying “he was, or became, adapted, &c.,” refutes the assertion of certain grammarians that these two forms of the verb deviate from general rule. (MF.)

8. Ajtdr binaMCahu; and jd-rhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyrN (Ḳ) and mujad-arN; (TA;) He raised his building high; or constructed it firmly and strongly, and raised it high; syn. Xay-adahu. (Ḳ, TA.) [In the CK, we read Aijtadara binaAhu, as though the pronoun h referred to the word jidaAr, which precedes; and thus the verb signified “he built a wall;” but it is shown in the TA that the right reading is that given above.]

Q. Q. 1. janodara AlkitaAba He passed the pen over what had become obliterated, of the writing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order that it might become distinct. (Ṣ.) And jndr Alv-awoba He renewed the variegated, or figured, work of the garment, or piece of cloth, after it had gone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [J says,] I think it to be an arabicized word. (Ṣ)

The basis, or foundation, of a wall: (Ḳ:) and the side of a wall: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) pl., in both these senses, juduwrN. (TA.) Aljadoru is applied to The [wall called the] HaTiym (A, Ḳ) of the Kaabeh; (Ḳ;) because in it is a part of the [original] foundations of the house: (TA:) and it is also called AlHijoru. (A.)

† A fence, or dam, raised of branches, to retain water; likened to a wall: (Az, Mṣb:) or a fence, or dam, to confine water:
pl. juduwrN: (Suh, Mṣb:) and judurN, [which is also a pl.,] signifies fences, or dams, between houses, which retain water. (TA.)
[The pl.] juduwrN also signifies Gardens, or walled gardens, (HawaAYiT,) of grapes. (TA.)
jadarapN: see jadiyrapN

judariI-N and jadariI-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [Small-pox;] certain pustules (Mṣb, Ḳ) in the body, (Ḳ,) which break forth (Mṣb, Ḳ) from the skin, full of water, and afterwards opening, (Mṣb,) and generating thick purulent matter; (Ḳ;) a well-known disease, that attacks people once during life. (TA.)
judariI-u AlOaroDi ‡ an appellation applied to Truffles (kamoOap), denoting disapprobation. (TA from a trad.)
jidaArN: see jadorN: and see also jadiyrapN.

hom.sense: jadiyrN A place having a wall built around it; a walled place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also mujad-arN.

Also Adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; syn. xaliyqN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and HaqiyqN: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {jadiyrapN}: (TA:) pl. masc. jadiyruwna and judaraMCu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. fem. jadiyraAtN and jadaAYiru. (TA.) You say, huwa jadiyrN bikacaA (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and likacaA (TA) He is adapted, disposed, apt, meet,, &c., for such a thing; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) and [naturally] drawn to it. (Ḥam p. 707.) And Oanota jadiyrN Oano tafoEala kacaA Thou art adapted, disposed, apt, meet,, &c., for doing such a thing; or worthy to do it. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lamajodarapN↓ Oano yafoEala, (Ḳ,) and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more, (TA,) and majoduwrN↓, (Ḳ.) Verily he is one who is adapted, disposed, apt, meet,, &c., for doing [such a thing]; or worthy to do [it]; syn. maxolaqapN. (Ḳ.) [majodarapN↓ properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted, disposed, apt, meet,, &c.; like maxolaqapN and maHoraApN: and majoduwrN↓, Made, or called, adapted or disposed, &c., though said by Aboo-Jaạfar Er-Ru- ásee to be a pass. part. n. having no verb.] Also Uin-ahaA lamajodarapN↓ bicelika Verily she is one who is adapted, disposed, apt,, &c., for that: and biOano tafoEala celika for doing that: and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more. (TA.) And hecaA AlOamoru majodarapN↓ licaAka This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet,, &c., for that; syn. maHoraApN. (Ṣ.) And hecaA AlOamoru majodarapN↓ minohu This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet,, &c., for him to do; i. e. he is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for doing it. (TA.)

jadiyrapN An enclosure for camels, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and for lambs and kids and calves, &c., (TA,) made of masses of stone; (AZ, Ṣ;) as also jadarapN↓: (TA:) if of mud, or clay, it is called jidaArN↓: (AZ, TA:) or an enclosure (zarob) for sheep or goats. (TA.)
Nature; or natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property. (Ḳ)

entry.sense: huwa Oajodaru bihi He, or it, is more, or most, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, for it, or him; or he is more, or most, worthy of it. (A.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce xuT-apN.]

hom.sense: OaroDN majodarapN A land in which is HudariI- [or small-pox]: (Lḥ, Ṣ:) or a land in which is much thereof. (Ḳ.)
See also jadiyrN, in five places.

entry.sense: mujad-arN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and majoduwrN↓ (Mgh, Ḳ) and jadiyrN↓ (Mṣb, TA) Having the judariI- [or small-pox]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And majoduwrN↓ Alwajohi [Having the face marked with the smallpox]. (A.)

hom.sense: majoduwrN: see mujad-arN:
and see also jadiyrN, in two places.

1. jadaEa AlOanofa, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. _a {yajodaEu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jadoEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut off the nose; and in like manner, the ear; and the hand, or arm; and the lip; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and a similar part: (TA:) and OajodaEotu↓ Oanofahu signifies the same as jadaEotu [I cut off his nose]: or jadoEN signifies [absolutely] the cutting off; or cutting so as to separate. (TA.) In the following saying of a poet, the verb is used metaphorically,
waOaSobaHa Ald-ahoru cuw AlEironiyni qado judiEaA [lit. And nosed fortune became mutilated in the nose; meaning, † became marred]. (TA.) And in the following phrase, occurring in a verse, kaOan-a Qll-eha yajodaEu Oanofahu waEayonayohi, the poet means, [As though God cut off his nose] and put out his eyes: see a similar saying in art. qld, voce taqal-ada. (TA.)

jadaEahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He mutilated him, or maimed him, by cutting off his nose, or his ear, or his hand or arm, or his lip, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or the like; (TA;) as also jd-Ehu↓ (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence the phrase,] jadoEFA↓ lahu (Ṣ, Ḳ) [(May God decree) to him mutilation, or maining, by the cutting off of his nose, or the like; or cause it to befall him: or] meaning Oalozamahu Qll-ehu AljadoEa [† may God make injury, or diminution of what is good, to cleave to him]: (Ḳ:) said in imprecating a curse upon a man: similar to EaqorFA lahu, q. v.: the first word being governed in the accus. case by a verb understood. (TA.) One says also, AijodaEohumo biAlOamori Hat-aI yacil-uwA, a phrase mentioned by IAạr, but not explained by him; thought by ISd to mean, ‡ Act thou, in commanding, as though thou mutilatedst them by cutting off their noses [until they become submissive]. (TA.) In the phrase Sawotu AlHimaAri Alyujad-aEu↓ [The voice of the ass that has his ear, or ears, cut off, (see mujad-aEN, below,)], occurring in a verse of Dhu-l-Khirak Et-Tuhawee, (Ṣ,) accord. to J, but not found by Ṣgh in the verses of that poet, and said to be in the Book [of Sb], though IB denies this, asserting it to be in the Nawádir of AZ, (TA,) Akh says, the poet means Al-aciI yujad-aEu, like as you say, huwaQloyaDoribuka, meaning Al-aciI yaDoribuka: Aboo-Bekr Ibn-es-Sarráj says, the poet, requiring refa for the rhyme, has changed the noun into a verb; and this is one of the worst of poetic licences. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] Als-anapu tajodaEu Aln-abaAta ‡ [The year of drought cuts off, or destroys, the herbage]: (A, TA:) and tajodaEu biAlmaAli destroys the camels or the like. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And jad-aEa↓ AlqaHoTu Alnab-aAti ‡ The drought prevented the growth, or increase, of the herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence also,] jadaEa EiyaAlahu, inf. n. jad-aEN, † He withheld good things from his family, or household. (TA.) And jadaEatohu Oum-uhu, aor. _a {yajodaEu}, inf. n. as above, ‡ His mother fed him with bad food; (Zj, Ḳ;) as also OajodaEatohu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijodaAEN; (TA;) and jad-aEatohu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajodiyEN: (TA:) and jd-Ehu↓ and AjdEhu↓ ‡ He (a pastor) confined him [a beast] to bad pasture. (TA.) jadaEotuhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) also signifies † I confined him, restricted him, or the like; syn. Habasotuhu: and † I imprisoned him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and so with c: (Ṣ:) or jadoEN and jacoEN both signify † the confining, or restricting, a person with evil management, and with contemptuous treatment, and want of good care. (AHeyth.)

jadiEa, aor. _a {yajodaEu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jadaEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a man) was, or became, mutilated, or maimed, by the cutting off of his nose, or his ear, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the like: (TA:) or, accord. to some, you do not say jadiEa, but judiEa: (TA:) and jadiEati AlX-aApu The sheep, or goat, was, or became, mutilated by having its ears entirely cut off. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) [as though meaning † He was, or became, injured;] ‡ he (a child) had bad food: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and he (a young weaned camel) had bad food: or was ridden while [too] young, and in consequence became weak. (TA.)
2. jd-Ehu, inf. n. tajodiyEN: see 1, in five places.
jad-aEahu waXar-aAhu ‡ He made him to experience evil treatment, and derided him; as when one cuts off the ear of his slave, and sells him. (TA.)
Also He said to him jadoEFA laka [explained above; see 1]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) [See also Eaq-arahu.]

entry.sense: 3. jAdE, inf. n. mujaAdaEapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jidaAEN (Ḳ,) ‡ He reviled, being reviled by another, (Ḳ,* TA,) saying jadoEFA laka; as though each of them cut off the nose of the other: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) or accord. to some, (TA,) ‡ he contended in an altercation; as also tjAdE↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) [but the latter is said of a number of persons, &c.] You say, tarakotu AlbilaAda tajaAdaEu↓ OafaAEiyhaA, (Th, Ṣ,) and tajad-aEu↓ also, (Th,) ‡ I left the countries with their vipers eating one another; (Th, Ṣ;) not meaning eating in reality, but rending in pieces, or mangling, one another: (Th:) and EaAmN tajad-aEu↓ OafaAEiyhaA, and tajaAdaEu↓, ‡ A year in which the vipers eat one another, by reason of its severity. (Th.)
4: see 1, in three places.
5: see 3, in two places.
6: see 3, in three places.

hom.sense: jadoEN What is cut off of the anterior parts of the nose, to its furthest, or uttermost, part: (Aṣ, TA:) an inf. n. used as a [proper] subst. (TA.)
jadoEFA lahu: see 1.
‡ Unwholesomeness in herbage. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jadiEN ‡ A child having bad food; or fed on bad food: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pronounced by El-Mufaddal with c; but Aṣ repudiated to him this pronunciation; (Ṣ, TA:) and his objection was confirmed by a young man of the Benoo-Asad called in as an umpire. (TA.)

jadaEapN What remains, of the nose, ear, hand or arm, or lip, after the cutting off [of the rest]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the place of the cutting off thereof; like EarajapN from AlOaEoraju, and qaTaEapN from AlOaqoTaEu. (TA.)

jadaAEi (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.) and jadaAEN (Ḳ, TA) ‡ A year of drought; because it cuts off, or destroys, (tajodaEu,) the herbage, and abases men: (A, TA:) or a severe, or calamitous, year, that destroys the camels or the like; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or that destroys everything; as though it cut off its nose or the like. (L.)
See also judaAEN.
judaAEN ‡ Withered herbage: (Ṣ:) or herbage that is unwholesome to the feeder upon it: (Ḳ:) or tall, unwholesome, and withered. (TA.)
And hence, AljudaAEu signifies ‡ Death: (Ḳ, TA:) written by some AljadaAEu↓. (TA.)

OajodaEu Mutilated, or maimed, by having his nose cut off, or his ear, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the like: (TA:) fem. jadoEaMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and the latter, applied to a she-camel, having the sixth part of her ear, or the fourth part of it, or more than that, to the half, cut off; and to a she-goat, having a third part, or more, of her ear cut off; or, accord. to IAmb, any ewe or she-goat having the ear lopped; (TA;) or a ewe or she-goat having her ear entirely cut off: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and mujad-aEN↓ an ass having the ear cut off, (Ṣ,) or having the ears cut off. (Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., Oanofuka minoka waUino kaAna OajodaEa [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be cut off]: applied with reference to him whose good and evil attaches to thee though he be not firmly connected with thee by relationship. (TA.)
AlOajodaEu one of the appellations applied to The devil. (Fr, Ḳ.*)
mujad-aEN: see OajodaEN.
Also † A plant, or herbage, of which the upper part has been eaten: (Ṣ:) or of which the upper part and the sides have been partly cut off or eaten. (AḤn.)

hom.sense: 1. jadafahu, aor. _i {yajodifu}, (IDrd, Ḳ,) inf. n. jadofN, (TA,) He cut it; or cut it off: (IDrd, Ḳ:) and so jacafahu. (TA.)

jadafa, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajodifu}, (Ks, IDrd, Ṣ,) inf. n. juduwfN, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or jadofN, (L as on the authority of Ks,) He (a bird) flew [with his wings] clipped, appearing as though he turned his wings backward: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or contracted his wing somewhat, in order to descend in his flight, and then inclined, or declined, in fear of the hawk: (TA:) and he (a bird) went quickly, (Ḳ in art. jcf,) with his wings; generally when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Ajdf↓ and Anjdf↓: and so, all, with c. (Ḳ ib.)

[Hence,] jadafa Almal-aAHu biAlmijodaAfi [The sailor rowed, or paddled, with the oar, or paddle]. (AA, TA.) And jadafa biAls-afiynapi, (TA,) or jadafa Als-afiynapa, aor. _i {yajodifu}, inf. n. jadofN, (Mgh,) [He rowed, or paddled, the ship, or boat;] he put the ship, or boat, in motion with the mijodaf [or mijodaAf]. (Mgh.)

Also jadafa He (a man) swung the arms; (Ḳ, expl. by Daraba biAlyadayoni; in the O, biAlyadi, as is said in the TA;) as a man does in walking, moving them about: and the meaning seems to be, he walked quickly: (TA:) you say, jadafa fiI miXoyatihi he (a man) was quick in his manner of walking; (AAF, TA;) and so with c: (Ṣ in art. jcf:) or jadofN signifies a repeated interrupting of the voice (taqoTiyEu AlS-awoti) in singing to camels to urge or excite them. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jadafati Als-amaMCu biAlv-aloji The sky cast down snow: (Ḳ:) and so with c. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. jd-f, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tajodiyfN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He denied, or disacknowledged, favours, or benefits; or was ungrateful, or unthankful, for them: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he deemed the gifts of God small: (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he said that he was in an evil state when he was in a good state: (TA:) or he said, layosa liI walayosa EinodiI [app. meaning There is nothing due to me nor by me]; (Ḳ;) thus explained by Moḥammad on his saying that the worst of deeds is Alt-ajodiyf: (TA:) [accord. to Golius, he blasphemed; and identified by him, in this sense, with the Hebr. גִּדֵּף.] It is said in a trad., laA tujad-ifuwA biniEomapi Qll-ehi (Ṣ, TA) Deny not ye, or disacknowledge not, or be not ungrateful or unthankful for, the bounty of God, and deem it not small. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
AjdfwA They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1.

hom.sense: jadafN A grave; a sepulchre; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like jadavN; for the Arabs made f and v interchangeable: (Fr, Ṣ:) the former is of the dial. of Nejd; and the latter, of the dial. of Tihámeh: (Mṣb in art. jdv:) [accord. to some,] the former is formed from the latter by substitution [of f for v]: (Ṣ:) IJ argues that this is the case because the former has not OajodaAfN for pl.: (TA:) but it has this pl., (Fr, Ṣ, R, TA,) used by Ru-beh. (R, TA.)

Also, said in a trad. to be the beverage of the jinn, or genii, (Ṣ, TA,) Beverage that has not been covered [at night according to a precept of the Prophet]: (Ḳatádeh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of which the mouth of the skin containing it has not been tied [at night]: (Ḳ:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, the eater of which needs not to drink after it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, eaten by camels, which thereby become in no need of water: (M, TA:) or the froth, or floating particles, cast up by beverage; (El-'Otbee, Hr, Ḳ;) as though it were cut off from the beverage. (El-'Otbee, Hr, TA.)

entry.sense: jadafapN Cries, shouts, noises, clamour, or a confusion of cries or shouts or noises: and the sound made in running. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
jawaAdifu [pl. of jaAdifapN,] Gazelles going with short steps. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
Oajodafu Short: (Lth, Ḳ:) applied to a man. (TA.)
And [the fem.] jadofaMCu A ewe, or she-goat, having somewhat cut off from her ear. (Ḳ.)
mijodafN: see mijodaAfN.
mujad-afN Straitened: so in the saying, Uin-ahu lamujad-afN Ealayohi AlEayoXu [Verily the means of living are rendered strait to him]: (Ḳ:) but in the L, lamajoduwfN↓. (TA.)
mijodaAfN The wing of a bird: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) sometimes with c. (Mṣb.)

And hence, (Ḳ,) [An oar; a paddle;] a certain appertenance of a ship or boat; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a piece of wood at the head of which is a broad board, with which one propels a ship or boat; (M, TA;) and mijodafN↓ [signifies the same;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is put in motion: (Mgh:) pl. majaAdiyfu: (Mṣb:) from jadafa said of a bird: (Aṣ, Ṣ, M:) also called mijocaAfN (IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb) and miqocafN and miqocaAfN. (TA.)
And hence, as being likened thereto, ‡ A whip: and so with c. (TA in this art, and in art. jcf.)
And for a similar reason, ‡ The neck. (TA.)
majoduwfN A [skin of the kind called] ziq- having the legs cut off: and so with c. (Ḳ,* TA.) And majoduwfu Alyadayoni A man having the arms, or hands, cut off. (TA.)
And [hence,] the latter, † A niggardly man. (TA.)
And majoduwfu Alkum-ayoni, (Ḳ, TA,) and Alyadi, and AlqamiySi, and AlUizaAri, (TA,) † Short in respect of the sleeves, (Ḳ, TA,) and of the arm, and of the shirt, and of the waistwrapper. (TA.)
See also mujad-afN.

hom.sense: 1. jadalahu, aor. _u {yajodulu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yajodilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jadolN, (Ṣ,) He twisted it firmly; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a rope. (Ṣ.)
He made it firm, strong, or compact. (TA.)
[Hence,] jaAriyapN HasanapN Aljadoli † [A girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make]. (Ṣ.)

[Hence also,] Eamila EalaI XaAkilatihi Al-atiI judila EalayohaA † [He did according to his own particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, to which he was strongly disposed by nature]. (TA.)
See also 2.
jadala, inf. n. juduwlN, It (a thing) was, or became, hard, and strong. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jadala AlHab-u fiI Als-unobuli The grain became strong in the ears: (Ṣ. O, TA:) or accord. to the Ḳ, it means waqaEa [i. e., came into the ears]. (TA.)
jadala said of a young gazelle, &c., He became strong, and followed his mother. (Ḳ.) [See also jaAdilN.]
jadila, aor. _a {yajodalu}, inf. n. jadalN, [said in the Ṣ to be a subst. from 3, q. v.,] He contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, vehemently, or violently. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2. jd-lhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajodiylN, (Mṣb,) He threw him down (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) upon the jadaAlap, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., (TA,) upon the ground; (Ṣ, TA;) as also jadalahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jadolN: (TA:) or the former signifies he did so much, or often. (TA.) You say, TaEanahu fajad-alahu [He thrust him, or pierced him, with a spear or the like, and threw him down, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [See also 3.]

3. jAdlhu, inf. n. mujaAdalapN and jidaAlN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) He contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, with him: (Ṣ, TA:) or did so vehemently, or violently, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and ably, or powerfully: (Ḳ:) [or he did so obstinately, or merely for the purpose of convincing him; for] mjAdlp signifies the disputing respecting a question of science for the purpose of convincing the opponent, whether what he says be wrong in itself or not: (Kull p. 342:) [he wrangled with him:] or jAdl, inf. n. mjAdlp and jdAl, as above, signifies originally he contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, by advancing what might divert the mind from the appearance of the truth and of what was right: and accord. to a later usage, of the lawyers, he compared evidences [in a discussion with another person, or other persons,] in order that it might appear which of those evidences was preponderant: and the doing this is commendable if for the purpose of ascertaining the truth; but otherwise it is blameable: (Mṣb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, jdAl signifies the competing in disputation or contention, and in striving to overcome [thereby]; from jadalotu AlHabola, meaning, “I twisted the rope firmly;” as though each of the two parties twisted the other from his opinion: or, as some say, it originally means the act of wrestling, and throwing down another upon the jadaAlap [or ground]: accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, a disputing that has for its object the manifesting and establishing of tenets or opinions. (TA.) [See also jadila.]
4. Ajdlt She (a gazelle) had her young one [sufficiently grown to be] walking with her. (Zj, Ḳ.)
5: see 7.
6. tjAdlwA The contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, [or did so vehemently, or violently,, &c., (see 3,)] one with another. (KL, MA, &c.,)
7. Anjdl He fell down upon the ground: (Ṣ:) he became thrown down upon the jadaAlap, i. e., the ground; and in like manner tjd-l↓, he became thrown down,, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

8. AijotidaAlN The act of building, or constructing. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says,
majaAdila Xad-a Alr-aASifuwna QjotidaAlahaA . (Ṣ, TA) i. e. [Pavilions of which the masons have made strong] the building, or construction. (TA.)
[Q. Q. 1. jadowala He ruled a book with lines; such as are ruled round a page, &c. See jadowalN.]
Also, and jidolN↓, A strong, firm, or compact, penis. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or the former, (Ṣ, TA,) Any member, or limb: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. juduwlN. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or the former, (TA,) Any complete bone, [app. with its flesh,] not broken, nor mixed with aught beside:pl. [of pauc.] OajodaAlN and [of mult.] juduwlN. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or [the pl.] juduwlN, (Lth, TA,) The bones of the arms and legs (Lth, Ḳ, TA) of a man: (Lth, TA:) and of the fore and hind legs of the victim termed Eaqiyqap. (TA from a trad.)
jidolN: see jadolN.

jadalN Vehemence, or violence, in altercation or disputation or litigation; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and ability, or power, to practise it: (Ḳ:) [or simply contention in an altercation; disputation; or litigation:] a subst. from jaAdalahu: (Ṣ:) or inf. n. of jadila [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)

Hence, as a term of logic, A syllogism composed of things well known, or conceded; the object of which is to convince the opponent, and to make him to understand who fails to apprehend the premises of the demonstration. (TA.)

hom.sense: jadilN: see jadolN.
jadolaMCu fem. of Oajodalu.
Also syn., in two senses, with jadiylapN, which see, in two places.

entry.sense: jadowalN A rivulet; a streamlet; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [whether natural, or formed artificially for irrigation; being often applied to a streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench, or gutter;] it is less than a saAqiyap; and this is less than a nahor: (Mgh in art. saqI:) as also jidowalN: (Ḳ:) pl. jadaAwilu. (Mṣb.)

Hence, AisotaqaAma jadowaluhumo ‡ Their affair, or case, was, or became, in a right, a regular, or an orderly, state; like the jdwl when its flow is uniform and uninterrupted. (TA.) And AisotaqaAma jadowalu AlHaAj-i † The caravan of the pilgrims formed an uninterrupted line. (TA.)
[Hence also jadowalN as meaning † A kind of small vein. (Golius from Ibn-Seenà.)]
Hence also jadowalu kitaAbK † [A ruled line, (such as is ruled round a page, &c.,) and a column, and a table, of a book]. (TA.)
jadiylN applied to a rope, Firmly twisted; as also majoduwlN↓. (TA.)

A camel's nose-rein (Ṣ, Ḳ) of hide, or leather, (Ṣ,) firmly twisted: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a cord of hide, or leather, or of [goats'] hair, [that is put] upon the neck of the camel: (Ḳ:) and the [kind of women's ornament termed] wiXaAH (Ṣ, Ḳ) is sometimes thus called: (Ṣ:) pl. judulN. (Ḳ.)
jadaAlapN The ground: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or hard ground: (TA:) or ground having fine sand. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jadiylapN A rahoT, [q. v.,] i. e., (TA,) a thing like an Uitob, of hide, or leather, which boys, and menstruous women, wear round the waist in the manner of an UizaAr. (Ḳ, TA.)

A [tribe, such as is termed] qabiylap: and a region, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so jadolaMCu↓, in both these senses, as used in the phrase, hecaA EalaI jadolaAYihi [This is according to the way of his region, and of his tribe]. (TA.) You say also, cahaba EalaI jadolaAYihi↓, in the Ḳ, erroneously, jadolaAnihi, (TA,) i. e., ElI wajohihi [He went his own way], (Ḳ, TA,) and naAHiyatihi [towards his region, or quarter, or tract]. (Ḳ.)
A state, or condition. (Ḳ.)

‡ A particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct; syn. XaAkilapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and TariyqapN. (Ḳ.) You say, Eamila EalaI jadiylatihi, i. e. [He did according to his own particular way,, &c.; or] Eamila EalaI XaAkilatihi Al-atiI judila EalayohaA [explained above: see 1]. (TA.)
‡ A determination of the mind. (TA.)
† The management, or ordering, of a people's affairs; the exercise of the office of Eariyf. (AA, TA.)

entry.sense: jaAdilN A boy becoming, or become, strong; vigorous, or robust. (Ṣ.)
A she-camel's young one above such as is termed raAXiH, which is such as has become strong, and walks with his mother- (Aṣ, Ṣ.) [See also jadala.]
janodalN and junodalN:, &c.: see art. jndl.

hom.sense: Also, [accord. to most of the grammarians OajodalN, but accord. to some Oajodalu,] The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OajodaliI-N↓: (Ḳ:) or an epithet applied to the hawk [and therefore without tenween]: (TA:) pl. OajaAdilu. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OajodaliI-N: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: mijodalN A qaSor [or palace, or pavilion,, &c.,] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA [in the CK AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqaSoru]) strongly constructed: (TA:) pl. majaAdilu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jadilN.
mijodaAlN A piece of rock or stone: [an oblong roofing-stone, of those which, placed side by side, form the roof of a subterranean passage,, &c.:] pl. majaAdiylu. (TA.)
See also jadilN.

entry.sense: majoduwlN: see jadiylN. [Hence,] diroEN majoduwlapN ‡ A compact coat of mail; (Ṣ, TA;) as also jadolaMCu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of the latter] judolN. (Ḳ.)

‡ A man (Ḳ, TA) of slender make, (TA,) slender in the [bones called] qaSab, of firm, or compact, make (muHokamu Alfatoli [as though firmly twisted]): (Ḳ, TA:) or slender, slim, thin, spare, lean, or light of flesh; not from emaciation: (Ṣ:) and majoduwlu Alxaloqi, as some say, of firm, or compact, make. (TA.)
And majoduwlapN † A woman small in the belly, and compact in flesh: (A in art. fyD:) or majoduwlapu Alxaloqi a girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make; syn. Hasanapu Aljadoli. (Ṣ.) Also saAEidN Oajodalu↓ † [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] of firm, or compact, make. (Ḳ,* TA.) And saAqN majoduwlapN and jadolaMCu↓ ‡ [A shank of beautiful compacture;] well rounded; well turned; syn. Hasanapu AlT-aI-i. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jadaA Ealayohi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jadaAhu, first pers. jadawotu, (IB, TA,) aor. _u {yajoduwu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jadowN (Mṣb, TA) and jadFA; (Mṣb;) and AjdI↓ Ealayohi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AjdAhu↓, (Ṣ,) the prep. in the former of these two being suppressed in the latter; (TA;) and AjtdAhu↓; (TA;) He gave him a gift. (Ṣ, IB, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.)

Hence also, AjdI↓ Ealayoka ‡ It (a thing) sufficed thee. (Mṣb.) maA OajodaI↓ fiEoluhu XayoYFA ‡ His deed, or act, did not profit him, or avail him, aught. (Mṣb.) And maA yujodiI↓ Eanoka hecaA † This does not stand thee in any stead; does not profit thee, or avail thee. (Ṣ.)

jadawotuhu, (Ṣ, IB, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) [aor. _u {yajoduwu},] inf. n. jadowN; (Ḳ;) and jadayotuhu; (Ḳ in art. jdI;) and Aijotadayotuhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and Aisotajodayotuhu↓; I sought, or demanded, (Ṣ,) or asked, (IB, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of him (Ṣ, IB, Mṣb, Ḳ) a gift, (Ṣ,) or a thing wanted. (Ḳ.) [See an ex. of the last of these verbs in a verse cited in art. tA.] Hence, mujaAdaApN [inf. n. of jAdI↓]: whence, in a trad., waqado EarafuwA Oan-ahu layosa Einoda marowaAna maAlN yujaAduwnahu Ealayohi, meaning yasoOaluwnahu Ealayohi [i. e. And they knew that there was not, in the possession of Marwán, property for which they should ask as owed by him]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in five places.
Also AjdI, He obtained a gift. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: jadFA i. q. jadowaI, q. v.

Hence, (Ḥar p. 32,) jadFA, (Ḳ,) also written jadFI, (ISk, TA,) or maTarN jadFA, (Ṣ,) and, accord. to the Ḳ, jadowaI↓, but this latter is not known except as signifying “a gift,” (TA,) A common, or general, rain; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) of wide extent: (TA:) or of which the uttermost is not known. (Ḳ.) One says also samaMCN jadFA, meaning A rain having a rain following it; making the latter word masc. because it has the force of an inf. n. (TA.) And Aal-ehum-a QsoqinaA gadaqFA wajadFA TabaqFA [O God, water us with a copious rain, and a rain that shall cover the land]: (Ṣ, TA:) occurring in a trad. respecting prayer for rain. (TA.)
And xayorN jadFA Ample good; (Ḳ;) of wide extent to men. (TA.)
laA Mtiyka jadaA Ald-ahori (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) i. e. [I will not come to thee] ever, like yada Ald-ahori; (Ṣ, TA;) or to the end of time. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: jadowaI A gift; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jadFA↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) dual (of the former, TA) jadowaAni and jadoyaAni; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) the former, regular; (M, TA;) the latter, anomalous, (M, Ḳ, TA,) formed by commutation. (M, TA.) You say, maA OaSabotu mino fulaAnK jadowaI qaT-u [I have not obtained from such a one a gift ever]. (TA.) And hence the prov., Xagalato XiEaAbiI jadowaAIa: see art. XEb. (Ṣ in that art.)
See also jadFA.
jadaMCN profit, utility, or avail. (Ṣ, TA.) So in the saying, fulaAnN qaliylu AljadaMCi Eanoka [Such a one is of little profit, utility, or avail, to thee; will stand thee in little stead]. (Ṣ.)
jadiI-N [originally jadiywN] Munificent, or bountiful. (TA.)
jaAdK Asking, seeking, or demanding, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a bounty, or benefit, (Ṣ,) or gift: (Ḳ:) pl. judaApN. (TA.)
OajodaI [More, and most, profitable, useful, or availing]. It is said in a prov., OajodaI mina Algayovi fiI OawaAnihi [More profitable than rain in its season]. (Meyd.)

hom.sense: 1. jadayotuhu: see 1 in art. jdw.
One says of the locust, yajodiI kul-a XaIoCK, meaning It eats everything. (TA.)
lamo Oajodi mino celika bud-FA I found no means of avoiding, or escaping, that, is sometimes said for lamo Oajido Alx. (Ḳz, TA in art. wjd.)

entry.sense: 2. jd-I Alr-aHoli, inf. n. tajodiyapN, He made, or put, to the camel's saddle a [jadoyap or] jadiy-ap. (TA.)
4. AjdI It (a wound) flowed [with blood: see jadiy-apN]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jadoIN A kid: (Ṣ:) or a male kid; (IAmb, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the female being called EanaAqN: (IAmb, Mṣb:) or a kid in his first year; (Mgh, Mṣb;) not yet a year old: (TA:) one should not say jidoIN; (Ṣ;) this being a bad dial. var.: (Mṣb:) pl. (of pauc., TA, applied to three, Ṣ) OajodK (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of mult., TA, applied to more than three, Ṣ) jidaMCN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jidoyaAnN: (Ḳ:) jadaAyaA [as pl. of jadoI] is not allowable. (Ṣ.)

Hence, as being likened thereto, (M, TA,) AljadoIu † A certain star, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [the star a of Ursa Minor, commonly called the pole-star,] that revolves with banaAtu naEoXK, (Ḳ,) by the side of the [north] pole, by which the kibleh is known, (Ṣ,) or according to which the kibleh is turned; (Mṣb;) the bright star at the extremity of the tail of the Lesser Bear; (Ḳzw;) the star of the kibleh; (Mgh;) also called jadoIu Alfaroqadi; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and called by the astronomers AljudaI-u↓, in the dim. form, to distinguish it from what next follows. (Mgh, MF.) [See also AlquTobu.]

Hence also, (M, TA,) A certain sign of the Zodiac; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [namely, Capricornus;] the tenth of the signs of the Zodiac; (Mgh;) that next to the dalow; unknown to the Arabs [of the classical times]. (Ḳ.) This and the former together are called [the] jadoyaAni. (TA.)
jadoyaAni is also an anomalous dual of jadowaI, q. v. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jadoyapN and jadiy-apN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but not jadiydapN, which is used by the vulgar, (Ṣ,) [A kind of pad, or] a stuffed thing, (Ṣ,) or a stuffed piece (Ḳ, TA) of a kisaMC, (TA,) that is put beneath a horse's saddle, (Ḳ,) or beneath the two boards (Ald-af-ataAni) of a horse's and of a camel's saddle; [one on either side; for] there are two of such stuffed things: (Ṣ:) the pl. of the former is jadayaAtN, (Sb, Ṣ,) which may be used as a pl. of mult., (TA,) or jadoyaAtN, so in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, [but omitted in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,] following the TṢ, as on the authority of AʼObeyd and AA and En-Naḍr, (TA,) and jadoIN↓; (Ṣ, IB, [in some copies of the Ṣ jadFA, but the former (which I find in two copies of the Ṣ) is said by IB to be the right; or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,]) like as XaroIN is of XaroyapN: (IB, TA:) the pl. of jadiy-apN↓ is jadaAyaA. (Ṣ.) [See also jadiydapN, and rifaAdapN.]

judaMCN, (Ḳ in this art.,) or jucaMCN, (A in art. jcr, and Ḳ in art. brj,) [the latter is the term commonly known, An arithmetical square;] the product of multiplication [of a number by itself]; as when you say, the jdAC [or jcAC] of three [in some copies of the Ḳ, of three multiplied by three,] is nine; (Ḳ,* TA;) also called maAlN. (Mṣb in art. jcr.) [See jacorN.]
Aljuday-u: see jadoIN.

jadaAyapN and jidaAyapN A young gazelle; syn. gazaAlN: (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ:) or a young doegazelle; syn. gazaAlapN: (so in another copy of the Ṣ:) said by Aṣ to be like the EanaAq of goats: (Ṣ:) or the male, and the female, of the young of gazelles, when it has attained the age of six months, or seven, and has run, and become strong: or, as some say, the male thereof: pl. jadaAyaA. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: jadiy-apN: see jadoyapN, in two places.

Also Flowing blood; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) blood not flowing being termed baSiyrapN: (Lḥ, TA:) or the former, blood adhering to the body; and the latter, blood upon the ground: (AZ, Ṣ:) or the former, a streak of blood: (Ṣ:) or the first quantity that flows at once, of blood: (TA:) pl. jadaAyaA. (Ṣ.)
A piece of musk. (Ḳ.)
The colour of the face. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, AiSofar-ato jadiy-apN wajohihi [The colour of his face became yellow]. (TA.)

I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract;, &c.]. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, huwa EalaI jadiy-atihi [app. meaning He is keeping to his own side: he is following his own course; like the phrase huwa EalaI Tariyqatihi: or he is by himself; like huwa EalaI waHodihi and Hidatihi]. (TA.)

entry.sense: jaAdK The locust; because it eats (yajodiI, i. e. yaOokulu) everything: but the appellation [more] commonly known is jaAbiYu. (TA.)

jaAdiI-N [erroneously written in the CK, in this art. and in art. jwd, without the sheddeh to the I] Saffron; (Az, IF, Ḳ;) as also jaAdiyaMCu↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) the former a rel. n. from AljaAdiyap, or jaAdiyap, a town of AlbaloqaMC, in Syria, said to produce saffron: it is mentioned by Az and IF in this art., being held by them to be of the measure faAEuwlN [originally jaAduwIN]: by J, in art. jwd, as being of the measure faEoliI-N. (TA.)
Also ‡ Wine; (Ḳ, TA;) as resembling saffron in colour. (TA.)
jaAdiyaMCu: see what next precedes.

1. jac-ahu, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajocucu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. jac-N, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut it, or cut it off; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as, for instance, a rope: (L:) or he cut it off utterly; (L, Ḳ;) and jacojacapN [inf. n. of jacojaca↓] signifies the same as jac-N, i. e. the cutting off utterly: (Ḳ:) and AijoticaAcN [inf. n. of Ajtc-↓], the act of cutting: (KL:) or jac-ahu signifies he cut it off utterly and quickly; and in like manner jc-chu↓ [applied to many objects, or as meaning he cut it,, &c., repeatedly, or many times, or in many pieces, or much]. (L.) [Hence,] jac-a Aln-axola,, aor. _u {yajocucu}, inf. n. jac-N and jacaAcN and jicaAcN, He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Sarama: (Lḥ, L:) or, accord. to some, jcAc signifies the cutting off of all fruits, and jdAd relates particularly to palmtrees. (TA in art. jd.) [Hence also,] juc-uwhumo jac-FA, in a trad. relating to the battle of Honeyn, † Cut ye them off utterly; exterminate them by slaughter. (L.)

Also, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajocucu}, (L,) inf. n. jac-N, (L, Ḳ,) He broke it; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or a hard thing: (M, L:) and AijoticaAcN [inf. n. of Ajtc-↓], also, signifies the act of breaking. (KL.)

Also, (L,) inf. n. jac-N, (L, Ḳ,) He hastened it; or hastened to it. (L, Ḳ.*) It is said in a prov., respecting one who boldly ventures upon taking a false oath, jac-ahaA jac-a AlEayori AlS-il-iyaAnapa He hastened to it as the ass hastens to the plant called Sl-yAnp. (L.)
2: see 1.
5: see 7.

7. Anjc- It became cut, or cut off: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and in like manner, tjc-c↓ [said of a number of things, or used in a frequentative or an intensive sense; being quasi-pass. of 2]. (L.)
8: see 1, in two places.
R. Q. 1. jacojaca, inf. n. jacojacapN: see 1.
jac-N A piece broken off; a fragment: pl. OajocaAcN: so in the phrase, kasarotuhu OajocaAcFA [I broke it in pieces, or fragments]; occurring in a trad., relating to an idol. (L.) [See also jucaAcN.]
maA Ealayohi juc-apN There is not upon him a piece of rag; i. e., any garment to cover him: (L:) or anything (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) of clothing: (Ṣ, L:) pl. jucacN. (Bḍ in xxi. 59.)
jicacN: see jucaAcN.

hom.sense: See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jucaAcN and jicaAcN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, (Ṣ, L,) and jacaAcN↓, (L, Ḳ,) substs. from jac-N the act of “breaking; “(Ḳ;) What is broken, of, or from, a thing: (Ṣ, L:) or what is broken, or cut, in pieces: or broken pieces: so in the Ḳur xxi. 59, in which the word is read in these three different forms: (L:) some also read jucucFA, which is pl. of jaciycN↓; and some, jucacFA, pl. of juc-apN: (Bḍ:) or the first signifies fragments of a thing much broken; [as a coll. gen. n.;] and the n. un. is jucaAcapN↓: (Lth, L:) [or] it is an extr. pl. of jaciycN↓; (L;) or i. q. majocuwcN; and jicaAcN↓ is a dial. var.; or is pl. of jaciycN↓. (Bḍ.) [See also jac-N.]
Also the first, Small pieces, or particles, of silver: and jucaAcaAtN↓, pieces of silver: (L:) or the latter, cuttings, or clippings, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of silver. (M and L in art. qc.)
Also Stones containing gold; (Ks, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) so called because they are broken: (Ks, Ṣ, L:) or stones containing gold, &c. which are broken; as also jicaAcN↓. (Mṣb.)
And jcAc [app. jucaAcN or jicaAcN↓], (L,) or jicacN↓, (TA,) i. q. firaqN [Distinct parties, or portions,, &c., of men or things]. (L, TA.)
jicaAcN: see jucaAcN, in four places.

jaciycN and majocuwcN↓ Cut; or cut off: or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and also broken: (L:) pl. of the former, jucucN and jicaAcN (Bḍ in xxi. 59) and jucaAcN, which last is extr. (L. See the paragraph headed jucaAcN, in three places.)

Also the former, (A, Ḳ,) and XaraAbN jaciycN, (A,) and jaciycapN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) Meal of parched barley or wheat; syn. sawiyqN; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) so prepared [by being moistened with water or with clarified butter, &c.] as to be drunk: (A:) and jcycp↓ is [a mess of the kind called] jaXiyXap made of coarse swyq; so called because it is broken and made into coarse particles: and a quantity of swyq, or the like, such as a man eats or drinks at one time. (L.)
jacaAcapN: see jacaAcN.
jucaAcapN and its pl. jucaAcatN: see jucaAcN, in two places.
jaciycapN: see jaciycN, in two places.
yado jac-aMCu [fem. of Oajac-u] ‡ An amputated arm or hand: used figuratively: see OaHac-u, in art. Hc. (L.)

raHimN jac-aMCu † A bond of relationship [cut, or severed, or] not made close by affection; expl. by UicaA lamo tuwSalo [a well-known phrase: erroneously explained by Golius as meaning “uterus infœcundus vel interruptæ conceptionis”]: (Fr, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) as also Hac-aMCu. (Fr, Ṣ, L.)
yamiynN jac-aMCu: see Hac-aMCu.
sin-N jac-aMCu A tooth much broken; or broken in pieces. (Ḳ, TA.)

jac-aAnN (Aṣ, L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ: in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, juc-aAnN:) Soft stones: (Aṣ, L, Ḳ:) as also kac-aAnN [q. v.]: (Aṣ, L:) n. un. (of both, Aṣ, L) with p {jac-aAnapN}. (Aṣ, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: majocuwcN: see jaciycN.
EaTaMCN gayoru majocuwcK [A gift, or stipend,] not cut short, or not interrupted; syn. gayoru maqoTuwEK. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L.)

1. jacabahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajocibu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jacobN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also jabacahu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jabocN, of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) or formed by transposition; (Ṣ, TA; [but see art. jbc;]) and Ajtcbhu↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) He drew it; dragged it; pulled it; tugged it; strained it; extended it by drawing, or pulling or tugging; stretched it; extended, lengthened, or protracted, it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; and sometimes relating to an ideal object. (TA.)

jacaba mina AlUinaMCi, (Ṣ,) or jacaba mina AlmaMCi, (Ḳ,) or jacaba AlmaMCa, (A, Mṣb,) nafasFA, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or nafasayoni, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) ‡ He drank (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the vessel, (Ṣ,) or of the water, (Ḳ,) by putting his mouth into it, [a draught, or two draughts:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he conveyed [or drew up] into the innermost parts of his nose [a draught, or two draughts, of the water]. (Mṣb.) And jacabato labanahaA ‡ She (a camel) drank her milk when she was milked. (A. [But see what next follows {3}: and see also 5.])

jacabato, said of a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a she-ass also, aor. _i {yajocibu}, inf. n. jicaAbN, (TA,) † She became scant of milk; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) she drew her milk (jacabato labanahaA) from her udder so that it went away upwards. (TA.)

jacabahu, (Ḳ,) or jacabahu Eano Oum-ihi, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _i {yajocibu}, inf. n. jacobN, (TA,) ‡ He weaned him; namely, a colt, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a young camel, and a lamb. (TA.) And one says of a mother, jacabato waladahaA ‡ She weaned her young one: so accord. to Lḥ, who does not specify the kind. (ISd, TA.) And accord. to the T, juciba is said of a child, or of a lamb or kid, meaning ‡ He was weaned. (TA.)
jacabahu and jaAcabahu↓ He transferred, or removed, it (a thing) from its place. (Ḳ.)

jacabatohu ‡ She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage; (T, A, TA;) as though from the saying jaAcabotuhu fajacabotuhu [which see below]; (T, TA;) [i. e.] as though she contended with him and overcame him, and thus he became separated from her; (T, A, TA;) as also jabacatohu. (T, TA.) [Accord. to the TA, jaAcabatohu↓ has the same meaning; but I think that this is a mistake of a copyist.]
jacaba fulaAnN Habola fulaAnihi † Such a one severed the bond of his union. (M, TA.) And jacaba fulaAnN AlHabola bayonanaA ‡ Such a one severed the bond of union between us. (A, TA.)
jacaba Aln-axolapa, aor. _i {yajocibu} (AḤn, Ḳ,) inf. n. jacobN, (AḤn, TA,) He cut off the jacab [q. v.] of the palm-tree, (AḤn, Ḳ,) to eat it. (AḤn, TA.)
jacaba AlEadowa † He ran quickly. (L in art. mEd.) See also 7.
jacab AlX-ahoru, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajocibu}, inf. n. jacobN, (TA,) ‡ The greater part of the month (EaAm-atuhu, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, i. e. Oakovaruhu, TA) passed. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

jacabahu, aor. _u {yajocubu}, He overcame him in AlmujaAcabap (Ḳ) [lit. drawing, dragging, pulling,, &c.; (see 3;) but also] used figuratively [as meaning ‡ he overcame him in contention]. (TA.) You say, jaAcabotuhu↓ fajacabotuhu [I contended with him in drawing, dragging,, &c., and I overcame him therein: and also] ‡ I contended with him and I overcame him. (T, A,* TA.)

entry.sense: 3. jAcbhu He contended with him in drawing, dragging, pulling or tugging, straining, or stretching,, &c. (L in art. md.) And jAcbhu AlHabola [He contended with him in pulling the rope]. (Mgh in art. nzE.) And jAcbhu Alv-awob He contended with him in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) And jAcbwA AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. mujaAcabapN, They pulled the thing, every one of them to himself. (Mṣb.) And jaAcabotuhu fajacabotuhu: see 1, last sentence: [a phrase having two meanings: for] you say, jaAcabaA, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. mujaAcabapN (TA) and jicaAbN, (Ḥar p. 636,) meaning † They two contended [in any manner], each with the other: (Ḳ, TA:) and [in like manner,] tjAcbA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajaAcabN, (Ṣ,) † They two contended together. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) You say also, kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAcabaAtN vum-a Qt-afaquwA ‡ [There were contentions between them: then they agreed]. (A, TA.) And jaAcabotuhu AlX-aIoCa † I contended with him for the thing. (Ṣ.)
See also 1, in two places, beside the instance in the last sentence.
5. tjc-bhu ‡ He drank it; (A, Ḳ;) namely, milk: said of a pastor. (A.)

6. tjAcbwA Alv-awoba They contended together in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) [Hence,] tjAcbwA OaToraAfa AlkalaAmi ‡ [They contended together in discourse, talk, or conversation]. (A.) See also 3.
And see 7.

7. Anjcb It (a thing) was, or became, drawn, dragged, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched,, &c.; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. Anjr-. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. jr.)
It was, or became, transferred, or removed, from its place; and so tjAcb↓. (Ḳ.)

AinojicaAbN also signifies † Quick going or journeying or travelling. (Ṣ.) [You say, Anjcb, and jacaba↓ Als-ayora, (the latter occurring in the TA in art. xlj, &c., like jacaba AlEadowa, mentioned above, see 1,) † He went, or journeyed, or travelled, quickly.] And AnjcbwA fiI Als-ayori and Anjcb bihimu Als-ayoru ‡ They brought, or purveyed, wheat, or corn, or provisions, from afar. (A, TA.)
8. Ajtcbhu: see 1.
Also He seized it, or took it, or carried it off, by force. (Ḳ, TA.)
And † He called, summoned, or invited, him. (Ḥam p. 645.)
jacobN † Quick journeying or travelling. (ISd, Ḳ.)
And The stopping, or a stoppage, of the flow of saliva (AinoqiTaAEu Alr-iyqi). (Ṣ.)

jacabN The pith that is at the head of the palmtree, from which the [fibres called] liyf are pulled off, and which is then eaten; as though so called because pulled off [or cut] from the tree; (TA;) the heart, pith, or cerebrum, (jum-aAr,) of the palm-tree; (AḤn, Ṣ, TA;) so in some copies of the Ḳ; (TA;) i. e. the XaHom of the palm-tree: (Ṣ:) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the M and L, only such as is coarse: (TA:) as also jicaAbN↓: (Ḳ:) n. un. jacabapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also jacamapN.]
jacobapN mino gazolK A portion that is drawn by a single pull of spun thread, or yarn. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] maA OaEoTaAhu jacobapa gazolK ‡ He gave him not aught. (A, TA.)

bayoniI wabayona Almanozili jacobapN † Between me and the place of alighting is a piece [of land or country, or a tract], meaning a distance: (Ṣ:) or a far-extending piece [of land or country]. (Ḳ.) And bayonanaA wabayona baniI fulaAnK jacobapN, and nabocapN, † Between us and the sons of such a one is a small space, or short distance; i. e., they are near to us. (ISh, TA.)

Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jacabaAtK [He took his way into the valley of Jedhebát]: (Ḳ:) or, as given by Meyd, [and in the A,] waqaEuwA [they fell into the valley of Jedhebát]: a celebrated prov.: (TA:) applied to a man who has missed the object of his aim or pursuit; (Ḳ,* TA;) jcbAt being said to be derived from jacaba AlS-abiI-a “he weaned the boy;” because, in weaning, a child sometimes dies: or from AinojacabuwA fiI Als-ayori, or Ainojacaba bihimu Als-ayoru, explained above: or, accord. to some, the right reading is jadabaAtK: or, as Az says, on the authority of Aṣ, the most correct reading is xadibaAtK, from xadabatohu AlHay-apu “the serpent bit him;” and the prov. is applied to him who falls into perdition, and to him who wanders in perplexity from the object of his aim or desire. (TA.) [See also another reading in art. xrb.]

jicib-aAnN The sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, maA OagonaI EaniI jicib-aAnFA He did not stand me in stead of, or avail me as much as, a sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (AA, TA.)
jacaAbi, indecl., [as a proper name, changed in form from AljaAcibu,] (TA,) Death: (ISd, Ḳ:) so called because it draws away the soul. (ISd, TA.)
jicaAbN: see jacabN.
jacuwbN: see jaAcibN.
jac-aAbapN Hairs, (TA,) or coarse hairs, or a coarse hair, (Ḳ,) tied, and made into a snare, (TA,) for catching larks. (Ḳ, TA.)

jaAcibN ‡ A she-camel that has exceeded the usual time of pregnancy, and passed beyond the time [of the year] when she had been covered: (Lḥ, TA:) or a she-camel that has extended, or protracted, the period of her pregnancy to eleven months. (A, TA.) † A she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a she-ass, (TA,) scant of milk; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also jaAcibapN and jacuwbN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. [of the first and second] jawaAcibu and jicaAbN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

juwcaAbN (M, Ḳ) and cuwbaAjN, the latter formed by transposition, (L and TA in art. cbj,) A kind of food, prepared with sugar and rice and flesh-meat: (M, Ḳ:) [from the Persian kuwcaAbo, as observed by Golius:] it might be hastily imagined to be arabicized from juwzaho Mbo; but this is not the case: (TA:) [n. un. with p {juwcaAbapN}: or] juwcaAbapN is a cake of bread (xubozapN) put into the oven (tan-uwr), and having suspended over it a bird or some flesh-meat, the gravy of which flows upon it as long as it is cooking; also called Oum-u Alfaraji, because it removes one's anxiety for seasoning, or condiment. (Ḥar p. 227.)

1. jacara, (A, TA,) aor. _u {yajocuru}, (TḲ,) inf. n. jacorN, (A, Ḳ,) He cut, or cut off, or severed, (Ḳ, TA,) a thing: (TA:) and (Ḳ) he extirpated, or cut off entirely, (A, Ḳ,) a thing; (A;) as also jc-r↓; (Ṣ;) and Ajcr↓, inf. n. UijocaArN. (AZ, Ḳ.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1.
7. Anjcr It became cut, or cut off, or severed. (Ḳ, TA.)

jacorN (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jicorN↓ (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) The root, or lower part, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of anything: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A:) or (so in the Ḳ, but in other lexicons “and”) particularly, of the tongue: (Sh, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and of the penis: (Sh, Ḳ:) and of a horn (Ṣ,* A) of a cow (Ṣ) or of a bull; (A;) or the horn [itself] of a cow: (TA:) and the latter word, the root, or foot, or lowest part, of a tree: (TA:) and the former word, the base of the neck: (El-Hejeree, Ḳ:) pl. jucuwrN. (Ḳ.) Hence, nazalati AlmaHab-apu fiI jacori qalobihi Love took up its abode in the bottom (OaSol) of his heart. (A.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., Uin-a AlOamaAnapa nazalato fiI jacori quluwbi Alr-ijaAli [app. meaning, Verily reason, or intellect, or rather conscience, each of which is a trust committed by God to man, and a faculty which renders him responsible for his faith and works, (see, in art. Amn, an explanation of OamaAnapN as used in the Ḳur xxxiii. 72,) hath taken up its abode in the bottom of the hearts of men]. (Ṣ.)
Also, both words, The origin, or stock, from which one springs. (TA.)

And the former, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the latter, or the latter only, (Ḳ,) or the former only, (IAạr, TA,) A root of a number; (A;) an arithmetical root; (Mgh, Ḳ;) [a square root;] a number that is multiplied by itself; (Mṣb;) as when you say that ten multiplied by ten is a hundred; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and three multiplied by three is nine; (A;) in the former of which cases, ten is the jcr, (Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e., the jcr of a hundred; (Mgh;) and in the latter, three; (A;) and in each case, the [square or] product of the multiplication is called the maAl, (Mṣb,) or the jucaMC, (A,) or the majcuwr↓: (Mgh:) [pl. of pauc. OjocaArN, and of mult. jucuwrN.]
It is of two kinds, naATiqN [i. e. rational], and OaSam-u [i. e. surd, or irrational]: the latter known only to God, accord. to a saying of ʼÁïsheh. (Mgh.)
jicorN: see jacorN.

juWocarN and juWocurN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juwcarN and jawocarN and jaWocarN and jiycarN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) the last of which is written in some copies of the Ḳ [and in the CK] jayocarN, (TA,) The young one of a wild cow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the first and second, jaMciru. (Ṣ.) ISd thinks that jawodarN and jiycarN are Arabic, and that juWocarN and juWocurN are Persian. (TA.) See also mujocirN.
jiycarN or jayocarN: see what next precedes.

mujocirN A wild cow having a young one. (ISd, Ḳ.) Hence we decide that the C in jWcr↓ is augmentative; and because it often occurs as an augmentative in the second place. (ISd, TA.) [In the Ṣ it is regarded as a radical.]
majocuwrN: see HacorN.

4. AjcE, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijocaAEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He (a beast) became such as is denoted by the term jacaEN; (TA;) said of the offspring of the sheep or goat, he became in his second year; of that of the cow, and of a solidhoofed beast, he became in his third year; and of that of the camel, he became in his fifth year: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but sometimes, when said of the offspring of the ewe, it means he became six months old, or nine months old; and such is allowable as a victim for sacrifice: (Ṣ:) IAạr says, it denotes a time, not a tooth (Mgh, Mṣb) growing or falling out: (Mṣb:) and said of a she-goat, AjcEt means she became a year old, and sometimes, less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; and of a sheep, AjcE means, when from young parents, he became from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents, from eight months old to ten. (Mgh, Mṣb.) [See jacaEN, below.]
6. tjAcE ‡ He (a man) pretended to be a jacaE [or youth]. (TA.)

jicoEN The trunk of a palm-tree: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord to some, only after it has become dry: or, accord. to some, only after it has been cut: (TA:) or the trunk of a tree when the head has gone: (Ḥam p. 656:) in the Ḳur, xix. 23, it is applied to the trunk of a palm-tree which had become dry and was without a head; (Bḍ;) therefore this does not indicate any restriction nor the contrary: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OjocaAEN (Mṣb) and [of mult.] jucuwEN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
The beam of a roof. (Mṣb, TA.)

jacaEN A beast (Lth, Mgh) before the vaniI- [q. v.], (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by one year; when it may for the first time be ridden and used: (Lth:) fem. with p {jacaEapN}: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. masc. [of pauc.] OjocaAEN (Yoo, O) and [of mult.] jucoEaAnN (Yoo, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jicoEaAnN (L, Mṣb) and jicaAEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jucaAEN; (Yoo, O;) and pl. fem. jacaEaAtN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) it is a name applied to the beast in a particular time, not denoting a tooth growing or falling out: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but it differs in its application to different kinds of beasts: (Az:) applied to a sheep or goat, it means a year old; (IAạr;) in his second year: (Mgh:) or, applied to a sheep, a year old; and sometimes less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; (IAạr;) or eight months old, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or nine; (TA;) or, when from young parents, from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents from eight months old to ten; (IAạr, Mgh;) and the sheep thus called is a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh, TA:) and applied to a goat, a year old; (Az, Mgh;) or in its second year; (AZ;) but the goat thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh:) applied to a bull, it means in like manner in his second year; (Mgh;) or in his third year; and the bull thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (TA:) applied to a horse, it means in his third year; (IAạr;) or in his fourth year: (Mgh:) [but see qaAriHN:] and applied to a camel, in his fifth year; (Az, Mgh;) fem. with p {jacaEapN}; and this (a jcEp) is what must be given for the poor-rate when the camels are more than sixty. (Az, TA.) [See also XaSarN.]
A youth, or young man. (Ḳ.)

† One who is light-witted, or weak and stupid, like a youth: opposed in this sense to baAzilN as meaning “old:” (IAạr, TA:) or one whose teeth have fallen out, here and there, [as though likened to a beast thus termed that has shed some of his first teeth,] because he has drawn near to his appointed term of life. (TA: [but it is not quite clear whether this explanation relate to jcE or to bAzl.])
‡ [A novice, or recent beginner.] You say, fulaAnN fiI hecaA AlOamori jacaEN ‡ [Such a one, in this affair, is a novice, or recent beginner,] when he has begun it recently. (Ṣ, Z.)
Ald-ahoru jacaEN OabadFA ‡ Time, or fortune, is ever new, like a youth. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Hence, (TA,) AlOazolamu AljacaEu ‡ Time, or fortune; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the saying, Oaholakahumu AlOazolamu AljacaEu ‡ Time, or fortune, destroyed them; and laA Mtiyka AlOazolama AljacaEa ‡ I will not come to thee ever. (TA.) [See also art. zlm.] And accord. to some, (Ṣ,) The lion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but this is a mistake. (IB, L.)
And hence, (TA,) Oum-u AljacaEi ‡ Calamity, or misfortune. (Ḳ, TA.)

OaEadotu AlOamora jacaEFA ‡ I renewed the thing, or affair, as it was at the first: as, for instance, a war which had been extinguished. (TA.) And far-a AlOamora jacaEFA [signifies, in like manner, ‡ He recommenced the thing: or] he commenced the thing. (TA.) And fur-a AlOamoru jacaEFA ‡ The thing was commenced: (TA:) or the thing returned to its first state; it recommenced. (Ḳ in art. fr.)
jucoEaAnu AljibaAli † Small mountains. (Ḳ.)
jucuwEapN [The state of being what is denoted by the term jacaEN;] a subst. from UijocaAEN [inf. n. of AjcE]. (TA.)

jacoEamapN Young; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) not arrived at puberty: (TA:) originally jacoEapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the m being augmentative: (Ṣ:) the p is either to give intensiveness to the meaning, or to denote the fem. gender; the word being considered as implying the meaning of nafosN or juv-apN. (TA.)

xaruwfN mutajaAciEN [A lamb approaching the age in which the term jacaEN is applied to him: expl. in some copies of the Ḳ by daAnK: in others, by waAnK:] in the copies of the O, expl. by waAnK mina AlUijocaAEi: in the TṢ and in the A, by daAnK, which is probably the right reading. (TA.)
jacoEamapN: see art. jcE.

hom.sense: 1. jacafahu, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajocifu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jacofN, (AA, Ṣ,) He cut it; or cut it off: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so with d. (TA.)

jadafa said of a bird, a dial. var. of jadafa: (Ṣ:) both signify He (a bird) went quickly (Ḳ, TA) with his wings; generally, when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Ajcf↓ and Anjcf↓: and so, both of these, with d. (Ḳ.)
[Hence, jacafa biAlmijocaAfi; and jacafa biAls-afiynapi, or Als-afiynapa; i. q. jadafa, q. v.]

jacafa fiI miXoyatihi He (a man) was quick in his manner of walking: (AO, Ṣ:) and so with d: (AAF, TA in art. jdf:) as also tjc-f↓. (TA.) And jacafato She (a woman) walked like those that are short: and she (a gazelle, and a woman, TA) went with short steps; as also Ajcft↓: and so, both, with d. (Ḳ.)
jacafati Als-amaMCu biAlv-aloji The sky cast down snow: and so with d. (TA.)
jacafa AlX-aIoCa i. q. jacabahu. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1.
7: see 1.
mijocaAfN, (Ṣ, TA,) in the Ḳ mijocaAfapN↓, but the former is the more proper, (TA,) i. q. mijodaAfN; (Ṣ;) The wing of a bird: and so with d. (Mṣb in art. jdf.)
And [hence, An oar; a paddle;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is propelled. (Ṣ,* TA.)
And hence, as being likened thereto, A whip: (Abu-l-Ghowth, Ṣ:) and so with d. (TA in art. jdf.)
majocuwfN A [skin of the kind called] ziq- having the legs cut off: and so with d. (Ḳ * and TA in this art. and in art. jdf.)
mijocaAfapN: see mijocaAfN.

hom.sense:
1. jacala, (aor. _u {yajoculu} TK,) inf. n. jucuwlN, It stood erect, and was firm, (Ḳ, TA,) like the jicol of a tree. (TA.) And He set himself up as an antagonist to others, in fight. (TA in art. Hk.)
And said of a chameleon, It became erect; as also Astjc↓. (TA.) You say also, baAta yasotajocilu↓ EalaI Zahori daAb-atihi ‡ He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Ajclhu He made him joyful, glad, or happy. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
10: see 1, in two places.
jacolN: see what next follows, in two places.

jicolN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jacolN↓ (Ḳ) The trunk, stem, stump, or lower part, (OaSol) of a tree, &c., after the branch or the like has gone;pl. [of pauc.] OajocaAlN and [of mult.] jicaAlN and jucuwlN and jucuwlapN, (Ḳ,) which last is pl. of jacolN: (TA:) or a large trunk, or lower portion, of a tree; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) pl. OajocaAlN: (Ṣ:) and a branch, or piece of wood, like the fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] EaAda UilaI jacolihi↓ [or jicolihi] † He returned to his original state, or condition. (TA.)

Also, the former, A post, or piece of wood, that is set up (Ṣ, Ḳ) in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, (Ṣ,) for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) Hence, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the saying of El-Hobáb Ibn-El-Mundhir, (Ṣ,) OanaA jucayoluhaA↓ AlmuHak-aku waEucayoquhaA Almuraj-abu † [I am their much-rubbed little rubbing-post, and their propped little palm-tree loaded with fruit, or their honoured little palmtree, &c.: see art. rjb]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) i. e., I am of those by means of whose counsel, or advice, people seek relief, like as the mangy camels seek relief from their mange by rubbing themselves against the post above mentioned, (TA,) and one having a family that will aid and defend me: (TA in art. rjb:) the dim. is here used for the purpose of aggrandizement. (Ḳ. [See also art. Hk.]) And hence, (TA,) huwa jicolu maAlK ‡ He is a gentle manager of cattle: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) likened to the jicol that is set up. (TA.) One says also, Uin-ahu jicolu rihaAnK, i. e., SaAHibuhu [app. meaning, † Verily he is one who is constantly engaged in contending for stakes, or wagers; rhAn being here an inf. n. of raAhana; not a pl. of rahonN; for if it were the latter, the explanation would be SaAHibuhaA]. (Ḳ.)
A small quantum of property, or a small number of cattle; (Ḳ;) as though it were the original stock thereof. (TA.)
The summit, or head, of a mountain; and a prominent portion thereof: pl. OjocaAlN. (Ḳ.)
The side of a sandal. (Ḳ.)
jacilN: see what next follows.

jacolaAnu [in copies of the Ḳ with tenween, but correctly without tenween, for the fem. is jacolaMCu,] Joyful, glad, or happy; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jacilN↓; (Ḳ;) and jaAcilN↓ occurs in poetry: (IDrd, Ḳ:) pl. jucolaAnN. (Ḳ.) You say, nafosuhu jacolaMCu bicelika His soul is joyful, glad, or happy, by means of that. (TA.)

hom.sense: jaAcilN [part. n. of jacala] † Erect, in his place, not moving therefrom; likened to the jicol that is set up in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (Ṣ.) You say, baAta jaAcilFA EalaI Zahori daAb-atihi ‡ He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.)
See also jacolaAnu.

1. jacamahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajocimu} (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and _u {yajocumu} also, (accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) inf. n. jacomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut it off; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so jc-mhu↓: (Ḳ:) or jc-m signifies he cut off many things; or cut off much, or frequently: and jacomN signifies also the cutting off quickly. (TA.) [It is like xacamahu.] You say, jacama yadahi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajocimu}, inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) He cut off, or amputated, his arm, or hand; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AjicmihA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UijocaAmN. (TA.)
[Hence,] jacama fulaAnN Habola wiSaAlihi ‡ Such a one severed the bond of his union; as also jacabahu. (TA.)

jacima, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yajocamu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jacamN, He (a man) had his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated; was maimed of it. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, maA Al-aciI Ojocamahu↓ Hat-aI j-cima [What is it that has maimed him of his arm, or hand, so that he has become maimed of it?] (TA.)
And jacimiti Alyadu, aor. _a {yajocamu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jacamN, (Mṣb,) The arm, or hand, was cut off, or amputated. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
jucima He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, affected, or smitten, with the disease termed jucaAm. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.

UijocaAmN also signifies The being quick in pace, or going. (Lth, TA.) You say, Ajcm fiI sayorihi, (Ṣ,) or Ajcm Als-ayora, (Ḳ,) He (a camel, Ṣ) hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Ajcm said of a horse, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and the like, of such as run, (Lḥ, TA,) He ran vehemently. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
Ajcm Eani AlX-aIoCi He abstained, or desisted, from the thing. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
Ajcm He decided, determined, or resolved, upon it. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 7.

7. Anjcm It was, or became, cut off; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tjc-m↓: (Ḳ:) [or the latter is said of a number of things; or implies muchness, or frequency:] the two verbs are syn. [respectively] with AinoqaTaEa and taqaT-aEa. (TA.)

[Hence] you say, Anjcm Eani Alr-akobi † He was, or became, cut off from the company of riders upon camels. (TA.) And En-Nábighah says,
Sad-ato sulayomaI waOamosaI HaboluhaA QnojacamaA
[Suleymà has turned away, and the bond of her union with me has become severed]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jacomN: see the next paragraph.
Also A cessation of the supply of corn or other provision. (TA.)
A rope cut off, or severed. (TA.)
A man whose extremities have fallen off in pieces, piece after piece, in consequence of the disease termed jucaAm. (TA; but in this last sense, the word is there written without any syll. signs.)

entry.sense: jicomN The root, source, origin, or original, or the fundamental or essential or principal part, syn. OaSol, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) whatever that thing be; (TA;) as also jacomN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OajocaAmN and [of mult.] jucuwmN. (Ḳ.)

The family of a people; their kinsfolk: whence the saying, in a trad., lamo yakuno rajulN mino qurayoXK Uil-aA lahu jicomN bimak-apa [There was not a man of Kureysh but he had kinsfolk in Mekkeh]. (TA.) [And app. The main stock from which tribes are derived: for,] accord. to some, it ranks before XaEobN. (TA voce baTonN.)

The places [or place] of growth of the teeth. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh, (TA,)
AaloMna lam-aA QboyaD-a masorubatiI
waEaDiDotu mino naAbiI EalaI jicomi , (Ṣ, TA,) [Now, when the hair in the middle of my bosom, extending downwards to my navel, has become white, and I have bitten upon the place of growth of my canine tooth]: i. e., I have become old, and eaten upon the jcm of my nAb. (TA.)
The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of a wall: (Mgh from a trad.:) or the remains thereof: or a portion thereof. (TA.)
See also jicomapN.
jacimN Quick; swift. (Ḳ.)
jacomapN The place of the arm, or hand, where it is cut off, or amputated; as also jacamapN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jucomapN The defect, or deficiency, of him who has had his arm, or hand, amputated, or who has lost the end-joints of his fingers: so accord. to the copies of the Ḳ: but in the L, the defect, or deficiency [resulting] from the amputation of the arm or hand (mina AlUijocaAmi.) (TA.)
maA samiEotu lahu jucomapF, with damm, meaning [I heard him not utter] a word, is not of established authority. (ISd, TA.)

entry.sense: jicomapN A piece cut off (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a rope, &c., (Ṣ,) or of a thing of which the extremity has been cut off, the lower, or principal, part remaining; (Ḳ;) as also jicomN↓. (TA.)
A whip: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because it becomes cut by that which is beaten with it. (TA.)

The part of a whip of which the slender extremity has become much cut [by use], the lower, or principal, part remaining; pl. jicamN: (L, TA:) or the remaining part of a whip; its lower, or principal, portion. (Aṣ, TA.)
A thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not; [i. e. a brand, or fire-brand;] like jicowapN. (AO, Ṣ and TA in art. jcw.)
† A company of men [as though cut off from others]. (TA.)
jacamapN: see jacomahN.
Also The uppermost pith of the palm-tree; which is the best; (Ḳ;) like jacabapN. (TA.)
And Dates that come forth upon one base. (TA.)

jucaAmN [Elephantiasis; a species of leprosy; the leprosy that pervaded Europe in the latter part of the Middle Ages;] a certain disease, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) arising from the spreading of the black bile throughout the whole person, so that it corrupts the temperament of the members, and the external condition thereof; and sometimes ending in the dissundering, or corrosion, (so accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, TA,) of the members, and their falling off, in consequence of ulceration; (Ḳ, TA;) so called because it dissunders the flesh, and causes it to fall off; (Mṣb;) or because the fingers, or toes, become cut off: (TA:) it is a cracking of the skin, and a dissundering, and gradual falling off, of the flesh. (Mgh.)
nawFI jacuwmN A tract towards which one journeys separating lovers or objects of love. (TA.)
jaciwmN Cut off; amputated. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) [See also Oajocamu.]
jucaAmapN What remains, of seed-produce, after the reaping. (Ṣ.)
[See also juraAmapN, in two places.]
jac-AmN [an epithet] of the measure faE-aAlN from Aljacomu meaning AlqaToEu: so in the phrase jac-aAmu Haboli AlhawaI [Wont to sever the bond of love], in a verse of Ows Ibn-Thaalabeh. (Ḥam p. 334.)

hom.sense: Oajocamu Having his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or having lost the endjoints of his fingers: (Ḳ:) fem. jacomaMCu: (Mṣb:) pl. jacomaI. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad., mano taEal-ama AlquroMna vum-a nasiyahu laqiIa Qll-eha yawoma AlqiyaAmapi wahuwa Oajocamu, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,*) i. e., [He who learns the Ḳur-án and then forgets it shall meet God on the day of resurrection] having his arm, or hand, cut off: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or having lost all his limbs, or members: (Ḳṭ, TA:) or † having his plea cut off; having no tongue with which to speak, nor any plea in his hand: (IAth, TA:) or † having his means of access cut off: (TA:) or † with his hand devoid of good and of recompense. (IAạr, El-Khaṭṭábee, TA.) And in another trad., kul-u xuTobapK layosa fiyhaA XahaAdapN kaQloyadi AljacomaMCi [Every oration from the pulpit in which there is not an acknowledgment of the unity of God and of the mission of Moḥammad is like the arm of which the hand is amputated]. (TA.)

Alk-f-u AljacomaMCu [The amputated hand;] † a name of the star a of Cetus; (so in the Egyptian Almanacs;) [i. e.] the star that is in the head of Cetus: so called because it is less extended [from the Pleiades] than that called Alkaf-a AlxaDiybu. (Ḳzw. [See Alkaf-u AlxaDiybu in art.xDb.])
naEolN jacomaMCu † A sandal of which the [thong called] qibaAl [which is between two of the toes] is cut, or cut off, or severed. (TA.)
See also majocuwmN.
mujac-amN: see majocuwmN.
Also A man tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs. (TA.)
