entry.sense: rajulN mijocaAmN and mijocaAmapN↓, [the latter of a very rare measure, (see miEozaAbapN,)] † A man who decides affairs. (Ḳ.) ‡ A man who, loving and being loved, when he is sensible of evil treatment quickly cuts the tie of affection: (A, TA:) or the latter, ‡ a man who quickly cuts the tie of love, or affection. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) rajulN mijocaAmu Alr-akoDi fiI AlHarobi † A man quick in running, or fleeing, in war. (TA.) And rajulN mijocaAmapN↓ liloHarobi, and lils-ayori, and lilohawaI, † A man who desists from, and relinquishes, war, and journeying, and love, or natural desire. (Lḥ, TA.)

majocuwmN A man (Ṣ, Mṣb) affected, or smitten, with the disease termed jucaAm; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also mujac-amN↓ (Ḳ) and Oajocamu↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) which J erroneously disallows: (Ḳ:) J says, one does not say Ojocamu: (TA:) [and Fei,] they say that Oajocamu, of the measure of OaHomaru, is not said in this sense. (Mṣb.)
mijocaAmapN: see mijocaAmN, in two places.
jacomaArN or jidomaArN: see what follows, in two places.
jucomuwrN The root, or lowest part, of a thing: or the first thereof; (Ḳ;) the beginning, or commencement, and fresh state, thereof; its first and fresh state. (TA.)

A piece, or portion, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the lowest part (Ṣ) of a palm-branch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e. a stump thereof,] remaining upon the trunk when the [rest of the] branch has been cut off; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jacomaArN↓, (Ṣ,) or jicomaArN. (Ḳ.) [Accord. to the Ṣ, the m is an augmentative letter.]
The stump of a [tree of the kind called] naboEap, remaining when the tree has been cut down. (TA.)

The stump of a hand of which the greater part has been cut off; (TA;) what remains of a hand that has been amputated, at the extremity of the two bones of the fore arm. (T, TA.) One says, Darabahu bijucomuwrihi and biqaTaEatihi [He struck him with the stump of his amputated hand]. (TA.)
What remains of anything that has been cut off. (IAạr, TA.)
[Pl. jacaAmiyru.]

You say, Oxacahu bijucomuwrihi † He took it altogether; (Ḳ;) as also Axch bijacaAmiyrihi: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he took it in its first and fresh state: and Fr also mentions the phrases Axch bijicomiyrihi↓ and bijicomaArihi↓. (TA.)
Oaxacahu bijicomiyrihi: see what next precedes.

1. jacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajocuwu}, (TA,) inf. n. jacowN and jucuw-N, (Ḳ,) It (a thing, TA) stood firmly; as also AjcI↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, jacaA EalaI XaIoCK He [or it, for instance, a stone of those (three in number) upon which a cooking-pot is places, as is implied in the Ṣ, (see jaAcK,)] remained firm upon a thing. (Ṣ.) And jacaA AlquraAdu fiI janobi AlbaEiyr The ticks stuck, and clave, to the side of the camel: (ISd, Ḳ, TA:) and jcA biAljamali clung to the camel. (TA.)

I. q. javFA [He sat upon his knees;, &c.]; (AA, Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AijocawaI↓, [in form] like AiroEawaI; (TA;) except that jcA is more indicative of keeping to a place: (Kh, TA:) or he stood upon the extremities of his toes: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Th, jucuw-N is [the standing] upon the extremities of the toes; and juvuw-N is [the sitting] upon the knees: (TA:) and accord. to IAạr, jaAcK↓ means [a man standing] upon his feet; and jaAvK, [one sitting] upon his knees. (Ṣ, TA.) Accord. to El-Ḥasan Ibn-ʼAbdAllah El-Kátib El-Iṣbahánee, jacaA, inf. n. jucuw-N, said of a bird, means He stood upon the extremities of his toes, and warbled, and went round in his warbling; which he does only when seeking the female: and said of a horse, it means he stood upon his toes; and in like manner when said of a man, whether for dancing or for some other purpose. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, En-Noamán Ibn-Nadleh, (TA,)
UicaA XiYotu gan-atoniI dahaAqiynu qaroyapK
waSan-aAjapN tajocuw EalaI Harofi manosimi
[When I will, the husbandmen of a village sing to me, and a female player with the cymbals, standing upon the extremity of a toe]. (Ṣ, TA: but in the latter, EalaI kul-i manosimi [upon every toe].)
Also, inf. n. jucuw-N, He, or it, was, or became, erect, and straight; (TA;) and so AijocawocaI↓, inf. n. AijociycaMCN. (Az, TA.) See jawaAci as applied to she-camels, in two places, voce jaAcK.
It (a camel's hump) bore fat [so that it became elevated]. (Ḳ.)
jacaA manoxiraAhu His nostrils were, or became, raised and extended. (TA.)

Er-Rá'ee, describing a strong, or sturdy, she-camel, says,
lamo yajocu mirofaquhaA fiI Ald-afi mino zawari
meaning Her elbow did not stand out far from the side by reason of [the distortion termed] zawar. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AjcI: see 1, first sentence.

Also He (a young camel) bore fat in his hump. (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ.) El-Khansà says,
yujociyna nay-FA walaA yjociyna qirodaAnaA
They bear fat [in their humps], and have not ticks clinging to them. (IB, TA.)

He lifted a stone, (AA, Ṣ, TA,) in order that he might know thereby his strength. (TA.) One says, humo yujocuwna HajarFA wayatajaAcawonahu↓ [They lift a stone, in order to prove their strength, and vie, one with another, in lifting it, for that purpose]. (TA.) tajaAcK↓, in the lifting of a stone, is like tajaAv: (Ṣ, TA:) tajaAcawoA meaning taraAbaEuwA liyarofaEuwhu [They vied, one with another, to lift the stone, for trial of strength]. (TA.)
AjcI Tarofahu [in the CK, erroneously, Tarafahu,] He raised his eye, or sight, and cast it before him. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see 4, in two places.
9. AijocawaI: see 1.
12. AijocawocaI: see 1.

jicowapN and jucowapN and jacowapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [A brand, or fire-brand;]
i. q. jicomapN, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. a thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not: (AO, Ṣ, in explanation of the first:) or a thick piece of fire-wood, not flaming: (AO, TA, in explanation of jicowapN mina Aln-aAri:) or a thick stick, one end of which is a live coal: (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA:) or a thick stick upon which fire is taken [by kindling one end]: (ISk, TA:) and a piece (qabosapN, Ḳ, or qiToEapN, Ḥar p. 471) of fire: (Ḳ, Ḥar:) or a portion of fire-wood that remains after flaming: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and a live coal: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a flaming live coal: (Mṣb:) or jicowapN mina Aln-aAri means a piece of live coal; so in the language of all the Arabs: (Mujáhid, Ṣ, TA:) pl. [of the first] jicFI and [of the second] jucFI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the third, TA) jacFI (Mṣb, TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ) and jicaMCN, (AAF, Ḳ,) which is held by ISd to be a pl. of the third. (TA.)
jucaMCN: see judaMCN, in art. jdI.

jaAcK [part. n. of 1; fem. jaAciyapN: pl. masc. jicaMCN; pl. fem. jaAciyaAtN and jawaAcK]. A rájiz says, (Ṣ,) namely, ʼAmr Ibn-Jebel-El-Asadee, (TA,)
lamo yuboqi minohaA sabalu Alr-acaAci
gayora OavaAfiI mirojalK jawaAciI
i. e. [The continual fine rain left not thereof save the three stones that were the supports of a cooking-pot] remaining firm. (Ṣ, TA.)

I. q. jaAvK [Sitting upon his knees;, &c.]: (Fr, TA:) or sitting upon his heels, with his feet upright, [resting] upon the extremities of his toes: (Ṣ:) or standing upon the extremities of the toes: (AA, Ṣ:) see also 1: pl. [masc.] jacaMCN. (Ṣ) Aboo-Duwád describes mares as jaAciyaAtN EalaI Als-anaAbiki, i. e. Standing upon the toes. (AA, Ṣ,* TA.)

jawaAcK, (Ḳ,) applied to she-camels, (TA,) means That bear themselves erect (tajocuw↓) in their course, or pace, as though they lifted their feet clear from the ground; (Ḳ, TA;) on the authority of Aboo-Leylà: (TA:) [the last words of the explanation in the Ḳ are kaOan-ahaA taqolaEu: in the TA, kAnhA tqlE Als-ayora: I suppose that Als-ayora is for fiI Als-ayori; and that the pret. of the aor. here used is qaliEa; for qaliEN, which is of the regular form of a part. n. of such a verb as qaliEa, means “raising the feet clear from the ground in walking, &c.:” but in one copy of the Ḳ, I find tuqal-Eu: and another reading in some work seems to be tuqoliEu; for] ISd says, I know not jacaA with the meaning of OasoraEa n or of OaqolaEa: and Aṣ says that jawaAcK means quick, or swift, camels, that do not stretch themselves forth in their course, or pace, but bear themselves erect (yajocuwna↓ wayanotaSibona). (TA.)

mujocK [act. part. n. of 4]. mivolu AlOarozapi Almujociyapi EalaI AlOaroDi, (Ṣ,) or kaAlOarozapi Almjcyp ElI wajohi AlArD, (TA,) occurring in a trad., (Ṣ, TA,) describing the unbeliever, (TA,) means [Like the pine-tree] that is firm (Ṣ, TA) and erect [upon the ground]. (TA.)

mujocawocK [in the CK, erroneously, AlmajocuwociI-u,] Keeping constantly to the dwelling, or to the camel's saddle and the dwelling, (Alr-aHol and Almanozil, AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) not quitting it: (AA, Ṣ:) like mujocawocK EalaI Alr-aHoli. (AA, Ṣ)
And A man who lowers, or abases, himself; (El-Hejeree, ISd, TA;) as though he clave to the ground by reason of his abjectness; from jacaA AlquraAdu fiI janobi AlbaEiyri [q. v.]. (ISd, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jar-a, aor. _u {yajoruru}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. jar-N; (Ṣ Ḳ;) and jr-r↓, inf. n. tajoriyrN (Ṣ Ḳ) [and app. tajir-apN, said in the TA to be of the measure tafoEilapN from Aljar-u], with teshdeed to denote repetition or frequency of the action, or its relation to many objects, or intensiveness; (Ṣ;) and Ajtr-↓, inf. n. AijotiraArN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and Aijdr-↓, inf. n. AijodiraArN; (L, Ḳ;) in which the t is changed into d, though you do not say AijodaraOa for AijotaraOa, nor AijodaraHa for AijotaraHa; (L;) and Astjr-↓; (Ḳ;) He dragged, drew, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (A,) or a rope, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the like. (Mṣb.) You say, jar-uwA OacoyaAlahumo They dragged along their hinder skirts. (A.) And AjAr-↓ Alr-umoHa He dragged, or drew along, the spear. (TA.) And fulaAnN yasotajir-u↓ AlHadiyva mino OabaAEidi OaToraAfihi † [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A in art. bEd.) And maA Al-aciI jar-aka UilaI hecaA AlOamori † [What drew thee, led thee, induced thee, or caused thee, to do this thing]. (TA in art. dEw.)

Also jar-a,, aor. _u {yajoruru}, (TA,) inf. n. jar-N, (Ḳ,) ‡ He drove (camels and sheep or goats, TA) gently, (Ḳ, TA,) letting them pasture as they went along. (TA.) And jar-a AlUibila EalaI OafowaAhihaA ‡ He drove the camels gently, they eating the while. (A.)

[Hence,] halum-a jar-FA↓ ‡ At thine ease. (TA.) El-Mundhiree explains halhm-a jur-uwA as meaning ‡ Come ye at your ease; from Aljar-u in driving camels and sheep or goats, as rendered above. (TA.) You say also, kaAna caAka EaAma kacaA wahalum-a jar-FA UilaI Alyawomi (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* TA) ‡ That was in such a year, and has continued to this day: (Mṣb, TA:) from Aljar-u meaning the act of “dragging,”, &c.: (TA:) or from Oajorarotuhu Ald-ayona, or from Oajorarotuhu Alr-umoHa. (Mṣb.) jr-A is here in the accus. case as an inf. n., or as a denotative of state: but it is disputed whether this expression be classical or post-classical. (TA.) [See also art. hlm]
jar-a AlOavara, said of a numerous army, means † [It made a continuous track, so that] it left no distinct footprints, or intervening [untrodden] spaces. (TA.)
jar-ati Alxayolu AlOaroDa bisanaAbikihaA ‡ The horses furrowed the ground with their hoofs. (Aṣ, A, TA.)

jar-a jariyrapF, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoruru} and _a, (Ḳ,) but the latter form is disallowed by MF as not authorised by usage nor by analogy, (TA,) inf. n. jar-N, (Ḳ,) He committed a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished, or an injurious action, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) against (EaliI [and UilaI, as in the Ḳ voce janaI,]) another or others, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or himself; (A, Ḳ;) [as though he drew it upon the object thereof;] syn. janaI jinaAyapF. (Ṣ, TA.) It is said in a trad., baAyaEahu EalaI Oano laA yajur-a Ealayohi Uil-aA nafosahu [He promised, or swore, allegiance to him on the condition that he should not inflict an injury, meaning a punishment, upon him but for an offence committed by himself;] i. e., that he should not be punished for the crime of another, of his children or parent or family. (TA.)
jar-a AlfaSiyla: see 4, in two places.

[jar-a AlHarofa fiI AlUiEoraAbi, aor. _u {yajoruru}, inf. n. jar-N, † He made the final letter to have kesreh, in inflection; i. q. xafaDa, q. v.:] Aljar-u is used in the conventional language of the Basrees; and AlxafoDu, in that of the Koofees. (Kull p. 145.)

jar-N, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. jaruwrN, (Ḳ,) ‡ She exceeded the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) ‡ She (a camel) arrived at the time [of the year] in which she had been covered, and then went beyond it some days without bringing forth: (Ṣ, TA:) or withheld her fœtus in her womb after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only: (Ḳ,* TA:) Th says that she sometimes withholds her fœtus [beyond the usual time] a month. (TA. [See also jar-ato.]) ‡ She (a mare) exceeded eleven months and did not foal: (Ḳ, TA:) the more she exceeds the usual term, the stronger is her foal; and the longest time of excess after eleven months is fifteen nights: accord. to AO, the time of a mare's gestation, after she has ceased to be covered, to the time of her foaling, is eleven months; and if she exceed that time at all, they say of her, All-ayolapu. (TA.) ‡ She (a woman) went beyond nine months without bringing forth, (Ḳ, TA,) exceeding that term by four days, or three. (TA.)
† It (the night, kbd,) was, or became, long. (L in art. kbd.)

jar-a, aor. _u {yajoruru}, (TA,) inf. n. jar-N; (Ḳ;) and Anjr-↓; (Ḳ;) † He (a camel) pastured as he went along: (IAạr. Ḳ: [if so, the aor. is contr. to analogy:]) or he rode a she-camel and let her pasture [while going along]. (Kudot;.)
jar-a Aln-awoCu biAlmakaAni † The nwC [or auroral setting or rising of a star or asterism supposed to occasion rain] caused lasting rain in the place. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

3. jArahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaArarapN, (TA,) or mujaAr-apN, (TḲ,) He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, by promising him payment time after time; syn. TaAwalahu, (Ṣ,) or maA Tilahu: (Ḳ:) or he put off giving him his due, and drew him from his place to another: (TA:) or i. q. jaAnaAhu, (so in copies of the Ḳ,) meaning, he committed a crime against him: (TḲ:) or HaAbaAhu. (TA, as from the Ḳ. [But this seems to be a mistranscription.]) It is said in a trad., laA tujaAr- OaxaAka walaA tuXaAr-ihi, i. e. Delay not, or defer not, with thy brother,, &c.: [and do not act towards him in an evil, or inimical, manner; or do not evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return; or do not contend, or dispute, with him:] or bring not an injury upon him: but accord. to one reading, it is laA tujaArihi, without teshdeed, from AljaroIu, and meaning, contend not with him for superiority. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajr-hu He pierced him with the spear and left it in him so that he dragged it along: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so Ajr-hu Alr-umoHa: (A, Mṣb:) as though [meaning] he made him to drag along the spear. (TA.)
He put the jariyr, i. e. the rope, upon his neck. (Ḥar p. 308.)

Ajr-hu jariyrahu [lit. He made him to drag along his rope; meaning,] ‡ he left him to pasture by himself, where he pleased: a prov. (L.) And Ajr-hu rasanahu [lit. He made him to drag along his halter; meaning,] ‡ he left him to do as he would: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he left him to his affair. (A, TA.)
Ajr-hu Ald-ayona ‡ He deferred for him the payment of the debt: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) he left the debt to remain owed by him. (Mṣb.)

Ajr-hu OagaAniI-a ‡ He sang songs to him consecutively, successively, or uninterruptedly; syn. taAbaEahaA: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ he sang to him a song and then followed it up with consecutive songs. (A, TA.)

Ajr- lisaAna AlfaSiyli, (Ṣ,) or Ajr- AlfaSiyla, (Aṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. UijoraArN; (Ḳ;) and jar-a↓ AlfaSiyla, (As Ḳ,*) inf. n. jar-N; (Ḳ;) ‡ He slit the tongue of the young weaned camel, that it might not suck the teat: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or UijoraAru AlfaSiyli signifies ‡ the slitting the tongue of the young weaned camel, and tying upon it a piece of stick, that it may not suck the teat; because it drags along the piece of stick with its tongue: or AlUijoraAru is like Alt-afoliyku, signifying † a pastor's making, of coarse hair, a thing like the whirl, or hemispherical head, of a spindle, and then boring the tongue of the [young] camel, and inserting it therein, that it may not suck the teat: so say some: (ISk, TA:) the animal upon which the operation has been performed is said to be majoruwrN↓ and mujar-N↓. (TA.) [But sometimes jar-a↓ signifies merely He drew away a young camel from its mother: see xaliy-apN voce xaliI-N, in three places.]

Hence, Ajr- lisaAnahu ‡ He prevented him from speaking. (A.) ʼAmr Ibn-MaadeeKerib Ez-Zubeydee says,
falawo Oan-a qawomiI OanoTaqatoniI rimaAHuhumo
naTaqotu walekin-a Alr-imaAHa Ojar-ati
[And if the spears of my people had made me to speak, I had spoken; but the spears have prevented speech]: i. e., had they fought, and shown their valour, I had mentioned that, and gloried in it, (Ṣ,) or in them; (TA;) but their spears have prevented my tongue from speaking, by their flight. (Ṣ,* TA.)
Ajr- as an intrans. verb: see 8.
Ajr-t AlbiYoru ‡ The well was, or became, such as is termed jaruwr. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. Anjr- It (a thing, Ṣ) was, or became, dragged, drawn, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. Ainojacaba. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

hom.sense: 8. AHtr- and Ajdr-: see 1, in three places.

Ajtr- said of a camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and any other animal having a kariX, (Ṣ, TA,) [i. e.] any clovenhoofed animal, (Mṣb,) He ejected the cud from his stomach and ate it again; ruminated; chewed the cud; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ * TA;) as also Ajr-↓. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
10: see 1, in two places.

Aisotajorarotu lahu ‡ I made him to have authority and power over me, (Ḳ, TA,) and submitted myself, or became submissive or tractable, to him; (A, Ḳ, TA;) as though I became to him one that was dragged, or drawn along. (TA.)
Astjr- Eani Alr-aDaAEi † He (a young camel) refrained from sucking in consequence of a purulent pustule, or an ulcer, in his mouth or some other part. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. jarojara, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. jarojarapN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) He (a stallion-camel) reiterated his voice, or cry, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or his braying, (TA,) in his windpipe. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

He, or it, made, or uttered, a noise, sound, cry, or cries; he cried out; vociferated; raised a cry, or clamour. (TA.) It (beverage, or wine,) sounded, or made a sound or sounds, (Ḳ, TA,) in the fauces. (TA.) And jarojarati Aln-aAru † The fire sounded, or made a sound or sounds. (Mṣb.)

Also, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He poured water down his throat; as also tajarojara↓: (Ḳ:) or he swallowed it in consecutive gulps, so that it sounded, or made a sound or sounds; (A, Mṣb, TA;) as also ↓the latter verb. (Ḳ,* TA.) It is said in a trad., (of him who drinks from a vessel of gold or silver, Mgh, TA,) yujarojiru fiI baTonihi naAra jahan-ama He shall drink down into his belly the fire of Hell (Az, A, Mgh, Mṣb) in consecutive gulps, so that it shall make a sound or sounds: (A:) or he shall make the fire of Hell to gurgle reiteratedly in his belly; from jarojara said of a stallion-camel. (Mgh.) Most read AlnAra, as above; but accord. to one reading, it is AlnAru, (Z, Mṣb,) and the meaning is, ‡ The fire of Hell shall produce sounds in his belly like those which a camel makes in his windpipe: the verb is here tropically used; and is masc., with I, because of the separation between it and AlnAr: (Z, TA:) but this reading and explanation are not right. (Mgh.)
You say also, jarojarahu AlmaMCa He poured water down his throat so that it made a sound or sounds. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

hom.sense: jar-N ‡ The foot, bottom, base, or lowest part, of a mountain; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) like cayolN: (A, TA:) or the place where it rises from the plain to the rugged part: (IDrd, TA:) or Alj-r-u OaSolu Aljabali is a mistranscription of Fr, and is correctly AljuraASilu Aljabalu [i. e. jurASilN signifies “a mountain”]: (Ḳ:) but juraASilN is not mentioned [elsewhere] in the Ḳ, nor by any one of the writers on strange words; and [SM says,] there is evidently no mistranscription: jar-u Aljabali occurs in a trad., meaning the foot,, &c., of the mountain: and its pl. is jiraArN. (TA.)
halom-a jar-FA: see 1.
See also jar-apN.
laA jar-a i. q. laA jarama: see art. jrm. (TA.)

jar-apN [A jar;] a well-known vessel; (Mṣb;) an earthen vessel; a vessel made of potters' clay: (T, IDrd,* Ṣ,* Ḳ:*) or anything made of clay: (Mgh:) dim. jurayorapN: (TA:) pl. jiraArN (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jar-aAtN (Mṣb) and jar-N↓, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or this last is rather a coll. gen. n., signifying pottery, or jars,, &c.,] like tamorN in relation to tamorapN; or, accord. to some, this is a dial. var. of jar-apN. (Mṣb.) Beverage of the kind called nabiyc made in such a vessel is forbidden in a trad.: (Mgh, TA:) but accord. to IAth, the trad. means a vessel of this kind glazed within, because the beverage acquires strength, and ferments, more quickly in a glazed earthen vessel. (TA.)
See also jir-apN:
and see what here next follows.

entry.sense: jur-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jar-apN↓ (Ḳ) A small piece of wood, (Ḳ,) or a piece of wood about a cubit long, (Ṣ,) having a snare at the head, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a cord at the middle, (Ṣ,) with which gazelles are caught: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) when the gazelle is caught in it, he strives with it awhile, and struggles in it, and labours at it, to escape; and when it has overcome him, and he is wearied by it, he becomes still, and remains in it; and this is what is termed [in a prov. mentioned below] his becoming at peace with it: (Ṣ,* TA:) or it is a staff, or stick, tied to a snare, which is hidden in the earth, for catching the gazelle; having cords of sinew; when his fore leg enters the snare, the cords of sinew become tied in knots upon that leg; and when he leaps to escape, and stretches out his fore leg, he strikes with that staff, or stick, his other fore leg and his hind leg, and breaks them. (AHeyth, TA.) naAwaSa Aljur-apa vum-a saAlamahaA He struggled with the jr-p and then became at peace with it [see above] is a prov. applied to him who opposes the counsel, or opinion, of a people, and then is obliged to agree: (Ṣ,* TA:) or to him who falls into a case, and struggles in it, and then becomes still. (TA.) And it is said in another prov., huwa kaAlbaAHivi Eani Aljur-api [He is like him who searches in the earth for the]. (AHeyth, TA.) In the phrase UicaA Oafolatato mino jur-atayohaA, in a saying of Ibn-Lisán-el-Hummarah, referring to sheep, [app. meaning When they escape from their two states of danger,] by jr-tyhA he means their place of pasture (Almajar-) in a severe season [when they are liable to perish], and when they are scattered, or dispersed, by night, and [liable to be] attacked, or destroyed, by the beasts of prey: so says ISk: Az says that he calls their mjr two snares, into which they might fall, and perish. (TA.)

hom.sense: jir-apN A mode, or manner, of dragging, drawing, pulling, tugging, straining, or stretching. (Ḳ.)
The stomach of the camel, and of a clovenhoofed animal: this is the primary signification: by extension of its meaning, it has the signification next following. (Mṣb.)

The cud which a camel [or cloven-hoofed animal] ejects from its stomach, (Az, Ṣ,* IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and eats again, (Ḳ,) or chews, or ruminates, (Az, IAth, Mṣb,) or to chew, or ruminate; (Ṣ;)
as also jar-apN↓: (Ḳ:) it is said to belong to the same predicament as baEor. (Mgh.) Hence the saying, laA OafoEalu celika maA Qxotalafati Ald-ir-apu waAljir-apu I will not do that as long as the flow of milk and the cud go [the former] downwards and [the latter] upwards. (Ṣ, A.* [See also dir-apN.]) And Aujotulibati Ald-ir-apu biAljir-api [The flow of milk was procured by the cud]: alluding to the beasts' becoming full of food, and then lying down and not ceasing to ruminate until the time of milking. (IAạr, TA.) And laA yaHonaqu EalaI jir-atihi † He will not bear rancour, or malice, against his subjects:: or, as some say, cross he will not conceal a secret: (TA:) and maA yaHonaqu EalaI jir-apK and maA yakoZimu ElI jir-apK † he does not speak when affected with rancour, or malice: (TA in art. Hnq:) [or the last has the contr. signification: for] laA yakoZimu EalaI jir-atihi means ‡ he will not be silent respecting that which is in his bosom, but will speak of it. (TA in art. kZm.)
Also The mouthful with which the camel diverts and occupies himself until the time when his fodder is brought to him. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaruwrN ‡ A female that exceeds the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) ‡ A she-camel that withholds her fœtus in her womb, after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only; (Ḳ,* TA;) or, three months after the year: they are the most generous of camels that do so: none do so but those that usually bring forth in the season called Alr-abiyE (AlmaraAbiyE); not those that usually bring forth in the season called AlS-ayof (AlmaSaAyiyf): and only those do so that are red [or brown], and such as are of a white hue intermixed with red (AlS-uhob), and such as are ash-coloured: never, or scarcely ever, such as are of a dark gray colour without any admixture of white, because of the thickness of their skins, and the narrowness of their insides, and the hardness of their flesh. (IAạr, TA. [See also 1: and see xaSuwfN.])

Also † A she-camel that is made to incline to, and to suckle, a young one not her own; her own being about to die, they bound its fore legs to its neck, and put upon it a piece of rag, in order that she might know this piece of rag, which they then put upon another young one; after which they stopped up her nostrils, and did not unclose them until the latter young one had sucked her, and she perceived from it the odour of her milk. (L.)

Also, applied to a horse, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a camel, (Ḳ,) ‡ That refuses to be led; refractory: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Az, TA:) or a slow horse, either from fatigue or from shortness of step: (AʼObeyd, TA:) pl. jururN. (TA.)
And † A woman crippled; or affected by a disease that deprives her of the power of walking: (Sh, Ḳ:) because she is dragged upon the ground. (Sh, TA.)

biYorN jaruwrN ‡ A deep well; (Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) from which the water is drawn by means of the saAniyap [q. v.], (Ṣ, A,) and by means of the pulley and the hands; like matuwHN and nazuwEN: (A:) or a well from which the water is drawn [by a man] upon a camel [to the saddle of which one end of the wellrope is attached]; so called because its bucket is drawn upon the edge of the mouth thereof, by reason of its depth. (Aṣ, L.)

jariyrN A rope: pl. Oajir-apN. (Sh, TA.) A rope for a camel, corresponding to the EicaAr of a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) different from the zimaAm. (Ṣ.) Also The nose-rein of a camel; syn. zimaAmN: (Ḳ:) or a cord of leather, that is put upon the neck of a she-camel: (Mṣb:) or a cord of leather, like a zmAm: and applied also to one of other kinds of plaited cords: or, accord. to El-Hawázinee, [a string] of softened leather, folded over the nose of an excellent camel or a horse. (TA.) [See also xiTaAmN.]
jiraArapN The art of pottery: the art of making jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jar-apN.])

jariyrapN A crime; a sin; an offence which a man commits, and for which he should be punished; an injurious action: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA:) syn. canobN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jinaAyapN: (Ṣ:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Mṣb:) pl. jaraAYiru. (A.) See also what next follows.

faEalotu kacaA mino jar-aAka, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,*) and mn jar-aAYika, (Ḳ,) and mn jaraAk, and mn jaraAYika, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mn jariyratika↓, (Ḳ,) means mn Oajolika, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) i. e., [originally, I did so] in consequence of thy committing it, namely, a crime: and then, by extension of its application, [because of thee, or of thine act, &c.; on thine account; for thy sake;] indicating any causation. (Bḍ in v. 35, in explanation of mn jar-aAka and mn Oajolika.) One should not say mijoraAka, (Ṣ,) or bijoraAka. (A.)

jir-iI-N (written in the Towsheeh with fet-ḥ to the j also, TA,) [The eel;] a kind of fish, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) long and smooth, (Ḳ,) resembling the serpent, and called in Persian maAro maAhiI; said to be a dial. var. of jir-iyvN; (TA;) not eaten by the Jews, (Ḳ,) and forbidden to be eaten by ʼAlee; (TA;) having no scales: (Ḳ:) or any fish having no scales. (Towsheeh, TA.)

jir-iy-apN The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jir-iyoYapN [q. v.] (Ḳ) and qir-iy-apN. (AZ, TA.) You say, OloqaAhu fiI jir-iy-atihi, meaning, ‡ He ate it. (A, TA.) See also art. jrI.

hom.sense: jar-aArN A man who leads a thousand. (T, end of art. Hfz.)

jayoXN jar-aArN, (Ṣ, A,) and katiybapN jar-aArapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ An army, and a troop of horse or the like, that marches heavily, by reason of its numbers: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or dragging along the apparatus of war: (A:) or numerous. (TA.)
A potter; a maker of jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jar-apN.])

entry.sense: jar-aArapN A small, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) yellow, (A, TA,) female (TA) scorpion, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) like a piece of straw, (TA, [thus I render ElI Xkl Altbnp, but I think that there must be here some mistranscription, as the words seem to be descriptive of form,]) that drags its tail; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) for which reason it is thus called; one of the most deadly of scorpions to him whom it stings: (TA:) pl. jar-aAraAtN. (A, TA.)
jar-aAnu: see jaAr-N, last sentence.

hom.sense: jarojarN The thing [or machine] of iron with which the reaped corn collected together is thrashed. (Ḳ.) [See naworajN and midowasN.]
See also jirojirN.
jirojirN: see jarojaArN.
Also The bean; or beans; syn. fuwlN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so jarojarN: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of the people of El-'Irák. (TA.)
See also jirojiyrN.

entry.sense: jarojarpN, an onomatopœia: (Mṣb:) A sound which a camel reiterates in his windpipe: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the sound made by a camel when disquieted, or vexed: (TA:) the sound of pouring water into the throat: (TA:) or the sound of the descent of water into the belly: (IAth, TA:) or the sound of water in the throat when drunk in consecutive gulps. (Mṣb.) [See R. Q. 1.]

hom.sense: The sound of thunder. (Ḳ.)
A certain plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of sweet odour; (Ṣ;) a certain herb having a yellow flower. (AḤn, TA.)

entry.sense: jurojuwrN A large, or bulky, camel: (Ḳ:) pl. jaraAjiru, (Kr, Ḳ,) without I [before the final letter], though by rule it should be with I, except in a case of poetic necessity. (TA.) And, as a pl., Large, or bulky, camels; as also [its pl.] jaraAjiru: (Ṣ:) or large-bellied camels: (TA:) and generous, or excellent, camels: (Ḳ, TA:) and a herd, or collected number, (Ḳ, TA,) of camels: (TA:) and maAYapN jurojuwrN a complete hundred (Ḳ, TA) of camels. (TA.)

jirojiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jirojirN↓ (Ḳ) [The herb eruca, or rocket;] a certain leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known: (Ḳ;) a plant of which there are two kinds; namely, bar-aI- [i. e. eruca sylvestris, or wild rocket], and busotaAniI- [i. e. eruca sativa, or garden-rocket]; whereof the latter is the better: its water, or juice, removes scars, and causes milk to flow, and digests food: (TA:) AḤn says that the jirojiyr is the baAqil-aI [q. v.]; and that the jirjiyr miSoriI- is the turomus: [but see this last word.] (TA in art. trms.)
jarojaArapN A mill, or mill-stone; syn. raHFI: (Ḳ:) because of its sound. (TA.)
juraAjirN: see jarojaArN.
And hence, (TA,) Water that makes a noise. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jaAr-N [act. part. n. of 1; Dragging, drawing,, &c.].

jaAr-u AlD-abuEi ‡ Rain that draws the hyena from its hole by its violence: or the most violent rain; as though it left nothing without dragging it along: (TA:) or rain that leaves nothing without making it to flow, and dragging it along: (IAạr, TA:)
or the torrent that draws forth the hyena from its hole: (A:) and in like manner, majar-u↓ AlD-abuEi the torrent that has torn up the ground; as though the hyena were dragged along in it. (IAạr, Sh, TA.) You say also maTarN jaAr-u AlD-abuEi, and maTorapN jaAr-apu AlD-abuEi. (A.)

UibilN jaAr-apN ‡ Working camels; because they drag along burdens; (A, Mgh;) or tropically so called because they are dragged along by their nose-reins: (Mgh:) or camels that are dragged along by their nosereins: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [but in the copies of the Ṣ, and in those of the Ḳ, in my possession, tajur-u is put for tujar-u, though the latter is evidently meant, as is shown by what here follows:]) jAr-p is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: it is like as when you say EiyXapN raADayapN in the sense of maroDiy-apN, and maMCN daAfiqN in the sense of madofuwqN: (Ṣ:) or it means such as carry goods, or furniture and utensils, and wheat, or food. (AZ, TA voce HaAn-N, q. v.) It is said in a trad. that there is no poor-rate (Sadaqap) in the case of such camels, (Ṣ, Mgh,) because they are the ridingcamels of the people; for the poor-rate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (Ṣ.)
laA jaAr-a liI fiI hecaA ‡ There is no profit for me in this to attract me to it. (A, TA.)

HaAr-N jaAr-N is an expression in which the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but accord. to AʼObeyd, it was more common to say HaAr-N yaAr-N, with I: (Ṣ:) and one says also Har-aAnu yar-aAnu jar-aAnu↓. (TA in art. Hr.)

entry.sense: jiwar-N is mentioned by Az in this art., meaning Rain that draws along everything: and rain that occasions the herbage to grow tall: and a large and heavy [bucket of the kind called] garob; explained in this sense by AO: and a bulky camel; and, with p {jiwar-apN}, in like manner applied to a ewe: Fr says that the w in this word may be considered as augmentative or as radical. (TA.) [See also art. w.]
jaAr-apN [fem. of jaAr-N, q. v.: and, as a subst.,] A road to water. (Ḳ.)
jaAruwrN A river, or rivulet, of which the bed is formed but a torrent. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)
AlOajar-aAni The jinn, or genii, and mankind. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

majar-N [The place, or track, along which a thing is, or has been, dragged, or drawn]. You say, raOayotu majar-a cayolihi [I saw the track along which his hinder skirt had been dragged]. (A.) See also Almajar-apu: and jaAr-N.
A place of pasture. (TA.)
The jaAYiz [or beam] upon which are placed the extremities of the EawaAriD [or rafters]. (Ḳ)
mujar-N: see 4, in the latter portion of the paragraph.

Almajar-apu ‡ [The Milky Way in the sky;] the Xaraj of the sky; (Ḳ;) the whiteness that lies across in the sky, by the two sides of which are the nasoraAni [or two constellations called Aln-asoru AlT-aAYiru and Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu]: or [the tract called] AlT-ariyqu AlmaHosuwspu [which is probably the same; or the tract], in the sky, along which (minohaA) the [wandering] stars [or planets] take their ways: (TA:) or the gate of Heaven: (Ḳ:) so called because it is like the trace of the majar- [or place along which a thing has been dragged, or drawn]. (Ṣ.) Hence the prov., siTiI majaro↓ turoTibo hajaro ‡ Reach the middle of the sky, O milky way, (mjr being for mjr-p,) and the palm-trees of Hejer will have ripe dates. (A,* TA.)
majoruwrN [pass. part. n. of 1]: see 4, latter portion.

1. jaruWa, aor. _u {yajoruOu}, inf. n. jaraMCapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaraAYiyapN and jaraAyapN, with I [in the place of C], which is extr., (Ḳ,) and juroOapN and jurapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) thus sometimes, without C, like as one says maroOapN and juroOapN, (Ṣ,) [all mentioned as inf. ns. in the TḲ, and app. as such in the Ḳ, but only the first is explicitly mentioned as an inf. n. in the Ṣ and Mṣb, and AstjrO↓ is said in the Mṣb to be a simple subst.,] He was, or became, bold, daring, brave, or courageous; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) so as to attempt, or venture upon, a thing without consideration or hesitation: (TA:) [said of a brute and the like, as well as of a man:] and AstjrO↓ is syn. therewith. (IJ, W p. 146.)
2. jar-aOotuhu Ealayohi, (inf. n. tajoriIoCN, Ḳ,) I emboldened him, or encouraged him, against him. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA.)
5: see 8.
8. AjtrO Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or tjr-O↓, (Mṣb,) He became emboldened or encouraged, or he emboldened or encouraged himself, against him. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA.)
AjtrO EalaI Alqawoli He ventured upon the saying hastily and unhesitatingly. (Mṣb.)
juroOapN Boldness, daringness, bravery, or courage; as also jurapN: (Ṣ: see 1:) the quality of venturing upon a saying [&c.] hastily and unhesitatingly. (Mṣb.)

jariIoCN Bold, daring, brave, or courageous: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA:) pl. OajoraMCN, accord. to a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ; [and so in the CK;] but in the M, OajoriYaMCu, with two hemzehs, on the authority of Lḥ; and so in some copies of the Ḳ; and sometimes juraOLCu, like HulamaMCu, occurring in a trad., as some relate it; but the reading commonly known is HuraOLC, with the unpointed H. (TA.)
jariIoCu Almuqodami Bold, daring, brave, or courageous, in venturing [against an adversary, or upon an undertaking]. (Ṣ.)
AljariIoCu The lion; as also AlmujotariYu↓. (O, Ḳ.)

jariyoYapN A chamber (Ḳ, TA) constructed of stones, with a stone placed over its entrance, (TA,) for the purpose of entrapping wild beasts: (Ḳ, TA:) the piece of flesh-meat for the wild beast is put in the hinder part of the chamber; and when he enters to take the piece of meat, the stone falls upon the entrance, and closes it: (TA:) pl. jaraAYiIu (accord. to some copies of the Ḳ,) or jaraAYiYu, (accord. to others,) mentioned by AZ as one of the forms of pl. repudiated by the Arabic grammarians except in some anomalous instances. (TA.)

Aljir-iyoYapu The qaAniSap [here app. meaning the stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird], and the Huloquwm [here app. meaning the gullet of a bird]; like Aljir-iy-apu; (Ḳ;) i. e. the HawoSalap [meaning the stomach, or the crop, of a bird]: it is said in the T, on the authority of AZ, that Alqir-iy-apu and Aljir-iy-apu and Aln-awoTapu signify the HawoSalap of a bird. (TA.)
AlmujotariYu: see jariIoCN.

1. jariba, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajorabu}, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jarabN, (Mṣb, TA,) He (a camel, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, and a man, Ṣ, or other animal, Mṣb,) was, or became, affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) maA lahu jariba waHariba is a form of imprecation against a man [meaning What aileth him? may he have the scab, and be despoiled of all his wealth, or property: or may he have his camels affected with the mange, or scab, and be despoiled, &c.: or may his camels be affected with the mange, or scab,, &c.]: it may express a wish that he may be affected with jarab: or jariba may be put for Oajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba: or it may be for jaribato Uibluhu. (L.)
See 4.
Also ‡ i. q. halakato OaroDuhu [meaning His land had its herbage dried up by drought; or became such as is termed jarobaMC, fem. of Oajorabu, q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

2. jr-bhu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoribapN, (M, A, Ḳ,) or tajoriybN, the former, which see also below, being a simple subst., (Mṣb,) or both, but the former is irreg., are inf. ns., (TA,) He tried, made trial of, made experiment of, tested, proved, assayed, proved by trial or experiment or experience, him, or it: (A, Ḳ:) or he tried it, made trial of it,, &c., namely, a thing, time after time. (Mṣb.) [You say also jar-aba, for jar-aba AlOumuwra, meaning He tried affairs: and hence, i. q.] jur-iba fiI AlOumuwr [He became experienced, or expert, in affairs]. (T, TA.) And jar-abatohu AlOumuwru [Affairs, or events, tried him., &c.: and thus, rendered him experienced, or expert]. (Ṣ, TA.) And maA jur-ibto Ealayohi faEolapN qabiyHapN qaT-u [A foul action was never found to be chargeable upon him]. (Ṣ voce nugobapN.)

4. Ajrb He had his camels [or found them to be] affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as also jariba↓, (L, Ḳ,) which may be for jaribato Uibiluhu; or used for Oajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba in a saying mentioned above; see 1. (L.)
Q. Q. 1. jaworabahu He put on him [i. e., on his (another's) foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Q. Q. 2. tajaworaba He put on [i. e., on his own foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And in like manner, tjwrb jaworabayoni [He put on a pair of socks or stockings]. (TA.)
jirobN: see jirobapN.

jarabN [The mange, or scab;] a certain disease, (A,) well known; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) accord. to the medical books, (Mṣb,) a gross humour, arising beneath the skin, from the mixture of the salt phlegm, (Mṣb, MF,) or the phlegm of the flesh, (so in a copy of the Mṣb,) with the blood, accompanied with pustules, and sometimes with emaciation, in consequence of its abundance; (Mṣb, MF;) or [an eruption consisting of] pustules upon the bodies of men and camels. (M, TA.) You say, OEodaI mina Aljarabi Einoda AlEarabi [More transitive, or catching, than the mange, or scab, among the Arabs]: (A, TA:) a proverb. (TA.)
† Rust upon a sword. (Ḳ.)

‡ A resemblance of rust upon the inner side of the jafon [or eyelid], (M, Ḳ,) sometimes covering the whole of it, and sometimes part of it. (M.) You say, biOajofaAnihi jarabN ‡ [In his eyelids is] a resemblance of rust upon their inner sides. (A.)
† A vice, a fault, a defect, an imperfection, or a blemish. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
jaribN: see Oajorabu.

jirobapN A place of seed-produce; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jariybN↓: (Ḳ:) and a tract of land such as is termed qaraAH [i. e. a field, or land, sown or for sowing, without any building or trees in it; or land cleared for sowing and planting; or a separate piece of land in which palm-trees, &c. grow;, &c.]: (Ḳ:) metaphorically applied by Imra-el-Ḳeys to [a grove of] palm-trees, where he says
kajirobapi naxolK Oawo kajan-api yavoriba
[Like a grove of palm-trees, or like the plantation of Yethrib]: (AḤn, TA:) or land prepared for sowing or planting: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or a piece of land differing in condition from the land adjoining it, [i. e. a patch of land,] producing good plants or herbage: (Lth, TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is jirobN↓, (Lth, AḤn,) like as tibonN is of tibonapN, and sidorN of sidorapN: (AḤn:) or jirobN signifies a qaraAH; and its pl. is jirabapN. (IAạr, TA.)

A skin, or a mat, which is placed upon the brink of a well, lest the water should be scattered into the well [app. in falling from the bucket into the channel of the tank or cistern, &c.]: or (a skin, TA,) that is placed in a rivulet or streamlet (jadowal [which is applied in the present day to an artificial streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench or gutter,]) that the water may flow down over it [app. from the well to the tank or cistern, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.)
jaribapu: see Oajorabu, last sentence but one.

hom.sense: jarobaAnu or jarobaAnN: see Oajorabu:
and for the latter, see jurub-aAnN.

entry.sense: jurobaAnN and jirobaAnN: see jurub-aAnN, in five places.
jurub-aMC and jirib-aMC: see what next follows.

jurub-aAnN (Ṣ, MF, TA) and jirib-aAnN, (Mj, MF, TA,) which are the two forms commonly known, (MF, TA,) or, accord. to the Ḳ, jirobaAnN↓ and jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to the L, jarobaAnN↓, and sometimes jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, [and so in the CK,] jirib-aMC↓ and jurub-aMC↓, which are evident mistranscriptions, or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh of El-Khafájee, jarib-aAnN, which is more strange, (MF,) but this last accords [most nearly] with its original, (TA,) [for it is] a Persian word arabicized, (Ṣ, TA,) originally GariybaAno; (TA;) The jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt: (Ḳ, TA:) or the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons: (IB and TA in art. bnq:) or the [part called] libonap [q. v.] of a shirt. (Ṣ, TA.)

jurub-aAnu sayofK (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and jurobaAnuhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or jirobAnhu↓, (CK,) The edge (Had-) of a sword: (Ḳ:) or a thing [i. e. a case] (Ḳ, TA) of sewed leather (TA) in which are put a sword and its scabbard with the cords or belts by which it is suspended: (Ḳ, TA;) i. q. qiraAbuhu: (Ṣ: [see also jiraAbN:]) or a large sword-case in which are a man's sword and his whip and what else he requires: (Fr, TA: [also called julub-aAn and jilib-aAn and julobaAn:]) in the L, the first is [also] said to signify the scabbard of a sword. (TA.)

hom.sense: jirobiyaMCu [a word of a very rare form, (see kiboriyaMCu,)] The north-west wind; a wind of the kind termed nakobaMCu, that blows in a direction between that of the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] XamaAl and that of the [west wind, or westerly wind, called] dabuwr, and that dispels the clouds: (Ṣ, TA:) it is a cold wind, and is sometimes attended by a little rain: (TA in art. nkb, q. v.:) or the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] XmAl: or the cold of that wind: (Ḳ, TA:) or, (Ḳ,) as also Oazoyabu, (TA,) the south east wind; the wind that blows in a direction between that of the [south wind, or southerly wind, called] januwb and that of the [east wind, or easterly wind, called] SabaA. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also, with the article Al, a name of The seventh earth: corresponding to AlEirobiyaMCu, a name of “the seventh heaven.” (TA.)
Also A weak man. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jiraAbN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) not jaraAbN, (ISk, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or this latter is of weak authority, (Ḳ, TA,) or peculiar to the vulgar, (Ṣ, L,) A provisionbag for travellers: (Ḳ, Ḥar p. 174:) or a bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils, &c.,; syn. wiEaMCN: (Ḳ, TA:) or such a receptacle made of sheep-skin, in which nothing is kept but what is dry: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jurubN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jurobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter a contraction of the former, (TA,) and [of pauc.] OajoribapN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
‡ A sword-case; or a case, or receptacle, in which a sword is put with its scabbard and its suspensory belt or cord; syn. qiraAbu sayofK. (TA. [See also jurub-aAnN.])
† The scrotum. (Ḳ.)
jiraAbu Alqalobi † [The pericardium, or heart-purse]. (Ḳ in art. vht, &c.)

jiraAbu AlbiYori † The cavity of the well; (M, Ḳ;) or ‡ its interior, (Lth, Ṣ, M, A,) from top to bottom. (Lth, Ṣ, M.) You say, AiTowi jiraAbahaA biAlHijaArapi Case thou its interior with stones. (A.)

jariybN A certain measure, (M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or quantity, of wheat, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) consisting of four Oaqofizap [pl. of qafiyzN]: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or ten Aqfzp; each qfyz thereof consisting of ten OaEoXiraMC [pl. of EaXiyrN]; so that the EXyr is the hundredth part of the whole: (TA:) or, as some say, a measure differing in different countries; as is the case of the rTol and mud- and ciraAE, &c. (MF, TA.) For the pl., see what follows.

Hence, (Mgh,) † A certain quantity of land; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as much as is sown with the measure of seed so called; (A, Mgh;) like as mules and the space that they travel are termed bariydN: (A, Mgh:*) it is sixty cubits by sixty cubits; accord. to Kudámeh, the extent termed OaXol multiplied by itself; the AXl being sixty cubits; the cubit being six qabaDaAt; and the qaboDap, four OaSaAbiE: the tenth part of the jryb is called qfyz, and the tenth of the qfyz is called EXyr; so that the qfyz is ten AEXrAC: (Mgh:) it is a distinct portion of land, differing according to the different conventional usages of the people of different provinces: it is said that the width of six moderate-sized barleycorns is called UiSobaEN; the qbDp is four ASAbE; the ciraAE is six qbDAt; ten OacoruE are called qaSabapN; ten qaSabaAt are called AXl; and the jryb is the extent termed AXl multiplied by itself: the AXl multiplied by the qSbp is called qfyz; and the AXl multiplied by the crAE is called EXyr: so the jiryb is ten thousand cubits: or, accord. to Kudámeh the Scribe, it is three thousand and six hundred cubits: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoribapN and [of mult.] jurobaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juruwbN. (R, TA.) See also jirobapN.

jaworabN [A sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings;] the wrapper of the foot or leg: (Ḳ:) or a pair of woollen envelopes for the feet, used for warmth: (TA:) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) from the Persian Guwrabo, originally Guwro, i. e. “tomb of the foot:” (TA:) pl. jawaAribapN and jawaAribu; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) in the former of which, the p is added because it is originally a foreign word. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, huwa Oanotanu mino riyHi Aljaworabi [He, or it, is more stinking than the smell of socks, or stockings]. (A, TA.)
jawaAribiI-N A maker of jawaArib [i. e. socks or stockings]. (TA.)

Ojorabu (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaribN↓ (A, Mgh, Ḳ) and jarobaAnu↓ or jarobaAnN (Ḳ accord. to different copies) [Mangy, or scabby;] affected with what is termed jarab: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) applied to a camel, (A, Mṣb,) and to a man: (Ṣ, A:) fem. (of the first, Mṣb) jarobaMCu (A, Mṣb) and [of the second] jaribapN: (A:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) jurobN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the first, Ṣ, Mgh, TA, or of the second, Mgh, or of the third agreeably with analogy, TA) jarobaI (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and [of the first] OajaAribu, which is like certain pls. of substantives, as OajaAdilu and OanaAmilu, (TA,) and (of the first contrary to rule, like EijaAfN and biTaAHN and EiSaAlN which are pls. of OaEojafu and OaboTaHu and OaEoSalu, Mṣb, or of the second, IB, Ḳ, or of jurobN, which is pl. of the first, Ṣ) jiraAbN: (Ṣ, IB, Mṣb, Ḳ:) this last occurs in the following verse [of ’Amr, or ’Omeyr, Ibn-El-Hobáb, or El-Khabbáb; these variations being in different copies of the Ḳ; but in the TA art. nXr, and in a copy of the Ṣ in that art. and in the present one, ’Omeyr Ibn-El-Khabbáb]:
wafiynaA waUino qiyla QSoTalaHonaA taDaAgunN
kamaA Tar-a OawobaAru AljiraAbi EalaI Aln-aXori
(Ṣ, Ḳ *) Within us, though it be said that we have made peace, one with another, and we are on good terms outwardly, is mutual rancour: as the soft wool of the mangy camels (while disease lurks beneath, within them, TA) grows by reason of [eating] the nXr [or herbage] that becomes green at the and of summer (in consequence of rain falling upon it, TA) and is injurious to animals that pasture upon it: (Ḳ, TA:) and it is said by IB, and in the Ḳ, that jrAb, here, is pl. of jaribN, not, as J says, of jurobN: but MF observes that fiEaAlN is the pl. measure of several words of the measure fuEolN, as rumoHN and duhonN, and is even said by IHsh and Ibn-Málik and AḤei to be regularly applicable to sings. of this latter measure; whereas no grammarian nor Arabic scholar asserts that a word of the measure faEilN assumes fiEaAlN as the measure of its pl. (TA.)
[Hence,] sayofN Oajorabu ‡ A sword reddened by much rust, which cannot be removed from it unless with a file. (A.)
And OaroDN jarobaMCu ‡ Land affected with. drought: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or salt land, affected with drought, and containing nothing. (ISd, TA.)

And AljarobaMCu ‡ The sky; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) so called because of the stars (Ṣ, TA) and the milky way, (TA,) as though it were scabbed with stars; (Ṣ, IF, ISd;) its stars being likened to the marks of jarab; (A;) like as the sea is called Oajoradu, and like as the sky is also called raqiyE because [as it were] patched with stars: (AAF, ISd:) or that tract of the sky in which the sun and moon revolve: (M, Ḳ:) or the lowest heaven: (AHeyth, TA:) and accord. to the M, jrbp [so in the TA, app. jaribapu↓,] is applied as a determinate [proper] name to the sky. (TA.)
And jarobaMCu † A beautiful girl; (IAạr, Ḳ;) so called because the women separate themselves from her, seeing that their goodly qualities are rendered foul by comparison with hers. (IAạr, TA.)

tajoribapN is a subst. from jar-aba: (Mṣb:) or it is an inf. n. of that verb, (M, A, Ḳ,) and is one of the inf. ns. from which pls. are formed: (M, TA:) its pl. is tajaArbu (M, Mṣb, TA) and tajaAriybu, (M, TA.) En-Nábighah says,
UilaI Alyawomi qado jur-ibona kul-a Alt-ajaAribi
[To this day, they (referring to females) have been tried with every kind of tryings]: and El-Aạshà says,
kamo jar-abuwhu famaA zaAdato tajaAribuhumo
OabaA qudaAmapa Uil-aA Almajoda waAlqanaEaA
[How often have they tried him, and their tryings of Aboo-Kudámeh have not increased aught save his glory and contentment!]; tjArb being here a pluralized inf. n. made to govern an objective complement; which is a strange fact. (M, TA.) [But in this latter instance, we may consider AbA qdAmp as a first objective complement of rAdt, and XayoYaA, understood before Al-A, as a second objective complement of the same verb.]

mujoribN A man who has his camels affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]: whence the prov., laA UilaAha limujoribK [There is no god to one who has his camels affected with the mange]; as though he renounced his god by frequently swearing falsely by him that he had no pitch when it was demanded of him [for the purpose of curing other camels]: (A:) or laA Oaliy-apa limujoribK [There is no oath to one who has his camels affected with the mange; for the reason above mentioned, or because he is likely to deny that he has mangy camels lest his camels should be prevented from coming to water: and hence also,] Oakodabu mino mujoribK [More lying than one who has his camels affected with the mange]; another prov. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 382.])

hom.sense: mujar-abN One who has been tried, or proved, in affairs, and whose qualities have become known: (T, TA:) or one who has been tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs: (Ṣ:) [experienced, or expert, in affairs:] or one whose qualities have been tried, or proved. (Ḳ, TA.) And mujar-ibN↓ One having experience in affairs. (Ḳ, TA.) In general, but not always, (MF,) the Arabs used the former of these two epithets [which are virtually synonymous]. (Ṣ, MF.)
daraAhimu mujar-abapN Weighed money. (Kr, Ḳ.)
Almujar-abu The lion. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

[It is also employed as an inf. n. of 2, in accordance with a usage of which there are many other instances; as in the saying,] Oanota EalaI Almujar-abi [Thou art about to have the proof, or experience]: a prov., mentioned by AZ: said to him who asks respecting a thing which he is about to know of himself: originally said by a woman to a man who asked her an indecent question which he was himself about to resolve. (TA.)

entry.sense: mujar-ibN: see mujar-abN.

jir-iyvN A kind of fish, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) well known, (TA,) also called jir-iI-N and Sil-aworN, (Mgh, TA,) resembling a serpent, called in Persian maAro maAhiI [snake-fish, or eel]; forbidden to be eaten by the Jews: whether it be lawful to the Muslims is disputed: (TA:) qir-iyvN is a dial. var. (Ṣ in art. qrv.)

hom.sense: Q. 2. tajarovama: see 3, in two places.
tjrvm AlX-aIoCa He took the greater, main, or chief, part of the thing. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. 3. Aijoranovama He, or it, drew himself, or itself, together; contracted; or shrank: (TA, Ḥar p. 297:) from jurovuwmapN signifying the “earth collected around a tree.” (Ḥar ib.) Also, and tjrvm↓, It (a thing, Ṣ) collected itself together, or became collected, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kept to a place. (Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., waEaAda lahaA Aln-iqAdu mujoranovimFA↓ And the lambs, by reason of it, namely, the vehement drought, became collected, or drawn, together [in one place, and kept to it]. (TA.)
He (a man, TA) fell from a high, or higher, to a low, or lower, place; as also tjrvm↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
jurovumapN: see what next follows.

jurovuwmapN [and accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the Ṣ, jurovuwmN, but this I have. not found in any Lexicon but his and that of Freytag,] The root, lowest part, base, stock, or source, syn. OaSolN, of a thing; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) whatever the thing be; (Mgh;) as also jurovumapN↓: (TA:) and the place of collection thereof: (Mgh, TA:) or the earth that is collected at the roots, or lower parts, of trees: (Ḳ:) or the earth collected around a tree: (Ḥar p. 297:) or the root of a tree to which the earth is collected: (Lth, TA:) pl. jaraAviymu. (Mgh.) One is related to have said, AlOasodu jurovuwmapu AlEarabi famano OaDal-a nasabahu faliyaOotihimo [ElAsd are those, of the Arabs, to whom most others congregate: therefore whoever loses his genealogy, let him come to them]: meaning AlOazodu. (TA.) And jaraAviymu jahan-ama means The greater, main, or chief, degrees of the punishment of Hell. (Mgh.)
The base (OaSol) of a sandhill overlooking what surrounds it. (Ḥar p. 99.) And the pl. (jrAvym), Places elevated above the ground, composed of clay and earth collected together. (TA.)
The earth collected by ants; (TA;) an ant-hill: (Ḳ:) or jurovuwmapu Aln-amoli signifies the ant-hill. (Ṣ.)
The earth, or dust, that the wind raises, or sweeps up and scatters. (Ḳ.)
The galoSamap [or epiglottis]. (Ḳ.)
mujoranovimN: see 3.
rakabN mujoranovamN [in the CK, erroneously, rakobN mujoranovamN,] i. q. musotahodifN, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, musotahodafN,]) i. e., A wide, elevated pubes. (TA in art. hdf.)

hom.sense:
1. jaraHahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yajoraHu}, (Ḳ, Mṣb, &c.,) inf. n. jaroHN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.,)
He wounded him; produced an effect, or made an impression, upon him with a weapon: (L:) he cut him: (A, MF:) or clave, or rent, some part of his body: (MF:) syn. kalamahu: (Ḳ:) and jr-Hhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoriyHN, (TA,) signifies the same (Ḳ) in an intensive sense, or as applying to several objects; (Ṣ;) or he wounded him much. (L.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or jaraHahu bilisaAnihi, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) [lit. He wounded him with his tongue; meaning] ‡ he reviled him, or vilified him; (A, Ḳ;) he imputed to him a vice, or fault, or the like; or spoke against him. (Mṣb.) And jaraHuwhu biOanoyaAb waOaDoraAsK [lit. They wounded him with dog-teeth and grinders; meaning] ‡ they reviled him, or vilified him, and imputed to him vices or the like. (A.) And hence, (Mṣb,) jaraHa AlX-iAhida (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) [and jr-Hhu↓, as in many of the law-books,] said of a judge, (A, L,) or other person, (I.,) ‡ He annulled the witness's claim to be legally credible, (L, Ḳ,) by happening to discover in him a falsehood, &c.; (L;) he evinced in the witness something that caused his testimony to be rejected: (Mṣb:) he censured the witness, and rejected what he said. (L.) And jaraHa Alr-ajula ‡ He invalidated the man's testimony. (L.) And jaraHa AlX-ahaAdapa ‡ [He, or it, invalidated the testimony; or annulled its claim to be legally credible]. (A, TA.)

Also jaraHa, and AjtrH↓, ‡ He gained, acquired, or earned; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) or applied himself with art and diligence to get, obtain, gain, acquire, or earn; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) a thing: (TA:) he worked, or wrought, with his hand, and gained, acquired, or earned;, &c.: (Mṣb:) from jiraAHapN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN yajoraHu liEiyaAlihi, and yajotariHu↓, ‡ Such a one [works, and earns sustenance, or] gains, acquires, or earns, and collects, for his family, or household. (TA) And biYosa maA jaraHato yadaAka, and QjotaraHato↓, ‡ Very evil is that which thy hands have done, or wrought, or effected: a metaphor taken from the signification of “cutting,” or “wounding;” (A, TA;) accord. to El-Khafájee, a metaphorical meaning conventionally regarded as proper. (TA.) QjotaraHuwA↓ Als-ay-aMti, in the Ḳur [xlv. 20], means ‡ Have committed crimes, sins, or evil actions. (TA.)
jariHa, aor. as above, He (a man, TA) received a wound. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ He had his testimony rejected as not legally entitled to credit: (Ḳ,* TA:) and so his relation. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
8: see 1, in four places.

10. AstjrH ‡ He deserved that his claim to be legally credible should be annulled. (A, TA.) And ‡ It (a tradition, or narrative, A, or a thing, Mṣb) deserved to be rejected [as unworthy of credit or regard]. (A, Mṣb.) AisotajoraHato hecihi AlOaHaAdiyvu means ‡ These traditions deserved to be rejected on account of their great number and the fewness of such as were true: (A:) or, by reason of their great number, obliged those who were acquainted with them to annul the claim of some one or other of their relaters to be credited, and to reject his relation: (L:) or were corrupt: (T, Ṣ,* TA:) [for] AisotijoraAHN signifies [also] the being faulty, defective, and corrupt. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, qado waEaZotukumo falamo tazodaAduwA Uil-aA QsotijoraAHFA: (Ṣ, A:) these words are from a xuTobap of ’AbdEl-Melik; and the meaning is, [I have admonished you and ye have not increased save] in corrupt conduct: or in what gaineth for you censure. (TA.)
jaroHN: see the next paragraph.

juroHN a subst. from jaraHa; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) A wound; (L;) and so jaroHN↓, in its original acceptation; but some of those skilled in the science of lexicology say that the former is employed to denote the effect produced upon bodies by iron instruments and the like; and the latter, that produced upon objects of the mind by the tongue: (MF:) the pl. of the former is juruwHN and OajoraAHN [which is a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and jiraAHN; (T, A, L;) but the second of these is of rare occurrence, (Ḳ,) only used in poetry: (Ṣ, L:) [respecting the third, see what follows:] jiraAHapN↓ also signifies the same as juroHN; (Mṣb;) and its pl. is jiraAHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jiraAHaAtN (A, Mṣb) and jaraAYiHu; (A;) or jiraAHN is a coll. gen. n., of which jiraAHapN is the n. un.; or, accord. to Az, this last has not a sing. sense, as Lth asserts it to have, but is a pl. of juroHN, like as HijaArapN is of HajarN, and jimaAlapN of jamalN, and HibaAlapN of HabolN. (L.)

juroHapN ‡ A thing whereby testimony is invalidated, or its claim to be legally credible annulled: as in the saying, halo laka juroHapN ‡ [Hast thou anything to adduce whereby to invalidate the testimony?]. (A, TA.) OaqoSaSotuka AljuroHapa faUino kaAna Einodaka maA tajoraHu bihi AlHuj-apa fahalum-ahaA, said by the judge of El-Medeeneh to one of the parties in a lawsuit, when about to give judgment against him, means ‡ I authorize thee to adduce anything whereby to invalidate the testimony: [therefore, if thou have anything whereby thou mayest invalidate the allegation, adduce it.] (A,* TA.)

jariyHN; pl. jaroHaI; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) each of which is masc. and fem.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Wounded. (Mṣb.) The pl. is not formed by the addition of w and n because the fem. is not formed by the addition of p. (TA.)
jiraAHapN: see juroHN.
jaraAYiHiI-N: see what next follows.
jar-aAHN A surgeon that dresses wounds. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof; and so in the present day; as also jaraAYiHiI-N↓.)
jaAriHapN sing. of jawaAriHu. (Mgh, L, Mṣb, TA.)

The latter signifies ‡ Beasts, and birds, of prey; or that catch game; (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus the falcon is a jArHp, and so is the dog trained for hunting, because it gains for its owner: (L:) and this appellation is applied alike to the male and the female, like raAHilapN and raAwiyapN. (Mṣb.)

And ‡ The members, or limbs, of a man, with which things are gained or earned; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) or with which one works; (A;) as the hands or arms, and the feet or legs: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) because they gain, or earn, or do, good and evil. (TA.)
[And ‡ The organs of the body: thus, for instance, jArHp is applied (in the Mṣb, art. bSr,) to the eye, which is termed (in the TA in that art.) the seeing jArHp (AljaAriHapu Aln-aAZirapu).]

Also † Mares: [and the like:] because they bring gain to their owners by their breeding. (AA, T.) You say, maA lahu jaAriHapN † He possesses not a female beast that bears young: he possesses not that which makes gain. (TA.) And hecihi Aln-aAqapu mino jawaAriHi AlmaAli, and hch AlOataAnu, (Ḳ,) and hch Alfarasu, (TA,) † This she-camel, and this she-ass, and this mare, is young, unimpaired by age (muqobilapN [i. q. muqotabalapN]) in the womb, (Ḳ, TA,) and in youthful vigour, and one of which the offspring is wished for. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jarada, aor. _u {yajorudu}, inf. n. jarodN: see 2, in nine places.
jarada AljaraAdu AlOaroDa, (A, L, Mṣb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) ‡ The locusts stripped the land of all its herbage; (A,* L;) ate what was upon the land. (Mṣb.)
jaradahumu AljaAruwdu ‡ [The year of drought destroyed them]. (A.)
juridati AlOaroDu † The land had its herbage eaten by locusts; (Ṣ;) was smitten by locusts. (Mṣb.)
jurida said of seed-produce, † It was smitten [or eaten] by locusts. (Ḳ.)
And said of a man, (Ṣ,) † He had a complaint of his belly from having eaten locusts. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jarida, aor. _a {yajoradu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaradN, (TA,) ‡ It (a place) was, or became, destitute of herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)
† He (a man) had no hair upon him [i. e. upon his body, or, except in certain parts: see Oajoradu]. (Ṣ: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.)
‡ He (a horse, Ḳ, TA, or similar beast, TA) had short hair: (TA:) or had short and fine hair: as also Anjrd↓. (Ḳ, TA.) [See Oajoradu.]
See also 7.
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) † He (a man, Ṣ) became affected with the cutaneous eruption termed XarFI, from having eaten locusts. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

2. jr-d, (A, L,) inf. n. tajoriydN, (Ṣ, A, L,) He stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, of garments, or clothes. (Ṣ, A, L.) You say, jr-dhu mino viyaAbihi, (A,) or mn vawobihi, (Th, L, Ḳ,) as also jaradahu↓, (Ḳ,) and jr-dhu vawobahu, (Th, L,) He stripped, divested, or denuded, him of his garments, or of his garment: (Th, A, L, Ḳ:) [this is the only signification of the verb given in the A as proper; its other significations given in that lexicon being there said to be tropical:] or jar-adotuhu mino viyaAbihi signifies I pulled off from him his garments: and jaradotu↓ AlX-aIoCa, aor. _u {yajorudu}, inf. n. jarodN, † I removed from the thing that which was upon it. (Mṣb.)
† He stripped skin of its hair; as also jarada↓. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ It (drought) rendered the earth, or land, bare of herbage: so in the L and other lexicons: in the Ḳ, jarada↓: but the former is the right. (TA.)
† I. q. Xc-b [generally signifying He pruned a tree or plant]. (Ṣ, TA.)
‡ [He bared a sword;] he drew forth a sword (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) from its scabbard; (A;) as also jarada↓ (TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ in the place of the former verb,) aor. as above. (TA.)
[† He detached a company from an army: see jariydapN.]
[† He divested a thing of every accessory, adjunct, appendage, or adventitious thing; rendered it bare, shere, or mere.]

† He made the writing, or book, (L, Ḳ,) and the copy of the Ḳur-án, (L,) free from syllabical signs, (L, Ḳ,) and from additions and prefaces: (L:) he divested the Ḳur-án of the diacritical points, and of the vowel-signs of desinential syntax, and the like: (Ibrá- heem [En-Nakha'ee]:) or he wrote it, or read it, or recited it, without connecting with it any of the stories, or traditions, related by the Jews or Christians. (Ibn'Oyeyneh, accord. to the L; or AʼObeyd, accord. to the TA.)

jr-d AlquTona, and jaradahu↓, † He separated the cotton from its seeds, with a miHolaAj: or separated and loosened it by means of a bow and a kind of wooden mallet, by striking the string of the bow with the mallet: syn. Halajahu. (Ḳ.)

jr-d AlHaj-a, (ISb, Ḳ,) and tjr-d↓ biAlHaj-i, (TA,) which latter alone is mentioned by Z and Ibn-El-Jowzee, (MF,) † He performed the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage (AlHaj-) separately from those of AlEumorap [q. v.]: (ISh, Z, Ibn-El-Jowzee, Ḳ:) or the former signifies he made the performance of the pilgrimage to be free from the vitiations of worldly desires and objects. (Ḥar p. 392.) [See also 5.]
jur-ida liloqiyaAmi bikacaA: see 5.
jr-d Alqawoma; (Ḳ;) and jaradahumo↓, (L, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (L;) † He asked, or begged, of the people, or company of men, and they refused him, or gave him against their will. (L, Ḳ.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He wore, or put on, juruwd, i. e., old and wornout garments. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tjr-d He was, or became, stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and he stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, himself,] mino viyaAbihi of his clothes or garments, (A,* Mṣb,) or mn vawobihi of his garment; (L, Ḳ;*) as also Anjrd↓, (A, L, Ḳ,) which latter, accord. to Sb, is not a quasi-pass. verb, (L,) [but it seems that he did not know jarada, in a sense explained above, (see 2, second sentence,) of which it is the quasipass, like as tjr-d is of jr-d.]
‡ It (an ear of corn, A, Ḳ, and a flower, TA) came forth from its envelope, or calyx. (A, Ḳ, TA.)
† It (expressed juice) ceased to boil, or estuate, (Ḳ,) [and so became divested of its froth, or foam.]
† He (a man) was, or became, alone, by himself, apart from others; as though detached from the rest of men. (Ḥar p. 430.)

tjr-d liloOamori ‡ [He devoted himself to the affair, as though throwing aside all other things; he applied himself exclusively and diligently to it;] he strove or laboured, exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, employed himself vigorously or diligently or with energy, or took pains or extraordinary pains, in the affair, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 430,) not diverted therefrom by any other thing. (Ḥar ib.) And tjr-d liloEibaAdapi ‡ [He devoted himself TO, applied himself exclusively and diligently to, or strove, &c. in, religious service, or worship]. (A.) And jur-ida↓ liloqiyaAmi bikacaA ‡ [He devoted himself to, applied himself exclusively and diligently to, or strove, &c. in, the performance of such a thing]. (A.) And tjr-d fiI Als-ayori, and Anjrd↓, ‡ He strove or laboured, exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, in pace, or going; he hastened therein; like Xam-ara fiI sayorihi. (L, TA.)

tjr-d biAlHaj-i: see 2. Accord. to Aḥmad, as related by Is-ḥáḳ Ibn-Manṣoor, (TA,) † He affected to be like, or he imitated, the pilgrim of Mekkeh, or the man performing the pilgrimage of Mekkeh. (Ḳ, TA.)
7. Anjrd: see 5, first sentence. [Hence,] Anjrdti AlUibilu mino OawobaArihaA † The camels cast, or let fall, their fur, or soft hair. (L.)
See also 1.
† It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became threadbare, or napless, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and smooth; (Ṣ, L;) as also jarida↓. (L.)
Said of a horse in a race: see 5.
Anjrd fiI Als-ayori: see 5.

Anjrd binaA Als-ayoru, (Ṣ, A, L,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, Anjrd bihi Als-ayolu, (TA,) ‡ The journey, or march, (Ṣ, A, L,) became extended, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and of long duration, [with us,] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) without our pausing or waiting for anything. (A.)
8. AjtrAd † The attacking one another with [drawn] swords. (KL.) [You say, AjtrdwA † They so attacked one another; like as you say, ADTrbwA.]

hom.sense: jarodN ‡ A garment old and worn out, (L, Ḳ, TA,) of which the nap has fallen off: or one between that which is new and that which is old and worn out: pl. juruwdN. (L, TA.) You say burodapN jarodN, (A,) and jarodapN↓ [alone], (Ṣ, L, TA,) ‡ A [garment of the kind called] brdp worn so that it has become smooth. (Ṣ, A, L, TA.*) And [the pl.] juruwdN, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK jaruwd,) as a subst., (TA,) † Old and worn-out garments. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr, layosa EinodanaA mino maAli Almusolimiyna Uil-aA jarodu hecihi AlqaTiyfapi, meaning † There is not in our possession, of the property of the Muslims, save this threadbare and worn-out qTyfp. (TA.)
† The pudendum, or pudenda; [app. because usually shaven, or depilated;] syn. farojN, (Ḳ,) i. e. EaworapN. (TA.)
And † The penis. (Ḳ.)
† A shield. (Ḳ.)
† A remnant of property, or of cattle. (Ḳ.)
See also jariydapN.

entry.sense: jurodN: see jariydapN.

hom.sense: jaradN † A wide, or spacious, tract of land in which is no herbage: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) an inf. n. used as an appellative subst. (A.)
rumiIa EalaI jaradihi and Oajoradihi↓ † He (a man, TA) was shot, or struck with a missile, on his back. (Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jaridN, (Ḳ,) fem. with p {jaridapN}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Oajoradu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) fem. jarodaMCu; (A, Ḳ;) and jaradN↓, (TA, as from the Ḳ,) which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) ‡ A place (A, Ḳ) destitute of herbage: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) you say OaroDN jaridapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jarodaMCu↓ (A, Ḳ) and jaradiy-apN↓, (TA,) and faDaMCN Oajoradu↓: of which last the pl. is [jurodN and] OajaAridu. (Ṣ.)
Also, the first, † A man affected with the cutaneous eruption termed XarFI, from having eaten locusts. (TA.)
jarodapN: see jarodN.
Also † An old worn piece of rag: dim. jurayodapN↓. (TA from a trad.)

jurodapN [The denuded, or unclad, part, or parts, of the body]. You say AimoraOapN baD-apu Aljurodapi (A,* Ḳ) and Almujar-adi↓ (A, Ḳ) and Almutajar-adi↓, (T, A, Ḳ,) [A woman thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump, in respect of the denuded, or unclad, part, or parts of the body: or] when divested of clothing: (T, A,* Ḳ:) the last of these words is here an inf. n.: if you say Almutajar-idi↓, with kesr, you mean, [in] the [denuded] body: (Ḳ:) [and so when you say Aljurodapi, and Almujar-adi; or this last may be regarded as an inf. n.:] Almtjr-ad is more common than Almtjr-id. (TA.) [In like manner,] you say, fulaAnN Hasanu Aljurodapi and Almujar-adi↓ and Almutajar-ad↓; like as you say, Hasanu AlEuroyapi and AlmuEar-aI, which signify the same. (Ṣ.) It is said of Moḥammad, kaAna Oanowara Almutajar-adi↓, i. e. He was bright in respect of what was unclad of his body, or person. (TA.)
Also † Plain, or level, and bare, land. (Ṣ.)

AljurodaAnu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Almujar-adu↓ and AlOajoradu↓ (Ḳ) † The yard of a horse, &c.: (Ṣ:) or of a solidhoofed animal: or it is of general application: (Ḳ:) or originally of a man; and metaphorically of any other animal: (TA:) pl. (of the first, TA) jaraAdiynu. (Ḳ.)
jaradiy-apN: see jaridN.

jaraAdN [a coll. gen. n., ‡ Locusts; the locust; a kind of insect] well known: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called from stripping the ground, (A, Mṣb,) i. e., eating what is upon it: (Mṣb:) n. un. with jrAd: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) applied alike to the male and the female: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) jrAdp is not the masc. of baqarN, but is a [coll.] gen. n.; these two words being like baqarN and baqarapN, andtamorN and tamorapN, and HamaAmN and HamaAmapN, &c.: it is therefore necessary that the masc. should be [in my copies of the Ṣ, “should not be,” but this is corrected in the margin of one of those copies,] of the same form as the fem., lest it should be confounded with the pl. [or rather the collective form]: (Ṣ:) but some say that jrAd is the masc.; and jrAdp, the fem.; and the saying raOayatu jaraAdFA EalaI jaraAdapK [as meaning I saw a male locust upon a female locust], like raOayotu naEaAmFA EalaI naEaAmapK, is cited: (TA:) it is first called sirowapN; then, dabFI; then, gawogaMCu; then, xayofaAnN; then, kutofaAnN; and then, jrAd: (AʼObeyd, TA:)
Aṣ says that when the males become yellow and the females become black, they cease to have any name but jrAd. (AḤn, TA.) [Hence,] Aibonu AljaraAdi, (T in art. bnI) or Abn AljaraAdapi (TA in that art.,) † The egg of the locust. (T and TA ubi suprà.)
maA OadoriI OaI-u jaraAdK EaArahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or OaI-u AljaraAdi, (A, L,) ‡ I know not what man, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or what thing, (A,) took him, or it, away. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jariydN [a coll. gen. n.], n. un. jariydapN↓: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the latter is of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN; (Mṣb;) signifying ‡ A palm-branch stripped of its leaves; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as long as it has the leaves on it, it is not called thus, but is called saEafapN: (Ṣ:) or a palm-branch in whatever state it be; in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: (TA:) or a dry palm-branch: (AAF, Ḳ:) or a long fresh palm-branch: (Ḳ:) pl. jaraAYidu. (TA.)
[Also, jariydapN↓, † A tally, by which to keep accounts; because a palm-stick is used for this purpose; notches being cut in it.]
[And hence, jariydapu↓ HisaAbK † An accountbook: and jariydapu↓ AlxaraAji † The register of the taxes, or of the land-tax.]
UibilN jariydapN ‡ Choice, or excellent, (A, L,) and strong, (L,) camels. (A, L.)
See also Oajoradu, in two places.

entry.sense: juraAdapN † Anything that is peeled off, or pared, from another thing. (Ṣ.)
jariydapN n. un. of jariydN as a coll. gen. n.: see the latter in four places.
Also fem. of the latter as an epithet.

Also ‡ A detachment of horsemen; a company of horsemen detached (jur-idato, Ṣ, A) from the rest of the force, (Ṣ,) or from the main body of the horsemen, (A,) in some direction, or for same object: (Ṣ, A:) or a company of horsemen among whom are no footsoldiers, nor any of the baser sort, or of those of whom no account is made: (A:) or horsemen among whom are no foot-soldiers; (Ḳ;) as also jurodN↓ [as though pl. of OajoradN], (Ḳ, TA,) with damm, (TA,) or jarodN↓. (So in the CK.) [See an ex. under the word bayotN, last sentence.]
jurayodaMCu dim. of jarodaMCu [fem. of Oajoradu]: so in the phrase jurayodaMCu Almatoni † The middle of the back of the neck, which is free from flesh. (L.)
jar-aAdN † One who polishes brazen vessels. (Ḳ.)
jaAruwdN ‡ An unlucky man; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one who strips off prosperity by his ill luck; (A;) or as though he stripped off prosperity by his ill luck. (TA.)
Also, and jaAruwdapN↓, (A,) or sanapN jaAruwdN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ A year of drought: (A, Ḳ:) or a year of severe drought and dryness of the earth; (Ṣ;) as though it destroyed men. (TA.)
jaAruwdapN: see what next precedes.

AljaAruwdiy-apN A sect of the Zeydeeyeh, (of the Shee'ah, TA,) so called in relation to Abu-lJárood Ziyád the son of Aboo-Ziyád: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Abu-l-Járood being he who was named by the Imám El-Bákir “Surhoob,” explained by him as a devil inhabiting the sea: they held that Moḥammad appointed ʼAlee and his descendants to the office of Imám, describing them, though not naming them; and that the Companions were guilty of infidelity in not following the example of ʼAlee, after the Prophet: also that the appointment to the office of Imám, after El-Ḥasan and El-Hoseyn, was to be determined by a council of their descendants; and that he among them who proved himself learned and courageous [above others] was Imám. (MF.)

hom.sense: Oajoradu ‡ A man having no hair upon him; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) i. e., upon his body; or except in certain parts, as the line along the middle of the bosom and downwards to the belly, and the arms from the elbows downwards, and the legs from the knees downwards; contr. of OaXoEaru, which signifies “having hair upon the whole of the body:” (IAth, L:) [fem. jarodaMCu: and] pl. jurodN. (A, TA.) The people of Paradise are said (in a trad., TA) to be jurodN murodN ‡ [Having no hair upon their bodies, and beardless]. (A, TA.)

Also applied to a horse, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and any similar beast, (TA,) meaning ‡ Having short hair: (TA:) or having short and fine hair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) This is approved, (Ṣ,) and is one of the signs of an excellent and a generous origin. (TA.) Pl. as above. (A.) In like manner, Oajoradu AlqawaAYimi means ‡ Having short, or short and fine, hair upon the legs. (TA.)
Also ‡ A check upon which no hair has grown. (TA.) And † A sandal upon which is no hair. (L from a trad.)
Applied also to a place; and the fem., jarodaMCu, to land: see jaridN, in three places.
Also ‡ Milk free from froth. (A.) And the fem., † Wine that is clear, (AḤn, Ḳ,) free from dregs. (AḤn, TA.) And † A sky free from clouds. (L.)
† Smooth. (Ḥam p. 413.)
† A heart free from concealed hatred, and from deceit, dishonesty, or dissimulation. (L.)

‡ Complete; (A, Ḳ;) free from deficiency; (A, TA;) as also jariydN↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) applied to a year (EaAmN), (Ṣ, A,) and to a month, (Th, TA,) and to a day: (Ḳ:) fem. as above, applied to a year (sanapN). (A.) Accord. to Ks, (Ṣ,) you say, maA raOayotuhu muco OajoradaAni and mc jariydaAni↓, meaning ‡ [I have not seen him, or it, for, or during,] two days, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or two months, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or two years,] complete. (A, TA.)
‡ A horse wont to outstrip others; (Ḳ;) that outstrips others, and becomes separate from them by his swiftness. (IJ, TA.)
And the fem., ‡ A voracious she-camel. (A.)
It is also used as a subst.: see jaradN:
and see AljurodaAnu.
Also † The sea. (AAF, M in art. jrb.)
And the fem., † A smooth rock. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: Uijorid-N, and sometimes without teshdeed, UijoridN, A certain plant which indicates the places where truffles (kamoOap) are to be found: a certain herb, or leguminous plant, said to have grains like pepper. (En-Naḍr, TA.)
mujoradN † A man ejected from his property. (IAạr, TA.)

hom.sense: mujar-adN: see jurodapN, in two places.
‡ A bare, or naked, [or drawn,] sword. (A.)
[† Divested of every accessory, adjunct, appendage, or adventitious thing; rendered bare, shere, or mere; abstract.]
