[In philosophy, Bodiless; incorporeal; as though divested of body.]
See also AljurodaAnu.

entry.sense: majoruwdN † Peeled, or pared; divested of its peel, bark, coat, covering, or the like. (Ṣ, L.)

OaroDN majoruwdapN † Land of which the herbage has been eaten by locusts: (Ṣ:) or land smitten by locusts: (Mṣb:) or land abounding with locusts; (AʼObeyd, ISd, Ḳ;) a phrase similar to OaroDN mawoHuwXapN; the epithet having the form of a pass. part. n. without a verb unless it be one that is imaginary. (ISd, TA.)
rajulN majoruwdN † A man having a complaint of his belly from having eaten locusts. (Ṣ.)
mutajar-adN and mutajar-idN: see jurodapN, in four places:
and see what follows.
munojaridN † A horse having short, and little, hair: (EM pp. 39 and 40:) or sharp, or vigorous, in pace, [and] having little hair. (Ḥar p. 455.)

maA Oanota bimunojaridi Als-iloki, (AZ, A, TA,) or bimotaj-r-idi↓ Als-iloki, (so in a copy of the A,) said to one who is shy, or bashful, [meaning † Thou art] not free from shyness in appearing [before others]: (AZ, TA:) or ‡ thou art not celebrated, or well-known. (A, TA.)

Q. 1. jarodaba [from jarodabaAnu] He put his hand upon the food (Ḳ, TA) that was before him on the table, (TA,) in order that no other person might take it: (Ḳ, TA:) or he ate with his right hand, and prevented [others from eating] with his left hand: (IAạr, Ḳ:) also, (Ḳ,) or jrdb EalaI AlT-aEaAmi, (TA,) he ate greedily, gluttonously, or voraciously: (Ḳ, TA:) or jrdb fiI AlT-aEaAmi he put his left hand upon food that was before him on the table, in order that no other person might take it; as also jarodama: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ:) or jrdb maA fiI AlUinaMCi he ate, and made an end of, devoured, or consumed, what was in the vessel; as also jrdm [q. v.]. (Sh, TA.)
jarodabiI-N: see what next follows, in two places.

jarodabaAnN, an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the Persian, (Ṣ,) originally Girodaho baAno “guardian of the cake of bread,” (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jurodubaAnN and jarodabiI-N↓ and mujarodibN↓, (Ḳ,) One who puts his hand, (Ḳ,) or who puts his left hand, (Ṣ,) upon food, (Ḳ,) or upon a thing that is before him on the table, (Ṣ,) in order that no other person may take it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or who eats with his right hand, and prevents [others from eating] with his left hand: and one who eats greedily, gluttonously, or voraciously: or the first and ↓third signify, (Ḳ, TA,) or signify also, ‡ a spunger; (Ḳ, TA;) because of his greediness, gluttony, or voraciousness, and his boldness. (TA.) A poet says, (namely, El-Ghanawee, TA voce jarodabiylN,)
UicaA maA kunota fiI qawomK XahaAwaI
falaA tajoEalo XimaAlaka jarodabaAnaA
[When thou art among a greedy company of men, put not thy left hand upon the food as a jrdbAn]: (Fr, Ṣ:) or the last word is jarodabiylaA, meaning, (accord. to Sh, as also jarodabaAn, TA voce jrdbyl,) one that takes a fragment [of food] with his left hand, and eats with his right hand, and, when what the party have is consumed, eats what is in his left hand. (TA.)
mujarodibN: see jarodabaAnN.
jarodabiylN: i. q. jarodabaAnN, explained in art. jrdb.

jarodaqN and jarocaqN, (T, JK, TA,) or jarodaqapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jarocaqapN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) the last asserted by IAạr to have been heard by him from a man of chaste speech, (TA,) A cake of bread: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) arabicized words, (T, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) from Girodaho, (Ḳ, TA,) which is Persian, meaning “round:” (TA:) pl. jaraAdiqu and jaraAciqu. (JK.)

Q. 1. jarodamapN, [inf. n. of jarodama,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in relation to food, (Ṣ,) i. q. jarodabapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., The covering the food that is before one with the left hand, [while eating with the right hand,] in order that no other person may take it: accord. to Yaạḳoob, the m is a substitute for the b. (TA.) And jarodama signifies He ate, made an end of, devoured, or consumed, what was in the bowl or vessel: (IAạr, Sh, Ḳ, TA:) and he ate entirely the bread. (Ḳ.)
Also jrdm, He talked much. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick; (Kr, Ḳ;) as also jrcm. (Ḳ.)
jrdm Als-it-iyna He passed the [age of] sixty. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
jarodamN [probably Voracious: see above: and hence,]
Black locusts, having green heads. (Ḳ.)
Loquacious; or a great talker. (Ḳ.)
1. jaraca, inf. n. jarocN, ‡ He (a horse [or similar beast]) became affected with the kind of swelling termed jaracN [q. v. infrà]. (A.)

jaracat AlqaroHapu † The wound, or ulcer, formed itself into a knot, or lump, (taEaq-adat,) like what is termed jaracN, or juracN. (Ḳ, accord. to different copies. [The former reading is app. the right.])
2. jr-c ‡ He trimmed a tree, as though by removing its jarac, meaning its faulty parts, or knots, which are likened to jirocaAn [pl. of juracN]: whence rajulN mujar-acN↓. (A.)
[And hence,] jr-chu Ald-ahoru ‡ Time, or fortune, tried and strengthened him by means of experience in affairs. (T, L, TA.)

jaracN ‡ Any swelling, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) and inflation of the sinews, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, L,) in the hock (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ) of a horse (AʼObeyd, Mgh, L) or similar beast; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in the side of the hock-joint, externally and internally; (AʼObeyd, Mgh, L;) derived from juracN, because resembling in form the rat (fOr) thus called: (Mgh:) or an inflation of the sinews of a horse's legs, occasioning swellings which are likened to [the rats called] jirocaAn: (A:) or a swelling in the side of a horse's hoof, and in his stifle-joint (vafinap), or in the hinder part of his hock, which grows so large as to prevent his walking and working; also written jaradN; (ISh, L in arts. jrc and jrd;) and likewise affecting the camel: (ISh, L in art. jrc:) the original word is with c. (TA.)
Also ‡ The faulty parts, or knots, of a tree, which are pared off; likened to jirocaAn. (A.)
OaroDN jaricapN Land containing, (Ṣ, L,) or abounding with, (Ḳ,) [the large field-rats called] jirocaAn; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) like ArD faYirapN. (A.)

daAb-apN jaricN, (M, L,) or farasN jaricN, (Mgh,) ‡ A beast, or horse, affected with the kind of swelling termed jaracN. (M, Mgh, L.) And rajulN jaricu Alr-ijolayoni ‡ [A man whose legs are affected with similar swellings]. (M, L, TA.)

juracN [The large field-rat; so in the present day;] a species of faOor [or rat]: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ:) or the male fOr: (T, M, IAmb, L, Mṣb:) or the large male fOr; said to be larger than the jerboa, of a dusky colour, with a blackness in his tail: (L:) or the large fOr that is in the deserts, or uncultivated plains, and that does not frequent, or keep to, houses: (Mṣb:) pl. jirocaAnN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or jurocaAnN. (TA.) Okovara Qll-ehu jirocaAna bayotika [lit. May God multiply the large rats of thy house, or tent,] means ‡ may God fill thy house, or tent, with wheat, or food. (A.) And tafar-aqato jircaAnu bayotihi [lit. The large rats of his house, or tent, became dispersed,] has a contr. meaning. (Ḥar p. 274.)

Oum-u jirocaAnK A sort of dates, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a large size: before the fruit is cut [from the tree], rats collect beneath: so called when fresh and ripe: when dry, kabiysN: called in El-Koofeh muwXaAnN: (L:) and a sort of palm-tree, the last in the time of the ripening of its fruit in El-Ḥijáz: (Aṣ, AḤn, L:) or [simply] the palm-tree. (T in art. Am.) Hence the saying, UicaA TalaEati AlxaraAtaAno Oukilato Oum-u jirocaAno [When El-Kharátán (the Eleventh Mansion of the Moon) rises aurorally (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl), the dates called Am- jrcAn are eaten]: for El-Khará- tán rises [aurorally] in the last part of the hot season, after the [auroral] rising of suhayol [or Canopus], and before the season called AlS-afariIF. (AḤn, L.)
jirocaAnapN (in the CK jarocaAnapN) A sort of date: pl. jaraAciynu. (Ḳ.)

mujar-adN ‡ A man freed from his faults by experience in affairs: see 2: (A:) or an intelligent, or a sagacious, man: (M, L:) one who has been tried and strengthened by experience in affairs. (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.)
jarocaqN and jarocaqapN: see jrdq.
Q. 1. jarocama, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jarocamapN, (L,) He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick, (L, Ḳ,) in walking, or going, and in work; (L;) like jrdm. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. jarazahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _u {yajoruzu}, inf. n. jarozN, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) He cut it; or cut it off. (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mgh, TA.) You say also, jurizati AlOaroDu, meaning, The land had its herbage cut, or cut off: (A:) or became without herbage; its herbage having been consumed by the locusts or the sheep or goats or the camels or the like: (Fr, TA:) and jarizati AlOaroDu, aor. _a {yajorazu}, signifies [the same, or] the land became what is termed juruz; as also Oajorazat↓. (TA.)
It (time, or fortune, Alz-amaAnu,) destroyed, exterminated, or extirpated, him or it. (A, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He slew him. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also jaraza (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He ate quickly. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And jaruza, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaraAzapN, (TA,) He ate much; was a great eater; (Ḳ, TA;) not leaving anything upon the table: (TA:) or (Ḳ and TA, but in the CK “and”) he ate quickly; was a quick eater. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Ajrzt AlOaroDu: see 1.

Ajrz Alqawomu, from OaroDN juruzN, (Ṣ,) is a phrase similar to juruz, (Ṣ, TA,) and signifies The people journeyed in a land such as is termed juruz: (TA in art. ybs:) also (TA) they were, or became, afflicted with dearth, scarcity, drought, sterility, or barrenness. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And hence, app.,] Ajrzt Aln-aAqapu The she-camel became lean, or emaciated. (Ḳ.)
jarozN: see juruzN; in two places.
jurozN: see juruzN.
jarazN: see juruzN.
Also sanapN jarazN A year of dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) pl. OajoraAzN. (Ṣ, TA.)

OaroDN juruzN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jurozN↓, and jarazN↓, and jarozN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and majoruwzapN↓, (Ḳ,) Land in which is no herbage; (Fr, Ṣ, Mgh;) as though the herbage or the rain were cut off from it: (Ṣ:) or from which the water is cut off, so that it is dried up and without herbage: (Mṣb, in explanation of the first:) or dried up, producing no herbage: (Jel in xviii. 7, in explanation of the first:) or of which the herbage has been cut: (Bḍ ibid., in explanation of the first; and A in explanation of the last:) or that produces no herbage: (Ḳ:) or of which the herbage has been eaten: (Ḳ: or this is the signification of the last [only] according to the Ṣ:) or not rained upon: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some of the expositions of the Ḳur, by the first is meant the land of El-Yemen: and by the second, accord. to El-'Otbee, [land] that takes, or receives, much water, and does not dry it up: and as to jarozN↓, it may be an inf. n. used as an epithet, as though meaning caAtu jarozK, i. e., of which the herbage has been eaten:
also OaroDN majoruwzapN↓ is explained as signifying land of which the herbage has been consumed by the locusts or the sheep or goats or the camels or the like: (TA:) and mafaAzapN mijoraAzN↓ a barren desert: (A,* Ḳ:) [see also jaArizN:] the pl. of jurozN is jirazapN, like as jiHarapN is pl. of juHorN; and that of jarazN is OajoraAzN, like as OasobaAbN is pl. of sababN: (Ṣ:) and one says also OaroDN OajoraAzN, (Ḳ, TA,) as well as OaraDuwna OajoraAzN. (TA.)

jarozapN, (Ṣ, A,) or jarazapN↓, with fet-ḥ to the r, (Ḳ, TA,) Extirpation: (Ṣ, A:) or destruction. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the saying, lano taroDaI XaAniYapN Uil-aA bijarozapK A female that hates, by reason of the vehemence of her hatred, will not be content save with extirpation [of the object of her hatred]: (Ṣ:) or lamo yaroDa XaAniYuhu Uil-aA bijarozapK, (A,) or bajarazapK↓, (TA,) His hater was not content save with extirpation of him whom he hated. (A, TA.) You say also, ramaAhu Qll-ehu biXarazapK wjarazapK↓, [or biXarozapK wajarozapK, thus, only, the former word is written in the Ḳ and TA in art. Xrz, and I think that the latter is correctly written in like manner, as in the Ṣ and A,] God smote him with destruction [and extirpation]. (TA.)
jurozapN A bundle of [the kind of trefoil called] qat- (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) or the like: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a handful thereof: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. jurazN. (A,* Mgh, Mṣb.)
jarazapN: see jarozapN, in three places.
juraAzN, applied to a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Cutting, or sharp: (Ḳ:) or cutting much, or very sharp: (Ṣ:) or penetrating: or that cuts off utterly, or entirely. (TA.)
Hence you say of a she-camel, likening her to such a sword, Uin-ahaA lajuraAzN lilX-ajari † Verily she is one that eats and breaks the trees. (TA.) See also jaruwzN.

jaruwzN ‡ That eats much; (A, Ḳ;) [when applied to a man,] that leaves nothing upon the table when he eats: (Ṣ, A:) or that eats quickly: (Ḳ:) applied to a man, and to a camel; (TA;) and to a woman; and to a she-camel, as also juraAzN↓; (Ṣ;) or [any] female: (TA:) or, applied to a she-camel, that eats everything. (Aṣ, TA.)
jaArizN, applied [to land, and hence,] to ‡ a woman, Barren: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) the woman is likened to land that produces no herbage. (TA.) [See also juruzN.]
OaroDN jaArizapN Dry and rugged land encompassed by sands or by a [level tract such as is called] qaAE: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. jawaArizu: (Ṣ, TA:) mostly applied to islands of the sea. (TA.)
mujorizapN, applied to a she-camel, Lean, or emaciated. (Ḳ.)
mijoraAzN: see juruzN.
majoruwzapN: see juruzN; in two places.

1. jarasa, [aor., app., _u and _i, as seems to be implied in the Ḳ, inf. n. jarosN, which see below,] He, or it, made a sound; (TA;) as also Ajrs↓: (Mgh, TA:) [or both signify he, or it, made a low, gentle, slight, or soft, sound; as appears from what follows.] You say, jarasa biAlkalaAmi, (A,) or jarasa AlkalaAma, (Mṣb,) He spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, voice or tone; or with modulation, or melody; syn. nagama fiyhi, (A,) or nagama bihi. (Mṣb.) And jarasa, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jarosN; (Ḳ;) and tjr-K↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He spoke: (Ḳ:) or he said a thing, and spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, voice or tone, or with modulation or melody; expl. by takal-ama biXaIoCK watanag-ama. (Lth, Ṣ.) And Ajrs↓ is also used in the senses here following. It (a bird) caused the sound of its passing to be heard: (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ:) and in like manner it is said of a man. (Ḳ, accord. to the TA; but not found by me in any copy of the Ḳ.) ↓And ‡ It (an ornament, HaloIN,) made a sound (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ) like that of a jaras [or bell]; (TA;) as also Anjrs↓. (A, TA.) ↓And It (a tribe, HaI-N,) made its sound (jaros) to be heard: or, accord. to the T, made the sound of the jaros of a thing to be heard. (TA.) ↓And He (a man) raised his voice. (TA.) ↓And He (a camel-driver) sang to camels for the purpose of urging or exciting: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or raised his voice in doing so. (A.)

[Hence, app.,] jarasa, aor. _u {yajorusu}, (Lth, AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and _i, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jarosN, (Lth, AO, Ḳ,) He ate [a thing: because a slight sound is made in doing so]: (AO, TA:) or he licked [a thing] with his tongue. (Ḳ.) You say, jarasat Aln-aHolu AlEurofuTa The bees ate the [trees called] ErfT: (Ṣ) and jarasati Aln-awora, (Lth, A,) and AlEasala [put tropically for Aln-awora because honey is made from flowers or blossoms], (Lth, TA,) the bees ate the flowers, or blossoms, making a sound in so doing: (A:) or licked the flowers, or blossoms, and thence made honey. (Lth, TA.) And jarasati AlmaAXiyapu AlX-ajara, and AlEuXoba, The beasts licked the trees, and the herbage. (TA.) And jarasati Albaqarapu waladahaA The cow licked her young one. (TA.)

hom.sense: jar-asatohu AlOumuwru, (Ṣ,) and Ald-uhuwru, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ [Events, and misfortunes,] rendered him experienced, or expert, and sound, or firm, in judgment, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA)

entry.sense: 4. Ajrs: see 1, in six places.
Ajrs biAlHaloIi ‡ [He made a sound with the ornament]: said of the owner [or wearer] of the ornament. (A.)
Ajrs Aljarasa He struck [or sounded] the bell. (TA.)
OajorasaniI Als-abuEu The animal of prey heard my sound (jarosiI): (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or heard it from afar. (TA.)
5: see 1.
7: see 1.

jarosN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jirosN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and jarasN↓ (Kr, ISd) A sound: (ISk, A, Ḳ:) or a low, faint, gentle, slight, or soft, sound: (IDrd, Ṣ A, Ḳ:) such, for instance, as the sound of the beaks of birds, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) pecking, (A,) upon a thing which they are eating: (Ṣ:) and that of bees eating flowers or blossoms: (A:) and of a tribe [or crowd of men, more particularly as heard from some distance; i. e., a hum]: (TA:) and of a camel-driver singing to his beasts to urge or excite them: (A:) and the slight sound of a letter of the alphabet: (TA:) and low, gentle, or soft, speech: (Mṣb:) or when the word is used alone, [i. e., not coupled with another noun as it is in the second of the two examples here following,] it is with fet-ḥ: thus one says, maA samiEotu lahu jarosFA; (A, Ḳ;) i. e., I heard not any sound of him, or it: (TA:) but you say, maA samiEotu lahu His-FA walaA jirosFA↓, with kesr; (A, Ḳ;) i. e., I heard not any motion, nor any sound, of him, or it: (TA in art. Hs:) pl. [app. of the third] OajoraAsN. (Ḥam p. 200.) [See also jaroXN.]
jirosN: see what next precedes, in two places.

hom.sense: jarasN [A bell;] a thing well known; (Mṣb;) the thing that is hung to the neck of the camel (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) &c., and that makes a sound: (Mgh:) or, accord. to some, the [little round bell called] julojul: (TA:) and also that which is struck [to make it sound]: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the thing that is struck by the Christians at the times of prayers: (Ḥar p. 616:) pl. OjoraAsN. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., laA taSoHabu AlmalaAYikapu rufoqapF fiyhaA jarasN [The angels will not accompany an assemblage of persons journeying together among whom is a bell]: (Ṣ, TA:) the reason is said to be, because it guides others to them; for Moḥammad liked not to let the enemy know of his approach until he came upon them suddenly. (TA.)
See also jarosN.

entry.sense: jurosapN The act of rendering [a person or persons] notorious, or infamous. (TA.) [See 2.]
jaAruwsN Voracious. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
jawaArisu [as though pl. of jaArisapN] Bees: (Ṣ:) or bees eating flowers, or blossoms, and making a sound in doing so: (A:) or jawaArisu Aln-aHoli signifies the males of bees. (TA.)

jaAwarosN [A species of millet;] a kind of grain, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) resembling curap, but smaller: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to some, a species of duxon: (Mṣb:) or i. q. duxonN: (Ṣ in art. dxn, and TA in art. dxl:) or a well-known grain, which is eaten, like duxon, of which there are three species, the best whereof is the yellow [AlSfr, or the word may be AlASgr, the smallest,] and weighty: it is likened to rice in its power, or virtue, is more astringent than duxon, promotes the flow of urine, and constringes: the word is arabicized, from [the Persian] GaAwiroso. (TA.)

mujar-asN (Ṣ) and mujar-isN (TA) ‡ A man (TA) experienced, or expert, in affairs, (Ṣ, TA,) and rendered sound, or firm, in judgment, &c. (TA.) And with p {mujar-asapN}, ‡ A she-camel tried and proved by use, or practice, in pace and riding. (TA.)
majoruwsN [Uttered with a sound: or with a low, gentle, slight, or soft, sound]. Every letter of the alphabet is majoruwsap, except the soft letters, (A, TA,) namely, wA, and I. (TA.)

1. jaraXahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoruXu} (MṢ, Ḳ) and _i {yajoriXu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaroXN, (A, TA,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and he ground it, namely, salt, and grain, (A,) coarsely, not finely. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
He stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its superficial part; syn. qaXarahu. (Ḳ.)
He scratched, scraped, rubbed, grated, chafed, or fretted, it; syn. Hak-ahu; (Ḳ, TA;) like as the viper does its fangs; when its folds rub, or grate, together, causing a sound to be head. (TA.)
He scratched it (Hak-ahu, namely, his head,) with a comb, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) so as to raise its scurf; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jar-aXahu↓. (TA.)
He rubbed and pressed it (namely, the skin,) with the hand, in order that it might become smooth (Ḳ, TA) and soft. (TA.)
2: see 1, last signification but one.
jaroXN The sound of a viper's coming forth form the skin [or slough] when the former rubs, or grates, one part against another. (Ḳ.)
And The sound of a viper's fangs, when they rub, or grate [together]. (TA.)
And The sound arising from eating a rough thing: or this is with s. (TA.)

jariyXN A thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) such as salt, (A,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and ground, (A,) coarsely, not finely: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or, applied to salt, it signifies maAlamo yuTay-abo [app. meaning such as has not been purified], (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that crumbles; as though one part thereof were rubbed against another. (TA.)
Also Coarse flour, such as is fit for [making the kind of food called] xabiyS muram-al. (TA.)
juraAXapu XaIoCK What falls, of, or from, a thing coarsely bruised or brayed or pounded, when what is bruised, &c. thereof is taken. (Ṣ.)
juraAXapN also signifies What falls from the head when it is combed: (A, TA:) and what falls and becomes scattered from wood: (A:) or cuttings, chips, parings, and the like. (TA.)
jawaAriXN [from the Persian GuwaAriXo, A digestive stomachic;] a thing that causes food to digest; as also haADuwmN. (Ṣ in art. hDm.)
majoruwXN A thing having its superficial part stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed. (TA.)
Skin rubbed and pressed with the hand in order that it may become smooth and soft. (TA.)

1. jariDa biriyqihi, aor. _a {yajoraDu}, (IDrd, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaraDN; (IDrd, Ḳ;) or jaraDa biriyqihi, aor. _i {yajoriDu}; (Ṣ;) but IḲṭṭ says that the former is the right; (IB;) His throat, or fauces, became choked by his spittle; he was choked with his spittle: (IDrd, A:) or, accord. to some, he suffered the chokings (guSaS) of death: (TA:) or the verb is sometimes used in a general manner, in the former of the senses explained above, and in the place of gaS-a and in that of Xariqa and in that of XajiIa: (MF in art. gS, q.v.:) and the above-mentioned phrase also signifies (A) he swallowed his spittle with difficulty, or trouble, or labour, contending against anxiety, or grief. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say also, huwa yajoriDu binafosihi, (Ṣ,) or yajoraDu bnfsh, (A,* TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He is near to dying; accord. to Aṣ: (Ṣ, TA:) or his soul reaches his fauces: (TA:) or he is at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces. (A.) And yajoraDu EalaI nafosihi He dies. (TA.) And jariDati Aln-aAqapu bijir-atihaA [app. meaning The she-camel was choked with her cud: or swallowed her cud with difficulty]. (TA.) And jaraDa riyqahu He swallowed his spittle. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN yajoriDu Ealayoka riyqahu [app. meaning Such a one swallows his choler against thee]. (A.)
jaraDahu He strangled him. (Ḳ.) You say, Oafolata minohumo waqado jaraDuwhu He escaped from them when they had strangled him [so as almost to kill him]. (TA.)
4. AjrDhu biriyqihi He caused his throat, or fauces, to be choked by his spittle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jaraDN Spittle: (A, Ḳ:) or spittle by which one is choked. (Ṣ.)
[The choking, or strangulation, or rattles, immediately preceding death. See 1: and see also jariyDN.]
Difficulty, trouble, or labour; syn. jahodN. (TA.)

hom.sense: jariyDN [A man having his throat, or fauces, choked by his spittle.]

[And hence,] Having his soul reaching his fauces: or near to dying: (TA:) or at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces, so that he is choked by it: (A, TA:) or dying: (TA:) or made, or suffered, to escape, after evil: (Lth:) or oppressed by grief or sorrow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jiroyaADN↓ and jiroMDN↓: (ADk, Ḳ:) or affected by intense anxiety or grief: (TA:) [see also jar-aADN:] pl. jaroDaI; (A, Ḳ;) like as maroDaI is pl. of mariyDN. (A, TA.) You say, Oafolata fulaAnN jariyDFA, or Oufolita, Such a one escaped, or was made to escape, being near to death; (TA;) or being at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces, so that he was choked by it. (A, TA.) And maAta fulaAnN jariyDFA Such a one died oppressed by grief or sorrow. (Ṣ.)

In the following prov., HaAla AljariyDu duwna AlqariyDi [The jryD interposed as an obstacle in the way of the qryD], AljryD signifies the thing choking the throat or fauces; (Ṣ, A;) and AlqryD signifies the cud: the meaning being, the thing choking the throat or fauces hindered from chewing the cud: (A:) or the former signifies the choking, or having the throat, or fauces, obstructed; and the latter, the poetry: (TA:) or the former, the swallowing of spittle in dying; and the latter, the sound, or voice, of a man in dying: (Er-Riyáshee:) or the former, spittle swallowed: (Ḥar p. 150, q. v.:) and also, the chokings (guSaS) of death: [see also jaraDN:] and the moving to and fro of the two jaws at death: (TA:) the prov. relates to an affair which is hindered by some obstacle: (A, O, Ḳ:) or it is said on the occasion of any affair which was possible and which has been hindered by the intervention of some obstacle: and the first who said it was ʼObeyd Ibn-El-Abras, when El-Mundhir [on one of the days when it was his custom to slay whomsoever he met] desired him to recite some of his verses: (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh:) or the first who said it was Jowshan [in some copies of the Ḳ, Showshan, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,] El-Kilábee, when his father, having forbidden him to poetize, and seeing him sick of grief thereat, and at the point of death, gave him permission to do so: (Ḳ, TA:) whereupon, after saying these words, he recited some verses, and died. (TA.)
jar-aADN A strangler. (TA.)
Suffering intense, or violent, grief. (TA.) [See also jariyDN.]

entry.sense: jiroMDN: see jariyDN.
jiroyaADN: see jariyDN.

1. jariEa AlmaMCa, aor. _a {yajoraEu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaroEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or HaraEN; (Mṣb;) and jaraEahu, aor. _a {yajoraEu}, inf. n. jaroEN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but the latter is disallowed by Aṣ; (Ṣ;) He swallowed the water; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AjtrEhu↓: (Mṣb:) or the latter signifies he swallowed it at once. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also 5.

2. [jr-Ehu AlmaMCa He made him to swallow the water.] tajoriyEN is The pouring beverage into the throat against one's will: but sometimes it is used of that which is not against one's will. (Ḥar p. 115.) And jr-Ehu signifies He gave him to drink gulp after gulp, or sup after sup, or sip after sip. (Ḥar p. 350.)
[And hence,] jr-Ehu AlguSaSa, (Ḳ,) or jr-Ehu guSaSa AlgayoZi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tajoriyEN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He made him to repress, or restrain, choking wrath, or rage. (Ṣ, TA.)
4. AjrEhu He made it (a rope or a bow-string) to have one or more of its strands thick [or rather thicker than the others]. (TA.)

5. tjr-E He swallowed in consecutive portions, one time after another, like him who acts against his own will: or, as IAth says, he drank in haste: or, accord. to some, he drank by little and little. (TA.)

[And hence,] tjr-E (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) ‡ He repressed, or restrained, choking wrath, or rage; (Ṣ;) as though he swallowed it: (Mṣb:) and [in like manner] you say also, jariEa↓ AlgayoZa ‡ he repressed, or restrained, wrath, or rage. (TA.)
8: see 1.

hom.sense: jaraEN A twisting in one of the strands of a rope, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a bow-string, (Ḳ,) so that it appears above the other strands. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [It is app. an inf. n., of which the verb, if it have one, is jariEa.]
See also jaraEapN.
jaroEapN: see what next follows, in three places:
and see jaraEapN, in two places.

entry.sense: juroEapN A gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once, of water; a juroEap of water being like a luqomap of food: (Mṣb:) or a sup, or sip; or as much as is supped, or sipped, at once; or a mouthful of what is supped, or sipped; (syn. HusowapN;) of water; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaroEapN↓ and jiroEapN↓: or juroEapN and jaroEapN↓ are substs. [signifying the act of swallowing water] from jariEa AlmaMCa “he swallowed the water:” (Ḳ:) or jaroEapN↓ signifies a single act of swallowing water: (IAth, L:) and juroEapN, what one swallows: (L, Ḳ:) or a mouthful which one swallows: (TA:) or a small draught: (IAth:) and its pl. is juraEN. (Mṣb, TA.) The dim. is jurayoEapN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hence the prov., Oafolata fulaAnN jurayoEapa Alc-aqani, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) the verb being intrans., and jryEp being in the accus. case as a denotative of state, as though the speaker said, Oafolata qaAcifFA jurayoEapa Alc-aqani; (Ṣgh;) or bijurayoEapi Alc-aqani; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or bijurayoEaMYihaA↓; (Ḳ;) Such a one escaped [from destruction] when his spirit, or the remains thereof, had become in his mouth; (L, Ḳ;) or near thereto, (Ḳ,) as a sup [or little sup] of water to the chin [of a person drinking]; (TA;) or when death was as near to him as a little sup of water to the chin; (L;) or when at his last gasp: (Fr, Ṣ:) applied to one who has been at the point of destruction, and then escaped: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to AZ, it is thus; OafolataniI jurayoEapa Alc-aqani, which may mean he made me to escape, &c., or he escaped from me, &c.; in the latter case, AfltnI being for Oafolata min-iI; and [it is said that] jryEp is prefixed to Alcqn because the motion of the chin indicates the nearness of the departure of the soul: or the meaning of the words related by AZ may be, he made me, i. e. the remains of my soul, to escape; the last two words being a substitute for the pronoun affixed to the verb. (Ṣgh.) One says also, OafolatanaIi jurayoEapa Alr-iyqi, meaning He outwent me, [or escaped me,] and I swallowed my spittle in wrath, or rage, against him. (TA.) And maA mino juroEapK OaHomadu EuqobaAnFA mino juroEapi gayoZK nakoZimuhaA ‡ [There is nothing that is swallowed more praiseworthy in its result than what is swallowed of wrath, or rage, which we repress, or restrain]. (TA.)
jiroEapN: see juroEapN.

jaraEapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaroEapN↓ (Ḳ) and jaroEaMCu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OajoraEu↓ (Ḳ) An even piece, (Ṣ,) or a round piece, or hill, or hillock, (Ḳ,) of sand, that produces no plants, or herbage; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and, as some add, that retains no water: (TA:) or a piece, or tract, of sand, good for producing plants, or herbage, in which is no softness, or looseness: (Ṣgh, L, Ḳ:) or land in which is ruggedness, resembling sand: (L, Ḳ:) or a hill of which one side consists of sand, and one side of stones: (Ḳ:) or what is termed jrEAC↓ and AjrE↓ is larger than what is termed jaraEapN: jrEAC↓ is also explained as signifying sand of which the middle is elevated, and of which the sides are thin: and, accord. to IAth, AjrE↓ signifies a wide place, in which is ruggedness: (TA:) or this last, a plain, or soft, place, intermixed with sand: (Ḥam p. 574:) jaraEapN is sing., or n. un., of jaraEN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or, accord. to some, this last word is a sing., like AjrE; and its pl. [of pauc.] is OajoraAEN and [of mult.] jiraAEN: the pl. of jaraEapN is jiroEaAnN: and the pl. of jaroEapN↓ is jiraAEN: and the pl. of jiriEAC↓ is jaroEaAwaAtN: and the pl. of AjrE↓ is OajaAriEu. (TA.)
jaroEaMCu: see jaraEapN, in four places.
jurayoEaMCu: see juroEapN.
OajoraEu: see jaraEapN, in four places.

mujoriEN A she-camel in which is not as much [milk] as will satisfy thirst, but only some sups: (Ḳ:) pl. majaAriyEu (L, Ḳ) and majaAriEu: (L:) J explains the former pl. as signifying she-camels having little milk; as though there were not in their udders more than some sups; and the sing. he does not mention. (TA.)
mujar-aEN: see jariEN, in two places.

1. jarafahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajorufu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. jarofN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jarofapN, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) He took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the greater part of it, (Ṣ,) or much of it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [in like manner jr-fhu↓; for its inf. n.] tajoriyfN signifies the act of carrying away wholly: (KL:) and Ajtrfhu↓ he took the whole of it. (TA in art. jft.)

Also, (inf. n. jarofN, TA,) He swept it away, namely, mud, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the surface of the earth; (TA;) and so jr-fhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoriyfN; (TA;) and tjr-fhu↓: (Ḳ:) or tajoriyfN↓ signifies the act of clearing away mud or the like well; in Persian, nyk rndydn: (KL: [Golius, app. misled by a mistranscription, has explained the verb, jr-f, as on the authority of the KL, by “bene effudit:”]) and Ajtrf↓ AlX-aIoCa he swept away the thing (jarafahu) from the surface of the earth. (TA.) You say also, jarafatohu Als-uyuwlu, (Mṣb,) or jr-fthu↓, inf. n. tajoriyfN; (Ṣ;) and tjr-fthu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) The torrents swept it away; (TA;) [or swept it partially away; or wore it away;] namely, a portion of land. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ. See jurufN.) And, of a death commonly prevailing, jarafa Aln-aAsa kajarofi Als-ayoli ‡ [It swept away, or destroyed, men, like the sweeping away of the torrent]: (TA:) and yajotarifu↓ maAla Alqawomi [It sweeps away, or destroys, the cattle of the people]. (Ṣ, TA.)

[He shovelled it, or scooped it, away, or up, or out.] You say, jarafahu bikilotaA yadayohi [He scooped it up, or out, with both his hands]; i. e. something dry, as flour, and sand, and the like. (Ṣ in art. Hfn.)
jurifa It (herbage) was eaten up utterly. (TA.)
2. jr-fhu, inf. n. tajoriyfN: see 1, in four places.

jr-fhu Ald-ahoru † Time, or fortune, or misfortune, destroyed, or exterminated, his property, or cattle, and reduced him to poverty. (TA.) A poet (of the Benoo-Teiyi, TA) says,
faUino takuni AlHawaAdivu jar-afatoniI
falamo Oara haAlikFA kaQbonaIo ziyaAdi
† [And if misfortunes have destroyed my property, or cattle, and reduced me to poverty, I have not seen any one in a state of perdition like the two sons of Ziyád]. (Ṣ, TA.)
4. Ajrf It (a place) was invaded by a torrent such as is termed juraAf. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1, in two places; and see jurufN.
8: see 1, in three places.
jurofN: see jurufN.
Also A smooth side of a mountain. (A boo-Kheyreh, Ḳ.)
jirofN: see the next paragraph.

jurufN and jurofN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) [An abrupt, water-worn, bank or ridge;] a bank (jaAnibN Ksh and Jel in ix. 110) of a valley, the lower part of which is excavated by the water, and hollowed out by the torrents, so that it remains uncompact, unsound, or weak; (Ksh ib.;) a bank, or an acclivity, of a water-course of a valley and the like, when the water has carried away from its lower part, and undermined it, so that it has become like what is termed a daHol, with its upper part overhanging; (L;) a portion of land (or sand, Ṣ in art. thr) which the torrents have partially swept away, or worn away, (tajar-afatohu↓, Ṣ, Ḳ, or jarafatohu↓, Mṣb,) and eaten; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a portion of the lower part of the side of a valley, and of a river, eaten by the torrent; (M, TA;) the side of the bank of a river, that has been eaten by the water, so that some part of it every little while falls: (Ḥar p. 47:) and the latter, [or each,] a place which the torrent does not take away; as also jirofN↓; (Ḳ;) [i. e. a bank, or ridge, that remains rising abruptly by the bed of a torrent or stream:] pl. [of pauc.] (of jurufN, TA) OajoraAfN, (Ḳ,) like OaTonaAbN pl. of TunubN, (TA,) and [of mult.] (of jurofN, though it is implied in the Ḳ that it is of jurufN, TA) jirafapN, like jiHarapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) pl. of juHorN, (Ṣ,) and juruwfN. (ISd, TA.)

juraAfN A torrent that carries away everything; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. q. juHaAfN applied to a torrent; as also jaworafN↓; (Ḳ;) and jaAruwfN↓ a torrent that sweeps away that by which it passes, by reason of its copiousness, carrying away everything, and so jaArifN↓ applied to rain. (TA.)
‡ A very voracious man: (Ḳ, TA:) a man who devours all the food: (Ṣ:) one who eats vehemently, leaving nothing remaining. (M, TA.)
‡ A man who marries much, or often, and is brisk, lively, sprightly, or active; as also jaAruwfN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ A sword that sweeps away everything. (TA.)
† A sort of measure of capacity; as also jiraAfN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a certain large measure of capacity. (ISk, TA.)
jiraAfN: see what next precedes.
nayoTalN jaruwfN [A capacious bucket: see 3 in art. nhz]. (Ṣ in art. nhz.)
jur-aAfapN: see mijorafapN.
jaArifN: see juraAfN.

Also ‡ A death commonly, or generally, prevailing, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that sweeps away, or destroys, (yajotarifu,) the cattle of the people. (Ṣ, TA.) And † Plague, or pestilence. (Ḳ.) AljaArifu means † A plague, or pestilence, that happened in the time of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr; (Ṣ;) or, as Lth says, AlT-aAEuwnu AljaArifu means the plague, or pestilence, that befel the people of El-'Irák [in the year of the Flight 69], spreading wide, and sweeping away the people like the sweeping away of the torrent. (TA.) And ‡ Evil fortune, or an affliction, that sweeps away, or destroys, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) a people, (Ḳ,) or the cattle of a people. (Lth, TA.)
jaworafN: see juraAfN.

Hence, as being likened to the torrent thus termed, (TA,) ‡ A quick, or swift, birocawn [or hack,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) And ‡ An ass; [app. meaning a wild ass, because of his swiftness.] (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) And, accord. to some, A male ostrich: (as in the Ḳ:) but this is a mistranscription for jaworaqN, with q. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, T, Ṣgh, L, TA.)
jaAruwfN: see juraAfN, in two places.
Also ‡ Greedy; having an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food. (Ḳ, TA.)
And An ‡ unfortunate man. (Ḳ,* TA.)
mijorafN: see mijorafapN.
[Hence,] banaAnN mijorafN [Fingers, or fingers' ends,] that take much food. (IAạr, TA.)

mijorafapN A broom, or besom; (Ḳ;) a thing with which mud is swept away from the surface of the ground: (Ṣ,* TA:) [applied in the present day to a shovel: and a hoe: and a rake:] as also mijorafN↓: vulgarly, jur-aAfapN↓; [now applied by many to a drag for dragging rivers, &c.;] of which the pl. is jaraAriyfu. (TA.)
mujar-afN ‡ A man who has had his property, or or cattle, destroyed, or exterminated, and who has been reduced to poverty, by time, or fortune, or misfortune. (TA.)
mujar-ifN ‡ Lean, or emaciated. (M, TA.) [See what next follows.]
mutajar-ifN ‡ A ram whose general fatness has gone; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) and so a camel. (TA.)
Lean, or emaciated; as also mutajal-ifN. (TA in art. jlf.) You say, jaMCa mutajar-ifFA ‡ He (a man, Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA) came in a lean and lax state (haziylFA muDoTaribFA). (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
jiroyaAlN A certain red dye. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The redness of gold. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Pure; applied to red and other colours. (Ḳ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jiroyaAlapN↓, (Ḳ,) Wine; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) inferior in goodness to such as is termed sulaAfN: (Ṣ:) or the colour of wine. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The phrase salabotuhaA jiroyaAlahaA, used by El-Aạshà, [lit. I deprived it, namely, wine, of its colour,] means I drank it red, and discharged it in urine white. (Ṣ.)
jiroyaAlapN: see above.

hom.sense: 1. jaramahu, aor. _i {yajorimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaromN, (Ṣ,) [like jazamahu,] He cut it, or cut it off. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

jarama Aln-axola, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. jaromN (Ḳ) and jaraAmN and jiraAmN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) He cut the palmtrees; (Mṣb;) [meaning] he cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Ajtrmhu↓: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, jarama Alt-amora he cut off the dates. (TA.) You say, hecaA zamanu AljaraAmi and AljiraAmi, (Ṣ,) i. e. [This is] the time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (TA.)
And jarama Aln-axola, inf. n. jaromN, He computed by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon the palm-trees; (Ḳ;) and so Ajtrmhu↓: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) [like jazamahu and Ajtzmhu.]

jarama, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajorimu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jaromN, (TḲ,) also signifies He gained, acquired, or earned, [wealth, &c.,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) liOaholihi for his family; and so Ajtrm↓. (Ḳ.) And you say, xaraja yajorimu liOaholihi and yajorimu Oaholahu, meaning He went forth seeking [sustenance], and practising skill, or artifice, for his family. (TA.)

walaA yajoriman-akumo XanaMnu qawomK, in the Ḳur [v. 3 and 11], is explained by some as meaning And let not a people's hatred by any means occasion you. or cause you: or it means let not a people's hatred by any means induce you, or incite you. (Ṣ, TA.) Some read lA yujoriman-akumo↓, with damm to the I; and Zj says that jaramotu and Oajoramotu signify the same: but some say that the meaning is, let it not by any means lead you into crime, or sin; Oajoramotuhu being like Mvamotuhu, I led him into sin,, &c. (TA.)

Fr says that the asserting jaramotu to mean Haqaqotu [or rather Huqiqotu, for this is evidently, I think, the right reading, though I find Haqaqotu in the TA as well as in a copy of the Ṣ, in another copy of which I find jaramato and Haq-aqato, suggesting that the right reading may perhaps be jaramato and Huq-ato,] is nought: they who so explain it having been confused in their judgment by the saying of the poet Aboo-Asmà, (Ṣ, TA,) or, as some say, El-Howfazán, (TA,) or, accord. to some, 'Ateeyeh Ibn-'Ofeyf, (IB, TA,)
walaqado TaEanotu OabaA Euyayonapa TaEonapF
jaramato fazaArapa baEodahaA Oano yagoDabuwA
in which they made fzArp to be in the nom. case, as though the meaning were Huq-a lahaA AlgaDabu [it was right, or fit, or proper, for it, (the tribe of Fezárah,) to be angry; nearly agreeing with an explanation of jarama given by Golius as on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, namely, “meritus, dignus fuit”]: but, he says, fzArp is in the accus. case; the meaning being, jaramatohumu AlT-aEonapu Oano yagoDabuwA [which will be found explained, on the authority of IB, in what follows]: AO says that the meaning is, OaHaq-ato Ealayohimu AlgaDaba, i. e., OaHaq-ati AlT-aEonapu fazaArapa Oano yagoDabuwA, and Haq-at also, [both having the same signification, i. e., the thrust required Fezá- rah to be angry,] from laA jarama laOafoEalan-a kacaA meaning Haq-FA [Verily I will do thus]: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to Fr, the meaning is, kasabato fazaArapa AlgaDaba Ealayoka, the right reading being, walaqado TaEanota, with fet-ḥ to the t; [so that the verse means And verily thou didst thrust Aboo-'Oyeyneh with a thrust of thy spear that occasioned, or caused, Fezárah, after it, to be angry against thee:] for he is addressing Kurz El-'Okeylee, bewailing his death; and Kurz had thrust Aboo-'Oyeyneh, who was Hisn Ibn-Hudheyfeh Ibn-Bedr El-Fezáree. (IB, TA.)

And jarama, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajorimu}, inf. n. jaromN, (Mṣb,) He committed a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) syn. Oaconaba, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Aikotasaba AlUivoma; (Mṣb;) [perhaps because he who does so brings upon himself the consequence thereof; as though originally jarama nafosahu Awlinafosihi Oavara juromK he drew upon himself the effect of a sin,, &c.; (compare kasaba and Aikotasaba;)] as also Ajrm↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijoraAmN; (Mṣb;) and Ajtrm↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tjr-m↓. (El-'Okberee, Ḥar p. 207.) You say, jarama Ealayohimo jariymapF, and Uilayohimo, (Ḳ,) and bihimo, used by a poet for Elyhm or Alyhm, (IAạr, TA,) He committed against them a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished; as also Ajzm↓. (Ḳ.) They said also, Ajrm↓ Alc-anoba [He committed the sin, or crime, amp;c.]; making the verb trans. (TA.) And a poet says,
wataraI All-abiyba muHas-adFA lamo yajotarimo
EiroDa Alr-ijaAli waEiroDuhu maXotuwmN
[And thou seest the intelligent envied, or much envied: he has not injured the honour of men, while his honour is reviled]. (Th, TA.)

jarima, aor. _a {yajoramu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaramN, (TḲ,) He (a man, TA) betook himself to eating the juraAmap [in the CK, erroneously, jarAmap,] of the palm-trees, (AA, Ḳ,) [i. e., the dates which had fallen in the cutting, and] which were among the branches. (AA, TA.)

jarima, said of a man, also signifies EaZuma juromuhu [His sin, or crime,, &c., was, or became, great]; and so jaruma, like karum: [both are thus explained, in different places in this art, by the author of the TA; and the explanation in the latter case is followed by AI Acnb, i. e., he committed a six,, &c.; probably added by him to show that the reading found by him was juromuhu, not jiromuhu: but I think that the right reading is EaZuma jiromuhu his body became great; and this is confirmed by what here follows:]
Ajrm↓ explained in the copies of the Ḳ by EaZuma [in the TḲ EZm yEnI jrmh wjsdh] should be jarima, a triliteral; and the meaning is EaZuma juromuhu: and in like manner, the three significations here following, assigned in the Ḳ to Ajrm↓, belong to jarima. (TA.)
It (his colour) was, or became, clear. (Ḳ,* TA.)
He (a man, TA) was, or became, clear in his voice. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jarima bihi It (blood) stuck to him, or it: (Ḳ,* TA, and so in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ:) and in like manner, tar to a camel. (The same marginal note.)

entry.sense: 2. [jr-m He cut off vehemently, or much. (Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL.)]
jar-amonaA humo, inf. n. tajoriymN, We went forth from them. (Lth, Ḳ.)
jar-amonaA AlX-itaMCa We completed the winter. (TA.) [See also 5.]

hom.sense: 4. Ajrm Alt-amoru The dates attained to the time for their being cut off. (TA.)
See also 1, in six places.
5. tjr-m [It became cut off.]

[And hence,] ‡ It (a year, HawolN) became completed; (Az, Ḳ, TA;) as though it became cut off from the preceding year: (Az, TA:) it ended; (Ṣ;) and so the winter: (TA:) and it (a night) passed away, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and became completed; (Ḳ;) it ended. (TA.)
tjr-m vamaAniyFA, a phrase used by Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh, means He passed eight nights. (TA.) [See also 2]

tjr-m Ealayohi He accused him of a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which he had not committed, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ṣ,) or though he had not committed any (Ḳ.)
And tjr-m He guarded against the commission of sin, or crime,, &c.; like tOv-m. (Ḥar p. 207.)
See also 1.
Also He called, cried out, shouted, or vociferated; from jiromN meaning SawotN. (Ḥar p. 207. [But see jiromN.])

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in five places.

hom.sense: jaromN Hot; syn. Har-N, (Ṣ,) or [rather] HaAr-N; (Ḳ;) contr. of SarodN; (Lth, TA;) a Persian word, (Ṣ,) arabicized; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) originally Garom. (TA.) You say OaroDN jaromN A warm land: (AḤn, TA:) or a hot land: (IDrd, TA:) or a vehemently hot land: (Ḳ:) pl. juruwmN, (AḤn, TA,) which, applied to countries, or regions, means the contr. of SuruwdN. (Ṣ.)

A boat (zaworaqN) of El-Yemen; (Ḳ;) also called naqiyrapN: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.) [In the dial. of Egypt, The largest kind of Egyptian boat used on the Nile for the conveyance of grain and merchandise in general, but used only when the river is high, and also in the coastingtrade, and generally carrying from 5,000 to 15,000 bushels of grain.]

juromN A sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, syn. canobN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) whether intentional or committed through inadvertence; (Kull voce UivomN;) as also jariymapN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and jarimapN↓: (Ḳ:) transgression: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoraAmN and [of mult.] juruwmN, (Ḳ,) both of juromN: the pl. of jariyampN is jaraAYimu. (TA.)
See also jaraAmN.
laA juroma: see laA jarama.

jiromN The body; syn. jasadN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or badanN; (Th, TA;) as also jiromaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) or the OalowaAHi [pl. of lawoH q. v.] and juvomaAn [q. v.] of the jasad: (T, TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OjoraAmN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is also used as a sing., (TA,) and (of mult., TA) juruwmN and jurumN. (Ḳ.) OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAmahu is a phrase mentioned, but not explained, by Lḥ: ISd thinks that it means He threw upon him the weight of his body; as though the term jiromN applied to each separate part of his body. (TA.)
[Hence,] AlOajoraAmu Alfalakiy-apu The [heavenly] bodies that are above the EanaASir, of the orbs and stars. (KT.)

The throat, or fauces; syn. HaloqN. (Ḳ.) The phrase yaDiyqu bihi Aljiromu, used by the poet Maan Ibn-'Ows, means † It is a great, or formidable, thing, or matter: [properly,] the throat (AlHaloqu) will not easily swallow it. (TA.)

The voice; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) mentioned by ISk and others; (Ṣ;) and so explained as used in the phrase Uin-a fulaAnFA laHasanu Aljiromi [Verily such a one is good in respect of voice]: (TA:) or highness, or loudness, of the voice: (Ḳ, TA:) you say, maA Earafotuhu Uil-aA bijiromihi [I knew him not save by his voice, or his highness, or loudness, of voice]: but some disapprove this: (TA:) AḤát says that the vulgar are addicted to saying, fulaAnN SaAfiI Aljiromi Such a one is clear in voice, or in throat: but it is a mistake. (Ṣ, TA.)
Colour. (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One may say, of najaAsap [or filth], laA jiroma lahaA, meaning It has no colour. (Mṣb.)
AlOajoraAmu (app. as pl. of jiromN, TA) The utensils, or apparatus, of the pastor. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: laA jarama (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and laA caA jarama, (IAạr, Ḳ,) cA being here a redundant connective as in several other instances, (IAạr, TA,) and laA Oano caA jarama and laA Eano caA jarama (Ḳ) and laA jara, (Ks, Ḳ, [in the CK lA jaroma,]) in which the m is elided in consequence of frequency of usage, as the I is in HaAXa lil-hi for HaAXaI lil-ehi, and the I and C in OayoXa for OaI-u XaIoCK, (Ks, TA,) and laA caA jara (IAạr, TA) and laA jaruma↓ and laA juroma↓, (Ḳ,) originally i. q. laA bud-a and laAmaHaAlapN [There is no avoiding it; it is absolutely necessary;, &c.]: then, by reason of frequency of usage, employed in the manner of an oath, as meaning Haq-FA [verily, or truly]; wherefore, as in the case of an oath, l is prefixed to its complement, (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) so that they say, laA jarama laMtiyan-ka [Verily I will come to thee], (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and laA jarama laOafoEalan-a kacaA [Verily I will do thus], (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) and laA jarama laqado kaAna kacaA and laA caA jarama and laA caA jara [Verily it was thus, or verily such a thing happened]: (IAạr, TA:) ISd says, Kh asserts that jarama [or laA jarama] is only a reply to something said before it; as when a man says, “They did such a thing,” and you say, laA jarama Oan-ahumo sayanodamuwna, or Oan-ahu sayakuwnu kacaA wakacaA; and Az says that lA in laA jarama is said to be a [mere] connective; and the meaning [of the former of the last two phrases] is kasaba lahumo Eamaluhumu Aln-adama [It (their deed) will earn for them, or occasion them, repentance; and that of the latter, it will occasion that such and such things shall happen]: and some say that jarama means wajaba, and Haq-a, and that lA is a contradiction to the words preceding it, and that a new proposition then begins; as in the Ḳur [xvi. 64] where it is said, laA jarama Oan-a lahumu Aln-aAra, i. e., [Nay, or] the case is not as they have said: the fire [of Hell] is their due. (TA.)
laA jaruma: see the paragraph next preceding.
jiromapN People cutting off the fruit of palmtrees. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [In this sense it is app. a pl. of pauc., or a quasi-pl. n., of jaArimN, q. v.]

Also Ripening dates cut off from the trees: and this sense, not the former as is implied in the Ṣ, is meant by Imra-el-Ḳeys, where he says,
Ealawona biOanoTaAkiy-apK fawoqa EiqomapK
kajiromapK naxolK Oawo kajan-api yavoriba
[They mounted, at Antioch, upon a variegated cloth, like the ripening dates cut off from palmtrees, or like the garden of Yethrib]: he likens the variegated cloth and wool upon the hawodaj to red and yellow ripening dates, or to the garden of Yethrib because it abounded with palm-trees. (TA.)
jarimapN: see juromN.
jiromaAnN: see jiromN.

jaraAmN (erroneously said in the Ḳ to be [juraAmN] like guraAbN, TA) and jariymN↓ Dry dates: (AA, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) mentioned by ISk among [syn.] words of the measures faEaAlN and faEiylN, like XaHaAHN and XaHiyHN, and bajaAlN and bajiylN, &c. (Ṣ.)

Also, both these words, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) but the former not heard in this sense by ISd, (TA,) Datestones; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so juromN↓: (mentioned in one copy of the Ṣ, but not in the TA, [probably an interpolation in the copy of the Ṣ above mentioned:]) and jariymapN↓ a date-stone; as in the saying of 'Ows Ibn-Háritheh, laA waQl-aciI Oaxoraja AlEacoqa mina Aljariymapi waAln-aAra mina Alwaviymapi [No, by Him who has produced the palm-tree with its fruit from the date-stone, and fire from broken stones]. (TA.)

hom.sense: jariymN Dates (tamorN) cut off from the tree; (Ṣ, TA;) as also majoruwmN↓. (TA.) And XajarapN jariymapN A cut tree. (TA.)
See also jaraAmN, with which it is syn. in two senses: in the latter sense having jariymapN for its n un.
Also A thing with which date-stones are brayed, or crushed. (TA.)
See also mujorimN.

Also Large-bodied; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) and so majoruwmN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. (of the former, Ṣ) jiraAmN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The fem. of the former is with p {jariymapN}: (Ḳ:) [but] one says also jil-apN jariymN, meaning Largebodied camels advanced in age. (Ṣ.)
In El-Ḥijáz, The [measure commonly termed] mud- is thus called; accord. to Z, the mud- of the Prophet. (TA.)

entry.sense: juraAmapN i. q. jucaAmapN; (Ḳ;) i. e., (TA,) The dates that have fallen when they are cut off from the tree: (Ṣ, TA:) so says Aṣ: (TA:) [but see the latter word as explained on the authority of the Ṣ in art. jcm:] and, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (TA,) dates cut off from the tree: or what are gotten (yujoramu) thereof, after their being cut off, being picked up from the lower ends of the branches. (Ḳ, TA. [See jarima.]) And The qaSal of wheat and barley; i. e., the extremities thereof, which are bruised, and then cleared, or picked: (Ḳ, TA:) but the term more known is jucaAmapN, with cAl. (TA.)

hom.sense: jariymapN The last of one's offspring: (Ḳ:) as though there were a cutting off after it. (TA.)
See also jaArimN:
and see juromN:
and jaraAmN.
jaArimN Cutting off, or one who cuts off, the fruit of the palm-tree: pl. jur-amN and jur-aAmN. (Ṣ.) [See also jiromapN.]
jaArimu Oaholihi (TA) and jariymapu↓ Oaholihi (Ṣ, Ḳ *) The gainer, acquirer, or earner, [of the sustenance] of his family. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also mujorimN, in two places.

entry.sense: mujorimN A sinner; a criminal; committing, or a committer of, a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; as also jariymN↓ (Ḳ) and jaArimN↓: (TA:) and Almujorimuwna particularly signifies the unbelievers: (Zj, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur vii. 38. (Zj, TA.) You say, huwa jaArimN↓ EalaI nafosihi waqawomihi, [as also mujorimN,] He is committing a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished, against himself and his people or party. (TA.)
mujar-amN, (fem. with p {mujar-amapN}, Ṣ,) A complete year (Ṣ, Ḳ) and month; (Ibn-Háni, TA;) a year past, completed. (AZ, TA.)
majoruwmN: see jariymN, in two places.

juromuwqN [A kind of galoche;] a thing that is worn over the [kind of boot called] xuf-; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) called in Persian xarokaXo: (Mgh:) or a small xuf- (JK, TA) which is worn over the [ordinary] xuf-: (TA:) an arabicized word; (Ṣ;) [probably from the Persian Jarom “leather,” and muwq, which is said by some to be arabicized, but by ISd to be a genuine Arabic word, meaning “a kind of xuf-:” or it may be from saromuwzaho, given as its Persian equivalent in the PṢ:] pl. jaraAmiyqu. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. jarana, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajorunu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. juruwnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, and of a beast, (ISk, Ṣ,) He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to a thing, or an affair. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And jaranato yadaAhu EalaI AlEamali, inf. n. as above, His hands became accustomed, or inured, to the work. (M, TA.)

Also, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a coat of mail, (Ḳ,) and of a skin for water or milk, (Ṣ,) It became threadbare, or worn, and soft, or smooth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, said of a skin, and of a book, or writing, it became old and worn out. (M, TA.)
jarana, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaronN, (TA,) He ground grain (Ḳ, TA) vehemently: (TA:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Ajrn He collected dates in the jariyn. (ISd, Ḳ.)
8. Ajtrn He made, or prepared, a jariyn. (Ḳ.)

juronN A hollowed stone, [or stone basin,] from which the [ablution termed] wuDuwoC is performed; (Ḳ;) water being poured into it; called by the people of El-Medeeneh mhrs [app. mihoras, perhaps a dial. var. of mihoraAsN, or a mistranscription for this]: so in the M: in the Jm, the mihoraAs with which the wDwC is performed. (TA.)
See also jub-N.
[In the present day, applied also to A stone mortar in which things are pounded.]
See also jariynN, in two places.

jironN The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jisomN; said to be a dial. var. of jiromN; or the n may be a substitute for the jrm of OajoraAnN; but the former is the more probable, as the word has a pl., namely, OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAnahu, and this is scarcely ever the case when a word is formed by substitution. (TA.) Hence the saying, OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAnahu, i. q. AlqI Elyh OajoraAmahu and XaraAXirahu [He threw upon him, or it, the weight of his body]: (Lḥ, TA: [see also XaroXarpN, under which other explanations are given:]) or he threw his weights [meaning his whole weight] upon him, or it; and so AlqI Elyh jiraAnahu↓: or, accord. to the A, he disposed, or subjected, his mind to it; or persuaded himself to do it; namely, an affair. (TA.)

jiraAnN The anterior [or under] part of the neck of a camel, from his macobaH [or the part a little below the under jaw] to the place where he is stabbed: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner, of a horse; (Ṣ, TA;) the inner [or under] part of the neck, from the pit of the uppermost part of the breast to the extremity of the neck at the head: and, metaphorically, of a man: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jurunN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajorinapN; (Mṣb, TA;) which last is used by Tarafeh as a sing. (TA,* and EM p. 68.) You say, of a camel, OaloqaI jiraAnahu biAlOaroDi [He threw the under part of his neck upon the ground]; meaning that he lay down, and stretched out his neck upon the ground. (Mṣb, TA.) See another ex. voce jironN. [And see a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. Hnw.] You say also, Daraba AlHaq-u bijiraAnihi, meaning † The truth, or right, or just claim, became established, or settled. (T, TA.)
Also The inner [or under] part of the penis: pl. jurunN and OajorinapN, as above. (TA.)
jariynN What one has ground [of grain]: (Ḳ, TA:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)
See also jaArinN.

Also, and juronN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and mijoranN↓, (Ḳ,) or majoranN↓, (so in a copy of the Ṣ, but in other copies not mentioned,) The place in which dates are dried: (Ṣ:) or a bayodar: (Ḳ:) or the jariyn is for grain; and the byd, for dates: (Towsheeh, TA:) or the place where dates are collected [and dried] when they are cut from the tree: or, accord. to Lth, the place of the byd in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, the generality of whom pronounce the word [jiriyn,] with kesr to the j: (T, TA:) or the mirobad; i. e. the place in which fresh ripe dates are thrown to dry: (Mgh:) or the bydr in which wheat is trodden out; and also the place in which fruits are dried: (Mṣb:) the place of wheat; and sometimes [the place] for [drying] dates and grapes: (M, TA:) its pl. [of mult.] is jurunN, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) not jaraAYinu, (Mgh,) and [of pauc.] OajoraAnN and OajorinapN: (TA:) AʼObeyd says that mirobadN and jariynN are of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; and OanodarN, of that of Syria; and bayodarN, of El-'Irák: (TA in art. rbd:) juronN↓ is of the dial. of the people of Egypt, who use it as meaning the bydr of seed-produce, which is [sometimes] walled round; and its pl. is OajoraAnN. (TA.) [See also mirobadN.]
jiroyaAnN a dial. var. of jiroyaAlN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) meaning A certain red dye. (ISd, TA.)

jaArinN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a skin for water or milk, &c., (T, TA,) Old, and worn out: (T, TA:) or threadbare, or worn, and soft, or smooth: and in like manner applied to a coat of mail: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also jariynN↓: (TA:) or, applied to a coat of mail (diroE), in which case it is with p {jaArinapN}, that has become smooth from much use: (Ḥam p. 656:) pl. jawaArinu: (Ṣ, TA:) and, applied to a commodity, or utensil, or an article of furniture, used, and worn out: and to a skin for water or milk, dried up, and rough, or coarse, from use: (TA:) and to a road, worn, or effaced. (Abu-l-Jarráh, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also The young one of a serpent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a viper, (Lth, M, TA,) such as is smooth. (Lth, TA.)
majoranN: see jariynN.

hom.sense: mijoranN: see jariynN.
Also Very voracious: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

entry.sense: mujar-anN A whip of which the thong has become soft, or smooth. (Ḳ.) Az says, I have seen them make their whips from the jurun [pl. of jiraAnN q. v.] of camels such as are termed buzol [i. e. in the ninth year, or nine years old], because of the thickness thereof. (TA.)

4. Oajorato [in its primary sense app. signifies She (a bitch, and any female beast of prey,) whelped; or had a whelp, or whelps: see mujorK. (Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of J, Cum fœtu abiit vel asportavit eum fera: but I have not found it in any copy of the Ṣ, nor in any other lexicon.)]

[And hence,] said of a tree (XajarapN), It had upon it [fruits such as are termed] jiraMC [pl. of jirowN]; (Aṣ, TA;) said [for instance] of a mawozap [or banana-tree]: (AḤn, TA in art. mwz:)
and [in like manner] said of a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) it had jiraMC; (Ḳ in art. jrI; [in the CK, erroneously, jarAC;]) belonging to the present art., not to art. jrI. (TA.)

jirowN and jurowN and jarowN (of which the first is the most chaste, Mṣb) The whelp, or young one, of the dog, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and so, app., jirowapN↓, q. v.,] and of the lion, (Ḳ,) and of any beast of prey: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajorK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally OajoruwN, (Ṣ,) and OajoriyapN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and OajoraMCN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] jiraMCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) OajoriyapN, as pl. of jrw, being anomalous; (TA;) or it is pl. of jiraMCN [and therefore not anomalous]. (Ṣ, TA.)

And the same, (Ḳ,) or the first of these, (Ṣ, El-Bári', Mṣb, TA,) only, (TA,) ‡ The small of anything, (El-Bári', Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) as also jirowapN↓; (TA;) even, (Ḳ,) of the colocynth, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of the melon, and the like; (Ḳ;) as, for instance, (TA,) of the pomegranate, (Ṣ, TA,) and of the poppy, (AḤn, TA in art. Etr,) and of the baAcanojaAn, (TA,) and of the cucumber, (Ṣ, TA,) as also jirowapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) likened to the whelps of dogs, because of their softness and smoothness: (Mṣb:) or what is round of the fruits of trees; as the colocynth and the like: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OjorK (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, erroneously, AajoruWN]) and [of mult.] jiraMCN. (Aṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
† Fruit when it first grows forth, (AḤn, Ḳ,) in its fresh, juicy, state. (AḤn, TA.)

† The seeds, (M, TA,) or envelope, or receptacle, of the seeds, (Ḳ,) of the kaEaAbiyr [app. meaning the round and compact pericarps (in some of the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, as is observed in the TA, EkAbyr,)] that are at the heads of branches. (M, Ḳ.)
‡ A tumour in a camel's hump; and in the withers; so called by way of comparison [to a whelp]: (TA:) and in the fauces. (Ḳ.)
See also what next follows, last sentence.

hom.sense: jirowapN: see jirowN, in three places. A huntsman beat, or disciplined, or trained, his dog for the purpose of the chase (Darabahu EalaI AlS-ayodi); and thereupon it was said, Daraba jirowatahu [app. meaning He beat, or disciplined, or trained, his whelp]: and hence this phrase became proverbially used, in instances here following. (Z, TA.)

I. q. nafosN [as meaning Self]. (TA.) You say, Daraba Ealayohi jirowatahu, meaning † He disposed and subjected himself to it; (Ṣ, TA;) namely, a thing, an affair, or a case: and he endured it with patience: and in like manner, Daraba jirowapa nafosihi: (TA:) and OaloqaI fulaAnN jrowatahu he endured the thing with patience. (Ṣ, TA.) Also Darabotu jirowatiI Eanohu † I endured with patience the want, or loss, of it: (TA:) or my mind became at ease [respecting it]. (AA, IB, TA.)
Also (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK jirowN↓,]) ‡ A short she-camel. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense:
mujorK and mujoriyapN applied to a bitch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a female beast of prey, (TA,) Having a whelp, or young one: (Ḳ:) or having with her her whelps, or young ones. (Ṣ.) El-Aạlam says,
watajur-u mujoriyapN lahaA
laHomiI UilaI OajorK HawaAXibo
And a hyena having young ones shall drag for her my flesh to young ones with swollen bellies, and short. (Skr p. 57.)

1. jaraI, said of water (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb), &c., (Ṣ,) or of water and the like, (Ḳ,) more properly thus, as in the Ḳ, aor. _i {yajoriIu}, (TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jarayaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jiroyapN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) [which last see below,] It ran, or passed along quickly; originally said of water: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it flowed;; syn. saAla; contr. of waqafa and sakana. (Mṣb.)
Said also of farina, in the phrase jaraI Ald-aqiyqu fiI Als-unobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.)

And of a horse (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and the like, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jarayaAnN (Mṣb) and jiraMCN (Lth, Ḳ) and majorFI, (Ṣ,) [He ran;] from the same verb said of water. (Mgh)
And of a ship: you say, jarati Als-afiynapN, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (TA) and majorFI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [The ship ran.]

And of the sun, and a star: you say, jarati AlX-amosu, aor. _i {yajoriIu}, inf. n. jaroIN, [The sun pursued its course:] and jarati Aln-ujuwmu The stars travelled, or passed along, from east to west. (TA.)

jaraI UilaI kacaA, (Mṣb, and Ḥar p. 152,) inf. n. jaroIN and jiraMCN; (Mṣb;) and AjrI↓ Uilayohi, inf. n. UijoraMCN; (Ḥam p. 224, and Ḥar p. 152;) He betook, or directed, himself to such a thing; made it his object; aimed at it; intended, or purposed, it: (Mṣb, and Ḥar ubi suprà:) and he hastened to it: (Mṣb:) but in the latter phrase, an objective complement is understood; and it is used in relation to something disapproved, or disliked; (Ḥam and Ḥar;) properly, AjrI fiEolahu Uilayoh, (Ḥam,) or AjrI fiEolahu biAlqaSodi Uilayohi. (Ḥar.)
Hence, perhaps, the saying, jaraI AlxilaAfu fiI kacaA ‡ [frequently used as meaning A controversy ran, or ran on, respecting such a thing between such and such persons]. (Mṣb.)

jaraI lahu AlX-aIoCu, (Sh, TA,) and jaraI Ealayohi, (TA,) † The thing was permanent, or continued, to him. (Sh, TA.) [And, more commonly, † The thing happened, or occurred, to him. Whence, maAjarayaAtN↓, as pl. of maAjaraI, used as a single word, by late writers, meaning † Events, or occurrences.]

huwa yajoriI majoraAhu † It is like it, or similar to it, in state, condition, case, or predicament. (TA.) [It (a word or phrase) follows the same rule or rules, or occupies the same grammatical place, as it (another word or phrase). And similar to this is the saying,] Ald-ayonu waAlr-ahonu yatajaArayaAni↓ mujaAraApa AlmabiyEi wAlv-amani † [The debt and the pledge are subject to the same laws as the thing sold and the price]. (Mgh.)

[Also † It acts as, or in a similar manner to, it: and † he acts in his stead: see jariI-N. Hence the phrase, jaraI minohu majoraI kacaA † It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or in a similar manner to, such a thing: as in the prov.,] jaraI minohu majoraI All-aduwdi † [It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or similarly to, the medicine, or draught, called ldwd: mnh here having the meaning of fiyhi]. (ISk, Ṣ in art. ld.)
[One says, also, of an inf. n., and of a part. n., that is regularly formed, yajoriI EalaI AlfiEoli, meaning † It is conformable to the verb.]

2. jr-I He sent a deputy, or commissioned agent; as also AjirI↓. (Ḳ.) And jr-I jariy-FA He made, or appointed, a deputy, or commissioned agent; (ISk, Ṣ,* TA;) as also AstjrAhu↓. (Ṣ,* TA.) Hence the trad., (TA,) laA yasotajoriyan-akumu↓ AlX-ayoTiAnu (Ṣ, TA) By no means let the Devil make you his followers and his commissioned agents. (TA.) You say also, AjrAhu↓ fiI HaAjatihi [He sent him to accomplish his needful affair]. (TA.)

3. jArAhu, inf. n. mujaAraApN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jiraMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He ran with him. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, jaArayotuhu Hat-aI fut-uhu I ran with him until I passed beyond him, or outwent him. (TA in art. fwt.)

[He vied, contended, or competed, with him in running: and hence, † in any affair; like saAyarahu.] You say, jArAhu fiI kacaA wafaEala mivola fiEolihi † [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in such an affair, and did like as he did]. (Mgh in art. fwD.) And jArAhu fiI AlHadiyvi † [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in discourse]. (Ṣ.) And jaArawoA fiI AlHadiyvi (TA) and tajaArawoA↓ fiyhi (Ṣ, TA) † [They vied, contended, or competed, one with another, in discourse]. And it is said in a trad., mano Talaba AlEiloma liyujaAriIa bihi AlEulamaMCa † He who seeks knowledge in order that he may run [i. e. vie] with the learned in discussion and disputation, to show his knowledge to others, to be seen and heard. (TA.) And in another trad., laA tujaAri OaxaAka walaA tuXaArihi walaA tumaArihi † [Contend not for superiority with thy brother, (so explained in the TA, voce jaAr-a, in art. jr,) nor dispute with him, nor wrangle with him]: (El-Jámi'-es- Sagheer:) or, as some relate it, laA tujaAr-i OaxaAka walaA tuXaAr-ihi. (TA in art. jr, q. v.)

hom.sense: 4. AjrAhu He made it to run; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) said of water, &c., (Ṣ,) or of water and the like. (Ḳ,* TA.) [Hence, AjrI damoEFA, or dumuwEFA, He shed tears.]
Also He made him to run; namely, a horse (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and the like: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) in which sense mujorFI [as well as UijoraMCN] is used as an inf. n. (Ṣ.)
AjrI Als-afiynapa [He made the ship to run]: (Ṣ:) in this sense, also, mujorFI [as well as UijoraMCN] is used as an inf. n. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AjrI as syn. with jr-I; and AjrAhu fiI HaAjatihi: see 2.
AjrI Uilayohi: see 1.

Oajorayotu Ealayohi [and lahu] † I made a thing permanent, or continual, to him. (IAạr, TA.) [And hence, both of these phrases, in the present day, † I made him, or appointed him, a permanent, or regular, allowance of bread, &c.; I provided for him, or maintained him.]

[AjrAhu mujoraI kacaA † He made it to be like, or similar to, such a thing in state, condition, case, or predicament. † He made it (a word or phrase) to follow the same rule or rules, or to occupy the same grammatical place, as such another. † He made it to act as, or in a similar manner to, such a thing.]
[Hence,] AisomN laA yajoraI i. q. laA yanoSarifu † [A noun that is imperfectly declinable]. (TA in art. Smt, &c.)
Oajorato said of a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see art. jrw.

6. tajaArawoA fiI AlHadiyvi: see 3. Hence, in a trad., tatajaAraI bihimu AlOahowaMCu † [Natural desires, or blamable inclinations, or erroneous opinions, contend with them for the mastery: or] they vie, or compete, one with another, in natural desires,, &c. (TA.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 10. AstjrAhu He demanded, or desired, that he should run. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
laA jara and laA caA jara, for laA jarama and laA caA jarama: see art. jrm.
jurapN and jaraAyapN↓: see 1 in art. jrO.

hom.sense: jarFI: see jaraOCN
faEalotuhu mino jaraAka, and mn jaraAYika↓, I did it because of thee, or of thine act; on thine account; or for thy sake; i. q. mn Oajolika; like mn jar-aAka [which see in art. jr]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jiroyapN i. q. jaroIN as inf. n. of jaraI said of water (Mṣb, Ḳ) and the like: (Ḳ:) and also A mode, or manner, of running [thereof]. (TA.) You say, maA OaXad-a jiroyapa hecaA AlmaMCi [How vehement is the running, or manner of running, of this water!]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jaraMCN and jiraMCN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jarFI↓ (Ḳ) and jaraAyapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaraAYiyapN↓ (IAạr, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK jiraAyapN]) Girlhood; the state of a jaAriyap. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, kaAna celika fiI Oay-aAmi jaraAYihaA That was in the days of her girlhood. (Ṣ.)
faEalotuhu mino jaraAYika: see jaraI.

entry.sense: jiraMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: jariI-N A commissioned agent; a factor; a deputy: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) because he runs in the affairs of him who appoints him, (Mgh,) or acts in his stead (yajoriI majoraAhu): (Ṣ, Mgh:) [in this and other senses following] used alike as sing. and pl., and also as [masc. and] fem.: (Ḳ:) but sometimes, though rarely, jariy-apN is used for the fem., accord. to AḤát; and accord. to J [in the Ṣ, and Mṭr in the Mgh], it has OajoriyaMCu for its pl. (TA.) And A messenger, or person sent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that runs in an affair. (TA.) But accord. to Er-Rághib, it is weaker [in signification, or in point of chasteness,] than rasuwlN and wakiylN [which are given as its syns. in the Ṣ and Ḳ]. (TA.)
A servant. (TA.)
A hired man; a hireling. (Kr, Ḳ.)
A surety; a guarantee; one who is responsible, accountable, or answerable, for another. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
The word signifying “bold,” or “daring,” is jariIoCN, with C. (Ṣ.)
jaraAyapN: see jiraAyapN:
and jaraMCN:
and jurapN.
jiraAyapN The office of a jariI-, i. e. a commissioned agent, factor, or deputy; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of a messenger: (Ṣ:) as also jaraAyapN↓. (TA.)
A running [or permanent] daily allowance of food or the like. (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence, in the present day, xubozu jiraAyapK Bread made of inferior flour, for servants and other dependants.]

entry.sense: jaraAYiyapN: see jaraMCN
jiriy-aMCu: see Uijoriy-aA
jir-iI-N [The eel;] a certain fish, well known. (Ḳ: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.)

jir-iy-apN, like qir-iy-apN, (Ṣ,) The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.:) so called because the food at the last runs into it, or because it is the channel through which the food runs: (Er-Rághib, TA:) thus pronounced by Fr, and by Th on the authority of Ibn-Nejdeh, without C: by Ibn-Háni, [jir-iyoYapN,] with C, on the authority of AZ. (TA.)
jaArK applied to water [and the like], [Running, or flowing, or] pressing forward, in a downward and in a level course. (Mṣb.)
Also, [as meaning Running,] applied to a horse and the like. (Mṣb.)
SadaqapN jaAriyapN † A permanent, continuous, charitable donation; such as the unalienable legacies provided for various benevolent purposes. (TA.)
jaAriyapN A ship; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because of its running upon the sea: (Mṣb:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: pl. jawaArK (TA.)
The sun; (Ḳ;) because of its running from region to region: (TA:) or the sun's disk in the sky. (T, TA.) And AljawaAriI Alkun-asu The stars. (TA. [But see art. kns.])
The wind: pl. as above. (TA.)

A girl, or young woman; (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) a female of which the male is termed gulaAmN; so called because of her activity and running; opposed to EajuwzN: (Mgh:) and ‡ a female slave; (Mgh voce gulaAmN;) [in this sense] applied even to one who is an old woman, unable to work, or to employ herself actively; alluding to what she was: (Mṣb:) pl. as above. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
† The eye of any animal. (TA.)
† A benefit, favour, boon, or blessing, bestowed by God (Ḳ, TA) upon his servants. (TA.)
UijoriI-N A kind of running: pl. OajaAriI-u. (TA.) You say farasN cuwOajaAriI-a A horse that has several kinds of running. (TA.)
See also Uijoriy-aA.
Uijoriy-apN: see what next follows.
UijoriyaAhu: see what next follows.
Uijoriy-aA The act of running: (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ: [in this sense, erroneously said in the TA to be btxfyf:]) or UijoriI-N↓. (So in this sense in some copies of the Ḳ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Uijoriy-aMCu↓, (Ḳ,) † A custom, or habit, (Ṣ,) or manner, (Ḳ,) that one adopts (Ṣ, Ḳ) and follows; (Ḳ;) [like hijoriy-aA, &c.;] and so UijoriyaMCu↓ without teshdeed: (TA:) and † nature, constitution, or natural disposition; [in the CK, Alxaloqu is erroneously put for Alxuluqu;] as also jiriy-aMCu↓ and Uijoriy-apN↓. (Ḳ.) One says, Alkaramu mino Uijriy-aAhu and mn Uijoriy-aAYihi↓ † Generosity is [a quality] of his nature,, &c. (Lḥ, TA.)
Uijoriy-aMCu: see what next precedes, in two places.
majorFI [A place, and a time, of running,, &c.]. The channel of a river [and of a torrent, &c.: a conduit; a duct; any passage through which a fluid runs: pl. majaArK]. (TA.)
Also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)

mujorK [Making to run]. It is said in a prov., kul-u mujorK fiI AlxalaMCi yusar-u [Every one who makes his horse to run in the solitary place rejoices, because no one can contradict his account of his horse's fleetness]. (Mgh.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 315 and 316, where two other readings are added: kl- mjr bixalaMCK mujiydN, i. e., is possessor of a fleet horse; and kl- mjr bixalaMCK saAbiqN, i. e., is one who outstrips.]
maAjarayaAtN: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. jaz-a, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajozuzu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. jaz-N, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jaz-apN↓, (Ḳ,) [but the latter seems to be an inf. n. of un.,] He cut (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) wool, (IDrd, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) [see Halaqa,] and, as some say, other things, (Mṣb,) or a dense thing, (Mgh,) or hair, (A, Ḳ,) and dry herbage, (Ḳ,) and seed-produce, (A,) and wheat, (Ṣ,) and palm-trees, (Ṣ, ISd, A, Mgh,) meaning their fruit; (Mgh;) as also Ajtz-↓. (Ḳ.) You say, Aijotazazotu↓ AlX-iyHa wagayorahu, and Aijodazazotuhu↓, in the sense of jazazotuhu [I cut the sheeh, a species of wormwood, &c.]. (Ṣ.) You say also, jazazotu AlkaboXa wAln-aEojapa, [I shore, or sheared, the ram and the ewe]; but of the she-goat and he-goat you say, HalaqotuhumaA. (TA.) And jaz-a Aln-axolapa, (Lḥ, A, Mgh,)) aor. _u {yajozuzu}, inf. n. jaz-N and jazaAzN and jizaAzN, (Lḥ, TA,) [like jac-a and jad-a,] He cut off the fruit of the palm-tree. (Mgh, TA.)
See also 4, in four places.

entry.sense: 2. jz-r, inf.n. tajoziyzN, He dried dates. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajz- It attained to the proper time for being cut; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) said [app. of wool, and] of hair, and of herbage, (A,) and wheat, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and barley; (AZ, Mṣb;) as also Astjz-↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of wool, (Mṣb,) and of wheat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and jaz-a↓, [aor., app., _i, as below,] said of wheat. (TA.)

Ajz- AliX-yHu The sheeh [a species of wormwood] attained to the proper time for being cut: (L, TA:) or Ajz- AlX-ayoxu † The old man attained to the proper time for dying. (Ḳ.) [SM says,] AlX-ayoxu seems to be a mistranscription, for AlX-iyHu: if not, it is a tropical expression. (TA.) [But see 4 in art. jzr, and 8 in art. xDr.]
Ajz- Alganamu The sheep attained to the proper time for being shorn; (Ṣ, TA;) as also jaz-a↓. (TA.)
Ajz- Aln-axolu The palm-trees attained to the proper time for having their fruit cut off; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also jaz-a↓. (Ḳ.)

[Hence, app.,] Ajz- Alt-amoru The dates dried; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaz-a↓, aor. _i {yajozizu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. juzuwzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or jaz-N: (Mṣb:) you say tamorN fiyhi juzuwzN Dates in which is dryness. (Ṣ, TA.)
Ajz- Alqawomu The people attained to the proper time for the shearing of their sheep: (Ḳ:) or had their sheep shorn: or had their seed-produce cut. (Ṣ, L.)
Ajz- Alr-ajula He assigned to the man the jiz-ap [or wool,, &c.,] of a sheep. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. Ajtz- and Ajcz-: see 1, in three places.
juz-N i. q. juzoCN. (Bḍ in xv. 44.)
jaz-apN [A single cutting, or shearing, or the like.]. (Ḳ.) See 1.

hom.sense: jiz-apN [A mode, or manner, of cutting, or shearing, or the like]. You say, jaz-ahu jz-apF HasanapF [He cut it, or sheared it,, &c., in a good manner]. (Ḳ, TA.) [in the CK, wajiz-apF is omitted after wajaz-apF; so that the reading there is jaz-apF HasanapF.]

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jazazN↓ and juzaAzN↓ and juzaAzapN↓, (Ḳ,) What is cut, of dates: (Ḳ:) or [a fleece; i. e.,] the wool of a sheep [shorn] in one year: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and the hair of a goat, and of a camel, (see tim-apN,) when shorn; a shorn crop of wool, and of goat's hair, and of camel's hair:] or the wool of a ewe, (Ḳ, TA,) or of a ram, (TA,) when shorn, and not mixed with any other: (Ḳ, TA:) so accord. to AḤát: (TA:) or wool not used after being shorn; (Ḳ;) in which last sense you say also SuwfN jazazN↓: (TA:) pl. jizazN and jazaAYizu: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) the latter like DaraAYiru as pl. of OaqoriDoniI jiz-apF, without regard to the difference of the vowels [in the sing.]. (TA.) One says to another, Oawo jiz-atayoni kaOan-ahu EaAD-N EalaI jiz-apK [Lend thou me the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep]; and the latter gives him the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep. (Ṣ.) And one says of a man with a large beard, EalaI jaz-apK [As though he were biting] the wool of a shorn sheep. (Ḳ, TA: in the CK, jazazN.)

entry.sense: jazazN: see jiz-apN, in two places.

jazaAzN and jizaAzN↓ The act of cutting, or shearing, wool, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) and hair; (Mgh;) and of reaping; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of cutting seed-produce (Mgh, Ḳ) before it has attained to maturity; (Ḳ;) and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees: (Fr, Ṣ, Mgh:) and the time, or season, of shearing sheep [and the like]. (TA.) You say, hecaA zamanu AljazaAzi, and AljizaAzi, This is the time of cutting, or shearing, wool: (Mṣb:) and of reaping: and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees. (Ṣ.)
