juzaAzN What one cuts, or cuts off, of anything; (Ḳ;) the cuttings of wool or any other thing: n. un. with p {juzaAzapN}: (TA:) [as, for instance,] what is redundant of a skin or hide when it is cut: (Ḳ:) or juzaAzapN↓ signifies what falls from a skin or hide (Ṣ, A) or other thing (Ṣ) when it is cut. (Ṣ, A.) See also jiz-apN.
jizaAzN: see jazaAzN

jazuwzN What is cut, or shorn; a masc. n.; and, as also jazuwzapN↓, fem.: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies sheep of which the wool is shorn; (Ṣ, A;) and is similar to rakuwabpN, and HaluwbapN and EaluwfapN: (Ṣ:) Th says that a subst. of this class is only with p, like the three words just mentioned: Lḥ says that it may be with p and without p; and that the pl. in both cases is of the measures fuEulN and faEaAYilu: [in this instance, juzuzN and jazaAYizu:] but ISd says, I hold that fuEulN is the measure of the pl. of a subst. of this class without p, such as rakuwbN, of which the pl. is rukubN; and faEaAYilu, of that which is with rakaAYibu, such as rakuwbapN, of which the pl. is rakaAYibu. (TA.)

hom.sense: jaziyzN and majozuwzN↓ Cut, or shorn. (Ḳ.)
See also jaziyzapN.

entry.sense: juzaAzapN: see jiz-apN:
and juzaAzN.
jazuwzapN: see jazuwzN.

jaziyzapN A flock, or tuft, of wool; as also jizojizapN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which [latter] is a tuft of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonapN,) that is hung upon a woman's camel-vehicle (hawodaj): (Ṣ:) or the latter signifies a tuft of wool tied with threads or strings, with which the woman's camel-vehicle (hwdj) is ornamented: and jazaAYizu [pl. of the former] and jazaAjizu [pl. of the latter] signify tufts of dyed wool which are hung upon the camel-vehicles (hawaAdij) of women on the day of going forth on a journey; also called vukanN: or jazaAYizu, (TA,) or jaziyzN↓, (L,) signifies a kind of beads (xaraz) with which the girls, or slave-girls, (jawaArK,) of the Arabs of the desert are adorned, resembling jazoE: or tufts of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonN,) which were used in the place of anklets. (TA.)
jizojizapN: see jaziyzapN.
mijaz-N An instrument for cutting or shearing. (Ṣ.)
majozuwzN: see jaziyzN.

hom.sense: 1. jazaOahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajozaOu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazoCN, (Ṣ,) He divided it (a thing, Ṣ) into parts, or portions; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) made it to consist of parts, or portions; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also jz-Ohu↓, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoziYapN, (Ṣ,) or tajoziIoCN: (Mṣb:) when that which is divided is property, as, for instance, slaves, only this latter form of the verb, with teshdeed, is used. (TA.)

Also, aor. and inf.n. as above, He took a part, or portion, of it; namely, a thing. (Ḥam p. 117.) And jazaOa AlX-iEora, inf. n. as above; and jz-Ohu↓; He curtailed the poetry of two feet in each verse: or he made the poetry to consist of two feet in each verse. (TA. [See majozuwoCN.])
Also He made it firm, fast, or strong; or he bound it firmly, fast, or strongly; (Xad-ahu;) namely, a thing. (Ḳ.)

jazaOa bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajozaOu}, (TA,) inf. n. jazoCN, (Ṣ,) [and app. juzoCN also,] He was, or became, satisfied, or content, with it; namely, a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaziYa, a dial. var. mentioned by IAạr; (TA;) and AjtzO↓ bh, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tjz-O↓ bh. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
waUin-a AlmaroCa yajozaOu biAlkuraAEi
[And verily the man is satisfied, or content, with the shank of the sheep or goat, &c.]. (TA.) And you say TaEaAmN laA jazoCa lahu Food whereof one is not satisfied with a little. (TA.) And lahu fiI hecaA ganaMCN wajuzoCN [He has, in this, competence and] sufficiency. (Mgh.) And jazaOati AlUibilu biAlr-uTobi Eani AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or [simply] jazaOati AlUibilu, (Ḥar p. 475,) inf. n. juzoCN, with damm, (Ṣ, TA,) and juzuwoCN; (TA;) and jaziYat, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and AjtzOt↓; (Mgh, and Ḥar ubi suprà;) The camels were satisfied, or content, with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.) And AjtzO↓ Eani QmoraOatihi [He was content to abstain from, or be without, conjugal intercourse with his wife]. (M in art. Abl.)
2: see 1, in two places:
and see also 4.

4. AjzOhu It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) [Hence,] AjzO mujozaI gayorihi [or mujozaOa gayorihi] It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, in lieu of another thing or other things; stood, or served, in stead thereof. (Mṣb.) And OajozaOotu Eanoka mujozaOa fulaAnK (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and majozaOa flAn and mujozaOapa flAn and majozaOapa flAn, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also mujozaI flAn and mujozaApa flAn without C and with damm, and majozaI flAn and majozaApa flAn, (Ḳ in art. jzI,) I satisfied, sufficed, or con tented, thee as such a one; I stood thee, or served thee, in stead of such a one. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) And AjzO AlUibila biAlr-uTobi Eani AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijozaMCN; (TA;) and jz-OhA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoziYapN, (Ṣ,) or tajoziIoCN; (TA;) He satisfied, or contented, the camels with green, or fresh, pasture or hesrbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AjzO is also syn. with jazaI; the former being of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; (Akh, Mṣb;) and one may suppress the C, and say OajozaI: (Mgh, Mṣb:) this last is used by some of the lawyers in the sense of [jazaI, i. e.] qaDaI. (Az, Mgh, Mṣb.) One says, OajozaOatN Eanoka XaApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA) as a sacrifice; (TA;) syn. qaDato; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the verb being here a dial. var. of jazato. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Albadanapu tajoziYu Eano saboEapK The camel, or cow, makes satisfaction for seven: or serves in stead of seven. (Mgh.) And hecaA yujoziY uEano hecaA [This will make satisfaction, for this: or this will serve in stead of this]: and, accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-ʼEesà, yujoziI also, suppressing the C (Mgh.)
Also, said of pasture, or herbage, (Ḳ, TA,) and of a meadow, (TA,) ‡ It was, or became, luxuriant: (Ḳ, TA:) because satisfying the beasts that feed upon it. (TA.)
And, said of a company of men, They had their camels satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (TA.)
OajozaOato She (a woman) brought forth females. (Ḳ. [But see juzoCN, from which it is derived.])
AjzO He furnished an awl (mixoSaf, Ṣ, Ḳ, or UiXofaI, Ṣ), (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a knife, (Mṣb,) with a juzoOap, i. e. handle; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AjzI. (Mṣb.)
AjzO AlxaAtama fiI UiSobaEihi He put the ring upon his finger. (Ḳ.)
5. tjz-O It became divided into parts, or portions. (Mṣb, KL.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in three places.

hom.sense: jazoCN: see juzoCN.

It is said by El-Khaṭṭábee to be a name for ruTb [app. meaning ruTobN, i. e. Green, or fresh, pasture or herbage, (see 1 and 4,)], with the people of El-Medeeneh; and occurs in a trad.; but the reading commonly known is jrw. (TA.)

entry.sense: juzoCN A part, or portion, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or division, (TA,) of a thing; (Mṣb, TA;) properly and conventionally; (TA;) as also jazoCN↓; (Ḳ;) a constituent part of a thing, as of a ship, and of a house or tent, and of a sum in reckoning; (B, TA;) [an ingredient of any compound or mixture;] a share, or lot: (TA:) pl. OajozaMCN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.:) it has no other pl. (Sb, TA.)
[A volume of a book.]
A foot of a verse. (TA.)

In the Ḳur [xliii. 14], where it is said, wajaEaluwA lahu mino EibaAdihi juzoCFA, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as some read, juzuCFA, (Bḍ,) it means Females; (Ḳ, TA;;) i. e., they asserted the angels to be the daughters of God: so says Th: and Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says that it means, they asserted God's share of offspring to be the females; but that he had not found this in old poetry, nor had persons worthy of confidence related it on the authority of the Arabs [of the classical times]: Z disallows it, asserting it to be a lie against the Arabs; and Bḍ follows him: El-Khafájee says that the word may be used figuratively; for, as Eve was created of a part (juzoC) of Adam, the word jzC may be applied to denote the female. (MF, TA.)

juzoOapN The handle of the [kind of awl called] mixoSaf, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of the UiXofiI: (Ṣ:) AZ says that it is not [the handle, or hilt,] of the sword, nor of the dagger; but is the handle of the miYovarap with which camels' feet are branded. (TA.) [See also Dab-apN.]
A vine-prop; (Ḳ, TA;) a piece of wood with which a vine is raised from the ground. (TA.)
In the dial. of the tribe of Sheybán, The hinder, or hindermost, Xuq-ap [or oblong piece of cloth] of a tent. (TA.)
[juzoYiI-N Relating to a part or portion or division; partial; particular; contr. of kul-iI-N.]
[And, as a subst., A particular: pl. juzoYiy-aAtN.]
[juzoYiy-apN The quality of relating to a part or portion or division; relation to a part, &c.; particularity.]
jaAziYN [act. part. n. of 1].
hecaA rajulN jaAziYuka mino rajulK This is a man sufficing thee as a man. (Ḳ,* TA.)

ZaboyapN jaAziYapN A doe-gazelle that is satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]: pl. jawaAziYu. (Ṣ.) The pl. is explained by IḲt as meaning Gazelles: (TA:) [or] it signifies [or signifies also] Wild bulls or cows; (Ḳ, TA;) because they are satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage so as to be in no need of water. (TA.) Also, the pl., Palm-trees; as not needing irrigation. (TA.)
OajozaOu More [and most] satisfying or sufficing or satisfactory: hence, AlfaArisu OajozaOu mina Alr-aAjili [The horseman is more satisfactory than the footman]. (Mgh.)
majozaON and mujozaON are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: mujoziYN: see jaziIoCN.
Also A strong, fat, camel; because sufficing for the wants of the rider and carrier. (TA.)
Also, and mujoziYapN, A woman who brings forth females. (TA. [But see juzoCN, from which the verb is derived.])

entry.sense: majozaOapN and mujozaOapN are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)
majozuwoCN Divided into parts, or portions. (TA.)
[Having a part, or portion, taken from it: see 1.]

A verse curtailed of two [of the original] feet: [like the hazaj and muDaAriE, &c., which were originally of six feet each, but of which every known example is of four only:] or a verse consisting of two feet only: [as a kind of the rajaz, and two kinds of the munosariH: to each of which, or, accord. to some, to the former of which only, when thus consisting of only two feet, the term manohuwkN is also applied:] the former is said to be EalaI Als-alobi; and the latter, EalaI Alwujuwbi. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jazara, aor. _i {yajoziru} and sometimes _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jazorN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) He cut, or cut off, (Mgh, Ḳ,) a thing. (TA.)

jazara, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajozuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [inf. n. as above,] He slaughtered a camel (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) or other animal, (Mṣb,) and skinned it; (Ṣ;) as also Ajtzr↓. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, jazara lahumo, meaning He slaughtered for them a camel. (A.) And Ajtzr↓ Alqawoma jazuwrFA He slaughtered and skinned for the people a camel. (TA.)

jazara Aln-axola, aor. _i {yajoziru} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _u {yajozuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jazorN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jazaArN and jizaArN, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, he spoiled the palm-trees in fecundating them. (TA.)
And jazara, (TA,) inf. n. jazorN, (Ḳ,) He gathered honey from the hive. (Ḳ, TA.)

jazara, aor. _i {yajoziru} and _u {yajozuru}, inf. n. jazorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) ‡ It (water) sank, and disappeared; became low; or became remote; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) decreased; went away; (TA;) flowed away, or retired, (A, Mgh,* Mṣb,) from the earth, or land: (A, Mgh:) it (the sea, and a river, Lth, ISd) ebbed; contr. of mad-a; (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ; [but in this last sense, only _i is authorized by the Ḳ, and app. by ISd also, as the aor.;]) i. e., retreated, or went back; (Ṣ. Mṣb;*) as also Anjzr↓; (ISd, TA;) or ceased to increase. (Lth, Mgh.)

4. Ajzrhu, (Ḳ,) or Ajzr Alqawoma, (ISk, Ṣ,) He gave to him, or to the people, a sheep or a goat, for him, or for them, to slaughter; (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning a ewe or a ram or a she-goat; (ISk, Ṣ;) or a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: (TA:) and Oajozarotuhu XaApF I gave to him a ewe or a ram or a she-goat, and he slaughtered it: (ISk, TA:) and Oajozarotuka baEiyrFA, or XaApF, I gave to thee a camel, or a sheep or goat, that thou mightest slaughter it: (A:) [but] accord. to ISk, one does not say Oajozarotuhumo naAqapF, because a she-camel is fit for other purposes than that of slaughter: (Ṣ:) and accord. to some, one should not say Ajzrhu jazuwrFA, but Ajzrhu jazarapF. (TA.)
Ajzr He (a camel) attained to the fit time for his being slaughtered. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Ajzr Aln-axolu The palm-trees attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[And hence,] Ajzr AlXayoxu ‡ The old man attained to the fit time for his dying; (Ḳ, TA;) being aged, and near to his perishing; like as the palm-tree attains to the fit time for having its fruit cut off. (TA.) Youths used to say to an old man Oajozarota yaA Xayoxu, meaning, Thou hast attained to the fit time for thy dying, O old man: and he would say, OaIo baniI-a watuHotaDaruwna, i. e., “ [O my sons, and] ye shall die youths:” but accord. to one way of relation, it is Oajozazota; from Oajaz-a Albur-u “the wheat attained to the proper time for being out.” (Ṣ.)
Ajzr Alqawomu The people attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (Yz, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 8.
6. tajaAzaraA † They reviled each other (Ḳ, TA) vehemently, or excessively. (TA.)
7: see 1.
8. Ajtzr: see 1, in two places.

AjtzrwA fiI AlqitaAli and tjz-rwA↓ (Ḳ, TA) They fought one another [app. so that they cut one another in pieces]. (TA.) [In the Ḳ, this is immediately followed, as though for the purpose of explanation, by the words tarakuwhumo jazarFA lils-ibaAEi OaIo qiTaEFA: but there is evidently an omission in this place, at least of the conjunction wa.]
And AjtzrwA They had a camel slaughtered for them. (A.)

hom.sense: jazorN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
And also † The sea (Ḳ, TA) itself. (TA.)

jazarN, (not jizarN↓, Fr, Ṣ, [but see what follows,]) [a coll. gen. n.,] Fat sheep or goats: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) n. un. jazarapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or sheep, or goats, that are slaughtered; (M;) as also jazuwrN↓: (Ḳ:) n. un. as above: (M: in the Ḳ jazorapN:) or jazarapN signifies a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: or a sheep, or goat, to which the owners betake themselves and which they slaughter: and anything that is lawful to be slaughtered; n. un. of jazarN, which is sometimes [written jizarN↓,] with fet-ḥ to the z. (TA.)

jazaru Als-ibaAEi The flesh which beasts or birds of prey eat. (Ṣ, Mgh.) One says, tarakuwhumo jazarFA (Ṣ, Ḳ) They slew them: (Ṣ:) or they left them cut in pieces lils-ibaAEi [for the beasts or birds of prey]. (Ḳ.)
And SaAruwA jazarFA liloEaduw-i [They became a prey to the enemy, cut in pieces]. (Mgh.)
See also jaziyrapN.

Also, and jiz-rN↓, (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter with kesr to the j, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) arabicized, (Ḳ,) from the Persian [Gazaro], (AḤn,) [coll. gen. ns., meaning Carrots, or the carrot;] a certain root, (Oaruwmap,) which is eaten, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known: (TA:) n. un. with p {jazarapN}; (Ḳ;) or jazarapN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb:) the best kind is the red and sweet, which grows in winter: it is hot in the extreme of the second degree; moist in the first degree; (TA;) diuretic; (Ḳ, TA;) lenitive; emollient; (TA;) strengthening to the venereal faculty; emmenagogue: the putting of its pounded leaves upon festering ulcers is advantageous: (Ḳ, TA:) it is difficult of digestion; and engenders bad blood; but is made wholesome with vinegar and mustard. (TA.)
[See also HinozaAbN, in art. Hzb.]

entry.sense: jizarN: see jazarN, in three places.
jizaArN The time of the cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (Yz, TA.) [See also 1.]

jazuwrN A camel [that is slaughtered, or to be slaughtered]; (Ḳ;) applied to the male and the female: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or (as some say, Ṣgh, Mṣb) properly a she-camel that is slaughtered: (Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but the former is the correct assertion; (TA;) though the word is fem., (IAmb, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) on the authority of hearsay; (TA;) therefore you say, raEati AljazuwrC [the camel for slaughter pastured]: (IAmb, Mṣb:) or when used alone, it is fem., because what are slaughtered are mostly she-camels: (TA:) and when used as a common term, it implies the like of predominance [of the fem. gender]: (Háshiyeh of Esh-Shiháb, TA:) [the shares into which the jzwr is divided in the game called Almayosir are described voce badoCN:] pl. juzurN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jazaAYiru and juzuraAtN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last of which is pl. of juzurN, like as TuruqaAtN is of TuruqN. (TA.)
See also jazarN.

juzaArapN, of a camel, The extremities; (Ṣ, A;) namely, (Ṣ,) the fore and kind legs, (AlyadaAni waAlr-ijolaAni, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the head, (Ṣ,) or neck: (A, Ḳ:) because the slaughterer receives them; (Ṣ;) they being his hire, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or right, (A,) not being included among the shares in the game called Almayosir. (TA.) But when a horse is said to be Eabolu AljuzaArapi, (Ṣ,) or Daxomu AljuzaArapi, (M,) what is meant is thickness of the fore and hind legs, and abundance of sinews; and the head is not included, because largeness of the head, in a horse, is a fault. (Ṣ, M.)
jizaArapN The trade of him who slaughters camels (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) and other animals. (Mṣb.)

jaziyrapN ‡ An island; land in the sea [or in a river], from which the water has flowed away, so that it appears; (Az, Mgh;) and in like manner, land which a torrent does not overflow, but which it surrounds; (Az, TA;) land from which the tide retires; as also jazarN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because cut off from the main land: (Ṣ:) or because of the retiring of the water from it: (Mṣb:) pl. jazaAYiru: (Ṣ, Mgh:) [also, a peninsula:] and a piece of ground or land. (Kr, TA.)
jaz-aArN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jiz-iyrN↓ (Ḳ) and jaAzirN↓ (A) One who slaughters camels (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and other animals. (Mṣb.)
jiz-iyrN: see what next precedes.
jaAzirN: see what next precedes.

majozarN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or majozirN, with kesr to the z, (Ṣ, Ibn-Málik,) contr to rule, as the aor. of the verb is with damm, (Ibn-Málik, TA,) and sometimes majozarapN↓ [or majozirapN], (Mṣb,) A place where camels are slaughtered, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and other animals, (Mṣb,) namely, bulls and cows and sheep and goats, and where their flesh is sold: pl. majaAziru. (TA.) In a trad. of ʼOmar, persons are enjoined to avoid majaAzir, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning as above; because of their uncleanness; (TA;) or because the witnessing of the slaughter of animals hardens the heart and dispels mercy: (IAth, TA:) or the meaning is, places of assembly; because a camel is slaughtered only where people are collected together: (Ṣ, TA:) the majozarap↓ is one of the places in which it is forbidden to perform the usual prayers. (Mgh.)
majozarapN or majozirapN: see majozarN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. jazoEN [inf. n. of jazaEa] signifies The act of cutting; or cutting off. (TA.) [See also 8.]
[Hence,] jazaEa lahu jizoEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off for him a portion of the property. (Ṣ.)

And jazaEa AlwaAdiI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajozaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazoEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He passed the valley to the other side: (Mṣb:) or he passed the valley [in any manner]: (Ḳ:) or he passed across it; i. e., crossed it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, AlOaroDa the land: (Ḳ:) and AlmafaAzapa the desert: and AlmawoDiEa the place. (TA.)

jaziEa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajozaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazaEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juzwEN, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, impatient, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) mina AlX-aIoCi [of the thing]; (Ṣ;) and EalaI fulaAnK [on account of such a one]; (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Alh, &c.;) jazaEN being the contr. of SaborN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, (O, Mṣb,) and found not patience: (Mṣb:) or he manifested grief and agitation: (TḲ:) or he was, or became, affected with grief: or he was, or became, affected with most violent grief, such as prevented him and turned him from that to which he was directing himself, or from his object, and cut him off therefrom: this meaning of cutting off being said by ʼAbd-el-Kádir El-Baghdádee to be the primary signification. (TA.)

2. jz-E, inf. n. tajoziyEN, It (a full-grown unripe date) became ripe to the extent of two thirds of it: (Ṣ:) or to the extent of half of it; (Ḳ, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or became partly ripe: and in like manner one says of a grape. (TA.)
It (a watering-trough, or tank,) had but little remaining in it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
He put a little water into a skin. (TA.)

jz-E fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He caused the impatience (jazaE) of such a one to cease: (Ḳ:) he said to him that which comforted him, or consoled him, and which caused his grief and fear to cease. (IAth.)
4. AjzE jizoEapF, and juzoEapF, He left, or caused to remain, a remainder: (O, Ḳ:) or less than half. (TA.)
AjzEhu He caused him to be impatient: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he caused him to want sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and to be impatient. (Mṣb.)
5: see 7, in two places.
tjz-EwA Alganiymapa They divided among themselves the spoil. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnjzE It (a rope) broke, (Ḳ, TA,) in any manner: (TA:) or broke in halves; (Ḳ, TA;) but if it have broken at its extremity, one does not say AnjzE. (TA.) And AnjzEt AlEaSaA, and tjz-Et↓, The staff, or stick, broke (Ḳ, TA) in halves. (TA.) tjz-E↓ is also said of a spear, and of an arrow, &c., meaning It broke in pieces. (TA.)
8. AjtzEhu He broke it, and cut it off: (Ḳ:) or he broke it off, and cut it off, for himself; namely, a branch, rod, or piece of wood, from a tree. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jazoEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jizoEN↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) but IDrd ascribes the latter to the vulgar, (TA,) [The onyx; so called in the present day;] certain beads, or gems, (xarazN,) (Mṣb,) the beads, or gems, (xaraz, [here rendered by Golius “Murœna seu concha Veneris,” though he also gives what I regard as the only correct signification, namely “onyx,”]) of El-Yemen (Ṣ, Ḳ) [and] of China, (Ḳ) in which are whiteness and blackness, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and to which eyes are likened, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in particular, by Imra-el-Ḳeys, the eyes of wild animals, because their eyes, while they are alive, are black, but when they die, their whiteness appears; (TA;) a kind of stone having many colours, brought from El-Yemen and China; (Ḳzw;) so called because interrupted by various colours; its blackness being interrupted by its whiteness and its yellowness: (IB:) ʼÁïsheh's necklace [which she lost on the occasion that subjected her to the accusation of adultery] was of jazoE of Dhafári: (TA:) the wearing it in a signet induces anxiety, or disquietude of mind, and grief, and terrifying dreams, and altercation with men; and if the hair of one who experiences difficulty in bringing forth be wound upon it, she brings forth at once: (Ḳ: [and Ḳzw says the like, and more of a similar kind:]) n. un. jazoEapN (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) and jizoEapN. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also what next follows.

jizoEN, (Ṣ, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but AO says that it should be with fet-ḥ, [jazoEN↓,] (Ḳ) The place of bending, or turning, (munoEaTaf, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, or munoHanFI, Aṣ, Ḳ,) of a valley: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the middle thereof: or the place where it ends: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or its side: (Mṣb:)
or the place of passing, or crossing, of a valley: or a widening part, of the narrow places, thereof, whether it produce plants, &c. or do not produce them: (TA:) or it is not so called unless [it be a part] having width, and producing trees, &c.: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it may be without plants, or herbage, or the like: (TA:) or a place, in a valley, in which are no trees: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or a place, of a valley, taking a round and wide form: (TA:) pl. OajozaAEN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
A place of alighting, or abiding, of a people. (Ḳ.)
Elevated land, or ground, by the side of which is a low, or depressed, part. (Ḳ.)
A bee-hive: pl. as above. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
See also jazoEN.

entry.sense: jazuEN: see what next follows.

jaziEN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaAziEN↓ and jazuEN↓ (Ḳ) and jazuwEN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and juzaAEN↓ (Ḳ) part. ns. of jaziEa; [Impatient;, &c.;] (Mṣb, Ḳ;) but the last two have an intensive signification [very impatient, or having much impatience;, &c.]. (IAạr.)
juzoEapN: see what next follows, in two places.

hom.sense: jizoEapN A little, or small quantity, of property, or wealth; and of water, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) remaining in a skin, (Lḥ, IDrd,) and in a leathern bottle, or other vessel, (IDrd,) and in a pool left by a torrent, but not in a well, (TA,) as also juzoEapN↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) and [the dim.] juzayoEapN↓, (IDrd,) and of milk, in a skin; (Lḥ;) or a third part, or nearly that quantity, of water, in a trough, or tank; (ISh;) or a quantity of water, and of milk, less than the half of the skin or other vessel, and of the trough; (TA;) and, as also juzoEapN↓, somewhat remaining; (O, Ḳ;) or the latter, particularly, of milk; (IAạr;) or both, accord. to some, [a remainder consisting of] less than half; (TA;) and the former, a portion [not defined] of property, or wealth; (Ṣ;) and particularly a portion of a flock of sheep or goats; (Aboo-Leylà, Ḳ;) as also juzayoEapN↓; (Ṣ;) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee; but in the Mj of IF, jaziyEapN↓, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (TA:) the pl. of jizoEapN is jizaEN. (ISh.)
And [hence,] ‡ A part, or portion, of the night, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) past or to come, (TA,) less than half, (O, Ḳ,) of the former part thereof or of the latter part. (Ḳ.)

A place in which is a collection of trees (Ḳ, TA) among which the camels or other beasts are made to rest at night from the cold, and are confined when they are hungry, or returning from water, or under rain. (TA.)
Also n. un. of jizoEN as syn. with jazoEN. (TA.)

entry.sense: juzaAEN: see jaziEN.
jazuwEN: see jaziEN.
jaziyEapN and juzayoEapN: see jizoEapN, in three places.

hom.sense: jaAziEN: see jaziEN.

Also The piece of wood which is placed in the trellis of a grape-vine, crosswise, upon which are laid the branches of the vine; (Ṣ, Ḳ) not known to Aboo-Saʼeed; (Ṣ;) it is thus placed for the purpose of raising the branches from the ground; and this piece of wood is also called xaXabapN jaAziEapN; the latter word being thus used as an epithet. (TA.) Also Any piece of wood that is put crosswise between two things for a thing to be borne upon it (Ḳ, TA) is called its jAzE. (TA.)

entry.sense: mujaz-aEN Interrupted by various colours [like the jazoE or onyx]: (IB:) or anything in which are blackness and whiteness; as also mujaz-iEN↓: (Ḳ:) and flesh-meat in which are whiteness and redness. (TA.) [Hence,] nuwFI mujaz-aEN and mujaz-iEN↓ Datestones of which some, or some parts, have been scraped, or abraded, so as to have become white, the rest being left of their [original] colour: (Ḳ:) likened to the jazoE. (TA.) And busorN majaz-iEN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mujaz-aEN; (Ḳ;) the former, says Sh, accord. to El-Ma'arree, but he adds that he himself held the latter to be the right; Az says that he heard the former from the people of Hejer, and it has the authority of A' Obeyd; (TA;) Full-grown dates that have ripened to the half; (Ḳ, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or to the extent of two thirds: (Ṣ:) or that have become partly ripe: (TA:) fem. with p {mujaz-aEapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner you say tamorN mutajaz-iEN↓ dates that have ripened to the half. (TA.)
mujaz-iEN: see mujaz-aEN, in three places.
HawoDN mujaz-iEN A watering-trough, or tank, having but little water remaining in it. (Ḳ.)
mutajaz-iEN: see mujaz-iEN.

1. jazofN [inf. n. of jazafa] signifies The taking a thing [in the manner termed] majaAzafapF and jizaAfFA [i. e. by conjecture, not knowing the measure nor the weight]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the taking largely, or copiously: (IF, Mṣb, TA:) and it is [from] a Persian word. (Mṣb. [See juzaAfN, below.]) And you say, jazafa fiI Alkayoli, inf. n. jazofN, He gave large measure: (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb:) and jazafa lahu fiI Alkayoli He gave him large measure. (Jm, TA.)
3. jAzf, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. mujaAzafapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and jizaAfN, (Ṣ, TA,) He sold, or bought, a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Mṣb:) or he conjectured in selling and buying. (Ḳ.)
He acted in an easy, or a facile, manner, (Mṣb, TA,) in selling or buying. (Mṣb.)
And hence, jAzf binafosihi ‡ He perilled, endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself; as though he acted in an easy manner with himself. (TA.)
5. tjz-f fiyhi He picked out, or selected, the good in it; syn. tanaq-ada [in the CK, erroneously, tanaf-aca]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
8. Ajtrf He bought a thing by conjecture, not knowing the measure nor the weight. (AA, Ḳ.)
jazofN Of unknown quantity, whether measured or weighed. (Nh, TA.)
jizofapN A portion of a number of cattle: (Ḳ:) and of hair. (TA)
jazaAfN: see what next follows, in two places.

juzaAfN, accord. to the ʼEyn, in selling and buying, is [The selling, and buying,] by conjecture, without measuring and without weighing; and by rule should be jizaAfN↓, with kesr; i. e., if formed in accordance to the verb [which is jaAzafa]: (Mgh:) or the selling or buying a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Mṣb:) or conjecture in selling and buying; as also jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and juzaAfapN↓ and jizaAfapN↓ and jazaAfapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) arabicized, from GuzaAfo, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) which is Persian: (Mṣb, TA:) they say laAfo wGazaAfo, meaning “excess in speech, by conjecture:” accord. to the Jm, its primary signification is muchness, or copiousness: (TA:) some say that the most chaste form of jzAf is jizaAfN↓, with kesr; [because this is a regular inf. n. of jaAzafa;] (MF, TA;) and some, that the triple vocalization of the j in jzAf is a kind of jzAf [i. e. conjecture], since all assert it to be a Persian word arabicized, and it cannot be so and be also an inf. n., conformable to the verb and to rule: it seems that, when they arabicized it, its original was gradually forgotten, so they formed from it a verb, and derived from it, and made it analogous. (TA.)
bayoEN juzaAfN and jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and jaziyfN↓ (Ḳ) and mujotazafN↓ (TA) A thing sold, or bought, of unknown quantity, whether measured or weighed. (TA.) [See also jazofN.]
jizaAfN: see juzaAfN, in four places.
jazuwfN A pregnant female exceeding the term of her bringing forth. (Ḳ.)
jaziyfN: see juzaAfN.
jazaAfapN and juzaAfapN and jizaAfapN: see juzaAfN.
jaz-aAfN A fisherman. (El-'Azeezee, Ḳ.)
jaAzifN fiI kalaAmihi † One who pours forth his speech without rule. (Mṣb.)
mijozafapN A fishing-net. (El-'Azeezee, Ḳ.)
bayoEN mujotazafN: see juzaAfN.

hom.sense: 1. jazalahu, (Ḳ,) or jazaluwA naAqapF, (Ṣ,) aor. _i {yajozilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jazolN, (Ṣ,) He cut it (a thing, Ṣ) in two pieces, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a sword. (Ḳ.)

jazaluwA naAqapF They cut the base of the neck of a she-camel, that was slaughtered and dead, in the part between the two shoulder-joints, in order that the neck might become relaxed; not cutting the whole of it; previously to skinning. (Ḥam p. 689.)
jazalahu Alqatabu, (Ḳ,* TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; and Ajzlhu↓; The saddle cut it; namely, the withers of a camel. (Ḳ,* TA.)

jazila, aor. _a {yajozalu}. (Ḳ.) inf. n. jazalN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a camel) had a gall, or sore, in the withers, in consequence of which a bone came forth from it, and the place thereof became depressed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he had his withers cut by the saddle: (Ḳ:) or he had a gall, or sore, in the withers, penetrating into the interior, and killing him. (TA.) The epithet applied to a camel in this case is Oajozlu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) fem. jazolaMCu: pl. juzolN (Ḳ.) See also Oaxozalu
jazula, aor. _u {yajozulu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazaAlapN, (Mṣb,) said of firewood, (Mṣb, TA,), &c., (TA,) It was thick and large. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) ‡ He possessed good, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA,) strong, firm, (TA,) judgment, (Ṣ * Ḳ, TA,) [and natural disposition, and intelligence; for] jazaAlapN is used in relation to judgment and natural disposition and intelligence: (Ḥam p. 770:) and jazaAlapu Alr-aOoI signifies † firmness of judgment: (TA:) and AljazaAlapu fiI AlmanoTiqi, † chasteness, or clearness, or eloquence, and firmness, in speech. (Ḥar p. 8.)
4: see 1.
Ajzl EaTiy-atuhu ‡ He made his gift large. (TA.) And Ajzl lahu mina AlEaTaMCa, (Ṣ,) or fiI AlEaTaMCi, (Mṣb, TA,) ‡ He gave to him largely. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

entry.sense: 10. Astjzl raOoyahu fiI hecaA † He esteemed his judgment, or opinion, good [and strong and firm (see jazula)] in this [matter]; syn. Aisotajowadahu (TA.)
jazolN Large and dry firewood: (Ṣ:) or dry firewood: (Ḳ:) or thick, large firewood. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

‡ Much of a thing; as also jaziylN↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter, great, or large; [and so the former:] you say EaTaMCN jazolN and jaziylN↓ ‡ [a great, or large, gift]: (Ṣ, TA:*) and vawaAbN jaziylN↓ ‡ [a great, or large, recompense]: (TA:) pl. jizaAlN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) either of the former or of the latter. (TA.) And [the fem.] jazolapN ‡ [A woman] large in the posteriors. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ Generous; munificent. (Ḳ, TA.)

‡ Intelligent; firm, or sound, in judgment. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, fulaAnN jazolu Alr-aOoIi ‡ [Such a one is firm, or sound, in judgment]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And when this is said to you, and you desire to deny it, say, balo jazilu↓ Alr-aOoIi ‡ Nay, unsound in judgment; from jazalN, [inf. n. of jazila,] relating to a gall, or sore, in the withers [of a camel]. (A, TA.) You say also AimoraOapN jazolapN † A woman possessing judgment: (Ṣ:) or intelligent; firm, or sound, in judgment; as also jazolaMCu↓: (Ḳ:) [but] IDrd says that jzAlMC, [app. a mistranscription for jazolaMCu,] as syn. with jazolapN, is not of established authority. (TA.)
Applied to a word, or an expression, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) ‡ Strong, (PṢ,) sound, correct; (PṢ, TḲ;) contr. of rakiykN (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And applied to language, † Chaste, clear, or eloquent, and comprehensive. (TA.)
jizolN: see jizolapN
jazilu Alr-aOoIi: see jazol
jizolapN A piece, or portion cut off. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
A large portion of dates; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jizolN↓ (Ḳ)
zamanN AljizaAlu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AljazaAli (Ḳ) The time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jaziylN: see jazolN, in three places.

hom.sense: Oajozalu; fem. jazolaMCu; pl. juzolN: see jazila:
and for the fem., see also jazolN.
1. jazamahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor _i, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazomN, (Mṣb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) namely, a thing: (Mṣb:) [like jaramahu, &c.]

jazama Aln-axola He cut off the fruit of the palmtrees: (Mṣb:) [like jarama Alnxl: but see another explanation, below.] And jazama mina Aln-axolapi jizomFA [He cut off a portion of the fruit from the palmtree]. (TA.)

jazama AlHarofa, (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) He made the letter quiescent; (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i.e., the final letter of a declinable word; (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb;) he cut it off from motion: (Mṣb:) or as though he cut off from it declinability: (Mbr, TA:) from jazama in the first of the senses explained above: jazomN in a declinable word being like sukuwnN in an indeclinable word. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. of En-Nakha'ee, Alt-akobiyru jazomN wAlt-asoliymu jazomN, meaning that neither should be prolonged in utterance, and that the last letter in each should be without a case-ending, i.e., be quiescent; so that one should not say [in prayer] Aall-ehu Oakobaru [nor Als-alaAmu Ealayokumo waraHomapu Qll-ehi, but Oakobaro in the former instance, and Qll-eho in the latter]: or, accord. to Z, that one should not exceed the due bounds in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd: (TA:) or that one should abstain from giving fulness and depth to the sound of the vowel, and should elide it entirely in the places of pausing, and avoid excess in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd. (Mgh.)

jazama EalaI fulaAnK kacaA wakacaA, He made such and such things to be binding, or obligatory, on such a one. (Ḳ.) And jazama Alyamiyna, (Ḳ,) inf.n. as above, (TA,) i. q. OamoDaAhaA; (Ḳ) i. e., He made the oath to be unconditional, without exception, absolutely or decidedly or irreversibly binding; (TḲ;) OamoDaAhaA Albat-apa. (TA.) One says also, Halafa yamiynFA HatomFA jazomFA [He swore an oath in an absolute, a decided, or an irreversible, manner]. (TA.) And jazama AlOamora, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He decided the affair irreversibly. (Ḳ.) And jazamotu maA bayoniI wabayonahu I decided the matter between me and him. (TA.) And OafoEalu celika jazomFA I will do that decidedly; without any indulgence therein. (Mṣb.) And jazama bihi [He asserted it decisively]. (TA passim.) And jazama EalaI AlOamori He decided, or determined, upon, or upon doing, the thing, or affair. (TA.)
Also, this last phrase, He was silent respecting the affair; and so jz-m↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jazama AlbaEiyru famaA yaboraHu [app., The camel stopped, and would not quit his place]. (TA: but the verb jzm is there without any syll. sign.)

jazama Aln-axola, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Ajtzmhu↓; (Ḳ; and the act. part. n. of the latter is also mentioned in the Ṣ;) like jaramahu (Ṣ) [and Ajtrmhu]; He computed by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon the palm-trees. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And jazomN also signifies The selling, or buying, fruit [by conjecture, while yet in a rudimental state,] in its calyxes, for money. (IAạr, TA.)
Also jazama (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He filled a skin; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so jz-m↓, (Ṣ,*K,) inf. n. tajoziymN (Ṣ.)
jazamati AlUibilu, (Fr, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Fr, TA,) The camels satisfied their thirst [as though they filled themselves] with water. (Fr, Ḳ.)
And jazama, (IAạr, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (IAạr, TA,) He ate one meal and was filled thereby: (IAạr, Ḳ) or he ate one meal in every day and night. (Th, Ḳ.)

jazama AlqiraMCapa, (Lth, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, TA,) He performed the reading, or recitation, so as to put the letters in their proper places, in a distinct, or perspicuous, and leisurely, manner. (Lth, Ḳ.)
And jazomN in writing means The making the letters even. (Ḳ.)
jazama bisaloHihi He voided part of his excrement, part thereof remaining: or he cast forth his excrement. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in four places.
4. Ajzm naxolahu He sold his palm-trees. (TA.)
5. tjz-mti AlEaSaA The staff became split or cracked. (Ḳ.)
7. Anjzm [It became cut, or cut off.]
[And hence,] It (the final letter of a declinable word) became, or was made, quiescent. (Ṣ, TA.)
It (a bone) broke, or became broken. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
Ajtzm jizomapF mina AlmaAli He took a portion of the cattle, or property, and left a portion. (Ḳ.)
Ajtzm HaZiyratahu He bought his HZyrp [or enclosure for camels, &c.]: (AḤn, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemámeh. (AḤn, TA.)
Ajtzm Aln-axolapa He bought the fruit, only, of the palm-tree: and Ajtzm naxola fulaAnK he bought the palm-trees of such a one. (TA.)

hom.sense: jazomN [an inf.n. (see 1) used as an epithet]. You say HukomN jazomN An indissoluble and irreversible decree or ordinance, or sentence; like qaDaMCN HatomN. (Mṣb.)
A reed-pen (qalamN) having the nib evenly, not obliquely, cut. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)

The modern Arabic character, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) composed of the letters of the alphabet: (Ḳ:) accord. to AḤát, (TA,) so called because it was cut off from the character of Himyer, (Ḳ, TA,) i.e., the musonad, which they have still in El-Yemen. (TA.)

A thing that is stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ,) that she may think it to be her young one, [when it is taken forth,] and incline to it, [and therefore yield her milk;] like the durojap [q. v.]. (El-Umawee, Ṣ.)
A thing, or an event, that comes before its time, or season: (Ḳ:) that which comes in its time, or season, is termed wazomN. (TA.)

entry.sense: jizomN A portion, share, or lot, (Ḳ,) of palmtrees (TA) [and app. of the fruit of a palm-tree, &c.: see 1, third sentence].

hom.sense: jazomapN [The sign that is written over the final letter of a declinable word when it is quiescent].
A single act of eating. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense:
jizomapN A hundred [head] of cattle, and upwards: or from ten to forty: (Ḳ:)
or it is peculiarly of camels; like SiromapN: (TA:) or such a portion as is termed Siromap of camels; and such as is termed firoqap of sheep. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 8.]
jaAzimN A full water-skin or milk-skin; as also mijozamN↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) and [the pl.] jawaAzimu filled milk-skins. (Ḳ.)
Also, applied to a camel, and jawaAzimu applied to camels, Satisfied with water. (Ḳ.)
mijozamN: see jaAzimN
majozuwmN [Cut, or cut off.]
[And hence,] applied to the final letter of a declinable word, Made quiescent. (TA.)

1. jazaI, aor _i, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jazaMCN, (Mṣb,) It (a thing) paid; gave, or rendered, as a satisfaction; or made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction: (Mṣb:) or satisfied; sufficed; or contented. (Ḳ.) And jazayotu Ald-ayona I paid the debt. (Mṣb.) And jazayotu fulaAnFA Haq-ahu I paid such a one his right, or due. (TA.) And maA yajoziyniI hecaA Alv-awobu This garment does not suffice me. (TA.)

And hence, (TA,) jazaI Eanohu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) It (a thing) paid for him; gave, or rendered, [a thing] as a satisfaction for him; made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction for him; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) and some of the lawyers use AjzI↓ in this sense, like AjzO: (Az, Mgh, Mṣb:) jazaI is of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, and AjzO of the dial. of Temeem. (Akh, Mṣb.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ii. 45], laA tajoziI nafosN Eano nafosK XayoYFA [A soul shall not give anything as a satisfaction for a soul, i. e. for another soul: or a soul shall not make satisfaction for a soul at all; accord. to the latter rendering, XyYA being put in the accus. case after the manner of an inf. n.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say also, jazato Eanoka XaApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee [as a sacrifice]; (Ṣ, TA;) as also Oajozato↓: (TA:) Benoo-Temeem say OajozaOato, with C: (Ṣ, TA:) this last, thus explained, is a dial, var. mentioned by IḲṭṭ (Mṣb.) And AjzI↓ kacaA Eano kacaA Such a thing stood, or served, in lieu, in the place, or in stead, of such a thing, without sufficing. (Zj, Ḳ.) And yujoziI↓ qaliylN mino kaviyrK; and hecaAmino hecaA; A little stands, or serves, in lieu of much; and this, of this. (IAạr, TA.) And AjzI↓ Eanohu mujozaI fulaAnK and mujozaApa fulaAnK and (as though the augmentative letter [A in AjzI] were imagined to be rejected, TA) majozaI flAn and majozaApa flAn He satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him as such a one; he stood, or served, him in stead of such a one; a dial. var. of AjzO. (Ḳ.) And AjzI↓ mujozaI gayorihi It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, as another thing; it stood, or served, in stead of another thing. (Mṣb.) And AjzAka↓, with the [second] objective complement suppressed, It was sufficient for thee. (Mgh.)

jazaAha kacaA (Mṣb,* TA,) and jazaAhu bihi (Ḳ,) or bimaA SanaEa, (Ṣ,) and Ealayohi, (Ḳ,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him (Mṣb, Ḳ TA) [for such a thing, for it, or for what he had done]; as also jAzAhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAzaApN and jizaMCN: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Fr, [contr. to many instances in the Ḳur,] the former verb relates only to good; and the latter, to good and to evil: but accord. to others, the former may relate to good and to evil; and the latter, to evil. (TA.) [See also jazaMCN, below.] One says, in praying for another, jazaAhu Qll-ehu xayorFA May God repay him good: and requite, or recompense, him for good [that he has done]. (Mṣb.) And jaAzayotuhu↓ bicanobihi I punished him for his crime, or sin, or act of disobedience. (Mṣb.) And jazaI Eanohu fulaAnFA He requited, compensated, or recompensed, for him, such a one. (TA.)
jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu: see 3.
3: see 1, latter part, in two places.
[jAzAhu xayorFA He prayed for a reward for him from God: or said to him, May God reward thee. (Golius, on the authority of Z.)]

[jAzI biHarofK and biZarofK, He employed a particle, and an adverbial noun, as conditional; to denote that, with what follows, it expresses a condition with its complement. For instance, in the Ṣ, voce Hayovu, it is said,Hayovu mina AlZ-uruwfi Al-atiI laA yujaAzaI bihaA Uil-aA maEa maA, i. e. Hyv is one of the adverbial nouns that are not employed conditionally, or to denote that, with what follows, they express a condition with its complement, unless with mA affixed thereto. See jazaMCN, below.]
jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu↓ [I vied, or contended, with him in repaying, requiting, compensating, or recompensing, and] I overcame him [therein]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 4. AjzI: see 1, in seven places.
Also He furnished a knife with a handle; a dial. var. of AjzO: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) but ISd doubts its being so. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAzI dayonahu, and bidayonihi, He demanded payment of his debt. (Ḳ.) You say, tajaAzayotu dayoniI EalaI fulaAnK I demanded payment of my debt [owed by such a one]. (Ṣ.)
tajaAzayA [They two repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, each other]. (TA in art. qrD.)
8. AjtzAhu He sought, or demanded, of him repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense. (Ḳ.)
jizoIN [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p {jizoyapN}]: see what next follows.

jizoyapN The tax that is taken from the free nonMuslim subjects of a Muslim government; (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) whereby they ratify the compact that ensures them protection: (IAth:) [from jazaI;] as though it were a compensation for their not being slain: (IAth, Mgh:) [or from the Persian Gizoyaho:] and also, (metaphorically, Mgh,) ‡ a land-tax; (Mgh, Ḳ;) a tax that is paid by the owner of land: (TA:) pl. jizFI (Ṣ,) or jizoIN↓, (Mṣb,) or both, (Ḳ,) [but the latter is, properly speaking, a coll. gen. n.,] and jizaMCN, (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, jazACN,]) like kitaAbN. (TA.)

jazaMCN Repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense, for a thing; as also jaAziyapN↓ (Ḳ;) a satisfaction, good for good, and evil for evil; (Er-Rághib, TA;) sometimes a reward, and sometimes a punishment: (AHeyth, TA:) [the former word is an inf. n.; see 1;] the latter, a quasi-inf. n.: jawaAzK is pl. of the latter, or of the former, or of jaAzK↓, accord. to different writers explaining the saying of El-Hoteí-ah,
mano yafoEali Alxayora laA yaEodamo jawaAziyahu
[Whoso doth good, he will not want his rewards, or his rewarders]. (TA.)

[Hence,] jazaMCa AlEuTaAsi In the time between the complimentary prayer addressed to a sneezer (called Alt-aXomiyt) and the sneeze; [or as soon as one can compliment a sneezer by repeating the usual prayer of yaroHamuka Qll-ehu (God have mercy on thee).] (TA voce muEaAqibN)
[And jazaMCu XaroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; also called jawaAbu XaroTK, q.v. in art. jwb]
[And Harofu jazaMCK A particle denoting compensation, or the complement of a condition. And A conditional particle; as Uino; also termed HarofN lilojazaMCi, and jazaMCN alone, and Harofu XaroTK.]
huwa cuw jazaMCK He is possessed of sufficiency, or competence, or wealth. (TA.)
jaAzK [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.]: see jazaMCN
hecaA rajulN jaAziyka mino rajulK This is a man sufficient for thee as a man. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jaAziyapN: see jazaMCN.
Also Wild bulls, or cows. (TA.) [See jaAziYN.]

entry.sense: majozFI and mujozFI are used as inf. ns. of 4. [See 1.] (Ḳ.)

mujozK [act. part. n. of 4. It is said in the TA that mjzI, applied to a camel, signifies Sufficing for a load or burden; and its pl. is mjAzI. And that mjzI liOamorihi, applied to a man, signifies Sufficing for his affair. But mjzI in these instances is evidently a mistranscription, for mujozK; and mjAzI, for majaAzK, Mistranscriptions of this Kind are of frequent occurrence in Lexicons.]
majozaApN and mujozaApN are used as inf. ns. of 4. [See 1.] (Ḳ.)

1. jas-ahu, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,*) or jas-ahu biyadihi, (Ṣ Mṣb,) aor _u, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf.n. jas-N, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He felt it with his hand (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also Ajts-hu↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, jas-ahu AlT-abiybu, (Mgh,) and jas-a yadahu, (A,) The physician felt him, (Mgh,) and felt his arm, or hand, (A,) to know if he were hot or cold. (Mgh.) And jas-a AlX-aApa He felt the sheep, or goat, to know if it were fat or lean. (A, Mgh.)

jas-N is also, sometimes, with the eye. (IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb.*) You say, jas-ahu biEayonihi (IDrd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) ‡ He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at him, or it, for the purpose of investigation and clear perception. (Ḳ, TA.) IDrd cites as an ex. a verse (of ʼObeyd, or 'Abeed, [for I find it written without any syll. signs,] the son of Eiyoob El-'Amberee, TA,) in which occurs the expression jas-uwhu biOaEoyunihimo: (Ṣ:) but Ṣgh says that the right reading is Has-uwhu. (TA.)
jas-a AlOaroDa † He traversed the land. (Aboo-Saʼeed El-Yeshkuree, TA.)

jas-a AlOaxobaAra, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tajas-asahaA↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He searched, or sought, for, or after, news or tidings; inquired, or sought for information, respecting news or tidings; searched or inquired or spied into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, news or tidings: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he searched, or sought, repeatedly, or leisurely and by degrees, for news or tidings. (Mṣb.) You say also, tjs-s↓ fulaAnFA, and mino fulaAnK ‡ He inquired, or sought for information, respecting such a one; as also tHs-s, which latter verb occurs in an extr. reading of verse 87 of ch. xii. of the Ḳur: or the former signifies he sought after him for another; and the latter, “he sought after him for himself:” or tjs-s↓ signifies [he acted as a spy;] he inquired respecting, or searched or inquired or spied into, things which others veiled or concealed by reason of disdainful pride or of shame or pudency; and tHs-s, “he listened:” (TA:) in the last of the senses here assigned to it, the former verb is used in the Ḳur, xlix. 12, where it is said, walaA tajas-asuwA↓, for tatajas-asuwA; (Mujáhid, Bḍ, Ḳ;) ↓or the meaning here is, and do not ye inquire respecting, or search or inquire or spy into, private circumstances: or take ye what appeareth, and leave ye what God hath concealed. (Mujáhid, Ḳ.) You also say, Ajts-↓ lahumo Oamori Alqawomi He examined or spied into, and sought out, for them, the circumstances of the people. (Mgh.)
5: see 1, in five places.
8: see 1, first and last sentences.

Ajt-st AlUibilu AlbaAriDu, (A,) or AlkalaOa, (Ḳ,) ‡ The camels sought out the first sprouts of the herbage with their mouths: (A:) or cropped the herbage with their majaAs-, (Ḳ,) i. e., their mouths. (TA.)
jasiysN: see jaAsuwsN
jas-aAsN: see jaAsuwsN
‡ The lion that marks his prey with his claws: (Ḳ, TA:) or one that traverses a land. (Aboo-Saʼeed El-Yeshkuree, TA.)
Aljas-aAsapN A certain beast, that will be in the islands, that will search after news, or tidings, and bring them to Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist]. (Lth, L, Ḳ.)
jaAs-apN a dial. var. of HaAs-apN, (Mṣb,) and sing. of jawaAs-N, (Mṣb, TA,) which is syn. with HawaAs-N, (Kh, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) signifying The five senses. (TA.) See HaAs-apN.

jaAsuwsN ‡ A spy, who searches for, and brings, information, news, or tidings: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) or one who is acquainted with private affairs of an evil nature: as also jasiysN↓ (Ḳ) [and jas-aAsN↓:] and naAmuwsN signifies one who is acquainted with private affairs of a good nature: (TA:) pl. jawaAsiysu. (A.)

majas-N (A, TA) and majas-apN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) The place which one feels with his hand, (A,* Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) for the purpose of testing it, that he may form a judgment of it: (Mgh:) and ↓the latter, the place which the physician feels [to know if a patient be hot or cold]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. majaAs-u. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, majas-atuhu HaAr-apN↓ [The place in which one feels him is hot]. (A, TA.) And kayofa taraI majas-ahaA [How dost thou find the place in which one feels her?]; referring to a sheep or goat; to which one answers, “Indicative of fatness.” (A.)

[Hence, † Anything external which indicates the internal condition.] It is said in a prov., (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) relating to camels, (Mṣb,) OafowaAhuhaA majaAs-uhaA, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or majaAs-uhaA OafowaAhuhaA, (Mṣb,) or OaHonaAkuhaA majaAs-uhaA, (A, Ḳ,) † [Their mouths, or their palates, are the things which indicate their internal condition:] for if they eat well, he who looks at them sufficiently knows their fatness, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) without feeling them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) if one see them eat well, it is as though he felt them: (A, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, they feel the herbage, to test it, with their heads [or mouths] and their palates: so that, accord. to his explanation, the term mjAs- is tropically applied to these parts. (TA.) The prov. relates to external evidences of things explaining their internal qualities. (Ḳ) [And hence,] raEati AlUibilu AlkalaOa bimajaAs-ihaA, (Ḳ) ‡ The camels cropped the herbage with their mouths. (TA.)

You say also, fulaAnN waAsiEu Almajas-i, like as you say raHobu Alc-iraAEi ‡ [app. meaning Such a one is liberal, munificent, or generous]: and in the contrary case, Day-iqu Almajas-i, (A,) or Almajas-api↓, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) signifying gayoru raHobi AlS-adori ‡ [app., not liberal]; (Ḳ, TA;) and not waAsiEu Als-arobi [which is explained as meaning of ample bosom, and judgment, and love; and of ample way, or course of proceeding: but I rather incline to think that the right reading is waAsiEu Als-irobi, and the meaning, of ample, or large, mind, or heart]. (TA.) You also say, Uin-a fiI majas-atika↓ laDiyqFA (A) or majas-ika (TA) ‡ [app,. Verily in thy bosom, or mind, or heart, is narrowness; or in thee is illiberality.]
majas-ahu: see, majas-N, throughout.
It may also be used as an inf. n. of jas-ahu in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 1. jasaOa, aor _a, inf. n. jusuwoCN and jusoOapN, (Ḳ,) thus in the corrected copies of the Ḳ, but in some copies the latter inf. n. is written jusaMCapN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff; (Ḳ, TA;) as also jasaA, aor _u. (Mṣb and Ḳ in art. jsw.)
jasaOato yaduhu, aor _a, inf. n. jasoCN, His hand became hard, tough, callous, (Ṣ, TA,) coarse, or rough, (TA,) from work. (Ṣ, TA.)
jasaOato mafaASiluhu His joints became rigid, or stiff. (TA.)
jusiYati AlOaroDu The ground became hard, or hard and level, and rough: from jasoCN, explained below. (Ks, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: HasoCN Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground, (jaladN xaXinN, Ks, Ḳ, TA,) resembling small pebbles. (TA.) [Accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, Rough skin (jilodN xaXinN).]
Frozen water, (Ḳ, TA,) resembling hail [strewed on the ground], (TA.)
jusoOapN Hardness, toughness, callousness, [coarseness, or roughness,] of the hand, from work. (Ṣ.)
Rigidity, or stiffness, of the neck, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in a horse or the like. (Ṣ, TA.)
yadN jasoMCN A hard, tough, callous, coarse, or rough, hand. (Ḳ, TA.)

jaAsiYN [Hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: see 1]. You say jabalN jaAsiYN [A hard, or hard and rugged, mountain]. (TA.) And SxuwrN jaAsiYapN [Hard, or hard and rugged, rocks]. (TA.) And nabotN jaAsiYN A rigid, or tough, plant. (TA.) And OaroDN jaAsiYapN Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground; (TA;) as also majosuwoCapN↓. (Ks, Ḳ.) And makaAnN jaAsiYN A rugged place; as also XaAsiYN. (TA.) And daAb-apN jaAsiYapN AlqawaAYimi A beast, or horse or the like, having rigid, or stiff, legs, that will hardly bend. (TA.)
jaAsiYaMCu [in the CKjA siyAC] Hardness, toughness, rigidness, or stiffness; and ruggedness, or roughness. (Ḳ,* TA.)
majosuwoCapN: see jaAsiYN
1. jasida, aor _a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf.n. jasadN. (Ṣ, KL,) It (blood) stuck, or adhere, (Ṣ Ḳ, KL,) bihi [to him, or it]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and it (blood) became dry. (KL.)
4. Oujosida It (a garment) was made to stick, or adhere, to the jasad [or body]. (Fr, Ṣ.)
Also, inf. n. UijosaAdN, It (a garment) was dyed so that it stood up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye. (ISK, Ṣ.) [See mujosadN.]

5. tjs-d from Aljasadu is like tjs-m from Aljisomu: (Ṣ:) [apparently signifying He became, or assumed, a jasad, or body; or became corporeal, or incarnate; and thus it is used by late writers, and in the present day: but tjs-m generally signifies he became corpulent: accord. to the TA, tjs-d, said of a man, is like tjs-m: accord, to the KL, the former signifies he became possessed of a body: accord. to the PṢ, he became corporeal, or corpulent.]

hom.sense:
jasadN The body, with the limbs or members, [or whole person,] of a human being, and of a jinnee (or genie), and of an angel: (El-Bári', L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is thus applied only to the body of a rational animal; (El-Bári', Mṣb;) to no body that is nourished with food except that of a human being; but to the body of every rational creature that neither eats nor drinks, such as the genii and the angels: (L:) [the genii, however, are commonly believed to eat and drink:] or, accord. to ISd, it seems to be applied to a body other than that of a human being tropically: (TA:) the [golden] calf of the Children of Israel cried, but did not eat nor drink; [wherefore it is termed jsd;]
and in the Ḳur [vii. 146 and xx. 90], jasadFA is a substitute for EijolFA, or it may be meant for caA jasadK: (L:) [but see another explanation of jsdA, as there used, below:] or jasadN is syn. with badanN [which is generally held to signify the body without the head and arms and legs]: (Ṣ, A:) the pl. is OajosaAdN. (Lḥ, Mṣb, TA.) Lḥ mentions the saying, Uin-ahaA laHasanapu AlOajosaAdi [Verily she is beautiful in respect of body]; as though the sing. of which the pl. is thus used were applied to every separate part. (TA.)

Saffron; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) as also jisaAdN↓: (Lth, IAạr, ISk, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a similar dye: (Ṣ:) and ↓the latter signifies also a similar dye; (Lth, Mṣb,) red, or intensely yellow: (Lth, TA:) or bastard saffron; syn. EuSofurN; (Mṣb;) and so the former word. (L.)

Also, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jasidN↓ (L, Ḳ) and jaAsidN↓ (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jasiydN↓ (L, Ḳ) and jisaAdN↓, (R,) † Blood; (Ṣ;) as also mujosadN↓, as being likened to saffron: (Ḥam p. 215:) or dry blood: (R, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. of the first as above. (Ḥam p. 127.)
Some say that EijolFA jasadFA, in the Ḳur, [in two verses referred to above,] means A red golden calf. (Ṣ.)
jasidN: see jasadN:
and see also jaAsidN.

entry.sense: jisaAdN: see jasadN, in three places.
jasiydN: see jasadN.

hom.sense: jaAsidN Blood sticking to (bi) a person; as also jasidN↓. (Ṣ.)
See also jasadN.

entry.sense: jalosadN (L, Ḳ in art. jlsd) and Aljalosadu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA, in the CK Aljal-asadu) the name of A certain idol, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) which was worshipped in the time of paganism: (L:) the l is an augmentative letter accord. to J and most of the leading lexicologists; but F disapproves of the mention of the word in this art. (TA.)
mujosadN Red. (Ṣ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sometimes mijosadN↓, (IF, Mṣb,) and mujas-adN↓, (Ḳ,) A garment dyed with saffron: (Ḳ:) or with bastard saffron: (IAth, TA:) dyed with jisaAd: (IF, Mṣb:) or saturated with dye: (Ṣ:) or one says, EalaI fulaAnK vawobN muXobaEN mina AlSibogi [Upon such a one is a garment saturated with dye]; and Ealayohi vawobN mufodamN [Upon him is a garment saturated with red dye]; and when it is standing up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye, it is termed mujosadN: (ISK, Ṣ:) the pl. of this word is majaAsidu. (Ṣ.)
See also what next follows:
and see jasadN.

mijosadN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or mujosadN↓, (A,) the latter is the original form, because it is from Oujosida, meaning, “it was made to stick, or adhere, to the body,” (Fr, Ṣ,) like miTorafN and muTorafN, and miSoHafN and muSoHafN, (Fr, TA,) A garment worn next the body (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) by a woman, so that she sweats in it: (TA:) and a garment worn next the body dyed with saffron: (A:) pl. majaAsidu. (IAạr, A.) [Hence,] laA yaxorujan-a UilaI AlmasaAjidi fiI AlmajaAsidi (IAạr, A) They (women) shall by no means go forth to the mosques in the shirts that are next the body. (IAạr.)
See also mujosadN.
mujas-adN: see mujosadN.

hom.sense: 1. jasara, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajosuru}, (TA,) inf. n. jasaArapN (A, Ḳ, KL) and jusuwrN, said of a man, (Ḳ,) He was daring, courageous, or bold: (A, KL:) he acted with penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness; syn. maDaI and nafaca. (Ḳ.) You say, jasara EalaI kacaA, aor. _u {yajosuru}, inf. n. jasaArapN, He ventured upon such a thing daringly, courageously, or boldly; (Ṣ, A;) as also tjAsr↓: (Ṣ:) and tjAsr↓ Ealayohi he emboldened himself against it, or him. (A, Ḳ.) And jasara EalaI Eaduw-ihi, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajosuru}, inf. n. jusuwrN and jasaArapN, (Mṣb,) He acted daringly, conrageously, or boldly, against his enemy. (A.) And laA yajosuru Oano yafoEala kacaA He dares not to do such a thing. (A.)
jasara, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jasorN, (TA,) He (a man) arched, or vaulted, a jisor [or bridge]. (Ḳ.)

It is said of [the giant] 'Ooj (Euwj), in a trad., waqaEa EalaI niyli miSora fajasarahumo sanapF, i. e., ‡ [He fell down upon the Nile of Egypt, and] became a bridge to them [for the space of a year]. (A.)

And one says, jasarati Alr-ikaAbu AlmafaAzapa, and AijotasaratohaA↓, ‡ The travellingcamels crossed, or passed over, the desert, (A, Ḳ,) as by a bridge: (A:) and Ajtsrti↓ Als-afiynapu AlbaHora ‡ The ship crossed, or passed over, the sea: (A:) or rode upon, and passed through, the sea. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. js-rhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajosiyrN; (Ḳ;) [and Ajsrhu↓; (see Oagar-ahu;)] He encouraged him; emboldened him. (A, Ḳ.)
4: see 2.
6. tjAsr: see 1, in two places.
Also He stretched himself up, and raised his head. (Ḳ.)
tjAsr lahu biAlEaSaA He put himself in motion to him (En-Nawádir, Ḳ) with the staff, or stick. (Ḳ.)
tjAsrwA They acted with mutual daring or courage or boldness. (KL.)
They journeyed [app. with boldness, or emulating one another in boldness]. (TA.)
Alxayolu tajaAsaru biAlkumaApi [for tatajaAsaru] ‡ The horses convey the brave armed men away, or along, or across. (A.)
8: see 1, last sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: jasorN: see jasuwrN, in two places.

Also, applied to a he-camel, Sharp, spirited, or vigorous; syn. maADK [as contr. of baliydN]; as also jasorapN and mutajaAsirapN↓ applied to a she-camel: or (so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA; but in the CK, “and”) tall: (Ḳ:) or tall and bulky: and with p {jasorapN}, applied to a she-camel, it has this last signification; (TA;) or signifies strong, and bold to endure travel: (A, TA:) the masc. epithet applied to a he-camel is rare. (Lth, TA.)
Also Large, or bulky; applied to a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ,) or to anything, (Ḳ,) or to any limb, or member: (TA:) fem. with p {jasorapN}. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jasorapu Als-awaAEidi, and Almuxad-ami, Full or plump [in the fore arms, and in the place of the anklet]; applied to a girl, or young woman. (A, TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jisorN and jasorN↓ [A bridge; and a dyke, or causeway:] that on which one crosses over a river or the like; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as a qanoTarap and the like; (TA;) whether built or not built: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and a bridge of boats; boats bound together, and tied to stakes in the bank, being over a river; see qanoTarapN: (TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OajosurN (Ḳ) and (of mult., TA) jusuwrN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] Almawotu jisorN yuwaS-ilu AlHabiyba UilaI AlHabiybi ‡ [Death is a bridge that conveys the friend to the friend]. (TA.) And jaEala TaAEatahu jisorFA UilaI najaAtihi ‡ [He made his obedience a bridge to his safety]. (A, TA.)
jas-aArN Very daring or courageous or bold. (TA.)
mutajaAsirapN: see jasorN.

1. jasuma, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yajosumu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jasaAmapN, (Mṣb, TA,) He, or it, (a thing, Ṣ,) was, or became, great, or large: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so jasima, aor. _a {yajosamu}, inf. n. jasamN: and the former, it (a thing) was, or it, was, or became, great, big, or bulky: (Mṣb:) or he, or it, was, or became, great, or large, in body: (KL:) or he, or it, was, or became, corpulent; or corporeal, or bodied; as also tjs-m↓. (MA, PṢ.)
2. js-m, inf. n. tajosiymN, He, or it, made, or rendered, corporeal; or great, large, big, or bulky. (KL.)
[He made to be solid, or to have length and breadth and thickness.]

hom.sense: 5: see 1.

[Hence,] tjs-m fiI EayoniI kacaA ‡ Such a thing assumed a form, or shape, [or an embodiment,] in my eye. (TA.) And tjs-m fulaAnN mina Alkarami ‡ [app. Such a one was, or became, an embodiment of generosity]. (TA.) And kaOan-ahu karamN qado tajas-ama ‡ [app. As though he were generosity embodied]. (TA.)

tjs-m fulaAnFA ‡ He chose such a one (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) mino bayoni Alqawomi [from among the people, or party], (Ṣ,) or mina AlEaXiyrapi faOarosalahu [from the kinsfolk, or tribe,, &c., and sent him]: (TA:) as though he directed his course, or aim, to, or towards, his jisom [or body]; like as you say, taOay-ayotuhu, meaning “I directed my course, or aim, to, or towards, his Myap, and his XaxoS.” (Ṣ.) [See also 5 in art. jXm.] One says also, tajas-amohaA naAqapF mina AlUibili qaQnoHarohaA [Choose thou her, a she-camel from among the camels, and stick her]. (TA.)
tjs-m AlOaroDa † He betook himself towards the land, or country, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) desiring to go thither. (Ṣ.)
tjs-m Alr-amola, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Aljabala, (Ṣ,) † He mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of the mountain. (Ṣ.) [See also 5 in art. jXm.]

tjs-m AlOamora ‡ i. q. rakiba muEoZamahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., He ventured upon, embarked in, or undertook, the main part, or bulk, of the affair: (TḲ:) or he constrained himself to do it, or perform it; as also tjX-mhu: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or both these verbs signify he took it, or imposed it, upon himself, or he undertook it, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. jXm.) You say also, fulaAnN yatajas-ama AlmajaAsima↓ and yatajaX-amu AlmajaAXima ‡ [app. meaning Such a one undertakes, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, those things, or affairs, that are causes of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; i. e., difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient things or affairs: supposing the two nouns to be pls. of which the sings. are majosamapN and majoXamapN, of the measure mafoEalapN, like maboxalapN and majobanapN and maX-aqapN (originally maXoqaqapN), &c.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: jisomN The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jasadN; (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also jusomaAnN↓ and juvomaAnN: (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb:*) or jisomN and jusomaAnN↓ are syn. with jasadN; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) or signify the whole body and limbs or members of a man, (Ḳ, and T and Mṣb in explanation of jsm,) and of a beast, a camel, and the like, (T, Mṣb,) and of any other species, (Ḳ,) of large make; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and juvomaAnN is syn. with XaxoSN [app. as meaning “a person”]; and jusomaAnN↓ signifies the whole jisom of a man: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or jisomN signifies [a body, or material substance; a solid;] a thing having length and breadth and thickness; so that, when it is cut and divided, no portion thereof ceases to be a jisom; whereas a XaxoS [meaning “a person”] ceases to be a XaxoS by its being divided: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a thing that is capable of being divided in length and breadth and thickness is called jisomN TabiyEiI-N, and also, because it is a subject of investigation, or inquiry, in instruction in the mathematical studies, jisomN taEoliymiI-N: (KT:) pl. [of pauc.] OajosaAmN and [of mult] jusuwmN. (Ḳ.) You say, vaAba jisomuhu, (M, A, Ḳ, in art. vwb,) and OavaAba jisomuhu, (IḲt, M, ib.,) and vaAba Uilayohi jisomuhu, (T, M, A, ib.,) ‡ He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (M, Ḳ;*) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.) And Uin-ahu laHaniyfu AljusomaAni↓ [Verily he is slender, spare, or lean, of body]. (TA.)

AlOajosaAmu Almuxotalifapu AlT-abaAYiEi [The material substances of different natures; also called AlOajosaAmu Als-aboEapu the seven material substances, and AlfilicaAtu; namely,] the EanaASir [which are the four elements, fire, air, earth, and water,] and the three products composed of these, (KT,) which are minerals, vegetables, and animals. (Note in a copy of the KT.) AlOajosaAmu AlT-abiyEiy-ahu, as used by those who study to discover occult things, signifies The EaroX and the kurosiI-: and AlOajosaAmu AlEunoSuriy-apu, everything beside these two, of the heavens and the [elements termed] OusoTuqusaAt therein. (KT.)
[jisomiI-N Bodily, or corporeal.]
[jisomiy-apN Bodiliness, or corporeity.]
jusomaAnN: see jisomN, in four places.
jusomaAniI-N: see jasiymN.
jusaAmN: see what next follows

jasiymN Great; large; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jusaAmN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) big; bulky: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {jasiymapN}: (Ḳ:) pl. jisaAmN (Ṣ, Mṣb) [and jusumN also, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN]: and corpulent, large in body, or big-bodied; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also jusomaAniI-N↓, applied to a man. (TA.) You say, huwa mino jisaAmi AlOumuwri [It is one of great affairs or events]: and mino jasiymaAti AlxuTuwbi [meaning the same, or of great afflictions or calamities]. (TA.) And jusumN [likewise, or OumuwrN jusumN,] signifies Great affairs or events. (TA.) jasiymu AlOamori signifies [also] The bulk, or the greater, main, principal, or chief, part, of the affair; and so Oajosamu↓ AlOamori. (Ṣ.)
[The pl.] jusumN also signifies † Intelligent men. (TA.)
jasiymu AlOaroDi Elevated land over which water has risen: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. jisaAmN. (Ḳ.)
Oajosamu Greater, larger, bigger, or bulkier; or greatest, largest, biggest, or bulkiest. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also jasiymN.
majaAsimu: see 5, last sentence.

dictScrap.label: [omitted in some copies of the Ṣ.]

entry.sense: 1. jasaA, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajosuwu}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jasowN (M, Ḳ) and jusuw-N, (M, TA,) He, or it, (a man, M, TA, or a thing, Mṣb,) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see also jasaOa: or, said of a man,] he was, or became, hard, rough, harsh, or ungentle; contr. of laTufa. (Ṣ.) And jasati Alyadu, inf. n. jusuw-N and jasFA, The hand, or arm, was, or became, dry, or tough, or hard, (Ṣ, TA,) in the bones, with little flesh; (TA;) and in the same sense the verb is said of other things. (Ṣ.)
It (water) congealed, or froze. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, inf. n. jusuw-N, He (an old man) attained the utmost age [so that his limbs became rigid]. (Ṣ, TA.)
3. jAsAhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAsaApN, (TA.) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (Ḳ, TA.)

yadN jaAsiyapN A hand, or an arm, dry, or tough, or hard, in the bones, with little flesh. (TA.) And daAb-apN jaAsiyapN AlqawaAYimi A beast having tough, or hard, legs. (TA.) And rimaAHN jaAsiyapN Stiff, rigid, or tough, and hard, spears. (TA.) [See also jaAsiYN, in art. jsO.]
1. jaX-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajoXuXu}, inf. n. jaX-N, (Ṣ,) He ground it (namely wheat, Ṣ, or grain, A) coarsely; (Ṣ, A;) as also OajaX-ahu↓. (Ṣ.)
He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it: and he broke it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also OajaX-ahu↓. (Ḳ)
He beat him, or struck him, with a staff or stick. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4: see 1, in two places.

juX-apN (A, Ḳ, TA) and jaXaXN↓ (TA) Loudness, or vehemence, of voice or sound: (A, Ḳ, TA:) and a rough sound coming forth from the xayaAXiym [or air-passages in the nose], in which is a hoarseness. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, fiI Sahiyli Alfarasi jaXaXN↓ In the neighing of the horse is a rough sound: (TA:) which is one of the qualities approved in horses. (IDrd.) And fiI Sawoti Alqawosi juX-apN Einoda Alr-amoIi In the sound of the bow is a roughness of twanging on the occasion of shooting. (AḤn TA.)
jaXaXN: see juX-apN, in two places.
jaXiyXN Wheat coarsely ground; as also majoXuwXN↓. (Ṣ.)

And, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] (TA,) as also jaXiyXapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) What is coarsely ground, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of wheat, &c., (Ṣ,) or of wheat and the like: (Ḳ, TA:) or the former, grain when bruised, brayed, or pounded, before it is cooked: and ↓the latter, such as is cooked: but ISd says that this distinction is not of valid authority. (TA.)

Also, the former, i. q. sawiyqN [Meal of parched barley or wheat, coarsely ground, which is made into a kind of gruel]; (El-Fárisee, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so ↓the latter: (A:) or ↓the latter is the n. un. (El-Fárisee.) You say, AisoqiniI jaXiyXapN↓ Give thou me to drink [some] swyq. (A.) Or swyq is not called jXyXp↓, but is called jaciycapN, q. v. (TA.)

And the former, (Sh, Ḳ,) or jaXiyXapN↓, (TA in art. dX,) Wheat coarsely ground, and put into a cooking-pot, into which some flesh-meat is thrown, or some dates, and then cooked: (Sh, Ḳ:) also called daXiyXapN: (TA:) or a soup made of coarsely bruised wheat. (TA in art. dX.)
jaXiyXapN: see jaXiyXN, in seven places.

OajaX-u Having a rough, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or loud, or vehement, (A,) voice, or sound: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) applied to a man, and a horse, and thunder, (A, Ḳ,), &c. (Ḳ.) You say, rajulN OajaX-u AlS-awoti A man having a [rough, or] loud, or vehement, voice. (A.) And farasN OajaX-u, (A,) or Oaj-aXu AlSawoti, (Ṣ, TA,) A horse in whose neighing is a roughness. (TA.) And saHaAbN OajaX-u, (Aṣ,) or OajaX-u Alr-aEodi, (Ṣ,) Clouds that thunder vehemently. (Aṣ.) And qawosN jaX-aMCu, [jX-MC being the fem. of AjX-,] A bow having a rough twanging, (AḤn, Ḳ,) when one shoots with it. (AḤn.)

AlOajaX-u is also the name of One of the sounds of which musical modulations are formed, (Kh, Ḳ,) which are three in number; [app. meaning the treble, tenor, and bass, clefs; the last being that to which this term is applied;]
the sound thus called being from the head, (Kh,) issuing from the xayaAXiym [or air-passages in the nose], having in it a roughness and hoarseness, (Kh, Ḳ,) and followed by a gradual fall (taHad-ur) [of the voice] modulated in accordance to that same sound, and then followed by a sound [in my original biwaXoIK, but I think it probable that this is a mistranscription for biwaHoIK, or biwaHFI, or the like, for, though waXoIN might perhaps, by straining a metaphor, be applied to denote a varied sound, its being understood in this sense seems to be forbidden by its being here added] like the first. (Kh, TA.) [This explanation is perhaps illustrated by the fact that the bass in the music of the Arabs is often formed of one prolonged note, falling and rising.]
Also jaX-aMCu, [OaroDN being understood,] A pebbly plain, fit for palm-trees. (Ḳ, TA.)
mijaX-N, (Ṣ,) or mijaX-apN↓, (A,) or both, (Ḳ,) A mill (Ṣ, Ḳ) with which jaXiyX is ground: (Ṣ:) or a small mill with which one grinds coarsely. (A.)
mijaX-apN: see what next precedes.
majoXuwXN: see jaXiyXN.

1. jaXaOato nafosuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoXaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. juXuwoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) like quEuwdN, (TA,) and jaXaMCN, (KL, [or jaXaON, so Golius on the authority of the KL,]) [like jaOaXato nafosuhu, and jaAXato,] His soul [or stomach] heaved, by reason of grief or fright: (Ṣ, Ḳ; and so in the O; but in one copy of the Ḳ, by reason of grief or joy: TA:) or [simply] heaved, or rose: (T in art. vwr:) and heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; (Ḳ;) i. q. xabuvato and laqisato: (Sh, TA:) and jaXaOato UilaI-a nafosiI My soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit, or became heavy, (xabovato,) in consequence of pain from something that it disliked. (ISh, TA.)
jaXaOa Eani AlT-aEaAmi He nauseated food, in consequence of indigestion. (TA.)
jaXaOati Alganamu The sheep emitted a sound from their throats. (Lth, Ḳ.)
jaXaOati AlOaroDu ‡ The earth put forth all its plants, or herbage: like as they say, qaMCati AlOaroDu OukolahaA [lit. “the earth vomited her victuals”]. (TA.)
jaXaOati Alr-iyaADu birub-aAhaA ‡ [The meadows, or gardens,] put forth [their good things]. (TA.)
jaXaOati AlbilaAdu biOaholihaA ‡ [The countries, or towns,, &c.,] cast forth [their inhabitants]. (TA.)
jaXaOati AlbiHaAru biOamowaAjihaA ‡ [The seas] cast forth [their waves]. (TA.)

Also jaXaOa said of the sea, ‡ It rushed on, (TA,) grew dark, (Ḳ, TA,) and was tumultuous with its waves; (TA;) and [in the CK “or”] impended over one. (Ḳ, TA.) And in like manner said of the night, ‡ It came on suddenly, (TA,) grew dark; (Ḳ, TA;) and [in the CK “or”] impended over one. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaXaOati AlwaHoXu † The wild animals made a single leap, or spring. (TA.)

jaXaOa Alqawomu † The people, or company of men, went forth from one country, or town, to another. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) It is said in a trad., jaXaOati Alr-uwma EalaI Eahodi Eumara † The Greeks rose, and advanced from their country [in the time of ʼOmar]. (TA.)
2: see 5.

5. tjX-O, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tajaX-uWN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ; [in the CK, Alt-ajaX-u is erroneously put for Alt-ajaX-uWu;]) or tajaX-aI, inf. n. tajaX-K; (Mṣb;) and jX-O↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tajoXiYapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) both signify alike; (Ṣ;) He eructed, or belched; i. e., emitted a sound accompanied with wind, from his mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach, (Mgh, Mṣb,) intentionally: (Mgh:) or it (the stomach) emitted wind (Ḳ, TA) on an occasion of its impletion with food or drink. (TA.)
8. AjtXO AlbilaAda, and AijotaXaOa AlbilaAdu † [He found the country to disagree with him, and] the country disagreed with him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jaXoCN A light bow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a bow that makes a ringing sound: (Lth, TA:) or a light rod of the tree called naboE: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) pl. OajoXaMCu, (Ḳ,) anomalous, and asserted by IHsh to be rare, (TA,) and jaXaMtN. (Ḳ: in the CK, jaXoMtN.)
sahomN jaXoCN A light arrow. (Yaạḳoob, TA.)
A large number (IAạr, Ḳ, TA) of men, and of cattle. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: juXoOapN: see juXaMCN.
Also ‡ Daybreak: [or,] accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh, the blowing of the wind at daybreak. (TA.)
juXaOapN: see juXaMCN, in two places.
qawosN jaXoOaI A ringing bow. (TA. [See also jaX-aMCu, voce OajaX-u, in art. jX.])

juXaMCN A belch; i. e., a sound accompanied with wind, from the mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach; (Mgh, Mṣb;) a subst. from 5; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also juXaOapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juXoOapN↓: (Ḳ: but the first and last of these three words are omitted in some copies of the Ḳ:) or ↓the second of these three words, accord. to some, is a superlative epithet, signifying a great, or frequent, belcher. (MF.)
Also † An invasion of the night, and of the sea. (Ḳ, TA.) The torrent and the night (Als-ayolu waAll-ayolu) are called AlOaEomayaAni [the two blind things] because their invasion is vehement. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jaXaba, aor. _u {yajoXubu}; and jaXiba, aor. _a {yajoXabu}; (Ḳ;) and jaXuba, aor. _u {yajoXubu}, inf. n. jaXaAbapN; (TA;) said of wheat, or food, (TaEaAm,) It was gross, or coarse: (Ḳ, TA:) it was badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or it was without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury. (Ḳ.)
And the first, It (a thing) was thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough. (TA.)
And jaXuba, aor. _u {yajoXubu}, inf. n. juXuwbapN, He (a man, TA) was a foul, or bad, eater. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaXabahu He ground it coarsely; namely, wheat. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaXaba Qll-ehu XabaAbahu God caused his youth, or youthful vigour, to pass away: or rendered him vile and despicable (rad-aOahu waOaqomaOahu): or may God cause, &c. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 12. AijoXawoXibuw accord. to some, or AixoXawoXibuwA accord. to others, occurs in a trad. of ʼOmar; (TA in art. xXb;) [and J says, and so Az accord. to the TA,] the former, if used like the latter, is not improbably correct; but I have not heard it. (Ṣ.) [See art. xXb.]
jaXobN: see jaXibN
juXobN The rinds of pomegranates: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

jaXibN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaXobN↓ and jaXiybN↓ and mijoXaAbN↓ (Ḳ) and majoXuwbN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to wheat, or food, Gross, or coarse: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury: (Ḳ, TA:) jXb [probably jaXibN] signifies also anything disagreeable in taste, and choking: (TA:) and gross, or coarse, and dry, or tough: (IAth, TA:) and what is dry, or tough, of herbage. (TA.)
Also, the first, A bulky and strong camel: (ISk, TA:) a thickboned horse. (Ḥam p. 207.)
jaXuwbN A rough, or coarse, (or, as some say, TA,) short woman. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaXiybN: see jaXibu.
Also Anything rough, gross or coarse, disagreeable to the taste, and choking. (Ḳ.)
A thick, rough, or coarse, garment, or piece of cloth. (Ṣ.)
A rough, or coarse, and old, worn-out, skin for water or milk. (TA.)
Rude, uncivil, unkind, rough, speech or language. (TA.)
And (applied to a man, TA) A foul, or bad, eater. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: mijoXabN Big, or bulky, and courageous, brave, or bold. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
[Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, but in this case probably a mistranscription for miXojabN, A wooden thing upon which clothes are put.]
