entry.sense: mujaX-abN A man (Sh) coarse in his means of subsistence. (Sh, Ḳ.)
mijoXaAbN: see jaXibN
Thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough, (Ṣ, and Ḥam p. 207,) and short. (Ḥam ib.)
mijoXaAbu Albadani Thick, gross, or big, in body. (T, TA.)
majoXuwbN: see jaXibN.

hom.sense: 1. jaXara, aor. _u {yajoXuru}, (Aṣ, A, Mgh,) inf. n. jaXorN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and jX-r↓, (A,) inf. n. tajoXiyrN; (Ḳ;) He took, or sent, forth his beasts to pasture, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) not to return in the evening: (Aṣ, Ṣ Mgh:) [or] he pastured his beast near to the tents or houses: (A:) [or] jaXorN signifies also one's pasturing his horse before his tent or house, after their covering: (Ḳ:) or a people's taking forth their horses and pasturing them before their tents or houses. (L.)

And jaXorN and tajoXiyrN↓ also signify The leaving or neglecting [a thing]:(Ḳ, TA:) and dismissing [it]. (TA.)
jaXara AlquroMna, meaning He estranged himself from the Ḳur-án, is said of him who has neglected the reading or reciting of it for two months. (L from a trad.)
jaXara AlmaAlu Eano Oaholihi The cattle went forth to the places of pasturage from their owners. (A.)
jaXara Alr-ajulu Eano Oaholihi ‡ The man journeyed away from his family, or wife. (A.)
jaXara AlS-uboHu (aor. _u {yajoXuru} S,) inf. n. juXuwrN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ The dawn broke, (Ṣ,) or rose, (Ḳ,) or came forth. (A.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
jaXorN: see jaXarN, in three places.

hom.sense: jaXarN Camels or sheep or goats pasturing in their place, not returning to their owners (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) at night: (Ḳ:) or [simply] not returning to their owners. (Aṣ, TA.) [See also mujaX-arN.]

† A people who pass the night with the camels, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in their place, not returning to their tents or houses: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) who go forth with their beasts to the place of pasturage, and remain in their place, not returning to the tents or houses: the doing this is not considered as travelling, and therefore is not a legal reason for shortening the ordinary prayers: (AʼObeyd, TA:) and jaXorN↓ signifies the same. (TA, as on the authority of A'Obeyed. [But perhaps this latter is a mistranscription for juX-arN: see what follows.]) ‡ A man who is away (EazabN, Ḳ, TA) from his family, or wife, with his camels; (TA;) as also jaXiyrN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner the former is applied to a company of men; and so juX-arN [a pl. of jaAXirN↓, q. v.]: you say qawomN jaXarN and juX-arN. (L, TA.)
The herbs, or leguminous plants, of [the season, or rain, called] the rabiyE; (L, Ḳ;) as also jaXorN↓. (L.) And jXr [app. jaXarN or jaXorN↓] also signifies A pasture-land in which horses feed. (TA.)
jaXiyrN: see jaXarN

Also A [quiver of the kind called] wafoDap; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., a kinaAnap; and so jafiyrN; accord. to ISd, a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap, of skins, slit in the side in order that the wind may enter it and the feathers may therefore not be eaten: (TA:) or, accord. to Z, i. q. jiraAbN (IAth, TA.)
And A large juwaAliq [or sack]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoXirapN and [of mult.] juXurN. (TA.)

entry.sense: jaX-aArN The owner (SaAHib) of a pasture-land in which horses feed. (Ḳ.) You say, “He is the jaX-aAr of our camels.” (A, TA. [But it seems to be implied in the A that it signifies the same as jaAXirN as explained below.])
jaAXirN One who takes forth horses and camels to the pasture-land, and remains there: [see also jaX-aArN:] pl.juX-aArN: (TA:) [and juX-arN is another pl. of the same:] see jaXarN
Also [the pl.] juX-arN Camels, and asses, going whithersoever they will. (TA.)

jaAXiriy-apN ‡ A drink that is taken at daybreak: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) you say, AiSoTabaHonaA AljaAXiriy-apa We drank the morning-draught that is taken at daybreak: (Ṣ, A:) and it has no verb: (Ṣ:) or it is only of camels' milk: (Ḳ:) or it is correctly of general application: or is properly of wine; for this is what is most frequently mentioned: and it is also used as an epithet: thus you say XarobapN jaAXiriy-apN (TA.)
† A certain kind of food: (Ḳ, TA:) or a kind of food eaten at daybreak. (TA.)
† The [last part of the night, called the] saHar: (Ḳ:) because near to daybreak. (TA.)
† Midday: (Ḳ:) because of the appearance and spreading of its light. (TA.)

mujaX-arN [A beast] made to pass the night in the pasture, away from its owner, not brought back in the evening: (Ḳ,* TA: [see also jaXarN:]) or not pastured near the water: (IAạr, TA:) or that is pastured near to the water. (El-Mundhiree, TA.) And xayolN mujaX-arapN Horses pastured (Ṣ, Ḳ) biAlHimaI [in the place of pasturage that is prohibited to the public]. (Ṣ.)

1. jaXiEa, aor. _a {yajoXaEu}, inf. n. jaXaEN, He was, or became, affected with the most vehement desire, eagerness, avidity, cupidity, or hankering, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and, (O, Ḳ,) as explained by an Arab of the desert to Aṣ, (IDrd,) with the worst kind thereof, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) for eating, &c.: (TA:) or, as explained by another Arab of the desert to Aṣ, (IDrd,) he took his own share, and coveted the share of another: (IDrd, Ḳ:) and tjX-E↓ sig nifies the like; (Ṣ;) or i. q. taHar-aSa, q. v. (Ḳ.)
jaXaEN also signifies The being impatient on account of separation from an associate. (TA.)
And The being frightened, terrified, or afraid. (TA.)
5: see 1.

6. tajaAXaEaA AlmaMCa They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and [so I render taEaATaXaA] vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst; (Ḳ;) on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.)
jaXiEN part. n. of jaXiEa, Affected with the most vehement desire,, &c.: pl. jaXiEuwna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jaXaAEaI and juXaEaMCa and jiXaAEN are also pls. [of the same]. (TA.)
AljaXiEu The lion. (TA.)
rajulN jaXiEN baXiEN, A man in whom are combined impatience and fright and a heavy, or a heaving, state of the soul. (TA.)
jaXiyEN One who assumes a false disposition, and that which is not in him. (TA.)
OajoXaEu [comparative and superlative of jaXiEN; More, and most, affected with most vehement desire,, &c.]. (TA.)

1. jaXima AlOamora aor. _a {yajoXamu}, inf. n. jaXomN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaXaAmapN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He took, or imposed, upon himself the affair, or he undertook it, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tjX-mhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) and tjs-mhu: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or ↓the second and third signify he constrained himself to do it, or perform it: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. jsm:) and tjX-m↓ kacaA wakacaA He did such and such things against his will, and in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (TA.) [See also an ex. of tjX-m↓ in art. jsm;conj. 5, last sentence.] jaXimotu Uilayoka Earaqa Alqirobapi is said to mean [I have imposed upon myself difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, in coming to thee,] so that I have journeyed, and become in want of the water of the water-skin in the journey: or the meaning is, I have suffered, and imposed upon myself, difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, so that I have sweated like the water-skin: or by the Earaq of the qirobap is meant its Ealaq, i. e., its miEolaAq, by which it is carried; and the phrase means tajaX-amotu↓ Uilayoka Hamola Alqirbapi [I have impose upon myself, in spite of difficulty, &c., in coming to thee, the carrying of the water-skin]; alluding to journeying and its difficulties: (Ḥar p. 511:) [and in like manner,] one says, tajaX-amotu↓ laka Earaqa Alqirobapa (Ṣ in art. Erq.) The sportsman, when he has not taken any game, and has returned disappointed, says, maA jaXimotu Uilayoka ZilofFA [app. meaning I have not had the trouble of bringing to thee so much as a hoof of a gazelle or the like]. (AZ, TA.) And maA jaXimotu Alyawoma TaEaAmFA i. e., I have not eaten, to-day, food, is said on the occasion of the disappointment of any one seeking a thing. (AZ, TA.)

2. jX-mhu AlOamora (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoXiymN; (Ṣ;) and AjXmhu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He imposed upon him, or made him to undertake, the affair, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; or he ordered, required, or constrained, him to do the thing, it being difficult or troublesome or inconvenient. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, (Ṣ, TA,) in a trad. of Zeyd Ibn-ʼAmr Ibn-Nufeyl, (TA,)
mahomaA tujaX-imoniI faUin-iI jaAXimu↓
[Whatever thou impose upon me, in spite of difficulty, &c., I undertake it, in spite of difficulty, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.)
4: see 2.
5: see 1, in six places.
tajaX-amotu Alr-amola I mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand: some say thus; and some say tajas-amotu (TA.)
tajaX-amotu fulaAnFA mino bayoni Alqawomi I directed my course, or aim, towards such a one, [and chose him, (like tajas-amotuhu q. v.,)] from among the people, or party. (Abu-n-Naḍr, TA.)
jaXomN A state of destruction, perdition, or death. (AA, TA.)
See also juXamN.

hom.sense: juXomN: see juXamN
Also Bad money: pl. juXuwmN (IKh, TA.)
jaXamN: see juXamN, in two places.
Also Fatness. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaXimN: see jaXiymN

hom.sense:
juXamN Weight, or heaviness; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaXamN↓ (Ḳ,) and jaXomN↓ accord. to the Ḳ, but correctly juXomN↓, as in the A and L: (TA:) [and and unpleasing, and a difficult or troublesome or an inconvenient, affair:]
a subst. from tajaX-ama kacaA wakacaA. explained above: see 1. (TA.) You say, OaloqaI fulaAnN EalaI-a juXamahu, (Ṣ,) or jaXamahu↓, (TA,) Such a one threw upon me his weight, or heavi ness: (Ṣ, TA:) to which Z adds, or his difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient, affair, that he had imposed upon himself, or that was imposed upon him. (TA.)

Also The jawof [i. e., the belly; or the chest;, &c.]: or the breast, with the ribs that contain it: (Ḳ:) or the breast of a camel: (Ṣ, TA:) and the part [of the skin] of the camel's breast, and of the rest of the body thereof, with which the [kind of quiver called] qrn [i. e. qaranN] is covered. (TA.) You say, gat-ahu bijuXamihi meaning He threw his breast upon him. (TA.)

entry.sense: juXumN [app. pl. of jaXiymN↓, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN] Fat men: (IAạr, Ḳ:*) and tall, crafty or cunning, and wicked or malignant, men. (IAạr, TA.)
jaXuwmN A man who takes, or imposes, upon him self, or who undertakes, affairs, with energy or vigour, or in an extraordinary degree, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Mṣb.)
jaXiymN (Ḳ.) or, as in the book of Kr. jaXimN↓, (TA,) Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky. (Ḳ.) See also juXumN
jaAXimN A man taking, or imposing, upon himself, or undertaking, an affair, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Mṣb.) See 2.
AlmujoXimu The lion. (Ḳ.)
majaAXimu: see 5 in art. jsm
jawoXanN and jawoXaniI-N: see art. jwXn
2. jS-S He plastered a building with jiS- [or gypsum]: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or he made a house therewith: (Mṣb:) i. q. qaS-aSa, (Ṣ, TA,) which is of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz. (TA.)

jiS-N (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaS-N (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) but the former is the more chaste: (TA, from an Expos. of the Fṣ:) the latter is disapproved by IDrd, and disallowed by ISk; (TA;) and it is said in the Bári', on the authority of AḤát, that the latter is the form used by the vulgar, and the former is that which is correct: (Mṣb:) [Gypsum; a certain substance] with which one builds, (Ṣ,) or plasters; (Mgh;) well known: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) arabicized; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because j and S do not occur in any Arabic word; (Mṣb;) or, accord. to AZ, there are some [Arabic] words in which they both occur, as has been mentioned in art. AjS: from kajo (Mgh, Ḳ, [in the CK kaJo]) or, as some say, GaJo; which are Persian: (TA:) in the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz, qS- [i. e.qiS-N or qaS-N]. (Lth, TA.) [The n. un. is with p {jiS-apN}: see art. qS.]
jaS-aASN A preparer of jiS- [or gypsum]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jaS-aASaAtN [pl. of jaS-aASapN] Places in which jiS- [or gypsum] is made. (Ḳ.)
1. jaZ-a, [aor., accord. to rule, _i, and inf. n., probably, jaZ-N,] He was short and fat. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
4. AjZ- He was, or became, proud; or excessively proud, corrupt, unbelieving, or disobedient. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

jaZ-N [probably an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Large; big; bulky; or large in body, corpulent, and fleshy: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or tall, large in body, a great eater and drinker, who exults, and behaves insolently and ungratefully to God: (Fr, TA:) occurring in a trad. describing the people of Hell. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. jaEabahu (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoEabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaEobN, (TA,) He prostrated him; he threw him down upon the ground; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) like jaEafahu; (Ṣ;) as also jE-bhu↓, (Ḳ,) ing. n. taEojiybN; (TA;) and jaEomaAhu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, [in the CK erroneously written jaEobaOah,]) like saloqaAhu from salaqahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jiEobaMCN. (Ṣ, TA [in the latter, in one place, probably by a mistake of a copyist, written jEbAp].)
He in verted it, or him; he turned it, or him, upside down, or over, or inside out; syn. qalabahu. (Ḳ.)
He collected it; (Ḳ;) mostly used in relation to that which is small in quantity, paltry, or inconsiderable. (TA.)
jaEaba, (A, Ḳ,) and jaEaba jaEobapN, (A,) He made a quiver of the kind called jEbp. (A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5: see 7.
7. AnjEb and tjE-b↓ (Ḳ) and tajaEobaI↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) He became prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 1. jaEobaAhu: see 1.
Q. Q. 2. tajaEobaI: see 7.

jaEobapN A kinaAnap [or quiver] (A, Ḳ) for arrows (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the kind called nuX-aAb (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and for those that are called nabol also: (Ḥam p. 154:) but some make a distinction between jaEobapN and kinaAnapN: the former, they say, is for nX-Ab; and the latter, for nbl: (Mz, MF:) accord. to IDrd, the knAnp is only for nbl, and is of leather: that which is of wood is called jafiyr: and that which is of two pieces [of wood] joined together is called qrn [i. e. qaranN]: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) accord. to ISh, the jEbp is round and wide, with a cover on the top, over its mouth: the wafoDap is smaller, and its upper and lower parts are of equal size; whereas the jEbp is wide in its upper part, and contracted in its lower part; wide in its upper part that the feathers of the arrows [having ample room] may not become detached; for the arrows are put in the quiver with the points downwards: each of these two kinds is made of two corresponding pieces of wood: (TA:) the pl. is jiEaAbN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaEabaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say, nakabuwA AljiEaAba wasakabuwA Aln-uX-aAba [They inverted, or inclined, the quivers, and poured forth the arrows]. (A, TA.) And maEahu jaEobapN fiyhaA banaAtu Almawoti [With him is a quiver in which are the daughters of death; i. e., deadly arrows]. (A, TA.)
Also The largest of drinking-vessels. (MF, TA.)

juEobuwbN A man (Ṣ) short, and ugly, or contemptible; or ugly, and small in body: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or weak, and destitute of good: or vile, or mean, and despicable: (Ḳ:) or a low, mean, or sordid, and weak man: pl. jaEaAbiybu. (TA.)
jiEaAbapN The art of making quivers of the kind called jiEaAb, pl. of jaEobapN. (A, Ḳ.)
jiEaAbiI-N: see what next follows.
jaE-aAbN [and app. jiEaAbiI-N↓ also, as seems to be indicated in the Ḳ, where it is mentioned as a surname, but in the CK written jaE-AbI-,] A maker of quivers of the kind called jiEaAb. (A, Ḳ.)
mijoEabN One who often prostrates, or throws down, others, (Sir-iyEN, [in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, SariyE,]) but is not himself prostrated, or thrown down. (Ḳ, TA.)
munojaEibN or mutajaE-ibN (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ) Dead, or dying; syn. may-itN. (Ḳ.)

1. jaEuda, aor. _u {yajoEudu}, inf. n. juEuwdapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaEaAdapN, (Ḳ,) said of hair, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It was, or became, crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Mṣb;) was, or became, the contr. of saboT, (Ḳ,) or of musotarosil: (Mṣb:) or was, or became, short: (Kr, Ḳ:) and jaEida, [aor. _a {yajoEadu},] (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. jaEadN, (TA,) signifies the same; (Mṣb, TA;) as also tjE-d↓. (Ḳ.)

† It became contracted, and compacted in lumps; (L;) as also tjE-d↓; (L, Ḳ;*) said of earth, (Ḳ,) or of moist earth. (L.) [The inf. n.] juEuwdapN is also sometimes used in describing the state of the froth, or foam, of a camel's mouth, when it is accumulated. (Ṣ. [See jaEodN.])
Also, said of a cheek, inf. n. juEuwdapN, † It was rough, or coarse, and short; contr. of Oasula. (L.)

2. jE-dhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoEiydN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) He crisped, or curled, or twisted, and contracted, it; (Mṣb;) made it the contr. of saboT, (Ḳ,) or of musotarosil; (Mṣb:) or made it short: (Ḳ:) namely, hair. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
5: see 1, in two places.
jaEodN, applied to hair, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Mṣb;) contr. of saboTN (Ḳ,) or of musotarosilN: (Mṣb:) or short. (Kr, Ḳ.)

Applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Having hair such as is termed jaEod: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:)
[or] so jaEodu AlX-aEari: (A, TA:) fem. with p {jaEodapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. jiEaAdN. (A, Mṣb.)

As an epithet of praise, it has two meanings; namely, † Compact in limbs, and strong in make; not flabby, nor of slack, or incongruous, make; (L;) or big, or bulky, and compact; (Ḥam p. 238;) or, as some say, light, or active: (TA:) and having crisp, or curly, not lank, hair; because lankness is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Greeks and Persians; and crispness, or curliness, is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Arabs: but very crisp, or frizzled, or woolly, hair, like that of the Zenj and the Nubians, is disapproved. (L.)

[Hence,] ‡ Generous; bountiful; munificent; (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) alluding to a man's being an Arab of generous disposition, because the Arabs are characterized by crisp, or curly, hair. (A.) Aṣ did not know jEd in this sense; but it occurs in many verses of the Ansár. (T, TA.)
As an epithet of dispraise, it has also two meanings; namely, † Short, and incongruous in make: (L:) [contr. of saboTN:]

and ‡ Niggardly; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also jaEodu Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jaEodu AlOanaAmilu, (Ṣ,) and jaEodu AlOaSaAbiEu, (A,) or this signifies † having short fingers, (Ḳ,) and jaEodu AlbanaAni, and jaEodu Alkaf-i, (Ḥar p. 96,) and jaEodu AljanaAni; (A;) contr. of [saboTu Alyadayoni, and] sbTu Alyadi and sbTu AlbanaAni [&c.]: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) and mean; ungenerous; base: (L:) and jaEodu AlqafaA ‡ mean, or ignoble, in respect of rank, quality, reputation, or the like. (A, Ḳ.)
A camel having much fur: (Ḳ:) or having crisp, or curly, and abundant, fur. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] Oabuw AljaEodi a surname of The camel. (L.)
† Soft moist earth; as also vaEodN: (Ṣ:) or moist earth. (Ḳ.)

† A mess of the kind called Hayos that is thick, (L, Ḳ,) not flowing; (L;) as also mujaE-adN↓. (L, Ḳ.) IAạr cites the following words of a poet, accusing a woman of foul conduct:
wataxoliTu biAlmaOoquwTi HayosFA mujaE-adFA↓
[And she mixes thick Hys with the food prepared with OaqiT]; meaning, she confounds men together, and does not select him who is to have intercourse with her. (L.)
† Froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of the mouth of a camel. (Ṣ,* L.) And jaEodu All-ugaAmi † A camel having froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of his mouth. (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ.*)

† A cheek rough, or coarse, and short; not Oasiyl. (L, Ḳ.) And † A round face, with little miloH [or beauty], (Ḳ, TA,) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, laHom [or flesh]. (TA.) And qadamN jaEodapN ‡ A short foot; (A, TA;) characteristic of low origin. (TA.)
It is also applied, in the manner of an intensive epithet, to the plant called Sil-iyaAn; and in like manner, with p {jaEodapN}, to the plant called buhomaI. (TA.)
naAqapN jaEodapN † A she-camel compact in make, and strong. (TA.)
mujaE-adN: see jaEodN, in two places.
mutajaE-idN Moist earth contracted, and compacted in lumps. (L in art. Eqd.)

1. jaEara, aor. _a {yajoEaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaEorN; (Mṣb;) and AnjEr↓; (Ḳ;) said of a beast or bird of prey (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) having claws, or talons, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or a hyena, and a dog, and a cat, (TA,) and metaphorically of a rat or mouse, (Mṣb,) He voided his dung. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
5. tjE-r, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or tjE-r bijiEaArK, (TA,) He bound upon his (i. e. his own) waist a rope of the kind called jiEaAr. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
7: see 1.

hom.sense: jaEorN, originally an inf. n., (Mṣb,) The dung of a beast or bird of prey (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) having claws, or talons; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaAEirapN↓; (Ḳ;) which is like rawovN in relation to a horse: (TA:) or the dung of the hyena: (A:) [and of the dog, and cat: see 1:] or dry dung upon the majoEar, q. v.: (Ḳ:) or dung that comes forth dry: (IAth, TA:) and ‡ that of the rat or mouse: (Mṣb:) pl. juEuwrN. (Ḳ.)
See also juEoruwrN.
Also Costiveness. (TA.)

entry.sense: juEorapN A mark left by the rope called jiEaAr (Th, Ḳ) upon the waist of a man. (Th, TA.)
jaEoraMCu: see majoEarN.

Oabuw jiEoraAna [in which the latter word is imperfectly decl. because it is a proper name ending with the augment An] The [black beetle called] juEal, (Kr, Ḳ, TA,) in a general sense: or, as some say, a certain species thereof. (TA.)
And Oum-u jiEoraAna, (Ḳ, TA,) or Oum-u jiEoraAnapa, (so in a copy of the Ḳ,) The raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus]. (Kr, Ḳ.)

juEoruwrN A bad kind of dates; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) also metaphorically called jaEoru↓ AlfaOorapi [the rat's, or mouse's, dung], because of the bad smell, and the diminutiveness, thereof: (Mṣb:) and you also say juEoruwrN: (TA:) or a species of the daqal, which is the worst kind of dates: (Ṣ:) or a species of the [kind of palm-tree called] daqal that bears small things [or dates] in which is no good. (Aṣ, TA.) [See Eacoqu Aljubayoqi, in art. jbq.]
jiEir-aI: see majoEarN.

jaEAri, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) like qaTaAmi, (Ḳ,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it deviates from its original form, which is jaAEirapN, and is of the fem. gender, and has the quality of an epithet in which that of a subst. is predominant, so that the thing to which it applies is known by it like as it is known by its proper name; and as it is prevented from being perfectly decl. by two causes, it must be indecl. by reason of three; as we also say with respect to HalaAqi, a proper name of death; (Ṣ;) The she-hyena; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a name of that animal (Ṣ) because of the abundance of its dung; (Ṣ, A;) as also Oum-u jaEaAri, and jayoEarN↓, and Oum-u jaEowarK↓. (Ḳ.) Hence, OaEoyavu mino jaEaAri [More mischievous than the she-hyena]: a prov. (A, TA.) And tiysiI jaEaAri (Ḳ) Be thou like the he-goat in stupidity, O she-hyena; a prov. applied to a stupid man: (A and TA in art. tys, q. v.:) or EiyviI jaEaAri [Do mischief, O she-hyena]; a prov. used in declaring a thing to be vain, or false. (Ḳ.) And
ruwEiI jaEaAri waQnoZuriI Oayona Almafori [for Almafir-u, Be afraid, O she-hyena, and look where is a place to which to flee]: (Ḳ,* TA:) or ruwgiI [i. e. turn aside, this way and that]: (Ṣ and TA in art. rwg:) a prov. applied to him who seeks to escape, and cannot: (TA:) or with reference to a coward, and his submissiveness. (Ḳ.) And quwmiI jaEaAri [Rise, O she-hyena]: said to a woman, in reviling her; likening her to a she-hyena. (ISk, TA.)

hom.sense: jiEaArN A certain mark made with a hot iron upon [the part called] the jaAEarataAni: (Ḳ:) accord. to the Tedhkireh of Aboo-ʼAlee, one of the marks, so made, of camels. (Ibn-Ḥabeeb, TA.)

A rope which a man who waters ties to a stake, and then binds upon his waist, when he descends into a well, lest he should fall into it: (Ṣ:) or a rope which a drawer of water binds upon his waist, (Ḳ, TA,) when he descends into a well, (TA,) lest he should fall into the well; (Ḳ, TA;) the end being in the hand of another man, who, if he falls, pulls him up with it. (TA.)

entry.sense: Oum-u jaEowarN: see jaEaAri.
jayoEarN: see jaEaAri.

hom.sense: jaAEirapN: see majoEarN.

AljaAEirataAni The place of the [two marks made by cauterization which are called the] raqomataAni, in the buttocks (Aisot) of an ass: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the places of cauterization in the hinder part, upon the [two portions of the thighs called the] kaAcataAni, of an ass: (TA:) and the part, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or two parts, (A,) which the tail strikes, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) upon the two thighs of a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a beast, where he is cauterized: (A:) or the two edges of the haunches projecting over the thighs [behind]; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., the two places which the farrier marks, making lines upon them [with a hot iron] (yaroqumuhumaA): or the heads of the upper parts of the two thighs: or the depressed part of the haunch and thigh, in the place of the joint. (TA.)
See also jaEorN.

entry.sense: majoEarN The rump, or podex; or the anus; [in the present day, the latter;] syn. duburN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and jaEoraMCu↓ and jiEir-aI↓ and jaAEirapN↓ the same; syn. AisotN; (Ḳ;) or the last (jAErp), as some say, i. q. Haloqapu Ald-uburi. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mijoEaArN A man very, or often, costive; (Ḳ;) as also mijoEaAru AlbaToni. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. jaEomasa He (a man, TA) deposited his ordure, or excrement, at once: (Ḳ, TA:) or in a dry, or tough, state. (TA.) The m is augmentative. (Ṣgh, TA.)

jEosN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jiEosN↓, (TA,) and juEomuwsN↓; (AZ, Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. jEms,)
the first of which is post-classical; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the last, the term used by the Arabs [of the classical ages]; (Ṣ;) Human ordure, or excrement; (AZ, TA in art. jEms;) syn. rajiyEN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the first signifies the place in which the juEomuws falls: (IDrd, Ḳ:) the m in the last word is augmentative; and its pl. is jaEaAmiysu. (Ṣ.) You say, ramaI bijaEaAmiysi↓ baTonihi [He cast forth the excrements of his belly]. (Ṣ.)
jiEosN: see the next preceding paragraph.
juEaAmisN A man (TA) who deposits his ordure, or excrement, at once: (Ḳ:) or in a dry, or tough, state: as also mujaEomisN↓. (TA.)
mujaEomisN: see what next precedes.

1. jaEafahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoEafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaEofN, (TA,) He prostrated him; threw him down upon the ground; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) cast him upon the gronnd; like jaEabahu; (TA;) namely, a man; (Ṣ;) as also AjEfhu↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
He pulled it, or plucked it, out, or up; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ,) or a tree; (Ḳ, TA;) and turned it over, or upside down; (TA;) as also AjtEfhu↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
4: see 1.
7. AnjEf [He became prostrated, thrown down upon the ground, or cast upon the ground: see its part. n., below].
It (a thing, Ṣ, or a tree, Ḳ) became pulled, or pluckt, out, or up. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
juEaAfN: see what next follows.
jaAEifN, applied to a torrent, i. q. juHaAfN [That carries away everything]; as also juEaAfN↓: (Ḳ:) and that overturns everything upon which it comes. (TA.)
majoEafN A place where one is prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground. (TA.)
munojaEifN: see what next precedes.

Q. 1. jaEofadapN [inf. n. of jaEofada] a compound word from the phrase jaEalaniI Qll-ehu fidaAka [May God make me thy ransom]. (Ibn-Diḥyeh, TA.) [You say, jaEofadahu, meaning He said to him jElnI Qll-eh fdAk.]

jaEofarN A small river; a rivulet, streamlet, or brook; (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or one that is larger than a jadowalN: (Ḳ:) or, as in the Nawádir, a small river, larger than a jdwl: (TA:) or a river, (IDrd, IJ, TA,) absolutely: (TA:) if small, it is a falaj: (IDrd, TA:) or (TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) a large, wide river: (Ibn-El-Ajdábee, Ḳ:) [if so,] bearing two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) or (in some copies of the Ḳ “and”) a full river. (Ḳ.)
Also (from the last of these significations, TA) ‡ A she-camel abounding with milk. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jaEala, aor. _a {yajoEalu}, inf. n. jaEolN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juEolN and jaEaAlapN and jiEaAlapN (Ḳ) and majoEalN, (Ṣ, TA,) He made a thing; syn. SanaEa; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) but having a more general signification than faEala and SanaEa and their equivalents [as will be shown by what follows]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so AjtEl↓: (Ḳ:) both these verbs signify the same. (Ṣ.)

He made a thing of, or from, a thing; as in the saying [in the Ḳur xvi. 74 and xlii. 9], jaEala lakumo mino Oanofusikumo OazowaAjFA [He hath made for you, of, or from, yourselves, wives]; and [in the Ḳur xvi. 83] wajaEala lakumo mina AljibaAli OakonaAnFA [And He hath made for you, of the mountains, places of retreat; as caves, and excavated houses or chambers: so explained by Bḍ]. (TA.)

He created; (Ḳ, TA;) brought into being, or existence; (TA;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur vi. 1], waJaEala AlZ-ulumaAti waAln-uwri [And hath created, or brought into being, the darknesses and the light]; (Ḳ, TA;) and [in the Ḳur xxi. 31] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaMCi kul-a XaIoCK HaI-K [And We have created of water, or the seminal fluid, everything living]; and [in the Ḳur xvi. 80, &c.,] wajaEala lakumu Als-amoEa waAlOaboSaAra waAlOafoYidapa [And He created for you the ears and the eyes and the hearts]. (TA.)

He made, or prepared; as in the saying [in the Ḳur lxv. 2], yajoEalu lahu maxorajFA [He will make, or prepare, for him a way of escape, or safety]; and [in the Ḳur lxv. 4] yajoEalu lahu mino Oamorihi yusorFA [He will make, or prepare, for him an easy state of his circumstances; i. e., will make his circumstances, or case, easy to him]. (TA.)

He made; meaning he made to be, or become; he constituted; he appointed; [in which sense it is doubly trans.;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the saying in the Ḳur [xix. 31], wajaEaloniI nabiy-FA [And He hath made me a prophet]; (Ṣ;) [and in the elliptical phrase, jaEalahu Ealayohi He made him to be superintendant, or the like, over it; set him, or appointed him, over it:] and in the phrase, jaEala AlqabiyHa HasanFA [He made that which was bad to be, or become, good]. (Ḳ.)

He made a thing to be in a particular state or condition; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 20], Al-aci jaEala lakumu AlOaroDa firaAXFA [Who hath made for you the earth to be as a bed]; and [in the Ḳur lxxi. 15] wajaEala Alqamara fiyhin-a nuwrFA [And hath made the moon, in them (the heavens), to be as a light]; and so, as some say, in the saying [in the Ḳur xliii. 2], Uin-aA jaEalonaAhu quroMnFA Earabiy-FA [Verily we have made it an Arabic Ḳur-án]. (TA.)

[He made a thing to be in an altered, or changed, state or condition; i. e.,] the verb signifies also the changing a thing from its state or condition; as in the saying [in the Ḳur xi. 84 and xv. 74], jaEalonaA EaAliyahaA saAfilahaA [We made their upper part to be their lower part]; (Ḳ;) and in the words of the Ḳur [lvi. 81], watajoEaluwna rizoqakumo Oan-akumo tukac-ibuwna [And do ye make the thanks that ye should render for your sustenance to be that ye charge with falsehood the Giver thereof by attributing it to the stars called OanowaMC as expl. by Bḍ and Jel]. (TA.)

He pronounced (Er-Rághib, Ḳ) a thing by a true judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or as a legal ordinance; (Ḳ;) as in the saying (of the Legislator, TA), jaEala Qll-ehu AlS-alawaAti AlmaforuwDaAti xamosFA [God hath pronounced the prayers that are made obligatory to be five] (Ḳ.) And He pronounce (Er-Rághib, Ḳ *) a thing by a false judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or according to his own judgment, heretically; (Ḳ;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur xv. 91], Al-aciyna jaEaluwA AlquroMna EiDiyna [Who pronounced the Ḳur-án to be lies, or enchantment,, &c.]. (Er-Rághib, Ḳ.)

He called, or named, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing; (Mṣb;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur xliii. 18], wajaEaluwA AlmalaAYikapa Al-aciyna humo EibaAdu Alr-aHomeni UinaAvFA [And they have called the angels, who are the servants of the Compassionate, females]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the meaning is, have described them as, and pronounced them to be, females; like as one says, jaEala fulaAnN zayodFA OaEolama Aln-aAsi [Such a one described Zeyd as, and pronounced him to be, the most learned of men]: or have held, or believed, them to be females; like as the verb signifies in the saying in the Ḳur [xvi. 59], wayajoEaluwna lil-ehi AlbanaAti [And they hold, or believe, God to have daughters: or this may be rendered and they attribute to God daughters]. (TA.) You say also, jaEalotu zayodFA OaxaAka, meaning I asserted Zeyd to be related to thee [as a brother; or I called Zeyd thy brother]. (Ḳ.)

He thought; as in the saying, jaEala AlbaSorapa bagodaAda [He thought El-Basrah to be Baghdád]; (Ḳ;) and so in the saying, jaEalotuhu EabodFA faXatamotuhu [I thought him to be a slave, and consequently I reviled him]. (Ḥam p. 31.)

He made known, or plain, or perspicuous; as in the saying [in the Ḳur xliii. 2, of which one explanation has been given above], Uin-aA jaEalonaAhu quroMnFA Earabiy-FA [Verily we have made it known,, &c., as an Arabic Ḳur-án]: (Ḳ:) or the meaning is, we have revealed it [as such]. (TA.)

He exalted, or ennobled; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 137], jaEalonaAkumo Oum-apF wasaTFA [We have exalted you, or ennobled you, as a nation conforming to the just mean; or just, or equitable, or good]: (Ḳ:) [or it may be rendered, we have made you a nation, &c.:] or, as some say, the meaning is, we have called you, or named you, a nation, &c. (TA.)
Also, inf. n. jaEolN, He put, or laid, a thing; or put it, or laid it, down. (Ḳ.) And jaEala baEoDahu fuwoqa baEoDK He put, or threw, one part of it upon another. (Ḳ.)
He inserted a thing into a thing; as in the Ḳur [ii. 18], yajoEaluwna OaSaAbiEahumo fiI McaAnihimo [They insert, or put, their fingers into their ears]. (TA.)

He put into the heart, or mind; as in the Ḳur [lvii. 27], wajalonaA fiI quluwbi Ql-aciyna Qt-abaEuwhu raOofapF waraHomapF [And we put into the hearts of those who followed him pity and com- passion]. (TA.)

[He appointed, or assigned, or stipulated to give, or gave, wages, pay, or a stipend, &c.]. You say, jaEalotu lahu juEolFA [I appointed him,, &c., wages, pay, or a stipend]. (Mṣb.) And jaEala lahu kacaA EalaI kacaA He stipulated with him to give him such a thing for [doing] such a thing. (Ḳ.) And jaEala [alone] He gave wages, pay, or a stipend, to another to serve for him in war, i. e., in his stead. (Mgh.) And OajoEalotu↓ lahu I gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (Ṣ,* Mgh.) And OajoEalahu↓ juEolFA and OajoEalahu↓ lahu, He gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (Ḳ, TA.) And it is said in a trad., jaEala liqawomihi miAYapF mina AlUibili EalaI Oano yusal-imuwA [He gave, or stipulated to give, to his people, or party, a hundred camels on the condition that they should surrender]. (Mgh.)
jaEala yafoEalu kacaA He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing; (Ḳ,* TA;) he became occupied in doing such a thing. (TA.)

jaEala is also, sometimes, an intrans. verb included among the verbs of appropinquation (OafoEaAlu AlmuqaArabapi); as in the saying,
waqado jaEalotu UicaA maA qumotu yuvoqiluniI
vawobiI faOanohaDu nahoDa AlX-aAribi Alv--amili
[And I was beginning to be, or at the point of being, in such a state that, when I rose, my garment heavily burdened me, so that I stood up as stands up the intoxicated drinker]. (Ḳ.)
jaEila, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoEalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaEalN; (Ṣ;) and AjEl↓; (Ḳ;) It (water) had in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or had in it dead jiEolaAn. (Ḳ.)
And jaEila, (TḲ,) inf. n. jaEalN, (IAạr, Ḳ, TḲ,) He (a boy, TḲ) was, or became, short and fat. (IAạr, Ḳ. [In the explanation of AljaEalu in the CK, AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqiSaru.])
And He (a man, TḲ) persisted; or persisted obstinately; or persisted in contention, or litigation; or contended, or litigated; jaEalN being syn. with lajaAjN. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. jAElhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAEalapN and jiEaAlN, (TA,) He endeavoured to conciliate him by means of a bribe. (A, Ḳ.* [In the CK, raX-Ahu is erroneously put for raAXaAhu.])

hom.sense: 4: see jaEala, above, in three places:
and see jaEila, above.
AjEl Alqidora He put down the cooking-pot (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the fire (Ṣ) with the piece of rag called jiEaAl. (Ṣ, Ḳ,)

OajoEalato and AstjElt↓ said of a bitch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of other animals, (Ḳ,) of any beasts of prey, (Ṣ,) She desired, (Ṣ, Ḳ, Er-Rághib,) or loved, (Ḳ,) copulation: (Ṣ, Ḳ, Er-Rághib:) metonymically used in this sense. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAElwA AlX-aIoCa They stipulated among themselves to give the thing as wages, pay, or stipend: (Ḳ:) from juEolN. (TA.) You say also, tjAEl Aln-aAsu bayonahumo Einoda AlbaEovi [The people stipulated among themselves to give wages, or pay, to such of them as should serve as substitutes, on the occasion of being ordered forth to war]. (TA.)
8. AjtEl: see 1, first sentence.
Also He took, or received, wages, pay, or a stipend. (Mgh, TA.)

jaEolN Short palm-trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or shoots, or offsets, of palm-trees, cut off from the mothertrees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted: or bad palm-trees: or palm-trees that rise beyond the reach of the hand: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {jaEolapN}: (Ṣ: [in the Ḳ, not so correctly, pl. of jaEolapN:]) and palm-trees such as are called baEolN [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

juEolN Wages; pay; a stipend; or a thing that is appointed, or stipulated, to be given to a man for work, or service; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) of more general import than OujorapN and vawaAbN; (TA;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (as some say, Mṣb) jaEaAlapN↓ (Aṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juEaAlapN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaEiylapN↓ (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jiEaAlN↓ (Ḳ) and jaEalN↓: (Ḥar p. 134:) pl. juEulN (TA) and (of jEylp or jEAlp, Mgh) jaEaAYilu. (Mgh, TA.) Afterwards, (Mgh,) or jaEaAlapN↓ and jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) Wages, or pay, or the like, which one gives to a man who goes to war (Mgh, Ḳ, TA) as a substitute for the giver, (Ḳ, TA,) that he may aid himself thereby to serve in the war: (Mgh:) pl. of the last three words jaEaAYilu (TA.) And juEolN, (TA in art. rXw,) or jaEaAlapN↓, (Ḳ,) A bribe. (Ḳ, TA.) And jaEiylapN↓ Algaraqi What is given, or stipulated to be given, to him who dives for goods or for a man drowned. (TA.)
jiEolN and jaEilN↓ and mujoEilN↓ Water having in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: or having in it dead jiEolaAn. (Ḳ.) And OaroDN mujoEilapN↓ A land abounding with jiEolaAn. (Ḳ.)
jaEalN: see juEolN.
jaEilN: see jiEolN.

juEalN [The species of black beetle called cantharus;] a certain insect (duwayob-ap); (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a certain black insect, found in moist places, (TA,) that rolls along a little ball [of dung] called duHoruwjap [in which it deposits its eggs]: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dHrj:) [see also xunofasaMCu: it is strangely explained in the Mṣb as the HirobaMC, which is the male of the Oum-u Hubayon:] pl. jiEolaAnN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) A black and ugly and small man: or one who is wont to persist, or to persist obstinately, or to persist in contention or litigation, or to contend or litigate: and (as some say, TA) i. q. raqiybN [a watcher, an observer,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: jiEaAlN A piece of rag with which a cooking-pot is put down (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the fire; (Ṣ;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. juEulN (Ṣ, TA) and jaEaAYilu. (TA.)
See also juEolN.

entry.sense: jaEowalN The young of the ostrich. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
jaEaAlapN: see juEolN, in three places.

hom.sense: juEaAlapN: see juEolN, in two places:
and jiEaAlN.
jiEaAlapN: see juEolN, in two places:
and jiEaAlN.

entry.sense: jaEiylapN: see juEolN, in two places.
jaAEilN [act. part. n. of jaEala] Giving [wages, pay, or a stipend:, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: mujoEilN applied to a bitch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to any animal (Ṣ, Ḳ) or beast of prey, (Ṣ,) Desiring, (Ṣ,) or loving, (Ḳ,) copulation. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See 4])
Also, fem. with p {mujoEilapN}: see jiEolN, in two places.

entry.sense: mujotaEilN Taking, or receiving, [wages, pay, or a stipend.] (Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 1. Q. accord. to the Ḳ, but Q. Q. accord. to Ṣgh jaEumasa: see art. jEs.
juEomuwsN: see art. jEs.
juEaAmisN: see art. jEs.
mujaEomisN: see art. jEs.

hom.sense: 1. jaf-a, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) sec. pers. jafafota, (Ḳ,) aor. yajif-u (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and yajaf-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter aor. mentioned by AZ, but rejected by Ks; (Ṣ;) and sec. pers. jaffota, aor. yajaf-u, (Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Benoo-Asad; (Mṣb;) inf. n. jafaAfN and jufuwfN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which are assigned by J and Ṣgh to jaf-a aor. yajif-N; (TA;) It (a thing, Mgh, or a garment, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and also said of other things, Ṣ) was, or became, dry; it dried, or dried up. (Mgh, Mṣb.) Hence the saying, mani QHotalama vum-a OaSobaHa EalaI jafaAfK He who experiences an emission of semen in sleep, then rises in the morning with what is on his garment, of the semen, dry. (Mgh.) And jaf-a Aln-ahoru, an elliptical phrase, for jaf-a maMCu Aln-ahori [The water of the river dried up]. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN laA yajif-u liboduhu Such a one does not remit, or become remiss, in his work, or labour: (TA:) or does not cease to go to and fro. (Ḥar p. 589.)
jaf-a, inf. n. jufuwfN, said of a man, He was, or became, silent; he did not speak. (Mṣb.)
jafafotu AlX-aIoCa UilaI-a, aor. Oajuf-u, inf. n. jaf-N, I collected the thing to me. (Nawádir of AZ, TA.)
jaf-uwA OamowaAlahumo They collected together their camels, and took them away. (Ṣgh,* Ḳ,* TA.)
2. jf-fhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. tajofiyfN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tajofaAfN, (Ḳ,) He dried it. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
jf-f Alfarasa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajofiyfN, (Ṣ,) He clad, or attired, the horse with a tijofaAf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see R. Q. 2.
8. Ajtf- maA fiI AlUinaMCi He consumed what was in the vessel; (Ḳ;) i. e., drank up all of it; as also AXtf-. (TA.)

R. Q. 2. tajafojafa It (a garment, or piece of cloth), having been moist, dried so far as to retain some moisture: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
if it has dried entirely, you say of it, qado qaf-a: (Ṣ:) the verb is originally tjf-f↓; the medial f being changed into j: it is like tabaXobaXa, originally tbX-X. (Lth, Ṣ.)
jaf-N: see jaf-apN.

hom.sense: juf-N The spathe of the palm-tree; the envelope of the TaloE; (AA, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jub-N; (AA, TA;) or [in other words] the qiyqaMC of the TlE; (Ḳ;) i. e., the envelope that is with the waliyE: (Lth, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the envelope of the TlE when it has become dry: (TA:) pl. jufuwfN. (A' Obeyd, TA.) [See jub-N.]
A receptacle such as is termed wiEaMC that is not to be tied round at its mouth. (Ḳ, TA.)

An old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin, of which half is cut off and made into a bucket: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and sometimes it is made of the lower part of a palm-tree hollowed out: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or a thing that is hollowed out in (fiI [probably a mistranscription for min, i. e. of]) the trunks of palm-trees: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or a worn-out milk-skin or butter-skin: (IAạr, TA:) or a water-skin, or milk-skin, of which part is cut off at the fore legs, and in which the beverage called nabiyc is prepared: (Ḳṭ, TA:) or the lower half of a water-skin or milk-skin, made into a bucket: (IDrd, TA:) or a thing of camel's skin, like a vessel, or like a bucket, in which the rainwater is taken, holding half the quantity of a water-skin or the like. (TA.)
An old man; (Ḳ;) as being likened to an old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin: mentioned in the L from El-Hejeree, and by Ṣgh from Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
Anything hollow, such as has something within it, like the nut, and the magodap [or fruit of the tanoDub, &c.: in the CK, the maEidap]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA.)
The body, or substance, (XaxoS,) of a thing. (TA.)
An obstruction that one sees between him and the kibleh. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
huwa juf-u maAlK He is a good manager of cattle, (Ḳ,) acquainted with the art of pasturing them, and of collecting them at their proper time in the place of pasture. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jaf-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juf-apN↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) but the latter is rare, (Ṣgh,) and juf-N↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaf-N↓, (Ḳ,) A company of men or people; a collective body thereof: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a great number (Ḳ) thereof. (TA.) You say, duEiytu fiI jaf-api Aln-aAsi [I was summoned, or invited, among the collective body of people]. (Ṣ.) And jaAWuwA jaf-pF waAHidapF (Ṣ, Ḳ) They came in one collective body. (Ḳ.) laA nafala fiI ganiymapK Hat-aI tuqosama jaf-apF, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or juf-apF↓, (Ḳ,) means [There shall be no gift of spoil] until it is divided altogether: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) a saying of Ibn-ʼAbbás: (Ṣ, Mgh:) accord. to one reading, EalaI juf-atihi↓, i. e., [until it is divided] among the collective body of the army first. (Ḳ. [Golius (here copied by Freytag) appears to have read, laA taqulo fiI ganamK; and hence to have said, of jaf-apN, erroneously, “de pecore non dicitur nisi totus grex sit.”])

hom.sense: juf-apN: see what next precedes, in three places.
Also A great dalow [or bucket]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jufaAfN What is dry of a thing that one has dried. (Ḳ.) You say, AiEozilo jufaAfahu mino raTobihi [Put thou apart what is dry thereof from what is fresh and moist thereof]. (TA.)

jafiyfN Dry herbs or herbage: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or dry leguminous plants or herbs, of the kind that are eaten without being cooked: (TA:) or of this kind and of such as are thick and inclining to bitterness; as also qafiyfN: (TA in art. qf:) or, as some say, mA Dmnt mn AlryH. (TA in the present art. [But what this means I know not; the verb being evidently mistranscribed.])
jufaAfapN What has become scattered, or strewed, of dry herbage (HaXiyX) and of [the kind of trefoil called] qat-, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and the like. (TA.)

tijofaAfN A thing, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e. a kind of armour, (IAth, Ḳ,) [a cataphract,] with which a horse is clad, (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in war, in the manner of a coat of mail, (Mgh, Mṣb,) to defend him from being wounded; (IAth;) and sometimes worn by a man, to defend him in war: (Ḳ:) of the measure tifoEaAlN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) the t being augmentative, (Aboo-ʼAlee the Grammarian, Ṣ, IJ,) to render the word quasi-coordinate to the class of qiroTaAsN; (IJ;) from jaf-a, because of its hardness and toughness: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. tajaAfiyfu (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., OaEid-a lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; and one says, Ailobaso lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; [both] meaning, Make thou preparation for poverty. (TA.)
mutajaf-ifN Having a tijofaAf upon his horse. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 1. jafaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajofaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jafoCN, (Ṣ,) It (a valley [flowing with water]) cast forth froth, or foam, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and particles of rubbish or refuse; (Ṣ;) as also AjfO↓; (Ḳ;) but this latter is said in the O to be of weak authority. (TA.) And jafaOati Alqidoru, and AjfOt↓, The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in boiling: (Ṣ:) or jfOt bizabadihaA it cast forth its froth, or foam: (Ḥam p. 132:) originally jafat and Ajft, without C. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jfw.)

jafaOa AlwaAdiI, (Ḳ,) or jafaOa AlguvaMCa Eani AlwaAdiI, (IAạr, O,) He (a man, IAạr, O) swept off the scum and rubbish of the valley [after it had flowed, or while it was flowing, with water]. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) And jafaOa Alqidora He cleared off the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also jafaOa Alqidora, (Ṣ, Z in the Fáïk, TA,) inf. n. as above; (Ṣ, TA;) and OajofaOahaAs↓; (Z ubi suprà, TA;) but the former is that which is commonly known; (ISd, TA;) the latter is rare; (IAth, TA:) or the latter should not be said, though it occurs in a trad., (Ṣ, TA,*) accord. to one relation; (TA;) He turned the cooking-pot upsidedown, or inclined it, (Ṣ, Z ubi suprà, TA,) and poured out what was in it: (Ṣ:) or he emptied the cooking-pot, and turned it upside-down: (TA:) and jafaOa Alburomapa fiI AlqaSoEapi He turned the cookingpot upside-down upon the bowl. (Ḳ.)

jafaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [like HafaOahu,] and jafaOa bihi AlOaroDa, (TA,) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) namely, a man: (Ṣ:) and AjfO↓ bihi [signifies the same; or] he threw him, or it, (Ḳ, TA,) on the ground. (TA.)
See also 8.

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in four places.

8. AjtfO He pulled, or plucked, up, or out, or he uprooted, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and threw down, or away, a thing, (Ṣ,) or plants, or herbs, such as are termed baqol, (Ḳ,) and trees; (TA;) [but see AHtfI;] as also jafaOa↓, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) [or] both signify he cut a plant, or herb. (IAạr, Nh.)

hom.sense: jufaMCN What is cast forth [of froth, or foam, and particles of rubbish or refuse, (see 1,)] by a torrent: (ISk, Ṣ:) the froth, or foam, cast forth by a valley [flowing with water]; and by a cooking-pot, (Ḳ, TA,) in boiling. (TA.)

Hence, as being likened to the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot, of which no use is made, (Fr, TA,) i. q. baATilN [meaning A thing that is worthless, useless, or unprofitable]. (Fr, Ḳ, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xiii. 18], faOam-aA Alz-abadu fayacohabu jufaMCF, meaning baATilFA [i. e. Now as to the froth, or scum, it passeth away as a thing that is worthless, or useless, or unprofitable], (Fr, Ṣ, Jel, TA,) and thrown away. (Jel.) You say also, cahaba Alz-abadu jufaMCF, meaning [The froth, or scum, passed away] driven from its water. (TA.)

jufaMCN mina Aln-aAsi, occurring in a trad., is explained by IAth as meaning The first, or foremost, of the men or people (saraEaAnuhumo): but Bkh and Muslim read (instead of jfAC) Oaxif-aMCu, pl. of xafiyfN. (TA.)
Also, [like jufaAyapN,] An empty ship. (O, Ḳ.)

1. jafara He, or it, became wide: (Ḳ:) or became inflated, or swollen. (A.) And jafara janobaAhu His (a kid's, Ṣ and Mṣb, or lamb's, Mṣb) sides became widened, or distended: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and Ajfr↓ janobaAhu [and Anjfr↓ (Ḳ in art. hDm)] his (a horse's) sides became inflated, or swollen. (A.)

He (a lamb, Ḳ, and a kid, TA) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjf-r↓ and Astjfr↓: (Ḳ:) and tjf-rt↓ and Astjfrt↓ she (a kid) became a jaforap. (ISh, TA.) And He (a boy) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjf-r↓ (TA) and Astjfr↓: (A:) and this last verb, he became large in the sides. (L.)

jafara (Ṣ, A) Eani AlD-iraAbi, (Ṣ,) or Eani AlUibili, (A,) aor. _u {yajofuru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jufuwrN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Ajtfr↓; and Ajfr↓, inf. n. UijofaArN; and jf-r↓, inf. n. tajofiyrN; (Ḳ;) He (a stallioncamel) ceased, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or abstained, (A,) from covering, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and avoided it; having indulged in it so much that he was wearied; (Ṣ;) and his seminal fluid became little: (TA:) you say of a ram, rabaDa, (Ṣ, A,) not jafara. (Ṣ.)
And jafara Eani AlmaroOapi, (IAạr, TA,) and Ajfr↓ EanohaA, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and Ajtfr↓, and jf-r↓, (IAạr, TA,) He (a man) abstained from the woman; (Ḳ;) he abstained from sexual intercourse with her. (IAạr, TA.)
jafara mina AlmaraDi He recovered from the disease. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
jf-rhu AlOamoru Eanohu The thing, or affair, cut him off from him, or it. (IAạr, L.)
4: see 1, in three places.

Ajfr also signifies He cut, abandoned, or forsook, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) another, (Ṣ,) or his companion, or friend, (Ḳ,) and left off visiting him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Oajofarotu maA kunotu fiyhi I left, or relinquished, that in which I was occupied. (Ṣ.)
Also It (a thing, TA) was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed, (Ḳ, TA,) from one. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in three places.
7: see 1.
8: see 1, in two places.
10: see 1, in three places.

hom.sense: jaforN A lamb, or kid, whose sides have become widened, or distended: (Mṣb:) or a lamb, (IAmb, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a kid, (Ḳ,* TA,) that has become large, and begun to pasture, (Ḳ, TA,) and whose sides have become widened, or distended: (TA:) or a lamb, (Ḳ,) or a kid, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) that is four months old, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and whose sides have become widened, and that is weaned, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) and has taken to pasture: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or this is sometimes four months, and sometimes five months, after the birth: or a young lamb, and a kid, after it has been weaned, when six months old: (IAạr, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaArN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] jifaArN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jafarapN: (Ḳ) fem. with p {jaforapN}: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or jaforapN signifies a female kid that has become satiated with leguminous herbs and with shrubs, and is independent of its mother: (ISh, TA:) IAmb applies it to a female lamb and a female kid; and this is correct, though some say that it is applied to the latter only. (TA.)
A boy when his belly has become widened, (A,) or when his flesh has become swollen out, (Ḳ,) and he has begun to eat: (A, Ḳ:) fem. with p {jaforapN} (Ḳ.) [See XaAdixN; and see also muTab-ixN.]

A well, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a wide well, (Ṣ, A,) not cased, or walled round, within; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jaforapN↓: (R, TA:) or, of which a portion is cased, or walled round, within, (Ḳ, TA,) and a portion is not: (TA:) the former of the masc. gender: pl. jifaArN. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] fulaAnN munohadimu Aljafori (A, Ḳ *) [Such a one's well is in a state of demolition; meaning,] such a one has no judgment: (A:) or has no intelligence. (Ḳ.) And Uin-a jaforaka EalaI-a lahaArK [Verily thy well is falling in upon me; meaning] thy mischief is coming quickly upon me. (A, TA.)
[The pl.] jafaArN also signifies [simply] Wells. (Ḳ.)
And hence, (TA,) She-camels abounding with milk. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: jaforapN: see jaforN.
juforapN A round space in the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a round and wide cavity in the ground: (L:) pl. jifaArN. (Ṣ.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) The belly, or interior of the body: (Ṣ:) or the cavity of the chest: or what comprises the belly [in the TA the chest] and the two sides: (Ḳ:) or the place where the ribs curve; and so in a horse, &c.: (TA:) the middle of a horse, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a camel: and, as some say, the middle, and main part, of anything: and thus, the main part of the sea: (TA:) pl. jufarN and jifaArN, accord. to the Ḳ; but the latter is pl. of juforapN in the sense of “a round cavity.” (TA.)
Also [the pl.] jufarN signifies The holes that are dug in the ground for props. (TA.)

jafiyrN A kind of quiver like the kinaAnap, but wider, (Lth, Ṣ, TA,) in which are put many arrows: (Lth, TA:) or a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap [q. v.], of skins, in which is no wood: or of wood, in which are no skins; (Ḳ;) or in which is no skin; as in some good lexicons: (TA:) or of skins, and slit in its side, that the wind may enter it, and the feathers in consequence may not be eaten: (TA: [see also jaXiyrN:]) or the same as the jEbp and the knAnp: (El-Aḥmar, TA:) or a quiver for nabol, wide, of wood. (Ḥam p. 358.) Hence, layosa fiI jafiyrihi gayoru zanodayoni [There is not in his quiver aught save two pieces of wood for producing fire]: a prov. applied to him in whom is no good. (Meyd.)
majofarN: see majofarapN.

mujofarN, applied to a horse, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and with p {mujofarapN} applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ,) Large in the middle: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and mujofaru Aljanobayoni a horse inflated, or swollen, in the sides. (A.)

majofarapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and majofarN↓ (Lḥ, Ḳ) An impediment to venery; (Lḥ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and a cause of diminishing the seminal fluid: (AʼObeyd, TA:) applied to food: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) and such is fasting said to be; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the sun, (A,* TA,) i. e., sitting in the sun; and such, also, the sleeping between daybreak and sunrise, or in the first part of the day. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jafala, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajofilu} and _u {yajofulu}, inf. n. jafolN (Mṣb) and jufuwlN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a camel) took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness: and Ajfl↓ he (a bird) took fright, and flew away; or became scared away: (Mṣb:) or the former, he (an ostrich, Ḳ) hastened, or sped, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in his pace, (TA,) and went away in the land, or country; as also Ajfl↓; (IDrd, Ḳ;) both, said of an ostrich, mean he spread his wings, running; (Ḥam p. 555;) or spread his wings, and ran quickly, or went away at random and swiftly: (TA:) or jafalati Aln-aEaAmapu means the ostrich fled: (Mṣb:) and Ajfl↓ Eanohu, said of anything, he fled from it: (TA, Ḥam p. 555:) and jafaluwA, aor. _u {yajofulu}, inf. n. jafolN; (Mṣb;) and AjflwA↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) and AnjflwA↓ and tjf-lwA↓; (Mṣb;) they (a company of men) fled quickly; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or the second (Ḳ) and third (Ṣ, Ḳ) signify they became displaced, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and quickly defeated, (TA,) and went away; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) or these two and the fourth, (TA,) or all the four, (Ḥar p. 373,) they hastened in defeat and flight: (TA, and Ḥar ubi suprà:) and jafalati Alr-iyHu, (Ḳ,) and Ajflt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the wind was swift (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in blowing. (TA.)

jafala, inf. n. jufuwlN, ‡ It (hair) became shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in smell, in consequence of its being seldom dressed; or dusty and matted, by reason of its being seldom anointed; (Ḳ, TA;) and became raised and spread. (TA.)

jafala is also trans., signifying He made a bird to take fright, and fly away; or he scared it away: its quasi-pass. is Ajfl↓ [explained above]; the reverse of the rule commonly obtaining: (Mṣb:) or the former verb, as in the O; not the latter, as in the Ḳ; he made a male ostrich to hasten, or speed, in his pace, and to go away in the land, or country; or made him to spread his wings, and run quickly, or go away at random and swiftly: (TA:) and jf-l↓ he, or it, made an animal, or animals, to take fright, and flee, or run away at random; or scared away it, or them: (TA:) [and, app., he frightened; tajofiylN being also said in the TA to be syn. with taforiyEN, which, I think, is evidently a mistranscription for tafoziyEN.] You say, jf-l↓ Alqan-aASu AlwaHoXa [The sportsman scared away the wild animals]. (TA.) And Oatawohumo fajaf-aluwhumo↓ Eano maraAkizihimo [They came to them, and scared them, or frightened them, or made them to flee, away from their stations]. (TA.) And jafalati Alr-iyHu AlZ-aliyma The wind put in motion the male ostrich, and drove him away, or along: (Ḳ:) and [in like manner] Als-afiynapa [† the ship]. (TA.) And jafalati Alr-iyHu Als-aHaAba ‡ The wind smote the clouds, and put them into a state of commotion, (Ḳ, TA,) and made them to speed along. (TA.) And Alr-iyHu tajofilu AljahaAma † The wind carries away the rainless clouds. (Mgh. [See also 4.]) Whence, app., (Mgh,) jafala AlbaHoru samakFA † The sea cast fish upon the shore; (Lth, Mgh, Ḳ;) a verb like Daraba; occurring in a trad., in which it is erroneously said to be Oajofala. (Mgh.)

Also, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajofilu}, inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He prostrated a man; threw him down upon the ground. (Ḳ.) You say, TaEanahu fajafalahu, meaning He thrust him, or pierced him, [with a spear or the like,] and displaced and prostrated him. (Mgh.)
He threw goods one upon another. (IDrd, Mṣb, TA.)
He, or it, overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.)

Also, aor. _i {yajofilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped off, a thing; (AZ, Ḳ, TA;) as, for instance, flesh from the bone, and fat from the skin; (AZ, TA;) and so jf-l↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajofiylN: (TA:) he removed flesh from the bone: (Ḳ:) app. formed by transposition from jalafa. (TA.)

Also, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajofulu}, (Mṣb,) or _i, (Ḳ,) He swept away mud (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) from the ground; (TA;) and so jf-l↓. (Ḳ.) [It seems that Golius found, in a copy of the Ḳ, Alt-ibona erroneously put for AlT-iyna; and Haraqahu for jarafahu; for he has explained the former verb as meaning “combussit stramen.”]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in five places.
4: see 1, in six places.
You say also, Oajofalati Alr-iyHu biAlt-uraAbi † The wind carried away the dust; made it to fly away. (Ṣ.) And Ajfl Algayomu The clouds, or mist, became removed, or cleared off. (TA.)
5: see 1.
You say of a cock, tjf-l, meaning nafaXa buraAYilahu [i. e., † He ruffled the feathers around his neck]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA.)
7: see 1.
Anjfl also signifies ‡ It went away, or departed; said of the shade, (Ḳ, TA,) and of the night. (TA.)
He, or it, became overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.)
Anjflti AlX-ajarapu The tree, blown upon by a violent wind, became uprooted. (TA.)

hom.sense: Also A cloud that has poured forth its mater and gone away (Ṣ, Ḳ) quickly; (Ṣ;) because it is then lighter and quicker. (Ḥar p. 373.)
A ship; (Ḳ;) because the wind drives it along (tajofiluhaA): (TA:) pl. jufuwlN. (Ḳ.)
Ants: black ants: (Ḳ:) large black ants: (TA:) a dial. var. of javolN. (Ḳ.)
waqaEato fiI Aln-aAsi jafolapN [Fear fell upon the people;] the people feared. (TA.)
jafolapN XajarapN A leafy tree; a tree having many leaves. (Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: jufolapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jafolapN↓ (TA [there said in one place to be bAlftH, but this is most probably a mistranscription for bAlDm-,]) A fleece of wool: (Ṣ, Ḳ) [a word used in the sense of] a pass. part. n., like gurofap in the phrase Aigotarafa gurofapF. (Ṣ.)

daEawotuhumu AljafalaI, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) and AlOajofalaI↓, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) which latter was unknown to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) I invited them to my feast, or food, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) in common, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) without distinction, (Mṣb,) or with their company and commonalty. (Ḳ.) And duEiIa fulaAnN fiI Aln-aqaraI laA fiI AljafalaI, (Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb,*) and AlOajofalaI↓, Such a one was invited among the distinguished persons, not among the commonalty. (Akh, Ṣ.) And daEowapN jafalaI A general invitation; contr. of daEowapN naqaraI. (Mṣb.) And jaMCa Alqawomu OajofalapF↓, and OazofalapF, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) The people came in a company; (Fr, Ṣ;) and biOajofalatihimo↓, and Oazofalatihimo, with their company. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to some, (Ṣ,) OajofalaI↓ signifies A collection, or an assemblage, of any things; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OazofalaI: (Ṣ:) and juf-aAlapN↓, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, TA,) or jufaAlapN↓, (Ḳ,) a company, or an assembly, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) of men, (Ṣ, TA,) going along quickly. (TA.)
jafolaAnu, or jafolaAnN, [whether with or without tenween is not shown,] Fearful; wont, or apt, to take fright and flee, or run away at random. (TA.) [See also jaf-aAlN.]
jafaAlN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: jufaAlN What is cast forth by a torrent, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of rubbish and scum, or of rotten leaves mixed with scum; (TA;) as also jafaAlN↓, like saHaAbN; (TA;) and jufaAlapN↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)
The froth of milk. (Ḳ.)

Much (Ḳ) of anything: (TA:) or of wool; as also jafiylN↓: (Ḳ:) or much wool. (Ṣ.) The ewe is represented as saying, Ouwal-adu ruxaAlFA waOujaz-u jufaAlFA waOuHolabu kuvabFA viqaAlFA walamo tara mivoliI maAlFA [I am delivered of lambs, and I am shorn of much wool, and I am milked of heavy bowlfuls, and thou hast not seen cattle the like of me]: by Oujaz-u jufaAlFA is meant I am shorn [of much wool] at once; for nought of her wool falls to the ground until all of it is shorn. (Ṣ.) jfAl is applied, by Dhu-r-Rummeh, as an epithet to hair; [meaning Much, or abundant;] and it is not applied as an epithet to anything save what is much, or abundant. (Ṣ.) Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist] is described, in a trad., as jufaAlu AlX-aEari Having much hair: (TA:) and jaAfilu↓ Alr-aOosi [also] has this meaning. (Ḥam p. 469.)

entry.sense: jafuwlN A wind (riyH) that smites the clouds, and puts them into a state of commotion; (Ḳ;) or that makes them to speed along: (TA:) a swift wind; (TA;) as also jaAfilapN↓ and mujofilN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the first, (i. e., of jfwl,) jufolN. (Ḳ.)
Great, or large: so in the phrase jum-apN jafuwlN [A great, or large, quantity of hair extending beyond the ears]. (Ḳ.)
An aged woman; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also UijofiylN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former as above. (Ḳ.)
jafiylN: see jufaAlN.
jafaAlapN: see jafolN.
jufaAlapN: see AljafalaI:
and jufaAlN.
Also AljufaAlapu, (Ḳ,) or jufaAlapu Alqidori, (Ṣ,) What one takes from the head [of the contents] of the cookingpot with the ladle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jaf-aAlN an intensive epithet from jafala in the first of the senses explained above; i.e., A camel that takes fright, or shies, and flees,, &c., much, or often. (Mṣb.) [See also jafolaAnu.]
juf-aAlapN: see AljafalaI.
jaAfilN part. n. of jafala in the first of the senses explained above: (Mṣb:) [and in other senses.]
Hastening, or speeding. (TA.) See jafuwlN.
Disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also jufaAlN.
jayofalN a name of [The month] cuw AlqaEodapi, (Ḳ, TA,) in the time of paganism. (TA.)
OajofalapN: see AljafalaI, in two places.
OajofalaI: see AljafalaI, in three places.

UijofiylN Cowardly, or a coward, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that is frightened at everything. (TA.) A heostrich (Ṣ, Ḳ) that takes fright, (Ḳ,) and flees from everything (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) that he sees; (TA;) as also jafolN↓. (Ḳ.)
A bow of which the arrow goes far. (Ḳ.)
See also jafuwlN.
mujofilN Turning away, or going back, or retreating; going away. (TA.)
See also jafuwlN.

mijofalN applied to a camel's hump, Heavy: [properly, an instrument of overturning:] applied as an epithet to a camel's hump that is so heavy as to overturn the animal when, after rolling on the ground, he desires to rise. (TA.)
1. jafana naAqapF, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jafonN, (TA,) He slaughtered a she-camel, and gave her flesh for food (Ḳ, TA) to the people, (TA,) in bowls (jifaAn). (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 2. jf-nwA They made bowls (jifaAn [probably meaning they prepared bowls of food: accord. to Freytag's Lex., jf-n means “apposuit scutellam; but he does not name his authority]). (TA.)
jf-n and tjf-n↓ It (a grape-vine) attained to the state of having an OaSol [i. e., app., a stock]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 2.
jafonN The eyelid; both the upper and the lower: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) of the masc. gender: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaAnN and OajofunN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (Ḳ.)
The upper surface, and the lower, of a cake of bread: both together being called jafonaA Alr-agiyfi. (Lḥ, TA.)

The scabbard, or sheath, (gimod, Ṣ, Ḳ, or gilaAf, Mṣb,) of a sword: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or] the case, or receptacle, in which is [put] the sword together with its gmd and suspensory belt or cord: (Ṣ voce qiraAbN:) [but the former signification only is commonly known:] and [it is said that] jifonN↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ;) but this is doubted by IDrd: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaAnN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (Mṣb.)

The OaSol [app. here meaning stock] of a grape-vine: (Ḳ:) or a grape-vine itself, in the dial. of El-Yemen; (T, TA;) so called as being imagined to be the receptacle of the grapes: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a species of grape: (ISd, Ḳ:) or the skin of the grape, in which is the juice: (IAạr, TA:) or a climbing shoot of a grape-vine: (AḤn, TA:) or the shoots of the grape-vine: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {jafonapN}: (T Ṣ, M:) or, accord. to IAạr, jafonapN is syn. with krEp [app. a mistranscription for karomapN a single grape-vine]: or, accord. to some, as ISd says, the leaves of the grape-vine. (TA.) [Hence,] maMCu Aljafoni The juice of the vine; (A, TA;) wine: (TA:) [or it may originally mean tears; then, rain; and then, wine: for] wine is also called maMCu Als-aHaAbi: and jafonu AlmaMCi means the clouds. (TA.)
A kind of tree, of sweet odour. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
A certain plant, of the kind called OaHoraAr, that grows in a spreading manner, and, when it dries up, contracts; having grains like the Hulobap [or fenugreek]. (AḤn, TA.)
jifonN: see jafonN.

jafonapN A [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEap: (Ḳ:) or like a qSEp: (Ṣ:) the largest kind of qSEp; (Ks, Ṣ in art. SHf, M;)
next to which is the qSEp [properly so called], which satisfies the hunger of ten [men]; then, the SaHofap, which satisfies five; then, the miYokalap, which satisfies two men, and three; then, the SuHayofap, which satisfies one man: (Ks, Ṣ in art. SHf:) it is peculiarly applied to a receptacle for kinds of food: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jafaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jifanN (Sb, TA) and (of pauc., TA) jafanaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] kufiYato jafonatuhu [His bowl was turned upside-down; meaning] ‡ he was slain; a phrase similar to huriyqa rifoduhu. (A in art. rfd.)
† A small well; (Ḳ;) as being likened to the jfnp for food. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

‡ A generous man: (Ḳ:) jafonapN gar-aMCu is an appellation applied to a generous man who entertains many guests and feeds many: (IAạr, TA:) he is called jfnp because people are fed in the jfnp, and the epithet gr-MC is added because of the whiteness of the camel's hump in the jfnp. (TA.)
Also i. q. xamorapN [meaning Some wine, or a kind of wine: see also maMCu Aljafoni, voce jafonN]. (IAạr, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jafaA, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajofuwu}, (TA,) inf. n. jafaMCN; and tjAfI↓; It did not keep, or cleave, to its place. (Ḳ.) You say, jafaA janobuhu Eani AlfiraAXi, (Mgh,) and tjAfI↓ Eanohu, (Ṣ, Mgh,) His side did not rest, or was restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or shrank from it; (Ṣ, Mgh;) and heaved, or rose, from it: (Mgh:) or the former, his side did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon the bed: and the latter, it became withdrawn, or removed, from it. (TA.) And jafaA Als-aroju Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (Ṣ Mṣb, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (Mṣb;) and tjAfI↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) The saddle heaved, or rose, from the back of the horse: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon his back. (TA.)

[Hence,] it is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, Uin-iI Oajofuw Eano OaXoyaMCa mina AlEilomi Verily I recoil, shrink, or am averse, from some matters of knowledge, or science, and ignore them, or neglect them. (Mgh.)

Also jafaA, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) [and so the inf. n.,] said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was thick, coarse, or rough: (Mṣb, TA:) and in like manner said of a reed-pen, it was thick, coarse, or rough, in its nib. (TA.)

[And hence, (see jafaMCN, below, and jaAfK,) He was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make: and, more commonly, coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition, or in his intercourse and dealings with others; unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (See also 10.)] It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. [He who abides in the desert] becomes coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; [or unkind, hard, churlish,, &c.;] by reason of mixing little with men. (TA.)
jafaA Ealayohi kacaA Such a thing was, or became, heavy, onerous, burdensome, or oppressive, to him. (Ḳ.)
jafaA janobahu Eani AlfiraAXi: and jafaA Als-aroja: see 3.

jafati Alqidoru zabadahaA The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam; as also Ajft↓; (TA;) [like jafaOat and AjfOt;] originally without C. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And jafaA Als-ayolu The torrent drove away [things in its course]. (Mṣb.)

jafaA Alr-ajula, aor. as above, He turned away from the man; avoided him; or shunned him: or he drove away the man; from jfA Als-ayolu, explained above: sometimes meaning, with hatred. (Mṣb.) And jafaAhu He withdrew, or removed, far, or to a distance, from him: whence the saying of Moḥammad Ibn-Sookah, lam-aA qal-a maAliI jafaAniI UixowaAniI [When my property became little, my brethren withdrew far from me]. (TA)
And jafaA maAlahu He did not keep, or cleave, or hold fast, to his property. (Ḳ.)

And jafaAhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajofuwu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jafaMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jafowN, (Ḳ,) He treated him, or behaved towards him, coarsely, roughly, rudely, unkindly, hardly, churlishly, uncivilly, or surlily: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you should not say jafayotu. (Ṣ.) The pass. part. n. is majofuw-N↓ and majofiI-N↓: (Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. jfI:) the latter formed in accordance with jufiIa, in which the w is changed into I. (Fr, Ṣ.)

He did to him what displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; did to him what he disliked, or hated; did evil to him. (TA.) So in the trad., mano Haj-a walamo yazuroniI faqado jafaA [He who performs the pilgrimage to Mekkeh and does not visit me, i.e. does not visit my tomb afterwards, either on his homeward journey or by journeying to El-Medeeneh for that special purpose, does what displeases me]. (TA.)
jafati AlmaroOupu waladahaA The woman neglected to take care of her child, or to pay frequent attention to it. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. tajofiyapN [inf. n. of jf-I] signifies, in Persian, jfAC frmwdn [app. as meaning The ordering one to act, or to treat another, coarsely, roughly, rudely,, &c.]. (KL. [Accord. to Golius, as on this authority, “i. q. jafaA, sign. injuria affecit; duriter et inique tractavit: seu transit. ejus.”])

3. jAfI janobahu Eani AlfiraAXi, and jafaAhu↓, He caused his side not to rest, or caused it to be restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or caused it to shrink therefrom: and he heaved it, drew it up, or raised it, [making it to be separated by some space or interval] from the bed. (Mgh.) And hence, (Mgh,) jAfI EaDudayohi (Mgh, TA) Eano janobyohi (TA) He put, or set, his upper arms apart, or remote, from his sides. (Mgh, TA.) [Thus the Muslim is enjoined to do in prostrating himself in prayer.] And jAfI Als-aroja Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) and AjfAhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jafaAhu↓, (Ḳ, [said in the TA to be a mistake, but a similar usage of this verb has been mentioned above on the authority of the Mgh,]) He raised the saddle from the back of the horse: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner, Oajofayotu↓ Alqataba Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri [I raised the saddle from the back of the. camel]. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AjfAhu He made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof. (TA.)
See also 3, in two places.
AjfI AlmaAXiyapa He fatigued the cattle, [in some copies of the Ṣ, tabiEahaA is put for OatoEabahaA,] and did not let them eat, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) nor fed them previously, driving them vehemently. (TA.)
Oajofati Alqidoru: see 1.
Ojofati AlOaroDu The land became like the jufaMC, or rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, or by a cooking-pot, in respect of the departure of the good thereof. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAfI: see 1, in three places. [Said of a person prostrating himself, or lying down, it means He drew up his body from that on which he rested. And tjAfI Eanohu generally signifies He, or it, receded, withdrew, removed, or became remote or aloof or separated by some space or interval, from him, or it: and he drew away, shrank, or flinched, from him, or it.] It is said, of the difference between Alc-aboH and Alqatol, that the former is by cutting the external jugular veins; and the latter, biUiyqaAEi AlfiEili fiI AlmaHal-i maEa Alt-ajaAfiI [By causing the act to take effect upon the place thereof while standing aloof]; meaning that the qaAtil strikes from a distance, not knowing whether he will hit the place or not. (Mgh.) And [hence] you say, tjAfI lahu Eano Haq-ihi † [He relinquished, i. e.] he gave, to him, his right, or due. (TA in art. xmS.)
He inclined, or declined, or turned, from side to side: and from right to wrong. (Ḥar p. 125.) [See 6 in art. dfw.]
8. AjtfAhu He removed him, or it, from his, or its, place. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 10. AstjfAhu He esteemed it (namely, a bed, &c., Ḳ) jaAfK (Ṣ, Ḳ) i. e. thick, coarse, or rough. (TA.)
He demanded, or required, of him that he should do what was displeasing, grievous, vexatious, or evil. (TA.)
AstjfI He became coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (KL. [See also 1.])

entry.sense: jafFA: see jafaMCN.
jafowapN A single act of coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, treatment, or behaviour. (TA.)
See also jafaMCN, in three places.
jifowapN: see jafaMCN.

jafaMCN is in make; [signifying Thickness, grossness, coarseness, roughness, or rudeness:] and in nature, or disposition; (TA;) signifying coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in one's intercourse and dealings with others; (Mgh;) unkindness, hardness, churlishness, incivility, or surliness; a predominant quality of the people of the desert; (Mgh, Mṣb;) from jafaA said of a garment, or piece of cloth; (Mṣb;) contr. of bir-N (Ṣ,) or of SilapN; (Ḳ;) as also jafFA↓, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth; but Az says that he knew not any one who allowed this latter: (TA:) so, too, jifowapN↓ and jafowapN↓, in the sayings fiyhi jifowapN and jafowapN [In him is coarseness, roughness, or rudeness,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) and fulaAnN ZaAhiru Aljifowapi Such a one is a person in whom coarseness, roughness, or rudeness,, &c., is apparent: (Ṣ:) but accord. to Lth, jfwp [whether jafowapN or jafowapN is not shown] denotes a more constant quality than jafaMCN (TA.)
You say also, bihi jafowapN↓, meaning He is suffering coarseness, roughness, or rudeness,, &c. (Ḳ.) And OaSaAbatohu jafowapu↓ Alz-amani ‡ [The roughness, or rudeness,, &c., of time, or fortune, smote him]; and jafawaAtuhu [its roughnesses, or rudenesses,, &c.]. (TA.)
jufaMCN The rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, and by a cooking-pot. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See also art. jfO.]
And hence, as being likened to the jufaMC of the torrent, ‡ The first, or foremost, of men, or people. (TA.) [But see art. jfO.]
jaAfK [act. part. n. of 1:] applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and to a bed, &c., (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA,) Thick, coarse, or rough. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)

And [hence] applied to a man, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning Thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make; and coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, in his treatment of, or behaviour towards, his companions: pl. jufaApN. (TA.) You say also, rajulN jaAfiI Alxiloqapi [A man thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make]: and jaAfiI Alxuluqi niggardly and incompliant; coarse, rough, or rude, (Ḳ, TA,) in his intercourse and dealings with others; oppressive when angry and irritated against his companion with whom he sits. (TA.) And jaAfK Eani AlmawoEiZapi [Obdurate against admonition]. (TA in art. jEZr.)
majofuw-N: see 1.
majofiI-N: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. jal--a, aor. yajil-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jalaAlapN, (Ṣ,) or jalaAlN, (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, julAlFA is put for jalaAlFA,]) or both, (TA, [but see what follows,]) and jul-aI, (Ḥam p. 218, see this word below, under jalalN,) [in its primary sense, It was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky: (see jaliylN:) and then,] it, (a thing, Mṣb,) or he (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, great; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [said of a thing, meaning in size; and] said of a man, meaning in estimation, rank, or dignity: (Ṣ, TA:) or jalaAlapN signifies greatness of estimation or rank or dignity: but jalaAlN, supreme greatness thereof: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the latter is an attribute of God only; (As in Ḥam p. 607, Er-Rághib, TA;) except in few instances: (As ubi suprà:) or it means the greatness, or majesty, of God: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or his absolute independence. (Bḍ in lv. 27.) [Eaz-a wajal-a, referring to the name of God expressed or understood, is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning, To Him, or to Whom, belong might and majesty, or glory and greatness]

yajilPu Eani AlUiHaATapi bihi [He is too great to be comprehended within limits] and yajil-u Oano yudoraka biAlHawaAs-i [He is too great to be perceived by the senses] are phrases used in speaking of God. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

The saying of El-Aḥmar,
yaA jal-a maA baEudato Ealayoka bilaAdunaA
faQboruqo biOaroDika maA badaA laka waQroEudi
[O, how greatly distant to thee is our country! therefore threaten in thy land as long as it seems fit to thee, and menace], means maA Oajal-a↓ mA bEdt [&c.]. (Ṣ.)

Also jal-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajolilu}, inf. n. jalaAlapN and jalaAlN, (Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) He became old, or advanced in age, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and firm, or sound, in judgment. (Ḳ.) And jal-ato said of a she-camel, She was, or became, old, or advanced in age: (Abu-n-Naṣr, Ṣ:) and so tjAl-t↓ said of a woman. (TA.)

jal-ati AlhaAjinu Eani Alawladi [The girl married before she had arrived at puberty, or the beast covered before she was of fit age,] was too young [to bear offspring]: (Ṣ:) a prov. (TA.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. See also haAjinN.]

jal-a Alqawomu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) Eani Albaladi, (Ṣ,) or Eano manaAzilihimo, (Ḳ,)) aor. _i {yajolilu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or _u [contr. to rule], (Ṣ, Ṣgh,) or both, accord. to Ibn-Málik and others, (TA,) inf. n. juluwlN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and jalaMCN accord. to the Ḳ, but this is an inf. n. of jalaA], The people, or company of men, went forth, or emigrated, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like jalaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from a country, or town, (Mṣb,) [or from their places of abode,] to another country, or town. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
jal-uwA AlOaqiTa, (Ḳ,) [aor., accord. to rule, _u,] inf. n. jal-N, (TA,) They took the main part, or portion, of the [preparation of milk termed] AqT. (Ḳ.) [See also 5.]
jalalota hecaA EalaI nafosika Thou hast brought this as an injury (janayotahu) upon thyself. (Ḳ.)

jal-a AlbaEara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajolulu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jal-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jal-apN, (Ḳ,) He picked up, (Ṣ,) or collected with his hand, (Ḳ,) the camels', or similar, dung; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Ajtl-pu↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ,) or he picked it up for fuel. (Ḳ.) [See jal-apN.]
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. jl-l, inf. n. tajoliylN, said of a thing, i. q. Eam-a [as meaning It included persons, or things, &c., in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of its influence, or effects]. (Ṣ, TA.)
