So in the phrase saHaAbN yujal-ilu AlOaroDa biAlmaTari [Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal, extent]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as in the A, thundering clouds, covering the land with rain. (TA.) And so in the phrase, jal-ala AlmaTaru AlOaroDa The rain included the general, or universal, extent of the land within the compass of its fall; and covered the land so as not to leave anything uncovered. (IF, Mṣb.)
And hence, [in a general sense,] He covered a thing. (Mṣb.) It [or he] ascended, rose, mounted, got, was, or became, upon, or over, a thing; (Ḥam p. 45;) as also tajl-l↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He clad a horse (Ṣ, Ḳ) or beast (Ḳ) with a jul- [or covering for protection from the cold]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jal-a↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajl-hu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijolaAlN, (TA,) [He made it jaliyl, i. e., thick,, &c.: contr. of Oadaq-ahu: see Ḥam p. 546.]

[And hence,] He magnified him; honoured him; (Ḳ, TA;) as also tjAl-hu↓: (TA:) he exalted him (TA) in rank, or station. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad., Oajil-uwA Qll-eha yagofiro lakumo, meaning [Magnify ye God, and He will forgive you: or] say ye, yaA caA AljalaAli waAlUikoraAmi [O Thou who art possessed of greatness, or majesty, and bounty], and believe in his greatness, or majesty: it is also recited otherwise, with H; (TA in the present art.;) i. e. OaHil-uwA Qll-eha, meaning “Resign yourselves to God;” or “quit ye the danger and straitness of belief in a plurality of Gods, to avail yourselves of the freedom of El-Islám;” (TA in art. Hl;) but the former recital is confirmed by another trad., namely, OaliZ-uwA biyaAcaA AljalaAli waAlUikoraAmi [see art. lZ]. (TA in the present art.) [Hence,] faEalotu mino UijolaAlika, and mn Oajoli UijolaAlika: see jalalN.

He gave him much. (Ṣ.) You say, maA Oajal-aniI walaA Oadaq-aniI (Ṣ, TA) He gave me not much, nor gave he me little: (Ṣ:) or † he gave me not a camel, nor gave he me a sheep, or goat. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Marrár El-Fak'asee, describing his eye, (TA,)
bakato faOadaq-ato fiI AlbukaI waOajal-ati
† It wept, and shed few tears, and shed many. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, Oajal-a farasahu firoqFA mino curapK He gave his horse a large feed of millet. (TA.)

He gave him a jaliylap, i. e., a she-camel that had brought forth once. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, maA Oajal-aniI walaA OaHoXaAniI He gave me not a she-camel that had brought forth once, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) nor gave he me a young, or small, camel. (Ṣ.)
maA Oajal-a: see 1. [You say, maA Oajal-ahu How great,, &c., is he, or it!]
Ajl- He was, or became, strong:
and He was, or became, weak: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tjl-lhu He took the greater, main, principal, or chief, part of it; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Ajtl-hu↓ (Ḳ) and tjAl-hu↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ. [In the CK, in the explanation of the second and third of these verbs, jilaAlahu is erroneously put for julaAlahu.])
See also 2.
[Hence,] He sat upon him; namely, a horse. (Ḳ,) And tjl-l AlfaHolu Aln-aAqapa (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dOm) The stallion-camel mounted the she-camel. (TA in that art.)

hom.sense: 6. tjAl- i. q. taEaAZama (Ṣ, Ḳ) and taraf-aEa. (Ṣ.) You say, fulaAnN yatajaAl-u Eano celka (Ṣ, Ḳ *) Such a one exalts himself above that; holds himself above it; disdains it; or is disdainful of it; syn. yataraf-aEu Eanohu, (Ṣ,) or yataEaAZamu; (Ḳ;) as also ytjAl- Ealayohi. (TA.)
See also 1.
tjAl-hu: see 4:
and 5.
8: see 5:
and see also 1.

R. Q. 1. jalojala [app. It sounded; or made a sound, or sounds; said of a little bell, such as is called julojul: said also of thunder: and it sounded vehemently; or made a vehement sound, or vehement sounds: and he threatened: (see jalojalapN, which seems to be the inf. n. of the verb in these senses:) and,] said of a horse, he neighed clearly; or had a clear neigh. (Ḳ.)

jalojalahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jalojalapN, (Ḳ,) He put it (a thing, Ṣ) in motion (Ṣ, Ḳ) with his hand. (Ṣ.) And jljl AlqidaAHa He (a player at the game called Almayosir) moved about [or shuffled] the gaming-arrows. (TA.)
He mixed it. (Ḳ.)
He twisted it vehemently, or strongly; namely, the string of a bow or the like. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tajalojala It was, or became, in a state of motion; or was put in motion. (Ḳ.)
It was, or became, agitated in the mind. (Ḳ,* TA.)

He sank into the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEa. (Ḳ.) One says, tajalojalato qawaAEidu Albayoti The foundations of the house sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEato. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jal-N The sail of a ship: pl. juluwl-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jul-N, in two places:
and jil-N:
and jaliylN.
Also Contemptible, mean, or paltry: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)

jul-N The greater, main, principal, or chief, part of a thing; the most thereof; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also julaAlN↓. (Ḳ.) You say, Oaxaca jul-ahu (Ḳ, TA) and julaAlahu↓ (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ) [He took the greater part of it].

A horse-cloth, or covering (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a horse or similar beast, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for protection (Mṣb, Ḳ) from the cold; (Mṣb;) as also jal-N↓: (Ḳ:) [in Persian jalo:] pl. [of mult.] jilaAlN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajolaAlN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Oajil-apN is pl. of jilaAlN. (Ṣ, TA.)
The cover of, or a thing with which one covers, a book, or volume; which latter is hence called majal-apN↓. (Er-Rághib in TA; but, in this sense, written without any vowel-sign.)
The place of the pitching and constructing of a tent or house. (Ḳ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jal-N↓, (Ḳ,) The rose, (AḤn, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the white and the red and the yellow; (AḤn, Ḳ;) plentiful in the countries of the Arabs, both cultivated and wild: (AḤn, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (AḤn,* Ṣ, Ṣgh;) from kulo: (Ṣgh, TA:) and the jasmine: n. un. with p {jul-apN}. (Ḳ.)
See also jil-N:
and jalalN.
jil-N: see jaliylN, in six places

Also The stalks of seed-produce [or corn] when it has been reaped; (Ṣ, O, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also jul-N↓ and jal-N↓: (Ḳ:) when it has been removed to the place where the grain is trodden out, and has been trodden, and cut by means of the midowas, it is called tibonN. (AḤn, Mgh.) And, by amplification, applied to The stalks remaining upon the field after the reaping. (Mgh in the present art. and in art. HSd.)

entry.sense: jal-apN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jil-apN↓ and jul-apN↓, (Ḳ,) the second whereof is that which is most known [in the present day], and next the first [which seems to be the most chaste], (TA,) Camels', or sheep's, or goats', or similar, dung; syn. baEarN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a single lump thereof: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or such as has not been broken. (Ḳ.) [Commonly applied in the present day to Such dung kneaded with chopped straw and formed into round flat cakes, which are dried in the sun, for fuel.] You say, Uin-a baniI fulaAnK waquwduhumu Aljal-apu [Verily the sons of such a one, their fuel is the dung of camels or sheep, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
Also (metonymically, Mgh) applied to Human ordure. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: See also jal-ahN.
jil-apN: see jal-apN:
and jaliylN; of which it is in most instances a pl.

jalalN A great, momentous, or formidable, thing, affair, matter, case, or event; as also jul-aI↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and jul-aMCu↓: (TA:) or julaI↓ [as also jalalN and jul-aMCu↓] signifies a hard, difficult, severe, or distressing, and a great, momentous, or formidable, thing, or affair,, &c.: (Mṣb:) pl. [of jalalN,] OajolaAlN; (TA;) and of julalN jul-aI↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ.) El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh says,
qawomiI humu qataluwA Oumayoma OaxiI
faUicaA ramayotu yuSiybuniI sahomiI
falaYino Eafawotu laOaEofuwano jalalFA
walaYino saTwotu laOuwohinano EaZomiI
[My people, they have slain, O Umeymeh, (Oumayoma being apocopated, for Oumayomapu,) my brother; so, if I shoot, my arrow will strike me; and verily, if I forgive, I shall indeed forgive a great thing; but verily, if I assault, I shall indeed weaken my bone: see Ḥam p. 97]. (Ṣ.) And Beshámeh Ibn-Hazn says,
waUino daEawota UilaI jul-aI↓ wamakorumapF
yawomFA saraApF kiraAma Aln-aAsi faQdoEiynaA
[And if thou invite to a great affair, and a generous act, any day, manly and noble persons, the generous of mankind, invite us]: (TA:) or jul-aI is here an inf. n. in the place of jalaAlN and jalaAlapN, like rujoEaI, &c. (Ḥam p. 218.)

Also, i. e., jalalN, A small, (Ḳ,) an easy, or a mean, paltry, or contemptible, thing, affair, matter, case, or event: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says, on the occasion of his father's having been slain,
biqatoli baniI OasadK rab-ahumN
OalaA kul-u XaIoCK siwaAhu jalalo
meaning [By Benoo-Asad's slaying their lord: now surely everything beside it is] a mean, paltry, or small, matter. (Ṣ,* TA.)

faEalotu celika mino jalalika I did that on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino Oajolika; (Ṣ, Ḳ *) as also mn jul-ika↓, (Ḳ,) and mn jalaAlika↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mn tajil-atika↓, and mn UijolaAlika↓, and mn Oajoli UijolaAlika↓. (Ḳ.) Jemeel says,
rasomu daArK waqafotu fiI Talaliho
kidotu OaqoDiI AlgidApa mino jalalipo
meaning [The remains marking the site of a house, I paused at the relic thereof that was still standing: I almost died, in the early morning,] on account of it (mino Oajolihi), or, as some say, because of its greatness in my eye. (Ṣ.)
Accord. to Zj, jalalo is a particle syn. with naEamo. (Mughnee.)

entry.sense: jalaAlN an inf. n. of jal-a. (Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence,] faEalotu celika mino jalaAlika: see jalalN.
julaAlN: see jul-N, in two places:
also, and its fem. with p {julaAlapN}, see jaliylN, in three places:
and see julaAjilN.
jilaAlN The deck, or part resembling a roof, of a ship: a sing. word. (Mgh.)
[See jul-N and jul-apN, of each of which it is a pl.]

hom.sense: jaliylN, in its primary acceptation, signifies Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky; applied to a material substance; (Er-Rághib, TA;) opposed to daqiyqN; (Ṣ, Er-Rághib, TA;) as also jil-N↓, (Ṣ,) opposed to diq-N: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and then,] great; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jil-N↓ and jal-N↓ (Ḳ) and julaAlN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is also explained as signifying large, big, bulky, or large in body, (Ḳ,) and jul-aAlN↓: fem. jaliylapN and julaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) [also] great in respect of estimation, rank, or dignity: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] Oajil-apN and jil-apN and [of mult.] Oajil-aMCu. (TA.) You say, maA lahu diq-N YalaA jil-N↓, i. e., daqiyqN walaA jaliylN [He has neither slender, or fine, or small, nor thick, or gross, or coarse,, &c., or great]. (Ṣ.) And XajarN jil-N↓ [Large trees; or trees as] opposed to XajarN diq-N [or shrubs, or bushes]. (Lth, Mgh in art. bql.) And Hulalu jil-K↓ Thick, or coarse, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu diq-N: (Mgh in art. dq:) or the things termed jil-N, of commodities, are carpets, and [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC], and the like; (Ḳ;) contr. of diq-N; such as the [cloth called] Hilos, and the mat, and the like. (TA.) And julaAlapN↓ signifies A great she-camel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) big-bodied. (TA.) You say also, TaHatapu TaHonFA jaliylFA [He ground it coarsely]. (Ṣ in art. jX.) Aljaliylu, meaning The great in dignity, is not applied peculiarly to God: when it is applied to Him, it is because of his creating the great things that are indicative of Him, or because He is too great to be comprehended within limits or to be perceived by the senses. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And qawomN jil-apN means A great people; lords, chiefs, or people of rank or quality; (Ḳ;) a good people; (TA;) a people of eminence, nobility, dignity, or high rank. (Ḳ.)

Also Old, or advanced in age, and firm, or sound, in judgment:
pl. jil-apN: (Ḳ:) which pl., as meaning old, or advanced in age, is applied to camels, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) as well as to men. (Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., faQEotaraDa lahumo Uiboliysu fiI Suwarpi XayoxK jaliylK [And Iblees presented himself to them in the form of an old man advanced in age]. (TA.) jil-apN↓ in the sense last explained above, is also used as a sing., and is applied to the male and the female [of camels]: or signifies such as is termed vaniy-ap, [i. e., a she-camel that has entered her sixth year,] until she has become a baAzil [in her ninth year]: or a male camel that has become a vaniI-: or it is applied to a she-camel, and jil-N↓ to a he-camel. (Ḳ.) And [the fem.] jaliylapN↓ [used as a subst.] signifies A she-camel that has brought forth once: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and [simply] a she-camel; as in the saying, maA lahu jaliylapN walaA daqiyqapN He has neither a she-camel nor a ewe, or she-goat: (Ṣ:) or camels. (JK and TA in art. dq [q. v., voce daqiyqN].) Also (i. e. jlylp↓) A great palm-tree having much fruit: pl. jaliylN; (Ḳ;) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, the pl. is jilaAlN. (TA.)

Also i. q. vumaAmN [Panicum, or panic grass]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a weak plant, with which the interstices of houses are stopped up: n. un. with p {jaliylapN}: (Ṣ:) or jaliylapN↓ signifies a species of vumaAm: (TA in art. vm:) pl. jalaAYilu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaliylapN [used as a subst.]: see the latter part of the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
jul-aI: see jalalN, in four places.
jul-aMCu: see jalalN, in two places.
jul-iI-N a rel. n. from jul; A seller of jilaAl [pl. of jul-N] for horses or similar beasts. (TA.)
jul-alN: see jaliylN

jal-aAlapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaAl-apN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb) A cow that repeatedly seeks after filths [to eat them]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the milk of which is forbidden: (Ṣ:) a beast that eats jal-ap, meaning human ordure; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) the flesh of which is forbidden: (Mgh:) pl. [of the former] jal-aAlaAtN; (Mṣb) and of the latter jawaAl-u; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the latter pl. occurring in a trad., in which some erroneously substitute for it jaw-aAlaAt. (Mgh.)

julojulN [A little bell, consisting of a hollow ball of copper or brass or other metal, perforated, and containing a loose solid ball;] a small jaras [or bell]; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) a thing that is hung to the neck of a horse or similar beast, or to the leg of a hawk: (Mgh:) pl. jalaAjilu. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) You say, fulaAnN yuEal-iqu Aljulojula fiI Eunuqihi [Such a one hangs the little bell upon his neck;] meaning, ‡ such a one imperils, or endangers, himself. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
Uil-aA QmoraON yaEoqidu xayoTa Aljulojuli
[Except a man who ties the string of the little bell;] meaning, ‡ except a bold man, who imperils himself: AA says that it is a prov., meaning, except a man who makes himself notorious, so that no one precedes him except a courageous man who cares not for him, and who is stubborn and notorious. (TA.)
See also julaAjilN.

jalojalapN [app. inf. n. of jalojala, q. v.;] The sound, or sounding, of a julojul, (Ṣ,) or of a jaras [or bell]; (TA;) and of thunder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and vehemence of sound: and a threatening (Ḳ, TA) from behind a thing covering or concealing. (TA.)

hom.sense: julojulaAnN What is jaliyl [app. meaning great in estimation] of a thing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

Also The fruit of the kuzoburap [or coriander]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) and, (Mgh,) accord, to Abu-1-Ghowth, (Ṣ,) sesame, or sesamum, (Ṣ, Z, Mgh, TA,) in its husks, before it is reaped: (Ṣ:) or it signifies also the grain of sesame or sesamum. (Ḳ.)

‡ The heart's core (Hab-apu Alqalobi). (Ṣ, Z, Ḳ, TA.) You say, OaSabotu julojulaAna qalbihi ‡ [I hit his heart's core]. (Ṣ.) And Aisotaqar-a celika fiI julojulaAna qalobihi ‡ [That rested, or remained, in his heart's core]. (Z, TA.) And kalaAmN xaraja mino julojulaAni Alqalobi UilaI qimaEi AlOucuni ‡ [Speech that came forth from the core of the heart to the meatus of the ear]. (Z, TA.)

entry.sense: jalojaAlN: see mujalojilN

hom.sense: julaAjilN An ass that brays clearly; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also julaAlN↓ ; (El-Moḥeeṭ, Ḳ) which is in like manner applied to a she-camel. (El-Moḥeeṭ, TA.)
A boy light in spirit; brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his work; (Ḳ;) as also julojulN↓ (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Oabovavotuhu julaAjila nafosiI I revealed to him what was agitated in my mind. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,* TA.)

jaAl-N Going forth, or emigrating, from a country, or town, to another country, or town; (Mṣb;) [as also jaAlK; (see art. jlw;)] and so jaAl-apN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) its pl., (Mṣb,) applied to a people, or company of men; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) originally applied to the Jews who were expelled from El-Ḥijáz; as also jaAliyapN. (Mṣb.)

Hence, jaAl-apN↓, as a subst., meaning The poll-tax; (Mṣb;) as also jaAliyapN, (Ṣ and Mṣb in art jlw.) You say, AusotuEomila ifulaAnN EalaI AljaAl-ap [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]; like as you say, ElI AljaAliyapi. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
jaAl-apN as a fem. epithet used as a subst.: see jal-aAlapN.

entry.sense: jaAl-apN (as a subst.): see jaAl-N; of which it is also pl. and fem.

Oajal-u [Thicker, &c., and thickest, &c.; see jaliylN: and] i. q. OaEoZamu [more, and most, great, &c.]: (Ṣ, TA:) fem. jul-aI. (Ḥam. p. 45.) With the article, [as a superlative epithet,] it is applied to God; (Ṣ, TA;) and so, by poetic license, AlOajolalu. (TA.)
tajil-apN a subst. [signifying The act of magnifying, or honouring]; (Ḳ, TA;) like takorimapN. (TA.)
[Hence,] faEalotu celika mino tajil-atika, like mn UijolaAlika, &c.: see jalalN

majal-apN A SaHiyfap [or book, volume, writing, or written paper or the like;] in which is science: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and any book, or writing, (A' Obeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) is thus called by the Arabs; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) as, for instance, that of Lukmán, and one of poetry: (TA:) and so in the phrase used by En-Nábighah (Edh-Dhubyánee, TA) majal-atuhumo caAtu AlUilehi [Their book is that of God]: or, as some recite it, he said maHal-atuhumo, with HAC, meaning, their abode is one of pilgrimage and of sacred sites. (Ṣ, TA.) See jul-N
[Hence,] Science; and the doctrine, or science, of practical law. (AA, TA.)
mujal-alN A horse clad with a jul-; as also majoluwlN↓; (TA;) which latter is likewise applied to a camel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

saHaAbN mujal-ilN Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal extent: (Ṣ, TA:) or thundering clouds, covering the land with rain: (A, TA:) or clouds in which are thunder and lightning. (Aṣ, TA in art. qSb.) [See also mujalojilN.]

hom.sense: majoluwlN: see mujal-alN.
Also Water into which jal-ap [q. v.] has fallen. (TA.)
mujalojalN A man very excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, or the like; in whom is no fault, or vice. (Ḳ.)
A camel that has attained his full strength. (Ḳ, TA.)
UibilN mujalojalapN Camels having small bells, of the kind called julojulo, hung upon them. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mujalojilN Clouds (saHaAbN) in which is the sound of thunder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:* [in the CK, in this instance, erroneously written mujalojalN:]) or sounding: (TA:) [see also mujal-ilN:] and in like manner jalojaAlN↓ applied to rain. (Ḳ, TA.)

A strong chief: or [in the CK, “and,”] one whose voice, or fame, (Sawot,) reaches far: and bold, vehement in repelling or defending, eloquent, or able in speech, (Ḳ,) who subjects himself to peril, or danger. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. jalaba, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajolibu} and _u {yajolubu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jalobN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jalabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He drove, (A, Ḳ,) or brought, conveyed, or transported, (Mgh,) a thing, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or things, such as camels, sheep, goats, horses, captives, or slaves, or any merchandise, (TA,) from one place to another, (A, Ḳ,) or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as also Ajtlb↓, (A, Ḳ, KL,) and Astjlb↓. (KL.) And jalabotu AlX-aIoCa UilaI nafosiI and Aijotalabotuhu↓ signify the same; (Ṣ;) i. e. † I brought, drew, attracted, or procured, the thing to myself. (PṢ.) [Hence,] caA mim-aA yajolibu AlUixowaAna ‡ [This is of the things that bring, draw, attract, or procure, brothers, or friends]. (A, TA.) And jalabatuhu jawaAlibu↓ Ald-ahori ‡ [The calamities of time, or of fortune, or of fate, brought, drew, or attracted, him, or it]. (A, TA.)
[Hence also, accord. to some,] laA jalaba walaA janaba, a trad., explained as meaning, The owner of cattle shall not be required to drive them, or bring them, to the town, or country, in order that the collector may take from them the portion appointed for the poor-rate, but this shall be taken at the waters; and when the cattle are in the yards, they shall be left therein, and not brought forth to the place of pasture, for the collector to take that portion: or, as some say, wlA jnb means, nor shall one have a horse led by his side, in a race, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may tranfser himself to it, and so outstrip his fellow: and other explanations have been given: (Mṣb:) [accord. to some,] lA jlb here means, they shall not drive, or bring, their cattle to the collector of the portions appointed for the poor-rate in the place where he alights, but he shall himself come to their yards and take those portions: or [jlb here is from the verb jalaba in a sense which will be explained below, and] the trad. relates to horse-racing, and means, one shall not cause his horse to be followed by a man crying out at it and chiding it; nor shall he have a horse without a rider led by his own horse, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may transfer himself to it, and outstrip upon it: (Mgh:) or Aljalabu, which is forbidden, means the collector's not coming to the people at their waters to take the portions appointed for the poor-rate, but ordering them to drive, or bring, their cattle to him: or it relates to contending for a stake, or wager, and means the mounting a man upon one's horse, and, when he has drawn near to the goal, following his horse and crying out at it, in order that it may outstrip; which is a kind of fraud: (Ṣ:) or it is used in both these cases: (AʼObeyd: [his explanations are virtually the same as those in the Ṣ:]) or the meaning of the trad. [so far as the former clause of it is concerned] is, that the contributions to the poor-rate shall not be driven, or brought, to the waters nor to the great towns, but shall be given in their places of pasture: or it means, [or rather Aljlb means,] the collector's alighting in a place, and then sending a person, or persons, to drive, or bring, to him the cattle from their places, that he may take the portion thereof appointed for the poor-rate: or it [relates to horse-racing, and] means the sending forth a horse in the racecourse, and a number of persons' congregating, and crying out at it, in order that it may be turned from its course: or a man's following his horse, and spurring on behind it, and chiding it, and crying out at it: (Ḳ, TA:) or the shaking a thing behind a horse that is backward in a race, that it may be urged on thereby, and outstrip: or one's riding a horse, and leading behind him another, to urge it on, in contending for a stake, or wager: or the crying out at a horse from behind, and urging it to outstrip. (TA. See also 1 in art. jnb.)

jalabuwA, aor. _i {yajolibu} and _u {yajolubu}, (Ḳ,) [inf. n. jalabN, and perhaps jalabapN also;] and jl-bwA↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AjlbwA↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UijolaAbN; (Mgh;) [the second of which is the most common;] They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) or confused cries or shouts or noises. (Mgh, Ḳ.*) And jalaba EalaI farasihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajolubu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. jalabN, (Ṣ,) or jalobN, (Mṣb,) He chid, or urged on, his horse; as also jl-b↓ and Ajlb↓; (Ḳ;) the first, rare; the second and third, usual: (TA:) he cried out at his horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from behind him, and urged him to outstrip [in a race], (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yajolubu} and _i {yajolibu}; (Ḳ; but this explanation is erased in the copy of the Ḳ in its author's handwriting, as being a repetition; and rightly, accord. to MF; though this requires consideration; TA;) as also Ajlb↓: (Ṣ:) he urged his horse to run, by striking, or goading, or by crying out, or the like; as also Ajlb↓: or, as some say, he led behind his horse that he was riding another horse to urge on the former, in contending [in a race] for a stake, or wager; as is shown in an explanation of the tradition cited above, laA jalaba walaA janaba. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xvii. 66], waOajolibo↓ Ealayohimo bixayolika warajolika And raise thou confused cries against them, (Mgh,) or cry out against them, with thy forces riding and on foot. (Bḍ. But see another explanation in what follows.) And it is said in a wellknown prov., jalabato jalobapF vum-a Oamosakato It, i. e. a cloud (saHaAbap), thundered, then refrained from raining: applied to a coward, who threatens, and then is silent: but accord. to some, it is with H in the place of j (MF. See art. Hlb.)

[Hence,] jalaba, aor. _i {yajolibu} and _u {yajolubu} and Ajlb↓; He threatened with evil; (Ḳ, TA;) followed by an accus. (TA) [or, app., by EalaI before the object]: or (so in the TA, but in some copies of the Ḳ “and,”) he collected a company, a troop, or an army. (Ḳ, TA.) [It is said that] waOajolibo↓ Ealayohimo, in the Ḳur [xvii. 66], means And collect thou against them [thy forces], and threaten them with evil. (TA. But see another explanation above.) And Ajlbw↓ Ealayohi signifies also They collected themselves together against him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and aided one another; like AHlbwA. (Ṣ.)
jalaba Ealayohi, aor. _u {yajolubu}, inf. n. jalobN, He committed a crime against him; or an offence for which he should be punished. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jalaba, aor. _i {yajolibu} and _u {yajolubu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (a wound) healed: (Ḳ:) or it (an ulcer, Aṣ, or a wound, Ṣ) became covered with a skin in healing: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) as also Ajlb↓. (Ṣ, L.)
And It (blood) dried; became dry; as also Ajlb↓. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
jaliba, aor. _a {yajolabu}, It [app. a company or troop] assembled, or became collected together. (Ḳ.)
2: see 1, in two places.
The inf. n. tajoliybN also signifies The act of bringing together: or collecting. (KL.)

entry.sense: [3. jAlb is explained by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, as meaning He helped, or assisted: but this is a mistake for HAlb; for I find muHaAlabapN explained by yArI krdn in a copy of the KL, and the order of the words there shows that it is not a mistranscriptiou for mjAlbp.]

hom.sense: 4. Ajlb: see 1, in eleven places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Also His camels brought forth males; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because the males that they produce are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; opposed to AHlb “his camels brought forth females:” (Ṣ:) and his camel brought forth a male. (TA.) Oajolabota walaA OaHolabota May thy camels bring forth males, and may they not bring forth females, is a form of imprecation against a man, implying a wish that he may lose the milk [that he would have otherwise]. (TA.)
He aided, helped, or assisted, another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [So, too, AHlb.]
He put an amulet into a julobap [which must therefore signify the piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed, as well as an amulet enclosed in a piece of skin: see mujolibN]. (Ḳ.)

Ajlb qatabahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijolAbN, (T,) He covered his qtb [or camel's saddle] (Ṣ, Ḳ) with a julobap, i. e., (Ṣ,) with a piece of fresh, moist skin, which he left upon it until it became dry [and tight]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or he covered the head of his qtb with a piece of kid's, or lamb's, skin, and left it to dry upon it. (T.)

entry.sense: [5. tjl-b rendered by Golius Clamorem ac murmur excitavit, as on the authority of the Ḳ, I do not find in that lexicon nor in any other.]

7. Anjlb It [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels, &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] was driven [or brought] from one place to another [or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic]. (Ḳ.)
8. Ajtlb: see 1, first and second sentences.
Also † He (a poet) took, or borrowed, from the poetry of another. (TA.)
And He sought or demanded [a thing]. (Ḥar p. 44.)

10. Astjlbhu He sought, or demanded, or desired, that it [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels, &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] should be driven [or brought] from one place to another [in which he was, or from one country or town to another, for sale]. (Ḳ.)
See also 1, first sentence.

R. Q. 1. jalobabahu, (Ḳ,) or jlbbhu jilobaAbFA, (TA,) inf. n. jalobabapN, the second b not being incorporated into the first because the word is quasi-coordinate to the class of daHorajapN, (Ṣ,) He put on him a garment of the kind called jilobaAb. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to Kh, the first b in jlbb is [augmentative] like the w in jahowara and dahowara: accord. to Yoo, the second is [augmentative] like the I in saloqaI and jaEobaI. (IJ, TA.)

R. Q. 2. tajalobaba, (Ḳ,) and tajalobabato, (A, Mṣb,) He, and she, put on a garment of the kind called jilobaAb; or clad himself, and herself, therewith. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And tjlbb bivawobaha He covered himself with his garment. (Ḥar p. 162.)
julobN: see jilobN
Also The blackness of night; (Ḳ, TA;) and so jilobaAbN↓. (Ḥar p. 480. [The latter evidently tropical in this sense, and perhaps the former also.])

hom.sense:
jilobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and julobN↓ (Ṣ, L) A camel's saddle of the kind called raHol,
with what it contains, or comprises: (Ḳ:) or its cover: (Th, Ḳ:) or its pieces of wood: (Ṣ:) or its curved pieces of wood: (TA:) or its wood, without [the thongs called] OanosaAE and other apparatus. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also, both words, Clouds, (Ḳ,) or thin clouds, (Ṣ,) in which is no water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or clouds appearing, or extending sideways, (muEotariDN,) [in the horizon,] like a mountain [or mountainrange]: (Ḳ, TA:) or a cloud like that which is termed EaAriDN [q. v.], but narrower, and more distant, and inclining to blackness: (AZ, TA in art. ErD:) pl. OajolaAbN. (TA.) [See also julobapN.]

jalabN A thing, or things, driven, or brought, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from one country or town to another, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or from one place to another, (A, Ḳ,) for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as horses, &c., (Ḳ,) camels, (TA,) sheep or goats, captives or slaves, (Lth, TA,) or any merchandise: (TA:) and so jalabapN↓, thus in the handwriting of the author of the Ḳ in his last copy of that work, and mentioned by more than one, (MF, [who adds that it is correct, but SM thinks it a mistake,]) and jaliybapN↓ and juluwbapN↓: (Ḳ:) [see this last, below:] pl. [of the first] OajolaAbN. (Ḳ.) Hence the prov., Aln-ufaADu yuqaT-iru Aljalaba The failure of provisions causes the camels, driven, or brought, from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale. (TA.)
[And, app., Male camels; like jaluwbapN; because they are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; (see 4;) opposed to HalabN, q. v.]

Also Persons who drive, or bring, camels and sheep or goats [&c.] from one place or country or town to another, for sale; and so [its pl.] OajolaAbN. (Ṣ.) [In the present day, jal-aAbN↓ signifies One who brings slaves from foreign countries, particularly from African countries, for sale.]

Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and jalabapN↓, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Ḳ,) [the former an inf. n., and so, perhaps, the latter, but often used as simple substs., the latter more commonly, meaning] Cries, shouts, noises, or clamour: (Ṣ, TA:) or a confusion, or mixture, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) of cries or shouts or noises, (A, Mgh,) or of crying or shouting or noise. (Ḳ.)
And the former, An assembly of men. (TA.)
julobapN The small piece of skin, (Ṣ,) or the crust, or scab, (A, Ḳ,) that forms over a wound (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) when it heals: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. julabN. (A.)
A piece of skin that is put upon the [kind of camel's saddle called] qatab. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 4.]
[A piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed: see 4.]
An amulet upon which is sewed a piece of skin: (Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)
A detached portion of cloud: (Ḳ:) [or] a cloud covering the sky. (IAạr, TA.) [See also jilobN.]

A piece of land differing from that which adjoins it; a patch of ground; syn. buqoEapN. (Ḳ.) One says, Uin-ahu lafiI julobapi SidoqK i. e. fI buqoEapi SidoqK [app. meaning † Verily he is in a good station or position: see art. bqE]. (TA.)
A detached portion of herbage or pasture. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Also Severity, or pressure, of time or fortune; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like kulobapN: (Ṣ:) and hunger: (so in some copies of the Ḳ:) or vehemence of hunger: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) or severity; adversity; difficulty; trouble: (TA:) and a hard, distressful, or calamitous, year. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jalabapN: see jalabN, in two places.

jilib-aAtN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and jilobaAbN↓; (Ḳ;) the latter mentioned as an ex. of form by Sb, and thought by Seer to be syn. with the former, but not explained by any one except the author of the Ḳ; masc. and fem.; (TA;) A [woman's outer wrapping garment called] miloHafap: (Ṣ:) or this is its primary signification; but it is metaphorically applied to other kinds of garments: (El-Khafájee, TA:) or a shirt, (Ḳ, TA,) absolutely: or one that envelopes the whole body: (TA:) and a wide garment for a woman, less than the mlHfp: or one with which a woman covers over her other garments, like the mlHfp: or the [kind of head-covering called], ximaAr: (Ḳ:) so in the M: (TA:) or a garment wider than the xmAr, but less than the ridaMC (Mgh, L, Mṣb,) with which a woman covers her head and bosom: (L:) or a garment shorter, but wider, than the xmAr; the same as the miqonaEap: (En-Naḍr, TA:) or a woman's head-covering: (TA:) or the [kind of wrapper called] UizaAr: (IAạr, TA:) or a garment with which the person is entirely enveloped, so that not even a hand is left exposed, (Ḥar p. 162, and TA,) of the kind called mulaMCap, worn by a woman: (TA:) or a garment, or other thing, that one uses as a covering: (IF, Mṣb:) pl. jalaAbiybu. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
See also julobN.
† Dominion, sovereignty, or rule [with which a person is invested]. (Ḳ.)
julobaAnN and julabaAnN: see julub-aAnN, in three places.
jilib-aAbN: see jilobaAbN.
jalab-aAnN: see the next paragraph, last sentence.

hom.sense: julub-aAnN, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK jul-abAn, and so in the TA in art. xrf,) and without teshdeed, (Ḳ,) [i. e.] julobaAnN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and, accord. to some, julabaAnN↓ also, (Mṣb,) not heard by AḤn from the Arabs of the desert but with teshdeed, though many others pronounce it without teshdeed, and pronounced in the latter manner, he says, it may be a dial. var.; (TA;) [a coll. gen. n.;] A certain plant; (Ḳ;) or a certain grain, or seed, of the kind called qaTaAniI- [i. e. pulse]; (Mṣb;) the [grain, or seed, called] xul-ar, which is a thing resembling the maAX: (Ṣ:) or a dust-coloured, dusky hind of grain or seed, which is cooked; of the colour of the mAX, except in its being of a more dusky shade; but larger: (T, TA:) a certain kind of grain or seed, resembling the mAX, of the kind called qaTaAniI-, well known: (TA:) [a common kind of vetch, or pea, the common lathyrus, or blue chickling vetch, the lathyrus sativus of Linn., is called in Upper Egypt, and by some of the people of Lower Egypt also, jilobaAn:] n. un. with p {julub-aAnapN}. (TA.)

Also the first, (Ḳ,) and p↓, (TA,) and julobaAnN↓, (MF, on the authority of Ibn-El-Jowzee,) [like jurub-aAnN and jurobaAnN or jirobaAnN,] A thing like a jiraAb [or sword-case], of skin, or leather, (Ḳ, TA,) in which is put the sword sheathed, and in which the rider puts his whip and implements, &c., and which he hangs upon the Mxirap or the waAsiT [see these two words] of the camel's saddle; derived from julobapN meaning “a piece of skin that is put upon a qatab:” (TA:) or the case (qiraAb) of the sword-sheath, or scabbard: (Ḳ:) or jlb-Anu Als-ilAHi, occurring in a trad., signifies the case (qrAb) with its contents: or the sword and bow and the like, which require some trouble to draw forth and use in fight; not such a weapon as the lance. (L, TA.)
Also the first, and jalab-aAnN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or jilib-aAnN↓, (so in the CK,) A clamorous man; or one who makes a confused crying or shouting or noise. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: jilib-aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
julub-aAnapN and jilib-aAnapN: see jal-aAbapN.
julubonaAnapN and jilibonaAnapN: see jal-aAbapN.

jaliybN, applied to a male slave, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) One who is brought from one place or country or town to another [for sale]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one who is brought to the country of the Muslims [for sale]: (Mgh:) pl. jalobaI and julabMCu. (Ḳ.) It is also applied [in like manner] to a woman: pl. jalobaI and jalaAYibu. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

jaluwbapN A thing that is driven or brought from one place or country or town to another for sale; (T, Ṣ, TA;) such as an aged she-camel, and a he-camel, and a young she-camel such as is called qaluwS, and any other thing; but not applied to stallion-camels of generous race, that are used for procreation: pl. jalaAYibu: or the pl. signifies camels that are brought to a man sojourning at a water, who has not means of carriage; wherefore they put him [and his companions or goods, &c.] thereon: (TA:) or jlwbp signifies male camels: [see also jalabN:] or camels that are laden with the goods or utensils, &c. of the people: and it is used alike as pl. and sing. (Ḳ.) See jalabN, with which it is syn. (Ḳ.)
jaliybapN: see jalabN.
Also † An affected habit or disposition. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF.)
jal-aAbN: see jalabN.
jul-aAbN Rose-water: an arabicized word, (Ḳ,) from the Persian [Gulo Mbo]. (TA.)

jal-aAbapN and mujal-ibapN↓ and jilib-aAnapN↓ (Ḳ, TA) and julub-aAnapN↓ (CK) and jilibonaAnapN↓ and julubonaAnapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a woman, Clamorous, noisy, very loquacious or garrulous, and of evil disposition: (Ḳ, TA:) or jlb-Anp signifies, thus applied, rude and coarse: (TA:) the l in this word is not a substitute for the r in jirib-aAnapN [which has a similar meaning]: for it is from Aljalabapu. (IJ, TA.)

jaAlibN (A) and jaAlibapN↓ (L) and majolabapN↓ (Ḥar p. 194, &c.) [all signify] † A cause of bringing or drawing or attracting or procuring of a thing: (Ḥar p. 194, in explanation of the last:)
thus majolabapu Ald-amoEi means † the cause of drawing tears: (1d p. 15:) pl. of the second, jawaAlibu; as in the phrase jawaAlibu Alqadari † [the drawing, or procuring, causes of destiny]: (L, TA:) pl. of the third, majaAlibu. (Ḥar p. 430.) You say, likul-i qaDaMCK jaAlibN walikul-i dar-K HaAlibN ‡ [For every decree of fate there is a drawing, or procuring, cause; and for every flow of milk there is a milker]. (A, TA.) And [hence] the pl. jawaAlibu signifies † Calamities, misfortunes, evil accidents, adversities, or difficulties. (TA.) See an ex. in the first paragraph, near the beginning.
quruwHN jawaAlibu and jul-abN Wounds, or ulcers, healing, or becoming covered with skin in healing. (Aṣ, TA.)
jaAlibapN: see the paragraph next preceding.
mujolibN A person who puts an amulet into a case of skin: after which it is sewed upon [the headstall, or some other part of the trappings, of] a horse. (TA.)
majolabapN: see jaAlibN.
mujal-ibN, applied to thunder, (Ḳ,) and to rain, (TA,) Boisterous. (Ḳ, TA.)
mujal-ibapN: see jal-aAbapN.

yanojalibN A xazarap [i. e. bead, or gem, or similar stone] (T, Ḳ, TA) used by the Arabs of the desert, (T, TA,) [or by the women of the desert, as a charm,] for captivating, or fascinating, men; (Ḳ,* TA;) or for bringing back after flight; (T, Ḳ;) or for procuring affection after hatred: (T, TA:) Az mentions it as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) The Arab women used to say,
Oax-acotuhu biAlyanojalibo
falaA yarumo walaA yagibo
walaA yazilo Einoda AlT-anabo
[I have fascinated him with the yenjelib, and he shall not seek another, nor absent himself, nor cease to remain at the tent-rope]. (Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jaliHa, aor. _a {yajolaHu}, inf. n. jalaHN, He (a man, Ṣ, L, &c.) was, or became, bald in the two sides of his head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Mṣb:) or in the fore part of his head: or a little more bald than he who is termed OanozaEu. (L.) [See also jalaHN and OajolaHu.]

jaliHati AlOaroDu, inf. n. as above, The herbage of the land was eaten; as also juliHat. (TA.) And juliHati AlX-ajarapu The branches of the tree were eaten, and it became reduced to its stem, or root. (AḤn, TA.)

jalaHa AlmaAlu AlX-ajara, aor. _a {yajolaHu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. jaloHN; (Ṣ;) and jl-Hhu↓, inf. n. tajoliyHN; (TA;) The cattle ate the trees: or ate the upper parts thereof: (TA:) or fed upon the upper parts thereof, and peeled them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 3.
2: see 1.

tajoliyHN [the inf. n.] signifies also the acting, or advancing, boldly, (Ḳ,) or very boldly: (Ṣ:) or being bold to do evil or mischief; and showing open enmity or hostility: (A:) and acting with penetrating energy, vigour, or effectiveness, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in an affair: (TA:) and going, or journeying, vehemently: (TA:) and the assaulting, or attacking, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) of a man, (AZ, TA,) and of an animal of prey. (Ḳ.) See also 3. You say, lat tujal-iHo EalayonaA yaA fulaAnu [Be not bold to do evil or mischief, or to show open enmity or hostility, to us, O such a one]. (A.) And fiI wajohihi tajoliyHN In his face is [apparent] boldness to do evil or mischief, and a show of open enmity or hostility. (A.) And jl-H EalaI Alqawomi He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon the people or party. (AZ, TA.) And jl-H tajoliyHa Alc-iYobi [He assaulted with the assaulting of the wolf]. (A.) And jl-H EalayonaA He came upon us; or came down upon us and overcame us; or destroyed us; syn. OataI EalayonaA. (ISh, TA.) And jl-H fiI AlOamori He went at random, heedlessly, without any certain aim or object, or without consideration, in the affair; or pursued a headlong, or rash, course therein. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. mujaAlaHapN [the inf. n.] signifies the acting openly with another in an affair: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) and the showing open enmity or hostility with another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, jaAlaHotu Alr-ajula biAlOamori I acted openly with the man in the affair. (Ṣ.) And jaAlaHaniI fulaAnN Such a one showed open enmity or hostility with me; as also jl-H EalaI-a↓. (A.)

Also The contending with another for superiority in strength; syn. muXaAd-apN (Ṣ) and mukaAlaHapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, jaAlaHaniI fulaAnN wajalaHaniI↓ [app. meaning Such a one contended with me for superiority in strength, and overcame me therein]. (TA.)
And i. q. mukaAbarapN [The contending with another for superiority in greatness;, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 1. jalomaHa He shaved his head: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the m is augmentative. (Ṣ.)

jalaHN Baldness in the two sides of the head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in the two sides of the fore part of the head: (Mṣb:) it is more than nazaEN, and less than SalaEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which is less than jalahN: (Mṣb:) or baldness in the fore part of the head: or baldness that is a little more than what is termed nazaEN. (L.)
jalaHapN A part, or place, in which is baldness such as is termed jalaHN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
OaroDN jilaHaMCapN Land that produces no herbage. (Ḳ.)
julaAHN A torrent that carries away everything in its course. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jilowaAHN Wide (Ḳ, TA) and bare, or open, (TA,) land. (Ḳ, TA.)
jul-aHN: see OajolaHu.

jaAliHapN (TA) and jawaAliHu (Ṣ, Ḳ [the latter being pl. of the former]) What flies about in successive portions from the heads of reeds and papyrusplants (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and other plants, in the wind, (TA,) resembling cotton; (Ṣ, TA;) and spiders' webs so flying about. (TA.) And the latter, Flakes of snow falling quickly and continuously. (TA.)

OajolaHu A man bald in the two sides of his head: (Ṣ:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Mṣb:) or in the fore part of his head: (Mgh, L:) or a little more bald than he who is termed OanozaEu: (L:) it signifies more than AnzE, and less than OajolaI and Oajolahu: (Mgh:) when a man is bald in the sides of his forehead, he is termed AnzE; when the baldness is a little more, AjlH; when it extends to the half, or the like, AjlI; and then, Ajlh: (AʼObeyd, TA:) the fem. is jaloHaMCu: and the pl. juloHN (L, Mṣb) and juloHaAnN. (L.)

‡ Having no horn; applied to a bull and a he-goat: (A:) and in this sense the fem. is applied to a ewe (T, M, Mṣb) or she-goat, (T, M, A, Mṣb,) and to a cow: (T, M, A:) and in like manner [the pl.] juloHN is applied to cows or bulls having no horns; (Ṣ, TA;) erroneously said in the Ḳ to be jul-aHN, like suk-arN. (TA.)

† A [woman's camel-vehicle of the kind called] hawodaj that has not a high head or top: (Ibn-Kulthoom, IJ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or without a top: (T:) or one that is of a square form: (Aṣ, IJ:) pl. OajolaAHN↓, (Ṣ, IJ,) like as OaEozaAlN is pl. of OaEozalu; a very rare form of pl. of a sing. of the measure OafoEalu. (IJ.)
† A flat roof not surrounded by a wall or anything else to prevent persons' falling from it. (IAth, Ḳ.)
qaroyapN jaloHaMCu ‡ A town having no fortress: (A, TA:) pl. qurFI juloHN: the fortresses being likened to horns. (TA.)
OakamapN jaloHaMCu † [A hill] not having a pointed summit. (TA.) And haDobapN jaloHaMCu † [A] smooth [hill]. (A.)
OaroDN jaloHaMCu † A land in which are no trees. (TA.)
yawomN OajolaHu † A hard, distressing, or calamitous, day; as also OaSolaEu. (A, TA.)
OajolaAHN: see OajolaHu.
UijoliyHN A plant of which the upper parts have been eaten. (TA.)
mujal-aHN Eaten: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) eaten until nothing of it is left: (Ṣ:) herbage so eaten. (TA.)

hom.sense: mujal-iHN A man (Ṣ) who eats much; a great eater; voracious. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also mijolaAHN.
sanapN mujal-iHapN A year of drought, barrenness, or death. (TA.)
Insolent and audacious. (L.) You say, fulaAnN waqiHN mujal-iHN [Such a one is impudent, insolent, and audacious]. (A, TA.)
A bold wolf. (TA.)

entry.sense: mijolaAHN A she-camel (Ṣ) that bears with hardiness a severe year, preserving her milk; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also mujal-iHapN↓. (L.)
See also mujaAliHN.
majoluwHN A tree having the head, or upper part, eaten. (L.)
A plant, or tree, that has been eaten and has grown again. (TA.)
mujaAliHN i. q. mukaAbirN [Contending with another for superiority in greatness;, &c.: see its verb, 3]. (Ṣ.)
The lion. (Ḳ.)

A she-camel that yields milk abundantly in winter: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that crops the twigs of the dry trees in winter, in a year of drought, and becomes fat upon them, and so preserves her milk: (IAạr, TA:) pl. majaAliyHu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or this is pl. of mujaAliHN and mijolaAHN↓ as epithets applied to a palm-tree and a she-camel that cares not for the want of rain. (AḤn, TA.) And mujaAlaHapN A she-camel that eats the samur and EurofuT, whether they have leaves upon them or not. (TA.)
majaAliyHu: see mujaAliHN.
Also Years of drought that carry off, or destroy, the cattle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. jaladahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, &c.,) aor. _i {yajolidu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jalodN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He hit, or hurt, his skin; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like as you say, raOasahu, and baTanahu: (Ṣ:) he beat his skin: (Mgh:) he beat him; namely, a criminal: (Mṣb:) he struck him with a whip, and with a sword: (TA:) he flogged him (A, Ḳ) with a whip, (Ḳ,) or with whips: (A:) jaladotu is sometimes written and pronounced jalad-u. (MF on the letter d.) You say, jaladahu AlHad-a, inf. n. as above, He inflicted upon him the flogging ordained by the law. (Ṣ, L.)
jaladati AlHay-apu The serpent bit: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, one says of the serpent called Oasowadu, specially, yajolidu bicanabihi [it strikes with its tail]. (TA.)

jalada jaAriyatahu, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He lay with his young woman, or female slave. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence,] jalada Eumayorapa [† i. q. nakaHa Alyada], a metonymical phrase: jalodu Eumayorapa meaning AlxaDoxaDapu, and AlAisotimonaMCu biAlyadi, also termed Alt-adoliylu, and AlAiEotimaAru: the similar act of a woman is termed AlUiloTaAfu. (Ḥar p. 572.)

jalada bihi AlOaroDa He smote the ground with him; (TA;) he threw him down prostrate on the ground. (A, TA.) And julida bihi He fell down (Ḳ, TA) upon the ground by reason of much sleepiness; as also julida bihi nuwomFA. (TA.) kunotu OataXad-adu fayujoladu biI, in a trad., means [I used to exert my strength, or energy, but] sleep would overcome me so that I fell down. (L.)
jaladahu EalaI AlOamori ‡ He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (A, Ḳ.)

yujoladu bikul-i xayorK (or, as related by AḤát, yjlc, with c, TA) ‡ He is imagined to possess every good quality. (A, Ḳ.) But the saying of EshSháfi'ee kaAna mujaAlidN yujoladu means † Mujálid used to be pronounced a liar, (Ḳ, TA,) or suspected and accused of lying. (TA.)

julidati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) the verb being in the pass. form, (Mṣb,) or jalidat, (A, Ḳ,) a verb of the same form as fariHa; (Ḳ;) [or both may be correct, like Duribat and Daribat in the same sense;] and Oajoladat↓; (Ḳ;) [but this last I believe to be a mistake for Oujolidat, like OuDoribat;] The land was, or became, affected or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And jld Albaqolu [in the TA jalida] The herbs, or leguminous plants, were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, TA.) And OujoliduwA↓ They (men) were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, Ḳ.)

jaluda, aor. _u {yajoludu}, inf. n. jalaAdapN and juluwdapN and jaladN (or this last is a simple subst., L) and majoluwdN, an inf. n. like maHoluwfN and maEoquwlN, (Ṣ, or from tajal-ada, M in art. Esr,) He (a man, Ṣ, L) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ,*) and enduring, or patient. (L.)
2. jl-d, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. tajoliydN, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) He skinned a camel (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) that had been slaughtered: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one seldom uses salaxa thus [in relation to a camel]. (Ṣ.)

Also He covered a thing with skin; as, for instance, a pair of socks, or stockings: (Mgh:) and in like manner, [he bound] a book: (A, Ḳ:*) and he clad a young camel in the skin of another young camel: (L: [see jaladN:]) thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Mgh.)
[He ordered to be flogged. (Freytag's Lex.: but without any indication of an authority.)]
[He, or it, rendered a man hardy, strong, sturdy, and enduring, or patient: so in the present day.]

entry.sense: 3. jAldhu He contended with him in fight, whether the fight were with swords or not. (A in art. Trd.) You say, jAldhu biAls-ayofi, (L,) inf. n. mujaAladapN (Ṣ, A, L) and jilaAdN, (A, L,) He contended with him in fight with the sword. (Ṣ,* A, L.) And jaAladuwhumo biAls-uyuwfi They contended with them in fight with swords. (A.) And jAldwA biAls-uyuwfi, (Ḳ, TA,) and tjAldwA↓ (Ṣ, A, L, and so in the CK instead of jAldwA) bAlsywf, (Ṣ,) and AjtldwA↓, (Ṣ, A, L,) They contended, one with another, in fight with swords. (Ṣ, A,* L, Ḳ.)
[See also HaADarahu.]

hom.sense: 4. Ajldhu Uilayohi † He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or betake himself to, him, or it: (so in some copies of the Ḳ:) or he made him to stand in need of, or to want, him, or it. (AA, L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA.)
Oajoladati AlOaroDu [or Oujolidat]: and OujoliduwA: see 1.

entry.sense: 5. tjl-d He affected hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience; constrained himself to behave with hardiness,, &c. (Ṣ,* A,* L, Ḳ.*) So in the phrase tjl-d lilX-aAmitiyna [He constrained himself to behave with hardiness,, &c., to those who rejoiced at his misfortune]. (A, TA.) In the phrase tjl-d Eanohu [He constrained himself to endure with hardiness and patience the loss, or want, of him, or it], the verb is made trans. by means of En because it implies the meaning of taSab-ara. (L.)
Also He feigned, or made a show of, hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience. (L.)
6: see 3.

hom.sense: 8: see 3.
Ajtld AlUinaMCa, (AZ, TA,) or maAfiI AlUinaMCi, (Ḳ,) He drank all that was in the vessel; (AZ, Ḳ, TA;) as also AHtld. (AZ, TA.)

entry.sense: jalodN (sometimes pronounced jaDodN, Ṣ) and jaliydN↓, (applied to a man, Ṣ, A, Mgh,) Hardy, strong, sturdy, (Ṣ,* A,* L, Ḳ,*) and enduring, or patient: (L:) not baliyd [q. v.]: (Mgh:) pl. [of either] julodN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or juludN, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and juladaMCu and OajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and jilaAdN. (Ḳ.) And [the fem.] jalodapN A hardy and strong she-camel; strong to labour and to journey; that heeds not the cold: and also swift: pl. jalodaAtN: (L:) and a she-camel that yields a copious flow of milk: (Th, TA:) sing. of jilaAdN, (Ṣ,) which signifies she-camels abounding with milk; as also majaAliydu, (Ḳ,) pl. of mijolaAdN↓; (TA;) or she-camels having neither milk nor young: (Ḳ:) [see also jaladN:] or she-camels that yield the most greasy, or unctuous, sort of milk: and so the sing., jldp, applied to a ewe or a she-goat. (Ṣ.) jilaAdN ( pl. of jalodapN, TA) is also applied to palm-trees, meaning Large, hard, hardy, or strong: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or such as are not affected by drought. (TA.) And tamorapN jalodapN signifies A tough-skinned, excellent, date; as also jilodapN↓: and a hard, compact, date. (L.)

jilodN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the only form of the word mentioned by the generality of the lexicographers; (TA;) occurring at the end of a verse with kesr to the second as well as the first letter, jilidN↓, agreeably with a license allowed to a poet in such a case, to give to a quiescent letter in a rhyme the same vowel as that which the preceding letter has; (Ṣ;) and jaladN↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) like XibohN and XabahN, and mivolN and mavalN; but this is said by ISk to be unknown; (Ṣ;) The skin of any animal; (Ḳ;) the integument of the body and limbs of an animal: (Az, Mṣb:) or the exterior of the baXarapN [or upper skin] of an animal: (Mṣb: [but this is a strange explanation:]) pl. juluwdN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (sometimes, Mṣb) OajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[The pl.] OajolaAdN signifies also, and tajaAliydu↓ likewise, The body and limbs (Ṣ, A, L) of a man; (Ṣ;) the whole person, or body and limbs, of a human being; (L, Ḳ;) and his self: (L:) so called because enclosed by the skin: pl. of the former, OajaAlidu. (L.) You say, maA OaXobaha OajolaAdahu biOajolaAdi Oabiyhi How like are his person and body to the person and body of his father! (L.) And fulaAnN EaZiymu AlOajolaAdi and Alt-ajaAliydi↓ (A, L) Such a one is large and strong (L) in respect of the body and limbs. (A, L.) And rud-uwA AlOayomaAna EalaI OajolaAdihimo Repeat ye the oaths to the persons, themselves: occurring in a trad.: said on the occasion of a man's entering among others of whom an oath had been demanded. (L.)

Aljilodu also signifies † The penis. (Fr, L, Ḳ: but in the CK, in this sense, it is written Aljalodu.) Agreeably with this explanation, its pl. juluwd is said by Fr to be used in the Ḳur xli. 20: (L:) or as meaning the pudenda: (L, Ḳ:) but ISd holds that this word there means the skins, with which, as in manual operations, acts of disobedience are performed. (L.)

hom.sense: jaladN: see jilodN.

Also The skin of a camel, or other beast, with which another beast is clothed: (L:) the skin of a young camel, which (being stripped off, Ṣ) is put over the body of another young camel, in order that the mother of the skinned young one (smelling it, Ṣ) may conceive an affection for it [and suckle it]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the skin of a young camel, which is stuffed with panic grass (vumaAm), (Ḳ, TA,) or some other plant, (TA,) and put before a she-camel, in order that she may be induced thereby to affect that which is not her young one [and so yield her milk], (Ḳ, TA,) or, to affect the young one of another. (L, TA.)

Also, [as a coll. gen. n.,] Great she-camels, having neither young ones nor milk; n. un. with p {jaladapN}: (Ṣ:) [see also jalodN:] or great camels, among which are no little ones; (Ḳ;) n. un. with p {jaladapN}: (TA:) and (app. as a quasi-pl. n., TA) sheep or goats, and camels, having neither young ones nor milk; (Ḳ;) app. meaning having no little ones to which they give such: (Moḥammad Ibn-El-Mukarram, TA:) or she-camels having no young ones with them, so that they endure patiently the heat and cold: (Fr, TA:) or she-camels having no milk, and the young ones of which have gone away from them; including what are called banaAtu All-abuwni, and such as are above these in age; and also such as are called maxaASN, and EiXaArN, and HiyaAlN; but when they have given birth to their young, they cease to be termed jaladN, and are called EiXaArN, and liqaAHN: the pl. is OajolaAdN and [pl. pl.] OajaAliydu. (Az, TA.)

Hard ground; as also Oajoladu↓: (Ṣ:) or hard and level ground; as also jaladapN↓: (Ḳ:) or level but rough ground; (L;) as also Oajoladu↓: (TA:) pl. (of the former, TA) OajolaAdN and (of the latter, TA) OajaAlidu. (Ṣ, TA.) You also say OaroDN jaladN, with fet-ḥ to the l; (AḤn, TA;) and jalodapN↓, with a quiescent l; (Lth, AḤn, TA;) and ArD jaladapN↓ also; and makaAnN jaladN. (Lth, TA.)
Also, as a subst. or an inf. n., (L, [see jaluda,]) Hardiness, strength, sturdiness, (Ṣ,* A,* L, Ḳ,*) and endurance, or patience. (T.)

entry.sense: jilidN: see jilodN.
jalodapN: see jaladN.

hom.sense: jilodapN a more particular term than jilodN; (Ṣ, L;) signifying A piece, or portion, of skin. (L.)
One says also jilodapu AlEayoni [app. meaning The eyelid]. (TA.)
And qawomN mino jilodatinaA A people, or company of men, of ourselves, and of our kinsfolk. (TA.)
See also jalodN.

entry.sense: jaladapN: see jaladN, in three places.

hom.sense: Hoarfrost, or rime; i. e. dew that falls (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) from the sky (Ṣ) upon the ground (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and congeals; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) also called DariybN and saqiyTN; (Ṣ;) like SaqiyEN. (Mṣb.)
Congealed, or frozen, water; ice. (TA.)
See also jalodN.

entry.sense: julayodapN [dim. of jilodapN] One of the TabaqaAt [coats, or tunics,] of the eye. (TA.)
juluwdiI-N [A dealer in skins;] a rel. n. from juluwdN, pl. of jilodN. (TA.)
jal-aAdN One whose office it is to flog others with a whip. (Mgh.) [In the present day, An executioner, in a general sense.]
Oajoladu: see jaladN, in two places.
tajaAliydu: see jilodN, in two places.

mijoladN A piece of skin which a wailing woman holds in her hand, and with which she slaps (Ṣ, Ḳ) her face (Ṣ) or her cheek: (Ḳ:) pl. majaAliydu; (Kr, Ḳ;) or, as ISd thinks, this is pl. of mijolaAdN↓ [as syn. with mijoladN], for mifoEalN and mifoEaAlN are often interchangeable as measures of words of this kind. (TA.)

hom.sense: mujal-adN Covered with skin: thus applied to a pair of socks, or stockings, meaning having skin put upon the upper and lower parts. (Mgh.) [A book, or portion of a book, bound:]
[and hence, A volume: pl. mujal-adaAtN.]
A bone covered only by the skin; having nothing remaining on it but the skin. (Ḳ.)
A horse [rendered hardy and enduring;] that is not frightened by, (Ḳ,) or not impatient at, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) being beaten (Ṣ, Ḳ) with the whip. (TA.)
A certain quantity of a burden, or load, of known measure and weight; (Ḳ;) six hundred pounds' weight. (IAạr, TA in art. bhr.)

entry.sense: mujal-idN One who binds books, or covers them with skin. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: mijolaAdN: see mijoladN:
and see also jalodN.
majoluwdN [Having his skin hit, hurt, or beaten: flogged:, &c.: see also jaliydN].
OaroDN majoluwdapN Land affected, or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
majoluwdN is also an inf. n. of jaluda [q. v.]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mujotaladN A place of contending in fight with swords. (L from a trad.)

1. jalasa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajolisu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. juluwsN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and majolasN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He placed his seat, or posteriors, upon rugged [or rather elevated] ground, such as is termed jalosN: this is the primary signification: (TA:) [and hence,] He sat; i. q. qaEada [when the latter is used in its largest sense]: (Mṣb, and so Ṣ and L and A and Ḳ in art. qEd:) you say, jalasa mutarab-iEFA and qaEada mutarab-iEFA [He sat cross-legged]: (Mṣb:) accord. to El-Fárábee and others, contr. of qaAma; and thus it has a more common application than qaEada [when the latter is used in its most proper and restricted sense]: (Mṣb:) but qaEada also signifies the contr. of qaAma: ('Orweh Ibn-Zubeyr, L in art. qEd:) properly speaking, jalasa differs from qaEada; the former signifying he sat up; or sat after sleeping, or prostration, (Mṣb,) or after lying on his side; (B, TA;) and the latter, he sat down; or sat after standing: (Mṣb, B, TA: and see other authorities to the same effect in art. qEd:) for juluwsN is a change of place from low to high, and quEuwdN is a change of place from high to low: and one says, jalasa mut-akiYFA, but not qaEada mut-akiYFA, meaning [He sat] leaning, or reclining, upon one side: (Mṣb:) but both these verbs sometimes signify he was, or became: and thus, [it is said,] jalasa mutarab-iEFA and faEada mutarab-iEFA signify he was, or became, cross-legged: and jalasa bayona XuEabihaA AlOarobaEi in like manner signifies he was, or became, [between her four limbs,] (El-Fárábee, Mṣb,) because the man, in this case, is resting upon his own four limbs. (Mṣb.) [jalasa maEahu and jalasa Uilayohi, like xalaA mEh and xlA Alyh, signify the same; i. e. He sat with him: or the latter, he sat by him; like “assedit ei.”] An instance of the inf. n. majolasN is found in a trad., in which it is said, faUicaA Oatayotumo UilaI Almajolisi faOaEoTuwA AlT-ariyqa Haq-ahu [But when ye come to sitting, perform ye the duties relating to the road]. (TA.) [The trad. commences thus: Uiy-aAkumo waAljuluwsa EalaI AlT-uruqaAti Beware ye of sitting on the roads: and then, after the words before cited, (in which, however, in my copy of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer, instead of Almjls, I find AlmajaAlisi, which is pl. of Almajolisu,) it is added that the duties thus alluded to are the lowering of the eyes, the putting away or aside what is hurtful or annoying, the returning of salutations, the enjoining of that which is good, and the forbidding of that which is evil.]
jalasati Alr-axamapu ‡ The aquiline vulture lay upon its breast on the ground; syn. javamat: a saying applied to him who is of the seceders. (A, TA.) [See also qaEada.]
jalasa also signifies † It (a thing, as, for instance, a plant,) remained, or continued. (AḤn, TA.)
Also, (aor. _i {yajolisu}, inf. n. jalosN, TA,) He came to Aljalos, (TA,) or [the high country called] Nejd: (T, Ṣ, A, TA:) and in like manner said of a cloud; it came to Nejd. (TA.)

3. jAlshu, inf. n. mujaAlasapN and jilaAsN, [He sat with him.] (TA.) You say, laA tujaAliso mano laA tujaAniso [Sit not with him with whom thou wilt not be congenial]. (A, TA.) And kariymu Aln-iHaAsi Tay-iybu AljilaAsi [Generous in origin, or disposition; pleasant to sit with;] is said of a man. (TA.)
4. Ajlshu [He seated him; made him to sit: or he made him to sit up]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he gave him place, or settled him, (mak-anahu,) in sitting. (TA.)
6. tjAslwA [They sat together; one with another;] (Ṣ, A, TA;) fiI AlmajaAlisi [in the sittingplaces]. (Ṣ.)

10. Astjlshu [He asked him, or desired him, to sit: or to sit up.]. You say, raMniI qaAYimFA faQsotajolasaniI [He saw me standing, and he asked me, or desired me, to sit]: (A, TA:) but this is at variance with what we have mentioned in the beginning of the art., respecting the distinction [between jalasa and qaEada]. (TA.)

hom.sense: jalosN Rugged ground or land: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) this is the primary signification. (TA.)
[Also, app., Elevated ground or land:] a place elevated and hard: or, as some say, a tract of land extending widely. (Ḥam p. 688.)
[And hence,] Aljalosu What is elevated above the gawor [or low country]: (TA:) applied especially to the country of Nejd. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

[Persons sitting: or sitting up:] a quasi-pl. n., accord. to Sb, or a pl., accord. to Akh, of jaAlisN↓: said to be used as sing. and pl. and fem. and masc.; but this assertion is of no account: (ISd, L:) or the people of a majolis: (Lḥ, ISd, L, Ḳ:) [juluwsN↓ is also a pl. of jaAlisN↓; like as bukiI-N, originally bukuwIN, is of baAki: or it is an inf. n. used as an epithet: see jaAvK:] you say qawomN juluwsN [a company of men sitting: or sitting up]. (Ṣ.) [See also majolisN.]
Also A woman who sits in the finaMC [or court of the house], not quitting it: (Ḳ:) or she who is of noble rank (Ḳ, TA) among her people. (TA.)

entry.sense: jilosN: see jaliysN, in two places.
jalosapN A single sitting: or sitting up. (Mṣb.)

jilosapN A mode or manner, (TA,) kind, (Mṣb,) or state, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) of sitting: or of sitting up. (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*) You say, huwa Hasanu Aljilosapi [He has a good mode,, &c., of sitting]. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
julasapN A man (Ṣ) who sits much; sedentary. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
juluwsN: see jalosN.

jaliysN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jil-iysN↓ (TA, as found in a copy of the Ḳ, [but this is an intensive form,]) and jilosN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) A companion with whom one sits: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. of the first with p {jaliysapN}: (TA:) and pl. [of the same] julasaMCu (A, Ḳ) and [irreg., being by rule pl. of jaAlisN,] jul-aAsN. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa jilosiI↓ and jaliysiI [He is my companion with whom I sit]; like as you say, huwa xidoniI and xadiyniI. (Ṣ.)
jil-iysN: see jaliysN.
jaAlisN: see jalosN, in two places.
Also A man, and a cloud, coming to [the high country called] Nejd. (TA.) You say, raOayotuhumo yaEoduwna jaAlisiyna I saw them running, coming to Nejd. (A, TA.)
majolasN: see 1:
and see majolisN.

majolisN A sitting-place; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also ↓ with p {majolisapN}; (Fr, Lḥ, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) similar to makaAnN and makaAnapN: (Ṣgh, TA:) [a place where persons sit together and converse; a sitting-room:] a thing upon which one sits: (MF:) some make a strange distinction between majolisN and majolasN↓, asserting the former to be applied to the chamber or house (bayot) [in which people sit]; and the latter, to a place of honour upon which it is forbidden to sit without permission; but the former is the only correct form of the two: (MF, TA:) pl. majaAlisu. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, Aurozuno fiI majolisika and majolisatika↓ [Be thou grave] in thy sitting-place. (Fr, Ṣgh.)

‡ The people of a majolis; (Mṣb, TA;) elliptical, for Oaholu majolisK: (TA:) an assembly, or a company of men, sitting [together]: (Th, TA:) not well explained as being, with the article Al, syn. with Aln-aAsu: (TA:) persons sitting, or sitting up. (A, TA.) [See also jalosN.] You say, AinofaD-a Almajolisu † [The assembly of persons sitting together broke up]. (Mṣb.) And raOayotuhumo majolisFA I saw them sitting. (A, TA.)
† An oration or a discourse, or an exhortation, (xuTobapN Oawo EiZapN,) delivered in a majolis; like maqaAmapN. (Mṭr, in the Preface to Ḥar.)

It is also used in the same manner as HaDorap and janaAb: you say majolisu fulaAnK [meaning † The object of resort, with whom others sit and converse, such a one]; like HaDorapu fulaAnK. (Kull p. 146.) [See arts. HDr and jnb. But this usage I believe to be post-classical.]
[Also † A stool; meaning, an evacuation. So in medical books.]
majolisapN: see majolisN, in two places.
jalosadN and Aljalosadu: see art. jsd

hom.sense: 1. jalafahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajolufu}, inf. n. jalofN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, it off; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) namely, a thing; (TA;) as, for instance, (Ṣ, TA,) the mud, or clay, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) from the head of a [jar of the kind called] dan-. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, jalafa Zuforahu Eano UiSobaEihi He stripped off his nail from his finger. (Lth, TA.) And accord. to some, jalofN signifies The scraping off, or stripping off, the skin with somewhat of the flesh: and the act of pulling, or drawing, out, or up, or off; or displacing. (TA.)

Also i. q. jarafahu [He took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, or the greater part of it, or much of it; or he swept it away]: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, jalofN signifies a more intensive and more exterminating action than jarofN. (TA.)
And He cut it off; (Ṣ;) or pulled it, or plucked it, out, or up; or eradicated, or uprooted, it; (Ḳ;) and exterminated it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Ajtlfhu↓. (Ḳ.)
jalafahu biAls-ayofi He struck him with the sword: (Ḳ:) or he cut, or cut a piece from, or cut in pieces, his flesh [with the sword]. (A, TA.)
julifa Aln-abaAtu The herbage was eaten to the uttermost. (TA.)
julifa fiI maAlihi jalofapF He suffered the loss of somewhat of his property, or cattle. (TA.)
jalifa, aor. _a {yajolafu}, inf. n. jalafN and jalaAfapN, † He was, or became, rude in disposition, or in make; coarse, or churlish. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. jal-afatohu Als-inuwna The years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, destroyed his cattle. (Ṣ.) And jal-afato kaHolu, (Ṣ,) or kaHolN, (Ḳ,) The year of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, exterminated the cattle. (Ḳ.) And Ajtlfto↓ OamowaAlahumo [It destroyed their cattle] is also said of a year of great drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (Ṣ.) And Ajtlfhu↓ Ald-ahoru Time, or fortune, or misfortune, destroyed his property, or cattle. (TA.)
4. Ajlf He (a man) removed the julaAf [or clay] from the head of the [jar called] xunobujap [i. q. dan-]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
8: see 1; and see also 2, in two places.

hom.sense: jilofN A [jar of the kind called] dan-: (M, Ḳ:) or an empty dan-: (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) this is said (Ṣ, Mṣb) by AO (Ṣ) to be the primary signification of the word: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or the lower part of a dan- when it is broken: (ISd, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) and a [receptacle such as is called] Zarof, (AA, Ṣ, Hr, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, Tarof,]) and wiEaMC, (AA, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any kind, (AA, Ṣ, Mṣb,) such as a saddle-bag, or pair of saddlebags, and a sack, in which bread or other food is kept: (Hr, TA:) pl. [of mult.] juluwfN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and [of pauc.] OajolaAfN and OajolufN, which last is rare. (Mṣb.)
Also A [skin of the kind called] ziq- without head and without legs. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

And A skinned animal, (AO, Ṣ,) or a skinned sheep or goat, (Ḳ,) of which the belly has been taken forth, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the head and legs of which have been cut off; (Ḳ;) the body of a skinned sheep or goat, without head and without belly and without legs: or, as some say, a body of any kind without a head upon it: (L:) or a beast without fat, and without back [to bear], and without belly to conceive: (IAth, TA:) or the skin of a sheep or goat, and of a camel: (Aṣ, Mṣb:) pl. OajolaAfN (Sb, L) and sometimes OajolufN: (Sb, TA:) and [it is also said that] OajolaAfu AlX-aApi signifies the shinned sheep or goat that is without head and without legs and without belly. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Hence, i. e., from AjlAf AlXAp, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ Rude in disposition or in make; coarse, or churlish; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jaliyfN↓; (Ḳ;) meaning that the person so termed is empty, without intellect: (M, TA:) applied to a DesertArab, (Ṣ,) or to an Arab: (so in a copy of the Mṣb:) or it is so applied as though meaning one with his skin; not having assumed the gentle and soft habits of the people of the towns or villages or cultivated lands; for when one does this, it is as though he pulled off his skin and clad himself with another: (Mṣb:) or ‡ stupid, foolish, or unsound in intellect; likened to a skinned sheep or goat because of the weakness of his intellect. (IAth, TA.)
Also Thick, or coarse, dry bread: or bread not rendered savoury by anything eaten therewith: or the edge [of a cake] of bread. (Ḳ.) [See also jilofapN.]
A male palm-tree, (Lth, Ḳ,) with the spadix of which the female palm-tree is fecundated: (Lth, TA:) pl. juluwfN. (TA.)
A certain well-known bird. (Ḳ.)
jalofapN [inf. n. of un. of julifa, q. v.].
See also jilofapN.

entry.sense: julofapN A part of a skin that is peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off. (L, Ḳ.)
jilofapN A broken piece of dry bread, (Ḳ, TA,) thick, or coarse, (TA,) and without anything to render it savoury: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. jilafN. (TA.) [See jilofN, of which it may be regarded as the n. un.]
A piece of anything: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)
The portion of a reed for writing that is between its maboraI [or place where the paring is commenced] and its point; as also jalofapN↓. (Ḳ.)
julaAfN Clay; such as is put upon the head of the [jar called] xunobujap. [See 4.] (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
jaliyfN Peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off; as also majoluwfN↓. (Ḳ.) It is said by some that the last word in the following saying of Keys Ibn-El-Khateem,
kaOan-a lab-aAtihaA tabad-adahaA
hazolaI jaraAdi OajowaAfuhu julofu
is pl. of the former in this sense: but accord. to ISk, [the meaning of the verse is, As though emaciated locusts without heads and without legs occupied the two sides, or the whole, of the part of her breast where the necklace lay; for he says that] the poet likens the ornaments upon her lab-ap to locusts without heads and without legs. (TA.) rijolN jaliyfapN [An excoriated leg]. (TA.)

jaliyfapN [or sanapN jaliyfapN] A year that destroys the cattle; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also jaAlifapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) any bane, or calamity, that destroys the cattle: pl. jalaAYifu and julufN and julofN. (TA.) You say, OaSaAbatohumo jaliyfapN EaZiymapN A great destruction of their cattle befell them. (Ṣ, TA.) And sinuwna jalaAYifu and julufN and julofN Years that destroy the cattle. (Ḳ.) And jalaAYifu also signifies Torrents. (TA.)
See also jilofN.

entry.sense: jaAlifN [act. part. n. of jalafa].

jaAlifapN [or Xaj-apN jaAlifapN] A wound of the head that peels off the skin with the flesh: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that peels off the skin but does not penetrate into the interior. (Mṣb.) And TaEonapN jaAlifapN A spear-wound, or the like, that does not penetrate into the interior; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) opposed to jaAYifapN. (Ṣ.)
zamaAnN jaAYifN i. q. jaArifN [A time, or season, that sweeps away, or destroys, the cattle]. (TA.) See also jaliyfN.
mujal-afN Having a portion, or portions, taken from its sides. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Having somewhat thereof remaining. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So explained by Abu-l-Ghowth as occurring in the saying of El-Farezdaḳ,
waEaD-u zamaAna yaA Qbona marowaAna lamo yadaEo
mina AlmaAli Uil-aA musoHatFA Oawo mujal-afu
i. e., [And a biting of fortune, O Ibn-Marwán, left not, of the cattle, save] such as were destroyed, or they were such as had only a remnant remaining. (Ṣ.)

A man (Ṣ) whose cattle have been destroyed by years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And qawomN mujotalafuwna↓ A people, or party, whose cattle have been destroyed by a year of drought or the like. (Ṣ, TA.)
majoluwfN: see jaliyfN.
Also A skinned sheep or goat. (L.)
xubozN majoluwfN Bread burnt by the oven, (Ḳ, TA,) so that its outer parts stick to it. (TA.)
qawomN mujotalafuwna: see mujal-afN.
mutajal-ifN Lean, or emaciated; (Ḳ;) as also mutajar-ifN. (TA.)

jawaAliqu (Ṣ, M, MA, Mgh, Ḳ) and juwaAliqN (IAạr, M, Ḳ) and jiwaAliqN (Ḳ) A sack; in Pers. juwaAlo; (MA, PṢ;) [not so well rendered in the KL by xurojiyno, which means a saddle-bag or a pair of saddle-bags, like the Arabic xurojN;] a certain kind of wiEaMCi [or receptacle], (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [for corn, &c.,] well known: (M, Ḳ:) it has a loop, into which is inserted a stick, or piece of wood, called XiZaAZN, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. XZ,) this being also inserted into the loop of another jwAlq, when they are bound upon the camel: (Ḳ * and TA in that art.:) or it has two loops, one of which is inserted into the other, (Ṣ and Ḳ voce qaTaba,) [and then the stick is put through,] on the occasion of putting it on a camel: (TA ibid.:) the word is arabicized; (M, TA;) said to be from kwAlh, (TA,) or kwAlk, (KL,) but correctly from JwAlh, which is Pers.: (TA:) the pl. is jawaAliqu (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Ḳ) and jawaAliyqu, (Sb, Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Ḳ,) the latter occurring in poetry, (TA,) and juwaAliqaAtN (Ṣ, Ḳ) was sometimes used, (Ṣ,) but this is disallowed by Sb. (Ṣ, M.) The saying [of a rájiz], cited by Th,
OuHib-u maAwiy-apa Hub-FA SaAdiqaA
Hub-a OabiI AljuwaAliqi AljuwaAliqaA
[I love Máweeyeh with a true love; with the love of the owner (lit. father) of the sack for the sack;] means that the speaker had a vehement love for the food, or wheat, that was in his jwAlq. (M.) Another says,
yaA Hab-acaA maA fiI AljawaAliyqi Als-uwdo
mino xuXokanaAni wasawiyqK maqonuwdo
[O, lovely is what is in the black sacks, of biscuit and meal of parched barley sweetened with sugarcandy!]. (Ṣ.)
1. jalamahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajolimu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jalomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [like jaramahu.]

He shore it, or sheared it; namely, wool, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and hair, with the jalamaAni, (Mṣb,) or jalam. (TA.) And jalamotu minohu I took [or clipped somewhat] from it; namely, wool; like jaramotu. (Ṣ in art. jrm.) And jalama AlX-aApa He shore, or sheared, the sheep or goat. (Ḥar p. 190.)
jalama Aljazuwra, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He took the flesh that was on the bones of the slaughtered camel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Ajtlmhu↓. (Ḳ.)
8: see what precedes {1}.
jilomN The fat of the varob [or thin integument that covers the stomach and bowels or intestines] of a sheep or goat. (Ḳ.)

jalamN The instrument with which one shears (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) wool and hair: (TA:) and jalamaAni signifies a pair thereof; a pair of shears: (Ṣ:) or jalamN and jalamaAni signify alike, i. q. miqoraADN; like as one says miqoraADN and miqoraADaAni, and qalamN and qalamaAni: and jalamaAnN↓ is also allowable, as a sing.; (Mṣb;) authorized by Ks; (TA;) and in like manner, qalamaAnN. (Mṣb. [But see miqoraADN.])
† The moon; (Az, Ḳ;) as also jayolamN↓: (Ḳ:) or the [new moon, or moon when it is termed] hilaAl: (Ḳ:) likened to the jalam [as meaning the blade of a pair of shears]. (TA.)
[Hence also, probably,] † A certain mark of camels, made with a hot iron. (Ibn-Ḥabeeb, Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] † The tick, or ticks. (Ḳ.)

And, accord. to some, as being likened to these, because of their smallness, (TA,) † The sheep of Mekkeh: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or certain sheep with long and hairless legs, found at Et-Táïf. (Ḳ.) And † The male of the gazelle, and of the sheep: pl. jilaAmN. (Ḳ.) And † A kid: (Kr, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ṣ, TA.)
jalomapN The whole of a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also julomapN↓ and jalamapN↓. (Ḳ.) You say, Oaxacotu AlX-aIoCa bijalomatihi I took the thing wholly. (Ṣ.)
julomapN: see what next precedes.
jalamapN A skinned sheep or goat (Ṣ, Ḳ) without the intestines and without the legs, (Ṣ,) [or] when the shanks and the redundant parts have gone. (Ḳ.) And the whole flesh of a slaughtered camel. (Ṣ.)
See also jalomapN.
jalamaAnN: see jalamN.
julaAmapN Shorn wool. (Ḳ.)
jul-aAmN Shorn he-goats. (Ḳ.)
jayolamN: see jalamN.
majoluwmN Cut, or cut off. (Mṣb.)
A shorn sheep or goat. (Ḳ,* TA.)
mujotalamN A bone having the flesh cut off with the jalam (TA in art. knt.) Quasi
jalomaHa: see Q. Q. 1. in art. jlH.

hom.sense: jalomadN and julomuwdN↓ Rock: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a rock; or mass, or piece, of rock: (M:) or a round stone: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or [a stone] smaller than what is termed janodal, of such a size as that which is thrown with a ballista: (L:) or a great stone: (Ḥar p. 95:) or the latter word, [a stone] like the head of a kid; or less, such as may be carried in the hand by grasping its side but over which the two hands will not meet, with which date-stones, &c. are bruised, or brayed: (ISh:) [pl. of the former, jalaAmida; and of the latter, jalaAmiydu. Accord. to the Mgh and Mṣb, the m is an augmentative letter; but most of the lexicographers regard it as radical.]
[Hence,] raXaHa jalomaduhu, said of one known to be a niggard, meaning, † He gave something. (Ḥar p. 95.)
And OaloqaI Ealayohi jalaAmiydahu † He threw his weight (viqalahu) upon him. (Ḳ. [See AlqI Elyh mavaAqiylahu, voce mivoqaAlN.])
Also jalomadN, (L,) or jilomidN↓, (Ḳ,) A mass of rock rising out of shallow water. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)

Also, jalomadN, Many camels: (Ṣ:) or camels composing a large herd: or camels advanced in years; as also julomuwdN↓: (Ḳ:) and sheep exceeding in number a hundred: (L, Ḳ:) you say DaOonN jalomadN. (L.)
And Oxen, or cows: (L:) and the same word, (Ḳ,) or jalomadapN↓, (AA, L,) a single ox or cow. (AA, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: julomadN: see above.
jilomidN: see above.
jalomadapN applied to land (OaroDN) Stony: (Ḳ:) and jalaAmidu is [its pl.,] like jaraAwilu. (TA.)
See also jalomadN, in two places.
julomuwdN: see jalomadN, in two places.

jul-anaArN The flower of the pomegranate: an arabicized word, from GulonaAro, (Ḳ,) which is Persian, composed of Gulo “a flower,” and naAro “a pomegranate.” (MF.) It is said that whoever swallows three grains of it, of the smallest that may be, (Ḳ,) on the condition of his taking them with his mouth from the tree, before their opening, at sunrise, on a Wednesday, (Tedhkiret Dáwood, TA,) will not have ophthalmia in that year. (Ḳ.)
