hom.sense: 1. jaliha, aor. _a {yajolahu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jalahN, (Sudot;,* Mṣb, TA,) He was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in the greater part of his head. (Mṣb.) [The latter seems to be the correct meaning: see jalahN below.]
jalihato saAHatuhu His court, or yard, was, or became, vacant, or void. (JK.)
jalaha, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajolahu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jalohN, (TA,) He uncovered a thing; or removed it [from a thing that it covered or concealed]. (Ḳ, TA.)
He raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of his forehead (Eano jabiynihi), (Ḳ, TA,) [like AijotalaI,] and from the fore part of his head. (TA.)
He removed the pebbles from a place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He turned back a person from a difficult, or hard, thing or affair. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jalahN, (JK, Ṣ,) or jalohapN↓, (Ḳ,) Baldness in the fore part of the head; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is the beginning of SalaEN; like jalaHN: (Ṣ:) or baldness of the greater part of the head; (Mṣb;) more than jalaHN, (JK,) and more than SalaEN, which is more than jalaHN. (Mṣb in art. jlH.)

hom.sense: jalohapN: see jalahu.

Also The part that faces one of the brows, or brinks, or edges, of a valley: (Ṣ:) or the side of a valley; (Ḳ, TA;) the bank, or border, thereof: (TA:) or elevated parts in the interior, or lower part, of a valley, rising above the water-course, so that, when the valley flows with water, the water does not reach them: (ISh, TA:) and, some say, the mouth of a valley: and some, a part of a valley uncovered by the torrents, and so made apparent: (TA:) and [the dual] jalohataAni, (JK, M, TA,) or jalohataA waAdK, (Ṣ,) the two sides, or borders, of a valley, (Ṣ, M, TA,) when there is in them hardness: (JK, M, TA:) occurring in a trad., or, as some relate it, jalohamataAni↓, with an augmentative m: (TA:) pl. jilaAhN. (Ṣ.)
A great round rock. (JK, Ḳ.)
A large [hill, or the like, such as is called] qaArapN; as also jalohamapN↓, with an augmentative m. (TA.)
The place of alighting and abiding of a people, or company of men: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) and a yard, or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides, of their dwelling. (JK.)
And A meadow in which water collects and stagnates: pl. as above. (JK.)

Dates, (Ḳ, TA,) of which the stones have been picked out, (TA,) macerated and mashed with milk, (Ḳ,* TA,) then given to drink to women; (TA;) having a fattening property; (Ḳ, TA;) as also jaliyhapN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jalohamapN: see jalohapN, in two places.
jalahiy-apN A mode of wearing the turban, in which the jabiyn [or side of the forehead] is uncovered, so that the part where the hair grows is seen. (JK, Ṣgh.)

hom.sense: jaliyhapN A place from which the pebbles have been removed. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jalohapN, last sentence.

entry.sense: Oajolahu Bald in the fore part of the head; (Ṣ;) i. q. OajolaHu: (TA:) or [it denotes more than the latter; meaning] bald in the greater part of the head: fem. jalohaMCu: pl. julohN. (Mṣb.) [See jalahN.]
Large in the forehead, having the places of growth of the hair receding. (Ḳ.)
† A bull having no horn; (Ks, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like OajolaHu. (Ks, Ṣ.)
majoluwhN A tent, or house, or chamber, (bayotN,) in which is neither door nor curtain. (JK, Ḳ.)

julaAhiqN Bullets, syn. bunoduqN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or rounded things, (En-Naḍr, TA,) made of clay, (En-Naḍr, Mṣb, TA,) which one shoots [from a cross-bow]: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {julaAhiqapN}: (En-Naḍr, Mṣb, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (Mṣb;) in Persian julaho, meaning “a ball of thread;” pl. julahaA; applied also to “a weaver;” (Ṣ Ḳ;) i. e., jlhA is so applied. (TA.) Hence, qawosu AljulaAhiqi [The cross-bow for shooting bullets]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
jalohamapN: see art. jlh.

hom.sense: 1. jalaA, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) [aor. _u {yajoluwu},] inf. n. jalaMCN, (Mṣb,) It (a thing, and † an affair, or a case, Mgh, or † information, or tidings, Mṣb,) was, or became, clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered, (Mgh, Mṣb,) llin-aAsi to men, or the people; (Mṣb;) as also tjl-I↓, said of a thing: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) it († information, or tidings, Ṣ, Mṣb, or † an affair, or a case, Mgh,) was, or became, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) liI to me, (Ṣ,) or liln-aAsi to men, or the people. (Mṣb.) One says, tjl-t↓ AlX-amosu The sun became unobscured, or exposed to view, and ceased to be eclipsed. (TA from a trad.) Er-Rághib says that waAln-ahaAri UicaA tajal-aI↓ is sometimes by the thing itself; as in the phrase [in the Ḳur xcii. 2], falam-aA tajal-aI rab-uhu lilojabali [By the day when it becometh clear,, &c.]: and sometimes, by the case, and the action; as in the saying [in the Ḳur vii. 139], falam-aA tajal-aI rab-uhu lilojabali [And when his Lord became manifested to the mountain]: Zj says that the meaning in this instance is, appeared, and so say the Sunnees; El-Ḥasan says that the meaning is, tjl-I biAln-uwri AlEaroXi [became manifested by light, the light of the empyrean]. (TA.)

jalaA, [aor. _u {yajoluwu},] inf. n. jalaMCN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jalowN; (Ḳ;) and AjlI↓; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He, (a man, Mṣb,) or they, (a company of men, Mgh, Mṣb,) went forth, or emigrated, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) Eani Albaladi from the country, or town, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and Eano OawoTaAnihimo from their homes: (Ṣ, Mgh:) [like jal-a:] or they (a company of men) dispersed themselves, or became dispersed, Eani AlmawoDiEi, and minohu, from the place: (Ḳ:) or jlA means, in consequence of fear: and AjlI↓, in consequence of drought: (AZ, Ḳ:) or OajolawoA↓ manozilahumo signifies they left their place of abode in consequence of fear; the verb in this case being trans. by itself: but if they have left for some other reason than fear, you say, Eano manozilihimo: (Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, jalaA signifies he fled, being driven away, from his home. (TA.) [See also 12.]

jaliIa, aor. _a {yajolawu}, inf. n. jalFA, He had that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA↓; (Ḳ;) i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like jalahN: (Ṣ:) or baldness of half of the head; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (Ṣ:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN. (Ḳ.) And jalA Aljabiyni, inf. n. jalFA, signifies the same as jaliIa [The part above the temple became bald]. (AʼObeyd, TA.)

jalaAhu, [aor. _u {yajoluwu}, inf. n., app., jilaMCN, or perhaps jalaMCN, but the former seems to be indicated by what follows;] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) and jl-Ahu↓; (MA;) He made it, or rendered it, clear, or unobscured; exposed it to view, displayed it, laid it open, disclosed it, or uncovered it; (Ṣ, Mgh, MA;) namely, a thing: (Ṣ, Mgh:) he made it, or rendered it, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, MA;) namely, † an affair, (Mgh,) or † information, or tidings. (Mṣb.) You say, jalaA AlEaruwsa, inf. n. jilaMCN and jilowapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jalowapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and julowapN; (Ḳ;) and AjtlAhA↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He displayed the bride, EalaI baEolihaA to her husband: (Ḳ:) or he looked at the bride displayed: (Ṣ:)
and you say also, juliyato EalaI zawojihaA (TA) She mas shown to her husband, and he looked at her displayed: (Ḥar p. 30:) and jalaAhaA zawojuhaA Her husband presented, or gave, to her a female slave (Ṣ, Ḳ) or some other thing at the time of her being displayed to him; as also jl-AhA↓: (Ḳ:) and jalati AlmaAXiTapu AlEaruwsa The female hairdresser adorned the bride [to display her to her husband]. (TA.) You also say, jalaA fulaAnN AlOamora ‡ Such a one displayed, discovered, disclosed, revealed, or manifested, the affair, or case; as also jl-Ahu↓, and jalaA Eanohu: (Ḳ,* TA:) or jalaA fulaAnFA AlOamori he displayed, discovered,, &c., to such a one the affair, or case; as also jl-Ah↓ [i. e. jl-Ahu AlOamora], and jalaA Eanohu [i. e. jlA Enh AlOamora or jlA fulaAnFA Eani AlOamori]. (So accord. to the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ. [The reading in the TA is, in my opinion, preferable to the latter.]) And Aall-ehu yujal-iI↓ Als-aAEapa † God will make manifest the hour, or time of the resurrection; or will make it to appear. (Ḳ in art. jlI: [but it belongs to the present art.:]) so in the Ḳur vii. 186. (TA.) And huwa yujal-iI↓ Eano nafosihi † He declares, or explains, his mind. (Ṣ.)

jalawotu Als-ayofa, inf. n. jilaMCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK jalAC, but it is]) with kesr, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and jalowN, (Ḳ,) I removed, or cleared off, the rust from the sword; (Mṣb;) I polished, or furbished, the sword; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AlmiroMpa the mirror; (Ḳ;) and the like; (TA;) [as, for instance,] AlfiD-apa the silver; and so jalayotuhaA. (Ḳ in art. jlI.) And jalawotu baSariI biAlkuHoli [I cleared my sight with collyrium]: (Ṣ:) [whence,] jalaA He applied collyrium to his eye or eyes. (IAạr, TA.) And jalawotu ham-iI Ean-iI ‡ I removed my anxiety, or caused it to depart, from me: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:*) and AjlI↓ Eanohu Alham-a † He removed, or cleared away, from him anxiety. (Lth, TA.) And jalaA Qll-ehu Eanohu AlmaraDa † God removed from him the disease. (TA.)

jalaAhumo, and AjlAhm↓, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or jalaAhu, and AjlAhu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AjtlAhu↓, (Ḳ,) He, (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb, or the Sultán, Mgh,) or it, (drought, Ḳ,) caused them, or him, to go forth, or emigrate; or expelled them, or him; or drove them, or him, forth; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [from their homes, or from his home.] And jalaA Aln-aHoli, inf. n. jilaMCN, or jalaMCN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) and jlwp [thus written without any syll. signs]; and AjtlAhA↓; (TA;) He smoked [out] the bees, in order to collect the honey; (Ḳ;) he drove away the bees by means of smoke. (TA.)
2. jl-I: see 1, in six places.

Also, inf. n. tajoliyapN and tajoliI-N, He (a hawk, or falcon,) raised his head, and looked, (Ḳ, TA,) seeing the prey: (TA:) or he (a hawk) closed his eyes, and then opened them, in order to see more clearly. (Ibn-Hamzeh, TA.)
And [hence,] jl-I bibaSarihi, inf. n. tajoliyapN, He cast his eyes (Ṣ, Ḳ) like the hawk looking at the prey. (Ṣ.)

[jl-I is also mentioned (in Ḥar p. 161), on the authority of Mṭr, as signifying He, or it, outstripped; from Almujal-iI meaning “the first of the horses in a race;” but as being not known in this sense on any other authority.]

entry.sense: 3. jaAlayotuhu biAlOamori, inf. n. mujaAlaApN, I acted openly with him in the affair; as also jaAlaHotuhu. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 4. AjlI as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places.
Oajolawo Eani Alqatiyli They cleared themselves away, or removed, from the slain person. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)

AjlI yaEoduw He hastened, running: (Ḳ:) or hastened somewhat, running: (TA:) or AjlI signifies he became distant, or remote, and hastened. (So accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, where we find waOajolaI baEuda waOasoraEa instead of waOajolaI yaEoduw OasoraEa.)
As a trans. v.: see 1, in four places.
5. tjl-I: see 1, in three places:
and see also 7.
tjl-I AlX-aIoCa He looked at the thing, (Ḳ in art. jlI,) standing upon a higher position. (TA.) [See also 8.]

entry.sense: 6. tajaAlayonaA Our states, or conditions, became disclosed to each other; the state, or condition, of each of us to the other. (Ṣ.)

7. AnjlI It became removed, or cleared away; said of anxiety, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) and of an affair [&c.]; as also tjl-I↓. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, AnjlI Eanohu Alham-u Anxiety became removed, or cleared away, from him, (Ṣ,) kamaA tanojaliI AlZ-ulomapu like as the darkness becomes removed, or cleared away. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AjtlAhu He looked at him, or it. (Ḳ.) [See also 5.] Hence, AjtlI AlEaruwsa, explained above: see 1. (TA.)
See also 1 in two other places, last two sentences.
Aijotalayotu AlEimaAmapa Eano raOosiI I raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of my forehead (Eano jabiyniI): (Ṣ:) [like jalahotuhaA.]
AjtlI It became polished, or furbished; said of a sword [&c.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 12. AjlwlI He went forth, or emigrated, from one country, or town, to another. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [See also 1.]

Aibonu jalaA ‡ A man who is well known, celebrated, or notable; (Mgh;) of whom it is said, jalaA AlOumuwra, i. e. he has made affairs clear, unobscured, or manifest; (Ṣ, Mgh;) or jalaA Oamoruhu, i. e. his case has become clear, unobscured, or manifest: (Mgh:) or one whose case is clear, apparent, plainly apparent, or manifest; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Aibonu OajolaI↓: (Ḳ:) applied to a man who is upon an elevated and conspicuous place; and applied by El-Hajjáj to himself, as meaning that he was one whom every one knew: (TA:) and also, (Ḳ,) for this reason, (TA,) the name of a certain man, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) of the Benoo-Leyth, who was a person of great daring. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, Soheym Ibn-Wetheel Er-Riyáhee, (TA,)
OanaA Qbonu jalaA waTal-aAEu Alv-anaAyaA
mataI OaDiEa AlEimaAmapa taEorifuwniI
[I am a man well known, celebrated, or notable,, &c.; and he who rises to eminences, or who is accustomed to embark in, or surmount, lofty and difficult things: when I put down the turban, ye will know me]. (Ṣ, TA.) Sb says, (TA,) jlA in this case is a verb in the pret. tense: ʼEesà Ibn-ʼOmar says that when a man is named qatala or Daraba or the like, the word is imperfectly decl.; and he adduces, in evidence, this verse: others say that jlA may be here without tenween because it is imitative of a phrase, as though the poet said, OanaA Qbonu Al-aciI yuqaAlu lahu jalaA AlOumuwri: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to IB, it is without tenween because it is a verb with its agent [implied in it]. (TA.)
Accord. to some, it signifies † The daybreak, or dawn; (Ḥar p. 498;) and so Aibonu OajolaI↓: (TA:) accord. to Hamzeh, † the beginning of day: and accord. to some, † the moon. (Ḥar ubi suprà)

hom.sense: jalFA: see 1, voce jaliIa:
and see jilaMCN.

entry.sense: jilFA: see jilaMCN.

jilowapN A female slave, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or some other thing, (Ḳ,) that is presented, or given, by the husband to his bride at the time of her being displayed to him. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) One says, maA jilowatuhaA [What is her bridal present?]; and is answered, “Such a thing.” (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: jalaMCN A thing, an affair, or a case, that is apparent, manifest, plain, or evident. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And Acknowledgment, or confession: so in the saying of Zuheyr:
faUin-a AlHaq-a maqoTaEuhu valaAvN
yamiynN Oawo nifaArN Oawo jalaMCN
[For verily the means of deciding the truth are three: an oath, and incongruity of circumstances, and acknowledgment, or confession]: (Ṣ:) but Az writes the last word jilaMC↓, with kesr to the j, as meaning an evidence, or a proof, and witnesses; from mujaAlaApN [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (TA.)
Oaqamotu Einodahu jalaMCayawomiI, (Ḳ, TA,) or jalaMCa yawomK, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) [I remained with him, or at his abode,] during the whiteness of my, or a, day. (Zj, Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
jilaMCN: see the paragraph next preceding.

Also, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) written by El-Muhellebee jalaMCN↓, (TA,) and jalFA↓, which is more correct than the first, (Mgh,) or it is allowable, as also jilFA↓, the former of the last two mentioned on the authority of En-Naḥḥás, (TA,) Collyrium: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a particular kind thereof, (Ḳ, TA,) that clears the sight; (TA;) [i. e.] i. q. UivomidN [antimony, or an ore of antimony]; (Mgh, TA;) so called because it clears the sight. (Mgh.)
maAjilaAWuhu What is his honourable name, or surname, (Ṣ,) or his good surname, (Ḳ,) by which he is addressed? (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaliI-N Clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered: apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) jaAlK thus used has not been heard. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It is applied as an epithet to information, or tidings, (Mṣb, TA,) and to analogy, or rule. (TA.)
EayonN jaliy-apN A seeing eye. (IB, TA.)
jaliy-apN Sure information or tidings. (Ṣ.)
OaxobaraniI Eano jaliy-apN AlOamori He informed me of the true, or real, state of the affair, or case. (TA.)
dawaMCN jal-aMCN [A medicine that clears the complexion or skin]. (Ḳ voce fuw-apN, &c.)
jiliy-aAnN The act of rendering apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: rendering clear, or unobscured; exposing to view, displaying, laying open, disclosing, or uncovering. (TA.)

hom.sense: Hence, (Mṣb,) jaAliyapN↓ [as a subst.] is applied to The poll-tax that is exacted from the persons last mentioned above; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also jaAl-apN: (Ṣ:) first, in this sense, applied to that which was exacted from the people expelled from Arabia by ʼOmar. (Mṣb.) You say, AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaI AljaAliyapi [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
See also jaAYilN, in art. jwl.

entry.sense: jaAliyapN (as a subst.): see what next precedes.

hom.sense: OajolaI Having that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA; i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head: or baldness of half of the head; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (Ṣ:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN: (Ḳ:) or baldness of half of the head, and the like: (AʼObeyd, TA:) fem. jalowaMCN. (Ḳ.) [See OajolaHu.]
Beautiful, or handsome, in face, bald in the sides of the forehead. (Ḳ.)
jabohapN jalowaMCu A wide forehead. (Ḳ.)
samaMCN jalowaMCN † A cloudless sky: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and layolapN jalowaMCu † a cloudless, bright, night. (TA.)
Aibonu OajolaI: see Aibonu jalaA, in two places.
Also (i. e. Abn AjlI) † The lion. (TA.)
faEalotuhu mino OajolaAka, and UijolaAka↓, I did it on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino Oajolika. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: faEalotuhu mino UijolaAka: see what next precedes.
majolFI sing. of majaAlK, which signifies The fore parts of the head, which are the [first] places of baldness: (Fr, Ṣ:) or what is seen of the head when one fronts the face. (TA.)
mujolK [act. part. n. of 4. Hence,] faUim-aA HarobN mujoliyapN waUim-aA silomN muxoziyapN And either war that shall cause you to emigrate, or abasing peace. (TA.)
Almujol-iI The first of the horses in a race. (Ḳ in art. jlI.)

dictScrap.label: Some words are mentioned in the Ḳ under this head belonging to art. jlw, q. v.

hom.sense: 1. jam-a, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajomimu}, inf. n. jam-N, (Mṣb,) said of water, (Ṣ,), &c., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) It became much, or abundant; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also Astjm↓; said of a thing: (TA:) and, said of water,, aor. _u {yajomumu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yajomimu}, (Ḳ,) the former of which is of the higher authority, (TA,) inf. n. jumuwmN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) it became much, or abundant, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) in the well, (Ṣ,) and collected (Ṣ, Ḳ) after it had been drawn from; (Ṣ;) as also Astjm-↓. (Ḳ.) And jam-uwA They became many. (TA.)

jam-ati AlbiYoru, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajomumu} and _i, inf. n. jumuwmN, (TA,) The water of the well returned by degrees, (Ḳ, TA,) and became much, or abundant, and collected; (TA;) and Astjm-t↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, jam-ato mavaAbapN jaholihi, a tropical phrase, explained in art. vwb.]
jam-a Alkayolu, inf. n. jumaAmN, with damm, The measure became full or filled. (KL. [But only the inf. n. is there mentioned: so that the verb may be jum-a, which see below.])

jam-a Alfarasu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajomumu} and _i, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jamaAmN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jam-N; (Ṣ;) and Astjm-↓; (Ṣ;) The horse abstained from covering, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so that his seminal fluid (maAWuhu) collected. (Ḳ.)

Also, (aor. of the former verb as above, TA, and inf. n. jam-N and jamaAmN, Ṣ, Ḳ,) The fatigue of the horse went away; (Ṣ;) [he recovered his strength after fatigue;] he recovered from his fatigue, being left unridden; (Ḳ, TA;) and so Oajam-a↓ [of which see also the pass. form, below]. (M, Ḳ.)
[And hence,] jam-a, [inf. n. jamaAmN, q. v. infrà,] He rested; said of a man [as well as of a horse]; (TA;) and so Astjm-↓. (Ḥar p. 324.)
Also, said of a bone, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jam-N, (TA,) It had much flesh; its flesh became much, or abundant. (Ḳ.)
Also i. q. EalaA [He, or it, became high,, &c.: perhaps said of water in a well]. (T, TA.)
Also, inf. n. jumuwmN, He rose (AirotafaEa) in his pace, or going. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. jam-N (TA) and jumuwmN, (Ṣ, TA,) said of an event, (Ḳ,) of the arrival of a person, (Ṣ,) It drew near; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) it came to pass: (Ṣ:) and Ajm-↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of an event, of separation from another, (Ṣ, TA,) and of an object of want: (TA:) AHm-, [q. v.,] with the unpointed H, in this sense, was not known to Aṣ. (TA.)
And, said of the naSiI-, and the Sil-iyaAn, [two plants, inf. n. not mentioned,] It attained to the state of having a jum-ap [app. meaning tuft, or flower-bud]. (TA.)

jam-a AlkaboXi, (TA,) or jamimati AlX-aApu, [perhaps a mistranscription for jam-at,] aor. _a {yajomamu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jamamN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) The ram, (TA,) or sheep or goat, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) was hornless. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

jam-ahu, (Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yajomumu}, accord. to rule,] inf. n. jam-N, (TA,) He left it (namely, water [in a well],) to collect; as also Ajm-hu↓. (Ḳ.) And jum-ati AlbiYoru [The well was left for its water to collect]. (TA.) And Astjm-↓ AlbiYora He left the well for some days until its water should collect: whence the metaphorical phrase, kaAna yasotajim-u↓ mavaAbapu safahihi, [explained in art. vwb,] occurring in a trad. (Ḥar p. 68.)

Also He filled it (namely, a measure, Ṣ, such as is called mak-uwk, Ḳ) so that it had what is termed jumaAmN; and so Ajm-hu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and jm-mhu↓. (Ḳ.) And jum-a It was filled. (T, TA.) See also jam-N, last sentence.
2. jm-mt AlOaroDu The jamiym [q. v.] of the land became full, or abundant. (ISh, TA.)
He made a jum-ap [q. v.] of his hair. (Z, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence but two.
4. Ajm-, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in two places.
Ajm-hu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places.
He left him unridden, so that he recovered from his fatigue; namely, a horse. (Ḳ.) And Oujim-a He (a horse) was left unridden. (Ṣ.)

[Hence, He rested him, or gave him rest.] You say, Oajomimo nafosaka yawomFA Oawo yawomayoni [Rest thyself a day, or two days]. (Ṣ.) And hence, in a trad. respecting the safarojalap [or quince], tujim-u AlfuWaAda, i. e. It rests the heart, and consolidates it, and completes its soundness and liveliness. (TA.) One says also, Uin-iI laOasotajim-u↓ qalobiI biX-aIoCK mina All-ahowi liOaqowaI bihi EalaI AlHaq-i [Verily I relieve my heart with somewhat of diversion, in order that I may become strong thereby for that which is substantial, or solid, not vain or frivolous]. (Ṣ.) And Ajm- AlOaroDa He gave the land rest from tilling. (TA in art. bxE.)
He gave him the jam-ap [or supply of water, that had collected after drawing,] of the well. (Th. TA.)
Oujim-a AlEinabu The grape-vine had all its branches that were above the ground cut off. (AḤn, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 2.

hom.sense: 10. Astj-m, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in five places.
Astjm-t AlOaroDu The land put forth its plants, or herbage, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it became like the [hair termed] jm-p [i. e. jum-ap]. (TA.)
As a trans. verb: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places:
and see 4.
Ausotujim-ato jam-apu AlmaMCi [The supply of water that had collected after drawing] was drunk. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. jamojama, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jamojamapN, (Ḳ,) He spoke indistinctly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not from impotence, or, accord. to the T, from impotence; (TA;) and tajamojama↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, Ḳ,) with which majomajapN is syn., accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, (Mgh,) He concealed (Mgh, Ḳ, TA) speech, (Mgh,) or a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) in his bosom. (Mgh, Ḳ, TA.) You say, jmjm XayoYFA fiI Sadorihi He concealed a thing in his bosom; did not reveal it. (TA.)
Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr, Ḳ,) He destroyed, or killed, (Kr, Ḳ, TA,) another or others. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. tajamojama: see R. Q. 1.
Hence, tjmjm Eani AlOamori ‡ [He held back from the thing, not daring to do it;] he did not dare to do the thing. (Ḥam p. 240.)

hom.sense:
jam-N, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Mṣb,) Much, or many; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jamiymN↓ accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly jamama↓, as in the L. (TA.) You say maAlN jam-N (Mṣb, TA) and jamama↓ (TA) Muck property, or many cattle. (Mṣb.) And it is said in the Ḳur [lxxxix. 21], wayuHib-uwna AlmaAla Hub-FA jam-FA (Ṣ) And they love property with much love. (AʼObeyd, TA.) Aboo-Khirásh El-Hudhalee says,
Uino tagofiri Ql-elhuma tagofiro jam-aA . (TA) i. c. [If thou forgive, O God, Thou forgivest] much sin. (Mgh.) jam-e AlbuEaAqi, in a trad. respecting prayer for rain, means Copious, abundant, extensive rain. (TA in art. bEq.)

The greater, or main, portion of the Zahiyrap [i. e. midday, or mid-day in summer, &c.]: and of water; as also jam-apN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or jum-apN↓: (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and accord. to the TA: [the former app. the right: if it were the latter, the author of the Ḳ, accord. to a rule which he has seldom neglected, would have added biAlD-am-i; as SM has here done, unless his transcriber have thus written by mistake for biAlfatoHi:]) or jam-N signifies the water, of a well, that has collected [after it has been drawn from]: and jam-apN↓, the place in which the water collects: (Ṣ:) and also, this last, the water itself: (TA: [i. e. the supply of water that has collected after drawing: see 4, last sentence but one; and see 4, last sentence:]) the pl. (of jam-apN Ṣ [or of th is and of jam-N also]) is jimaAmN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jumuwmN. (Ḳ.)
biYorN jam-apN: see jamuwmN.
jam-N also signifies People of the lowest, or basest, or meanest sort. (T, TA.)
Also The measuring to the head of the measure; [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is jam-a↓; see 1, last sentence but two;] and so jamaAmN↓ and jumaAmN↓ and jimaAmN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jam-apN: see jam-N, in two places.
Also The part, or place, of a ship, in which collects the water that leaks from its xuruwz [or seams: in the CK xuruwr]: (Ḳ:) a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jum-apN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 746,) A company demanding a bloodwit (Ṣ, Ḳ) or an obligation that must be discharged, (TA, and Ḥam ubi suprà,) or peace; or coming for some other purpose: (Ḥam:) pl. jmm [probably jumamN, pl. of the latter, or perhaps of both; or it may be jimamN, as pl. of both]. (TA.) You say, jaMCa fiI jam-apK EaZiymapK and jum-apK↓ EZymp He came in a great company, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jum-apN: see jam-N:
and see also jam-apN, in two places.

Also The collective mass of the hair of the head, or the head of hair, (mujotamaEa XaEori Alr-aOosi Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) when more in quantity than what is termed waforap: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or the collective mass of the hair (mujotamaEu AlX-aEori) when it hangs down from the head to the lobe of the ear, and to the two shoulder-joints, and more than that; what does not extend beyond the ears being termed wfrp: (TA:) or the collective mass (mujotamaEa) of the hair of the naASiyap [or anterior part of the head]: accord. to some, what reaches to the two shoulder-joints: (Mṣb:) in the M it is said to signify the hair; and in like manner in the Deewán el-Adab: but ISd adds that it is also said to mean hair more in quantity than that which is termed lim-ap: accord. to IAth, the hair of the head that falls upon the two shoulder-joints: in the Muhedhdhib, what extends beyond the ears: in the Mukaddameh of Z, what extends to the lobe of the ear: accord. to IDrd, much hair: (TA:) [see also lim-apN and waforapN:] pl. jumamN (Mṣb, TA) and jimaAmN: (TA:) dim. jumayomapN↓. (TA.) Hence, raOaI lumoEapF fagasalahaA bijum-atihi, meaning [He saw a spot, and washed it] by a moistening of his jm-p: or with the water of his jm-p: the prefixed noun being suppressed. (Mgh.)

Also [app. † A flower-bud;] the qbp [rendered by Golius “nodosior pars”] of a plant, from which the flower comes forth. (KL.) [See an ex. above, voce jam-a. If from jum-apN applied to hair, it would seem rather to mean A tuft.]
One says also, Hacafa jum-apu Aljawozapi vum-a OakalahaA ‡ [app. meaning He threw away the husk of the walnut: then ate it]. (TA.)
jamamN: see jam-N, in two places:
and see also jumaAmN.
jamaAmN A state of resting; (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jamaAmapN↓: (TA:) particularly of a horse. (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb.) [See jam-a, of which it is an inf. n.]
See also jam-N, last sentence: and see what next follows.

Also, and jimaAmN↓ and jamaAmN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [but see what follows,] The quantity [of flour or the like] that rises above the head of the [measure termed] mak-uwk, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) after the filling, (Mgh,) exceeding the TafaAf thereof; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also jamamN↓: (Ḳ:) or the fill of a bowl, without a head: accord. to ISk, only said of flour and the like: one says, OaEoTaAniI jmAma AlqadaHi daqiyqFA [He gave me the bowlful of flour]: but jmAm meaning the “resting” of a horse is with fet-ḥ only: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Fr, one says jimaAmN↓ AlqadaHi AlmaMCF, with kesr, meaning the bowlful of water; and jumaAmu Almak-uwki daqiyqFA, with damm; and jamaAmN Alfarasi, with fet-ḥ only; and one does not say jumaAmN, with damm, except in relation to flour and the like, meaning the quantity that rises above the head of the mk-wk, after the being filled: one says, OaEoTiniI jumaAma Almak-uwki when one puts what the head of the mk-wk will bear, and gives it: (Ṣ, TA:) in the T, it is said that OaEoTihi jmAma Almak-uwki means Give thou him [the quantity of] a mk-wk without a head: but [SM says,] I have seen in its margin written that the right meaning is, the quantity borne by the head of the mk-wk. (TA.)
See also jam-N, last sentence.

hom.sense: jimaAmN: see jumaAmN, in three places:
and jam-N, last sentence:
and see also jumojumapN.
It is also a pl. of jam-apN (Ṣ) [and perhaps of jam-N likewise: (see this latter:)] and of jum-apN. (TA.)

entry.sense: biYorN jamuwmN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jam-apN↓ (Ḳ) A well of much water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
farasN jamuwmN A horse that, after any run, runs again; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to the female as well as the male: (T, TA:) a horse that goes much. (KL.)

jamiymN A plant, or herbage, that has grown somewhat, but not attained its full height: (Ṣ:) or much, or abundant, herbage: (Ḳ:) or herbage standing up and spreading: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or that has grown up until it has become like the jum-ap of hair: (TA:) a plant, or herbage, when it first appears in the ground is termed baAriDN; then, jamiymN; then, busorapN; then, SamoEaMCu; and then, [when it is dry,] HaXiyXN: (Ṣ in art. bsr:) pl. Oajim-aMCu. (Ḳ.) And, with p {jamiymapN}, A [plant of the kind termed] naSiy-ap that has become half a month old, so that it fills the mouth. (Ḳ.)
See also jam-N.
jamaAmapN: see jamaAmN.
Also The state of being satiated, or satisfied, with food, and with drink. (TA.)
jumayomapN dim. of jum-apN, q. v. (TA.)
jum-aI The bean, or beans; syn. baAqil-aI. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
jum-iI: see jum-aAniI-N.
jam-aAmN: see what next follows.

jam-aAnN A measure, (Ṣ,) such as is called mak-uwk, (Ḳ,) filled so as to have what is termed jumaAm; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jam-aAmN↓: (Ḳ:) [fem. of the former jam-aI. Hence,] jumojumapN jam-aI [A] full [bowl]. (Ḳ. In the CK jamojamapN.)

jum-aAniI-N, with n, (Ṣ,) an irreg. rel. n., applied to a man, (Sb, Ṣ,) Having a long jum-ap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having a great and long jum-ap: (Sb, TA:) but if you name a person jum-ap, the rel. n. formed from it is jum-iI-N↓ (Sb, Ṣ) only. (Sb, TA.)
jumojumN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: jumojumapN The skull; i. e. the bone that contains the brain: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or i. q. qiHofN [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull]: (Ḳ:) or the bones of the head; (IAạr, Mgh, TA;) all of them; the uppermost of them being the haAmap; (IAạr, TA;) or the hAmp is the jmjmp altogether; (ISh, TA;) and the qHf is said to be a piece of the jmjmp: (TA:) pl. jumojumN↓, (Ḳ,) [or this (in the CK, erroneously, jamojamN) is a coll. gen. n.,] and jamaAjimu [is the pl. properly so called, and that which is more commonly known]. (TA.)

Sometimes it is used to signify A man; so that one says, xucuwA mino kul-i jumojumapK dirohamFA [Take ye from every man, or head, a dirhem]; like as one says, mino kul-i raOosK: (Mṣb:) and waDaEa AlUimaAmu AlxaraAja EalaI AljamaAjimi EalaI kul-i jumojumapK kacaA [The Imám imposed the tax, or land-tax, upon the heads; upon every head so much]. (Mgh.)
A wooden bowl: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a bowl of glass; as also qiHofN. (Az, TA.)
A kind of measure for corn or the like. (Ḳ.)

Also † Chiefs, or lords, of the Arabs; because the jmjmp is the head, which is the most noble of the members: (TA:) also, (TA,) [the pl.] jamaAjimu has this meaning. (T, Ḳ, TA.) And † Any sons of a father that are persons of might, or power, and eminence, or nobility: (T, TA:) and [the pl.] jamaAjimu the tribes (qabaAYil) of the Arabs which comprise buTuwn, and in relation to which persons are called; as Kelb Ibn-Webreh; for when you say kalobiI-N, you do not need to call the person in relation to any of the bTwn: (Ṣ:) or the tribes (qbAYl) in relation to which the bTwn are called; as also jimaAmN↓. (Ḳ.)
A well that is dug in salt ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Sixty head of camels. (IF, IB, TA.)
jamaAjimu AlHaArivi The piece of wood at the head of which is the ploughshare. (TA.)

Oajam-u [Greater, and greatest, in quantity, and in number,, &c.: fem. jam-aMCu. Hence,] waAlwaHoIu Oajam-u maA kaAna, in a trad. of Anas, means The revelation being the most that it used to be. (Sh, TA.)

A bone having much flesh. (Ḳ.) You say also AimoraOapN jam-aMCu AlEiZaAmi A woman having much flesh (Ḳ, TA) on the bones. (TA.) And AimoraOapN jam-aMCu AlmaraAfiqi [A woman having much flesh on the elbows: or, as seems to be indicated by J, having no prominence of the elbows; and if so, from jam-aMCu applied to a ewe, in a sense explained in what follows]. (Ṣ.)

jaAWuwA Aljam-aMCa Algafiyra, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and jam-aMCa gafiyrFA, &c.,] and jam-FA↓ gafiyrFA, (Ḳ,) [and Aljam-a↓ Algafiyra, &c.,] They came all together, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. gfr:) see art. gfr. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Hornless, applied to a ram (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) or he-goat; (Mṣb;) and so jam-aMCu applied to a ewe (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) or she-goat: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. jum-N. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

And [hence,] ‡ A man having no spear (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in war or battle: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) The pl. is also applied to horses, (Ṣ,) meaning † whose owners have no spears; the spears being regarded as the horses' horns. (Ḥam, p. 90.)
Also † A building having no [acroterial ornaments such as are termed] Xuraf: (Ṣ:) and the pl., † Mosques having no Xuraf (Mgh, TA) upon them, (TA,) [i. e.] upon their walls. (Mgh.)
† A flat house-top having no parapet, or surrounding wall. (TA.)
† Short; having no elevation. (TA.)
† A woman's anterior pudendum. (Ḳ.)
And, as being likened thereto, or the reverse may be the case, (TA,) † A bowl. (Ḳ.)
Also, the fem., † Smooth. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

And hence, because of its smoothness, (IAạr, TA,) † A helmet: (IAạr, Ḳ:) to which the epithet gafiyrN [q. v.] is applied because it covers the head: but this meaning of “a helmet” was not known to ISd on any other authority than that of IAạr. (TA.)

entry.sense: majam-N A place where water remains: or to which it reaches, and where it ends. (TA.)

† The breast, or bosom, or mind: (Ḳ, TA:) because it is the place in which are collected the knowledge, &c. that it retains. (TA.) You say, huwa waAsiEu Almajam-i, i. e. raHobu Alc-iraAEi waAsiEu AlS-adori ‡ [He is possessed of ample power and might, and free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind]. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.) And Uin-ahu laDay-iqu Almajam-i ‡ Verily he is contracted, or straitened, in mind by affairs, or events. (IAạr, TA.)
majam-apN A thing in which resting is usually known to take place. (TA.)
mujam-amN A boy (IDrd, TA) having a head of hair such as is termed a jum-ap. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)
mujam-imapN A woman who makes her hair to form a jum-ap, to make herself like a man: the doing of which is forbidden. (TA.)

1. jamaHa, aor. _a {yajomaHu}, inf. n. jimaAHN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and jumuwHN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jamoHN, (Ḳ,) or this last has not been heard, (Mgh,) He (a horse) overcame his rider, or gained the mastery over him, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) running away with him: (L:) or broke loose, or ran away, (Mṣb,) and went at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or ran so as to have the mastery over his rider: (Ḥam p. 568:) and jamaHa biraAkibihi (A, Mgh, Mṣb) he overcame his rider, (A, Mgh,) and ran away so that he could not govern him: (A:) or became refractory, so that he overcame his rider: (Mṣb:) and sometimes, (Mṣb,) this verb also signifies he was quick, or swift, (A, Mṣb,) and brisk, lively, or sprightly; denoting in this case a quality that is approved; whereas in the senses before explained it denotes a quality that is disapproved: but in the last sense it is obsolete [unless tropically applied to a man]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] † He (said of anything [i. e. of a man or any animal]) went at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course. (TA.) And † He (said of a man, Ṣ, L) hastened, or went quickly, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) Uilayohi to him, or it, so that his course was not turned for anything. (L, TA.) wahumo yajomaHuwna, in the Ḳur [ix. 57], means † They hastening, or going quickly: (AO, Ṣ, L:) or hastening so that nothing turns them back, like the horse that is termed jamuwH: (Bḍ, Jel:) or running like horses that overcome their riders and run away so as to be ungovernable by them. (A.) And jamaHa fiI Uivorihi, occurring in a trad., † He hastened after him, or it, so that nothing turned him back. (L.)

jamaHati AlmaroOapu ‡ The woman went forth from the place where she used to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband. (Mṣb.) And jamaHato mino zawojihaA, so in the Ṣ and L, &c., but in the Ḳ jamaHato zawojahaA, [which is evidently a mistake,] (TA,) ‡ She went forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, before he divorced her; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) inf. n. jimaAHN. (L, TA.) And jamaHato UilaI OaholihaA ‡ She went to her family without the permission of her husband. (A.)
jamaHati Als-afiynapu ‡ The ship quitted her course, (A, TA,) and became ungovernable by the sailors; inf. n. jumuwHN. (TA.)
jamaHati AlmafaAzapu biAlqawomi ‡ The desert led the people, or party, far away, by reason of its great extent. (A, TA.)
jamaHa bihi muraAduhu ‡ The object of his desire baffled his efforts to attain it. (A, TA.)

jamoHapu [A trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him]. You say, daAb-apN samoHapN maA bihaA jamoHapN walaA ramoHapN [A beast submissive, or easy, or gentle: there is not in her a trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him, nor a trick of kicking]. (A.)

jamuwHN (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaAmiHN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb) A horse that overcomes his rider, or gains the mastery over him, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) being refractory, (Mṣb,) and runs away with him, (L,) or runs away so that his rider cannot govern him, (A,) or goes away at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh:) or that will not bend his head: (TA:) the former epithet, (T, Mgh, TA,) and the latter, (Mgh, Mṣb,) applied alike to the horse and the mare: (T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and the former has two meanings; one denoting what is a fault, for which the horse may be returned; (T, Mgh, TA;) i. e., that habitually takes his own way, so that his rider cannot turn him from it; (T, TA;) or as explained before; (Mgh;) the other meaning being quick, or swift, and brisk, lively, and sprightly; and this does not imply a fault (T, Mgh, TA) for which he may be returned. (T, TA.)

[Hence,] † Anything [i. e. a man or any animal] that goes at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course: (TA:) and the former epithet, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or each of the two, (Ṣ,* A,) ‡ a man who follows his own natural desire, without consideration, not obeying a guide to the right course of conduct, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that he cannot be turned back. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And jum-aAHN↓ [is pl. of jaAmiHN↓, accord. to analogy, and] signifies † Men routed, defeated, or put to flight, in war. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

mafaAzapN jamuwHN † [A desert that leads one far away, by reason of its great extent: see 1, last sentence but one: likened to a horse that is termed jamuwH]: occurring in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (TA in art. nHb.)

hom.sense: jum-aAHN An arrow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a small arrow, (L,) without an iron point, having a round head, with which the art of shooting is learned (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) by a boy: (Ṣ, L:) or one with which boys play, putting upon its head a date or some clay, in order that it may not wound: (L:) or it signifies also a date put upon the head of a piece of wood, with which boys play: (Ḳ:) birds are shot at with it, and knocked down, without being killed, so that the shooter takes them: and it is also called jub-aAHN: (T, TA:) or a boy's arrow, upon the end of which he puts a lump of chewed dates of the size of the EifaAD [here meaning stopper] of a bottle, in order that it (the end) may go more directly, and be smooth; without feathers, and sometimes without a notch. (AḤn, L.)

Also That [kind of plant] at the extremities of which come forth what resemble ears of wheat, soft, (L, Ḳ,) like foxes' tails, or (L) resembling the heads of the HaliI- and the Sil-iyaAn and the like: (L, Ḳ:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {jum-aAHapN}: (L:) pl. jamaAmiyHu; and in poetry jamaAmiHu; (L, Ḳ;) the latter allowable only in cases of necessity. (L.)
See also jamuwHN.

entry.sense: jaAmiHN: see jamuwHN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. jamada, aor. _u {yajomudu}, inf. n. jamodN and jumuwdN, said of water, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,), &c., (Mṣb,) [i. e.,] of anything fluid, or liquid, (Ḳ,) It congealed; concreted; became solid, or contr. of fluid or liquid; froze; syn. qaAma; (Ṣ, M;) contr. of caAba; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jamuda. (L, Ḳ.) And said of blood, &c., (Ṣ, M,) It congealed, or concreted; syn. qAm: (M:) or became dry; dried. (Ṣ.) See also 2.
Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, † He, or it, remained fixed, or stationary. (KL.) You say, maA zilotu OaDoribuhu Hat-aI jamada ‡ [I ceased not to beat him until he became motionless]. (A.)
† [He, or it, was, or became, incapable of growth or increase; lifeless, or dead: see jaAmidN.]

[† He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance: see, again, jaAmidN.]
Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, ‡ said of a man's state or condition [as meaning, It was, or became, stagnant, or unimproving]. (A.)
Also jamadato, aor. _u {yajomudu}, inf. n. jumuwdN, ‡ She [a camel, &c.,] had little milk. (T, TA.) And jamadato Eayonuhu ‡ His eye shed few tears: a phrase alluding to hardness of the heart. (Mṣb.)

Also jamada, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajomudu}, (L,) [inf. n. jumuwdN;] and Oajomada↓; (A, TA; [in a copy of the A, Anjmd, but this is doubtless a mistranscription; see mujomidN;]) ‡ He was, or became, niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (L, A, Ḳ;) as also jamada kaf-uhu [or jamadato]; (Mṣb;) or jamadato yaduhu: (A:) and Ajmd↓ he possessed little good: (A, TA:) or jumuwdN signifies the refraining, or holding back, from beneficence. (Ḥar p. 149.)
jamada liI Ealayohi Haq-iI ‡ My right, or due, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established against him; (A, Ḳ,* TA;) as also caAba. (A, TA.)
jamadahu He cut it, or cut it off. (Ḳ.)

2. jm-d, inf. n. tajomiydN; (Ḳ;) or jamada↓; (so in the L;) It (water, and expressed juice, L) was about to congeal, concrete, become solid, or freeze; was at the point of congealing,, &c.; expl. by HaAwala Oano yajomuda. (L, Ḳ.)
[And the former, It caused water, &c. to congeal.]
4. Ajmd: see 1, in two places.
Also, inf. n. UijomaAdN, He was entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party [in the game called Almayosir: see mujomidN]. (T, TA.)
Oajomadotu Ealayohi Haq-iI ‡ I made my right, or due, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established it against him. (A, Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: jamodN: see jaAmidN, in two places.
jumodN: see jumudN.
jamadN pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also Congealed, or frozen, water; ice: [see also jamodN, mentioned with jaAmidN:] and snow. (Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

jumudN and jumodN↓ Elevated ground; as also jamadN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or a hard, elevated place: (Ṣ, TA:) or jumudN signifies rugged ground: (TA:) or an elevated, rugged place: (Aṣ, TA:) or a small isolated mountain, not high, sometimes rugged and sometimes soft, and producing trees, only found in rugged land; so called because of its dryness; it is the smallest kind of Oakamap, round and small, not extending along the ground, rugged at the top, and producing herbs, or leguminous plants, as well as trees; differing from jumuwdN [q. v.]: (ISh, L, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jimaAdN (ISh, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajomaAdN. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Also, the first, A stone: pl. jimaAdN. (Fr, TA.)

hom.sense: jamaAdN † [A thing that does not grow, or increase; that is incapable of growth, or increase; an inorganic thing; as a mineral and the like:] an inanimate thing; a thing that has no soul: [an epithet used as a subst.; or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] pl. jamaAdaAtN. (Ḥar p. 13.) [See also jaAmidN.]

‡ Land (OaroDN) upon which rain has not fallen: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or dry land, upon which no rain has fallen, and in which is nothing: (T, TA:) or land in which is no produce: (A:) or, as some say, rugged land: (L:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jahaAdN: pl. jumudN. (AA, L in art. jhd.)

‡ A year (sanapN) in which is no rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in which is no produce of the earth: (A:) and, in like manner, jaAmidapN↓ a year in which is no herbage, or pasture, no plenty, or fruitfulness, and no rain. (T, TA.)

‡ A she-camel having no milk; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and so a ewe or a she-goat: (L:) or having little milk: (T, TA:) and [accord. to some,] a slow she-camel; syn. baTiyoYapN; (L, Ḳ;) but [this is app. a mistranscription for bakiyoYapN “having little milk,” and] ISd says that the explanation bTyYp does not please him. (TA.)
See also jaAmidN, in two places.
A kind of cloth or garment; as also jimaAdN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
jamaAdi, like qaTaAmi, (Ḳ,) or jamaAdi lahu, (Ṣ, A, L,) said with reference to a niggard, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) in dispraise, (Ḳ,) as an imprecation, meaning ‡ May a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (jumuwdu AlHaAli) be his lot [or his constant lot]: (A:) or may he not cease to be in a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (laA zaAla jaAmida AlHaAli). (Ṣ, L.) jamaAdi is [a proper name,] indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is transformed from the inf. n., namely, Aljumuwdu, like fajaAri, which means Alfajorapu: (Ṣ:) and the contr. of jamaAdi lahu is HamaAdi lahu, (Ṣ,* A,) which denotes praise. (Ṣ.) El-Mutalemmis says,
jamaAdi lahaA walaA taquwliI
lahaA OabadFA UicaA cukirato HamaAdi
i. e., Say thou jumuwdFA to her, [jumuwdFA,] and say not to her [ever, when she is mentioned,] HamodFA and XukorFA. (Ṣ.)
jimaAdN: see jamaAdN, last meaning.
jamuwdN: see jaAmidN.

jumuwdN [app. Elevated tracts,] softer, or more plain, than what is termed jumudN, and more intermixed with soft, or plain, tracts, sometimes in, or by, that [kind of high ground] which is termed quf-N, and sometimes in, or by, soft, or plain, tracts. (ISh, L, TA.)
jamiydu AlEayoni: see jaAmidN.

jumaAdaI One of the names of the months, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to two of the Arabian months, together called jumaAdayaAni, (TA,) and distinguished by the appellations of jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI and jumaAdaI AlMxirapu [the fifth and sixth months of the Arabian year]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is of the measure fuEaAlaI, from Aljamodu; (Ṣ;) the two months to which it is applied being [said to be] so called because, when the months were named, these two fell in the season of the freezing of water: (ISd, L, Mṣb:) [but this derivation seems to have been invented when the two months thus named had fallen back, into, or beyond, the winter; for when they received this appellation, the former of them evidently commenced in March, and the latter ended in May; therefore I hold the opinion of M. Caussin de Perceval, that they were thus called because falling in a period when the earth had become dry and hard by reason of paucity of rain, from jamaAdN, an epithet applied to land upon which rain has not fallen, or from jumaAdaI, an epithet applied to an eye that sheds few tears; which opinion is confirmed by the obvious derivations of the names of other months, SafarN and rabiyEN and ramaDaAnu and Xaw-aAlN:]
afterwards, when the lunar months superseded the solar, the same names were retained: (Mṣb:) [see zamanN, and Alhijorapu:] jmAdI is determinate, (Ḳ,) being a proper name, (TA,) and of the fem. gender: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) if you find it masc., it is because it is made to accord to AlX-ahoru: all the other names of the months are masc.: (Fr, IAmb, Mṣb:) the pl. is jumaAdayaAtN, (Fr, L, Ḳ,) agreeably with analogy; and if the form jimaAdN [a mistranscription for jamaAYidu, like HabaAYiru, pl. of HubaAraI,] were used, it would also be agreeable with analogy. (Fr, L.) The former of these two months is also called jumaAdaI xamosapK; and the latter, jumaAdaI sit-apK; (Ḳ;) which mean, respectively, Jumádà the fifth month and Jumádà the sixth month, from the commencement of the year. (TA.) Lebeed says, [describing a pair of wild asses,]
Hat-aI UicaA salaxaA jumaAdaI sit-apF
jazaM faTaAla SiyaAmuhu waSiyaAmuhaA
[Until, when they both pass, and come to the end of, Jumádà, completing six months, they satisfy themselves with green pasture so as to be in no need of water, and his and her abstinence from water becomes of long continuance]: thus cited by Bundár; st-p being in the accus. case as a denotative of state, and by jmAdI being meant jmAdI AlMxrp: or, accord. to IAạr, the poet said st-pK, meaning the six months of winter, which are the months of dew; and Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee says the like. (MF.) AḤn says that the Arabs applied the name of jmAdI to The whole of the winter; [see above;] whether the winter were at the same time as the months so called or not: and Aboo-Saʼeed says the like. (L.)
See also jaAmidN.
layolapN jumaAdiy-apN A wintry night. (Aboo-Saʼeed, L.) [See jumaAdaI.]
jam-aAdN ‡ A sword such that he who is struck with it becomes motionless (yajomudu): (A, TA:) or a sharp, cutting, sword. (AA, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jaAmidN, applied to water, (Mṣb, Ḳ,), &c., (Mṣb,) [i. e.] anything fluid, or liquid, (Ḳ,) In a state of congelation, concretion, or solidity; freezing; as also jamodN↓; contr. of caAYibN: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say maMCN jamodN [as well as maMCN jaAmidN]: (Mṣb:) or jamodN↓ signifies what is congealed, or frozen, of water [&c.]; ice; (Ṣ, A;) contr. of cawobN: (Ṣ:) [see also jamadN:] it is originally an inf. n.: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or it is an epithet from jamuda, like DaxomN from Daxuma:] and jamadN↓ is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as xadamN is of xaAdimN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) you say, qado kavura Aljamadu [The frozen waters have become many]. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] mux-apN jaAmidapN A hard piece of marrow. (L.)
† Remaining fixed, stationary, or motionless. (Bḍ and Jel in xxvii. 90.)

† A thing that does not grow, or increase; [incapable of growth, or increase; inanimate;] as stone, in contradistinction to a tree [and an animal]. (Kull.) [See also jamaAdN.] You say, laka jaAmidu hecaA AlmaAli wacaAYibuhu (A, L, Ḳ *) ‡ To thee belongs, or shall belong, what consists of gold and silver [or the like inanimate things], of this property, and what consists of live stock, thereof: (L, Ḳ:) or what consists of stones, thereof, and what consists of trees, thereof: or what is solid, thereof, and what is fluid, or liquid, thereof. (L.)

[Hence its application in lexicology and grammar to † A noun that is not an inf. n. nor derived from an inf. n.; a noun having the quality of a real substantive (Aisomi EayonK), opposed to that which has the quality of an ideal substantive (Aisomu maEonFI): and † a verb that has but one tense and no inf. n., as layosa and niEoma, &c., opposed (as is said in the TA voce qado) to mutaSar-ifN: it may be rendered (and so I have rendered it), in these cases, aplastic.]
† Lifeless; dead. (Kull p. 147.)
† Stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance. (TA.)
It is also applied to a man's state, or condition: you say rajulN jaAmidu AlHaAli † [A man in a stagnant, or unimproving, state or condition]. (Ṣ, L.)

And to the eye: you say EayonN jaAmidapN † An eye that sheds no tears; (Ks, Ḳ;) as also jumaAdaI↓, (Ks, Ḳ,) and jamuwdN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or this last signifies ‡ an eye that sheds few tears. (A.) And rajulN jaAmidu AlEayoni, (A, Ḳ,) and jamiydu↓ AlEyn, and jamaAdu↓ AlEyn, (A,) ‡ A man whose eye sheds few tears; (A;) or whose eye sheds no tears. (Ḳ.)
See also jamaAdN.

Also, (L,) and mujomidN↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) and jamaAdu↓ Alkaf-i, (A, Ḳ,) ‡ Niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (M, A, Ḳ;) niggardly of that which it is incumbent on him to give: (L:) and mujomidN↓, also, a man of little, or no, good; possessing little, or no, good. (Ḳ.)
jawaAmidu, (as its pl., IAạr, L,) Limits, or boundaries, or boundary-marks, between lands, (IAạr, L, Ḳ,*) and between two dwellings. (L.)

entry.sense: mujomidN: see jaAmidN, last sentence but one, in two places.

The person who is entrusted with the management of affairs in a game of chance (qimaAr [here meaning the game called Almayosir]): (Ḳ:) [i. q. DariybN:] or the person entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party, (T, Ḳ, TA,) who does not take part in the game called Almayosir, except that he shuffles the arrows (yaDoribu bihaA) for the players, and has them placed in his hands, and is confided in with respect to them, and compels him who has incurred an obligation to fulfil it: (L, TA:) or one who takes no part in the game called Almayosir, (who is called baramN,) but who sometimes shuffles, or deals forth, the arrows, (yufiyDu bihaA,) for the players; so in the following verse of Tarafeh:
waOaSofara maDobuwHK naZarotu Hawiyrahu
EalaI Aln-aAri waQsotawodaEotuhu kaf-a mujomidi
[And of many a yellow arrow, changed in colour by fire, I have awaited the sound over the fire, and I have deposited it in the hand of one taking no part in the game but only shuffling, or dealing forth, the arrows for the players]; meaning, I have awaited its sound, which was like an answer proceeding from it, when I straightened it and marked it, over the fire: (Ṣ:) [or, accord. to the EM (p. 105), where we find HiwaArahu in the place of Hawiyrahu, the meaning is, and of many a yellow arrow,, &c., I have awaited the returning and gaining, while we were assembled at the fire,, &c.:] or mjmd here means a man taking with both his hands so as not to let anything go forth from them: (AA, TA:) or, accord. to Aṣ, it here means a man entering upon Jumádà, which was in that [the poet's] time a month of cold: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or one whose arrow does not gain anything in the game called Almayosir: (L:) or a person in whom one confides, and who is tenacious of that which is in his hand or possession, and not to be deceived. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
majomadapN A place in which ice is kept. (MA.)
huwa mujaAmidiI He is my neighbour, his house, or tent, adjoining mine. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1: see 2, in two places:
and see also 4:
and 5.
Also jamarahu He gave him jamor [live, or burning, coals]. (Ḳ.)
He put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance. (Th, Ḳ.)
jamarti AlX-amosu Alqamari, aor. _u {yajomuru}, The sun concealed [or as it were put out] the moon [by its proximity thereto: see Aibonu jamiyrK]. (IAạr, TA.)
jamara [said of the moon, It became concealed by its proximity to the sun: see an ex. voce jamiyrN: and see also 4].
2. jm-r, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (Ḳ;) and jamara↓; (Mṣb;) He collected together (Mṣb, Ḳ) a people, and anything. (Mṣb.)

jam-arato XaEarahaA, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and jamaratohu↓, (Mṣb,) and Oajomaratohu↓; (Ḳ;) She (a woman) collected together her hair, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tied it in knots, or made it knotted and crisp, (Eaqadatohu, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) at the back of her neck; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) not letting it hang down loosely: (Ṣ:) or plaited it: (T, TA:) and jm-r XaEarahu he collected together his hair at the back of his head: (Mgh:) and Ajmrt↓ raOosahaA she collected together the hair of her head, and plaited it: and Ajmr↓ XaEarahu he disposed his hair in cawaAYib [or locks hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back, or plaits hanging down]. (TA.)
And jm-r It (a thing) necessitated a people to unite together. (TA.)

Also, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ,) He (a commander, Aṣ, A) detained the army in the territory of the enemy, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or on the frontier of the enemy's country, (A,) and did not bring them back (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) from the frontier: (Ṣ:) the doing of which is forbidden: (TA:) or he detained them long on the frontier of the enemy, and did not give them permission to return to their families: (Aṣ, TA:) or he collected them on the frontiers of the enemy, and kept them from returning to their families. (TA.)
See also 4:
and 5.

jm-r Alv-awoba, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He fumigated the garment with perfume; (A,* Mgh, Mṣb;) as also Ajmrhu↓: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but the former is the more common. (Mgh.) And jm-r Almasojida, (Mgh, TA,) or Ajmrhu↓, accord. to different modes of writing the surname of a certain No'eym, i. e., Almujam-iru or Almujomiru, (TA,) [and accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,] He fumigated the mosque with perfume: (Mgh:) [or perhaps it may mean he strewed the ground of the mosque with pebbles; from jamorapN; like HaS-abahu, from HaSabapN or HaSobaMCu or HaSobapN.]
And jm-r [for jm-r laHomFA] He put flesh-meat upon live coals [to roast]. (A.)

Also, (A,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, A,) He (a pilgrim, A) threw the pebbles [in the valley of Minè]; (Ṣ;) and so Astjmr↓. (TA in art. tw.) Hence, yawomu Alt-ajomiyr [The day of the throwing of the pebbles, by the pilgrims, in the valley of Minè]. (A.) [See jamorapN.]
jm-r Aln-axolapa, (inf. n. as above, A,) He cut off the heart, or pith, (jum-aAr,) of the palmtree. (Ṣ, A. Ḳ.*)
4. Oajomarato XaEarahaA, and raOosahaA; and Ajmr XaEarahu: see 2.

Ajmr AlOamoru baniI fulaAnK The thing, or affair, included the common mass, (Ḳ,) or the whole mass, (TA,) of the sons of such a one within the compass of its relation or relations, or its effect or effects,, &c. (Ḳ, TA.)
Ajmr Aln-axolu He computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees, and then reckoned, and summed up the quantity so computed. (Ḳ.) He who does so is termed mujomirN↓. (TA.)
Ajmr Alxayolu He prepared the horses for racing, &c. by feeding them with food barely sufficient to sustain them, after they had become fat, (OaDomarahaA,) and collected them together. (Ḳ.)

Ajmr Alqawomu EalaI AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,) or ElI AlOamori; (Ḳ;) and jm-r↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajomiyrN; (TA;) and jamara↓, and Astjmr↓; (Ḳ;) The people, or party, agreed together to do the thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and united for it. (Ḳ.) [See also 5.]
Ajmr Alv-awoba, and Almasojida: see 2.
Ajmr Aln-aAra, inf. n. mujomarN, He prepared the fire [app. in a mijomarap]. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
Ajmr said of a camel, He had his foot rendered even, so that there was no line between its phalanges, (Ḳ, TA,) in consequence of its having been wounded by the pebbles, and become hard. (TA.)
Also, said of a camel, (Ṣ,) and of a man, (TA,) He hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and ran: (TA:) you should not say Ajmz. (Ṣ.)
See also 1.
Oajomarati All-ayolapu The night had its moon concealed by its proximity to the sun. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See also 1.]

5. tjm-r It (a people, or party,) collected together; (A, Mgh, TA;) [and] so jamara↓; this verb being intrans. as well as trans.: (Mṣb: [see 2:]) and jm-r↓ it (a tribe) collected together, and became one band. (Aṣ, TA.)
It (an army) became detained in the territory of the enemy, and was not brought back (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the frontier; (Ṣ;) as also Astjmr↓. (Ḳ.)
See also 10.

entry.sense: 8. Ajtmr biAlmijomari, (Ḳ,) and Astjmr↓, (AḤn, A, Mgh,) He fumigated, or perfumed, himself with aloes-wood [or the like]. (AḤn, A, Mgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 10. Astjmr: see 4:
and 5:
and 8:
and 2.
Also, [and vulgarly tjm-r↓,] He performed the purification termed AisotinojaMC with jimaAr, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., with stones, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or small stones. (Mgh, TA.)

entry.sense: jamorN: see what next follows, in two places.

hom.sense: jamorapN A live, or burning, coal; a piece of smokeless burning fire: (Mṣb:) or burning fire: (Ḳ:) [but the former is the correct explanation:] when cold, [before it is kindled,] it is called faHomN (TA) [or HaTabN, &c.]: and when reduced to powder by burning, ramaAdN: (L in art. rmd:) from jam-ara “he collected together:” (Mgh:) pl. jamorN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and jamaraAtN and jimaArN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] Aljamoru↓ fiI kabidiI ‡ [Live coals are in my liver]. (A.)

[Hence also,] AljamaraAtu Alv-alaAvu † [The three live coals; meaning the first three degrees of heat]: the first is in the air; the second, in the earth, or dust; and the third, in the water: [or, accord. to the modern Egyptian almanacs, the first is in the air, and is cold, or cool; the second, in the water, and is lukewarm; and the third, in the earth, or dust, and is hot: the first falling exactly a zodiacal month before the vernal equinox; and each lasting seven days:] whence the saying, kaAna celika Einoda suquwTi Aljamorapi † [That was at the time of the falling of the live coal]; i. e., when the heat had acquired strength. (TA.)

Any body of men that have united together, and become one band, and that do not form a confederacy with any others: (Ṣ:) or a body of men that congregate by themselves, because of their strength and their great valour; [said to be] from the same word signifying “a live coal:” (Mṣb:) or any people that endure patiently fighting with those who fight them, not forming a confederacy with any others, nor uniting themselves to any others: (Lth, TA:) or a tribe that does not unite itself to any other: (Ḳ:) or that comprises three hundred horsemen, (Ḳ,) or the like thereof: (TA:) or a tribe that fights with a company of tribes: (TA:) pl. jamaraAtN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, banuw fulaAnK jamorapN The sons of such a one are a people able to defend themselves, and strong. (TA.) jamaraAtu AlEarabi is an appellation especially applied to three tribes; namely, Benoo-Dabbeh Ibn-Udd, and Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab, and Benoo-Numeyr Ibn-' Ámir; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the first of which became extinguished by confederating with Er-Ribáb, and the second by confederating with Medhhij; the third only remaining [a jmrp] because it formed no confederacy: (Ṣ:) or it is applied to 'Abs and El-Hárith and Dabbeh; all the offspring of a woman who dreamt that three live coals issued from her faroj. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also A thousand horsemen. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says jamorapN kaAljamorapi [A troop of a thousand horsemen like the live coal]. (Ṣ, TA.)
A pebble: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a stone: (Mṣb:) or a small stone or pebble: pl. jimaArN (Mgh, Mṣb, Et-Towsheeh, TA) and jamaraAtN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

Also sing. of jamaraAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and of jimaArN (TA) in the appellations jamaraAtu minFI (Mṣb) or jamaraAtu AlmanaAsiki (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jimaAru AlmanaAsiki, (TA,) which were three in number, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) called Aljamorapu AlOuwlaI and Aljamorapu AlwusoTaI and jamorapu AlEaqabapi, (Ḳ,) at which jamaraAt (i. e. small pebbles, TA) were cast; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) each of these being a heap of pebbles, at Minè, and each two heaps [or rather each heap and that next to it] being about a bow-shot apart: (Mṣb:) accord. to Th, from jamarahu “he put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance:” or from Oajomara “he hastened;” because Adam pelted Iblees in Minè, and he hastened away before him: (Ḳ,* TA:) or from tjm-rwA “they collected together:” (Mgh:) or from jamarahu “he collected it together.” (Mṣb.)
See also jamiyrapN.

entry.sense: jamaArN An assembly; an assemblage; a collection: (Ḳ:) a people assembled together. (TA.)
Ead-a Uibilahu jamaArFA He counted, or numbered, his camels in one herd, (Aṣ, TA,) by looking at their aggregate. (Aṣ, T voce naZiyrN, q. v.)

jamaAraI↓ jaAWuwA, and with tenween, [i. e., app., jamaArFA, not, as might be thought at first sight, jamaArFI, a form which MF disapproves, though it is said in the TA that his disapproval requires consideration,] They came all together, or all of them. (Ḳ.)
jamiyrN A place of assembly of a people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AibonaA jamiyrK The night and the day: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because of the assembling [of people therein]; like as they are called AibonaA samiyrK because people held conversation therein: (Ṣ:) or the two nights during which the moon becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun. (TA.) And Aibonu jamiyrK, (IAạr, Ṣ,) or Aibonu jumayorK↓, (Lḥ, Th,) The moon in the night when it is concealed by its proximity to the sun: (TA:) or the moon in the end of the [lunar] month; because the sun conceals it (tajomuruhu, i. e. tuwaAriyhi): (IAạr, TA:) or the dark night: (Ṣ:) or the night in which the moon does not rise, either in the first part thereof or in the last: (TA:) or the last night of the [lunar] month. (Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid, TA.) You say, jaMCanaA faHomapa Qbonu jumayorK↓ [He came to us in the darkest part of the moonless night, or of the night in which the moon did not rise]. (Th, TA.) And laA OafoEalu celika maA jamara Qbonu jumayorK↓ [I will not do that as long as the moon in the end of the lunar month becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun; i. e., I will never do it]. (Lḥ, TA.)
jamiyru AlX-aEari What is collected together, of the hair, and tied in knots, or made knotted and crisp. (TA. [See 2.])
Aibonu jumayorK: see jamiyrN, in three places.

jamiyrapN A plait of hair: (T, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and i. q. cuWaAbapN [app. here meaning a plait of hair hanging down; or a lock of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back]: (TA:) and jamorapN↓ a lock of hair: (TA:) pl. of the former jamaAYiru. (T, Mṣb.)
jaAWuwA jamaAraI: see jamaArN.

jum-aArN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaAmuwrN↓ (Ḳ) [each a coll. gen. n.] The heart, or pith, [or cerebrum,] of the palm-tree, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) that is in the summit of its head, which part is cut off, and its outer portion is stripped off from the pith within it, which is a white substance, like a piece of the hump of a camel, large and soft: it is eaten with honey: (TA:) from it come forth the fruit and the branches; and when it is cut off, the tree dies: (Mṣb:) the spathe comes forth from it, amid the part whence two branches divide: (TA:) the head of the palmtree; a soft, white substance: from jam-ara “he collected together;” for a similar reason termed kavarN: (Mgh:) n. un. jum-aArapN. (A, TA.) [See also qalobN.] You say, lahu saAqN kaAljum-aArapi He has a shank like a piece of the heart of the palm-tree. (A.) And Aljum-aAru fiI xalaAxilihin-a ‡ [Legs like the heart of the palm-tree are within their anklets]. (A.) Sakhr El-Hudhalee says, using a double trope, likening the fresh juicy stalks of the barodiI- to the pith of the palm-tree, and then applying this expression to the legs of a woman,
UicaA EuTifato xalaAxuluhun-a gaS-abo
bijum-aAraAti barodiI-K xidaAli
‡ [When their anklets are bent, (for the anklet of the Arab woman is formed of a piece of silver, or other metal, which is bent round so that the two ends nearly meet,) they are choked, or entirely filled up, with plump legs like the pith of the papyrus]. (A, TA.)
jaAmirN: see mujam-irN.
jaAmuwrN: see jum-aArN.
Also ‡ A well-known appertenance of a ship or boat; [i. e., the head of the mast; a kind of truck, which is made of harder wood than the mast itself.] (TA.)
And hence, ‡ The head [absolutely]: but accord. to Kr, only the vulgar call it so. (TA.)
Oajomaru occurs in a trad., where it is said, daxalotu Almasojida waAln-aAsu Oajomaru maA kaAnuwA, meaning I entered the mosque when the people were in their most collected state. (TA.)
mujomarN: see mijomarN:
and see also mijomarapN, in two places.
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mujomirN↓, (Ḳ,) A hard solid hoof: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a hard, strong, compact camel's foot: or one that has been wounded by the stones, and become hard. (TA.)

hom.sense: mujomirN: see mujam-irN, in two places:
and Oajomara Aln-axola:
and see also mujomarN.

entry.sense: mijomaro: see mijomarapN.

Also, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and mujomarN↓, (Ḳ,) Aloes-wood, (AḤn, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like, (Mgh,) or other substance, (Mṣb,) with which clothes are fumigated, (Mgh,) or with which one perfumes himself by burning it: (Mṣb:) pl. majaAmiru. (Mgh.)

mijomarapN and mijomarN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter is sometimes fem. [like the former], (Ḳ,) or fem. when by it is meant the fire (Aln-aAr), and masc. when meaning the place [of the fire], (TA,) and mujomarN↓, (Ḳ,) A vessel for fumigation; a censer; (Mṣb;) a vessel in which live coals are put, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with incense, or some odoriferous substance for fumigation; (Ḳ;) a vessel in which aloes-wood is burned: it is disapproved, because generally of silver; but not so what is termed midoxanapN: (Mgh:) or mujomarN↓ signifies the thing for which the live coals are prepared: (Ṣ:) [and mijomarapN also signifies a blacksmith's fire-place: (Ḳ in art. kwr:)] pl. majaAmiru. (Ṣ.)
mujam-arN Flesh-meat put upon live coals [to roast]. (A.)

hom.sense: mujam-irN (Ṣ, Z) and mujomirN↓ (TA) One who collects together his hair, and ties it in knots, or makes it knotted and crisp, at the back of his neck, not letting it hang down loosely: (Ṣ:) or who plaits the hair of his head. (TA.) He who does so (while he is a muHorim, TA) is commanded to shave his head. (Ṣ and TA from a trad.)
Also, both the former and jaAmirN↓, which is a possessive epithet, without a verb, One whose business is to fumigate garments [&c.] with perfume. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. jamaza, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _i {yajomizu}, inf. n. jamozN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jamazaI, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a man, (A, Ḳ,) [He went at a gentle trot or run;] he went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but not so quick as that termed HuDorN, (Ḳ,) or not so quick as a vehement HuDor; (TA;) he went the pace with which corpses are conveyed [to the tomb; which, according to the practice prescribed by Moḥammad, is a quick pace]: (TA:) or simply, he went, or went along: (Mṣb:) and he ran; syn. EadaA: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and he went quickly. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) You say, jamaza biQlojinaAzapi He went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [with the corpse upon its bier]. (A.) And jamaza Alr-ajulu fiI AlOaroDa The man went away into, or in, the country or land. (Kr, Ḳ.)
[2. jm-z, if used, He rode a camel such as is called jam-aAzN or jam-aAzapN. See the act. part. n., below.]
See also jam-aAzN, in two places.

jam-aAzN, applied to a he-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jam-aAzapN, applied to a she-camel, (Ḳ,) That is ridden by the mujam-iz; (Ṣ;) that goes the pace described above, [voce jamazaI and] voce jamaza: (Ḳ, TA:) [the latter is also said in the TA to be mn MlaAt AlmHAml; but the correct reading seems to be mino OuwlaAt AlmaHaAmili; and the meaning, of those that carry the vehicles called mHAml, pl. of maHomil.]

HimaArN jam-aAzN An ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly: (Ḳ:) and HimaArN jamazaI↓ a quick ass; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or an ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly, and is swift; (TA;) the latter word in this phrase used as a masc. and fem. epithet, though its final letter is a denotative of the fem. gender. (Ḥam p. 277. [See below; and see also HayadaI.]) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh (Ṣ, TA) El-Hudhalee (TA) says,
kaOan-iI waraHoliI UicaA ruEotuhaA
EalaI jamazaI↓ jaAziYK biAlr-imaAli
[As though I and my she-camel's saddle, when I frightened her, were upon a swift wild ass satisfied with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water, in the sands]. (Ṣ, TA.) He likens his she-camel to a wild ass, to which he applies the epithet jmzI, that is, swift; meaning, EalaI HimaArK jamazaI. (TA.) Aṣ says that this is the only epithet of the measure faEalaI heard by him applied to a male; and that IAạr cited the verse above to him saying Hay-idK biAld-iHaAli, meaning Eani Ald-iHaAli, [i. e., “shying and turning aside from the hollows, narrow at the top but wide below, in the ground:” but this is probably a reading of some in the place of HayadaI biAld-iHaAli, which ends the next verse, agreeably with what is said in the L in art. Hyd:] Az says that EalaI jamazaI may be explained as for EalaI EayorK ciI jamazaI, i. e., upon an ass having the mode of pace termed jamazaI; and naAqapN wakaraI has a similar meaning. (TA.)
See also mujam-izN.

jum-ayozN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jum-ayozaI↓ (Ḳ) [The sycamorefig: and the sycamore fig-tree: ficus sycomorus; also called the Egyptian fig:] the male fig; (Ḳ, TA;) which is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, [here meaning the Valley of the Jordan,] (TA,) and is sweet: (Ḳ, TA:) this is the yellow: the black makes the mouth bleed: (TA:) it is of various colours, or kinds, (OalowaAn,) (Ḳ,* TA;) abundant in Syria and in Egypt: n. un. jum-ayozapN: (TA:) [a fruit] resembling the tiyn [or common fig]: (Ṣ:) AḤn says, of the kinds of fig is the fig of the jum-ayoz, a sweet, moist fig, which has long fruit-stalks, and which is dried in the sun: and there is another species of the jm-yz, the fruit of which is like the fig in make, but its leaves are smaller than those of the fig, and its figs are yellow, of a small size, and black: it is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, and is called the male fig: the yellow is sweet: the black makes the mouth bleed: and its fig has no stalk, but cleaves to the wood. ('Abd-el-Laṭeef, Account of Egypt: White's ed., entitled Abdollatiphi Historiæ Aegypti Compendium: p. 22. See also De Sacy's notes to his transl. of that work, pp. 82-86.)
[Aljum-ayozapu also signifies † The pudendum muliebre: opposed to Alt-iynapu as meaning “the anus.”]
jum-ayozaI: see jum-ayozN.
jum-ayoziI-N A seller of jum-ayoz. (TA.)
mujam-izN One who rides the camel called jam-aAz, (Ṣ,* TA,) or who rides the she-camel called jam-aAzap; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also jam-aAzN↓. (TA.)

1. jamasa, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajomusu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. jumuwsN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jamosN; (TA;) and jamusa, aor. _u {yajomusu}; (TA;) It (grease, Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, and clarified butter, and water, A, Ḳ, but jamada is more commonly said of the last, Ḳ, or jamasa is incorrect when said of water, Aṣ, TA) congealed. (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jumosapN A tough date: (IDrd,* M, Ḳ,* TA:) a date ripening (Aṣ, Ṣ, Z, Ḳ) altogether, (Aṣ, Z, Ḳ, TA,) but as yet hard, not mellow, or digestible, or easy of digestion: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Z, Ḳ:) pl. jumasN. (Aṣ, TA.) [See busorN.]
Also A distinct number, or herd, of camels. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaAmisN Grease, (A,) and clarified butter, (TA,) and water, (Ṣ,) or it is improperly applied to the last, (Aṣ, TA,) in a state of congelation. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, TA.)
A plant that has lost its freshness, or juiciness, (AḤn, Ḳ,) and become old, and hard, or tough. (AḤn, TA.)

SaxorapN jaAmisapN A tough rock, (TA,) firm in its place. (Ḳ, TA.) [In the TA is added muqoXaEir-apN: but this is evidently a mistranscription, for musotaqir-apN, which adds nothing to the explanation.]

jaAmuwsN [The buffalo;] a kind of baqar; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) well known: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {jaAmuwsapN}: (Ḳ:) and pl. jawaAmiysu: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) an arabicized word, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the Persian; (T, Ṣ;) originally GaAwo miyXo. (T, Ḳ.)

1. jamaXahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajomiXu} and _u {yajomuXu}, (TA,) inf. n. jamoXN, (Ṣ,) He shaved it, or removed its hair; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, his pubes; (Ṣ;) or his head. (A, Ḳ.) And jamaXatohu She shaved it; namely, her pudendum; or removed its hair: and it (nuwrap, q. v.) removed it; namely, hair. (A.)
jamuwXN, applied to nuwrap [q. v.], That removes hair; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jamiyXN↓. (Ḳ.)
Applied to a year (sanapN), † That shaves off, (Ṣ,) or nips, shrinks, shrivels, or blasts, [lit., burns, see OaHoraqa,] (Ḳ,) the plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jamiyXN, applied to the pubes, Shaven, or having its hair removed, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) by means of nuwrap [q. v.]. (TA.)
Applied to a place, † [Shorn of its plants, or herbage; or] having in it no plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jamuwXN.

entry.sense: 1. jamaEa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yajomaEu}, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. jamoEN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; (Mgh, Er-Rághib, B, Ḳ;*) a thing; (Er-Rághib, Mṣb, B;) so that the several parts or portions became near together; (Er-Rághib, B;) or a thing in a scattered, or dispersed, state; (Fr, Ṣ;) and a number of men; (Fr;) as also jm-E↓; [or this has only an intensive signification;] and AjmE↓. (TA.) [See also the inf. n., jamoEN, below; and] see 2; and 10.

[jamaEa bayonahumaA He brought them two together, into a state of union, after separation; and particularly, reconciled them; conciliated them: and he, or it, united, connected, or formed a connexion between, them two: see 3 (last sentence) in art. dnw.]
jamaEa Ealayohi viyaAbahu He put on, or attired himself with, his clothes. (TA.)
jamaEati AljaAriyapu The girl put on the diroE and the ximaAr and the miloHafap; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e., ‡ became a young woman; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) became full-grown. (TA.)
maA jamaEotu biQmoraOapK qaT-u, and Eani QmoraOapK, † I have never gone in to a woman; or I have never had a woman conducted to me as my bride. (Ks, Ḳ.)
faQjomaEuwA kayodakumo, and fajamaEa kayodahu: see 4.
jamaEa Oamorahu: see 4.
[jamaEa also signifies He composed, arranged, or settled, a thing, or an affair; as in the phrase jamaEa Qll-ehu Xamolahu: see art. Xml.]
[Also It comprised, comprehended, or contained.]
Also He pluralized a word; made it to have a plural, or plurals. (The Lexicons passim.)

2. jm-E, (Fr, Mṣb,) inf. n. tajomiyEN, (Ḳ,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; [thus I render jamaEa, as explained above;] much; with much, or extraordinary, energy, or effectiveness, or the like; vigorously; or well. (Bḍ in civ. 2; Mṣb, Ḳ.) Thus in the Ḳur [civ. 2], Al-aciI jam-aEa maAlFA waEad-adahu (Ṣ,* Bḍ) Who hath collected much wealth, and hath made it a provision for the casualties of fortune, or reckoned it time after time: (Bḍ:) [or who hath amassed, or accumulated, wealth,, &c.:] or who hath gained, acquired, or earned, wealth,, &c.; thus differing from jamaEa, explained above: but it is allowable to say jamaEa↓ maAlFA, without teshdeed; (Fr;) and thus it is [generally] read in this passage of the Ḳur. (Bḍ.) See also 1.
Ham-aEato, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) She (a hen) collected her eggs in her belly. (Ḳ, TA.)

jam-aEuwA, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ,) They were present on the Friday, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or with the congregation [then collected], (Mgh,) and performed the prayers [with the congregation] on that day. (Ṣ, Mgh.)

Hence the saying, Oaw-alu jumoEapK jum-iEato fiI AlUisolaAmu baEoda Almadiynapi bijuWaAviI [The first Friday that was observed by the performance of congregational prayer in the time of El-Islám, after the observance thereof in El-Medeeneh, was in Ju-áthà]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 3. jAmEhu EalaI Oamori kacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (TḲ) [and jimaAEN], He combined with him, (AjtmE↓ maEahu, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and aided him, (TA,) to do such a thing. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, walaA jimaAEa lanaA fiymaA baEodu i. e. laAQjotimaAEa↓ lanaA [which may mean Nor any combining, or nor any coming together, for us afterwards: see 8]. (TA.)

jAmE QmoraOatahu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jimaAEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) ‡ He lay with his wife; compressed her. (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*) [The latter inf. n. is the more common as meaning Coïtus conjugalis, or the act of compressing].
