AisotaOojara AlOajiyra mujaAmaEpF, and jimaAEFA, He hired the hireling for a certain pay every week. (Lḥ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AjmE: see 1. OajomaEotu AlX-aIoCa signifies I put the thing together; such, for instance, as spoil, or plunder. (Ṣ.) You say, OajomaEotu Aln-ahobi, meaning I collected together from every quarter the camels taken as spoil from the people to whom they belonged, and drove them away: (AHeyth:) or UijomaAEN signifies [simply] the driving of camels together, or collectively. (Ḳ.)

AlUijomaAEu also signifies The composing and settling a thing which has been discomposed [and unsettled]; as an opinion upon which one determines, resolves, or decides: (TA:) or jaEolu AlOamori jamiyEFA baEoda tafar-uqihi, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) i. e. the determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in the mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.) You say, OajomaEotu AlOamora, (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and EalaI AlOamori, (Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair; (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) as though I collected myself, or my mind, for it; (TA;) as, for instance, a journeying, and a fasting, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and a going forth, and a tarrying or an abiding; (TA;) and in like manner, jamaEa↓ Oamorahu He determined, resolved, or decided, upon his affair; as, for instance, a fasting: (TA:) and OajomaEotu Alr-aOoIi I determined, or settled, the opinion. (TA.) You say also, OajomiEo Oamoraka walaA tadaEohu munotaXirFA [Determine thou, or decide, upon thine affair, and do not leave it unsettled]. (Ṣ.) The saying, in the Ḳur [x. 72], faOajomaEuwA Oamorakumo waXurakaMCa kumo means Then determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your affair, (Fr, Ibn-ʼArafeh, Bḍ,) and prepare for it, (Fr,) or AijoEaluwhu jamiyEFA, [which has the former of these meanings, as shown above,] (AHeyth,) and call ye your companions, (Fr, Ṣ, Bḍ, Ḳ,) XrkACkm being governed in the accus. case by the verb understood, (Bḍ, TA,) becanse the verb in the text is not used with XrkAC for its object, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but only the unaugmented verb: (Ṣ:) or the meaning is then determine ye, with your companions, upon your affair; (Bḍ, Ḳ;) so says Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, adding that what Fr says is erroneous: (TA:) or then determine ye upon your affair and the affair of your companions, for waOamora XurakaAYikumo. (Bḍ.) It is also said that the phrase, in the Ḳur [xx. 67], faOajomiEuwA kayodakumo means Therefore determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your artifice, or stratagem: (TA:) but some read faQjomaEuwA↓ kayodakumo, (Bḍ, TA,) meaning therefore combine ye all your artifice; leave nothing thereof unexerted; (TA;) and this latter reading is favoured by the phrase fajamaE↓ kayodahu [in verse 62 of the same ch.]. (Bḍ.)

Also The agreeing, or uniting, in opinion. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, OajomaEuwA EalaI AlOamori meaning They agreed, or were of one mind or opinion, upon, or respecting, the affair; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [and so AjtmEwA↓ Ealayohi; and tjm-EwA↓ Elyh.]

Also The preparing [a thing], or making [it] ready; syn. AlUiEodaAdu. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, AlAaEodaAdu.]) You say, OajomaEotu kacaA I prepared, or made ready, such a thing. (TA.) And OajomiEuwA Oamorakumo Prepare ye for your affair. (Fr.)

Also The binding the teats of a she-camel all together with the SiraAr, q. v. (Ḳ.) You say, AjmE biAln-aAqapi, (Ṣ, TA,) and AjmE Aln-aAqapi, (TA,) He so bound the teats of the she-camel; (Ṣ, TA;) and so OakomaXa bihaA. (TA.)

Also The drying [a thing]; drying [it] up; making [it] dry; syn. Alt-ajofiyfu waAlUiybaAsu. (Ḳ TA. [In the CK, erroneously, Altaxofuyfu wAlAiyonAsu.]) Hence the saying of Aboo-Wejzeh Es-Saadee,
waOajomaEati AlhawaAjiru kul-a rajoEK
mina AlOajomaAdi waAld-amivi AlbavaMCi
i.e. [And the vehement mid-day-heats] dried up every pool left by a torrent [of the hard and elevated grounds and of the soft and even ground]. (TA.)

AjmE AlmaTaru AlOaroDi The rain made the whole of the land, both its soft tracts and its hard tracts, to flow: (Ḳ:) and in like manner you say, OajomaEati AlOaroDu saAYilapF The land flowed in its soft tracts [as well as in its hard tracts; i. e., in every part]. (TA.) [See also 10.]
5: see 8, in three places: and see also 4, latter half.
7. AnjmE Eani Aln-aAsi [He withdrew himself from men]. (TA in art. qbD.)

8. AjtmE It (a thing in a scattered or dispersed state, Ṣ, and a number of men, Mṣb, [and a number of things,]) became collected, brought together, gathered together, gathered up, assembled, congregated, mustered, drawn together, or contracted; or it collected, collected itself together, gathered itself together, came together, assembled, congregated, drew itself together, contracted itself; coalesced; combined; (Ḳ, TA;) so that the several parts or portions became near [or close] together; (TA;) as also AijodamaEa, (Ḳ,) with d [substituted for the t]; (TA;) and tjm-E↓ and AstjmE↓ signify the same: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and tjm-EwA↓ signifies they became collected,, &c., [from several places, or] hence and thence. (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [See also 10.] You say also, AjtmE maEahu (Mgh) and bihi (Mṣb) [meaning He was, or became, in company with him; came together with him; met with him; met him; had a meeting, or an interview, with him]. And AjtmE maEahu EalaI Oamori kacaA: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) see 3, first sentence: and see the sentence there next following. And in like manner, tjm-EwA↓ EalaI fulaAnK They combined, conspired, or leagued, together against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.) [See also AjtmEwA EalaI AlOamori in 4, latter half.] You also say, AijotamaEati MraAWuhumo EalaI AlOamori [Their opinions agreed together, or were in unison, upon, or respecting, the affair]. (Er-Rághib.) And AijotamaEato XaraAYiTu AlUimaAmapi The conditions of the office of Imám occurred together [or were combined, or they coexisted, in such a case]; as also AisotajomaEato↓. (Mṣb: [but it is implied in the Mgh that the latter verb in this sense is not of established authority.]) [See a similar ex. voce ArtfE.]
[He, or it, was, or became, compact in make or frame, compressed, contracted, or the like.]
[And hence,] He (a man) attained to his full state of manly vigour, and his beard became fullgrown. (Ḳ, TA.) The verb is not thus used in speaking of a woman. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence also,] AjtmE fiI AlHaAjapi [He was quick and vigorous in executing the needful affair, or in accomplishing that which was wanted; as though he compacted his frame, and collected all his energy: see maXaI mujotamiEFA, below: and see also 10]. (TA in art. kmX.)
[Hence also,] AijotamaEati Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled. (Z, TA.)
[Hence also, AjtmE said of a thing, or an affair, It was, or became, composed, arranged, or settled.]

hom.sense:
10. AstjmE kul-a majomaEK↓ [He desired, or demanded, the collecting together of every body of soldiers; or he summoned together every body of soldiers]: said of him who demands, or summons, armies, or military forces. (Ṣ, TA.) [But this usage of the verb is perhaps post-classical: for Mṭr says,] With respect to the saying of El-Abeewardee,
XaMmiy-apN tasotajomiEu AlX-awola Harojafu
[A north wind, cold and vehement, inviting to collect themselves together the she-camels whose milk has dried up, they having passed seven or eight months since bringing forth, or since pregnancy], it seems that he has compared this verb with the generality of others of the same class, [and so derived the meaning in which he has here used it,] or that he heard it [in that sense] from the people of the cities, or towns, or villages, and cultivated lands. (Mgh.)
AstjmE used intransitively is syn. with AjtmE, which see in two places, and tjm-E. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
AstjmE Als-ayolu The torrent collected itself together from every place. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)
AstjmE AlwaAdiI The valley flowed in every place thereof. (TA.) [See also 4, last signification.]
AisotajomaEato lahu Oumuwruhu His affairs, or circumstances, all combined in a manner pleasing to him. (Mgh, Ḳ.)

AstjmE Alfarasu jaroyFA (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) The horse exerted all his force, or energy, in running: (Ḳ, TA:) the last word is here in the accus. case as a specificative. (Mgh.) You say also, AisotajomaEuwA lahumo, meaning They exerted [all] their strength, force, or energy, for fighting them: and hence, Uin-a Aln-aAsi qado jamaEuwA↓ lakumo [app. meaning Verily the men, or people, have exerted all their strength for fighting you]. (A, TA.)
AstjmE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, all went away, not one of them remaining; like as one says of a valley flowing in every place thereof. (TA.)
AstjmE Albaqolu The herbs, or leguminous plants, all dried up. (TA.)

entry.sense: jamoEN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, &c.) [Hence,] yawomu AljamoEi The day of resurrection [when all mankind will be collected together]. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

Also, without the article Al, A name of El-Muzdelifeh [between 'Arafát and Minè]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) determinate, like EarafaAtu: (TA:) so called because people collect themselves there; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or because Adam there met with Eve (Mgh, Mṣb) after they had fallen [from Paradise]: (TA:) [or, app., a name of the tract from 'Arafát to Minè inclusive of these two places: and hence,] yawomu jamoEK the day of ʼArafeh [when the pilgrims halt at Mount 'Arafát]: and Oay-aAmu jamoEK the days of Minè. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

As an inf. n. used as a subst., properly so termed, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,) it also signifies A collection; a number together; an assembly; a company, troop, congregated or collective body, party, or group; a mass; syn. jamaAEapN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of men; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also majomaEN↓ (L, Mṣb, TA) and majomiEN↓ (Mṣb) and majomaEapN↓ (L, TA) and jamiyEN↓: (O, Ḳ:) but jamaAEapN↓ is also used as signifying a collection, a number together, or an assemblage, of other things than men; [of beasts, as camels, horses and the like, bulls and cows, and antelopes, gazelles, &c., i. e. a herd, troop, or drove; of dogs, i. e. a pack; of sheep and goats, i. e. a flock; of birds, i. e. a flock or bevy; of bees, and locusts, &c., i. e. a swarm;] and even of trees, and of plants; (L, TA;) it signifies a collection, or an assemblage, or aggregate, of any things, consisting of many and of few; (Mṣb;) [as also majomuwEN↓ and majomaEN↓;] a number, a plurality, and a multitude, of any things: (TA:) the pl. of jamoEN is jumuwEN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And particularly, An army; a military force; (TA;) as also jamiyEN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Whence the phrase, in a trad., lahu sahomN jamoEN, [or, more probably, sahomu jamoEK,] meaning For him or shall be, the like of an army's share of the spoil. (TA.)

Also The plural of a thing [or word; i. e. a proper plural, according to the grammarians; and also applied by the lexicologists to a quasi-plural noun, which the grammarians distinguish by the terms Aisomu jamoEK and jamoEN lugawiI-N]; and so jimaAEN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jamiyEN↓, except that this last is what is termed AisomN laAzimN [app. meaning a subst. which does not govern another as its complement in the gen. case like as jamoEN and jimaAEN do, being thus likened to what is termed fiEolN laAzimN, i. e. an intransitive verb; so that you say of AlxibaMCu, for instance, AljamiyEu AlOaxobiyapu the plural is AlAxbyp; for in this manner I always find it used when it has this signification, which is frequently the case in several of the older lexicons, and in some others; not jamiyEu AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu]; (TA;) [whereas] you say, [jamoEu AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu and] jimaAEu↓ AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. the jamoE [or plural] of AlxbAC is AlxibaMCi; (Ḳ) for AljimaAEu↓ is what comprises a number [of things]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also this last word below.
And see also the next paragraph, in three places.

The worst sort of dates; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because they are collected together and mixed, (Mgh, Mṣb,) from among the dates of fifty palm-trees: (Mgh:) and afterwards, by predominant usage, [any] bad dates: (Mgh,* Mṣb:)
or a certain kind of dates (Ḳ, TA) mixed together, of several sorts, not in request, and not mixed but for their badness: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or signifies also, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) palm-trees (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind, (Aṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) growing from the date-stones, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of which the name is unknown. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Red gum; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) [app. because collected and mixed with gum of lighter colour.]

AljumoEu, (TA, and EM p. 102,) and jumoEu Alkaf-i, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jimoEu↓ Alkaf-i, (Mṣb, Ḳ, and so in the margin of a copy of the Ṣ, as mentioned in the TA,) and jamoEu↓ Alkaf-i, (Mṣb,) The fist; the hand clinched; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the hand with the fingers put together and contracted in the palm: (TA,* and EM ubi suprà:) pl. OajomaAEN. (Ḳ.) You say, Darabotuhu bijumoEi kaf-iI I beat him, or struck him, with my fist. (Ṣ, Mṣb.*) And Darabuwhu biOajomaAEihimo They beat him, or struck him, with their [clinched] hands. (TA.) And jaMCa fulaAnN biquboDapK miloCK jumoEihi Such a one came with a quantity in his grasp as much as filled his clinched hand. (Ṣ, TA.) And jumoEu Alkaf-i signifies [also] The quantity that a hand grasps, of money, &c. (Ḥam p. 778.)
Oaxacotu fulaAnFA bijumoEi viyaAbihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) and bijamoEi↓ viyaAbihi, (Mṣb,) i. e. [I took, or seized, such a one] by the part where his garments met together. (Mṣb.)
Oamoruhumo bijumoEi, and bijimoEK↓, ‡ Their affair, or case, is concealed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) undivulged by them, and unknown by any one [beside them]. (Ṣ, TA.)
cahaba AlX-ahoru bijumoEK, and bijimoEK↓, The month passed away wholly; all of it. (Ḳ, TA.)

hiIa mino zawojihaA bijumoEK, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and bijimoEK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) She is as yet undevirginated, or undeflowered, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) by her husband. (Ṣ, Mgh.) And Tul-iqato bijumoEK, or bijimoEK↓, She was divorced being yet a virgin. (TA.) And maAtato bijumoEK, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bijimoEK↓, (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bijamoEK↓, (Ḳ,) She died a virgin: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it signifies, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or signifies also, (Mgh, Mṣb,) she died being with child; (AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) whether suffering the pains of parturition or not: (AZ:) or heavy with child: (Ḳ:) occurring in the first sense, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say, in the last, (TA,) in a trad., in which it is said that a woman who so dies is a martyr: (Mgh, TA:) it properly signifies she died with something comprised in her, not separated from her, whether it were a burden in the womb, or her maidenhead: (Ṣgh:) [the pl. is OajomaAEN; for] you say, maAtati Aln-isaMCu biOajomaAEK The women died [being virgins: or] being with child. (AZ.) You say also, naAqapN jumoEN A she-camel with young. (TA.) And AimoraOapN jaAmiEN↓ A woman with child. (TA.)
jimoEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.
jumaEN pl. of jamoEaMCu, fem. of OajomaEu [q. v.].

jumoEapN is [a subst.] from AlAijotimaAEu, like as [its contr.] furoqapN is [a subst.] from AlAAifotiraAqu: (Mgh:) and signifies A state of union, agreement, congruity, or congregation: or sociableness, socialness, familiarity, companionableness, companionship, fellowship, friendship, and amity: syn. OulofapN: as in the saying, OadaAma Qll-ehu jumoEapa maA bayonakumaA [May God make permanent the state of union,, &c., subsisting between you two]. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.)

Hence, (Mgh,) yawomu AljumoEapi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the original form, (TA,) of the dial. of 'Okeyl; (Mṣb, TA;) and yawomu AljumuEapi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the most chaste form, (TA,) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; (Mṣb, TA;) and yawomu AljumaEapi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem; (Mṣb, TA;) and, in consequence of frequency of usage, AljumaEapu alone; (Mgh;) A well-known day; (Ḳ;) [the day of the congregation; i. e. Friday;] formerly called (TA) the day of AlEaruwbap: (Ṣ, TA:) called ywm AljmEp because of the congregating of the people thereon: (Mṣb:) Th asserts that the first who named it thus was Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; and he is related to have said that it was thus called because Kureysh used to gather themselves together to Kuseí, [on that day,] in [the building called] daAru Aln-adowapi: (TA:) accord. to the R, Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí was the first who collected a congregation on the day of AlErwbp, which was not called AljmEp save since the coming of El-Islám; [or it was not generally thus called before El-Islám; for it is added,] and he was the first who named it AljmEp; for Kureysh used to congregate to him on this day, and he used to preach to them, and to put them in mind of the mission of the apostle of God, informing them that he should be of his descendants, and bidding them to follow him and to believe in him: (TA:) or, as some say, it was thus called in the time of El-Islám because of their congregating [thereon] in the mosque: accord. to a trad., the Ansár named it thus, because of their congregating thereon: (TA:) or it was thus named because God collected thereon the materials of which Adam was created: (I’Ab:) those who say AljumaEapu regard it as an epithet, meaning that this day collects men much; comparing it to humazapN and lumazapN and DuHakapN: (TA:) the pl. is jumaEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jumoEaAtN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jumuEaAtN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jumaEaAtN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) of which the last is pl. of jumaEapN, [as well as of jumoEapN, accord. to analogy,] but not so jumaEN (AḤát) [nor either of the other pls. mentioned above].
In like manner you say SalaApN AljumoEapi [The prayer of Friday], and, in consequence of the frequency of usage, AljumoEapu alone. (Mgh.)

AljumoEapu, with the m quiescent, is also a name for [The week; i. e.] the days of the week [collectively]; of which the Arabs are said, by IAạr, to have reckoned the Sabbath (Als-abot [i. e. Saturday]) as the first, though they called Sunday the first of the days. (Mṣb.)
jumoEapN is also syn. with majomuwEapN [meaning Things collected together; or a collection of things]; (Ḳ;) as in the phrase jumoEapN mino HaSFI [a collection of pebbles]. (TA.)
You say also jumoEapN mino tamorK, meaning A handful of dates. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[jamoEiI-N Of, or relating to, a plural.]
jumaEiI-N One who fasts on Friday by himself. (IAạr, Th.)

hom.sense: jimaAEN: see jamoEN as signifying “a plural,” in three places. [The primary signification seems to be the last there mentioned; where it is said,] AljimaAEu is What comprises a number [of things]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one says, Alxamoru jimaAEu AlUivomi (Ṣ, TA) [i. e. Wine is what comprises a number of sins: or] that in which sin is comprised, and known to be: the saying is a trad.: (TA:) or jimaAEu AlUivomi signifies the plurality (jamoE) of sins. (Mṣb.) Hence also the saying of El-Ḥasan El-Basree, Ait-aquwA hecihi AlOahowaMCa faUin-a jimaAEahaA AlD-alaAlapu wamaEaAdahaA Aln-aAru [Beware ye of these natural desires; for what they involve is error, and the place to which they lead is the fire of Hell]. (TA: in the L, wmyEAdhA.) And it is said in a trad., Had-ivoniI bikalimapK takuwnu jimaAEFA i. e. Tell me a saying comprising [virtually] a plurality of sayings. (TA.) [See a similar phrase below, voce jaAmiEN.]

[Hence also,] buromapN jimaAEN A stonecooking-pot of the largest size: (Ks, L:) or qidorN jimaAEN, and jaAmiEapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) a cooking-pot that comprises a slaughtered camel; or, accord. to the A, that comprises a sheep or goat: (TA:) or a great cooking-pot; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaAmiEN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. [most probably of this last] jumoEN [like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
You say also, fulaAnN jimaAEN libaniI fulaAnK Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one. (TA.)
[See also 3.]

entry.sense: jamuwEN: see jam-aAEN.

jamiyEN In a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; [as also mujotamiEN↓;] contr. of mutafar-iqN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say qawomN jamiyEN A people, or number of men, in a state of collection,, &c.; being together; met together; syn. mujotamiEuwna↓: (TA:) and in like manner, UibilN jam-aAEapN↓ Camels in a state of collection;, &c. (TA.)
[All, or the whole, of any things or thing.] See OajomaEu, last sentence.

[As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A tribe [or any number of men] in a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; syn. HaI-N mujotamiEN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also jamoEN, in four places.
A man compact, or compressed, or contracted, in make, or frame: (mujotamiEu↓ Alxaloqi;) strong; who has not become decrepit nor infirm. (TA.)
rajulN jamiyEN All-aOomapi A man having his arms, or weapons, collected together. (TA.)
rajulN jamiyEu Alr-aOoIi, and mujotamiEuhu↓, A man of right, not disordered or unsettled, opinion, or judgment, or counsel. (TA.)

jaEala AlOamora jamiyEFA baEoda tafar-uqihi (AHeyth, Ḳ) He determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in his mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.)
jamaAEapN: see jamoEN, in two places.

jam-aAEN and mijomaEN↓ [are mentioned together, but not explained, in the TA: the former signifies, and probably, judging from analogy, the latter likewise, as also jamuwEN↓, One who collects much; or who collects many things].
UibilN jam-aAEapN: see jamiyEN
Anything of which the several component parts are collected, brought, gathered, or drawn, together. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] as an epithet, applied to a woman, it means Short. (TA.)

[Hence also,] jum-aAEN Alv-uray-aA The cluster of the Pleiades: (IDrd:) or persons who collect together for the rain of the Pleiades, which is the rain called AlwasomiI-, looking for the fruitfulness and herbage resulting from it. (IAạr.)

And jum-aAEu Aln-aAsi A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of various tribes; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jum-aAEN alone: (TA:) or the latter, people scattered, or in a state of dispersion. (Ḥam p. 302.)

jum-aAEN also signifies The place [either properly or tropically] which comprises the origin of anything; (Ḳ, TA;) the source of descent or extraction of people; and hence applied by I’Ab to main tribes from which other tribes are derived; or, as some say, used by him as meaning various classes of men, such as are termed OawozaAE and OawoXaAb. (TA.)
[And The main, or most essential, part of a thing. Thus,] jum-aAEu jasadi AlUinosaAni means The head of the man. (TA.)
jum-aAEu Alt-amori The contraction (tajam-uE) of the envelopes of the flowers of dates, in one place, upon [the germs of] the fruit, or produce, thereof. (TA.)
jaAmiEN [act. part. n. of 1; Collecting;, &c.]

AljaAmiEu one of the names of God; meaning The Collector of the created beings for the day of reckoning: or, as some say, the Combiner of things of similar natures and of things of contrary natures, in existence. (IAth.)
The belly; [because it collects what passes from the stomach;] of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

Also, (Mṣb,) or Almasojidu AljaAmiEu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [The congregational mosque;] the mosque in which the [congregational] prayers of Friday are performed; because it collects the people for a certain time; (Mṣb;) and you may also say, masojidu AljaAmiEi, meaning masojidu Alyawomi AljaAmiEi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as you say AlHaq-u Alyaqiynu and Haq-u Alyaqiyni, [the latter] as meaning Haq-u AlX-aIoCi Alyaqiyni; for it is not allowable to prefix a noun to another of the same meaning except with this kind of subaudition; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves: (Ṣ:) or msjd AljAmE is a mistake: (Ḳ:) so says Lth; but all others allow it; for the Arabs prefix a subst. to another signifying the same thing, and also to its epithet, as in the phrases in the Ḳur diynu Alqay-imapi [ch. xcviii. v. 4] and waEoda AlS-idoqi [ch. xlvi. v. 15]: (Az, TA:) [pl. jawaAmiEu.]

miSorN jaAmiEN [A great town comprising a large population; a comprehensive great town]. (Mṣb in art. mdn [where it is given as the explanation of madiynapN]; and Ḳ in art. qrI [where it is less properly given as the explanation of qaroyapN].)
qidorN jaAmiEN and jaAmiEapN: see jimaAEN
AimoraOapN jAmiEN: see the paragraph commencing with AljumoEu; last signification.
OataAnN jaAmiEN A she-ass pregnant when beginning to be so. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
jaAmiEapN↓ A [collar of the kind called] gul-; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because it collects together the two hands to the neck: (Ṣ:) pl. jawaAmiEu. (TA.)

OamorN jaAmiEN An affair that collects people together: or, as Er-Rághib says, a momentous affair, on account of which people collect themselves together; as though the affair itself collected them. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying,] AlS-alaApu jaAmiEapN likul-i Aln-aAsi Prayer is a collector of all people. (Mṣb.)

It is said of Moḥammad, (Mṣb,) kaAna yatakal-amu bijawaAmiEi Alkalimi He used to speak comprehensive but concise language; language conveying many meanings in few words. (Mṣb, Ḳ. [In the CK, Alklm is omitted.]) And hence the saying of ʼOmar Ibn-ʼAbd-el-'Azeez, Eajibotu limano laAHana Aln-aAsa kayofa laA yaEorifu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning [I wonder at him who vies with men in endeavouring to show his superiority of intelligence,] how it is that he does not [know the way to] confine himself to conciseness, and abstain from superfluity, of speech. (TA.) In like manner, (TA,) it is said in a trad., Ouwtiytu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning I have had communicated to me the Ḳur-án, (Ḳ, TA,) in which many meanings are comprised in a few words. (TA.) AljawaAmiEu mina Ald-uEaMCi, also, signifies Prayers, or supplications, combining petitions for good and right objects of desire with praise of God and with the general prescribed observances proper to the case. (TA.) You say also, Hamidotu Qll-eha bimajaAmiEi↓ AlmaHaAmidi I praised God with words comprising various forms of praise. (Mṣb.) [See also jimaAEN.]

rajulN jaAmiEN A man who combines such qualities that he is suited to hardship and to easiness of circumstances. (Aṣ. T in art. Adm.) And rajulN jaAmiEN liloxayori (T and M and Ḳ in art. Am) A man combining all kinds of good qualities. (TḲ in that art.)
daAb-apN jaAmiEN A beast fit for the UikaAf and the saroj [i. e. for the saddle of either of the kinds thus called]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

jamalN jaAmiEN, and naAqapN jaAmiEapN, (Ḳ,) accord. to ISh, (TA,) A he-camel, and a she-camel, that fails of putting forth the tooth called nAb at the time expected; expl. by OaxolafaA buzuwlFA: but this is not said except after four years: (Ḳ:) so in the copies of the Ḳ; but correctly, accord. to the O and TṢ, this is not said after four years, [app. reckoned from the usual time of bzwl, for this is in the ninth year, or, sometimes, in the eighth,] without the exceptive particle. (TA.)
jaAmiEapN used as a subst.: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: OajomaEu [Collecting, comprising, or containing, a greater, or the greatest, number or quantity; more, or most, comprehensive. Of its usage in a superlative sense, the following are exs.]. UicaA Oaxaca XaAhida zuwrK baEava bihi UilaI Als-uwqi OajomaEa maA kaAna [When he took a false witness, he sent him to the market when it comprised, or contained, the greatest number of people]: AjmE being here in the accus. case as a denotative of state with respect to the swq: and the reason why kAnt is not here said [instead of kAn] is that swq is sometimes masc. (Mgh.) And AifoEalo maA huwa OajomaEu liOuSuwli AlOaHokaAmi [Do thou that which is most comprehensive in relation to the principles of the ordinances applying to the case]. (Mṣb in art. HwT.)

[As a simple epithet, Entire, complete, or whole: fem. jamoEaMCu. You say,] bahiymapN jamoEaMCu A beast free from defects, entire in all its limbs or members, without mutilation, and without cauterization; (TA;) a beast from the body of which nothing has gone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naAqapN jamoEaMCu [may sometimes have the like meaning: or,] accord. to IAạr, (TA,) A she-camel extremely aged, (Ḳ, TA,) so that her teeth have become short, and almost gone. (TA.)

It is also a sing. having the meaning of a pl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) without any proper sing. of its own: (Ṣ:) its pl. is OajomaEuwna: and its fem. is jamoEaMCu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the pl. of this last is jumaEu, though by rule it should be formed by the addition of A and t to the sing., like as the pl. of OajomaEu is formed by the addition of w and n; (Ṣ;) the original form from which jumaEu is changed being jamoEaAwaAtN; or it is jamaAEaI; it is not jumoEN, because OajomaEu is not an epithet, like as OaHomaru is, of which the pl. is HumorN; (L;) for it is determinate, though of the measure of an epithet, which is indeterminate; (AAF;) and though it is in concordance with the noun which precedes it, like an epithet, it is shown to be not an epithet by its not having a broken pl.: (L:) it is a simple corroborative; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so are OajomaEuwna and jamoEaMCu and jumaEu; not used as an inchoative nor as an enunciative nor as the agent of a verb nor as the objective complement of a verb, like as are some other corroboratives, such as nafosuhu and Eayonuhu and kul-uhu. (Ṣ.) You say, Oaxacotu Haq-iI OajomaEa [I took my right, or due, all of it, or altogether]: and rOayotu Aln-isowapa jumaEa [I saw the women, all of them, or all together]: the last word in this and similar cases being imperfectly declinable, and determinate word: (Sudot;, TA:) and jaAWuwA OajomaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: and raOayotuhumo OajomaEiyna [I saw them, all of them, or all together]: and mararotu bihimo OajomaEiyna [I passed by them, all of them, or all together]. (Mṣb.) Fr mentions the phrases, OaEojabaniI AlqaSoru OajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether],
and Ald-aAru jamoEaMCa [The house, all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow OajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows OajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSal-uwA juluwsFA OajomaEiyna and OajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, OaEoniykumo OajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]: (Ḳ in art. btE:) or AjmEyn in this case is a corruption committed by the relaters in the first age; and he is in error who says that it is in the accus. case as a denotative of state, for corroboratives are determinate, and the denotative of state is literally or virtually indeterminate. (Mṣb.) [Respecting the usage of this corroborative together with others similar to it, see OabotaEu.] You say also, jaAWuwA biOajomaEihimo, and biOajomuEihimo, with damm to the m, [They came, all of them, or all together,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by ISk. (Mṣb.) And you say, qabaDotu AlmaAla OajomaEahu [I took, or received, the property, all of it, or altogether]. (Mṣb.) And jamiyEN↓, also, is used as a corroborative: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) as in the saying jaAWuwA jamiyEFA, meaning They came, all of them: (Ṣ:) and qabaDotu AlmaAla jamiyEahu, like OajomaEahu [explained above]: (Mṣb:) and jamiyEapF occurs as its fem.; but this is extr. (TA.)

entry.sense: majomaEN and majomiEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter anomalous, like maXoriqN and magoribN, &c., (TA,) A place of collecting, and the like: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) [pl. majaAmiEu] [Hence,] majomaEu AlbaHorayoni, in the Ḳur [xviii. 59], means The place where the two seas meet. (Bḍ.) And in like manner, where it is said in a trad., fDaraba biyadihi majomaEa bayona EunuqiI wakatifiI, [in which maA seems to have been dropped by the copyist between mjmE and byn,] the meaning is, [And he struck with his hand] the place where my neck and my shoulder-blade meet. (TA.) [Hence also the phrase majaAmiEu AlmaHaAmidi, explained above: see jaAmiEN, near the end of the paragraph. And majaAmiEu AlOumuwri, meaning The concurrences of affairs, or of circumstances, or of events.]

A place in which people collect, assemble, or congregate: (Mṣb,* TA:) and [in like manner,] majomaEapN↓ signifies an assembly-room; a sitting room in which people assemble: (TA:) [pl. of both majaAmiEu.] You say, hecaA AlkalaAmu Oawolaju fiI AlmasaAmiEi waOajowalu fiI AlmajaAmiEi [This language, or discourse, is more, or most, penetrating into the ears, and more, or most, circulating in the places of assembly]. (TA.)
See also jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN, in two places; and see 10, first sentence.
[The whole of anything, considered as the place in which the several parts thereof are collected: see an instance voce xuf-N: and see also mujotamaEN.]

OamorN mujomaEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mujomaEN Ealayohi, (TA,) An affair determined, resolved, or decided, upon: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an affair agreed upon. (TA.) [The former signification applies to both of the abovementioned phrases: the latter signification, perhaps, only to the latter phrase.]
xuTobapN mujomaEapN [A discourse in rhyming prose, or the like,] in which is no flaw, or defect. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

EaAmN mujomiEN A year of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness: (Ks, Ḳ:) because it is an occasion of people's collecting together in the place where herbage, or plenty, is found. (Ks.) And falaApN mujomiEapN, (Ṣ, TA,) like muHosinapN; (TA;) [in Gol. Lex., erroneously, mujomaEapN;] and mujam-iEapN↓, like muHad-ivapN; (TA;) A desert in which people collect themselves together, not separating themselves, from fear of losing their way, or perishing, and the like; as though the desert itself collected them. (Ṣ, TA.) And OaroDN mujomiEapN, like muHosinapN, A land of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness, wherein the camels upon which people journey are not dispersed to pasture. (TA.)
mijomaEN: see jam-aAEN.

hom.sense: majomaEapN: see majomaEN:
and jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN.
Also Sands collected together: (Ḳ:) pl. majaAmiEu. (TA.) And A vacant, or void, land, destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: falaApN mujam-iEapN: see mujomiEN.

majomuwEN Collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drawn together; [or contracted;] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) [from several places, or] hence and thence, although not made as one thing. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, L, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xi. 105], celika yawomN majomuwEN lahu Aln-aAsi That is a day for which mankind shall be collected. (TA.)
See also jamoEN.

mujotamaEN [A place in which a thing becomes collected, brought together, or the like; or in which things have become so; where they collect themselves, come together, or unite; or in which they are comprised, or contained; a place in which is a collection of things]. You say, AlbayoDapu mujotamaEu Alwaladi [The egg is that which comprises the young bird]. (Mgh in art. byD.) And mujotamaEu Almawoti signifies the same as HawoDu Almawoti, which see, in art. HwD. (TA in that art.)
[Also The collective mass, or whole, of the hair of the head: (see jum-apN, in three places:) mujotamaEu XaEori Alr-aOosi meaning the whole head of hair: see also majomaEN.]
mujotamiEN: see jamiyEN, in five places.

A man who has attained to his full state of manly vigour, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) and whose beard has become fullgrown: (TA:) because at that time his powers have become collected, or because his beard is then full-grown. (Mgh.) [See the verb, 8. And see an ex. in a verse of Suheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. dwr, conj. 3.]
OaloqaAhu mujotamiEFA [He threw him down gathered together, or in a heap]. (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. kwr.)
maXaI mujotamiEFA He walked quickly, (Ḳ, TA,) with vehemence of motion, and strength of limbs, not languidly. (TA.)
mutajam-aEu AlbayodaMCi The main part of the desert; the part in which [as it were] it collects itself; syn. muEaZamuhaA wamuHotafaluhaA. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jamala, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajomulu}, inf. n. jamolN, (TA,) He collected [a thing, or things]. (Ḳ.) [See also 4.]

Also, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Mgh,) He melted fat; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and so Ajtml↓, and Ajml↓: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) this last was sometimes used: (Ṣ:) the best form is jamala: (Fr, TA:) accord. to Z, Ajtml↓ signifies he made the melted grease of fat to drip upon bread, putting it again over the fire. (TA. [See jamiylN.]) jamalaka Qll-ehu, meaning May God melt thee like as fat is melted, is a form of imprecation mentioned in a trad., as used by a woman. (TA.)
jamala Aljamala He put the he-camel apart from the she-camel that was fit to be covered. (TA.)

jamula, aor. _u {yajomulu}; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and jamila, aor. _a {yajomalu}; (Mṣb;) inf. n. jamaAlN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) originally jamaAlapN; (Mṣb;) He was, or became, beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in person, (M, Ḳ,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (Ḳ:) or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Sb, Mṣb:) or characterized by much goodness, beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also, characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See jamaAlN, below; and see also jamiylN.]

2. jm-l, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajomiylN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, embellished, or adorned, another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, UicaA lamo yujam-iloka maAluka lamo yujodi Ealayoka jamaAluka [If thy wealth do not embellish thee, thy beauty of person, or of moral character, will not suffice thee]. (TA.) And you say, jam-ala Qll-ehu Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, meaning, May God render him beautiful. (TA.)
He gave a camel to be eaten. (Ḳ in art. brqX.)
He detained an army long [on the frontier of the enemy]; (Ḳ, TA;) like jam-ara [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. jAmlhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAmalapN, (Ṣ, TA,) He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely behaviour or speech (biAljamiyli), not rendering him pure, or sincere, brotherly affection: (ISd, Ḳ:) or he associated with him in a good manner: (Ḳ:) or he treated him with comely behaviour. (Ṣ, TA.) One says, Ealayoka biAlmudaAraApi waAlmujaAmalapi [Keep thou to blandishment and coaxing,, &c.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajml He collected a thing (Mṣb, Ḳ) without discrimination, or distinction, (Mṣb,) or from a state of separation, or dispersion. (Ḳ.) [See also 1.] And Oujomila It was collected into an aggregate. (TA.)
He reduced a calculation to its sum; summed it up: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner, he summed up a speech, or discourse, and then analyzed and explained it. (TA.)
See also 1.
He made good and large [or liberal]: so in the phrase, Ajml AlS-aniyEapa (Ṣ, Ḳ) He made the benefit good and large [or liberal] (Ḳ) Einoda fulaAnK [to such a one]. (Ṣ.)

[He acted with goodness, or was good and liberal: and he acted with moderation, or was moderate. You say,] Ajml fiI SaniyEihi [He was good and liberal, or, perhaps, moderate, in his benefit]. (Ṣ.) And Ajml fiI AlT-alabi He was moderate, not extravagant, in demanding, or desire. (Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA.) It is said in a trad., OajomiluwA fiI Talabi Alr-izoqi faUin-a kul-FA muyas-arN limaA xuliqa lahu [Be ye moderate in demanding, or desiring, the means of subsistence, for every one is accommodated to that which is created for him]. (TA.)
Ajml Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had many camels; or their camels became many. (Ṣ.)
5. tjm-l He beautified, embellished, or adorned, himself. (Ḳ.)

He affected what is jamiyl [or beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, in person, or in action or actions or behaviour, or in moral character,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) You say, tjm-l biOakovara mim-aA Einodahu [He affected beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, qualities, more than he possessed]. (TA in art. XbE.)

He was, or became, patient; or restrained himself from impatience; or constrained himself to be patient: (Mgh, TA:) from jamaAlN meaning “patience.” (Mgh.) Hence the saying,
waUicaA tuSiboka xaSaASapN fatajam-ali
And when poverty, or straitness, befalls thee, then be patient, or restrain thyself, &c. (Mgh in art. xS.)
He ate what is termed jamiyl, i. e., melted fat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
8. Ajtml: see 1, in two places.
Also He anointed himself with fat. (TA.)
And He ate of a camel. (Ḳ in art. brqX.)

entry.sense: 10. Astjml He (a camel) became a jamal, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year], (Ṣ,) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year], or, accord. to Z, one that had covered. (TA.)
jamolN: see jamalN.
jumolN: see jumolapN and jum-alN; the latter in two places.

jamalN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and jamolN↓, (Ḳ,) which latter is so rare that it is said by some to be used only in poetry, in cases of necessity, (MF,) but it is a correct dial. var., (TA,) a word of well-known meaning; (Ḳ;) i. e., [A he-camel; but commonly applied to the camel as a generic term; in like manner as jaAmilN is applied to the males and the females; but properly,] the male of the Uibil; (TA;) the mate of the naAqap; (Fr, Ṣ, Mgh;) among camels, corresponding to rajulN among us; (Sh, Mṣb;) naAqapN corresponding to maroOapN, and bakorN to gulaAmN, and bakorapN to jaAriyapN; (Sh, TA;) [in general] peculiarly applied to the male; (Mṣb;) exceptionally to the female, as in the saying Xaribotu labana jamaliI, (Ḳ,) i. e., I drank the milk of my she-camel; but ISd doubts the correctness of this: (TA:) [as corresponding to rajulN among us, it signifies a full-grown he-camel:] or it signifies such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year]: (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ:) or such as is termed jacaEN [or one in his fifth year]: (ISd, Ḳ:) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year]: (ISd, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or such as is termed vaniI-N [or one in his sixth year]: (ISd, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Z, one that has covered: (TA:) [see also baEiyrN, and bakorN, and qaEuwdN:] pl. [of pauc.] OajomaAlN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which may be pl. of jamolN, (TA,) and OajomulN (Mṣb) and [of mult.] jimaAlN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jumolN (Ḳ) and jimaAlapN (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [quasi-pl. n.] jumaAlapN and jamaAlapN and jaAmilN, (Ḳ,) which last is disallowed by some, as will be seen below, (TA,) and [pl. pl.] jimaAlaAtN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is pl. of jimaAlN, (Mṣb, TA,) or it may be pl. of jimaAlapN, (TA,) and jumaAlaAtN [which see also voce jum-alN] and jamaAlaAtN (Ḳ) and jamaAYilu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. of jmAlp and jimAl, (Ḥam p. 527,) and OajaAmilu. (Ḳ.) One says of camels, when they are males, without any female among them, hecihi jimaAlapu baniI fulaAnK [These are the he-camels of the sons of such a one]. (ISk, Ṣ. [See also jumaAlapN.]) And they said also jimaAlaAni [meaning Two herds of camels, thus forming a dual from the pl. jimaAlN], like as they said liqaAHaAni. (ISd, in TA voce xayolN.) It is said in a prov., maAQsotatara mano qaAda Aljamala [He does not conceal himself who leads the he-camel]. (TA.) And in another prov., Ait-axaca All-ayola jamalFA † He journeyed all the night. (Ḳ, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 230.])

Aljamalu also signifies A certain fish (IAạr, Ḳ) of the sea, (IAạr, TA,) thirty cubits in length: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, jamalu AlbaHori is the name of a very great fish, also called the baAl, [i. e., the whale,] thirty cubits in length: accord. to some, this, (TA,) or jamalu AlmaMCi, (Mgh,) is what is called the kawosaj and kubaE (Mgh, TA) and luxom, [i. e., xiphias, or sword-fish,] which passes by nothing without cutting it. (TA.) [In the present day, jamalu AlbaHori is an appellation of The pelican.]
Eayonu Aljamali, in the dial. of Egypt, i. q. AlX-aAh bal-uwT [The chestnut]. (TA.)
jamalN signifies also † A woman's husband. (L in arts. Axc and qyd. See 2 in each of those arts.)

Also ‡ Palm-trees; (Ḳ;) as being likened to the he-camel in respect of their tallness and their bigness and their produce: in some of the copies of the Ḳ, Aln-aHolu is erroneously put for Aln-axolu. (TA.)
See also jum-alN.
jumalN: see jum-alN, in three places.
jumulN A company, or congregated body, of men. (ISd, Ḳ.)
See also jum-alN.
jumolapN A strand of a thick rope: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] jumolN↓: or many strands of a rope, put together [to compose a cable: see jum-alN]. (TA, in two places in this art.)

Hence, app., (TA,) The aggregate of a thing; (Ḳ;) the sum, whole, or total; (KL, PṢ;) it implies muchness, or numerousness, and means any aggregate unseparated: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. jumalN. (Ṣ.) [jumolapN mino maAlK generally means A large sum of money; and in a similar sense jumolapN is often used in relation to various things.] It is said in the Ḳur [xxv. 34], waqaAla Ql-aciyna kafaruwA lawo laA nuz-ila Ealayohi QloquroMnu jumolapF waAHidapF, i. e., [And those who disbelieved said, Wherefore was not the Ḳur-án sent down, or revealed, to him] aggregated? (TA:) [or in one aggregate?] or at once? (Bḍ.) [Hence, biAljumolapi as meaning Upon the whole; to sum up.]

And hence, in grammar, (TA,) [A proposition; a clause; a phrase; sometimes, a sentence;] a phrase composed of a subject and an attribute, [i. e., composed of an inchoative and an enunciative, (in which case it is termed jumolapN Qsomiy-apN,) or of a verb and its agent, (in which case it is termed jumolapN fiEoliy-apN,)] (KT, TA,) [&c.,] whether affording a complete sense, as zayodN qaAYimN [Zeyd is standing], or not, as Uino yukorimoniI [If he treat me with honour]. (KT.)
jamolaMCu: see jamiylN.
jamaluwna A building, or structure, in the form of a camel's hump: (TA:) [a ridged roof: so in the present day: pl. jamaAliynu.]

jamaAlN inf. n. of jamula: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) [when used as a simple subst., meaning] Beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, syn. HusonN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,* Ḳ,) in person, (M, Ḳ,) and goodness in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also, in moral character: (Ḳ:) or elegance, or prettiness; i. e., delicacy, or minuteness, of beauty: (Sb, Mṣb:) or much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in the mind, or in the person, or in the actions or behaviour; and also, much goodness that is communicated from its possessor to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to Aṣ, [when relating to the person,] HusonN is in the eyes; and jamaAlN, in the nose. (TA in art. Hsn.) [See also jamiylN.] One says, jamaAlaka Oano laA tafoEala kacaA, (ISd, Ḳ,) or Oano tafoEala kacaA, (IDrd, TA,) meaning, Keep to that which is most comely for thee to do, and do not thus. (IDrd, ISd, Ḳ. [But see what follows.])

Also Patience. (Mgh in art. xS.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
jamaAlaka Oay-uhaA Alqalobu AlqariyHu
sataloqaI mano tuHib-u fatasotariyHu , (Ṣ,* TA, the former of which cites only the first hemistich, and the latter substitutes AljariyHu for its syn. AlqariyHu,) meaning, [Keep thy patience, O thou wounded heart: thou wilt find whom thou lovest, and be at rest: or] keep to thy patience, or thy constraint of thyself to be patient, and thy shrinking from what is foul, and be not impatient in an evil manner. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: jumaAlN: see jamiylN:
and jumaAlapN.

entry.sense: jamuwlN A piece of fat melted. (IAạr, TA.) [See also jamiylN.]
A fat woman. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A person, (Ḳ,) or woman, (M,) who melts fat. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jamiylN Melted fat: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or melting fat: or fat that is melted and collected: (Ḳ, TA:) or fat that is melted, and, whenever it drips, made to drip upon bread, and then replaced over the fire [that it may drip again: see jamala]: (TA:) and jumaAlapN↓, also, signifies [the same; or] melted grease. (Mgh,* TA.) [See also jamuwlN.]

Hence, accord. to Abu-l-ʼAlà, because, when a man becomes fat and in good condition, his jamaAl becomes apparent, (Ḥam p. 155,) as also jumaAlN↓ and jum-aAlN↓, (Ḳ,) or this last denotes a higher degree of beauty than jamiylN, (Ṣ, Ṣgh,) and has no broken pl., (TA,) and Oajomalu↓, (TA,) Beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in person, (M, Ḳ,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (Ḳ:) [like the Greek καλὸς, the Latin pulcher, the French beau,, &c.; and so HasanN:] or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Mṣb:) [or characterized by much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others: see jamaAlN:] pl. of the first jamaAlN: (TA:) fem. jamiylapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to a woman; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also jamolaMCu↓, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [said to be] an instance of [the measure] faEolaMCu having no [masc. of the measure] OafoEalu; (TA;) [but see above;] or this is applied to any female as signifying perfect, or complete, in body. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Uin-a Qll-eha jamiylN yuHib-u AljimaAla Verily God is comely in deeds, (TA,) or an Abundant Bestower of good things: He loveth those who are of the like character. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And you say, EaAmalahu baAljamiyli [He treated him with comely, or pleasing, behaviour]. (TA.) And maAsaHahu biAljamiyl [He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely, or pleasing, behaviour or speech]. (ISd, Ḳ. [See 3.])

Oabuw jamiylK [The kind of plants called] Albaqol; because they embellish by their presence, and render good, the seasoning of food; or because they take away the jamiyl, i. e., the grease of the flesh-meat, and dry up the food. (Ḥar p. 227.)

entry.sense: jamaAlapN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: jumaAlapN: see jum-alN:
and jamiylN.

Also A herd, or distinct number, of camels; (Ḳ;) mentioned before as a pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: (TA:) or, of she-camels among which is no he-camel; as also jimaAlapN↓ and jamaAlapN↓; (Ḳ;) but this is contradictory to a saying of ISk [respecting jimaAlapN], mentioned above [voce jamalN; where all these three words are said to be pls. of jamalN]: (TA:) and also horses: pl. jumaAlN↓, which is extr. [as a pl.; though, in relation to jumaAlapN, it may be a coll. gen. n., forming its n. un. with p]. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jimaAlapN: see what next precedes.
jamiylapN A number of gazelles together: and of pigeons. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

jumaAliI-N applied to a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Large in make: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or tall in body: (Mṣb:) or firm [in make], (Ḳ,) or big in limbs, complete in make, (TA,) like a he-camel. (Ḳ, TA.) And with p {jumaAliy-apN} applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Resembling a he-camel in greatness of make: (Ṣ:) or firm (Ḳ, TA) in make, (TA,) like a he-camel (Ḳ, TA) in greatness of make and in strength. (TA.)

hom.sense: jum-alN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and jumalN↓ and jumolN↓ (Ḳ) and jumulN↓ and jamalN↓ (IJ, Ḳ) [A cable;] the rope of a ship, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., the thick rope thereof, (TA,) that is also called qalosN, (Ṣ, TA,) consisting of [a number of] ropes put together: (Ṣ:) and jumaAlapN↓ also signifies [the same; or] a thick rope, because consisting of many strands put together; pl. jumaAlaAtN; (Zj, TA;) which Mujáhid explains as meaning the ropes of bridges; but I’Ab, as the ropes of ships, put together so as to be like the waists of men [in thickness]. (TA.) In all the forms mentioned above, except the last (jmAlp), the word is read in the phrase [in the Ḳur vii. 38], Hat-aI yalija Aljum-alu fiI sam-i AlxiyaATi [Until the cable shall enter into the eye of the needle]: (Ḳ, TA:) I’Ab reads Aljum-alu, (Ṣ, TA,) and so do ʼAlee and many others: jumolN↓ is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of jumolapN, a strand of a thick rope; or, accord. to IJ, pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: the first is explained by Fr as meaning ropes put together; but Aboo-Tálib thinks that he meant jumalN↓, without teshdeed. (TA.)
HisaAbu Aljum-ali, (Ṣ Ḳ,) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic, (TA,) and Aljumali↓, (Ḳ,) but IDrd doubts its correctness, The calculation by means of the letters d j b A, &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: jam-aAlN An owner, or an attendant, of a camel or camels: (KL, TA:* [see also jAmilN:]) and jam-aAlapN owners, or attendants, of camels; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) similar to xay-aAlapN and Ham-aArapN; (Ṣ, TA;) as the former is to Ham-aArN. (TA.) [See an ex. of the latter in a verse cited voce UicaA.]
jum-aAlN: see jamiylN.

hom.sense: jaAmilN [act. part. n. of jamala.]

[And also part. n. of jamula.] The Arabs say, Aujomulo Uino kunota jaAmilFA [Become beautiful,, &c., if thou be becoming beautiful,, &c.]: but when they mean the quality [alone], they say, Uin-ahu lajamiylN [Verily he is beautiful,, &c.]. (Lḥ, TA.)
A man possessing a jamal [or he-camel]. (TA. [See also jam-aAlN.])

A herd, or distinct number, of camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) males and females, (TA,) with their pastors and their owners: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [also said in the Ḳ to be a pl. of jamalN: in the CK, AljAmiEu is erroneously put for AljaAmilu:]) or a word formed to denote a pl., meaning camels, (Ḥam pp. 122 and 490,) males and females; (Id p. 122;) derived from jamalN; (Id. p. 490;) like baAqirN (Id. ib. and TA) from baqarN, (Ḥam p. 490,) and kaAlibN [from kalobN]. (TA.)
Also A great tribe. (AHeyth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Oajomalu [More, and most, jamiyl, or beautiful,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also jamiylu.
mujomalN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]

[Also, applied to a phrase or the like,] properly, Including, or implying, a number of things, many and unexplained: (Er-Rághib, TA:) as used by the lawyers, [confused, or] requiring explanation. (TA.)
mujaAmilN [act. part. n. of 3, q. v.]
[Also] One who is unable to answer a question put to him by another person, and therefore neglects it, and bears malice against him for some time. (TA.)

jumaAnN Beads made of silver, like pearls; (Ṣ;) things in the form of pearls, of silver; (Ḳ;) one of which is called jumaAnapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. jumaAnaAtN: (Ḥar p. 181:) or pearls (Ḳ, TA) themselves: (TA:) or the first is the proper meaning, and this is metaphorical: (EM p. 161:) [said to be] a Persian word, arabicized. (TA.) Also A kind of belt (safiyfap) woven of leather, in which are beads of every colour, worn by a woman as a wiXaAH [q. v.]: or silvered beads. (Ḳ.)
Q. 1. jamohara, (T, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. jamoharapN, (A,) He collected together (T, A, Ḳ) a thing, (TA,) or earth, or dust, (T, A, TA,) one part upon another. (T, TA.)
jmhr Alqabora, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He collected the earth, or dust, over the grave, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) not plastering it with clay, or mud, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) nor making it even, or level. (TA.)
jmhr AlmataAEa He took the main part of the household-goods, or commodities: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to plants, or herbage. (Kitáb el- Addád, TA.)

jmhr Ealayohi Alxabara, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or lahu, (Lth, TA,) or Uilayohi, (AZ, TA,) He acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, and concealed what he desired, or meant: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, incorrectly, or not in the proper manner, and omitted what he desired, or meant: (Lth, TA:) or he acquainted him with a small portion thereof, omitting most of what was necessary for him to know, and relating it in a manner different from the proper way: (AZ, TA:) and accord. to the Kitáb el-Addád of Abu-t-Teiyib the Lexicologist, it seems to have a contr. signification; for he says that jamoharotu laka Alxabara means, I acquainted thee with the main part of the news, or story. (TA.)
Q. 2. tajamohara EalayonaA He held up his head with an assumption of superiority over us; domineered over us; or exalted himself above us. (TA.)
jamoharapN [originally inf. n. of jamohara]: see the next paragraph.

jumohuwrN (not jamohuwrN, which is a form of the word mentioned by Et-Tilimsánee, MF) A quantity of sand rising above what is around it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and collected together; (Ṣ;) as also ↓ with p {jumohuwrapN}; (L;) so called from its abundance and height: (Mṣb:) or a large quantity of sand, heaped up, and extensive: (Lth, TA:) and ↓ with p {jumohuwrapN}, sand compacted together, and extending in an oblong form upon the surface of the earth. (TA.)

The generality, or main part, of men, or people: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and the eminent, elevated, or noble, of them: (TA:) and a great number of people: (Mṣb:)
pl. jamaAhiyru; (A, Mṣb;) which signifies also collective bodies of men. (TA.) You say, hecaA qawolu Aljumohuwri This is the saying of the generality, or main part. (A.)
The generality; the greater, main, or chief, part; the main body, main, gross, mass, or bulk; of anything; (Ḳ;) as also jamoharapN↓. (W 95.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or jumohuwrapN↓, (TA,) A noble, or high-born, woman. (Ḳ, TA.)
jumohuwrapN: see jumohuwrN, in three places.

jumohuwriI-N An intoxicating beverage: (AO, Ḳ:) or [beverage of the kind called] nabiyc made of grapes, that is three years old: (Ḳ:) or i. q. buxotajN; (TA;) which is expressed juice [of grapes] cooked (Mgh voce bxtj, and TA) so as to be reduced to one third, (Mgh,) such as is lawful to be drunk: (TA:) or the beverage called bxtj to which what has gone from it has been restored, and which is then cooked, and put into vessels, and becomes very potent: (AḤn, and Mgh ubi suprà, and TA:) or juice of grapes cooked until half of it is gone and half remains: (KL:) called jmhwrI- because used by most men. (TA.)
jumaAhirN Large, big, bulky, or corpulent. (TA.)
mujamoharapN A she-camel compact in make; (Ḳ;) as though she were a jumohuwr of sand. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jan-ahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajonunu}, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. jan-N, (TA,) It veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, him; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) said of the night; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jan-a Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yajonunu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. junuwnN, (Ṣ,) or jan-N, (Ḳ,) or both; (TA;) so in the Ḳur vi. 76, meaning it veiled him, concealed him, or covered him, with its darkness; (Bḍ;) and Ajn-hu↓: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or this last signifies he, or it, made, or prepared, for him, or gave him, that which should veil him, conceal him,, &c.: accord. to Er-Rághib, the primary signification of jan-N is the veiling, or concealing,, &c., from the sense. (TA.) And jun-a Eanohu means It (anything) was veiled, concealed, or hidden, from him. (Ḳ.)

He concealed it; namely, a dead body; as also Ajn-hu↓: (Ṣ, TA:) or the latter, he wrapped it in grave-clothing: (Ḳ:) and he buried it. (TA.) And Oajonanotu↓ AlX-aIoCa fiI SadoriI I concealed the thing in my bosom. (Ṣ.) And Oajan-ato↓ waladFA, (Ṣ,) or janiynFA, (Ḳ,) said of a woman, (Ṣ,) or a pregnant female, (Ḳ,) She concealed [or enveloped in her womb a child, or an embryo, or a fœtus]. (TA.)
jan-a, aor. _i {yajoninu}, inf. n. jin-N, It (an embryo, or a fœtus,) was concealed in the womb. (Ḳ.)
Also, [inf. n., probably, jin-N and junuwnN and janaAnN, explained below,] It (the night) was, or became, dark. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof.)

jun-a, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. junuwnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jin-apN (Ṣ) and jan-N; (Ḳ;) and Ausotujin-N↓, and tjn-n↓, and tjAn-↓; (Ḳ;) He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jin-iI-, or by jin-; possessed by a devil or demon; (see Bḍ li. 39;) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: the verbs may generally be rendered he was, or became, possessed; or mad, or insane]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
jun-a Alc-ubaAbu, (Ṣ, A, TA,) inf. n. junuwnN, (TA,) † The flies made much buzzing: (Ṣ:) or made a gladsome buzzing in a meadow. (A, TA.)

jun-a Aln-abotu, inf. n. junuwnN, ‡ The herbage became tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and put forth its flowers or blossoms: (Ṣ, TA:) or became thick and tall and full-grown, and blossomed. (M, TA.) And jun-ati AlOaroDu, (Fr, Ḳ,) inf. n. junuwnN, (Ḳ,) ‡ The land produced pleasing herbage or plants: (Fr, TA:) or put forth its flowers and blossoms; as also tjn-nt↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in four places:
and see 8.

Also Ajn-hu He (God) caused him to be, or become, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jin-iI-, or by jin-; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [And so, vulgarly, jn-nhu↓, whoever, or whatever, be the agent.]

mA Ajn-hu [How mad, or insane,, &c., is he!] is anomalous, (Th, Ṣ,) being formed from a verb of the pass. form, namely, jun-a; (Th, TA;) for of the maDoruwb one should not say, maA OaDorabahu; nor of the masoluwl should one say, maA Oasal-ahu: (Ṣ:) Sb says that the verb of wonder is used in this case because it denotes want of intellect [which admits of degrees]. (TA.)
Ajn- also signifies waqaEa fiI majan-apK [app. meaning He fell into, or upon, a place containing, or abounding with, jin-]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.

tjn-n Ealayohi, and tajaAnana↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tajaAn-a↓, (Ṣ,) He feigned himself majonuwn [i. e. possessed by a jin-iI-, or by jin-; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane,, &c.;] to him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not being really so. (TA.)
6. tajaAn-a and tajaAnana: see 1:
and see also 5.

8. Ajtn-, (accord, to the Ṣ,) or Ajn-↓, (accord. to the Ḳ,) He was, or became, veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected, or he veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, himself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Eanohu from him, or it; (Ḳ;) as also Astjn↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Astjn↓ bijun-apK He was, or became, veiled,, &c., or he veiled himself,, &c., by a thing whereby he was veiled,, &c. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 10: see 8, in two places:
and see also 1.
AisotijonaAnN is also syn. with AisotiToraAbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Astjn-hu meaning AstTrbhu, i. e. He excited him to mirth, joy, gladness, or sport. (TḲ.)

jin-N The darkness of night; as also junuwnN↓ and janaAnu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) the last [written in the CK junAn, but it is] with fet-ḥ: (TA:) or all signify its intense darkness: (TA:) or all, the confusedness of the darkness of night: (Ḳ:) [all, in these senses, are app. inf. ns.: (see 1:)] the last, janaAnN↓, also signifies night [itself]: (Ḳ:) or [so in copies of the Ḳ, accord. to the TA, but in the CK “and,”] the dense black darkness of night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and junuwnN↓, the veiling, or concealing, or protecting, darkness of night. (ISk, Ṣ.)

Concealment: so in the phrase, laA jin-a bihecaA AlOamori There is no concealment with this thing. (Ḳ,* TA.) One of the Hudhalees says,
walaA jin-a biAlbagoDaMCi waAln-aZari AlX-azori
[And there is no concealment with vehement hatred and the looking with aversion]. (TA.)

[The genii; and sometimes the angels;] accord. to some, the spiritual beings that are concealed from the senses, or that conceal themselves from the senses; all of such beings; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the opposite of UinosN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Er-Rághib, TA;) thus comprising the angels; all of these being jin-; (Er-Rághib, TA;) thus called because they are feared but not seen: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to others, certain of the spiritual beings; for the spiritual beings are of three kinds; the good being the angels; and the evil being the devils (XayaATiyn); and the middle kind, among whom are good and evil, being the jin-; as is shown by the first twelve verses of ch. lxxii. of the Ḳur: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here means intelligent invisible bodies, predominantly of the fiery, or of the aerial, quality: or a species of souls, or spirits, divested of bodies: or human souls separate from their bodies: (Bḍ:) or the jin- are the angels [exclusively]; (Ḳ;) these being so called in the Time of Ignorance, because they were concealed, or because they concealed themselves, from the eyes: so, accord. to some, in the Ḳur [xviii. 48], where it is said that Iblees was of the jin-: and so, as some say, in the Ḳur [vi. 100], where it is said that they called the jin- partners of God: (TA:) but some reject the explanation in the Ḳ, because the angels were created of light, and the jin- of fire; and the former do not propagate their kind, nor are they to be described as males and females; contrary to the case of the jin-; wherefore it is generally said that in the phrase [in the Ḳur xviii. 48, above mentioned] Uil-aA Uiboliysa kaAna mina Aljin-i, what is excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made, or that Iblees had adopted the dispositions of the jin-: (MF, TA:) or, as some say, the jin- were a species of the angels, who were the guardians of the earth and of the gardens of Paradise: (TA:) jin-apN↓, also, signifies the same as jin-N: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so in the last verse of the Ḳur: (Ṣ:) in the Ḳur xxxvii. 158 meaning the angels, whom certain of the Arabs worshipped; (TA;) and whom they called the daughters of God: (Fr, TA:) a single individual of the jin- is called jin-iI-N↓, [fem. with p {jin-apN}:] (Ṣ, TA:) and jaAn-N↓, also, is syn. with jin-N: (Mṣb:) or AljaAnN means the father of the jin-; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) [i. e. any father of jin-; for] the pl. is jin-aAnN, like HiyTaAnN pl. of HaAYiTN: (Ṣ, TA:) so says El-Ḥasan:
it is said in the T, on the authority of AA, that the jAn- is, or are, of the jin-: (TA:) or jaAn-N is a quasi-pl. n. of jin-N; (M, Ḳ;) like jaAmilN and baAqirN: (M, TA:) so in the Ḳur lv. 56 and 74: in reading the passage in the Ḳur lv. 39, ʼAmr Ibn-ʼObeyd pronounced it jaOanN: (TA:) it is related that there were certain creatures called the jaAn-, who were upon the earth, and who acted corruptly therein, and shed blood, wherefore God sent angels who banished them from the earth; and it is said that these angels became the inhabitants of the earth after them. (Zj, TA.) baAta fulaAnN Dayofa jin-K [Such a one passed the night a guest of jn-] means, in a desolate place, in which was no one that might cheer him by his society or converse. (TA.) The saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir,
famaA nafarato jin-iI walaA ful-a miboradiI
may mean And my companions, who were like the jin-, did not flee when I came to them and informed them, nor was my tongue, that is like the file, deprived of its sharp edge: or by his jn- he means his familiar jn-, such as were asserted to aid poets when difficulties befell them; and by his mbrd, his tongue: (Ḥam p. 182 [where other explanations are proposed; but they are far-fetched]:) or by his jn- he means his heart; and by his mbrd, his tongue. (Ṣ.) The Arabs liken a man who is sharp and effective in affairs to a jin-iI- and a XayoTaAn: and hence they said, nafarato jin-uhu, meaning † He became weak and abject. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

The greater, main, or chief, part, or the main body, or bulk, of men, or of mankind; as also janaAnN↓; (Ḳ;) because he who enters among them becomes concealed by them: (TA:) or the latter means the general assemblage, or collective body, of men: (IAạr, Ṣ,* TA:) or what veils, conceals, covers, or protects, one, of a thing. (AA, TA.)
‡ The flowers, or blossoms, of plants or herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)

‡ The prime, or first part, of youth: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or the sharpness, or vigorousness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, thereof. (TA.) You say, kaAna celik fiI jin-i XabaAbihi ‡ That was in the prime, or first part, of his youth. (Ṣ, TA.) And OafoEalu celika AlOamora bijin-i celika ‡ I will do that thing in the time of the first and fresh state of that. (Ṣ, TA.) jin-N may also signify † The madness, or insanity, of exultation, or of excessive exultation. (TA.) And one says, Ait-qi Aln-Aqapa faUin-haA bijin-i DiraAmihaA, meaning † Fear thou the she-camel, for she is in her evil temper on the occasion of her bringing forth. (TA.)
Also i. q. jd- [app. jid-N, as meaning † Seriousness, or earnestness]; because it is a thing that is an accompaniment of thought, or reflection, and is concealed by the heart. (TA.)

entry.sense: jan-apN A [garden, such as is called] busotaAn: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or a garden, or walled garden, (Hadiyqap, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of trees, or of palm-trees, (Mṣb,) or of palms and other trees: (Ḳ:) or only if containing palm-trees and grape-vines; otherwise, if containing trees, called Hdyqp: (Aboo-ʼAlee in the Tedhkireh, TA:) or any bstAn having trees by which the ground is concealed: and sometimes concealing trees: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and palm-trees: (Ṣ:) or tall palm-trees: (Mgh:) or shadowing trees; because of the tangling, or luxuriousness of their branches; as though concealing at once what is beneath them: then a bstAn; because of its dense and shadowing trees: (Bḍ in ii. 23:) or a bstAn of palms and other trees, dense, and shadowing by the tangling, or luxuriousness, and denseness, of their branches; as though it were originally the inf. n. of un. of jan-ahu, and meaning “a single act of veiling” or “concealing”, &c.: (Ksh ib.:) then, with the article Al, [Paradise,] the abode of recompense; because of the jinaAn therein; (Ksh and Bḍ ib.;) or because the various delights prepared therein for mankind are concealed in the present state of existence: (Bḍ ib.:) [and] hence Aljan-aAtu [the gardens of Paradise], (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or jan-aAtu EadonK [the gardens of continual abode]: (so in another copy of the Ṣ:) [for] the pl. of jan-apN is Oajin-apN (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jinayonap (Mṣb, TA) and jun-apN, but this last is strange. (MF, TA.) [Dim. junayonapN↓, vulgarly pronounced jinayonap, and applied to A garden; as though it were a little Paradise.]

jun-apN A thing by which a person is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected: an arm, or armour, with which one protects himself: (Ṣ:) anything protective: (Ḳ:) or coats of mail, and any defensive, or protective, arm or armour: (TA:) pl. junanN. (Ṣ.)

A piece of cloth which a woman wears, covering the fore and kind parts of her head, but not the middle of it, and covering the face, and the two sides of the bosom, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to the M, the ornaments [HuliI- instead of janobaI] of the bosom, (TA,) and having two eyeholes, like the buroquE. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jin-apN: see its syn. jin-N:
and junuwnN.
jananN A grave; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because it conceals the dead: (TA:) and so janiynN↓, of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
Grave-clothing; (Ḳ;) for the same reason. (TA.)
A garment that conceals the body. (TA.) [See also janaAnN.]
A dead body; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because concealed in the grave; the word being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN. (TA.)

entry.sense: janunN: see junuwnN.

hom.sense: janaAnN: see jin-N, first sentence, in two places:
and see the same in the latter part of the paragraph.

Also A garment: (Ḳ:) or a garment that conceals one; as in the saying, maA EalaI-a janaAnN Uil-aA maA taraI [There is not upon me a garment that conceals me save what thou seest]. (Ṣ.) [See also jananN.]
The Hariym [or surrounding adjuncts, or appertenances and conveniences,] (Ḳ, TA) of a house; because concealing the house. (TA.)
The interior of a thing that one does not see; (Ḳ;) because concealed from the eye. (TA.)

The heart; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because concealed in the bosom; (T, M;) or because it holds things in memory: (M, TA:) or its ruwE [i. e. the heart's core, or the mind, or understanding, or intellect]; (Ḳ;) which is more deeply hidden: (TA:) and (sometimes, TA) the soul, or spirit; (IDrd, Ḳ;) because the body conceals it: (IDrd, TA:) pl. OajonaAnN. (IJ, Ḳ.) You say, maA yasotaqir-u janaAnuhu mina AlfazaEi [His heart does not rest in its place by reason of fright]. (TA.)
A secret and bad action. (TA. [Before the word rendered “secret” is another epithet, which is illegible.])
junaAnN: see mijan-N:
and what here next follows.
junuwnN: see jin-N, first sentence, in two places.

Also, inf. n. of jun-a; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [originally signifying A state of possession by a jin-iI-i, or by jin-; diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; and hence meaning] loss of reason; or madness, insanity, or unsoundness in mind or intellect; (Mgh;) or deficiency of intellect: (Sb, TA:) [it may generally be rendered possession, or insanity:] jununN↓ is a contraction thereof; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or accord. to some, an original form: (MF, TA:) and jan-apN↓, also, (an inf. n. and a simple subst., Ṣ,) signifies the same as junuwnN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also majan-apN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and junaAnN↓, but this last is vulgar. (TA.)
Also Persistence in evil; and pursuance of a headlong, or rash, course. (Ḥam p. 14.)
janiynN Anything veiled, concealed, hidden, or covered: (Ḳ:) applied as an epithet even to rancour, or malice. (TA.)
Buried; deposited in a grave. (IDrd, Ṣ.)
An embryo; a fœtus; the child, or young, in the belly; (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e.,] in the womb: (Mgh:) pl. Oajin-apN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajonunN. (ISd, Ḳ.)
And the former of these pls., Waters choked up with earth. (TA.)
See also jananN.
Also The vulva. (TA.)

entry.sense: junaAnapN: see mijan-N.

janiynapN, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but in the M jin-iy-apN↓, (TA,) A [garment of the kind called] miToraf, (Ḳ, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) like the TayolasaAn, (Ḳ, TA,) worn by women: (TA:) in the T, said to be certain well-known garments. (TA.)
junayonapN: see jn-apN, last sentence.

hom.sense: jin-iI-N Of, or relating to, the jin-, or jin-ap. (Ḳ.)

See jin-N. In the saying,
wayoHaki yaA jin-iI-a halo badaA laki
Oano turojiEiI EaqoliI faqado OanaI laki
[Mercy on thee! O Jinneeyeh, (jin-iI-a being for jin-iy-apu,) doth it appear fit to thee that thou shouldst restore my reason? for the time hath come for thee to do so], a woman resembling a jin-iy-ap is meant, either because of her beauty, or in her changeableness. (TA.)
The tallness, or length and height, of a camel's hump. (TA.)
jin-iy-apN [fem. of jin-iI-N, q. v.]

entry.sense: jinojinN and janojanN and jinojinapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jinojanapN↓ (Ḳ) and (as some say, TA) junojuwnN↓ (Ḳ) are sings. of janaAjinu, which signifies The bones of the breast: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the heads of the ribs of men and of others: (M, TA:) or the extremities of the ribs, next the sternum. (T, TA.)
janojanapN: see what next precedes.
junojuwnN: see what next precedes.
jaAn-N: see jin-N.

Also A white serpent: (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a small white serpent: (Mgh:) or a great serpent: (Zj, TA:) or a species of serpent (AA, M, Ḳ) having black-bordered eyes, (M, Ḳ,) inclining to yellow, (M, TA,) harmless, and abounding in houses: (M, Ḳ:) pl. jawaAn-u, (AA, TA,) or jin-aAnN. (TA.)

Oajin-aka kacaA i. q. mino Oajoli Oan-aka [Because that thou art thus]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from which it is contracted by suppressing the l and A and transferring the kesreh of the l to the A (Ṣ.) A poet says,
Oajin-aki EinodiI OaHosanu Aln-aAsi kul-ihimo
[Because that thou art in my estimation the goodliest of all mankind]. (Ṣ.) The mino is omitted as in the phrase faEalotuhu Oajolaka for mino Oajolika. (Ks, TA.)
tajoniynN [an inf. n. used as a simple subst.,] What is said by the jin- [or genii]: or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, strange, uncouth speech or language, difficult to be understood. (TA.)
mujan-N: see majonuwnN.

mijan-N A shield; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because the owner conceals, or protects, himself with it; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also mijan-apN↓ (Lḥ, Ḳ) and junaAnN↓ and junaAnapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. majaAn-u. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) Sb held it to be of the measure fiEal-N, from mjn; but his opinion is opposed by the fact that the word is of the form which is significant of an instrument, by the doubling of the n, and by the syns. jnAn and jnAnp. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., that the hand [of a thief] shall not be cut off save for the value of a mijan-; which in the time of the Prophet was a deenár, or ten dirhems; for this is the lowest amount for which that punishment is to be inflicted. (Mgh.) You say, qalaba mijan-ahu [He turned his shield], meaning ‡ He dropped shame, and did what he pleased: or he became absolute master of his affair, or case. (Ḳ, TA.) And qalabotu lahu Zahora Almijan-i [I turned towards him the outer side of the shield], meaning † I became hostile to him after reconciliation. (Ḥar p. 265.)
Also A [woman's ornament such as is commonly called] wiXaAH (Az, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: majan-apN A place in which one is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected; or in which one veils, conceals, hides, covers, or protects, himself. (Ṣ.)
A land having in it jin-: (Ṣ:) or abounding with jin-. (Ḳ.)
See also junuwnN.

entry.sense: mijan-apN: see mijan-N.

majonuwnN [Possessed by jin-iI-, or by jin-, or by a devil, or demon; a demoniac: (see Bḍ li. 39:) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: (see junuwnN:) it may generally be rendered possessed; or mad, or insane:] part. n. of jun-a: (Mṣb:) or anomalously used as pass. part. n. of Oajan-ahu: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) one should not say mujan-N↓: (Ṣ, TA:) [pl. majaAniynu.]

naxolapN majonuwnapN ‡ A tall palm-tree: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pl. majaAniynu. (Ṣ, TA.) And nabotN majonuwnN ‡ A plant, or herbage, that is tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, in part, and strong. (TA.) And OaroDN majonuwnapN † Land producing much herbage, that has not been depastured. (TA. [See also what next follows.])
OaroDN matajan-inapN ‡ Land having much herbage, so that it extends in every way. (Ḳ, TA.)
manojanuwnN and manojaniynN: see art. mnjn

hom.sense: 1. janaOa Ealayohi, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajonaOu}, inf. n. junuwoCN, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) He bent down over, or fell prostrate upon, him, or it; (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) namely, a man, (Th, L,) as one does in speaking to another [who is sitting], (Th,) or to shield or protect another from blows, (L,) and as a woman does over a child; (TA;) or a horse, said when a man has bent down to preserve himself [from an arrow, &c.]; or a thing; (Ṣ;) as also janiYa, aor. _a {yajonaOu}, inf. n. janaON; (Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, janAC;]) as also AjnO↓, (Aṣ, L, Ḳ,) likewise said of a man bending over another to shield or protect the latter; (L, TA;) and jAnO↓, and tjAnO↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AjtnO↓ (TA.)
janaOa fiI Eadowihi He persevered, or was fatigued and slow, OalaH-a, [which has these two different meanings,] and bent down, in his running. (T, TA.)

janiYa, aor. _a {yajonaOu}, (Lth, Ḳ,) inf. n. janaON, (Lth, Ṣ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) He had a bending forward of the upper part of his back over his breast: (Lth, Ḳ:) or was humpbacked: (Ṣ:) or he had a bent and humped back: but Lth denies that janaON signifies the being humpbacked. (TA.) [See also OajonaOu.]

entry.sense: 3: see 1.
4: see 1.
6: see 1.
8: see 1.

OujonaOu, applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Having a bending forward of the upper part of the back over the breast: (Lth, Ḳ:) or humpbacked: (Ṣ:) or having a bent and humped back; but see what Lth says, voce janiYa: (TA:) or i. q. OadonaOu and OaqoEasu, meaning a man having a bending in his breast towards his back: (AA, TA:) accord. to Aṣ, applied to him who has been straight in the back and has then been affected with what is termed janaON: it is also applied to an ostrich: fem. janoMCu and janowaMCu (TA.)
Also janoMCu A ewe, or a she-goat, having her horns bending backwards; (Esh-Sheybánee, Ḳ;) and so janowaMCu (TA in art. jnw.)

mujonaON A shield: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because of its being humped, (Ḳ, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, for liQHodiydaAbihi, we find laA Hadiydapa bihi, i. e. having no piece of iron in it,]) and on account of its bending form. (TA.)
mujonaOapN A grave. (Ḳ.) [App. so called because the grave of an Arab of the desert generally has a small oblong humped mound raised over it.]

hom.sense: 1. janabahu He broke his side: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he hit, or hurt, his side. (TA.) [The aor. of the verb in this sense is probably _u, and the inf. n., accord. to the TḲ, is janobN.]

He led him by his side; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a horse (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA) or the like, (Ṣ, A,) and a captive. (Ṣ, TA.) In this sense, its aor. is _u, (A, Mṣb, TA,) and the inf. n. janabN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and majonabN. (Ḳ.)
