Hence, TawoEu Aljanabi: see jinaAbN. janabN which is forbidden (Ṣ, A, TA) in a trad., [in which it is said, laA jalaba walaA janaba] (A, TA) relating to horse-racing and to [the collecting of] the poor-rate, (TA,) means [in the former case] A man's leading, by the side of a horse that he rides in a race, another horse, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) without a rider, (TA,) and when the horse that he rides has become languid and weak, (Ḳ,) or when he fears that he will not outstrip upon it, (Ṣ,) or when he draws near to the goal, (A,) transferring himself to the other, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in order that he may outstrip: (A:) and in relation to the poorrate, it means the collector's alighting in the most remote of the places whence the portion appointed for the poor-rate is to be collected, and then ordering that the camels or the like [that constitute that portion] shall be led to him: or the going of the owner of the property to a distance, [or aside, or out of the way,] with his property, so that the collector is obliged to go to a distance in quest of it. (Ḳ. See more in art. jlb, first paragraph.)

He placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, or he removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it; (Ḳ;) as though he put him, or it, aside, or as though he walked aside; as also jAnbhu↓ (TA.) And He pushed, thrust, or drove, him, or it, away, aside, or to a distance. (Ḳ,* TA.) And janabahu AlX-aIoCa (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or AlX-ar-a (Fr, Zj, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yajonubu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and jn-bhu↓, (Fr, Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but this has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) and Ajnbhu↓; (Fr, Zj, A, Ḳ;) He put aside, or away, or he warded off, from him, (Ṣ,) or he removed from him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or removed far from him, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or evil. (Fr, Zj, A, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xiv. 38], waQjonuboniI wabaniI-a Oano naEobuda AlOaSonaAma [And put Thou away from me and my sons our worshipping of idols], (Ṣ,) or, accord. to one reading, waOajoniboniI↓. (TA.)
He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him, or it. (Ḳ,* TA.)

janaba bihi, aor. _u {yajonubu}, [He went aside, apart, out of the way, to a distance, or far away, with him, or it: or, like janabahu, in a sense explained above,] he placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.)

janaba fiI baniI fulaAnK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yajonubu}, inf. n. janaAbapN; (Ṣ;) and tjn-b↓; (so, app., in the TA;) He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, as a stranger, among the sons of such a one. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) One says, niEoma Alqawomu humo lijaAri AljanaAbapi [Excellent are the people, they,] to the neighbour who is a stranger. (Ṣ. [See also junubN.]) And laA taHoriman-iI Eano janaAbapK Do not thou by any means refuse me because of being remote (Ṣ, A, TA) in respect of relationship. (A, TA.) [See also janaAbapN mentioned below as a subst.]

janabati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yajonubu}, (TA,) inf. n. junuwbN; (Ḳ;) and Ajnbt↓; (TA;) The wind was, or became, such as is termed januwb [i. e. south, or southerly]; (Ḳ;) it blew in the direction of the wind thus called: (A, TA:) or the former, (Ṣ,) or janibat, (TA,) the wind changed, or veered, so as to become januwb (Ṣ, TA.)

[And hence, (see januwbN,)] janaba Uilayohi, (IAạr, Ḳ,) or UilaI liqaAYihi, (TA,) aor. _u {yajonubu}; (Ḳ;) and janiba, aor. _a {yajonabu}; (Th, Ḳ;) [inf. n., app., janobN, for the verb is said in the Ḳ to be like naSara and samiEa;] † He was, or became, disquieted by vehement desire to see him, or to meet him. (Ḳ,* TA.)

janiba, aor. _a {yajonabu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. janabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a camel) limped, or halted, by reason of [pain in] his side: (Ṣ:) or he had an affection resembling ZaloE [i. e. limping, or halting], (Ḳ, TA,) but not the same as this: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) or accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) his lungs clave to his side by reason of vehement thirst: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the Arabs of the desert, as ISk says, he became bent, or contorted, by reason of vehemence of thirst: (Ṣ:) and he (a camel) had a pain in his side from vehemence of thirst. (TA.) The epithet is janibN↓; which is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to an ass. (Ṣ, TA.)
jnbt Ald-alowu [app. janibat] The bucket inclined to one side in consequence of the breaking of one or two of the thongs attacking it to the cross-bars. (L, TA.)
janiba and januba and janaba are syn. with Oajonaba in a sense explained below: see 4.
juniba He had, or became affected by, the disease termed caAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) he had a complaint of his side. (Ḳ.)

junibuwA They were, or became, affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] junuwb. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And also, [in allusion to the fertilizing effect attributed to the wind so called,] They were, or became, affected by that wind in their cattle. (L, TA.)
2. jn-bhu: see 1:
and see also 3.
jnb-, inf. n. tajoniybN, He did not send the stallion-camel among his she-camels, nor the ram or he-goat among his ewes or she-goats. (Ḳ.)

jn-b Alqawomu The milk of the people's camels became little: (Ṣ:) or the people's milk ceased; (Ḳ, TA;) or became little: or the people's camels had no milk: and jn-b said of a man, his camels had no milk, nor had his sheep or goats. (TA.) Hence, EaAmu tajoniybK [A year of little, or no, milk]. (Ṣ, TA.)
jn-bt AlOibilu The camels, with the exception of one or two, brought forth no young. (AZ, TA.) The camels did not conceive, so as to have milk. (TA.)

tajoniybN [as an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one in any of the following senses, is jun-iba,] also signifies A bending, or curving, and tension [of the sinews] (tawotiyrN), of the hind leg of a horse; which is a quality approved: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to AO, a turning aside of his fore legs in raising them and putting them down: but accord. to Aṣ, it is in the kind legs, and taHoniybN is in the back-bone and in the fore legs. (TA.) [See also 2 in art Hnb; and see also mujan-abN.]
3. jAnbhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mujaAnabapN and jinaAbN, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, at, or by, his side: (A, Ḳ:) and he walked, or went, by his side. (A.)

Also i. q. baA Eadahu; (A, Ḳ;) i. e. He was, or became, [distant, remote, far off, or aloof, from him; or] apart from him; or in a part, quarter, or tract, different from that in which he (the other) was; (TA;) thus bearing two contr. significations. (A, Ḳ.) jAnbhu and tjAnbhu↓ and tjn-buhu↓ and Ajtnbhu↓ all signify the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. He was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof, or he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off, or he alienated, or estranged, himself, or he stood, or kept, aloof, from him, or it; he shunned, or avoided, him, or it; as also jin-bh↓ (Ḳ) [and tjn-b↓ minohu]. You say, jaAnibi All-iYaAma [Remove thyself far from the mean, or ignoble; stand, or keep, aloof from them; shun, or avoid, them]. (A.) And laj-a fiI jinaAbK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ. [In two copies of the Ṣ, I find jnAb here written with fet-ḥ to the j; but it is expressly said in the TA to be with kesr.])
See also 1.
4. Ajnbhu: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places.

Ajnb, (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UijonaAbN; (IAth, TA;) and janiba↓; (IB, Ḳ;) but the former is more common than the latter; and the latter, than the next here following; (IB, TA;) and januba↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [inf. n. janaAbapN, agreeably with analogy;] and janaba↓, aor. _u {yajonubu}; (L, TA;) and Oujoniba, and Astjnb↓, (Ḳ,) and tjn-b↓; (L, TA;) He was, or became, in the state of one who is termed junub; (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (IAth, TA.) laA yujonibu, said by I’Ab, of a man, and of a garment, and of the ground, (TA,) and of water, (Mgh, TA,) means ‡ He, or it, will not become polluted (Mgh, TA) by the touch of him who is junub so that one should need total ablution in consequence of the touching thereof. (TA.)
AjnbwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [south, or southerly,] wind termed Aljunuwb. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
See also 1 in the latter half of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 5: see 1:
and 3, in two places:
and 4.
6: see 3.
8: see 3.

janobN, a word of well-known meaning; (Ṣ;) The side, or half, or lateral half, syn. Xiq-N, (A, Ḳ,) of a man, &c.; as also jaAnibN↓ and janabapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the part of a man that is beneath the arm-pit, extending to the flank; as also jaAnibN↓, because it is the side of the person: (Mṣb:) pl. (of the first, Mṣb) junuwbN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the same, a pl. of pauc.,] OajonaAbN (CK) and [of jaAnibN] jawaAnibu (Lḥ, ISd, Ḳ, but not in the CK) and [app. of janobN (like as layaAYilu is a pl. of layolN) or of janabapN (like as HawaAYiju is pl. of HaAjapN which is originally HawajapN) or of both these] janAYibu↓ (M, Ḳ,) which is extr. (M, TA.) [Hence,] qaEadotu UilaI janobi fulaAnK and AlI jaAnibi↓ flAnN [I sat by the side of such a one]: both meaning the same. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lamunotafixu AljawaAnibi↓ [Verily he is inflated in the side]: jwAnb being here one of those words which are used in the sing. sense though in the pl. form. (Lḥ, TA.) And OaEoTaAhu Aljanoba [lit. He gave him the side; meaning] he was, or became, submissive, manageable, easy, or tractable, to him. (A.) And jaAru Aljanobi He who cleaves to one, keeping by one's side. (Ḳ. [Differing from jaAru Aljunubi, q. v. infrà.]) And AlS-aAHibu biAljanobi [in the Ḳur iv. 40] The travelling-companion; the companion in a journey: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he who is near one; or by one's side: or the companion in every good affair: or the husband: or the wife. (TA.) And caAtu Aljanobi, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) with which AljunaAbu↓ is syn., (Ḳ,) [and sometimes Aljanobu, as will be seen in what follows,] A well-known disease; (Mgh;) [the pleurisy; called by the first of these three appellations in the present day;] a severe disease, being an inflammatory tumour in the [pleura, or] membrane within the ribs: (Mṣb:) or an ulcer, or a purulent pustule, that comes within a man's side: (Ṣ, TA:) it is a severe disease in the side: accord. to El-Hejeree, it is in either side; and they assert that when it is in the left side, the patient perishes: accord. to ISh, the dubayolap; which is an ulcer that penetrates into the belly: or the ulcer (dubayolap and dum-al) that comes forth within the side, and discharges internally; the sufferer from which seldom recovers: he who suffers from it [and dies in consequence], or, as some say, he who is afflicted by a complaint of the side (absolutely) while warring in the cause of God, is reckoned a martyr: (TA:) [soldiers in a campaign are notoriously more subject to it than persons in most other circumstances; and it is app. for this reason that] it is termed daMCu AlS-anaAdiydi [the disease of the courageous chiefs]. (A, TA.) cuw Aljanobi, of which caAtu Aljunobi is the fem., signifies Having a complaint of his side by reason of [the disease above mentioned, or what is termed] Ald-ubayolap. (TA. [See also majonuwbN.])

A poet says,
Aln-aAsu janobN waAlOamiyru janobu
[The people are a side and the prince is a side]: (Akh, Ṣ, TA:) as though he reckoned the latter equal to all the people. (TA. [This is cited in the Ṣ and TA as though it were an ex. of jnb in the sense here next following: but it seems to be rather an ex. of this word in the sense first explained in the present paragraph.])

I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; a vicinage, or neighbourhood]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jaAnibN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and janaAbN↓ and janobapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and janabapN↓ (Ṣ) and janaAbapN↓. (L, TA.) It is said that the primary signification of janobN is the part of the body mentioned in the beginning of this paragraph, and that its use in the sense of naAHyapN is metaphorical, as is the case of yamiynN and XimaAlN; but naAHiyapN is mentioned in the Mṣb as the primary signification of jaAnibN↓; (MF, TA;) though its primary signification accord. to the Ḳ and ISd seems to be that first mentioned. (TA.) You say, maXawoA jaAnibayohi↓ and janaAbayohi↓ and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ [They walked, or went on foot, on either side of him]. (A, TA.*) And mar-uwA yasiyruwna janaAbayohi↓ (Ṣ, L) and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ (L, TA) They went along journeying on either side of him. (Ṣ, L.) And kun-aA Eanohumo janaAbayoni↓ and janaAbFA↓ We were apart from them [on two sides and on one side]. (TA.) And nazaluwA fiI janaAbaAti↓ AlwaAdiI [They alighted in the sides of the valley, or in the tracts beside the valley]. (A.) And fulaAnN laA yaTuwru bijanabatinaA↓ Such a one will not approach our quarter: (Ṣ:) thus accord. to AO; with fet-ḥ to the n: IJ, however, says, people are wont to say, OanaA fiI caraAka wajanabatika↓ [meaning I am under thy protection and in thy quarter]; but that the correct expression is janobatika↓, with the n quiescent. (IB, TA.) The Arabs also said, AlHar-u jaAnibaIo↓ suhayolK, meaning † The heat is on either side of Suheyl [or Canopus: i. e., during the period next before, and that next after, the auroral rising of Canopus; which rising began, in central Arabia, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, about the 4th of August, O. Ṣ.]: this is the greatest heat. (TA.) One also says, OaHaATuwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi↓ [meaning They surrounded him on all his sides; lit., on his two sides]; dividing the surrounding parts into two, but not meaning that any of these remained vacant. (Expos. of the exs. cited as testimonies by Sb, TA in art. Hwl.)

Also, [and jaAnibN↓, which is thus used in the L in art. jnH, and by many authors,] A part, or portion, of a thing; (L;) the greater, or main, or chief, part or portion thereof; most thereof; (L, Ḳ;) or a great part or portion thereof; much thereof. (L.) Hence, [or perhaps from janobN in the second of the senses assigned to it above, conveying the idea of juxtaposition, and thus of comparison,] hecaA qaliylN janobi mawad-atika [This is little in comparison with the magnitude of thy love; or simply, in comparison with thy love]. (TA.)

yaA HasorataA EalaI maA far-aTotu fiI jnobi Qll-ehi [in the Ḳur xxxix. 57] means fI jaAnibih↓, i. e. † [O my grief, or regret, for my negligence, or remissness,] in respect of that which is the right, or due, of God! (A, Bḍ, TA,) i. e., (Bḍ,) in respect of obedience to God! (Bḍ, Jel:) or, in respect of [the means of attaining] nearness to God! (Fr, TA;) or, nearness to God in Paradise! (IAạr, TA:) or, in respect of the way of God, to which He hath called me! i. e., the profession of his unity, and the confession of the prophetic office of Moḥammad. (Zj, TA.) The saying of the Arabs, Ait-aqi Qll-eha fiI janobihi walaA taqodaHo fiI saAqihi [may be rendered † Fear God in respect of his (thy brother's) right, or due, and impugn not his honour, or reputation: or] means, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, laA taqotulohu [slay him not], or, as in the L, and in the original draught of the author [of the Ḳ] lA tagotalohu [slay him not clandestinely, or on an occasion of inadvertence], from Algiylapu, and throw him not into trouble, or trial: (TA:) or, accord. to some, fI jnbh means in detracting from his reputation, or reviling him. (Ḳ, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 240.]) A poet, cited by IAạr, says,
xaliylaI-a kuf-aA waQcokuraA Qll-eha fiI janobiI
† [O my two friends, refrain, and be mindful of God in respect of my reputation; (see also jaAnibN;)] meaning, in detracting from my reputation, or reviling me: or, accord. to MF, in my case. (TA.) And one says, maA faEalota fiI janobi HaAjatiI † What didst thou, or what hast thou done, in the case of the thing that I want? (L, TA.)

hom.sense: janabN: see janiybN.
TawoEu Aljanabi: see jinaAbN.
janabN also signifies Short; (Ḳ;) applied to a man. (TA.)

entry.sense: janibN: see janiba.
It is also applied as an epithet to a wolf, because he pretends to halt, from guile, or cunning. (L, TA.)
Also A man who goes aside, or to a distance, from the beaten way, for fear of guests' coming to him for entertainment. (Ḳ, TA.)

junubN, (El-Fárábee, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is sometimes used in the sing. form as pl., and has no fem. form, (TA,) and jaAnibN↓ and OajonabiI-N↓, (El-Fárábee, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is said by Az in art. rwH to be seldom or never used by the Arabs, but is mentioned by him in its proper art., (Mṣb,) and Oajonabu↓, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) are syn., (El-Fárábee, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) signifying A stranger; (Ḳ;) as also janiybN↓: (Ṣ:) or a man who is distant, or remote: (Mṣb:) or distant, or remote, in respect of relationship: (Az and Mṣb in explanation of the third and fourth:) [or not a relation; as will be seen from what follows:] and jaAnibN↓ [as an act. part. n.] signifies one alighting, or descending and abiding, or settling, as a stranger, among a tribe: (Ṣ:) pl. of the first OajonaAbN, (A, TA,) and of the second jun-aAbN, (Ṣ, TA,) and of the fourth OajaAnibu. (Mṣb.) AljaAru Aljunubu [occurring in the Ḳur iv. 40] (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaAru Aljunubi (TA) The person who is one's neighbour, but who belongs to another people; (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) who is not of one's family nor of one's lineage; (A;) who is of another lineage than he of whom he is a neighbour; (T, TA;) who is not a relation: (MF:) or one who is distant, or remote, in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the person who is not a relation to another, and who comes to him, and asks him to protect him, and abides with him: such has the title to respect that belongs to him as neighbour of the other, and to his protection, and as relying upon his safeguard and promise. (TA in art. jwr. [Differing from jaAru Aljanobi, q. v. suprà.]) It is said in a trad., humo OajonaAbu Aln-aAsi They are the strangers of mankind, or of the people. (TA.) And in another trad., qaAla lijaAriy-pK halo mino mugaribapi xabarK qaAlato EalaI jaAnibK↓ Alxabaru [He said to a girl, Is there any news from abroad? She answered,] It is for a stranger coming from a journey [to give such news]. (TA.) And one says, huwa OajonabiI-N↓ min-iI [He is a person not related to me]. (A.)
Also, ↓ the same four words, (of which only the last is mentioned in this sense in the Ṣ,) That will not be led; intractable. (Ḳ.)

junubN is also an epithet from AljanaAbapu; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) signifying A man under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen: (IAth, TA: [see 4:]) and is used alike as masc. and fem. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and sing. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dual (Mṣb, TA) and pl.; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) being regarded as quasi-coordinate to the class of inf. ns.; for the inf. n., when used as an epithet, must remain, in form, sing. and masc.: (MF in art. Eft:) or one may use the dual form junubaAni; (Ḳ;) and sometimes they used the pl. OajonaAbN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and junubuwna, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the fem. pl. junubaAtN; (Mṣb;) but not junubapN, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a female. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tadoxulu AlmalaAYikapu biyotFA fiyhi junubN, meaning [The angels will not enter a house, or chamber, or tent, in which is] one who usually neglects the total ablution when under an obligation to perform it for the cause above mentioned. (IAth, TA.)

hom.sense: janobapN: see janobN, in four places:
and see jaAnibN.

Also Retirement, or secession, from others: (Ḳ, TA:) and in a trad., in which it is enjoined, used as meaning retirement from women; avoiding the sitting by them, and the approaching the place that they occupy. (TA.) You say, rajulN cuw janobapK A man of retirement. (TA.) And nazala janobapF He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, in a place aside, or apart. (Ṣ, TA.) And qaEada janobapF He [sat apart, or] retired from others. (A, TA.)

The state of being a stranger; as also janaAbapN↓. (Ḳ. [Both are there mentioned as simple substs.; but the latter is an inf. n.: see janaba fiI baniI fulaAnK; and what next follows it: and see also 4.]) Both also signify Remoteness in respect of relationship. (TA.)

Also, janobapN, A piece of skin from the side of a camel, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) of which is made a kind of milking vessel (Eulobap), (Ṣ, L,) larger than the miEolaq, but smaller than the jawobap [a mistranscription for jawoCabap] (L.)

And Every kind of plant, (Ṣ,) or
every kind of tree in general, (Ḳ,) that produces [new leaves such as are termed] rabol in the season of the Sayof [which may mean either summer or spring]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or every kind of plant that produces leaves in that season without rain: (TA:) or a name given to many plants, all of them Euruwq [perhaps meaning resembling roots, i. e. straggling, or spreading like roots]; so called because less than large trees and higher than those that have no root-stock (Oaruwmap) in the earth; comprising the naSiI- and Sil-iyaAn and HamaAT and makor and Hcr [so in the TA, but I do not find it elsewhere, and think it may be a mistranscription for Hazor, of which Hazorap (the name of a certain sour tree) is probably the n. un.,] and dahomaMC; which are smaller than Xajar and superior to buquwl: all this has been heard from the Arabs: (T, TA:) or green and fresh Sl-yAn: (TA:) or what is [of a kind] between baqol and Xajar; (AḤn, Ḳ, TA;) being [in the TA whmA, but this is evidently a mistake for wahiIa,] of the kind of which the root remains in the winter while the branches perish: (AḤn, TA:) or herbage of which the root is deep in the earth; such as the naSiI- and the Sil-iyaAn. (TA voce xaDirN.)

entry.sense: janabapN: see janobN, in four places:
and see jaAnibN.
junabapN A thing from which one retires, or withdraws himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off; from which one stands, or keeps, aloof. (Ḳ.)
janaAbN: see janobN, in five places. [Hence,] kun-aA Eanohumo janaAbayoni and janaAbFA We were remote, or retired, from them; or out of their way. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jaAnibN↓, (Mṣb,* TA,) A court, or yard, or an open or a wide space in front of a house or extending from its sides: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) and a place of alighting or abode; or a settlement, or place of settling: (A:) a mansion; an abode; a habitation; or a place to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge, in a city or town or village or other place of settled habitations; syn. raHolN: (Ḳ:) and a vicinage, neighbourhood, or tract adjacent to the place of abode or settlement, of a people or company of men: pl. OajonibapN. (Ṣ.) You say, OanaA fiI janaAbi zayodK I am in the court, or yard, of Zeyd; and in his place of alighting or abode, or settlement. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN raHobu AljanaAbi, (A, TA,) and xaSiybu AljanaAbi, (Ṣ, A,) the former meaning Such a one is possessed of an ample raHol [or mansion,, &c., as explained above]: (TA:) [and the latter, such a one is surrounded by a plentiful, or fruitful, tract:] or both mean ‡ such a one is generous or bountiful [or hospitable]. (A.) And falaAnN jadiybu AljanaAbi (Ṣ, TA) [meaning Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought, or barrenness; as explained in the Ṣ in art. jdb: but generally used tropically, as meaning † such a one is ungenerous, illiberal, or inhospitable]. And OaxoSaba janaAbu Alqawomi [The neighbourhood of the people, or the tract surrounding them, became plentiful, or fruitful]. (Ṣ, TA.) And Oajodaba binaA AljanaAbu [Our neighbourhood, or the tract surrounding us, became affected with drought, or barrenness]. (TA from a trad.)
rajulN lay-inu AljanaAbi [perhaps a mistranscription for AljaAnibi] ‡ A man easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. (A.)

[AljanaAbu is also a title often given by writers of letters and the like to any great man to whom others betake themselves, or repair, for protection; and sometimes to God; meaning ‡ The object of recourse; the refuge; the asylum: similar to AlHaDorapu, q. v., and used in the same manner, i. e., alone, and, without the article, prefixed to the name of the person to whom it is applied, or to a pronoun; but the latter is generally considered as implying greater respect than the former.]
AljunaAbu i. q. caAtu Aljanobi: see janobu. (Ḳ.)

jinaAbN A cord tied to the head and neck of a beast, by which he is led, or drawn. (KL.) [Hence,] farasN TawoEu AljanaAbi A horse easily led; or easy to be led; tractable; [obedient to the jnAb;] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) as also TawoEu Aljanabi↓. (TA. [See 1, near the beginning.])

januwbN, of the fem. gender, and, accord. to Sb, both a subst. and an epithet, [so that one says riyHN januwbN, as well as januwbN alone and riyHu Aljanuwbi,] (TA,) [The south wind: or a southerly wind:] the wind that is opposite to that called the XamaAl: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [consequently, the wind that blows from the direction of the south pole, accord. to the Ṣ;] the wind that blows from the direction of the left hand of a person standing opposite to the kibleh [by which is here meant that corner of the Kaabeh in which is set the Black Stone; which corner is towards the east]: (Th, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises [Ṣ. 29? E. in central Arabia] and the place where the same star sets [Ṣ. 29? W. in the same latitude]: ('Omárah, TA:) or from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and the place where the sun sets in winter [W. 26? Ṣ. in central Arabia]: (Aṣ, TA:) or it is a hot wind, that blows in every season; blowing from that part of the tract between the quarter whence blows the east wind (AlS-abaA) and that whence blows the west wind (Ald-abuwr) which is next to the place where Canopus rises: (T, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and that where the Pleiades set [W. 26? N. in central Arabia]: (IAạr, Ḳ:) [the points whence it usually blows seem to differ somewhat in different parts:] Aṣ says that the jnwb is attended by good, and by fecundating influence; and the XmAl by drying up [of the earth, &c.]: (TA:) accord. to IAạr, it is hot in every place, except in Nejd, where it is cold, or cool: (MF:) pl. janaAYibu (T, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajonubN. (T, TA.)

One says, of two persons, when they are on terms of sincere friendship, riyHuhumaA januwbN † [Their wind is south, or southerly]; and when they are separated, Xamalato riyHuhumaA † [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA.)

hom.sense: janiybN, applied to a horse and a captive, (TA,) Led by one's side; as also majonuwbN↓ and mujan-abN↓: (Ḳ:) or you say xayolN majan-abapN↓, meaning horses led by the side; the teshdeed denoting application to many objects: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. [of the first, and of janiybapN, q. v., or only of this last,] janaAYibu and [quasi-pl. n.] janabN↓. (Ḳ.) One walking by the side of another; (A;) [and] so jun-aAbN↓. (Ḳ.)
Any animal or man that is obedient, tractable, or submissive. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, OaSobaHa janiybahu He became compliant to him. (A.)
See also junubN.

Also, applied to a man, [app. Having a pain in the side; or having the pleurisy; like majonuwbN: and hence, or from janiba, q. v., irregularly formed,] as though walking on one side, bent or crooked, mutaEaq-ifFA: so in the L: in the M and Ḳ, on the authority of IAạr, mutaEaq-ibFA [to which I am unable to assign an appropriate meaning, except its modern one of lagging behind]: so in the saying of a poet,
rabaA AljuwEu fiI Oawonayohi Hat-aI kaOan-ahu
janiybN bihi Uin-a Aljaniyba janiybu
[Hunger increased in him (lit. in the two sides of his saddle-bags); so that he seemed as though he walked on one side, bent thereby; for he who has a pain in his side walks on one side, in that manner]. (TA.)
Also An excellent kind of dates, (Ḳ, TA,) well known; (TA;) one of the best kinds of dates. (Mgh in art. jmE, Mṣb.)
janaAbapN: see janobN, in four places: and see jaAnibN.
See also janobapN.

Accord. to IAth, its primary signification is Distance: and hence it signifies The state of him who is under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (TA.)
The sperma genitalis [itself]. (Ḳ. [But in a marginal note in my copy of that work I find this last signification rejected as erroneous.])
See also the next paragraph.
janiybapN A led horse or mule or ass; (Ṣ, TA;) a horse that is led [by one's side], not ridden: (Mṣb:) pl. janaAYibu. (A, TA.)
janiybataA AlbaEiyri The [two equal] loads on the two sides of the camel. (Ḳ.)
[Hence, app.,] Ait-aqi Qll-eha Al-aciI laA janybapa lahu ‡ Fear thou God, to whom there is no equal. (A, TA.)

Also janiybupN, (Ṣ,) or janaAbapN↓, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) A she-camel that one gives [or lends] to people, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with money, (M, TA,) in order that they may bring corn or other provision for him; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) also called EaliyqapN: pl. janaAYibu. (Ṣ.)

Also, (Kr, M, Ḳ,) and xabiybapN, (M, TA,) The wool of a van-iI [or sheep in its third year]: (Kr, M, Ḳ:) it is better and cleaner than what is termed Eaqiyqap, which is the wool of a jacaE [or sheep in or before its second year]. (TA.)

entry.sense: [januwbiI-N Of, or relating to, the quarter of the wind termed the januwb; south, or southerly.]
janaAYibN as an extr. pl.: see janobN, first sentence.
jun-aAbN: see janiybN.

hom.sense:
jaAnibN; pl. jawaAnibu: see janobN, in eleven places.
[Hence, laAna jaAnibuhu † He was, or became, gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. And rajulN lay-inu AljaAnibi † A man who is gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious; contr. of galiyZu AljaAnibi; see art. glZ: and see janaAbN. And] tuzan-u biliyni AljaAnibi † [She is suspected of easiness, or compliance], (Ḳ in art. lms,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her. (TA in that art.) [Hence also,] jaAnibaA AlOanofi (CK) and janaAbataA↓ and janobataA↓ and janabataA↓ (Ḳ) The two sides of the nose: (Ḳ:) or the two lines that surround the two sides of the nose of a doe-gazelle: (Sb, TA:) pl. [of the second, agreeably with analogy,] janaAYibu. (TA.)
See also janaAbN. [It often signifies The vicinage or neighbourhood of a people, &c.: and a region or quarter or tract of a people or country: like nAHyp.]
[The bank of a river; and any bank, or steep acclivity.]
[And A limit, bound, or boundary: see a tropical usage of its pl. (jawaAnibu) voce. HinowN.]
[And EalaI jaAnibK means Beside, aside, or apart; and so jaAnibFA, and fiI jaAnibK.]
[jaAnibN mino maAlK, in posi-classical writings, means A portion, and particularly a large portion, of property: and jaAnibN alone, in the same, a sum, and particularly a large sum, of money.]

[The latter, also, in post-classical writings, signifies, like janobN, q. v., † A man's honour, or reputation, which should be preserved inviolate; so used in the Ḳ voce EiroDN, in an explanation of the latter word taken from IAth; i. q. naAmuwsN and HuromapN, as in the TḲ in that case.]
Avoided and despised. (Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence, perhaps, daEo kacaA jaAnibFA Let thou, or leave thou, such a thing alone: see an ex. voce Oaw-N.]
See also junubN, in four places.
And see mujan-abN.

entry.sense: Oajonabu: see junubN, in two places.
OajonabiI-N: see junubN, in three places
You say also, huwa OajonabiI-N mino kacaA, (A,) or Eino kcA, (TA,) ‡ He has no concern nor acquaintance with such a thing. (A, TA.)

majonabN (Ṣ, AAF, Ḳ) and mijonabN↓ (AAF, Ḳ) Much (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, AAF, Ḳ) of good (AʼObeyd, Ḳ) and of evil. (Ḳ.) You say, Uin-a EinodanaA laxayorFA majonabFA Verily with us is much good, and Xar-FA majonabFA much evil. (Ṣ.) And TaEaAmN majonabN means Much [wheat or food]. (Sh, TA.)
mujonibN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: mijonabN A shield; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) because it wards off from its possessor what is displeasing to him; (A, TA;) also with damm to the m [app. mujonibN↓, act. part. n. of 4]. (Ḳ.)
A thing by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, or hidden; a veil, curtain, or covering; (Ḳ, TA;) for a house, or chamber, or tent. (TA.)
A thing like a door, upon which the gatherer of honey stands; (Ḳ, TA;) he being let down [upon it] by means of ropes to [the place of] the honey [in the face of a rock or mountain]. (TA.)

A thing (XabaHN [app. here meaning a wooden implement]) resembling a comb without teeth (Ḳ, TA) and thinedged in its lowest part, (TA,) with which earth is raised upon, or against, the OaEoDaAd and fulojaAn [or raised borders of watering-troughs or the like, and streamlets for irrigation]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AlfilojAni is put for AlfulojAni.])
The extreme part of the territory of the foreigners towards that of the Arabs: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the nearest part of the territory of the Arabs to that of the foreigners. (Ṣ)
See also majonabN.

entry.sense: Also, the former, (TA,) or jaAnibN↓, (Ḳ, [but this is said in the TA to be a mistake,]) A horse wide in the space between the two kind legs, (Ḳ, TA,) without what is termed fajajN [which is an awkward kind of straddling, with the hocks wide apart]: it is a quality approved. (TA. [See also 2; and see muHan-abN.])
mujan-ibN A man whose sheep or goats [&c.] have few young ones; [and therefore, having little milk;] (TA in art. ysr;) contr. of muyasarN. (Ṣ and TA in that art. [See also 2.])
mujan-abapN The van, or fore part, (Ḳ, TA,) of an army. (TA.)

Almujan-ibataAni The right and left wings of an army: (Ḳ: [Golius has erroneously written mijonabataAni, and has given J as the authority instead of the Ḳ:]) or mujan-abapN signifies a portion of an army (katiybapN) that takes one of the two sides of a way: but the former meaning is the more correct. (IAạr, TA.)
majonuwibN pass. part. n. of 1 [q. v.].
See also jniybN.
Also Affected by the disease termed caAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and said to mean also having a complaint of his side, absolutely. (TA.)

And Affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb. (Ṣ, TA.) [And Affected by that wind in one's cattle: see 1, last sentence.] saHaAbapN majonuwbapN A cloud brought by the blowing of that wind. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
majonuwbapu AlOunosi maXomuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
means Her familiarity passes away with the januwb [or south-wind], and her promises pass away with the XamaAl [or north wind]. (IAạr, TA.)

jinovN i. q. OaSolN [as meaning The stock, or stem, or the root, or base, or lowest part, of a tree or plant: and the stock, or origin, of a man]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of jinosN, or a word mispronounced: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, a root (of a tree) of which the Oaruwmap [i. e. root-stock] is erect in the ground: or the part of the saAq [i. e. stock, or stem,] of a tree that is in the ground, above the Euruwq [or roots properly so called]: (L, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajonaAvN and [of mult.] junuwvN. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN mino jinovika and jinosika, meaning mn OaSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu layarojiEu UilaI jinovi SidoqK [Verily he traces back his lineage to an excellent stock, or origin]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. janaHa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yajonaHu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) agreeably with analogy, of the dial. of Temeem, and the most chaste form, (TA,) and _u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Keys, (TA,) and _i, (Ḳ,) inf. n. junuwHN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He, or it, inclined, leant, or propended, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ) Uilayohi (L, Mṣb) and lahu (L) [to, or towards, it]; as also AjtnH↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and AjnH↓. (Ḳ [but, by the omission of a w after it, this is made in some copies of the Ḳ to relate to what there follows it].) It is said in the Ḳur [viii. 63], waUino janaHuwA lils-alomi faQjonaHo lahaA (Mgh, L) And if they incline to peace, incline thou to it: slm being here made fem. because syn. with muSaAlaHap. (L.) You say, janaHuwA lils-alomi and Uilayohi. (A.)

He (a man) inclined, or leant, on one side; and leant upon his bow: as also AjtnH↓: and AjtnH↓ Ealayohi he leant upon him. (L.) And janaHato She (a camel lying on her breast) leant on one side. (AO, TA.)
He (a man) set about a thing, to do it with his hands, his breast leaning over it. (T, TA.)
janaHa EalaI mirofaqayohi, inf. n. junuwHN and janoHN, He (a man) rested himself upon his elbows, having set them upon the ground or upon a cushion. (ISh, TA.)
janaHa Uilayohimo and lahumo He [inclined to them; or] followed them and submitted to them; namely, a sect. (ISh, TA.)
janaHati AlX-amosu liloguruwbi [The sun inclined to setting]. (A.)

janaHa, (A, L, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yajonaHu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. junuwHN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) said of the night, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and of the evening, (A,) and of the darkness, (L,) It inclined to going, or to coming: (A:) or it came on, or approached. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also, with the same aor. and inf. n., said of a bird, It contracted its wings to descend, or alight, and approached like one falling, and repairing to a place of refuge. (L.)
janaHato said of camels, They lowered the fore part of the neck [in running]: or they went quickly, or swiftly. (TA.)
And, inf. n. junuwHN, said of a ship (safiynap), She came to shallow water, and stuck to the ground, (A, L,)so as to cease from motion. (L.)
janaHa, inf. n. junuwHN, He (a man) gave with his [janaAH, or] hand. (TA.)

janaHahu, (Ṣ, L,) aor. _a {yajonaHu}, inf. n. janoHN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, its janaAH [or wing]; (Ṣ, L;) i. e., the jnAH of the bird. (Ṣ.) And janaHa fulaAnFA He hit, or hurt, the arm (janaAH) of such a one. (Ḳ. [In some copies of the Ḳ, by the omission of a w, this signification is erroneously made to relate to AjnH: so in the copies used by MF and SM, who state that the right verb is janaHa])

juniHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ṣ,) like EuniIa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. junuwHN, (TA,) He (a camel) had his jawaAniH [the ribs so called] broken by reason of the heaviness of his load: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
or he (a camel) had the first of his ribs broken in the part next the breast. (TA.)

[janaHa also signifies He regarded an act as a crime, or sin. Thus,] Uin-I laOajonaHu Oano Mkula minohu, in a trad. respecting the property of the orphan, means Verily I regard as a crime, or sin, (junaAH,) my eating, or devouring, [aught] thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: [2. jn-Hhu, inf. n. tajoniyHN, He furnished it with wings, or † the like: see mujan-aHN.]

hom.sense: 4. AjnH: see 1, first sentence.
AjnHhu He made him, or it, to incline, lean, or propend. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 8.
8. AjtnH: see 1, in three places.

AijotinaAHN in a she-camel is The going quickly, or swiftly: (Sh, Ḳ:) or the going so that her hinder part as it were leans towards her fore part, by reason of her vehement pressing on, (ISh, Ḳ,*) by her pushing forward her kind legs towards her breast: (ISh:) and in a horse, the running with a uniform leaning on one side. (A, O, Ḳ.)
10. AstjnH It (the night) began. (L.)

junoHu All-ayoli (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jinoHuhu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) A part, or portion, of the night: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a great, or the greater, part thereof: or the first part thereof: or a part thereof, about the half: (L:) or the darkness thereof; and its confusedness. (Mṣb.) kaOan-ahu junoHu layolK [As though it were a portion,, &c., of a night] is said of a numerous army heavily encumbered. (L.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce Uin-a.]
jinoHN A side (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a road. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

And The vicinage or neighbourhood, or the region or quarter or tract, and the shadow or shelter or protection, syn. naAHiyapN and kanafN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also janaAHN↓, (Ḳ,) of a people, or party, or company of men: (Ṣ:) the latter word thus used is tropical. (TA.) You say, baAta bijinoHi Alqawomi He passed the night in the vicinage,, &c., of the people. (Ṣ, TA.) And OanaA fiI janaAHihi↓ ‡ I am in his shadow, shelter, or protection. (TA.)
See also the next preceding paragraph.

janaAHN The yad (Ṣ, Ḳ) [meaning wing] of a bird or flying thing; (Ṣ;) i. e., of a bird or flying thing, the limb that corresponds to the yd of a man: (Mṣb:) and also the yd [i. e. arm, sometimes also meaning hand, (see a signification of janaHa,)] of a man: (L, TA:) and (Ḳ) the upper arm, or arm from the shoulder to the elbow: (Zj, L, Ḳ:) each of these is so called because it is on one side of the body: (L:) and the armpit: (Ḳ:) pl. OajoniHapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajonuHN: (IJ, Ḳ:) the sing., though masc., has the latter pl., which properly belongs to a fem. sing. [of this form], because jnAH is assimilated to riyXapN; (IJ;) [or rather, I think, to yadN, which is fem.;] but some assert jnAH to be both masc. and fem. (MF.) [Hence,] huwa maqoSuwSu AljanaAHi [He has the wing clipped; meaning] ‡ he is one who lacks strength or power or ability; he is impotent. (A, TA.) And xafaDa lahu janaAHahu ‡ [He abased himself to him: lit. he lowered to him his wing: but see an explanation of a similar phrase in the Ḳur, below]. (A.) And rakibuwA janaAHaIi AlT-aAYiri, (Fr, L, Ḳ,) in [some of the copies of] the Ḳ, AlT-ariyqi, (TA,) † They quitted their homes, or accustomed places. (Fr, L, Ḳ.) And fulaAnN fiI janaAHaIo TaAYirK Such a one is in a state of disquiet, and confounded, or perplexed, unable to see his right course. (L, A.*) And rakiba fulaAnN janaAHaIi Aln-aEaAmapi ‡ Such a one employed himself vigorously, labouriously, sedulously, or diligently, in an affair; (A, Ḳ;) managing well. (Ḳ.) And naHonu EalaI janaAHi Als-afari [lit. We are on the wing of travel; meaning] ‡ we are about to travel, or journey. (Ḳ, TA.) And janaAHu Alfarasi † A certain star [γ] of Pegasus; one of the four bright stars, in Pegasus, which form a square; the other three being that at the extremity of the neck, called Eayonu Alfarasi, [i. e. a of Pegasus,] that called manokibu Alfarasi, [β of Pegasus,] and the star [α of Andromeda] that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda. (Ḳzw.) [And janaAHu samakapK † The fin of a fish.] And janaAHaA naSolK † The two wings, or blades, of a spear-head or of an arrow-head. (L.) And janaAHu Alr-aHaI † The wing (naAEuwr) of the mill or mill-stone. (L.) And janaAHaA EasokarK ‡ The two wings of an army. (A, TA) And janaAHaA AlwaAdiI ‡ The two sides of the valley (A, L) down which the water runs, on the right and left. (L.) And variydapN lahaA janaAHaAni mino EuraAqK and mujan-aHapN↓ biAlEuraAqi ‡ [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth, having two sidegarnishes of bones with some meat remaining upon them]. (A, TA.)
See also jinoHN, in two places.

Also The side, syn. jaAnibN. (Ḳ.) So in the saying in the Ḳur [xvii. 25], waQxofiDo lahumaA janaAHa Alc-ul-i, meaning waOalino lahumaA jaAnibaka Alc-aliyla ‡ [And make soft to them. (thy two parents) thy submissive side; i. e. treat them with gentleness and submissiveness: or the former words may be literally rendered lower to them the wing of submissiveness; meaning be submissive to them]. (Jel, TA.)
And A part, or portion, of a thing; as also junaAHN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: junaAHN A sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience: (AHeyth, Ṣ, A, IAth, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or an inclining thereto: (IAth,* L, TA:) and anxiety, and annoyance or molestation or hurt, which one is made to bear. (L, TA.) laA junaAHa Ealayokumo, in the Ḳur ii. 235, means, accord. to AHeyth, There shall be no sin, or crime, chargeable upon you: or, accord. to others, there shall be no straitening of you. (L.)
See also janaAHN, last signification.

entry.sense: jaAniHN Inclining, leaning, or propending: pl. OajonaAHN, like as OaXohaAdN is pl. of XaAhidN. (L, TA.)

jaAniHapN sing. of jawaAniHu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which latter signifies The ribs of the breast: (A:) or the ribs that are beneath [those called] the taraAYib, of the part next the breast; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like the DuluwE of the part next the back: (Ṣ:) or the anterior parts of those ribs; so called because they incline over the heart: or the short ribs that are in the anterior part of the breast: or, of a camel and a horse and the like, the ribs against which lies the shoulder-blade: and of a man, the ribs of the back which are called daOoI, six in number, three on the right and three on the left. (L.)
majonaHapN A piece of leather upon the fore part of the camel's saddle, upon which the rider leans with his hands, thus resting himself. (TA. [See 8.])
mujan-aHN [Furnished with wings, or † the like].
[Hence,] variydapN mujan-aHapN biAlEuraAqi: see janaAHN.
naAqapN mujan-aHapu Aljabiyni † A she-camel wide in the jbyn [app. here meaning the forehead]. (TA.)
2. jn-d junuwdFA (Ṣ, A) He collected, or assembled, jnwd [i. e. armies, military forces,, &c.]. (A.)
5. tjn-d He took or prepared, for himself, a junod [i. e. an army, a military force,, &c.]. (A, TA.)

junodN [a coll. gen. n.] An army; a military force; a legion; a body of troops or soldiers; (L, Ḳ;) a collected body of men prepared for war: (Mgh:) auxiliaries: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. junodiI-N↓ [signifying a trooper; a soldier; an auxiliary]; like as ruwmiI-N is n. un. of ruwmN: (Mṣb:) pl. of the former, junuwdN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb) and [pl. of pauc.] OajonaAdN. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., AlOarowaAHu junuwdN mujan-adapN↓ (Ṣ, A, L) Souls are troops collected together: meaning that they are created of two parties, each party agreeing together, and disagreeing with the other party, like two armies opposed, each to the other. (L.)

Also Any kind, or species, of creatures, or created things, regarded as alone, by itself, or apart from others. (Ḳ,* TA.) It is said in a prov., Uin-a lil-hi junuwdFA minohaA AlEasalu Verily to God belong kinds, or species, of created things [by means of which He effects his purposes as by armies or auxiliaries], of which is honey: (Z, Ḳ:) first said by Mo'áwiyeh, when he heard that El-Ashtar had been given to drink some honey containing poison, in consequence of which he died: and used on the occasion of rejoicing at a misfortune that has befallen an enemy: it occurs in the history of El-Mesʼoodee thus; Uin-a lil-hi junodFA fiI AlEasali. (MF.)

Also, [as a term used in Syria, and afterwards by the Arabs from Syria in Spain,] A city [with its territory; i. e. a province, or district]: (Ḳ:) or particularly a city of Syria [with its territory]: (AO, TA:)
pl. OajonaAdN. (TA.) Syria consists of five AjnAd; namely, Dimashk [or Damascus], Hims [or Emessa], Kinnesreen, El-Urdunn [or the Jordan], and Filasteen or Falasteen [or Palestine]: (Ṣ, M, A:) they were thus called because the military forces were thence collected. (A.) [See mixolaAfN.]
junodiI-N: see junodN.
Also Of, or relating to, a junod of Syria. (A.)
junodN mujan-adN An army, or a military force, collected. (TA.) See also junodN.
junodabN and junodubN and janodabN: see art. jdb.
janodara: see Q. Q. 1 in art. jdr.

Q. 1. [janodalahu He, or it, made him to cleave to the stones. Hence,] taribato yadaAhu wajunodilato [May his arms, or his hands, cleave to the dust, or earth, and the stones, by reason of poverty]. (M in art. trb.)

janodalN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and janodilN (Ḳ) Stones; (Ṣ in art. jdl;) used in the sense of [the pl.] janaAdilu: (Sb, TA:) n. un. janodalapN: (TA:) or what a man can lift, of stones: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, any stone: (TA:) or a mass of stone like a man's head. (T, TA.) [Hence, turobFA lahu wajanodalFA: see turaAbN.]

janadilN, (Ṣ in art. jdl,) or junadilN, (Kr, Ḳ,) A place in which are stones (Kr, Ṣ, Ḳ) collected together: (Kr, Ḳ:) but ISd doubts its correctness. (TA.) And OaroDN junadilapN, (Ḳ,) and sometimes with fet-ḥ, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) i. e., to the j, [janadilapN,] (TḲ,) A land abounding with stones. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
junaAdilN Strong and great. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. janazahu, aor. _i {yajonizu}, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _u, (A,) inf. n. janozN, (TA,) He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, it. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

He collected it; or gathered it together or up; (Ḳ;) as also jn-zihu↓, inf. n. tajoniyzN. (Ṣgh, TA.) You say also, junaza Alr-ajulu, part. n. majonuwzN↓, The man was gathered up [app. as a corpse is gathered up in the grave-clothes]: (TA:) or † he died. (Ḥar p. 122.)

entry.sense: 2. jn-zhu, inf. n. tajoniyzN: see 1.
It is used by El-Ḥasan El-Basree as signifying He put it (namely a corpse) upon the bier. (Ḳ,* TA.)

jinaAzapN and janaAzapN signify the same, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, A dead person; a corpse: (Ḳ:) but the former is the more chaste: (Mṣb:) or the former signifies the dead person; and the latter, the bier: (Aṣ, IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the former, the bier; and the latter, the dead person: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so accord. to Th, as related by Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid: (Mṣb:) or the former is said by the vulgar to mean the bier: (Aṣ, TA:) or the former signifies the bier with the dead person: (Ḳ:) or the dead person upon the bier: (Ṣ:) and the bier is not so called unless the dead person is upon it: (AAF:) when the dead person is not upon it, it is called sariyrN and naEoXN: (AAF, Ṣ:) but the vulgar say janaAzapN, with fet-ḥ; (Ṣ;) which is not allowable: (Lth, Aṣ, Mgh, TA:) or janaAzapN [so in the TA] signifies the man: or the bier with the man: (En-Naḍr, TA:) jnAzp is derived from janazahu, in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (A, Mṣb, TA:) so some assert: (IDrd, TA:) but ISd says, I know not whether this be correct: (TA:) or a janaAzap is so called because the clothes are gathered together when the man is upon the bier: ('Abd-Allah Ibn-El-Ḥasan, TA:) some say that it is Nabathean: (TA:) the pl. is janaAYizu. (Ṣ.) The Arabs say, tarakotuhu jinaAzapF I left him a corpse, or dead. (Aṣ, TA.) And Duriba Alr-ajulu Hat-aI turika janaAzapF [so in the TA, The man was beaten until he was left a corpse]. (ISh, TA.) And rumiIa fiI jinaAzatihi, meaning, He died: (Lth, Mgh:) or he has been carried, or lifted, and put [into his bier]: this they say when they give information of the death of a man: (TA:) and they say also, TuEina fiI jinaAzatihi, meaning the same. (Lth, Mgh, TA.)

Also jinaAzapN [or janaAzapN] ‡ A wine-skin [when emptied; as though it were a body without a soul]. (Ḳ.) A certain impudent man of the Arabs, ʼAmr Ibn-Ki'ás, says,
wakunotu UicaA OaraI ziq-FA SariyEFA
yunaAHu EalaI janaAzatihi bakayotu
[And I used, when I saw a wine-skin laid prostrate, its corpse being wailed over, to weep, or accord. to Th, as is said in the TA in art. bkI, to sing]. (TA.)
† Anything oppressive and grievous, EalaI qawomK to a people. (Lth, Ḳ.)
† A sick person. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
janaAYiziI-N, [from janaAYizu, pl. of janaAzapN,] One who recites [or chants the profession of the faith, &c.] before the dead [in a funeral-procession]. (TA.)
majonuwzN: see 1.

2. jn-shu bihi, (TḲ,) inf. n. tajoniysN, from Aljinosu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [He made it homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it: expl. in the TḲ, not well, by XAklh; but the inf. n., with tolerable correctness, by AykI XyYI brI brynh mXAkl qlmq. The usage of the term tajoniysN in rhetoric, to signify the use of two or more words completely or partly conformable, is post-classical, like jinaAsN, an inf. n. of jaAnasa.]

3. jAnshu, [inf. n. mujaAnasapN and jinaAsN,] It was, or became, homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it; syn. XaAkalahu: (Mgh, Mṣb:) AlmujaAnasapu is from Aljinosu. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, hecaA yujaAnisu hecaA This is homogeneous with this; syn. yuXaAkiluhu: (Mgh, Mṣb:) so says Kh. (Mṣb.) And kayofa yuWaAnisuka mano laA yujaAnisuka [How will he be sociable with thee who will not be congenial with thee?]. (A.) And of a man who has not discrimination nor intelligence, one says, fulaAnN yujaAnisu AlbahaAYima walaA yujaAnisu Aln-aAsa [Such a one resembles the beasts, and does not resemble men]: (Mgh, Mṣb,* TA:) so says Kh. (Mgh.) But Aṣ says that this usage, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in the first and last of the above-mentioned phrases, (Mṣb,) is post-classical. (Mgh, Mṣb.) The usage of the term jinaAsN by rhetoricians [to signify the complete or partial conformity of two or more words] is post-classical [like tajoniysN]. (TA.)
6. jn-shu bihi [The two things were, or became homogeneous, congenial, similar, or conformable,] is a phrase of the scholastic theologians, not [classical] Arabic. (TA.)

jinosN [A genus, kind, or generical class, comprising under it several species, or sorts; or comprised under a superior genus, in relation to which it is a species, or sort;] a Darpb of a thing; (Ṣ;) or of anything; (Mgh, Mṣb;) any Darob of a thing; (A, Ḳ;) [as] of men, and of birds, and of the definitions of grammar and of the art of versification, and of things collectively; so accord. to the lexicologists; (ISd, TA;) a term of more common import than nawoE [which is a species, or sort]: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus animal is a jns and man is a nwE, (Mgh, Mṣb,) because the latter is of more particular import than the former, though it is a jns in relation to what is under it; but the scholastic theologians reverse the case, (Mgh,) for with them jns is of more particular import than nwE: (Kull p. 139:) thus also camels are a jns of beasts: (A, Ḳ:) pl. OajonaAsN [properly a pl. of pauc. but used also as one of mult.] (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and junuwsN. (IDrd, Ḳ.) You say, Aln-aAsu OajonaAsN waOakovaruhumo OanojaAsN [Men are of several kinds, and most of them are impure]. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN mino jinosika, meaning OaSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (Ṣ in art. jnv.)
[Hence, Aisomu jinosK A generic noun: and Aisomu jinosK jamoEiI-N a collective generic noun.]

OawoSaI lijinosihi signifies He left by will, of his property, to the children of his father, [or his kindred by the father's side,] exclusively of all relations of the mother: and so, liOaholi bayotihi. (Mgh.)

The assertion, in the Ḳ, that J's saying, on the authority of IDrd, that Aṣ used to say Aljinosu as meaning AlmujaAnasapu is a vulgarism, is erroneous, is a matter for consideration; for Aṣ said not this, but [what has been cited above, voce jaAnasahu, or] what will be found below, voce mujaAnisN. (TA.)
[jinosiI-N Generic; generical.]
[jinosiy-apN Generical quality.]

mujaAnisN Homogeneous; congenial; similar; conformable; syn. muXaAkilN. (Ḳ.) But IDrd asserts that Aṣ used to reject the saying of the vulgar, hecaA mujaAnisu lihecaA [This is homogeneous with this,, &c.], and to say, It is post-classical. (Ṣ.) [See also 3.]

1. janafN (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and junuwfN, (Ḳ,) the former being inf. n. of janifa and the latter of janafa, (TA,) The act of inclining, or declining (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA) in speech and in all affairs: (TA:) and declining, or deviating, from the right course; acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) like HayofN, which some erroneously assert to be the act of a judge only. (T, TA.) You say, janifa, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yajonafu}, inf. n. janafN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) [and app. janafa, aor. _i {yajonifu}, inf. n. junuwfN;] and Ajnf↓; (T, Mṣb, TA;) He inclined or declined [in speech and in any affair]: (T, Ṣ, TA:) and he declined, or deviated, from the right course; acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) Ealayohi against him. (Mgh.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ii. 178], famano xaAfa mino muwSK janafFA (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. [And he who feareth, (or, as is said in the Ḳ in art. xwf, knoweth,) from, or on the part of, the testator,] an inclining [to a wrong course], or a declining [from the right course]: (TA:) or a manifest inclining or declining. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, janifa fiI waSiy-atihi, aor. _a {yajonafu}; [He inclined,, &c., in his testament;] and so Ajnf↓. (Ḳ.) And Ajnf↓ signifies He deviated from that which was right. (Ḳ.) And Ajnf↓ fiI Hukomihi [He declined from the right course, or acted wrongfully or unjustly, in his judgment]. (TA.) Or Ajnf↓ relates peculiarly to the case of a testament: and janifa signifies absolutely He declined, or deviated, from that which was right. (Ḳ.) And you say, janifa Eano Tariyqihi, aor. _a {yajonafu}; and janafa, aor. _i {yajonifu}, inf. n. janafN, (Ḳ, TA,) which is of the former verb, (TA,) and junuwfN, (Ḳ, TA,) which is of the latter verb; He turned away from his course, or way; deviated therefrom. (TA.)

Or [app. a mistake for “and”] janafN signifies Depression (duxuwlN and AinohiDaAmN) in one of the two sides of the breast, or chest, (Alz-awori,) with evenness of the other side: (Ḳ:) the verb is janifa: and the part. n. is janifN↓ and Oajonafu↓, fem. [of the latter] janofaMCu. (TA.)

3. jnaAfN [an inf. n. of which the verb (jAnf) is not mentioned]. You say, laj-a fiI jinaAfK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family; (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ;) like jinaAbK qabiyHK. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Ajnf He committed an act of inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course, or acting wrongfully or unjustly or injuriously or tyrannically]; like as you say, OalaAma, meaning “he did a thing for which he should be blamed.” (Ṣ.) See also 1, in five places.
Ajnfhu He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAnf fiI miXoyatihi He carried himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, [affecting an inclining of the body from side to side,] in his gait. (TA.) [And He inclined on one side in his gait: said of one who is lame of one leg: see maHoruwqN.]

tjAnf Eano Tariyqihi He affected a declining, or deviating, from his course, or way; he purposely declined, or deviated, therefrom; (Ḳ,* TA;) syn. tamaAyala. (Ḳ.) And in like manner, tjAnf UilaI AlX-aIoCi [He affected an inclining to the thing; intentionally inclined to it]. (TA.) You say, tjAnf liUivomK He inclined to a sin, (Ṣ, Mgh,) [or affected an inclining to it, (see the part. n., below,)] intending, or purposing, the commission of an act of disobedience. (Mgh.)

janafa is [an epithet] like danafa, applying to a sing. and a pl., [being] also an inf. n. [of janifa, q. v.]: Abu-l-'Iyál El-Hudhalee says,
Oal-aA daraOota AlxaSoma Hiyna raOayotuhumo
janafFA EalaI-a biOalosunK waEuyuwni
[Wherefore didst not thou repel the adversaries, when thou sawest them inclining, or acting wrongfully, against me with tongues and eyes?]: or, accord. to one reading, junufFA [which is a pl. of jaAnifN↓]: (Skr p. 128:) [or, as some say,] janafFA is a pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAnifN↓, like as rawaHa is of raAYiHN: or it may be for cawiI janafK. (TA.)
janifN: see Oajonafu, in two places:
and see also 1, last sentence.

junaAfiI-N One who carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, (muxotaAl, [for which Golius, here copied by Freytag, appears to have read muHotaAl, with the unpointed H,]) with an inclining [of the body from side to side]: (Sh, Ḳ:) or one who affects an inclining [of the body from side to side] (yatajaAnafu) in his gait, and carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner therein. (TA.)

Oajonafu [fem. janofaMCu] Inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course], or acting wrongfully or unjustly, [absolutely, as also janifN↓ and jaAnifN↓ and mijonafN↓, or peculiarly] in his testament. (Ḳ.) You say, SaAdafahu janifFA↓ fiI Hukomihi [He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein]. (Ḳ.) And xaSomN mijonafN↓ An adversary who inclines [to a wrong course], or declines [from the right course]; (Ḳ;) who acts wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (TA.)
Inclining; [or pendulous;] applied to a penis. (TA.)
Having a bending back; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man. (Ṣ.)
See also 1, last sentence.
Big, or large; applied to a bowl (qadaH). (TA.)
mijonafN: see Oajonafu, in two places.
gayora mutajaAnifK liUivomK, in the Ḳur [v. 5], means Not affecting an inclining to sin; intending, or purposing, it. (Mṣb, TA.)

1. janaquwA, aor. _i {yajoniqu}, (IAạr, Ḳ,) inf. n. janoqN; (IAạr, TA;) and jn-qwA↓, inf. n. tajoniyqN; (AZ, Ḳ;) They cast stones of [or with] the manojaniyq: (Ḳ,* TA:) and majonaquwA↓, (Ḳ,) or majonaquwA manojaniyqFA [app. meaning they constructed a mnjnyq], (Lth, TA,) is said by such as hold the m to be radical; (Ḳ;) or it may be that the m is augmentative, and that the verb is [denominative,] similar to tamasokana from misokiynN. (TA.)

janaquwnaA biAlmanojaniyqi They cast at us with the mnjnyq: mentioned by El-Fárisee on the authority of AZ. (M.) An Arab of the desert, in describing the wars of his people, said, taArapF nujonaqo waOuxoraI nuroXaqo [One time we are cast at with the mnjnyq, and another we are shot at with arrows]: (Ṣ,* M:) also mentioned by El-Fárisee. (M.)
2. jn-qwA AlmajaAniyqa and majonaquwhaA↓ [app. They constructed the engines of the kind called mnjnyq]. (JK.) See also 1.
Q. Q. 1. majonaquwA: see 1 and 2.
junuqN The stones of the mnjnyq. (M, TA.) [But] IAạr says that jnq [app. junuqN] means The people who manage the mnjnyq. (TA.)
mujayniyqN dim. of manojaniyqN, q. v. (Sb, Ṣ.)
manojanuwqN: see what next follows.

manojaniyqN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and minojaniyqN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and manojanuwqN↓ (Lth, IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ) [A kind of balista;] an instrument [or engine of war] with which stones are cast (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) at the enemy; made by binding [in some manner] very tall wooden poles, whereon is placed what is to be cast, which is then struck with a long pole, and so cast to a very distant place: [this imperfect description (the only one that I have found of this engine) seems to show that it was of a very simple and rude construction:] it is an ancient instrument, anterior to the invention [or use] of gunpowder and cannons by the Christians; and was used by Moḥammad in the siege of Et-Táïf; but the first [of the Arabs] who used it in the time of paganism is said to have been Jedheemeh El-Abrash, of the Mulook et-Tawáïf: (TA:) pl. manojaniyqaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and manojanuwqaAtN (Lth, TA) and majaAniyqu (Sb, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and majaAniqu: (Ḳ:) dim. mujayoniyqN↓: (Sb, Ṣ:) it is fem., (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) preferably, (Lth, TA,) and in most instances; (Mṣb;) and hence it is also called AlOunovaI; (M in art. Anv;) but sometimes it is masc.: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and is arabicized, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the Persian (Ṣ, Ḳ) mano JiI niyko, i. e. “How excellent am I!” (Ṣ,) or mano Jiho niyko, i. e. “I, how excellent am I!” (Ḳ;) [Golius asserts it to be from the Greek Μάγγανον but this is the original of manojanuwnN, which has a different meaning: its derivation, however, seems to have been unknown to the Arabs in general; for]
some say that manojaniyqN is of the measure mafoEaliylN, [so in copies of the Ṣ, but correctly manofaEiylN, as in the Mṣb and TA,] because of the phrase nujonaqu mar-apF [see 1]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) or, (Mṣb,) accord. to Sb, (Ṣ,) it is of the measure fanoEaliylN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) because majaAniyqu is its pl. and the dim. is mujayniyqN; and because, if the m were augmentative as well as the n, there would be two augmentative letters at the beginning of the noun, and this may not be in substs. nor in epithets that are not conformable to augmented verbs; and if the n were made an essential part of the word, the noun would be a quadriliteral-radical, and augmentative letters are not prefixed to words of this class except nouns conformable to their verbs, like mudaHorajN: (Ṣ, TA:) but MF says that these disquisitions are unprofitable; for in his opinion, all the letters of the word are radical, since it is a foreign word. (TA.)
manojaniyiqI-N [app. A maker of the kind of engine called mnjnyq; being mentioned as a surname:] a rel. n. from mnjnyq. (Ḳ.)

janokN [and junokN] A certain [musical] instrument, which is beaten like the Euwd [or lute; namely, the Persian harp; two specimens of which are figured in Note 26 to Chap. iii. of my translation of the “Thousand and One Nights”]; mentioned by El-Khafájee in the Shifá el-Ghaleel; and often spoken of: it is an arabicized word; (MF, TA;) from the Persian JanoG: and applied [also] to the df-, [duf- or daf-, i. e., tambourine,] with which one plays. (TA.)
janokiI-N [and junokiI-N] A player on the jnk above mentioned. (TA.)
janFA i. q. janaON [inf. n. of janiYa, q. v.]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
OajonaA, applied to a man, i. q. OajonaOu, q. v. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) And [its fem.] janowaMCu, i. q. janoMCu, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) applied to a ewe, or a she-goat, meaning Having her horns bending backwards. (TA.)

1. janaI Alv-amarapa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yajoniIu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. janFI, (Ṣ, TA,) or janoIN, (so accord. to one copy of the Ṣ, and written in the accus. case jnyA in the Ḥam p. 355,) and jinaAyapN, (Ḥam ib., but there without any vowel-signs,) He gathered, plucked, or took from the tree, the fruit; (Mgh, TA;) i. q. AjtnAhA↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tjn-AhA↓: (Ḳ:) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to fruit. (TA.) One says also, janaAhaA lahu and janaAhu Uiy-aAhaA [He gathered it, plucked it, or took it from the tree, for him]. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.) And janayotuka OakomuWFA [I gathered for thee truffles]. (TA.) And janaI cahabFA He collected gold from its mine. (TA.)
Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses this verb metaphorically, in the phrase janaI AlEulaI, meaning ‡ [He acquired] eminence, or nobility. (TA.)

You also say, janaI Ealayohi, (Ṣ,) or EalaI qawomihi, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jinaAyapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ He committed, [against him, or] against his people, or party, a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished; (Mṣb;) as also jAnAhu↓ [or jAnI qawomihi]: (TḲ in art. jr:) [and ‡ he brought an injury upon him, or them:] and janaI Alc-anobi Ealayohi, aor. _i {yajoniIu}, inf. n. jinaAyapN, (Ḳ,) with kesr, (TA,) ‡ He committed the crime, offence, or injurious action, against him; syn. jar-ahu Uilayohi: (Ḳ: [see art. jr:]) thus used, also, the verb is metaphorical, from janaI Alv-amarapa: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and so in the phrase, janaI Xar-FA, meaning ‡ He brought to pass an evil thing or action. (Mgh.) [See also jinaAyapN, below.] It is said in a trad., laA yajoniI jaAnK Uil-aA EalaI nafosihi † [An injurer shall not bring injury save on himself]; meaning that one shall not be prosecuted for an injurious action committed by another, of his relations or of others. (TA.) And a poet says,
jaAniyka mano yajoniI Ealayoka waqado
tuEodiI AlS-ijaAHa fatajorabu Aljurobu [which may be rendered, † Thine injurer whom thou shouldst punish is he who brings an injury upon thee: but sometimes the mangy camels infect the sound ones so that these become mangy; and thus a criminal sometimes brings punishment upon his relations: for] AʼObeyd says that jAnyk mn yjnI Elyk is a prov. applied to the case of a man who is punished for an injurious action; because brothers [sometimes] bring injury upon a man [by occasioning his being punished for an injurious action which they have themselves committed], as the latter hemistich of the verse cited above indicates: but AHeyth says that this prov. means AljaAniI laka Alxayora mano yajoniI Ealayoka AlX-ar-a [The person bringing thee good is he who brings, or will bring, upon thee evil: perhaps intended as a caution; for the Arabs often suspect that a benefactor has some evil intention]: and he cites the following hemistich:
tuEodiI AlS-iHaAHa mabaAriku Aljurobi
[meaning Sometimes the places where the mangy camels lie down, and which afford benefit to other camels, infect the sound ones]. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 298.]) You say also, janayota hecaA EalaI nafosika [Thou hast brought this as an injury upon thyself]. (Ḳ in art. jl.)
3. jAnI Ealayohi, inf. n. mujaAnaApN, He accused him of a jinaAyap [or crime,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also 1.

4. AjnI said of a tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a palmtree, (Mṣb,) It had ripe fruit: (Ṣ:) or it attained to the time for the gathering of its fruit: (Mṣb:) or it attained to maturity: (Ḳ:) or, said of a tree, it had fruit to be gathered and eaten: and, said of fruit, it became ripe: (TA:) and, said of grass, or herbage, it became abundant. (KL.)
And Ajnti AlOaroDu The land had much janFI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. herbage, and truffles, and the like. (Ṣ.)
5: see 1.

tjn-I Ealayohi, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or tjn-I Elyh canobFA, (TA,) † He accused him of a crime, an offence, or an injurious action, that he had not committed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. he forged against him the charge of his having committed a crime,, &c., he being guiltless [thereof]: (TA:) Aln-ajan-iI being like Alt-ajar-umu. (Ṣ.) You say also, yatajan-aI EalayonaA maA lamo najonihi [He accuses us of committing what we did not commit]. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA in art. jrm.)
8: see 1.
AijotanayonaA maMCi maTarK We came to rainwater, and drank it: (Ḳ:) a phrase mentioned with approval by IAạr, but not explained by him: thought by ISd to have this meaning. (TA.)

janFI [in the CK janiI-N] Whatever is gathered, or plucked; as also janaApN↓: (Ḳ:) or whatever is gathered, or plucked, from trees, (Ṣ,) &c.; (so in a copy of the Ṣ;) as also janaApN↓: (Ṣ:) so that these two words are of the same class as Hiq-N and Hiq-apN: or the latter of them is a n. un.: (TA:) or the former signfies what is gathered from trees while fresh; (Mṣb;) as also janiI-N↓: (Mṣb:) or this last is an epithet applied to fruit, signifying just gathered or plucked; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or gathered, or plucked, while fresh: (TA:) and majonFI↓, also, pl. majaAnK, signifies fruit gathered or plucked: (Ḥar p. 369:) janFI also signifies fruit [ready to be gathered or plucked]; so in the Ḳur lv. 54: (Jel:) and is applied to fresh ripe dates: (Fr, Ḳ:) and grapes: (TA:) and truffles, and the like: (Ṣ:) and even cotton: (TA:) and herbage: (Ṣ:) and gold, (Ḳ,) which is collected from its mine: (TA:) and cowries, (Ḳ,) as though gathered from the sea: (TA:) and honey, (Ḳ,) when it is gathered: (TA:) pl. OajonaMCN (Ḳ) and OajonK, originally OajonuIN. (TA.) Hence the saying,
hecaA janaAI waxiyaAruhu fiyhi
Uicokul-u jaAnK yaduhu UilaI fiyhi
[This is what I have gathered, and the best of it is in it; when every gatherer but myself has his hand to his mouth]: or, accord. to one reading, wahijaAnuhu fiyhi (which has the same meaning, TA in art. hjn): a prov., ascribed by Ibn-El-Kelbee to ʼAmr Ibn-'Adee El-Lakhmee, the son of the daughter of Jedheemeh: he says that Jedheemeh had ordered the people to gather for him truffles, and some of them ate the best that they found; but ʼAmr brought to him the best that he found, and addressed to him these words: and ʼAlee is related to have repeated them on an occasion of his entering the government-treasury; meaning that he had not defiled himself with anything of the tribute belonging to the Muslims, but had put it in its places. (TA.)
janaApN: see janFI, in two places.
janiI-N: see janFI. Also Dates cut from the tree. (TA.)
jinaAyapN, primarily, The act of gathering, plucking, or taking from a tree, fruit: [see 1:]
then, † The bringing to pass an evil thing, or action: (Mgh, Kull p. 147:)
then, † Evil, [itself]:
then, † The doing a forbidden action: (Kull ib.:) specially used in this last sense; though it has a general application: (Mgh:)

[as a simple subst., it generally signifies] A crime, an offence, or an injurious action, for which one should be punished: (Mṣb:)
or an action that a man commits requiring punishment or retaliation to be inflicted upon him in the present world and in the world to come: (TA:) or any forbidden injurious action: (Kull p. 134:) and in the language of the lawyers, especially a wounding: and an amputation, or a maiming: (Mṣb:) and janiy-apN↓ signifies the same as jinaAyapN: (Ḥam p. 241:) the pl. of jnAyp is jinaAyaAtN and janaAyaA; but the latter of these pls. is of rare occurrence. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: janiy-apN: see what next precedes.
Also A [garment such as is called] ridaMC (Ḳ, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) made of [the kind of cloth termed] xaz-. (Ḳ, TA.)
jaAnK A gatherer of fruit [&c.]:

and also † A committer of a jinaAyap [or crime,, &c.]: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. junaApN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jun-aMCN (Sb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajonaMCN, which last is extr., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or doubtful. (Ṣ.) Hence the prov., OajonaAWuhaA OabonaAWuhaA, explained in art. bnI. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence also,] AljaAniI † The wolf. (IAạr, TA voce jaAbK, q. v.)
Also i. q. laq-aAHN; (IAạr, Az, TA;) i. e. A fecundater of palm-trees. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: AljawaAniI i. q. AljawaAnibu [pl. of AljaAnibu]; (Ḳ;) similar to Alv-aEaAliI and AlOaraAniI. (TA.)
majonFI: see janFI.
mujotanFI A place of gathering, or plucking, fruits, &c. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jahada, (Ṣ, A, L, &c.,) aor. _a {yajohadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jahodN, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or toiled; exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, diligently, studiously, sedulously, earnestly, or with energy; was diligent, or studious; took pains, or extraordinary pains; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) fiI kacaA in such a thing; (Ṣ;) or fiI AlOamori in the affair; (A;) as also Ajthd↓; (A, Ḳ;) and so jAhd↓, with respect to speech and actions: (L:) or jahada fiI AlOamori, aor. and inf. n. as above, he did his utmost, or used his utmost power or efforts or endeavours or ability, in prosecuting the affair: (Mṣb:) and Ajthd↓ and tjAhd↓ he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or Ajthd↓ fiI AlOamori he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability, in the prosecution of the affair, so as to effect his utmost. (Mṣb.) You say also, Aijohado jahadaka fiI hcaA AlOamori ‡ Do thine utmost in this affair: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:*) but not juhodaka. (Fr, Ṣ.) And Ajthd↓ raOoyahu ‡ He took pains, or put himself to trouble or fatigue, to form a right judgment or opinion. (MA.) And Aijotahadotu↓ raOoyiI wanafosiI Hat-aI balagotu majohuwdiI † I exerted my judgment and my mind so that I attained the utmost of my power, or ability. (T, L.)
jahadabihi He tried, proved, or examined, him, (L, Ḳ,) Eani Alxayori wagayorihi [respecting good qualities, &c.]. (L.)

jahadahu, (Mgh, L, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yajohadu}, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. jahodN, (L, Mṣb,) It, (an affair, and a disease,) and he, (a man,) affected him severely; harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (Mṣb:) it (disease, L and Ḳ, and fatigue, and love, L) rendered him lean; emaciated him: (L, Ḳ:) he burdened him beyond his power; imposed upon him that which was beyond his power; as also Ajhdhu↓: (Mgh:) and, [as also Ajhdhu↓,] he importuned him, harassed him, or plied him hard, in asking, begging, or petitioning. (A.) [Hence,] juhida, said of a man, He was severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (Ṣ, L:) or was grieved, or made sorry or unhappy. (L.) And OaSaAbahumo quHuwTN mina AlmaTari fajuhiduwA jahodFA XadiydFA Drought befell them, and they consequently became severely distressed. (Ṣ.) And juhiduwA They were, or became, afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (L.) And rajulN yajohadu Oano yaHomila silaAHahu mina AlD-aEofi, for yajohadu nafosahu, A man who imposes upon himself a difficulty, or trouble, or fatigue, or a difficult or severe task, or who strains, or strains himself, in the carrying of his weapons, or arms, by reason of weakness. (Mgh.) And jahada daAb-atahu and AjhdhA↓ He jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied, his beast; i. q. balaga jahodahaA↓: (Ḳ:) or he tasked, or plied, his beast beyond his power in journeying, or marching, or in respect of pace. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And Oajohadotuhu EalaI Oano yafoEala kacaA wakacaA [I importuned him, or harassed him, to do such and such things]. (L.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb,) ‡ He deprived it (namely, milk,) of its butter, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) entirely: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or churned it so as to extract its butter and render it sweet and pleasant: or mixed it with water: (Mṣb:) or diluted it so that it consisted for the most part of water: and in like manner is used in relation to broth. (A.)
Hence, (Mṣb,) jahadahaA † He lay with her; or compressed her: (L, Mṣb, from a trad.:) or i. q. dafaEahaA, and HafazahaA [which has a similar meaning]. (L.)
jahada AlT-aEaAmi † He desired the food eagerly; longed for it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Ajhdhu↓. (Ḳ.) And juhida AlT-aEaAmu and Oujohida↓ † The food was eagerly desired, or longed for. (Ṣ.)
Also ‡ He ate much of the food: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he left nothing of it. (A.) You say also, hecaA kalaON yajohaduhu AlmaAlu † This is herbage, or pasture, of which the cattle eat perseveringly. (AA, TA.)
jahida It (a state of life) was, or became, hard, difficult, strait, or distressful. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. jihaAdN, inf. n. of jAhd, properly signifies The using, or exerting, one's utmost power, efforts, endeavours, or ability, in contending with an object of disapprobation; and this is of three kinds, namely, a visible enemy, the devil, and one's self; all of which are included in the term as used in the Ḳur xxii. 77. (Er-Rághib, TA.) See also 1, first sentence. You say, jAhd AlEaduw-a, (JK, A, Mgh,) inf. n. as above (JK, Mgh, Ḳ) and mujaAhadapN, (JK, Ḳ,) He fought with the enemy: (Ḳ:) or he encountered the enemy, imposing upon himself difficulty or distress or fatigue, or exerting his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, [or the utmost thereof,] to repel him, his enemy doing the like: and hence jAhd came to be used by the Muslims to signify generally he fought, warred, or waged war, against unbelievers and the like. (Mgh.) You say also, jAhd fiI sabiyli Qll-ehi, inf. n. jihaAdN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and mujaAhadapN, (Ṣ,) [He fought, &c., in the way of God; i. e., in the cause of religion.]

hom.sense: 4. Ajhd, as trans.: see 1, in six places.

Also He made, or incited, another, to strive or labour or toil, to exert himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability,, &c.; trans. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (JK.)
Oujohida He was thrown into a state of difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.)
Ajhd maAlahu He consumed, or wasted, and dispersed, his property: (Ḳ:) or gave it away, and dispersed it, altogether, here and there. (En-Naḍr, TA.)
As intrans., He (an enemy) strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in enmity, (Ḳ, TA,) EalayonaA against us. (TA.)

He acted with energy, or with the utmost energy: so in the phrases saAra faOajohada He marched, or journeyed, and did so with energy, or with the utmost energy; and Halafa biQll-ehi faOajohada He swore by God, and did so with energy,, &c.: in which cases one should not say fajahada. (Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà, L.)
He took the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, and sound judgment, fiI AlOamori in the affair; syn. AiHotaATa. (L, Ḳ.)
He became in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.)
† It (a thing) became mixed, or confused. (Ḳ.)
He entered upon land such as is termed jahaAd: he went forth into the desert; and into the plain, or open country. (JK.)

It rose up; rose into view; appeared. (JK.) You say, Ajhd liIa Alqawomu The people, or company of men, came within my sight, or view; syn. OaXorafuwA. (AA, Ḳ.) And Ajhd fiyhi AlX-ayobu Hoariness appeared upon him, and became much: (TA:) or ‡ became much, and spread: (A:) or became much, and was quick in its progress, (Ḳ, TA,) and spread. (TA.) And Oajohadato lahu AlOaroDu The land became open to him. (L, Ḳ.*) And in like manner, Ajhd lh AlT-ariyqu, (L,) and AlHaq-u, (L, Ḳ,*) The road, and † the truth, became open, apparent, and manifest, to him. (L, Ḳ.*) And Ajhd laka AlOamoru † The thing became, or has become, within thy power, or reach; (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ;) and offered, or presented, itself to thee. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see 1.
8: see 1, in five places.

AijotihaAdN as a conventional term means A lawyer's exerting the faculties [of the mind] to the utmost, for the purpose of forming an opinion in a case of law [respecting a doubtful and difficult point]: (KT:) the seeking to form a right opinion: (KL:) [investigation of the law, or the working out a solution of any difficulty in the law, by means of reason and comparison: and] the referring a case proposed to the judge, [respecting a doubtful and difficult point,] from the method of analogy, to the Kur-Án and the Sunneh. (L, TA.*)
