Power; ability; as also juhodN↓; (Ṣ, A, IAth, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, and the former of other dials.; (Mṣb;) and majohuwdN↓: (A:) jhd in the Ḳur ix. 80 is read both jahod and juhd↓: (Ṣ:) and jahodN signifies also labour, toil, exertion, effort, endeavour, energy, diligence, painstaking, or extraordinary painstaking: (L: [see jahada:]) or juhodN↓ has the signification first mentioned above, (Fr, Ṣ, IAth, Mṣb,) and jahodN, with fet-ḥ, is from Aijohado jahodaka fiI hecaA AlOamori, (Fr, Ṣ,) or from jahada fiI AlOamori, being an inf. n. from this verb, (Mṣb,) and signifies, [as also majohuwdN↓,] one's utmost; the utmost of one's power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy. (Fr, Ṣ, IAth, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, bacala Aljahoda, (Mṣb in art. blg, &c.,) and Almajohuwda↓, (Ṣ, A,) or jahodahu, (Mgh,) [and majohuwdahu↓,] He exerted unsparingly his power or ability: (Mgh:) [or his utmost power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy; as shown above.] And balaga jahodahu, (A, L,) and majohuwdahu↓, (A,) He accomplished the utmost of his power or ability; did his utmost. (A, L. [Like jahada jahodahu. See also balaga jahoda daAb-atihi, below.]) And juhayodaI↓ is syn. with jahodN; (Ḳ;) as in the saying, laOabolugan-a juhayodaAIa fiI AlOamori (JK, TḲ,) i. e. I will assuredly accomplish the utmost of my power, or ability, in the affair. (TḲ. [In a copy of the A, juhayodaAka; and so in the TA, I believe from that same copy.]) [So, too, is juhaAdaI↓; as in the saying,] juhaAdaAka Oano tafoEala The utmost of thy power, or ability, and the utmost of thy case, is, or will be, thy doing [such a thing]; syn. quSaAraAka [q. v.], (JK, Ḳ,) and gaAyapu Oamorika. (TA.) Al-aciyna OaqosamuwA biQll-ehi jahoda OayomaAnihimo, in the Ḳur [v. 58, &c.], means Who swore by God with the most energetic of their oaths: (Ḳ,* Jel:) or the strongest, or most forcible, of their oaths; jhd being originally an inf. n., and in the accus. as a denotative of state with yajohaduwna understood before it, or as an inf. n. (Bḍ.)

Also Difficulty, or grievousness; embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (Ṣ, A, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so accord. to some who say that juhodN↓, with damm, has the first of the significations assigned to it above; (Mṣb;) as also majohuwdN↓: (Mgh:) a disease, or difficulty, that distresses or afflicts, a man; as also juhodN↓. (JK.) Hence, jahodu AlbalaMCi, (Mṣb,) i. e. A state of difficulty, or trouble, to which death is preferred: or largeness of one's family, or household, combined with poverty. (L, Ḳ.*) [Hence also,] balaga jahoda daAb-atihi, [i. e. balaga maXaq-atahaA,] i. q. jahadahaA: see 1. (Ḳ.)

Also Small provision, upon which a man possessing little property can live (JK, L) with difficulty. (L.) And jahodN Almuqil-i What a man who possesses little property can afford to give in payment of the poor-rate required by the law. (L, from a trad.)

hom.sense: juhodN: see jahodN, in five places.
Also Milk mixed [with water: see majohuwdN]. (JK.)

jahaAdN Hard land: (JK, Ṣ:) or land in which is no herbage: (TA:) or hard land in which is no herbage: (Ḳ:) or level, or even, land: or rugged land: also used as an epithet; so that you say OaroDN jahaAdN: (TA:) or level, smooth land, in which is no hill: (JK:) or the most plain and even of land, whether it have produced herbage or not, not having any mountain or hill near it: and such is what is termed a SaHoraMC: (ISh, TA:) or an open tract of land: (Fr, TA:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jamaAdN: pl. juhudN. (AA, L.)
Also The fruit of the OaraAk; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and so jahaADN. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: maroEFI jahiydN ‡ Pasture much eaten by cattle. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And OaroDN jahiydapu AlkalaOi ‡ Land of which the herbage is much eaten by cattle. (A.)
juhaAdaI: see jahodN.
juhayodaI: see jahodN.

jaAhidN [Striving, labouring, or toiling;, &c.: see 1. Hence,] sayorunaA jaAhidN [Our journeying is laborious]. (TA in art. Axw.) And jahodN jaAhidN [Intense labour or exertion, or the like: or severe difficulty or distress, &c.]: an intensive expression, (Ḳ, TA,) like XiEorN XaAEirN and layolN laAYilN. (TA.)
† Eagerly desiring [food]; longing for [it]: (JK, Ṣ:) pl. OajohaAdN. (JK.)
garovaAnu jaAhidN ‡ Hungry and greedy, leaving no food. (A.)
mujohadN A man thrown into a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble, or fatigue. (L.)

huwa mujohadu laka He is one who takes the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or sound judgment, for thee; syn. muHotiyTN. (L.) And naSiyHN mujohidN A sincere, or faithful, and careful, adviser, or counsellor. (L.)
rajulN mujohidN A man in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble or fatigue: possessing little property; poor. (L.)
And A man whose beast is weak by reason of fatigue. (L.)

hom.sense: majohuwdN Severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (Ṣ, Mgh, L:) distressed, or afflicted, by disease or difficulty: (JK:) afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth: (L:) and angry. (JK.)
A hard, difficult, strait, or distressful, state of life. (TA.)

‡ Milk deprived of its butter (Ṣ, A) entirely: (Ṣ:) or mixed with water: (Mṣb:) or diluted so as to consist for the most part of water; and in like manner, broth: (A:) or churned so that its butter is extracted and it is rendered sweet and pleasant: and used as meaning eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk without its occasioning disgust, by reason of its sweetness and pleasantness: (Mṣb:) or eagerly desired, or longed for; and so food in general: (JK, L:) or eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk with perseverance, on account of its pleasantness and sweetness. (L.)
See also jahodN, in six places.

1. jahara, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoharu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) It (a thing, A, Mṣb) was, or became, plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public; syn. Zahara, (A, Mṣb,) and badaA, (TA,) and Ealana: (Ḳ:) or the radical signification is, it (a thing) was, or became, exceedingly plain to be perceived, either by the sense of sight or by that of hearing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Accord. to some, when relating to what is visible, it is tropical; and when relating to what is audible, proper: but if so, it seems to be so much used in the former sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper. See also jahorapN.]

jahura, aor. _u {yajohuru} [inf. n., app., jahaArapN and juhuwrapN,] He (a man, TA) was, or became, great, or bulky, (Ḳ, TA,) [and therefore a conspicuous object,] before the eyes of the beholder. (TA.) [And He was, or became, pleasing, or goodly, in aspect: see jahaArapN, below.]
Also, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (A, Mṣb,) It (the voice) rose [so as to be plainly heard]; was, or became, high, or loud. (A, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)
Also, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (TA,) He, (a man) was, or became, high, or loud, of voice. (Ṣ, TA.)
jibir aor. _a {yajoharu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jaharN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He (a man) was unable to see in the sun. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) And in like manner said of the eye. (Ḳ.)

jaharahu, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. jahorN; (TA;) and jahara bihi; (A, Mṣb;) and Ajhrhu↓, (A, Mṣb, TA,) [and Ajhr↓ bihi;] and jahowarahu↓; (TA;) He made it plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (A, Mṣb, TA.)

jahara AlkalaAma, and jaharabihi; (Ḳ;) and Ajhrhu↓, inf. n. UijohaArN; (Ṣ;) and Ajhr↓ bihi; (Ḳ;) and jahowara↓; (TA;) and jahara biAlqawoli, and biduEaAYihi, and biSalaAtihi, (TA,) and biqiraMCatihi, (Ṣgh, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _a {yajoharu}, inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN; (TA;) and Ajhr↓ bqrMCth; (Ṣgh, Mṣb, TA;) He uttered the speech, and the saying, and his supplication, and his prayer, and his recitation, with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; publicly: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or jahara bikalaAmihi, (A,) and biAlqawoli, and jahowara↓; (Ṣ;) and biqiraMCatihi; (A;) he uttered his speech, and the saying, and his recitation, with a raised, or loud, voice; aloud: (Ṣ, A:) and jahara AlS-awota he raised the voice [so as to make it plainly heard]. (Ḳ.)

jahara biAlmaEaASiI, and Ajhr↓, and jAhr↓, he made known the acts of disobedience that he had committed, by talking of them: he who does so is termed mujaAhirN↓ biAlmuEaASiI, and simply mujaAhirN. (TA.) And Ajhr↓ maA fiI Sadorihi He revealed what was in his bosom. (A.) And jahowara↓ AlHadiyva baEoda maA hayonamahu He revealed the story after he had concealed it. (A.) And Ajhr↓ AlOamora He made the case, or affair, notorious. (TA.)
Also jaharahu He discovered it (Ḳ, TA) ocularly. (TA.)

He saw him (a man) without any veil (Ḳ, TA) intervening; (TA;) as also Ajthrhu↓: (Ḳ:) or he looked towards him, or regarded him. (Ḳ.)
You say, maA fiI AlHaI-i OaHadN tajoharahu EayoniI There is not in the tribe any one whom my eye regards as worthy of notice or respect by reason of his greatness therein; syn. taOoxucuhu. (TA.) And Ajthr↓ Alqawomu fulaAnFA The people looked towards such a one without any veil intervening between them and him. (TA.)
He saw it (an army, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and a people, TA) to be numerous in his eyes; as also Ajthrhu↓. (Ṣ A, Ḳ.)

jahara AlbiYora, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajoharu}, inf. n. jahorN, (TA,) He cleared out the well, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and took forth from it the black fetid mud that it contained; as also AjtrhA↓: (Ṣ:) or both signify he entirely, or nearly, exhausted the well of its water: (Ḳ:) or the former, he reached the water of the well, (Ḳ, TA,) in digging: or so jahara alone: (TA:) and accord. to Akh, jaharotu Alr-akiy-apa signifies I cleared out the mud that the water covered in the well, so that the water appeared and became clear. (Ṣ.) ʼÁïsheh said, describing her father, Ajthr↓ dufuna Alr-awaMCi, lit., He cleared out the filled-up wells of abundant water so as to make the water well forth; alluding to his rectifying affairs that had become disordered. (TA from a trad.)
jaharonaAhumo We came to them in the morning, at the time called AlS-abaAH, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) when they were inadvertent. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
jahara AlOaroDa He traversed the land (Ṣ, Ḳ) without knowledge. (Ṣ.)
jahara Als-iqaMCa He shook the milk-skin to make butter, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and took forth its butter. (Fr, TA.)
jaharati AlX-amosu AlmusaAfira The sun dazzled the eye, and confused the sight, of the traveller; syn. Oasodarato Eayonahu. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. jAhr: see 1.

[Its inf. n.] mujaAharapN signifies The fighting [with any one] face to face: and the showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: and the reading, or reciting, a thing aloud: and the speaking loudly. (KL.) You say, jAhr biAlEadaAwapi, (Mṣb,) inf. n. mujaAharapN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and jihaArN, (Mṣb,) He showed open enmity or hostility, with another. (Ṣ,* Mṣb.) And jaAharotuhumo biAlOamori I acted openly with them in the affair, or case; syn. EaAlanotuhumo bihi. (JK.) [And jAhrhu He treated him openly with enmity, &c.]

jaAharahumo biAlOamori, (TA,) inf. n. mujaAharapN and jihaArN, (Ḳ,) [is explained as signifying] He vied with them, or strove to overcome or surpass them, in the affair, or case. (Ḳ,* TA.) [But gAlbhm, in the TA, and AlmugaAlabapu, in the Ḳ, are here evidently mistranscriptions for EaAlanahumo and AlmuEaAlanapu.]
4: see 1, in eight places.
Ajhr also signifies He begat sons goodly in stature (IAạr, Ḳ) and in aspect, (IAạr, TA,) or in cheeks: (Ḳ:) or, a squint-eyed son. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 6. [tajaAhurN signifies The showing oneself openly: and acting openly, or being open in one's conduct or converse, with others. You say,] tajaAharuwA biAlEadaAwapi They showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tabaAdawoAbihaA. (Ṣ in art. bdw.)
[And tjAhr He feigned himself unable to see in the sun: see the part. n., below.]

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in eight places.
10. Astjhrhu: see 1.
Also He took it forth. (TA from a trad.)
Q. Q. 1. jahowara: see 1, in four places.
jahorFA: see jahorapN, in two places.
juhorN: see jahaArapN, in six places.
jahirN: see jahiyrN, in two places.

jahorapN A thing that is plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (Ḳ.) You say, raMhu jahorapF (Ṣ, A, &c.) He saw him, or it, [plainly,] without the intervention of any veil: (TA:) and rMh jihaArFA↓ [signifies the same: or] he saw him, or it, with exceeding plainness: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the former signifies he saw him, or it, with his eyes, ocularly, or before his eyes, (Ṣ, A, Bḍ in ii. 52, Mṣb,) without anything intervening: (Ṣ:) so in the Ḳur. [ii. 52], Hat-aI naraI Qll-eha jahorapF: (Ṣ, Bḍ:) and [some say that] jahorapF is here originally an inf. n. of jaharotu in jaharotu biAlqiraMCapi, [like jahorFA↓,] and metaphorically used in the sense of muEaAyanapF: it is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: or it is thus used as a denotative of state relating to the agent or the object: and some read jaharapF↓, as an inf. n. like galabap, or as pl. of jaAhirN, and as such it is a denotative of state: (Bḍ:) or jahorapF is here from jaharotu Alr-akiy-apa: (Akh, Ṣ:) accord. to Ibn-ʼArafeh, it here signifies unconcealed from us: (TA:) and in the Ḳur. iv. 152, ocularly; not concealed from us by anything. (Ḳ,* TA.)
You say also, kal-amahu jahorapF [and jahorFA↓ He spoke to him plainly, with an open voice, aloud, or publicly]. (Ṣ, TA.)
And laqiyahu nahaArFA jihaArFA↓ and jahaArFA↓ [He met him in the daytime, openly, or publicly]. (Ḳ.)
juhorapN [A blaze covering the face of a horse: or the quality of having such a blaze:] a subst. from Oajoharu applied to a horse. (TA.)
A cast in the eye. (AA, TA. [See also Oajoharu.])
jaharapF: see jahorapN.
jahaArFA and jihaArFA: see jahorapN, in three places.
jahowarN: see jahiyrN.
Also, and mujotaharN↓, An army seen to be numerous. (A.)
And the former, Bold; daring: in the Ḳ, erroneously, jawoharN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: jahiyrN (in the TA, here, jahirN↓, but in another place, jahiyrN,) High, loud, or vehement, speech; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also mujoharN↓ and jahowariI-N↓: (Ḳ:) and so applied to the voice; (Mṣb, TA;) as also jahowariI-N↓. (A, TA.) Also, and mujoharN↓ (TA) and jahowariI-N↓ (A, TA) and jahowarN↓ (A) and jahiyru AlS-awoti (Ṣ, A) and jahowariI-u↓ AlS-awoti, (Ṣ,) A man having a high, loud, or strong voice. (Ṣ, A, TA.)

A man (Ṣ, A) of pleasing, or goodly, aspect; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also jahirN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. of the former with p {jahiyrapN}: (Ṣ:) beautiful: (Ḳ:) of goodly aspect, who pleases the beholder by his beauty: and a face of goodly, or beautiful, fairness: (TA:) and Oajoharu↓ a man (TA) of goodly aspect, (Ḳ, TA,) and of goodly and perfect body. (AA, Ḳ, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or jahiyrN liloxayori and lilomaEoruwfi, (A,) Adapted to, or constituted for, goodness: (A, Ḳ:) because he who beholds him desires his beneficence: (TA:) pl. juharaMCu. (A, Ḳ.)
Also Milk not mixed with water: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or from which the butter has been taken forth. (TA.)

entry.sense:
jahaArapN [an inf. n. (see jahura)] Pleasingness, or goodliness, of aspect; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also juhuwrapN↓ (Ḳ) and juhorN↓: (TA:) [and a quality pleasing to behold: for] Abu-n-Nejm says,
waOaraI AlbayaADa EalaI Aln-isaMCi jahaArapF
[And I regard fairness in women as a quality pleasing to behold]: (Ṣ:) and juhorN↓ signifies the form, or appearance, or the like, and goodliness of aspect, of a man: (Ḳ:) or what pleases by its beauty, of the form or appearance or the like, of a man, and and goodliness of aspect: (Ṣ:) [and simply aspect, or outward appearance.] You say, banuwna cawuw jahaArpK Sons goodly in stature and in aspect: (IAạr, TA:) or in stature and in cheeks: (Ḳ:) but the former is the more agreeable with authority. (TA.) And maA OaHosana juhora↓ fulaAnK How goodly is the form, or appearance, or the like, and the beauty of aspect, of such a one! (Ṣ, A:*) [or simply, the aspect; for] you say also, maA OasowaOa juhorahu↓ [How evil is his aspect!]. (A.) And rajulN Hasanu AljahaArapi and Aljuhori↓ A man goodly in aspect. (TA.) And raOayotu juhorahu↓ faEarafotu sir-ahu [I saw his aspect, and so knew his mind]. (A.)
juhuwrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
fulaAnN Eafiyfu Als-ariyrapi waAljahiyrapi [Such a one is chaste in secret conduct and in public behaviour]. (A.)
jahowariI-N: see jahiyrN, in four places.

hom.sense: jawoharN a word of well-known meaning, (Mṣb,) [a coll. gen. n., Jewels; precious stones; gems; pearls: any kind of jewel, precious stone, or gem: and also applied (as in the T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, and Ḳ, voce tiborN, q. v.,) to native ore:] any stone from which is extracted, or elicited, anything by which one may profit: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {jawoharapN}: (Ṣ:) [pl. jawaAhiru:] it is of the measure fawoEalu, (Mṣb,) and is from Aljahoru signifying a thing's “becoming exceedingly plain to be perceived by the sense of sight:” (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it is of Persian origin, (TA,) arabicized, (Ṣ, TA,) [from Gawoharo,] accord. to most persons. (TA.)
jawoharu sayofK The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword; syn. firinodN. (T and Ḳ voce firinodN.)
[Hence, Aljawoharu Alfarodu † The indivisible atom.]

In the conventional language of scholastic theology, jawoharN signifies ‡ Substance, as opposed to accident; in which sense, some assert the word to be so much used as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper. (TA.)
See also jahowarN.

entry.sense: jawohariI-N A jeweller; a seller of jawohar [or jawaAhir]. (TA.)
[In scholastic theology, † Of, or relating to, substance, as opposed to accident.]
Oajoharu: see jahiyrN.

Also A man having the eyeball, or globe of the eye, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZN: or resembling such as is termed jAHZ: fem. jahoraMCu. (TA.) And this latter, An eye having the ball, or globe, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZapN: (Ḳ:) or resembling what is thus termed. (TA.)
Having a pretty cast in the eye: (AA, Ḳ:) fem. as above. (Ḳ.)

That cannot see in the sun; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a man, (A, Mṣb,) and to a ram: (Ṣ:) fem. as above: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or weak-sighted in the sun: (Lḥ, TA:) or that cannot see in the daytime; OaEoXaI signifying “that cannot see in the night:” (TA:) and the fem., a woman who closes her eyes in the sun. (A.)
A horse having a blaze that covers his face: fem. as above. (Ḳ.)
Also the fem., Open, bare, land, not concealed by anything: (A:) or plain land, in which are no trees nor hills (Ḳ, TA) nor sands: (TA:) pl. jahoraAwaAtN. (A, TA.)

And A company (Ṣ, Ḳ) consisting of the distinguished part (TA) of a people: (Ṣ:) the more, or most, excellent persons of a tribe. (Ḳ.) You say, [with reference to distinguished persons,] kayofa jahoraAWukumo How is your company? (Ṣ.)
mujoharN. see majohuwrN: and see also jahiyrN, in two places.
mijoharN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mijohaArN↓ (Ḳ) A man accustomed to speak with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; or publicly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mijohaArN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: majohuwrN bihi Notorious; applied to a thing: (TA:) and so mujotaharN↓ applied to a man: (A, TA:) and mujoharN↓ plain, apparent, or conspicuous; applied to a thing. (TA.)

AlHuruwfu Almajohuwrapu [The letters that are pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only; the vocal letters;] the letters (nineteen in number, Ṣ) that are comprised in the saying Zil-u qaw-K rabaDN Uico gazaA junodu muTiyEN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) opposed to Almahomuwsapu: (TA:) so called [accord. to some] because there is a full stress in the place where any one of them occurs, and the breath is prevented from passing with it until the stress is ended with the passage of the voice. (Sb, Ṣ.)
maMCN majohuwrN Water which, having been buried in the earth, has been drawn until it has become sweet. (TA.)
majohuwrapN A well (biYorN) cleared out, and cleansed from the black fetid mud which it had contained. (Ṣ.)
And Wells frequented [and in use], (Ḳ,) whether their water be sweet or salt. (TA.)

entry.sense: mujaAhirN: see, above, jahara biAlmaEaASiI.
mujotaharN: see majohuwrN: and see also jahowarN.

mutajaAhirN Feigning himself Oajohar; as in the saying, cited by Th,
kaAln-aAZiri AlmutajaAhiri
[Like the looker that feigns himself unable to see in the sun]. (TA.)
1. jahaza EalaI AljariyHi: see 4, in two places.

hom.sense: 2. jh-z, inf. n. tajohiyzN, He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, a bride, and a traveller, and a corpse, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and an army, (Ṣ,) with her, or his, or their, jahaAz [i. e. requisites, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus]: (Ṣ, Mṣb. Ḳ:) he provided a warrior with a beast to ride, and with other requisites for his expedition: (TA:) he prepared him or it. (TA.) You say also, jhaz Ealayohi Alxayola [He fitted out the horsemen and sent them against him]. (Ṣ.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 4. Ajhz EalaI AljariyHi, (Aṣ, JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijohuAzN; (Mṣb;) and jahaza↓ Ealayoha, aor. _a {yajohazu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jahozN; (TA;) He despatched, or he hastened and completed the slaughter of, the wounded man; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he made his slaughter sure, or certain: (JK, Ḳ:) and jh-z↓, with teshdeed, signifies the same, but denoting muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, and intensiveness: (Mṣb:) or jahaza↓ ElI AljryH signifies he slew the wounded man. (IDrd, TA.) You should not say, Oajazotu ElI AljryH, (Ṣ,) or OajaAza Elyh. (ISd, TA.)

5. tjh-z He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, himself; or he or it became fitted out or equipped or furnished or supplied; with his or its jahaAz [or requisites,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) he prepared himself. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, tajah-azotu liOamori kacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and AijohaAzazotu↓, (Ḳ,) I prepared myself for such a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
11. AijohaAzazotu liOamorikacaA: see 5.

hom.sense: jahaAzN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) so accord. to the seven readers in the Ḳur xii. 59 and 70, (Az, Mṣb,) and jihaAzN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the latter is rare, (Mṣb,) or bad, (Az, TA,) or an erroneous pronunciation of the people of El-Basrah, (Lth, TA,) The requisites, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) equipments, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus, (Mṣb,) of a bride, [i. e. her paraphernalia,] and of a traveller, and of a corpse: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) provisions and other requisites for a traveller: (Ḥar p. 104:) pl. [of pauc.] OajohizapN, and pl. pl. OajohizaAtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Accord. to some, Household goods or furniture and utensils: accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-ʼEesà, excellent goods that are conveyed from country to country: and hence the jhAz of the bride: (Ḥar p. 104:) or excellent goods that are conveyed as merchandise. (Mgh.)

Also the former, What is upon a camel that is used for riding [consisting of the saddle and its appertenances]. (Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., Daraba fiI jahaAzihi, with fet-ḥ [to the j], (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. He took fright and fled or went away at random, and did not return: (Ḳ:) or it is said of a thing that goes away and does not return: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) originally relating to a camel from whose back the saddle with its apparatus tumbles, falling between his legs, in consequence of which he takes fright and flees or runs away at random, so that he goes away into the land: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) Daraba signifies he went; (sAr; for which in the CK is put SAr;) and the meaning of the phrase is, he went stumbling upon his apparatus. (Ḳ.) In the T it is said, The Arabs say, Daraba AlbaEiyru fiI jahaAzihi, meaning The camel took fright and ran away at random, beating the ground with his feet so as to throw down the apparatus and load that were upon him. (TA.)
Also the former, The pudendum of a woman. (Ṣ Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: jihaAzN: see jahaAzN.
farasN jahiyzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or jahiyzu AlX-ad-i, (AO, TA,) A horse quick, or swift, in running: (AO, Ṣ:) or the former, a horse that is light, or active. (Ḳ.)
mawotN jahiyzN, and mujohizN↓, A quick death. (Ḳ.)
mawotN mujohizN: see what next precedes.
mujah-azN One for whom are prepared travellingprovisions and equipage, that he may perform the pilgrimage for another. (Mgh.)
mujah-izN One who sends forth traders with excellent goods: or who travels with such goods. (Mgh.) Hence, app., the vulgar term mujaAhizN↓, meaning A rich merchant. (Mgh.)
And mujah-izuwna Travelling-companions who assist one in the loading of the beasts. (Mṣb.)
mujaAhizN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. jahaXa Uilayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jahiXa, (Ḳ,) which latter, accord. to IDrd, is the more common, (TA,) aor. _a {yajohaXu}, inf. n. jahoXN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juhuwXN and jahaXaAnN, (Ḳ,) He betook himself to him by reason of fright or fear, seeking protection, and being about, or ready, to weep; like as the child betakes himself to his mother by reason of fright or fear, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to his father, (Aṣ,) being about, or ready, to weep; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) as also OajohaXa↓. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

jahaXato nafosuhu, (Ṣ, A,) or jahaXato Uilayohi nafosuhu, inf. n. juhuwXN; (TA;) and OajohaXato↓; (Ṣ, A, TA;) His soul heaved, (Ṣ, A,) and he was about, or ready, to weep: (A:) or his soul heaved, and quitted him. (TA.)
jahaXa lilX-awoqi waAlHuzoni He was ready, or about, to desire, and to mourn: (IDrd:) and OajohaXa↓ biAlbukaMCi He was ready, or about, to weep. (El-Umawee, Ḳ.)
jahaXa mina AlX-aIpCi, (AA, Ḳ,) and jahiXa, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajohaXu}, inf. n. jahaXaAnN, (AA, Ḳ,) He was frightened at the thing, or afraid of it: (AA, Ḳ:) or he fled from the thing.. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
jahaXuwA faziEiyna They came quickly to me, frightened. (A.)
yajohaXu mino OaroDK UilaI OaroDK He removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (Ḳ.)
jahaXa UilaI Alqawomi, inf. n. jahoXN, He came to the people, or company of men. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in three places.
AjhX fulaAnFA He hastened such a one. (Ibn-'Abbaád, Ḳ.)
jahoXapN A flow of tears (A, Ḳ, TA) falling one after another on the occasion of jahoX [or the betaking oneself to another by reason of fright or fear,, &c.]. (TA.)
A company of men; as also jaAhiXapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies a party, and a multitude, of men. (TA.)

entry.sense: juhuwXN Quick; who removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (Ḳ.)
jaAhXapN: see jahoXapN.
1: see 4, in two places.

3. jAhDhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jihaADN, (TA,) He endeavoured to prevent him, or to turn him away [from a thing]; and strove to be before him; syn. maAnaEahu and EaAjalahu. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Moḥammad Ibn-Meslemeh, relating his endeavouring to attack a man on the day of Ohod, fajaAhaDaniI Eanohu Oabuw sufoyaAna But Aboo-Sufyán endeavoured to turn me away from him (maAnaEaniI Eanohu), and put me away [from him]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. OajohaDaniI He overcame me in contending for the thing; as also jahaDaniI↓. (Ṣ.) You say, AjhDhu Eani AlOamori, He overcame him in contending for the thing, and made him to quit it, or put him away from it; as also jahaDahu↓ Eanohu, aor. _a {yajohaDu}. (A, Ḳ.) And qutila fulaAnN faOujohiDa Eanohu Alqawomu Such a one was slain, and the people were overcome so that he was taken from them. (Ṣ.) And SaAda AljaAriHapu AlS-ayoda faOajohaDonaAhu Eanohu The beast, or bird, of prey caught the game, and we removed him, and overcame him in contending for that which he had caught. (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb.)

AjhD is also syn. with OaEojala. (A, Ḳ.) Thus, sometimes, (Ṣ,) OajohaDotuhu Eano kacaA, (Ṣ,) or Eani AlOamori, (Mgh, TA,) signifies I hurried him so as to prevent him from doing such a thing, or the thing; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) and made him to quit it. (Mgh.)

You say also, AjhDhu Eano makaAnihi He roused him, or made him to rise, from his place. (A,* TA.) And [elliptically] OajohaDonaA AlEaduw-a We roused the enemy, or made them to rise, from their places; and removed them therefrom, or made them to quit them. (Mgh.)

AjhDt She (a camel, AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) cast her young one: (Ṣ, A:) or cast her young one with its fur grown, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) before it was perfect: (Aṣ:) or cast her young one before its form was apparent: (AZ:) or in an imperfect state: (TA:) or AjhDt waladahaA, inf. n. UijohaADN, she (a camel, and a woman,) cast her young one imperfect in form. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: jihoDN: see jahiyDN, in two places.
jihaADN [The act of a camel's, and of a woman's, casting an imperfect fœtus;] a subst. from AjhDt said of a camel and of a woman. (Mṣb.)

jahiyDN, applied to the young one, or fœtus, of a camel, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and of a woman, (Mṣb,) i. q. mujohaDN↓ [pass. part. n. of OajohaDato, q. v.]: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:*) or, (Ḳ,) as also jihoDN↓, on the authority of Fr, being, as he says, like xidojN, in the Ḳ, erroneously, jahiDN, (TA,) an abortion: or a young one perfectly formed, and into which the spirit has been inspired, without its living: (Ḳ:) or jihoDN↓ signifies the young one of a camel that is cast before its form is apparent. (TA.)
mujohaDN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mujohiDN, applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and to a woman, (Mṣb,) act. part. n. of OajohaDato [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also with majaAhiyDu: (Mṣb:) pl. mKjohaADN. (Ḳ.)
mijohaADN A she-camel that is accustomed to cast her young (Ṣ, A) in an imperfect state. (TA.)

1. jahila; (Ṣ;) and jahilahu, (Sh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jahila bihi (JK) [and minohu (see jaAhilN)]; aor. _a {yajohalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jaholN and jahaAlapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juhuwliy-ahN; (TA;) He was ignorant; (Ṣ;) he was characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word below: (TA:) and he was ignorant of it; he did not know it; (Sh, JK, Mṣb, Ḳ;) contr. of Ealimahu. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, mivoliI laA yajohalu mivolaka The like of me will not be ignorant of the like of thee. (Sh, TA.) And jahila EalaI gayorihi He acted in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner towards another: and wrongly. (Mṣb.) And jahila fulaAnN raOoyahu [i. q. safiha raOuyahu, He was ignorant, or silly, or foolish, in his opinion, or judgment]. (Sh, TA.) And jahila AlHaq-a He neglected the truth, or the right, or due; [or he ignored it;] syn. OaDaAEahu. (Mṣb.) See also 6.
jahilati Alqidoru ‡ The cooking-pot boiled vehemently; contr. of taHal-amat. (TA.)
2. jh-lhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajohiylN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He attributed to him jahol [or ignorance,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And He caused him to fall into jahol. (TA.)
3. mujaAhalapN The acting with levity, and in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner, with any one. (KL.) [You say, jAhlhu, meaning He so acted with him.]
6. tjAhl He feigned, or made a false show of, jahol [or ignorance,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And jahila↓ Ealayohi He feigned ignorance [to him]. (Ḳ.)
10. Astjhlhu He reckoned him, or esteemed him, jaAhil [or ignorant,, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.)
He, or it, excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Aisotjohalati Alr-iyHu AlguSona ‡ The wind put the branch into a state of commotion. (Ḳ, TA.)

jaholN an inf. n. of 1: Ignorance; contr. of EilomN: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:*) [and silliness, or foolishness: and wrong conduct: (see 1:)] it is of two kinds; namely, simple, which is the non-existence of knowledge of that which should be known; and compound, which is a decisive belief not agreeable with the fact, or reality: so accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of three kinds; namely, the mind's voidness of knowledge, which is the primary meaning; and the believing a thing to be different from what it is; and the doing a thing in a manner different from that in which it ought to be done: or, accord. to El-Harállee, the proceeding in dubious affairs without knowledge. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kafiI biAlX-ak-i juholFA [Doubt is sufficient ignorance]. (Mṣb.) And it is said in a trad., Uin-a mina AlEilomi jaholFA [Verily there is, among the kinds of knowledge, what is ignorance]: this is one's learning what is not requisite, and neglecting what is requisite; or a learned man's affecting, or pretending, a knowledge of that which he does not know. (TA.)
jahilaOCu: see AljaAhiliy-apu.
jahuwlN: see what next follows.

jaAhilN and jahuwlN↓, [but the latter has an intensive signification,] Ignorant: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and silly, or foolish, in conduct: and wrong in conduct: (Mṣb:) [characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word above:] pl. juh-aAlN (Ḳ, KL) and juholN and juhulN and juh-alN and juhalaMCu: (Ḳ:) see jaAhiliI-N. The former epithet is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes not in dispraise; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 274], yajosibuhumu AljaAhilu OagoniyaMCa i. e., The ignorant of their [real] state [would reckon them possessed of competence]. (TA.) huwa jaAhilN minohu means hw jAhl bihi, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., He is ignorant [of him, or it, or] of his, or its, state, or condition. (TA.)
AljaAhilu The lion (Ḳ, TA) that is ignorant of the prey. (TA.) [In the CK, waAljaAhilu AlAasadu is a mistake for waAljaAhilu AlOasadu.]

hom.sense: jayohalu: see jayohalapN.
Also Great as an epithet applied to a smooth rock (SafaApN). (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jayohalapN (IDrd, JK, Ḳ) and jayohalN↓ and mijohalN↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) and mijohalapN↓ (Ḳ) A piece of wood with which one stirs live, or burning, coals (jamor), (JK, Ḳ, TA,) or wine (xamor); (so in some copies of the Ḳ;) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

jaAhiliI-N [A pagan; a pagan Arab; one of those who are called collectively AljaAhily-apN↓; and sometimes muxaDuramuwn↓, pl. of XaAhidN: and particularly, a pagan poet;]
a poet of the first, or earliest, of the four classes which are ranked in chronological order; of the class which was succeeded next by the muxaDoramuwn. (Mz, 49th nwE.) [See also XaAhidN.]
AljaAhiliy-apN: see what next precedes.

[Also, or] AljaAhiliy-apu AljaholaMCu↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the latter word is a corroborative, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in layolapN layolaMCu, &c., (Ṣ,) [The time, or state, of ignorance, or paganism; or of intense ignorance;] the time of the fatorap [or cessation of the mission of apostles, and of the effacement of the signs of their religion]. (JK.) One says, kaAna celika fiI AljaAhiliy-api AljaholaMCi [That was in the time, or state, of paganism, or of intense ignorance]. (Ṣ.)

majohalN An affair, or an event, or a case, and a land, and a habit, a property, a quality, a practice, or an action, that induces a man to believe a thing to be different from what it is. (Er-Rághib, TA.) A desert (mafaAzapN) in which are no signs of the way. (Ṣ.) And OaroDN majohalN A land in which are no signs of the way: (TA:) or in which one will not go aright (Ḳ, TA) unless by means of the [signs of the way called] MraAm: (TA:) pl. majaAhilu, which is the contr. of maEaAlimu: (TA:) accord. to the Ḳ, it has neither dual nor pl.; but it has both, as ʼIyáḍ and others have affirmed. (MF, TA.)
mijohalN: see jayohalapN.

majohalapN [A cause of, or an incitement to, ignorant, silly, foolish, or wrong, conduct;] a thing that incites one to Aljahol. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu majohalapN [Children are a cause of silly, or foolish, conduct]. (Ṣ.)
mijohalapN: see jayohalapN.
mijohaAlN ‡ A she-camel light, brisk, or agile, in her pace, or going. (TA.)
majohuwlN [Unknown]. You say, rakibotu AlmafaAzapN EalaI majohuwlihaA [I ventured upon traversing the desert notwithstanding its unknown character]. (Ṣ, TA.)
[A man of unknown origin. A book of unknown authorship.]
[In grammar, The passive voice.]
naAqapN majohuwlapN ‡ A she-camel that has never been milked: or that has no brand upon her: (Ḳ, TA:) and ‡ a she-camel that has never conceived. (Z, TA.)
musotajohilN Making himself like the jaAhil [or ignorant; feigning himself ignorant]: or reckoning, or esteeming, jaAhil. (Ḥar p. 572.)

hom.sense: 1. jahuma, aor. _u {yajohumu}, inf. n. juhuwmapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jahaAmapN, (Ḳ,) He (a man) became frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (Ṣ:) or he was, or became, coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, in face. (Ḳ.)
Also, said of the pubes, It was coarse, rough, or big. (TA.)

jahamahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jahimahu, aor. _a {yajohamu}, in both instances; (Ḳ;) and tjh-mhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tjh-m↓ lahu; (JK, Ḳ;) He grinned, frowning, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely, in his face: (Ṣ:) or he met him, or regarded him, with a displeasing, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) frowning, or grinning and frowning, (TA,) face: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) or tjh-m↓ signifies he showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face. (TḲ in art. Ebs.) A poet says,
wabalodapK tajah-amu↓ AljahuwmaA↓
zajarotu fiyhaA EayohalFA rasuwmaA , (Ṣ,* TA,) i. e. [Many a region] that exhibits to the impotent that which he dislikes, [or that frowns upon the weak, or impotent, I have chidden therein a strong she-camel that leaves the marks of her footsteps upon the ground.] (Ṣ.) You say also, Ald-ahoru yatajah-amu↓ AlkiraAma ‡ [Fortune frowns upon the generous]. (TA.) And tajah-amaniI↓ OamaliI ‡ [My object of hope frowned upon me] is said when one has not attained his object of hope. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Oajohamati Als-amaMCu The sky had clouds such as are termed jahaAm. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1, in six places.
8. Ajthm He entered upon, (Ḳ,) or journeyed in, (A, TA,) the portion of the night termed juhomap. (A, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: jahomN A coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, face; as also jahimN↓; (Ḳ;) or, as in some of the lexicons, jahiymN↓. (TA.) And jahomu Alwajohi Frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or coarse, or rough, in face: (JK, TA:) applied to a man: (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, TA:) and to a lion. (JK, TA.) And [hence,] Aljahomu The lion. (Ḳ.)
See also jahuwmN.

entry.sense: jahimN: see jahomN.

hom.sense: jahomapN: see juhomapN, in two places.
Also A big cooking-pot. (Ḳ.)

juhomapN and jahomapN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) both mentioned by Fr, (Ṣ,) A portion of the night: (JK:) the first of the last portions of the night, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) extending [app. from midnight] to near the period a little before daybreak: (TA:) or the remaining portion of the darkness of the last part of the night: (Ḳ:) or the former signifies, [or each,] the beginning of the night, extending to a fourth part: or, as some say, the middle of the night: (KL:) pl. of the former juhamN. (JK.) You say, maDaI mina All-ayoli juhomapN and jahomapN↓ [app. meaning A portion, or a portion at the commencement of the latter part, of the night passed]. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
Also the former, Eighty camels: or the like. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jahaAmN Clouds in which is no water: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that have poured forth their water (Ḳ, TA) with the wind. (TA.)
juhuwmN, applied to a man, (JK, Ṣ,) Impotent; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) weak; as also jahomN↓. (Ḳ.) See an ex. in the first paragraph.
jahiymN: see jahomN.
See also jihin-aAmN.
[jahan-amiI-N Of, or relating to, jahan-am, i. e. Hell, or Hell-fire.]

jihin-aAmN (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḥam p. 817) and [jahin-aAmN and juhin-aAmN], with each of the three vowels (Ḳ, TA) to the j (TA,) [but accord. to the Ḳ it would rather seem to be jahan-aAmN and juhun-aAmN,] and jahan-amN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a well (rakiy-apN, Ṣ, Ḳ, or biYorN, Ḥam), Deep; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḥam;) in which he who falls into it perishes. (Ḥam.)

jaw-N The air: (Ḳ:) or [the atmosphere; i. e.] what is between the heaven, or sky, and the earth; (Ṣ, Mgh;) the air [or the region] between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: pl. OajowaMCN. (TA.) fiI jaw-i Als-amaMCi, in the Ḳur [xvi. 81], means In the air between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: (Jel:) or in the middle of the sky: (Ḳatádeh, TA:) or in the air that is remote from the earth. (Bḍ.)

A low, or depressed, part of the ground; (M, Ḳ;) as also jaw-apN↓: (Ḳ:) or a wide part of a valley: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. (in the latter sense, Mṣb, or in the former, Ḳ, TA) jiwaMCN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajowiyapN. (TA.) It has the latter meaning in the saying of Tarafeh, [addressing a lark,]
xalaA laki Aljaw-u fabiyDiI waQSofiriI
[The wide part of the valley has become vacant for thee; so lay thine eggs, and whistle]. (AA, Ṣ.) Az says, I entered, with an Arab of the desert, a [hollow place in which water collected, termed a] daHol, in El-Khalsà, and when we came to the water, he said, hecaA jaw-N mina AlmaACi laA yuwqafu EalaI OaqoSaAhu [This is an abyss of water: one knows not the utmost extent of it]. (TA.)
A vacant, void, or desolate, place, in which is no one to cheer by his company. (Ḥam p. 293.)

The inside, or interior, of a house or tent; (Ḳ;) and of anything; of the dial. of Syria; also termed jaw-apN↓, (TA,) and jaw-aAniI-N↓; (Ḳ; [in the CK A is erroneously put for n;]) in which last, the A and Ouriydu jaw-FA wayuriydu bar-FA are augmentatives for the purpose of corroboration. (TA.)
[Hence,] jaw-apN I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A in art. br.)
jaw-apN: see jaw-N, in two places.

jaw-aAniI-N: see jaw-N. Hence the saying of Selmán, mano OaSolaHa jaw-aAniy-ahu OaSolaHa Qll-ehu bar-aAniy-ahu [explained in art. br]. (TA.) [It generally signifies Inner, inward, or interior; and secret, or private; opposed to bar-aAniI-N; and is now vulgarly pronounced juw-aAniIo.] It is a rel. n. [irregularly formed] from jaw-N signifying “any low, or depressed, part of the ground.” (T in art. br.)

1. yajuwoCu is a dial. var. of yajiIoCu [aor. of jaMCa and meaning He comes, or will come]: (Ḳ:) mentioned by Sb, who gives as an ex. OanaA OajuwoWuka waOanobuWuka [for AnA OajiyoWuka wOanobaWuka, I will come to thee and inform thee]. (TA.)
juwaAliqN and juwaAlaqN and jiwaAliqN: see art. jlq.

hom.sense: 1. jaAbahu, (Ṣ,* TA,) aor. yajuwbu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jawobN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) and tajowaAbN, (Ḥar p. 336,) He made a hole in it; or rent, or tore, it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) as also AjtAbhu↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) he made a hole through, or in, or into, it; perforated, pierced, or bored, it: (TA:) he cut it: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) he cut it in like manner as one cuts a jayob [or an opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt, &c.]: (L, TA:) he made, or cut, a hole in the middle of it; cut a piece out of the middle of it; hollowed it out; or excavated it. (TA.) You say, jAb AlS-axorapa He made a hole in the rock; (A, TA;) perforated, pierced, or bored, it. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [lxxxix. 8], wavamuwda Al-aciyna jaAbuwA AlS-axora biAlwaAdi (Fr, Ṣ, TA) And Thamood, who made holes in the rocks, (Fr, TA,) or cut the rocks, (Bḍ, Jel,) [or hollowed them out,] and made them dwellings, in the valley, (Fr, Bḍ, Jel, TA,) i. e., in Wádi-l-Kurà. (Bḍ, Jel.) You say also, jAb AlqamiySa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. bajuwbu, [inf. n. jawobN;] (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Mṣb in art. jyb;) and aor. yajiybu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [inf. n., app., jiybN, originally jawobN; see a verse cited below, and a remark of Sh thereon;] and jw-bhu↓; (A, Ḳ;) He hollowed out, or cut out in a round form, the jayob of the shirt: (Ṣ, and Mṣb in art. jyb:) or he cut the jayob of the shirt: (A:) or he made a jayob to the shirt; (Ḳ;) as also jay-abahu, (Ṣ, and Mṣb in art. jyb,) inf. n. tajoyiybN. (Ṣ.) And jAb Alv-awoba He cut the garment, or piece of cloth; [or cut it out;] as also AjtAbhu↓. (A.) And jAb Aln-aEola, inf. n. jawobN, He cut out the sandal. (TA.) And jAb Alqaronu [i. e. jAb All-aHoma] The horn cut the flesh and came forth. (TA.)

[Hence, also,] jAb, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) aor. yajuwbu (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and yajiybu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jawobN; (TA;) and AjtAb↓; (Ṣ, A, TA;) ‡ He traversed, or crossed, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, TA,) or cut through by journeying, (TA,) a country, (Ṣ, TA,) or a land, (Mṣb,) and a desert, and the darkness: (A,* TA:) and jawobN signifies likewise the pouncing down of a bird. (TA.) A rájiz says,
baAtato tajiybu OadoEaja AlZ-alaAmi
jiyba AlbiyaTori midoraEa AlhumaAmi
† [She passed the night cutting through the black darkness, like as the tailor cuts through the woollen tunic of the valiant chief, making the opening at the neck and bosom]: (Ṣ: [but in one copy, instead of jiyba, I here find jayoba; and in art. bTr, Xaq-a:]) and Sh remarks that this [verb tjyb, or the inf. n. jyb,] is not from Aljayobu [meaning “the opening at the neck and bosom” of a shirt, &c.], because its medial radical is w, and that of Aljyb is I: (TA:) [i. e., jAb, aor. yjyb, is originally jawaba, aor. yajowibu.] One says also, of news, yajuwbu AlOaroDa mino baladK UilaI baladK † [It traverses the earth from country to country, or the land from town to town]. (Ṣ, TA.) And of proverbs, tajuwbu AlbilaAda † They are current in the countries, or towns. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., jiybati AlEarabu Ean-aA kamaA jiybati Alr-aHaA Eano quTobihaA † The Arabs were rent from us, like as the mill-stone is rent from its pivot; we being in the midst, and they around us. (TA.)
jaAbati Ald-aEowapu: see Oajowabu.
2. jw-b: see 1.
Also, said of the light of the moon, † It illumined, and rendered clear, [by penetrating,] a dark night. (TA.)
jw-b Ealayohi [from jawobN “a shield”] He shielded him. (TA: so accord. to an explanation of the act. part. n.)

entry.sense: 3. [jAwbhu, inf. n. mujaAwabapN, He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, with him; bandied words with him.] See 6, in two places.

hom.sense: 4. AjAbhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. UijaAbapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) and UijaAbN (Ḳ,* TA) and jaAbapN↓, (Kr, TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (AHeyth, Ṣ, TA,) like TaAEapN and TaAqapN, (Ṣ, A,) used in the place of an inf. n.; (AHeyth, TA;) and AstjAbhu↓ (A, Ḳ, TA) and Aisotajuwabahu↓ and AistjAb↓ lahu; (Ḳ, TA;) [for] UijaAbapN and AisotijaAbapN↓ are syn.; (Ṣ, TA;) He answered him, replied to him, responded to him, (Mṣb, TA,) either affirmatively or negatively. (Mṣb.) And AjAb qawolahu He answered, or replied to, his saying. (Mṣb.) And AjAb Eano suWaAlihi (Ṣ, TA) He answered, or replied to, his question. (TA.) And AjAb duEaMCahu, (Mṣb, TA,*) and AstjAb↓ duEaMCahu, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and AstjAb↓ lahu, (Mṣb,) and AstjAb↓ minohu, (Ḥar p. 307,) said of God, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) [He answered his prayer;;] He accepted his prayer; (Mṣb;) He recompensed his prayer by gift and acceptance. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 182], Oujiybu daEowpa Ald-aAEiI UicaA daEaAni faloyasotajiybuwA↓ liI [I answer the prayer of him who prayeth to me;] therefore let them answer me; (TA;) i. e., let them answer my call by obedience, (Jel,) when I call them to belief and obedience: (Bḍ:) accord. to Fr, what is here meant [by the last verb] is talobiyap [q. v. in art. lbI]: (TA:) [or let them give me their assent, or consent, to my call; or let them obey my call: for you say, AjAbhu UilaI XaIoCK and EalaI XaIoCK, (for the latter of which there is authority in this art. in the TA, but the former is more common,) and] AstjAb↓ lh, He obeyed him, or complied with his desire, in doing a thing, [or consented to do it,] when summoned, or invited, to do it. (Mṣb.)
AjAbt AlOaroDu † The land produced plants, or herbage. (Ḥam p. 94.)
damoEN yujiybu † Tears running, or flowing; as though called for and answering the call. (Ḥar p. 71.)

The forms Oajowaba and Oajowibo [as verbs of wonder] are not used: therefore you say, maA Oajowada jawaAbahu and Oajowido bijawaAbihi [How good is his answer, or reply!]; not maA Oajowabahu nor Oajowibo bihi: nor do you say, huwa Oajowabu minoka [meaning He is better in answering, or replying, than thou: but see Oajowabu, below]. (Sb, TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAwbwA i. q. jaAwaba↓ baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; they answered one another; replied, one to another; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, together; bandied words, one with another]: (Ḳ:) mujaAwabapN↓ and tajaAwubN both signify i. q. taHaAwurN. (Ṣ, TA.) In like manner one says of turtle-doves, (A,) of pigeons, of braying camels, and of neighing horses. (TA.)
[Hence,] yatajaAwabu Oaw-alu kalaAmihi waMxiruhu ‡ The first and the last parts of his speech correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 7. AnjAb [It (a garment) became rent, or slit: see munojaAbN].

Said of a cloud, or a collection of clouds, It cleared away [so as to leave an open space]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., waQnojaAba Als-aHaAbu Eani Almadiynapi Hat-aI SaArakaAlUi koliyli And the clouds became gathered and drawn together, and cleared away from the city [so that they became like a crown]. (TA.)
[It (a place) was, or became, clear, open, or unobstructed.] See jawobapN

AnjAbt She (a camel) stretched forth her neck, to be milked; (Ḳ;) as though she complied with the desire of her milker to be restrained [for that purpose]: but Fr says that he had not found a verb of this measure from OajaAba. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AjtAb: see 1, in three places.
He dug a well. (Ḳ.) And AjtAbt, said of a wild cow, She hollowed out, or excavated, a place to shelter herself from the rain. (TA.)
He put on, i. e. clad himself with, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a garment, (T,) or a shirt; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he entered into a shirt: and in like manner, † the darkness. (TA.)
10. AstjAb and Aisotajowaba, inf. n. AisotijaAbapN: see 4, nine places.
jaAbN: see jaOubN, in art. jOb

hom.sense: jawobN [an inf. n. (of 1, q. v.,) used in the sense of a pass. part. n. Hence,] a tribe is said to be jawobu OabK as meaning Cut [as it were] from one father; [sprung from the loins of one father;] occurring in a trad. (TA.)
A fire-place; [so called because hollowed out;] syn. kaAnuwnN. (Ḳ.)
A large dalow [or bucket; because of its hollow form]. (Kr, Ḳ.)
A shield; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jawobapN↓ (TA) and mijowabN↓: (Ḳ:) [see a verse cited voce yalabN:] pl. of the first OajowaAbN. (TA.)
A garment like the baqiyrap: [so called because it has a slit in the middle, through which the head is put:] (Ṣ:) or a woman's shift. (Ḳ.)

[A kind, or sort.] You say, fulaAnN fiyhi jawobaAni mino xuluqK [In such a one are two kinds of temper, or disposition]; i. e., he does not remain in one temper, or disposition. (TA.) And Dhu-Rummeh says,
jawobayoni mino hamaAhimi AlOagowaAli
meaning Thou hearest two kinds of the sounds, or voices, [or mutterings,] of the ghools. (TA.)

entry.sense: jayobN meaning The [part called] Tawoq of a shirt, (see art. jyb,) is, accord. to some, from the root jwb, because the middle of it is cut out: accord. to others, from the root jyb. (TA.)

hom.sense: jaAbapN is an inf. n. of OajaAba, (Kr, TA,) or a simple subst. (AHeyth, Ṣ, TA) used in the place of an inf. n. (AHeyth, TA. See 4.) Hence, OasaMCa samoEFA faOasaMCa jaAbapF [He heard ill, and therefore answered ill]: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) a prov., and therefore not to be rehearsed otherwise than in the original way, as above: [not to be altered by the substitution of UijaAbapN or UijaAbFA for jaAbapF:] its origin is said to have been this: Sahl [or Suheyl] Ibn-ʼAmr had an insane son; and a man said to him, Oayona Oam-uka, i. e. “Whither is thy tending?” to which he (thinking that he said, Oayona Oum-uka [“Where is thy mother!”],) answered, “She is gone to buy flour:” whereupon his father uttered the words of this prov. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 603.]) See also jawaAbN

jaAbapu AlmidoraI is a dial. var. of jaOobapu AlmdrI: (Ḳ: [see art. jOb:]) accord. to AO and Sh, it is without C: accord. to the former, it means A doe-gazelle when her horn has come forth; and accord. to the latter, when her horn has cut the skin and come forth: (T, TA:) or it means having smooth horns; and if so, it has no [known] derivation. (TA.) [See also art. drI.]

entry.sense: jawobapN A depressed place amid the houses of a people, into which the rain-water flows: (TA:) a pit, an excavation, or a hollow, (T, Ḳ, TA,) round and wide: (T, TA:) a gap, or an opening, in the clouds; and in mountains: and a clear space (mawoDiEN yanojaAbu↓) in a [stony tract such as is called] Har-ap: (Ṣ:) a place (AḤn, Ḳ) that is clear, (AḤn,) plain and smooth, (AḤn, Ḳ,) such as is termed daArapN, with few trees, like a round gaAYT [or wide and depressed tract], (AḤn,) in a tract that is hard, or hard and level, or level but rough, (AḤn, Ḳ,) and such as is of large extent, not in sands nor in a mountain; so called because [for the most part] clear of trees: (AḤn:) and an intervening space between houses; (Ḳ;) as also jawobN↓: (TA:) and a wide, or spacious, and smooth tract, between two lands: (Ḳ:) any wide gap, or opening: any gap, or opening, without buildings: (TA:) pl. juwabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jawobaAtN (TA.)
The former of these pls. also signifies The pudenda of women; syn. furuwjN. (TA.)

jiybapN i. q. jawaAbN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the phrase, Uin-ahu laHasanu Aljiyabpi [Verily he is good in respect of answer or reply or response: or here it seems rather to signify, agreeably with analogy, the mode, or manner, of answering or replying or responding]. (Ṣ.)

jawaAbN An answer, a reply, or a response, (Mṣb, TA,*) to a letter, or writing, and to a saying, or question; and this is either affirmative or negative: (Mṣb:) [accord. to some, it is only after a question or demand; but this is not correct; for it is often a reply to an affirmation:] jiybapN↓ [q. v.] is syn. therewith; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so are jaAbapN↓ [q. v.] and majuwbapN↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. of jwAb is OajowibapN and jawaAbaAtN (Mṣb.) [Hence, in grammar, Harofu jawaAbK A responsive, or replicative, particle. And jawaAbu XaroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; as Oakoramotuka in the saying, Uino jiYotaniI Oakoramotuka; also called jazaMCu XaroTK, and jawaAbu jazaMCK. And jawaAbu qasamK The complement of an oath.]
Also The sound of a bird pouncing down from the sky. (TA from a trad.)
jaw-aAbN [An excellent well-digger:] a surname given to Málik Ibn-Kaab El-Kilábee, (AO, ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) because he dug not a well nor bored a rock without making it to yield water. (AO, ISk, Ṣ.)

† A traverser of countries; one who travels much. (TA.) Hence, jaw-aAbu layolK saromadK † One who travels all the night without sleeping. (TA.) And jaw-aAbN jaO-bN † One who traverses the countries and gains wealth. (TA.) And jaw-aAbu AlfalaApi † The guide of the desert. (TA.)
AljaAYibu AlEayoni The lion. (Ḳ.)

jaAYibapu xabarK ‡ News that traverses the earth, from country to country, or town to town: (Ṣ, A:*) or i. q. Tariyqap xaAriqap [app. a mistranscription for Tiriyfap xArqp, meaning recent news that traverses the land]. (Ḳ.) And [the pl.] jawaAYibu † Tidings from afar. (Ḳ.) And jawaAYibu AlOamovaAli † Current proverbs; such as traverse the countries. (TA.)

Oajowabu, [see 4,] in the following question, put to Moḥammad, (TA,) OaI-u All-ayoli Oajowabu daEowapF is either from jubotu AlOaroDa (Ḳ, TA) “I traversed the land,” (TA,) and signifies ‡ More, or most, penetrating to the places whence the answer is imagined to proceed; (Ḳ, TA;) or [it signifies more, or most, quick in being answered,] from jaAbati↓ Ald-aEowapu, of the measure faEulat, [i. e., originally jawubat,] “the prayer became answered,” which, however, is a verb not in use, like as faqiyrN and XadiydN are imagined to be derived from faqura and Xaduda: (Z, TA:) or it signifies more, or most, quick of answer, [from OajaAba,] and is [anomalous, and] similar to OaTowaEu [“more obedient”], from AlT-aAEapu, [i. e. from OaTaAEa “he obeyed,”] (M, L, TA,) and to OaEoTaI [“more, or most, excellent in giving,” from OaEoTaI “he gave”], and lawaAqiHa [pl. of laAqiHapN a “fecundating” wind, (in the Ḳur xv. 22,) from OaloqaHa “he, or it, fecundated”], (M, L, Ḳ, TA,) and the like; (M, L, TA;) and if so, the word is anomalous because a word of the measure OafoEalu of this kind is not derived from a verb of more than three letters, except in certain cases of deviation from the constant course of speech: (L, TA:) the meaning is, ‡ What part of the night is that [in which prayer most quickly penetrates? or] in which prayer is most quick in being answered? (Mgh:) or what part of the night is that in which God is most quick in answering prayer? (L, TA.)
majuwbu [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.:] Anything cut in the middle, or of which the middle is cut out; as also mujaw-abN↓; (T, TA;) and the latter, anything hollowed out in the middle. (TA.)
mijowabN An iron instrument with which one cuts [or perforates or hollows out]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Almujiybu one of the names of God; The Answerer of prayer; He who recompenses prayer and petition by gift and acceptance. (TA.)
majuwbapN: see jawaAbN
mujaw-abN: see majuwbN
[Hence,] OaroDN mujaw-abapN † A land of which one part has been rained upon (Ḳ, TA) and not another. (TA.)
mijowaAbN An instrument with which palm-sticks and canes, &c. are bored by the maker of cages or crates or the like. (TA in art. vTb.)
mutajaAwibN ‡ Speech, or language, of which the several parts correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)
munojaAbN A garment rent, or slit. (Ḥam p. 338.)

hom.sense:
1. jaAHa, (Ṣ, A,) aor. yajuwHu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jawoHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ) extirpated, or exterminated, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a thing: (Ṣ:) He (God, Ṣ) destroyed (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) a man's property, or cattle, (Ṣ,) by what is termed jaAYiHap: (Ṣ, A:) as also AjAH↓, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. UijaAHapN; (Ḳ;) and AjtAH↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. AijotiyaAHN. (Ḳ.) You say [also], jaAHiti AlMfapu AlmaAla, i. e. AljaAYiHapu, aor. tajuwHuhu, inf. n. as above; and AjAHthu↓; and AjtAHthu↓; The bane, or pest, or the like, destroyed the property, or cattle; as also jaAHatohu, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN: (Mṣb:) and one says of anything, such as drought, or dearth, and civil war, or conflict and faction, &c., jAH AlmaAla and AjtAHhu↓, meaning it extirpated, or exterminated, the property, or cattle. (TA.) And jaAHatohumu AljaAYiHapu, (Ṣ,) or Als-anapu, inf. n. jawoHN and jiyaAHN; and OajaAHatohumo↓; (TA;) and AijotaAHatohumo↓; (Ṣ, A, TA;) i. e. [The calamity, bane, pest, or the like, or drought, or dearth, destroyed or] extirpated [them, or] their property, or cattle. (TA.)
And AjtAH↓ AlEaduw-u maAlahu The enemy destroyed, or made an end of, his property, or cattle; syn. OataI Ealayohi. (TA.)
Also jAH, aor. yajuwHu, inf. n. jawoHN, He destroyed the property, or cattle, of his relations. (IAạr, TA.)
And, aor. yajuwHu, He deviated from the road, or beaten track. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in three places.
8: see 1, in five places.
jawoHapN: see jaAYiHapN.
jaAYiHN [act. part. n. of 1]. You say MfapN jaAYiHapN A destructive bane or pest or the like: (Mṣb:) and sanapN jaAYiHapN a year of drought or dearth or sterility: (Mgh:) pl. jawaAYiHu. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
[And hence,] The locust. (IAạr, T in art. jHI.)

jaAYiHapN [fem. of jaAYiHN, q. v.: and hence, as a subst.,] A bane, a pest, (Mṣb,) a calamity, or the like, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a great calamity, (Mgh, TA,) that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) as drought, or dearth; or civil war, or conflict and faction, and the like: (Ṣ, TA:) drought, or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; as also jawoHapN↓: (Wásil, TA:) or a calamity that befalls a man, and destroys all his property, or cattle: (AʼObeyd, T:) or severe drought or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle: (ISh:) sometimes it is the effect of large hail; and sometimes, of excessive cold or heat: (T:) or (accord. to Esh-Sháfiʼee, Mgh, Mṣb) a blast, or blight, or calamity arising from the atmosphere, that destroys the fruits, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or some thereof; (Mgh;) only relating to fruits: (TA:) pl. jawaAYiHu. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., Oamara biwaDoEi AljawaAYiHi, which is an elliptical phrase, meaning He commanded to remit the poor-rate in respect of things affected by a blast, or blight, (Mgh, Mṣb,) namely, property, (Mgh,) or fruits, (Mṣb,) so affected; (Mgh, Mṣb;) i. e., that no portion thereof, (Mgh,) or of the remains thereof, (Mṣb,) should be taken for the poor-rate. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
mujaAHN: see what next follows.
majuwHN Property, or cattle, destroyed by a bane, or pest, or the like; as also majiyHN [belonging to art. jyH], and mujaAHN↓. (Mṣb.)
mijowaHN [A person or thing] that destroys, or extirpates, everything. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. jaAda, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. juwdapN and jawodapN, It (a thing, Ṣ, or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, Mṣb, and a work, or performance, TA) was, or became, jay-id [i. e. good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; the verb being the contr. of raduWa, as is implied in the A and Ḳ]: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) in this sense, accord. to some, of the class of qaAla; accord. to others, of the class of qaruba. (Mṣb.) [Also said of a man, meaning He was, or became, excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.]

And jAd, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the class of qAl, (Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. juwdN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He was liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (Ḳ:) or he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous: (Mṣb:) or he gave without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than OaHosana. (MF.) You say, jAd bimaAlihi [He was liberal,, &c., with his property]: (Ṣ:) or jAd biAlmaAli he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous with the property. (Mṣb.)

Hence, (Mṣb,) jAd binafosihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. jawodN (TA) and juWuwdN, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ He gave up his spirit, (A, Mṣb, TA,) at death; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) like as one gives away his property; said of one in the agony of death: (TA:) and ‡ he gave away his life, in war. (Mṣb.) And you say also, jaAdato nafosuhu † [His soul, or spirit, resigned itself, or departed]. (Mṣb in art. nfs.)

jAd AlmaTaru, inf. n. jawodN, The rain was, or became, copious, or abundant. (Ṣ.) And jaAdati Als-amaMCu, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. jawodN, with fet-ḥ, The sky rained. (Mṣb.) And jaAdati AlEayonu, inf. n. jawodN and juWuwdN, The eye shed many, or abundant, tears. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

jAd said of a horse, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ,) inf. n. juwdapN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jawodapN; (Mṣb, and some copies of the Ḳ;) and jwd↓, (A, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajowiydN; (TA;) and AjAd↓, (L,) and Oajowada↓; (L, Ḳ;) He became fleet, or swift, and excellent, (L,) SaAra raAYiEFA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) fiI Eadowihi in his running. (A, L, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAma, in art. dwm.]
See also 4, in two places.
jAd Uilayohi He inclined to him, or it. (TA.)
jAdhu He overcame him in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (Ḳ.) See 3.

jaAdahumo, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. jawodN, It (rain) rained, or descended, upon them copiously, or abundantly. (L.) And jiyduwA They were rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (L.) And jiydati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. jawodN; (Aṣ, TA;) and Oujiydat↓; (Ḳ;) The earth, or land, was rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, so that the moisture of the rain met that of the soil. (Aṣ, TA.)

jiyda, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yujaAdu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. juwaAdN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) † He (a man, Ṣ, A) thirsted, or became affected by thirst: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or thirsted vehemently: (accord. to an explanation of juwaAdN in the Ḳ:) or was at the point of death, or destruction; (Ḳ;) as though destruction rained upon him. (TA.)

[Hence,] Uin-iI OujaAdu UilaIliqaAYika ‡ Verily I am affected with a longing desire to meet thee: (A:) or Uin-iI laOujaAdu Uilayoka (Ḳ, TA [in the CK, erroneously, laAajAdu]) ‡ Verily I am affected with a longing desire for thee, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., to meet thee, (TA,) and am impelled towards thee: (Ḳ:) and yujaAduUilaI fulaAnapa ‡ He is affected with longing desire for such a female; like as you say yaZomaOu. (A.) One says also, jAdhu AlahawI ‡ Love affected him with longing desire, (XaAqahu, L, Ḳ, in the CK XAq-ahu,) and overcame him. (Ḳ.)

[Also, app., jyda, aor. yujaAdu, inf. n. juwaAdN, (as in a sense explained above,) † He became affected, or overcome, or distressed, (see majuwdN,) by drowsiness, or slumber: for] juwaAdN is syn. with nuEaAsN: (L, TA:) and you say, jAdhu Aln-uEaAsu † Drowsiness, or slumber, overcame him; (L;) as though sleep rained upon him. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4:
and see also 1.

3. jAwdhu He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, jAwdhu fajaAdahu↓ He vied with him, or contended, &c., in liberality,, &c., and overcame him therein. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AjAdhu He made it good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;) as also Oajowadahu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) like as they said ATAl and ATwl, and AHAl and AHwl, and ATAb and ATyb, and AlAn and Alyn; (Ṣ;) and jw-dhu↓, (Ṣ,* A,) inf. n. tajowiydN. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] AjAdhu Aln-aqoda He gave him the cash, or ready money, good. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Oajadotuka vawobFA I gave thee a garment, or piece of cloth, that was good, goodly, or excellent; or in a good state. (A, TA.)
He gave him a dirhem, or piece of silver. (Ḳ.)
Oujiydati AlOaroDu: see 1.
He, or it, slew him, or killed him. (L.)

AjAd, (inf. n. UijaAdapN, Mṣb,) He said, gave utterance to, uttered, or expressed, what was good, approvable, or excellent; he said, or did, well, or excellently; OataI biAljay-idi (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) mino qawoli Oawo fiEolK; (Mṣb;) as also Oajowada; (L;) and jAd↓, inf. n. jawodapN. (L.) [You say, qaAla faOajaAda He said, and said well: and faEala faOajaAda He did, and did well.] And AjAd fiI Eamalihi, and Ajwd, He did well, or excellently, in his work. (L.)
Said of a horse, and Ajwd likewise: see 1.
Also He had with him a horse such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: (Ṣ:) or he became possessed of such a horse; (A, Ḳ;) as also Ajwd. (Ḳ.)

OajaAdato She brought forth a child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition. (A.) And AjAd biAlwaladi He begot the child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition; (Ḳ;) and in like manner, jAd↓ bihi OabawaAhu [His two parents so engendered him]. (TA.)

5. tjw-d He chose what was good, goodly, approvable, or excellent, among all things. (Ḥam p. 299.) He affected nicety, or refinement; he was, or became, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best, to be done; and exceeded the usual bounds; fiI SanoEatihi in his work of art, or his manufacture; syn. tanaw-aqa. (A, TA.) And tjw-d wabaAlaga fiI maToEamihi wamalobasihi [He was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best; and exceeded the usual bounds; in his food and his apparel]; (JK and Ḳ in art. nwq;)
he was studious of his diet and apparel, always eating exquisite food and wearing sumptuous clothing. (TḲ in that art.)
tjw-dhu: see 10. tajaw-adotuhaA laka I chose, or selected, the best, or most excellent, (AlOajowada↓,) thereof for thee. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tjAwdwA They considered [or tried] which of them had the best argument, or plea, or allegation: (Ḳ, TA:) so says Aboo-Saʼeed on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.) And yatajaAwaduwna AlHadiyva They consider, or see, [or try,] which of them will be best in narration, or talk, or discourse. (A.)
[Also They vied, or contended together for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity.]

hom.sense: 10. AstjAdhu He reckoned it, or esteemed it, good, goodly, approvable, or excellent: (Ṣ:) or he found it to be so: (Ḳ:) or he desired, or sought, that it might be so, (A, Ḳ,) and chose it, or selected it; (A;) as also tjw-dhu↓. (A.) You say also, Aisotajowada raOoyahu [He esteemed his judgment, or opinion, good: or found it to be so]. (TA in art. jzl.)
He desired, or sought, or demanded, his liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (Ḳ.)
He desired, or sought, that he (a horse) might be such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]. (Ḳ.)
AstjAd It came or happened, well. (KL.)

entry.sense:
jawodN Copious, or abundant, rain; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also jaAYidN↓: (Ṣ:) or rain that thoroughly irrigates everything: (M:) or rain that is not exceeded: (M, L, Ḳ:) accord. to some, who observe that the phrase, mentioned by Sb, OaxacotanaA biAljawodiwafawoqhaA [Thou hast assailed us with a storm of reproach or the like not to be exceeded, and with that which is above it,] is one of hyperbole and reproach. (M, L.) It is an inf. n. thus used as an epithet [and therefore applicable without variation to a fem. as to a masc. n., and to a dual and a pl. as to a sing. n.]: (L:) and is also pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAYidN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN. (Ṣ, L.) You say maTarN jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain;, &c.]: (L:) and saHaAbapN jawodN [A cloud yielding a copious, or an abundant, rain;, &c.]: (IAạr, L:) and haAjato lanaA samaMCN jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain,, &c., became stirred up for us]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and you also say, [contr. to the usage mentioned above, or as though jawodN were an epithet from jaAda, and this originally jawoda, like DaxomN from Daxuma, but used as a subst.,] maTorataAni jawodaAni [Two showers of rain, copious, or abundant,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) tajaAwiydu↓, [app. signifying the same as jawodN used as a pl.,] occurring in the following verse of Sakhr El-Ghei,
yulaAEibu Alr-iyHa biAlEaSorayoni qaSoTaluhu
waAlwaAbiluwna watahotaAnu Alt-ajaAwiydi
[Its dust makes sport with the wind in the morning and evening, or night and day, and so do the violent showers of big drops, and the pouring of copious, or abundant, rains,, &c.], (L, Ḳ,*) is a pl. having no sing.; (Ḳ;) or it may be so, like taEaAjiybu and taEaAXiybu and tabaAXiyru; or it may be pl. of tajowaAdN [an inf. n.]. (L.) You say also, OaSaAbatohu tajaAwiydu↓ AmaTari [Copious showers of rain fell upon him, or it]. (A.)
See also jawaAdN.
jawodapN [an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in two senses; as also juwdapN: and an inf. n. of un., signifying] A single affection of thirst; a thirsting. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also juwaAdN.
jaAdiI-N Saffron. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

jawaAdN, used alike as masc. and fem., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or one who affects, or constrains himself, to be generous: (Mṣb:) or who gives without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than muHosinN: (MF:) pl. [of pauc., masc.,] OajowaAdN and (of mult., TA) juwodN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) like as quculN is pl. of qacaAlN, but the w is made quiescent because it is an unsound letter, (Ṣ,) [in some copies of the Ḳ juwudN,] and OajaAwidu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) or OajaAwiydu, [reg., as pl. of OajowaAdN,] (A,) and juwadaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juwadapN, (CK, [in some copies of the Ḳ omitted,]) or juwodapN, or juwudapN, [written in the latter manner in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,] with p added to the [proper] pl. form [juwodN or juwudN], accord. to the doctrine of Sb: (TA:) juwodN is used as a fem. pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and is like nuworN pl. of nawaArN. (Ṣ.)

Also, applied alike to the male and the female, (Ṣ,) A courser; a fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (L;) a horse fleet, or swift, in running; or excellent in running, or in the motion of his legs; as also jawodN↓: (Bḍ in xxxviii. 30:) or that outstrips others: (Jel ib.:) i. q. raAYiEN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. jiyaAdN, (Ṣ, A, Bḍ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which by rule should be jiwaAdN, like TiwaAlN, but this latter form has not been heard from the Arabs; (L;) or jiyaAdN is pl. of jawodN, or of jay-idN; (Bḍ ubi suprá;) and jawaAdN has also for its pl. OajoyaAdN, [a pl. of pauc., and irregular, or this is pl. of jay-dN, and therefore, though irregularly, retains the I substituted for w] (Ṣ, L,) and OajowaAdN, [also a pl. of pauc., but agreeable with rule, or this is pl. of jawodN,] (L,) and OajaAwiydu (Ṣ, L) is pl. of OajowaAdN. (L.) Hence, Oaqobala jawaAdFA † He came on, or advanced, like a horse that is termed jwAd: and sirotu Uilayohi jawaAdFA † I went to him, or it, like a horse that is so termed. (Mgh in art. gc.) You say also, EadaA EadowFA jawaAdFA He ran a long run. (A, TA.) And sironaA EuqobapF jawaAdFA, and Euqobatayoni jawaAdayoni, and EuqabFA jiyaAdFA (Ṣ, A) and OajowaAdFA, (A, TA,) We journeyed a long march or stage, and two long marches or stages, and long marches or stages. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
juwaAdN [accord. to the TA inf. n. of jiyda, which see in two places,] † Thirst: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or vehemence of thirst. (Ḳ.)
Also, [accord. to the Ḳ jawodapN↓, but this is corrected in the TA,] † Drowsiness, or slumber. (TA.)
jaAYidN: see jawodN.

jay-idN, originally of the measure fayoEilN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as the Basrees say, i. e. jayowidN, (Mṣb, TA,) the w being changed into I because of its being meksoor and preceded by I, and the augmentative I being then incorporated into it; (TA;) or, as the Koofees say, of the measure fayoEalN, like EayoTalN, &c., because there is found no sound word of the measure fayoEilN except SayoqilN, a woman's name, and the unsound is accorded to the sound; or, as others say, of the measure faEiylN, [and so I find in one copy of the Ṣ,] originally jawiydN, the kesreh of the w being, accord. to them, suppressed because difficult of pronunciation, and the quiescent w and I thus coming together, [the latter receives the rejected kesreh, and] the w is changed into I and incorporated into the [augmentative] I; (Mṣb;) Good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; contr. of radi Io; (A, Ḳ;) applied to a thing, (Ṣ,) or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, (A, Mṣb,) and a work, or performance: (TA:) pl. jiyaAdN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jiyaAdaAtN, (Ḳ,) the latter a pl. pl., [i. e. pl. of jiyaAdN,] (TA,) and jayaAYidu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with hemz, [and, accord. to some,] contr. to analogy. (Ṣ.) [It is also applied to a man, meaning Excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.]
Oajowadu [Better, and best; more, and most, goodly or approvable or excellent]: see 5.
[More, and most, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous. Hence,] Oajowadu mino HaAtimK [More liberal,, &c., than Ḥátim]: a prov. (Meyd.)
[More, and most, fleet, or swift, and excellent; relating to a horse. Hence,] Oajowadu mina AljawaAdi Almubir-i [More fleet,, &c., than the courser that surpasses others]: a prov. (Meyd.)
tajaAwydu: see jawodN, in two places.
majuwdN A field, or garden, rained upon: (A:) [or rained upon copiously, or abundantly.] And OaroDN majowdapN Land rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
† A man (Ṣ, A) affected with thirst: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) [or, with vehement thirst: (see juwaAdN:)] or at the point of death, or destruction. (Ḳ.)
And [hence,] ‡ Affected with longing desire. (L.)
Also † Overcome by drowsiness, or slumber: (TA:) or distressed by drowsiness, or slumber, &c. (Lḥ, L.)
mujiydN: see mijowaAdN.
Also A man possessing a horse such as is termed jawaAdi [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: pl. majaAwiydu [by rule pl. of mijowaAdN, q. v.]. (A, TA.)
HatofN mujiydN ‡ Present death. (Ḳ, TA.)

mijowaAdN One who says, utters, or expresses, or who does, (Ḳ, TA,) much, or often, (TA,) what is good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (Ḳ, TA;) as also mujiydN↓: (TA:) [or rather the latter is a simple, not an intensive, epithet:] the former is applied to a poet, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as syn. with the latter, (Ḳ,) or as meaning who says, or utters, much, or often, what is good, or excellent: (Ṣ:)
and both are applied to a workman, or an artificer: pl. of the former majaAwiydu. (A.)
juwcaAbN: see art. jcb.

hom.sense: 1. jaAra, aor. yajuwru, (TA,) inf. n. jaworN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He declined, or deviated, from the right course; (Ṣ, A;) and so jArEani AlqaSodi: (A:) he wandered from the right way: (TA:) he pursued a wrong course: (Ḳ:) or he left the right way in journeying: and it (anything) declined. (TA.) You say also, jAr Eani AlT-iriyqi He declined, or deviated, from the road, or way. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)

And jAr, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Ealayohi against him, (Ṣ, TA,) fiI Hukomihi in his judgment, (Mṣb,) or fiI AlHukomi in judgment. (Ṣ, TA.)
jArti AlOaroDu ‡ The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall: (A, TA:) and so jaOarat. (TA.)
See also 10.

2. jw-rhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajowiyrN, (Ṣ,) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, conduct; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of Ead-alahu. (A.)
He prostrated him (Ṣ, Ḳ) by a blow, (Ṣ,) or by a thrust of a spear or the like; from jAr “he, or it, declined;”; (A;) like kaw-arahu. (Ṣ.)
He threw it down, (TA,) and overturned it; (Ḳ, TA;) namely, a building, and a tent, &c.: (TA:) he took it to pieces; namely, a tent. (A.)

entry.sense: 3. jAwirhu, inf. n. mujaAwarapN and jiwaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juwaArN↓, (Ṣ, M, and some copies of the Ḳ,) or the last is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and jawaArN↓, (M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ instead of juwaArN,) of which forms the second (jiwaArN) is more chaste than the third (Ṣ, TA) and than the fourth, as relating to the verb in the sense here following, though some disapprove of it, and assert the third and the fourth to be more chaste; (TA;) He became his jAr [or neighbour]; (Ḳ;) he lived in his neighbourhood, or near to him: (Mṣb, TA:) or he lived in a dwelling contiguous to his. (Mṣb.)

Also jAwrhu, (TA,) inf. n. jiwaArN, (Ḳ,) and juwaArN↓ is said to be a quasi-inf. n., and more chaste than jiwaArN as relating to the verb in the sense here following; (TA;) He bound himself to him by a covenant to protect him. (Ḳ, TA.)
And jAwr ban-I fulaAnK, and fiI bnI flAn, inf. n. majaAwarapN and jiwaArN, He protected himself by a covenant with the sons of such a one; from mujaAwarapN signifying the “living near.” (TA.)

And jAwr, inf. n. mujaAwarapN, i. q. AiEotakafa fiI masojidK [He confined himself in a mosque, or place of worship, during a period of days and nights, or at least during one whole day, fasting from daybreak to sunset, and occupying himself in prayer and religious meditation, without any interruption by affairs distracting the mind from devotion and not pressing]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) But jAwr bimak-apa, and biAlmadiynapi, signifies absolutely He abode in Mekkeh, and El-Medeeneh; not necessarily implying conformity with the conditions of AiEotikaAf required by the law [though generally meaning for the purpose of study: and so in the neighbourhood of the great collegiate mosque called the Azhar, in Cairo: so that the term mujaAwirN↓ means a student of Mekkeh, &c.]. (TA.)

4. AjArhu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) inf. n. UijaArapN (Mgh, Ḳ) and jaArapN↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) [or the latter is rather a quasi-inf. n., like TaAEapN from OaTaAEahu,] He protected him; granted him refuge; (Ḳ;) preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) from (mino) wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from punishment; (Ṣ, A;) or from what he feared: (Mṣb:) he aided him; succoured him; delivered him from evil: the Oa having a privative effect. (Mgh.) It is said of God, yujiyru walaA yujaAru Ealayohi He protects, but none is protected against him. (TA.) And in the Ḳur [lxxii. 22], qulo Uin-iI lano yujiyraniI mina Qll-ehi OaHadN Verily none will protect me against God. (TA.)
AjAr AlmataAEa He put the household-goods, or commodities, into the repository, (Ḳ, TA,) and so preserved them from being lost. (TA.)
It is said [of God] in a trad., yujiyru bayona AlbuHuwri He makes a division between the seas, and prevents one from mixing with another and encroaching upon it. (TA.)
5. tjw-r He became prostrated; (Ṣ;) he fell down; (Ḳ;) by reason of a blow. (Ṣ, TA.)
It (a building, TA) became thrown down, or demolished. (Ḳ.)
He (a man, TA) laid himself down on his side (Ḳ) upon his bed. (TA.)

6. tajaAwaruwA and AijotawaruwA↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) are syn., (Ṣ,) signifying They became mutual neighbours; they lived near together: (Ḳ,* TA:) the [radical] w in the latter verb remaining unaltered because this verb is syn. with one in which the w must preserve its original form on account of the quiescence of the preceding letter, namely, tjAwrwA, (Ṣ, TA,) and to show that it is syn. therewith: but AijotaAruwA also occurs. (TA.)
[Also They bound themselves by a covenant to protect one another.]
8: see 6.
