10. AstjAr and jaAra↓, (Ḳ,) the latter like jaArN as syn. with musotajiyrN, (TA,) He sought, desired, or asked, to be protected; to be granted refuge; to be preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated. (Ḳ.) And AstjArhu He desired him, or asked him, to preserve, save, rescue, or deliver, him, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) mino fulaAnK from such a one. (Ṣ.) And AstjAr bihi He had recourse to him for refuge, protection, or preservation; he sought his protection. (TA.)

jaArN A neighbour; one who lives near to another; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) one who lives in the next tent or house: (IAạr, Th, T, Mṣb:) pl. [of mult.] jiyraAnN (Mṣb, Ḳ) [and jiwaArN (a pl. not of unfrequent occurrence, and mentioned by Freytag as used by El-Mutanebbee,)] and [of pauc.] jiyrapN and OajowaArN; (Ḳ;) like qaAEN, pl. qiyEaAnN and qiyEapN and OaqowaAEN, the only similar instance: (TA:) fem. with p {jaArapN}. (Mgh.) AljaAru cuw AlqurobaI [in the Ḳur iv. 40] is The relation, or kinsman, who is abiding in one's neighbourhood: or who is abiding in one town or district or the like while thou art in another, and who has that title to respect which belongs to nearness of relationship: (TA:) or the near neighbour: (Bḍ, Jel:) or the near relation: (Jel:) or he who is near, and connected, by relationship or religion. (Bḍ.) jaAru Aljanobi: and AljaAru Aljunubu and jaAru Aljunubi: see art. jnb. jaArN nif-iyjN A stranger [who has become one's neighbour]. (TA.)
A person whom one protects from wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
One who seeks, or asks, protection (Mṣb, Ḳ) of another: jaAruka signifying he who seeks thy protection. (TA.)

A protector; (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) one who protects another from that which he fears; (Mṣb;) one who grants refuge, or protects, or preserves. (AHeyth.) humo jaArapN↓ mino celika AlOamori They are protectors from that thing, is a phrase mentioned by Th, respecting which ISd says, I know not how this is, unless the sing. be supposed to be originally jaAYirN, so as to have a pl. of the measure faEalapN [as jaArapN is originally jawarapN]. (TA.)
An aider, or assister. (IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
A confederate. (IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
A woman's husband. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

A man's wife; (Mṣb;) as also jaArapN↓: (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the latter, the object of his love: (M:) and the latter also, a woman's fellow-wife; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) so called because the term Dar-apN is disliked, (Mgh, Mṣb,) as being of evil omen. (Mgh.)
A partner who has not divided with his partner: so in the trad. AljaAru OaHaq-u biSaqabihi [explained in art. Sqb]; as is shown by another trad. (Az, Mṣb.)

A partner, or sharer, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in immoveable property, such as land and houses, (Mṣb, TA,) and in merchandise, (Ḳ, TA,) whether he divide the property with the other or not, (Mṣb,) or whether he be partner in the whole or only in part. (TA.)
One who divides with another. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
‡ The froj [or pudendum] of a woman: and ‡ The anus; as also jaArapN↓. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
The part (IAạr, Ḳ) of the sea-shore (IAạr) that is near to the places where people have alighted and taken up their abode. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

jaworN, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (TA,) i. q. jaAYirN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. Declining, or deviating, from the right course: and acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (TA:) pl. [of the latter], applied to men, jawarapN↓, (Ḳ,) in which the w remains unaltered contr. to rule, (TA,) and jaArapN↓, (A, Ḳ,) as in all the copies of the Ḳ, but some substitute for it, as a correction, juwarapN↓, [found in a copy of the A,] which, however, requires consideration, (TA,) and jaAYiruwna. (Ḳ.) You say TariyqN jaworN A road, or way, deviating from the right course. (TA.) And huwa jaworN Eano TariyqinaA He is declining, or deviating, from our way. (TA.)
Also, for cuw jawor, meaning Wronged, or unjustly treated, by the judge. (Mgh from a trad.)
Einodahu mina AlmaAli Aljaworu ‡ He possesses, of property, an extraordinary abundance. (A, TA.) See also jiwar-N.

hom.sense: jaArapN: see jaArN, in three places:
and jaworN:
and see also 4.

entry.sense: jawarapN and juwarapN: see jaworN.
Uin-ahu laHasanu Aljiyrapi Verily he is good in respect of the mode, or manner, of jiwaAr [i. e. living as a neighbour, or binding himself by covenant to protect others]. (TA.)

jiwar-N A rain accompanied by vehement thunder: (Ḳ:) or by a vehement sound of thunder: (Ṣ:) or a copious rain; as also jaOorN and juWarN; (Ḳ in art. jOr;) and, accord. to Aṣ, juWaArN: (TA:) and an exceedingly great torrent. (TA. [In this last sense written in a copy of the A jaworN↓, and there said to be tropical.]) See jawaArN: and see also art. jr.
You say also baAzilN jiwar-N (Ṣ) [app. meaning A camel nine years old that brays loudly: or] hard and strong: and baEiyrN jiwar-N a bulky camel. (TA.)

hom.sense: jawaArN: see 3.
Also The part of the exterior court or yard of a house that is coextensive with the house. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Abundant and deep water. (Ḳ.) Whence jiwar-N↓ applied to rain. (TA.)
Ships: a dial. var. of jawaArK; on the authority of Sá'id, (Ḳ,) surnamed Abu-l-ʼAlà: (TA:) said in the Ḳ to be strange; but similar instances are well known. (MF.)

entry.sense: juwaArN: see 3, in two places.
Also, and jiwaArN↓, or the latter is only an inf. n., The covenant between two parties by which either is bound to protect the other. (TA.)

hom.sense: jiwaArN: see what next precedes.
[Also a pl. of jaArN.]

entry.sense: jaAYirN: see jaworN.
Also ‡ Wide and big; applied to a [bucket of the kind called] garob: and so, with p {jaAYirapN}, applied to a [skin of the kind called] qirobap. (A, TA.)

mujaw-arN [as meaning Thrown down, or overturned,] occurs in the following prov.:
yawomN biyawomi AlHafaDi Almujaw-ari
[A day for a day of the household-goods (or, accord. to the TA, the hair-cloth tent) thrown down, or overturned]: applied in the case of rejoicing at a calamity befalling another: a man had an aged paternal uncle, and used continually to go into the latter's tent, or house, and throw down his household-goods, one upon another; and when he himself grew old, sons of a brother of his did to him as he had done to his paternal uncle; wherefore he said thus, meaning, this is for what I did to my paternal uncle. (Ḳ.)
mujaAwirN: see 3, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. jaAza AlmawoDiEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or AlmakaAna, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. yajuwzu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. jawaAzN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jawozN and juWuwzN and majaAzN, (Ḳ,) He went, or passed, in, or along, the place, and left it behind; (Mgh, Ḳ;) [whether this be meant for one signification or two, does not appear; but in either case it is evident that one signification is he passed through, or over, or along, and beyond, the place; and this signification is of frequent occurrence;] as also jAz bihi; (Ḳ;) and AjAzhu↓; (Mgh;) and jAwzhu↓, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. jiwaAzN; (Ḳ, TA; in the CK jawaAzN;) and tjAwzhu↓; (Mgh;) lit., he traversed, or crossed, its jawoz, i. e., middle, and passed through it: (Mgh:) or he went, or passed, in, or along, the place; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA;) as also jAz bihi, and jAwzhu↓, (TA,) and AjAzhu↓, (A,) and AjtAzhu↓: (Ṣ: [so it appears from its being said that AijotiyaAzN is syn. with suluwkN:]) and in like manner, AlT-ariyaqa the road: (TA:) jAwz↓ AlmwDEa and jAzhu signify the same: (TA:) or AjAzhu↓ (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and jAwzhu↓ and tjAwzhu↓ (A) signify he left it behind him, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and traversed, or crossed, it; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) and jAwzhu↓ and jAwz↓ bihi also signify he left it behind. (TA.) You say, juzotu xilaAla Ald-iyaAri, which is like jusotu [I passed amid, or among, the houses: (see the remarks on the letter z:) or I went to and fro amid, or among, the houses, in a hostile attack upon them: or went round about them]. (Ibn-Umm-Kásim, TA.) And juzotu bikacaA, i. e., Aijotazotu↓ bihi [I passed by, and beyond, such a thing]. (TA.) And jAz Ealayohi He passed by him, or it; syn. mar-a bihi, and Aimotar-a bihi and Ealayohi. (M and Ḳ in art. mr.) And jaAzahu He passed, or crossed, over it. (L.) jAz and AjAz↓ are syn. [in this last sense]. (TA.) You say, OaEaAnaka Qll-ehu EalaI UijaAzapi↓ AlS-iraATi (A, TA) May God aid thee [to pass, or cross, over, or] to pass along, and to leave behind thee, the Sirát. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the Sirát, faOakuwnu OanaA waOum-atiI Oaw-ala mano yujiyzu↓ Ealayohi [And I, with my people, shall be the first who will pass over it]: yjyz being here syn. with yajuwzu. (TA.)
juzotu AlX-aIoCa UilaI gayorihi: see 3.

jAz Ald-irohamu fatajaw-azahu↓ [The piece of money passed, or was current, and he accepted it as current: in the TA written jAz Aldrhm ktjwzh, and without any syll. signs; but that the reading which I have adopted is right appears from what immediately follows:] a poet says,
wazuy-afu
[Pieces of money whereof there are current and bad]: and Lḥ mentions the saying, lamo Oara Aln-afaqapa tajuwzu bimakaAnK kamaA tajuwzu bimak-apa [I have not seen money for expenses pass away in a place as it passes away in Mekkeh]: ISd says, He has not explained it, but I think that the meaning is tanofuqu. (TA.)

jAz AlX-aIoCu, inf. n. jawaAzN, The thing was, or became, allowable; it passed for lawful: as though it kept the middle (jawoz) of the road. (TA.) You say, jaAza AlbayoEu, and Aln-ikaAHu, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqodu wagayoruhu, (Mṣb,) [The sale, and the marriage, and the contract, or other thing, was, or became, allowable; or] passed as right, sound, valid, or good [in law:] (Mṣb:) or had effect. (Mgh.) [And jAz lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA It was allowable to him to do so. And yajuwzu Oano yakuwna kacaA It may be so; or such a thing may be.]
jaAzahu in the sense of AjAzhu: see 4, second sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in nine places.

hom.sense: 3. jAwzhu and jAwz bihi, inf. n. jiwaAzN: see 1, in six places.
jaAwazotu AlX-aIoCi OilaI gayorihi (Ṣ, Mṣb *) I passed from the thing [to another thing]; (Mṣb;) as also tajaAwazotuhu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. q. juzotuhu↓. (Ṣ.)
jAwz Eano canobihi: see 6.
[Hence, app.,] kaAna mino xuluqiI AljiwaAzu It was of my disposition to be easy, or facile, in selling and demanding. (TA from a trad.)
jAwz bihi: see 4, in two places.
4. AjAz and AjAzhu: see 1, in six places.

AjAzhu He made him to go, or pass along; as also jaAzahu↓: (TA:) he made him to pass through, or over, or along and beyond: (Ṣ, IF, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also [jAwz↓ bihi, as will be shown by an ex. below, and jw-zhu↓, and] jaAzahu↓, for which we find jAwzhu incorrectly substituted in the Ḳ. (TA.) A rájiz says,
xal-uwA AlT-ariyqa Eano OabiI say-aAraho
Hat-aI yujiyza saAlimFA HimaAraho
[Leave ye the road to Aboo-Seiyárah until he make his ass to pass through, or over, safely]. (Ṣ.) And it is said in the Ḳur [vii. 134, and x. 90], wajaAwazonaA↓ bibaniI UisoraAYiyla AlbaHora [And we made the Children of Israel to pass through the sea]. (TA.) You say also jaw-aza↓ lahumo Uibilahumo, inf. n. tajowiyzN, He led for them their camels one by one until they passed. (Ḳ.)

[He made it to pass, or be current; as also jw-zhu↓: as in the following phrases.] Oajazotu EalaI Qsomihi i. q. jaEalotuhu jaAYizFA [I made his name to pass, or be current, by stamping money with it]: (ISk, Ṣ, TA:) and Darabotu [I coined, or minted, money in his name]. (ISd, TA.) And jw-z↓ AlD-ar-aAbu Ald-araAhima, inf. n. tajowiyzN, [The coiner, or minter,] made the dirhems, or pieces of money, to pass, or be current. (Mgh.)

He made it, or held it, to be allowable, or to pass for lawful; he allowed it, or permitted it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also jw-zhu↓: (Ṣ, TA:) syn. saw-aga: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and syn. of UijaAzapN, [the inf. n. of the former verb,] UiconN. (Ḳ, TA: omitted in the CK.) You say, AjAz lahu maA SanaEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and jw-z↓ lh, (Ṣ,) He made, or held, what he did to be allowable,, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hecaA mim-aA laA yujuw-izuhu↓ AlEaqolu [This is of the things which reason will not allow]. (A, TA.)

[He granted him the authority or degree of a licentiate in some one or more of the various departments of learning, for the instruction of others therein;] he granted him a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) You say also, AjAz lifulaAnK jamiyEa masomuwEaAtihi mino maXaAYixihi [He ters which he had heard from his sheykhs, to teach the same to others]. (TA.) The licentiate is termed mujaAzN↓: and the matters which he relates are termed mujaAzaAtN↓. (TA.)

AjAz AlbayoEa, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and Aln-ikaAHa, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqoda, (Mṣb,) He (the judge, A, Mgh) made the sale, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and the marriage, (A, Mgh,) and the contract, (Mṣb,) to have effect; he executed or performed it; (Mgh, Mṣb Ḳ;) lahu for him: (Ḳ:) he decreed it. (Mgh.) And [in like manner] AjAz raOoyahu, and jw-zhu↓, He made his judgment, or opinion, to have effect; he executed or performed it. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, qabola Oano yujayzuwA EalaI-a, i. e., Before they slay me, and execute your order upon me. (TA.)

OajaAzaniI (Ṣ, Ḳ *) ‡ He gave me water for, (Ṣ,) or he watered [for me], (Ḳ,) my land, or my beasts. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And jw-z↓ Uibilahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tajowiyzN, (TA,) He watered his camels. (Ḳ.) And AjAz Alwafoda He gave to the party who came as envoys, or the like, the quantity of water sufficient to pass therewith from one watering-place to another. (TA.) And OajaAzahu maMCF yajuwzu bihi AlT-ariyqa † He gave him water wherewith to travel the road. (A.) And OajizoniI maMCF Give thou me some water that I may go my way, and pass from thee. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.)

Hence, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) AjAzhu bijaAYizapK, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and AjAzhu bijaAYizapK saniy-apK, (Ṣ, A,) † He (the Sultán) gave him a gift, or present, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and he gave him a gift, or present, of high estimation. (Ṣ, A.*) Or the origin of the expression was this: Katan the son of 'Owf, of the tribe of Benoo-Hilál-Ibn-'Ámir-Ibn-Saasa'ah, gave the government of Fáris to ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-ʼAbbás; and El-Ahnaf passing by him with his army on an expedition to Khurásán, he waited for them upon a bridge, and said, Oajiyzuwhumo [Make ye them to pass over]; and he began to mention the lineage of each man and to give him according to his rank: (Ṣ:) or from the fact that a certain commander, having a river between him and an opposing force, said, mano jaAza hecaA Aln-ahora falahu kacaA [Whoso passeth this river shall have such a thing]; and whenever one passed over, he received a jaAYizap. (TA.) You say also, OajaAzahu, meaning † He gave him. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., OajiyzuwA Alwafoda binaHowi maA kunotu Oujiyzuhumo bihi Give ye to the party who come as envoys, or the like, a similar jaAYizap to that which I used to give them. (TA.)
5. tjw-z All-ayolu The darkness of the night cleared away. (A.)

tjw-z fiI SalaAtihi He relaxed, or remitted, in his prayer; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so in other things; (A;) and abridged it; and was quick in it: said to be from Aljawozu “the act of traversing, and going, or passing along:” (TA:) or did less than was sufficient in it. (Mṣb.)

Hence, tjw-z fiI Oaxoci Ald-araAhimi, (A, Mgh,) or tjw-z Ald-araAhima, (Ḳ,) He accepted the dirhems, or pieces of money, as current; did not reject them: (A, Mgh:) see 1: or he accepted them as they were, or notwithstanding what was in them: (Lth, TA:) or he accepted them notwithstanding what was intermixed with them, (Ḳ, TA,) [of bad money,] concealed therein, and notwithstanding their fewness. (TA.) In the phrase Alt-ajaw-uzu biduwni AlHaq-i [The accepting less than what was due], the inf. n. is made trans. by means of bi because it implies the meaning of Alr-iDaA [which is made trans. by the same means]. (Mgh.) tajaAwazo↓ also occurs in the sense of tajaw-azo in a trad. of Ibn-Rawáhah: hecaA laka watajaAwazo fiI Alqasomi This is thine, or for thee, and be thou remiss, or not extreme, in, or with respect to, the division: and is allowable, though we have not heard it. (Mgh.) You say also, tajaw-aza fiI hecaA AlOamori maA lamo yatajaw-azo fiI gayorihi He bore patiently, or with silence and forgiveness, and with feigned neglect, or connivance, in this affair, or case, what he did not so bear in another. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 6, in three places.
tjw-z fiI kalaAmihi He made use of a trope, or tropes, in his speech. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See majaAzN, below.]
6. tjAwzhu: see 1, first sentence: and see also 3.
tjAwz i. q. OaforaTa, [i.e., jAwz AlHad-a, explained above,] fiyhi in it, or with respect to it. (Ḳ. See 3.)

tjAwz Eanohu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and tjw-z↓; (Ṣ, A, Mgh;) and tjAwzEano canobihi, (A, Ḳ,) and tjw-z↓, and jAwz↓; (Ḳ;) He (God, Ṣ, A, or a man, Mṣb) passed him by, or over, without punishing him; or forgave him; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) namely, an evil-doer; (A, Mgh, Mṣb;) and He passed by, or over, without punishing, or forgave, his sin or offence. (A, Ḳ.*) You say, Aall-ehum-a tajaAwazo Ean-iI, and tajaw-azo↓ Ean-iI, O God, pass me by, or over, without punishing me; or forgive me. (Ṣ, A.) tjAwz Eanohu, followed by a noun in the accus. case, also signifies He forgave him a thing. (L.) And the same alone, He feigned himself neglectful of it; he connived at it. (Ḳ.)
[Also, this last phrase alone, He transcended it.]
tajaAwazo fiI Alqasomi: see 5.

entry.sense: 8. AjtAzhu and AjtAz bihi: see 1.

hom.sense: 10. AstjAzhu He asked, or demanded, of him permission. (Ḳ,* TA.)

He asked, or demanded, of him [the authority or degree of a licentiate; i. e.,] a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) [See 4.]
‡ He asked, or demanded, of him (Ṣ, Ḳ) water for, (Ṣ,) or to water [for him], (Ḳ,) his land, or his beasts. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He approved it. (Ḥar p. 326.)

jawozN The middle (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a thing, (Ḳ,) or of anything; (Ṣ;) [as, for instance,] of a desert, (A,) and of a camel, (TA,) and of the night: (A, TA:) and the main part of a thing, (Ḳ,) or of the night: (TA:) pl. OajowaAzN; (Sb, Ṣ, A;) beside which it has no other. (Sb.)

[The walnut; or walnuts;] a well-known fruit, (Ḳ,) which is eaten: (Mṣb:) a Persian word, (Ṣ,) arabicized; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) originally Gawozo: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. jawozapN: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. jawozaAtN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: in the CK jawozaAnN:) the tree thereof abounds in the land of the Arabs, in the province of El-Yemen, where it bears fruit and is cultivated; and in the Sarawát (Als-arawaAt) are trees thereof, which are not cultivated: the wood thereof is characterized by hardness and strength. (AḤn. TA.)

jawozu baw-aI, (Ḳ,) or jawozu baw-aA, with the short alif, as heard from the physicians, in Persian Gawozi buwyaA, (Mgh, under the letter b,) [vulgarly called jawozu AlT-iybi, The nutmeg;] a certain medicine; (Ḳ;) it is of the size of the gall-nut (EafoS), easily broken, with a thin coat, (Mgh, TA,) having a pleasant odour, (Mgh,) or a pleasant and sharp odour; and the best kind is the red, with a black coat, and heavy: (TA:) it is good for the [affection of the face termed] laqowap, strengthens the stomach and heart, and removes cold. (Mgh.)

jawozu maAvilK [The datura stramonium, or thorn-apple;] also a certain medicine; (Ḳ;) having the property of producing torpor; resembling the jawozu AlqaIoCi (see what follows); having upon it small, thick thorns; and its seed is like that of the Outoruj- [or citror.]. (TA.)
jawozu Alq-IoCi [Nux vomica;] also a certain medicine, (Ḳ,) having a power similar to that of the white xarobaq [or hellebore]. (TA.)
jawozu Alhinodi [The cocoa-nut;] what is commonly called the naArajiyl. (TA.)
jawozapN: see jaAYizapN, in four places.
Also n. un. of jawozN [q. v.].

entry.sense: jiyzapN: see jaAYizapN.

AljawozaMCu A certain constellation (najomN); (Ṣ;) a certain sign of the Zodiac; (Ḳ;) [namely, Gemini;] said to cross the jawoz (i. e. the middle, TA) of the sky; (Ṣ, TA;) for which reason it is [asserted to be] thus called. (TA.)

Also i. q. Aljab-aAru [The constellation Orion]: (A and Ḳ in art. jbr:) it has three very bright stars disposed obliquely in the midst thereof, called by the Arabs Aln-aZomu, and niTaAqu AljawozaMCi, and faqaAru AljawozaMCi. (Ḥar p. 456.)

hom.sense:
jawaAzN † The act of watering, or giving to drink: (Ṣ:) or a single watering of, or giving drink to, camels. (TA.) [See also jaAYizapN.] A rájiz says,
yaA SaAHiba QlomaMCi fadatoka nafosiI
Eaj-ilo jawaAziI waOaqil-a HabosiI
[O master of the water (may my soul be thy ransom) hasten the watering of my camels, and make my detention little]. (TA.)
‡ The water with which beasts are watered, or with which seed-produce is watered: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and] water which is given one that he may travel with it the road. (A, Mgh.) [See also jaAYizapN.]
Hence, (Mgh,) † The traveller's pass, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) given him to prevent any one's offering opposition to him: (A, Mgh:) pl. OajowizapN. (A, TA.)
The office, or authority, of a guardian and affiancer. (TA.)
jaAYizN [act. part. n. of jaAza, in all its senses].

Passing, or current, money. (Mgh.) See an ex. above, voce jaAza. [And hence,] jawaAYizu AlOaXoEaAri, and AlOamovaAli, (Ḳ, TA,) for the former of which we find, in some copies of the Ḳ, AlX-iEori, which is incorrect, (TA,) Verses, or poems, and proverbs, current from country to country, or from town to town. (Ḳ, TA.)
Applied to a contract, [and a sale and a marriage, Allowable; passing for lawful;] passing as right, sound, valid, or good [in law]; having effect. (Mṣb.)

[The beam of a house, or chamber, upon which rest the EawaAriD, or rafters;] that upon which are placed the extremities of the pieces of wood in the roof of a house or chamber; (AO, TA;) the palm-trunk, (Ṣ,) or piece of wood, which passes across between two walls, (Ḳ,) called in Persian tiyor, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is the sahom of the house or chamber: (Ṣ:) pl. [of pauc.] OajowizapN, (Ṣ, CK, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, incorrectly, OjowuzN, (TA,) [and both these are given in the CK,] and [of mult.] juwzaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jiyzaAnN (CK, but omitted in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and jawaAYizu. (Seer, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaAYizapN † A draught of water; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also jawozapN↓: (Ḳ:) or ↓the latter signifies a single watering, or giving of water to drink; (Ṣ, Ḳ; [see an ex. in art. Acn, conj. 2;]) or such as a man passes with from one person to another: and ↓both signify the quantity of water with which the traveller passes from one watering-place to another; as also jiyzapN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., likul-i jaAbihK jawozapN↓ vum-a yuWuc-anu, i. e., † For every one that comes to us for water is a single water-ing, or giving of water to drink; then he is repelled from the water: or, as in the M, then his ear is struck, to indicate to him that he has nothing more than that to receive from us. (TA.)
Hence, (A, Mgh,) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, (TA,) [but see 4,] † A gift, or present: (Aboo-Bekr, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) pl. jawaAYizu. (Ṣ, A, Mgh.)

Hence also, (Mgh,) ‡ Kindness and courtesy: (Ḳ:) or kindnesses and courtesy shown to those who come to one as envoys or the like: (Mgh:) or provisions for a day and a night given to a guest at his departure after entertainment for three days. (Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., AlD-iyaAfapu valaAvapu Oay-aAmK wajaAYizatuhu yawomN walayolapN wamaA zaAda fahuwa SadaqapN, meaning, [The period of] the entertainment of a guest is three days, during the first of which the host shall take trouble to show him large kindness and courtesy, and on the second and third of which he shall offer him what he has at hand, not exceeding his usual custom; then he shall give him that wherewith to journey for the space of a day and a night; and what is after that shall be as an alms and an act of favour, which he may do if he please of neglect if he please. (TA.)

hom.sense: majaAzN A way, road, or path, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) which one travels from one side [or end] to the other; (Ḳ, TA;) as also majaAzapN↓. (TA.) You say, jaEala fulaAnN celika AlOamora majaAzFA UilaI HaAjatihi † Such a one made that thing a way to the attainment of his want. (Ṣ, TA.) majaAzapu↓ nahorK signifies A bridge. (A.) And majaAzapN↓ alone [also] signifies A road (TariyqapN) in a saboxap [or salt tract]. (Ḳ.)
A privy, or place where one performs ablution; syn. mutabar-azN. (TA.)

A trope; a word, or phrase, used in a sense different from that which it was originally applied to denote, by reason of some analogy, or connexion, between the two senses; as, for instance, OasadN, properly signifying “a lion,” applied to “a courageous man;” (KT, &c.;) what passes beyond the meaning to which it is originally applied; (TA;) [being of the measure mafoEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN;] contr. of HaqiyqapN. (Ḳ.) [This is also called majaAzN lugawiI-N, and majaAzN lugapF; to distinguish it from what is termed majaAzN EurofiI-N, and majaAzN EurofFA, which is A word, or phrase, so little used in a particular proper sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as tropical; as, for instance, daAb-apN in the sense of “a man,” or “a human being;” it being commonly applied to “a beast,” and especially to “a horse” or “a mule” or “an ass.”] A Haqiyqap, when little used, becomes what is termed majaAzN EurofFA. (Mz, 24th nwE.) The majaAz is either what is termed AisotiEaArapN [i. e. a metaphor] (as OasadN used as meaning “a courageous man”), or majaAzN murosalN [a loose trope] (as yadN used as meaning “a benefit,” “benefaction,” “favour,” or “boon”). (KT, &c.) [majaAzN also signifies A tropical meaning.]

entry.sense: mujaAzN and mujaAzaAtN: see 4, in the middle of the paragraph.

mujiyzN A commissioned agent of another; an executor appointed by a will; syn. wakiylN, and waSiI-; because he executes what he is ordered to do: so in the conventional language of the people of El-Koofeh: (Mgh:) or a slave who has received permission to traffic. (Mgh, Ḳ.)

The guardian and affiancer [of a woman]; syn. waliI-N. (Ḳ.) You say, hecihi QmoraOapN layosa lahaA mujiyzN [This is a woman who has no guardian and affiancer]: and Shureyh is related to have said, UicaA OanokaHa QlomujiyzaAni faAln-ikaAHu liloOaw-ali [When the two guardians and affiancers give a woman in marriage, the marriage is the former's]. (TA.)
The manager of the affairs of an orphan. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: majaAzapN: see majaAzN, in three places.
OaroDN majaAzapN (Ṣ, A) A land containing trees of the jawoz [or walnut]: (Ṣ:) or a land (in the Ḳ, makaAn [a place], which is wrong, TA) abounding with jawoz. (A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: [majaAziI-N Tropical.]
mujataAzN Going, or passing along. (Ḳ.)
One who travels, or penetrates, along a road. (Ḳ.)
One who loves to hasten, or outstrip. (Ḳ, TA.)
1. jaAsa, aor. yajuwsu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. jawosN, (A, Ḳ,) He sought for, or after, (Zj, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a thing, (Zj, A, Ḳ,) or news, or tidings, (Ṣ,) with the utmost of his endeavour. (Zj, A, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] jaAsuwA xilaAla Ald-iyaAri, (Ṣ, A,) in the Ḳur [xvii. 5], (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) They went through the midst of the houses (taxal-aluwhaA), and sought for what was in them, as a man seeks for news, or tidings; as also AjtAswA↓: (Ṣ:) or they went to and fro among the houses, in a sudden attack: (A, Ḳ:) or the meaning in the Ḳur is, they slew you amid your houses; and HaAsuwA signifies the same; going and coming: (Fr, TA:) and, inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) and jawasaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) they went round about (Zj, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) by night, (Ṣ,) among the houses, (Zj, A, Ḳ,) looking if any remained whom they had not slain, (Zj, TA,) or doing mischief: (A:) and AijotiyaAsN↓ signifies the same as jawasaAnN, (Ḳ, TA,) the going round about by night. (TA.)

jiysa also signifies It (anything) was trodden: jawosN is said to be like dawosN: (TA:) and you say, jaMCa fulaAnN yajuwsu Aln-aAsa Such a one came stepping over the people; syn. yataxaT-aAhumo. (A, TA.*) And accord. to A' Obeyd, jusotuhu and Husotuhu both signify I came into it, and trod it; (xaAlaTotuhu wawaTiYotuhu;) meaning, any place. (TA.) You say also, jaAsahumu AlOasadu The lion trod upon them: or came into the midst of them, and did mischief among them. (TA; [in which the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is said to be jawosN and jawosaMCu: but the latter is probably a mistranscription for jawasaAnN.])
8: see 1, in two places.
jaw-aAsN One who treads upon everything: or who comes into the midst of a people, and does mischief among them. (TA.)
Hence, (TA,) The lion. (Ḳ, TA.) And in like manner it is applied to a man. (TA.)

jawosaqN i. q. qaSorN [A palace: or a pavilion, or kind of building wholly or for the most. part isolated, sometimes on the top of a larger building, i. e., a belvedere, and sometimes projecting from a larger building, and generally consisting of one room if forming a part of a larger building]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 823:) or a fortress; syn. HiSonN: (M, IB, TA:) or [a building] resembling a HiSon: (M:) an arabicized word, (Lth, JK, Ṣ, M,) from the Persian kuwXok: (TA:) its primary meaning is a HiSon in a state of demolition; and a ruined qaSor: pl. jawaAsiqu and jawaAsiyqu; the latter formed by giving fulness of sound to the kesreh, or by poetic license. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) There were, in the Karáfeh, [the great burial-ground of the Egyptian metropolis,] numerous quSuwr, i. e., what are called jwAsq, having belvederes (manaAZir) and gardens: but most of the jwAsq were without gardens and without a well; being lofty belvederes: all of them were called quSuwr. (El-Makreezee's “Khitat,” ii. 453.)

jawoXN The breast; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also juWoXuwXN (Ṣ) and jawoXN: (Ṣ, A:) and [particularly] that of a man;
as also juwXN↓: (Ḳ:) and the middle of a man. (Ḳ.)

Also † The fore part (Sador) of the night; like jaroXN; (Ṣ;) and so juwXN↓: (TA:) or the middle thereof; (Ḳ;) as also jawozN: (AA:) and a great portion thereof: or of the latter part thereof: (Ḳ:) or a portion of the latter part thereof: (TA:) or from the time of a quarter to a third thereof. (T, TA.) You say, maDaI jawoXN mina All-ayoli † [A portion of the fore part,, &c., of the night passed]. (Ṣ.)
juwXN: see above, in two places.
jawoXanN The breast: (IDrd, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or the broad part of the middle of the breast: and the fore part of the body of a locust. (TA.)
A coat of mail: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or mail with which the breast and the Hayozuwm [or parts adjoining the breast] are clad. (M, TA.)

The middle of the night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or”) the fore part thereof: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. jawaAXinu. (Ṣ.) You say, maDaI jawoXanN mina All-ayoli An early portion of the night passed: (Ṣ:) or [simply] a portion of the night. (M, TA.) It is a dial. var. of jawoXN, [in the first of the meanings explained above, and also as relating to the night,] although augmented. (TA.)
jawoXaniI-N A manufacturer of coats of mail. (Ḳ.)

1. jaAEa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yajuwEu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jawoEN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or juwEN, (Ṣ, so in two copies,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb, TA,) and majaAEapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was, or became, hungry; or empty in the belly; (TA;) contr. of XabiEa. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See also juwEN below.]

[Hence,] jaAEa Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) or jaAEa UilaI liqaAYihi, (M, TA,) ‡ He desired, (M, Ḳ,*) and longed, (Ḳ,) [as though hungering,] to meet with him; like EaTiXa. (M, Ḳ.*) And jaAEa UilaI maAlihi ‡ He longed for his property. (AZ.)
2: see 4, in two places.

4. AjAEhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UijaAEapN; (Mṣb;) and jw-Ehu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tajowiyEN; (Mṣb;) He constrained him to be hungry, or empty in the belly: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) or he debarred him from food and drink. (Mṣb.) It is said in a prov., OajiEo kalobaka yatobaEoka [Make thy dog to be hungry and he will follow thee]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning † constrain thou the ignoble to have recourse to thee, by want, in order that he may continue by thee; (Ḳ,* TA;) for if he be in no need of thee, he will leave thee: and for OajiEo, some say jaw-iEo↓. (TA.)

5. tjw-E He made himself hungry, or empty in the belly, intentionally, or purposely. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, tawaH-aXo lild-awaMCi and tajaw-aEo lild-awaMCi, [Make thyself hungry, or make thy stomach empty of food and beverage, (see art. wHX,) or] abstain thou from eating the full quantity of food, for the purpose of taking medicine. (TA.)
10. AstjAE He showed hunger. (KL, PṢ.)
[Hence,] AisotijaAEapu AlEilomi † The being insatiable of knowledge. (TA.)

juwEN, a subst., (Mṣb, TA,) signifying Hunger; or emptiness of the belly; (TA;) contr. of XibaEN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also majaAEapN↓, [properly an inf. n.,] and majowaEapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and majuwEapN↓. (TA.) You say, juwEFA lahu wanuwEFA [May God decree hunger to him]: accord. to Sb, an instance of inf. ns. in the accus. case by reason of a verb understood: it is a form of imprecation: and the latter noun may not be put before the former, because it is a corroborative to it: (TA:) or, accord. to some, nuwEN means “thirst.” (Ṣ, &c., in art. nwE.) And EaAmu majaAEapK↓ and majowaEapK↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and majuwEapK↓ (TA) A year in which is hunger, or emptiness of the belly: (Ḳ, TA:) and EaAmu AlmajaAEapi↓ and AlmajuwEapi↓ [the year of hunger,, &c.]: (Mṣb:) pl. majaAYiEu (Ḳ) and majaAwihu: as in the phrases OaSaAbatohumu AlmajaAwiEu [Cases of hunger,, &c., befell them] and waqaEuwAfiI AlmajaAwiEi [They fell into cases of hunger,, &c.]. (TA.) And Alr-aDaAEapu mina AlmajaAEapi↓, meaning The sucking which occasions interdiction [of marriage with the woman whose milk is sucked and certain of her relations] is that consequent upon hunger which is stopped by the milk in the time of infancy of the child; not when the child's hunger is only to be stopped by solid food. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. rDE.] And it is said in a prov., samanu kalobK bijuwEi Oaholihi, i. e. [The dog's becoming fat is] by reason of [the hunger of his owners occasioned by] murrain befalling the camels; (Ḳ,* TA;) his owners falling into hunger and distress and leanness: (TA:) or klb was the name of a certain man, who was an object of fear, wherefore he was asked for a pledge, and he pledged his family: then obtaining possession of the camels, or cattle, of the people to whom he had pledged his family, he drove them away, and left his family: (Ḳ, TA:) some relate this prov. differently, saying [samina kalobN “a dog,” or “Kelb,” “became fat,” and] bibuWosi Oaholihi [“by reason of the distress of his owners,” or “his family”]. (TA.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 615.]
jawoEapN A single temporary affection of hunger. (Ṣ, TA.) A state of destitution and hunger of a tribe. (TA.)
jawoEaAnu: see the next paragraph.

jaAYiEN and jawoEaAnu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) but not jayoEaAnu, [as the vulgar say,] for this a mistake, (TA,) Hungry; or empty in the belly: (Ḳ,* TA:) or debarred from food and drink: (Mṣb:) the fem. [of the former] is jaAYiEapN and [of the latter] jawoEaI: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the pl. [of the former] is juw-aEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and juy-aEN, with the w changed into I, (L,) and [of the latter, or perhaps of both,] jiyaAEN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and jaAEapN (Ḳ * in art. swE) and jayaAEaI [with the w changed into I contr. to rule, if this be not a mistake for jiyaAEN, in which the w is changed into I by rule]. (Mṣb.) You say jaAYiEN naAYiEN; the latter word being an imitative sequent; (TA;) or, accord. to some, signifying “thirsty.” (Ṣ, &c., in art. nwE.)
rajulN jaAYiEu Alqidori ‡ A man whose cookingpot is not full. (TA.)
AimoraOapN jaAYiEapu AlwiXaAHi ‡ A woman slender in the [waist, or] belly. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See art. wXH.]

majaAEN [The space in which one becomes hungry]. You say, huwa min-iI EalaI qadori majaAEi AlX-aboEaAni, i. e., EalaI qadori maA yajuwEu AlX-aboEaAnu [He, or it, is distant from me as far as the space in which he who is satiated with food becomes hungry]: (O, Ḳ:*) and in like manner, EalaI qadori maEoTaXi Alr-ay-aAni [as far as the space in which he who is satisfied with drink becomes thirsty]. (Z, TA.)
majaAEapN: see juwEN, in four places.
majowaEapN and majuwEapN: see juwEN, in five places.
musotajiyEN A man (Ṣ) who always shows himself, or is seen, to be hungry: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, who is always eating one thing after another. (Ṣgh, L.)

hom.sense: 1. jawafN The being [hollow, or] wide and hollow within: (PṢ:) or the being empty, vacant, or void: an inf. n. of which the verb is of the class of taEiba [i. e. jaAfa, originally jawifa, like xaAfa, sec. pers. jifota, aor. yajaAfu]: (Mṣb:) the being wide, spacious, or ample: (Ḳ:) the inf. n., or source, whence XaIoCN Oajowafu. (Ṣ.) [See also 10.]

jaAfahu, [aor. yajuwfu,] inf. n. jawofN, It reached his jawof [or inside, or interior,, &c.]. (TA.) It (medicine) entered his jawof. (TA. [See also 8.]) And jaAfatohu AljiraAHapu The wound reached his jawof. (Mṣb.)

TaEanahu fajaAfahu, and AjAfhu↓, He pierced him and pierced his jawof: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and jw-fhu↓, inf. n. tajowiyfN, he pierced him in his jawof. (TA.) jufotuhu biAlT-aEonapi, and Oajafotuhu↓ AlT-aEonapa, I made the spear-wound, or the like, to reach his jawof. (Ks, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.) jaAfa AlS-ayoda He made the arrow to enter the jawof of the object of the chase. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. tajowiyfN The making [a thing] hollow, or empty in the middle. (KL, PṢ.) You say, jw-fhu, inf. n. tajowiyfN, [He made it hollow; hollowed it out;] he made it to have a jawof. (Mṣb.) And of a thing that is mujaw-af, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. Ojowaf, (Ṣ,) you say, fiyhi tajowiyfN [In it is a hollowing out; meaning a hollow, in which sense tjwyf has a pl., namely, tajaAwiyfu]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1.
4: see 1, in two places.
AjAf AlbaAba ‡ He shut, or closed, the door. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Hence, in a trad., waOajiyfuwA AlOabowaAa waOaTofiYuwA AlmaSaAbiyHa [And shut ye the doors, and extinguish the lamps]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tjw-f It was, or became, hollow, or empty within. (KL.)
tjw-fhu: see 8.
tajaw-afati AlxuwSapu AlEarofaja The leaf was in the jawof [or inside] of the [plant called] Erfj, not having yet come forth. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 8. AjtAfhu He entered its jawof [or inside, or interior; he entered into the midst of it]; as also tjw-fhu↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed, voce OaSolN: and see also 1.]

hom.sense: 10. AstjAf and Aisotajowafa It (a thing) became wide, spacious, or ample. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 1, first sentence.]
AstjAfhu He found it (a place) to be Oajowaf [i. e. hollow, or empty within; or wide, spacious, or ample]. (O, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jawofN [A hollow; an interior empty, vacant, or void, space;] a vacancy: pl. OajowaAfN: this is the primary signification: then it was used in relation to a thing capable of being occupied and of being unoccupied; so as to be applied in the sense next following. (Mṣb.)
The inside, or interior, (Mṣb, KL,) of a house [&c.]. (Mṣb.)
[The midst, or middle, of a thing.]

A low, or depressed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and wide, (TA,) tract, or portion, of land, or ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) what is wider than the XiEob; the [water-courses termed] tilaAE, and the valleys, flow into it; and it has jirafap [or abrupt, water-worn, banks]: sometimes it is wider than a valley, and deeper: and sometimes it is a plain, or soft, tract, that retains water: and sometimes it is completely round, so that it retains water: accord. to IAạr, it signifies a valley: or, as some say, the interior (baTon) of a valley. (TA.)

The belly, or abdomen, of a man: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to ISd, the interior of the belly: and the part upon which close the shoulder-blades and the upper arms and the ribs and the two flanks (AlS-uqolaAni): (TA:) the chest, or thorax; i. e., the part of the body that is separated from the baTon [or belly, or abdomen,] by the HijaAb [or diaphragm, or midriff]; containing the heart and its appertenances: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) pl. as above. (TA.) See also jaAYifN. It is one of the words that are not used adverbially except with prepositions. (Sb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tanosawuA Aljawofa wamaA waEaI [Forget not ye the jwf and what it hath collected]; meaning what enters into it, of food and beverage: but some say that Aljwf here means the belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre], together, which are also called AlOajowafaAni↓: and some say that the meaning is, the heart and what it hath retained, and kept in memory, of the knowledge of God. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
AlOajowaAfu is also applied by the people of El-Ghowr (Ḳ) and of El-Yemen (TA) to The tents (fasaATiyT) of their Eum-aAl [or governors, or collectors of the poor-rates]. (Ḳ.)
jawofu All-ayoli AlMxiru, occurring in a trad., means † The last third of the night: [or] the fifth of the sixths of the night: (Ḳ:) not the half, as some assert. (TA.)
jawofiI-N: see Oajowafu.

hom.sense: juwfiI-N: see Oajowafu.

entry.sense: juwfaAnN The penis of an ass: (El-Muärrij, Ḳ:) and of a man. (TA.)
juwaAfN: see juwfiI-N.

jaAYifN Reaching the jawof. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] TaEonapN jaAYifapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, &c.,) or jiraAHapN jaAYifapN, (Mṣb,) A spear-wound, or the like, that reaches the jawof↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by which is here meant [the interior of the body or head, or], accord. to IAth, any vital part, as the belly and the brain: (TA:) and sometimes, that penetrates into the jwf: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh:) and that passes through also: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) and said to be such as is in the pit between the collarbones, and in the pubes; but not in the neck, nor in the throat, nor in the thigh, nor in the leg: (Mgh:) not if it reaches the interior of the bone of the thigh: (Mṣb:) opposed to jaAlifapN. (Ṣ in art. jlf.)
Hence, jaAYifapN is applied to ‡ A great fault or imperfection or vice. (TA from a trad.)
taloEapN jaAYifapN A deep [water-course,, &c.: see tlEh]: pl. jawaAYifu. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, qaSiyrapN is erroneously put for qaEiyrapN.])

jawaAYifu Aln-afosi The deep recesses of the jawofa [or chest] in the places where the soul has its seat; expl. by maA taqaE-ara mina Aljawofi fiI maqaAr-i Alr-uwHi. (L, Ḳ.) So in the phrase, used by El-Farezdaḳ, warad-a Aln-afosa bayona AljawaAYifi [And he drove back the soul into the midst of the deep recesses of the chest]: (L, TA:) but some read byn AlX-araAsifi. (TA.)
AljaAYifu [The cephalic vein;] a vein that runs along the upper arm to the [cartilage called] nagoD of the shoulder-blade; it is the faliyq. (TA.)

Oajowafu Having a jawof; (TA;) [i. e.,] hollow, or empty within; (KL, PṢ;) having in it a tajowiyf [or hollowing out, meaning a hollow], (Ṣ,) and so mujaw-afN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [but the latter is more properly rendered hollowed, or hollowed out:]) empty, vacant, or void: (Mṣb:) wide, spacious, or ample; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also musotajaAfN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and juwfiI-N↓, with damm, (Ḳ,) thus correctly written, being a rel. n. altered from the original form, like suholiI-N and duhoriI-N, (Ṣgh, TA,) but meaning wide in the jawof [or belly,, &c.], written by J [in the Ṣ] jawofiI-N↓, with fet-ḥ: (TA:) great in the jawof; (TA;) as also majuwfN↓; (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ;) each applied to a man: (TA:) [fem. jawofaMCu:] pl. juwfN. (TA.) You say luWoluWN Oajowafu, and mujaw-afN↓, [Hollow, and hollowed, pearls; or] both signify the same. (TA.) And qanaApN jawofaMCu An empty [or a hollow] cane, or reed: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, XajarapN [a tree]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) having a jawof. (Ṣ.) And dalowN jawofaMCu A wide, or an ample, bucket: (Ḳ:) and dilaMCN jawfN wide, or ample, buckets: (Ṣ:) and qidorN jawofaMCu a wide, capacious, cooking-pot. (Ḥam p. 719.) And AlOajowafu The lion that is great in the jawof [or belly,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) And AlOajowafaAni The belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because of their width. (TA.) See also jawofN. Hence the trad., Uin-a Oaxowafa maA OaxaAfu Ealayokumu AlOajowafaAni [Verily what I most fear for you are the belly and the vulva]. (TA.)
‡ A cowardly man; as also mijowafN↓, and mujaw-afN↓; the last explained in the Ḳ as meaning having no heart: pl. [of the first] juwfN. (TA.)
A horse white in the jawof [or belly] as far as the part where the sides terminate, whatever be the colour of the rest of him; (AO, TA;) as also mijowafN↓. (TA.) [See also mujaw-afN.]
In the conventional language of the science of inflection, † [A hollow word; i. e.] a word having an infirm letter for its medial radical; (Ḳ, TA;) as qaAla and baAEa. (TA.)
mujaAfN ‡ A shut, or closed, door. (TA.)
majuwfN: see Oajowafu.
mijowafN: see Oajowafu, in two places.
mujaw-afN: see Oajowafu, in three places.
Also A beast whose balaq [q. v.] reaches up to his belly: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a horse whose balaq reaches to his sides is said to be mujaw-afN balaqFA. (AA, TA.) [See also Oajowafu, last meaning but one.]
And an epithet applied to the bird called Surad, because it is white in the belly. (Mgh and Mṣb in art. Srd.)
musotajaAfN: see Oajowafu.

hom.sense:
1. jaAla, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yajuwlu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. jawolN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and juwlN (Ḳ) and jawalaAnN (Az, Ṣ, ISd, Z, Ṣgh) and juWuwlN (ISd, Ḳ) and jiylaAlN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ jiylaAn; (TA;) and in like manner, AjtAl↓ and AnjAl↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He went round or about, or or round about; as also jw-l↓, inf. n. tajowaAlN: (Ḳ:) or jw-l signifies he went round, or about, or round about, much, or often; agreeably with what Sb says of the measure tafoEaAlN; but accord. to the O, tajowaAlN is an inf. n. of jAl. (TA.) You say, jAl fiI AlbilaAdi He went about, or round about, in the countries, or districts, not remaining fixed, or settled: (Mṣb:) and jw-l↓, (T, TA,) or jw-l fiI AlbilaAdi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tajowiylN, (T, TA,) or tajowaAlN, (Ṣ,) he went about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts. (T, Ṣ, TA.) And jAl fiI AlmayodaAni, aor. as above, inf. n. jawolapN and jawalaAnN, He (a horse) traversed the sides, or lateral parts or tracts, of the horse-course; which are termed OajowaAlN, pl. of juwlN. (Mṣb.) And jAl fiI AlHarobi, inf. n. jawolapN, He wheeled round, or about, in battle. (Ḳ.) And far-a lilojawalaAni vum-a EaAda liloqitaAli [He fled, to wheel round, or about, and then returned to the fight]. (Mṣb in art. kr.) And jAluwA, (Mṣb,) or tajaAwaluwA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) means jAl baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,)
i. e., They assailed, or assaulted, one another, (TA,) fiI AlHarobi [in battle]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [and so, app., jaAwaluwA↓, inf. n. mujaAwalapN:] and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ *) There were between them mutual [assailings, or assaults, and] defendings. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.) And jAl Alqawomu, inf. n. jawolapN, The company of men were routed, defeated, or put to flight, (AinokaXafuwA,) and then returned to the fight, or charged, or assaulted. (Ḳ.) And OaSaAba Almusolimiyna jawolapN Defeat befell the Muslims: a metonymy; used only in relation to the favourites of God; from AljawalaAnu. (Mgh.)

jAlwuA fiI AlD-alaAlapi, (Ṣgh, TA,) or UilaI AlD-alaAlapi, (A, TA,) † They became excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, and carried away, and driven, (Ṣgh, TA,) or they became fascinated, and turned away, (A, TA,) by the influence of devils, (A, Ṣgh, TA,) from their religion, (Ṣgh, TA,) or from the right course, (A, TA,) to error. (A, Ṣgh, TA.)

jAl Alt-uraAbu, (ISd, Ḳ,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) The dust went away, and rose; as also AnjAl↓: (ISd, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies became removed, or cleared away [by the wind]; syn. AinokaXaTa. (T, TA.)
yajuwlu fiI SadoriI Oano OafoEalahu ‡ [It is revolved in my bosom, or mind, that I should do it]. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

jAl AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) He chose, or selected, the thing. (Ḳ.) You say, julotu hecaA mino hecaA I chose, or selected, this from this. (AA, Ṣ.) And Aijotalotu↓ minohumo jawolFA I chose, or selected, from them [a choice portion]; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) and separated some of them from others. (TA.) And AjtAl↓ mino maAlihi jawolFA, and jawaAlapF, He chose, or selected, from his property, or cattle, a choice portion. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
3. jaAwaluwA, inf. n. mujaAwalapN: and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN: see 1.

4. AjAlhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AjAl bihi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UijaAlapN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also jAl↓ bihi. (Zj, Ḳ.) One says in the game called Almayosir, [see this word,] Oajili Als-ihaAma [Turn thou round about, i. e., shuffle, the arrows in the ribaAbap]. (Ṣ, TA.) And AjAl Als-ihaAma bayona Alqawomi He moved about the arrows, [i. e., shuffled them in the ribaAbap,] (Az, ISd, TA,) and then distributed them among the people, or party. (Az, TA.) And AjAl sayofahu He brandished, flourished, or played with, his sword, turning it round about. (Mṣb.) And Alr-iyHu tajuwlu↓ baAlt-uraAbi, (Lth, TA,) and biAlHaSaI, (Ḳ, TA,) [The wind makes the dust, and the pebbles, to turn round about, to circle, or to revolve.]

OajaAluwA Alr-aOoIa fiymaA bayonahumo ‡ They turned about, or revolved, [in their minds, the idea, or opinion, respecting the matter that was between them.] (TA.) And AjAlwA Alfikari † [They turned about, or revolved, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in their minds]. (Jel in ix. 48.)

[AjAl xamosahu fiI wiEaAYihi, in the 7th Maḳámeh of Ḥar, (p. 76 of the sec. ed.,) is explained in a MṢ. of that work as meaning Adxl, (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., p. 185,) i. e., He inserted: but the proper meaning is, he turned about, or round about, his five fingers in his bag.]
Oajilo jaAYilataka↓ ‡ Accomplish, or finish, the affair in which thou art engaged. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
6: see 1.
7: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: 8: see 1, first sentence.

AjtAlhumo He turned them from their course. (Ḳ.) He (the devil) caused them to leave, or forsake, the right way. (T, TA.) AijotaAlatohumu AlX-ayaATiynu Eano diynihimo The devils excited them to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, so that they turned away from their religion, to error; i. e., they carried them away and drove them [from their religion]. (Ṣgh, TA.) [See also 10.]
See also 1, last two sentences.

entry.sense: 10. AisotajaAlatohumu AlX-ayaATiynu The devils turned them from the right course, to error; fascinated them so that they turned with them. (A, TA.) And AstjAlhu AlX-aIoCu The thing excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 8.]
AstjAlti Alxayolu maA mar-ato bihi The horses removed, or displaced, that by which they passed. (O, TA.)

Ausotujiyla Alr-abaAbu The rbAb [or white clouds] were driven together after a state of dispersion, and became ready to rain: (M, TA:) or it means jaMCatohu Alr-iyHu faQsotajaAlatohu, i. e., the wind came to them, and removed them, or displaced them, and dissundered them, and drove them away. (TA.)
AisotajalonaA AljahaAma ‡ We saw the rainless clouds going about, or round about, in the horizon, (A, TA,) or in the sky. (TA.)
jaAlN: see juwlN, in five places:
and mijowalN.
jaAlK: see jaAYilN.

hom.sense: jawolN: see jawolaAnN, in two places.

Also A large army, or military force, or troop of horse: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. juwlN. (Ṣgh, TA.) A herd of camels: and a troop of xayol [meaning horses or horsemen]: as also juwlN↓ in both these senses: (Ḳ:) or the latter, which is also explained in the Ḳ as signifying a herd of camels, and a flock of ostriches and of sheep or goats, is pl. of the former: (TA:) or the former signifies thirty [horses or horsemen]: or forty: (Ḳ:) or less: or more: (TA:) or the choice, or best, of camels: and [in like manner] jawaAlapN↓ signifies the choice and best; as in the saying, Oaxaca jawaAlapa maAlihi [He took the choice and best of his cattle, or property]. (Ḳ. [See also 1, last two sentences: and see jawalaAn.]) And Many great sheep or goats. (Ḳ.)
Also A male mountain-goat that is old, or advanced in age: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OajowaAlN. (M, TA.)

juwlN The wall [that surrounds the interior] of a well: accord. to AʼObeyd, every side of a well, from its top to its bottom: and jaAlN↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ:) or the former, the side, or lateral part, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a well, and of a grave, and of the sea, and of a mountain; as also jaAlN↓ (M, Ḳ) and jiylN↓: (Ḳ, TA; in the CK jayol:) or the surrounding parts [or sides] of a grave: (M, TA:) and jaAlaA↓ AlwaAdiI the two sides of the water of the valley: and jaAlaA↓ AlbaHori the two shores of the sea, or great river: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajowaAlN, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) pl. of juwlN and jaAlN, (TA,) and [of mult.] jiwaAlN and jiwaAlapN; (so in copies of the Ḳ, and in the M, but in some copies of the Ḳ juwaAlN and juwaAlapN;) and OajaAwilu is pl. of OajowaAlN. (TA.) Also, as in the T and the Moḥeeṭ, (TA,) The portion of rock that is at the bottom of the water, (Ḳ, TA.) upon which is the casing of the well; so that if it quit its place, the well falls to ruin: this is [said to be] the primary meaning of the word: and hence the saying, hecaA maMCN laA yudoraku juwluhu [This is water of which the rock beneath it is not to be reached]. (TA.)

[And from this word as signifying the casing of a well, or the portion of rock above mentioned,] ‡ Intelligence; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) judgment, and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which one has recourse; (T, TA;) understanding of the heart; (TA;) and resolution, or fixed purpose of mind; (Ṣ, M;) and prudence: (T, TA:) AlEazomu in the Ḳ is erroneously put for AlHazomu. (TA.) You say, of a man, maAlahu juwlN ‡ He has not intelligence and judgment, or fixed purpose of mind, to withhold him, or protect him; like the jwl of a well; (Ṣ, M,* TA;*) because a well, when cased with stone or the like, is stronger. (TA.) And rajulN lahu zaborN wajuwlN ‡ A man having judgment and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which recourse is had; whose jwl does not become demolished: and in like manner, huwa mazobuwrN maAfawqa Aljuwli minohu waSulobN maAtaHota Alz-abori mina Aljuwli: and in the contr. case, layosa lifulaAnK juwlN ‡ Such a one has not intelligence nor prudence; i. e., his jwl is demolished, therefore one is not sure that the zbr [that rests upon it] may not also fall: and layosa lahu juwlN, and jaAlN↓, ‡ He has not prudence. (T, TA.)
faEalotuhu mino juwlihi I did it on account, or for the sake, or because, of him, or it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
See also jawolN:
and jawolaAnN.

entry.sense: jiylN: see juwlN.

hom.sense: jawolaAnN Dust; as also jawolN↓ and juwlN↓, (Ḳ,) both mentioned by Az, (TA,) and jayolaAnN↓, (Ḳ,) mentioned by ISd: [or] all signify dust which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve, upon, or from, the surface of the earth. (TA.) And Small pebbles which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve; (Ḳ, TA;) as also jawolN↓ and jayolaAnN↓. (TA.)
jawolaAnu: see Oajowalu.

jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi ‡ The first, or beginning, [lit. the revolving, (see 1,)] of anxieties. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, jawolAnu.]) You say, fiI qalobihi jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi ‡ In his heart are revolving anxieties. (A, TA.)

jawalaAnu AlmaAli The small, or young, and bad, of cattle: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the M and O; but in a copy of the M, written jawolAn; which is app. a mistake. (TA.)
Accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, The choice, or best, of cattle: the contr. of what is said by Fr. (TA. [See also jawolN.])
jayolaAnN: see jawolaAnN, in two places.
jyolaAnu: see Oajowalu.

entry.sense: jawolaAniI-N: see Oajowalu.
Also ‡ A man whose benefits are common to the near and the distant; (Ḳ, TA;) whose benefits go round to every one. (Ṣgh, TA.)
jayolaAniI-N: see Oajowalu.
jawiylN What the winds sweep away (AḤn, M, Ḳ) and round about, (AḤn, M,) of fragments of plants and of the fallen leaves of trees; (AḤn, M, Ḳ;) as also jaAYilN↓. (M, TA.)
jawaAlapN: see jawolN.
jawaAYilu OamorK † The turns (dawaAYir) of an affair, or event. (TA.)

jaw-aAlN One who goes about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts, (Mṣb, TA,) not remaining fixed, or settled; (Mṣb;) as also jaw-aAlapN↓ [but in a more intensive sense, meaning who does so very much, or very often]. (TA.)
A horse having a flexible head: (TA:) and OajowaliI-N↓ a swift horse, that turns about howsoever one turns him. (Ḳ,* TA.)
jaw-aAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
jaAYilN: see jawiylN.
Also Rainless clouds going round about. (A, TA.)

And, applied to a [woman's ornament of the kind termed] wiXaAH, and to a camel's belly-girth, Loose; not tight; unsteady; as also jaAlK↓. (T, TA.) [Hence,] AimoraOapN jaAYilapu AlwiXaAHayoni ‡ A woman slender in the waist. (Z, TA.)
jaAYilapN An affair in which one is engaged. (M, Ḳ.) See 4, last sentence.

Oajowalu [More, and most, wont to go round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve;] is from the first of the verbs in this art.: and hence the prov., Oajowalu mino quTorubK [More wont to go about, or round about, or more restless, than a qTrb; a certain animalcule, or insect, that is constantly moving about: see art. qTrb]. (Ḥar p. 661.)
Also, [as meaning † More, and most, circulating,] applied to language, or discourse. (TA in art. jmE.) [See an ex. voce majomaEN.]
yawomN Oajowalu, and jayolaAniI-N↓, and jawolaAniI-N↓, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) and jawolaAnu↓, and jayolaAnu↓, (M, Ḳ,) A day of much dust (T, M, Ḳ) and wind: (T, TA:) from jawolN signifying “dust.” (TA.)
OajowaliI-N: see jaw-aAlN.
majaAlN A place in which one goes round, or about, or round about: (TA:) [a field of battle: a circus:] a place of exercise for horses. (Ḥar p. 16.)
[Hence] one says, lamo yaboqa majaAlN fiI AlOamori ‡ [There remained not any scope in the affair, or case]. (TA.)

hom.sense:
mijowalN A certain garment for women, (M, Ḳ,) doubled, and sewed together at one of its two sides, and having an opening made to it at the neck and bosom; in which a woman goes about: (M, TA:) or for a young girl; (Ḳ;) the diroE being for a woman: (TA:) a small garment in which a girl goes about: (Ṣ:) or a garment which a girl wears before she is made to keep herself behind, or within, the curtain, and in which she goes about: (Z, TA:) accord. to IAạr, i. q. SudorapN. (TA.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
UilaI mivolihaAyaronuw AlHaliymu SabaAbapF
UicaA maA Qsobakar-ato bayona diroEK wamijowali
[At the like of her the staid would fixedly gaze with tenderness of desire, when she has become of erect and justly-proportioned stature, between such as wears a woman's shirt and such as wears a young girl's garment]. (Ṣ,* TA.)
A woman's anklet. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
An amulet, a phylactery, or charm of the kind termed Euwcap. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A crescent of silver in the middle of the necklace termed qilaAdap. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Silver [itself]. (Th, Ḳ.)
A good, or sound, diroham [or silver coin]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A shield; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) sometimes used in this sense; (Ṣ, O;) as also jaAlN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
A large wooden bowl. (IAạr, TA.)

A white vawob [or piece of cloth] that is put upon the hand of him to whom the players at the game called Almayosir commit the arrows [to be shuffled and distributed, in order that he may not be able to distinguish them by the feel,] when they have collected themselves. (ISd, Ḳ,* TA.) [For the same purpose, a piece of thin skin was also used: see ribaAbapN.]
A pool of water left by a torrent; because the water goes round about in it. (IF, TA.)
A wild ass. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: musotajaAlN [pass. part. n. of 10, Turned from the right course,, &c.:] excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness: (TA:) being bereft of his reason, or intellect. (AA, TA.)

jaAmN A vessel, (Ḳ,) or faAvuwr [i. e. a basin, or a table, or a tray used as a table], (IAạr, TA,) of silver: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) or a white dish or tray, of glass or of silver: (Mgh:) or a vessel (Zarof) of glass: (Ḥar p. 200:) [a Persian word, i. e. jaAmo, arabicized; or] a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoWumN, with C, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and OajowaAmN, and (as some say, IAạr, TA, [of mult.,]) juwmN, (Ḳ,) with damm, (TA, in the CK jawomN,) and [of pauc. or mult.] jaAmaAtN: (IAạr, Ḳ:) but IB says that jaAmN is pl. of jaAmapN↓, as is also jaAmaAtN: [instead of which he should rather have said that jAm is a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is jAmp, (though this requires consideration, as the former is commonly used as a sing.,) and that the pl. of the latter is jAmAt:] that its dim. is juwayomapN↓: and that it, i. e. jAm, is of the fem. gender. (TA.)
jaAmapN: see above.
juwayomapN: see above.
1. jaAna, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jAn-a,]) inf. n. jawonN, (TA,) It (the face) became black. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: jawonN White: and black: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (Ṣ:) and juwniI-N↓, also, has the latter signification: (IAth, TA in art. Hwt:) or jawonN signifies black tinged over with red: (T, M, TA:) and black intermixed with red; the colour of the qaTaA: (T, TA:) and also red: (Ḳ:) or of a pure red colour: (TA:) and, applied to a horse and a camel, of the colour termed Oadoham, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) intensely black: (Ṣ:) every camel, and every wild ass, seen from a distance, is of this colour: fem. with p {jawonapN}: (T, TA:) and, applied to a plant, or herbage, green, (Ḳ,) or intensely green, (TA,) inclining to blackness: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. juwnN; (Ṣ, TA;) like as SutomN is of SatomN, (Ṣ,) and wurodN of warodN. (M, TA.) You say also, AlX-amosu jawonapN The sun is characterized by what is termed juwnapN: (Ṣ:) or is intensely glistening and clear. (Az, TA.) [See also jawonapN below.] See also juwniI-N. Accord. to ISk, Oabuw Aljawoni means The white man: opposed to OabuwAlbayoDaMCi meaning the negro. (TA in art. byD.)

Also † Day: (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.) So in the saying,
gay-ara yaA binota AlHulayosi lawoniI
mar-u All-ayaAliI waQxotilaAfu Aljuwoni
[The passing of the nights, and the alternating of the day, have changed, O daughter of El-Holeys, my colour]. (AO, Ṣ.)
And, accord. to certain of the lawyers, metaphorically, ‡ The light: and the darkness. (Mṣb.)
And accord. to IAạr, † The frq [app. faraq, meaning day-break]. (TA.)
AljawonaAni The two extremities of the bow. (Fr, Az, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jawonapN The sun; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] the sun's disc; because it becomes black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting; (Ṣ;) or it may be because of its whiteness and clearness; but it is said to be only applied to the sun when it is setting; opposed to gazaAlapN; as observed by MF: (TA:) [see also jawonN:] the sun is also called jawonaMCu↓, (Ḳ,) because of its becoming black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting. (TA.)
A [jar such as is called] xaAbiyap: (IAạr, TA:) or a xAbyp smeared with tar, or pitch. (Ṣ.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn.] See also juwnapN.
And A bucket (dalow) that has become black. (IAạr, TA.)
And i. q. faHomapN [which may here mean either A piece of charcoal, or the blackness of night or the like]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And i. q. OaHomaru [perhaps as a subst., meaning A red thing]. (Ḳ.)
See also jawniI-N.

hom.sense:
juwnapN The quality [i. e. colour], in horses, denoted by [the epithet] jawonN; like gubospN and duhomapN; (Ṣ;) in horses, i. q. jawonapN: (Ḳ:) and in the sun, also, the quality denoted by jawonapN [as fem. of jawonN, q. v.]: and blackness; as in the saying, laA OafoEaluhu Hat-aI taboyaD-a juwnapu AlqaAri [I will not do it until the blackness of pitch, or tar, become white]:
but if you say jawonapu↓ AlqaAri, the meaning is the xaAbiyp [smeared with tar, or pitch]. (Ṣ.)

A small basket (sulayolap), (Ḳ,) or safaT, (Ḳ in art. jOn,) of a round form, (TA,) that is with the sellers of perfumes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) used for containing their perfumes: (Ḳ in art. jOn:) called in Persian XiyXaho daAnN [a receptacle for bottles or the like]: (KL:) originally with C: (Ḳ:) or sometimes pronounced with C: (Ṣ:) El-Fárisee approved the suppression of the C: (M, TA:) pl. juwanN. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [See also raboEapN.]
A small mountain. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jawonaMCu: see jawonapN.
Also A cooking-pot; (Ḳ;) because it is black. (TA.)
And A she-camel such as is termed dahomaMCu [of an intense, or a dark, gray colour, without any admixture of white]; from jaAna said of the face. (Ḳ.)
juwniI-N: see jawonN.

Also A species of the kind of bird called qaTFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) black in the belly and wings, larger than the [species called] kudoriI-, one of the former species being equal to two of the latter: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to ISk, the qTA compose two species; one called juwniI-N and kudoriI-N; and the other, gaTaATN; and the former is dusky, or dingy, or of a hue inclining to black and dust-colour, (Oakodar,) in the back, black in the inner side of the wing, yellow in the throat, short in the legs, having in the tail two feathers longer than the rest of the tail: (T, TA:) or, as some say, the kudoriy-ap and juwniy-ap are one of the two species of the qTA, and the other is the gTAT; and the former are short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials: (TA voce gTAT, q. v.:) [but see kudoriI-N: the jwnI- is described by De Sacy, on the authority of the book entitled dr-p AlmntqAp mn EjAYb AlmxlwqAt wgrAYb AlmwjwdAt, thus: “le djouni a les barbes internes des ailes et les pennes primaires noires; il a la gorge blanche, ornée de deux colliers, l'un jaune et l'autre noir; son dos est d'un gris cendré, moucheté, mêlé d'un peu de jaune: on appelle cette espèce djouni, parce que sa voix ne rend pas un son clair et sonore, mais qu'elle fait entendre seulement une sorte de gargouillement dans le gosier:” (Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 369:)] it is stated in the handwriting of Aṣ, on the authority of the Arabs, that jwnI-, applied to the qTA, is with C; app. meaning that it was pronounced juWuniI-N: (M, TA:) a single bird of this species is termed juwniy-apN: (Ṣ:) and you say also qaTaApN jawonapN↓, with fet-ḥ: (TA:) [but juwniI-N seems to be also used as a n. un., like ruwmiI-N: for it is said that] juwnN is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of juwnI-N, like as tamorN is of tamorapN. (Ḥam p. 605.)

1. jaAhahu biAlmakoruwhi, (Ṣ,) or bimakoruwhK, (Ḳ,) [aor. yajuwhu,] inf. n. jawohN, (Ṣ,) i. q. jabahahu bihi [He met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, or he accused him, to his face, of, that which was, or a thing that was, disliked, or hated]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And [in like manner,] jAhhu biXar-K He encountered him with evil [speech or conduct]; or confronted him therewith: whence laA jihota, i. e. Mayest thou not be encountered with evil; said in chiding a he-camel: see jaAhi below. (TA.) A woman of Ghatafán, being chidden by her son, and being asked why she did not reply against him, said, OaxaAfu Oano yajuwhaniI biOakovara mino hecaA, meaning I fear that he would encounter me with more than this. (JK.)

[2. jw-h and AjAh↓ are rendered by Golius Ad dignitatem evexit: spectabilem reddidit: as on the authority of the Ṣ: but in my copies of the Ṣ the two verbs are Awjh and wj-h; and belong to art. wjh, though mentioned in the present art.]
5. tjw-h He magnified himself; or was, or became, proud, haughty, or disdainful: or he affected rank, station, or dignity, not possessing it. (TA.)

hom.sense: jaAhN Rank, station, or dignity, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, and JK in art. wjh,) with, or in the estimation of, the Sultán; (JK, TA;) as also jaAhapN↓, (Ḳ,) on the authority of Lḥ, (TA, as from the Ḳ, [but not in my copies,]) or, accord. to Ṣgh, of Ks.: the former word [probably arabicized from the Persian jaAho; but] said to be formed by transposition from wajohN; this being first changed to jawohN; then, to jawahN; and then, to jaAhN: or, accord. to Lḥ, it is not from wajohN, but from juhot [app. juhotu, first pers. sing. of jaAha, q. v.]; though he does not explain what is juhot. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN cuw jaAhK [Such a one is possessed of rank, station, or dignity]. (Ṣ.) And lifulaAnK jaAhN fiyhimo To such a one belongs rank, station, or dignity, among them. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) The dim. of jaAhN [or of jaAhapN] is juwayohapN↓. (TA.)

jaAhi, indecl., with kesr for its termination; and, accord. to Aṣ, sometimes, jaAhK, with tenween; (Ṣ;) or jaAhi jaAhi, (JK, Ḳ,) and jaAhK jaAhK, and jaAho jaAho, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and juwh juwh↓, or jawoh jawoh, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, but) indecl., with kesr for the termination, [i. e. juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi,] mentioned in the M, (TA,) and jaAhi laA jihota↓, (IDrd, TA, [see 1,]) ejaculations used for chiding a he-camel, not a she-camel: (Aṣ, JK, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one says to a she-camel, EaAjK and jaAhK. (AʼObeyd, TA in art. Ewj: [or perhaps there is an omission here: I think it more likely that what AʼObeyd said was that one says to a she-camel EaAjK, and to a he-camel jaAhK.])

juwhN The face, or countenance: syn. wajohN; as also jiyhN: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) the latter with kesr: (TA:) so in the saying, naZara bijuwhi sawoCK and bijiyhi sawoCK [He looked with an evil face or countenance]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi: see the next preceding paragraph.

entry.sense: jaAhapN: see jaAhN.
juwayohapN: see jaAhN.
tujaAha and tijaAha and tajaAha: see art. wjh.
jawoharN: see art. jhr.
jawohariI-N: see art. jhr.

1. jawiIa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yajowaIu}, (TA,) inf. n. jawFI, (Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, affected with what is termed jawFI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning ardour: and violence of amorous desire; or of grief, or sorrow: (Ṣ:) or inward love: (M, Ḳ:) and grief, or sorrow: (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ:) and ardour: and violence of love: or of grief, or sorrow: (Ḳ:) [see Hub-N:]

and also as meaning consumption; or an ulcer in the lungs: and long continuance, or oppressiveness, of disease: and a disease in the chest: (Ḳ:) or any inward disease during which one does not find food to be wholesome: (TA:) part. n. jawK↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) fem. jawiyapN. (TA.)

You say also, jawiyato nafosiI, meaning I found the country, or town, to disagree with me. (Ṣ.) And jawiyato nafosuhu minohu and Eanohu [He found it to disagree with him: a meaning indicated, but not expressed]. (Ḳ.) See also 8.
And jawiyati AlOaroDu The land stank. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AjtwAhu He disliked residing in it, namely, a country, or town, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: (Ṣ:) or he disliked it, (Ḳ, TA,) and found it to disagree with him; (TA;) as also jawiyahu↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or he disliked it, namely, a city, and found it to be insalubrious: or, as AZ says, he disliked it, namely, a country, even if it agreed with him in respect of his body: and he says, in his Nawádir, that AijotiwaMCN signifies the yearning towards, or longing for, home, and disliking a place, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: and disliking it without yearning towards, or longing for, home: and also the not finding the food nor the beverage in a land to be wholesome: but not when one likes the residing in it but its food and beverage do not agree with him. (TA.)
And AjtwI His heart was burnt by the fire of enmity. (Ḥam p. 219.)

entry.sense: jawFI: see 1:
and see what next follows, in two places.
jawK part. n. of 1, q. v.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and jawFI↓ signifies the same, being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Ḳ.)
Hence, (Ṣ,) the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also ↓the latter, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) signifies Stinking water; (Ḳ;) or water that has become altered and stinking. (Ṣ, TA.)
OaroDN jawiyapN and jawiy-apN↓ A land that disagrees with one. (Ḳ.)
jawiI-N Contracted in the bosom, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of disease therein, (TA,) so that his tongue cannot explain for him, (Ḳ,) or so that his tongue can hardly, or not at all, explain for him. (TA.)
OaroDN jawiy-apN: see jawK.

3. jaAyaAhu, inf. n. mujaAyaApN, He faced him, fronted him, was opposite to him, or was over against him: a dial. var. of jaAyaOahu. (IAạr, Ḳ.) You say also, mar-a biI mujaAyaApF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.)

1. jaMCa, aor. yajiIoCu, inf. n. majiIoCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c., [the most common form, but] deviating from the general rule [respecting inf. ns. of this class], for the inf. n. of a verb of the form faEala having its aor. of the form yafoEilu is [accord. to the general rule, if commencing with an augmentative m,] mafoEalN, though some words, beside majiIoCN, deviate from this rule by being of the measure mafoEilN, [for majiIoCN is originally majoyiYN,] as maEiyXN and makiylN and maSiyrN and masiyrN and maHiydN and mamiylN and maqiylN and maziydN and maEiylN and mabiyEN and maHiySN and maHiyDN, Ṣ,* TA) and jayoYapN (Ṣ, Ḳ, of the form of an inf. n. of un., but used as an inf. n. in an absolute sense, like rajofapN and raHomapN, Ṣ, TA) and jaIoCN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, came; or was, or became, present; syn. OataI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or HaDara, said of a man [&c.]; (Mṣb;) or HaSala [meaning it came, came to pass, happened, took place, betided, befell, or occurred; it resulted; it ensued;, &c.]; and it is used in relation to ideal, as well as real, substantives; so that UicaA jaMCa naSoru Qll-ehi [When the assistance of God shall come (in the Ḳur ex. 1)] is [not a figurative but] a proper phrase. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Sb mentions, on the authority of certain of the Arabs, huwa yajiyka [for hw yajiyoWuka He comes, or will come, to thee], with the hemzeh suppressed: (TA:) and he also mentions yajuwoCu as a dial. var. of yajiIoCu. (Id. in art. jwO, q. v.) [As shown above,] jaMCa is used intransitively and transitively. (Mṣb, MF.) say, jaMCa zayodN Zeyd came; or was, or became, present. (Mṣb.) And jiYotu majiyoYFA HasanFA [I came with a good coming; or in a good manner]. (Ṣ.) And jiYotu zayodFA I came to Zeyd. (Mṣb.) And sometimes one says, jiYotu Uilayohi meaning I went [as well as I came] to him, or it. (Mṣb.) And jiYotu mina Albaladi [I came from the town, or country]: and mina Alqawomi, meaning mino Einodi Alqawomi [from the presence of the people, or company of men]. (Mṣb.) And jaMCa Algayovu The rain [came, or] descended. (Mṣb.) And jaMCa Oamoru Als-uloTaAni The order, or command, of the Sultán came, or arrived. (Mṣb.) And jiYotu bihi (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajaOotuhu↓, both signifying the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [I came with him, or it;] I brought him, or it, with me. (Mṣb.) And AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI jaMCa bika [Praise be to God who brought thee]; and AlHamodu lil-ehi Uico jiYota [Praise be to God because, or that, thou camest, or hast come]; but not AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI jiYota: (Ṣ, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, AlHamodu lil-ehi Uico kaAna kacaA; but not AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI kaAna kacaA unless you say bihi or minohu or Eanohu [after AlcI]. (ISk, TA.) [Hence, jaMCa biwaladK He begot a child, or children; like OataI biwaladK. And jaMCto bihi She brought him forth; gave birth to him; like Oatato bihi. And jaMCa bimaEonFI It (a word) conveyed, or imported, a meaning.]

[jaMCa biXaIoCK also signifies He brought to pass, did, executed, performed, or effected, a thing: and he said, gave utterance to, or uttered, a thing: like OataI bihi in both these senses.] And jaMCa kacaA He did thus, or such a thing. (TA.) Hence, [in the Ḳur xix. 28,] laqado jiYoti XayoYFA fariy-FA (TA) [Verily, O Mary, thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange. (Bḍ. [See another ex. voce UimorN, likewise from the Ḳur.]) And jiYotu XayoYFA HasanFA I did a good thing. (Mṣb.) And jaMCa biAlbadiyEi He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA in art. bdE.) And jaMCa jaroyFA baEoda jaroIK (Ḳ in art. tOm) or [more commonly] jAC bijaroIK baEoda jaroIK (M in that art.) [He (a horse) performed, or fetched, run after run].

jaMC is also syn. with SaAra, like OataI; as in the saying, jaMCa AlbinaMCu muHokamFA The building became, or came to be, firm, strong, or compact. (Kull p. 11.) [And hence the phrase,] maA jaMCato HaAjataka, (M, Ḳ,) thus in all the copies of the Ḳ, with the noun in the accus. case; i. e. What became, or has become, thy want? syn. maA SaArato; (M, Ḳ;) or What was thy want? syn. maA kaAnato: (Er-Raḍee, TA:) mA being here an interrogative, and the [implied] pronoun [in the verb] being made fem. because its predicate is fem.: but some say HaAjatuka, in the nom. case, [as it is in the CK, meaning What did, or has, thy want become?] regarding HAjtk as the subject of jACt, and mA as the predicate of this verb. (TA.)
See also 3.

3. mujaAyaOapN [inf. n. of jaAyaOa] signifies The act of facing, or fronting; being opposite, or over against: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and the act of coinciding; as also jiyaMCN. (AZ, Ḳ.) You say of a man, jaAyaOaniI mino qurobK He faced me, fronted me, was opposite to me, or was over against me, at a short distance. (TA.) And mar-a biI mujaAyaOapF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.) And jaAyaOotu fulaAnFA I coincided with such a one in his coming. (TA.) And lawo jaAwazota hecaA AlmakaAna lajaAyaOota Algayova Hadst thou passed beyond this place, thou hadst met with rain, or coincided with rain in its coming. (TA.)

jaAMniI fajiYotuhu↓, [so in copies of the Ṣ, and in copies of the Ḳ, as from the Ṣ, but in the TA, as from the Ṣ, jaMCaOaniI, and said to be with two hemzehs, though this is evidently wrong,] aor. OajiyoWuhu, the former verb of the measure faAEalaniI, (Ṣ,) is [said to be] a mistake for jaAyaOaniI fjYth, since the former verb has an infirm letter [I] for its medial radical and C for its final, not the reverse, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) [therefore] what J says is not allowable unless it be an instance of transposition; (IB, TA;) but what is given by F [and Ṣgh as the correct form] is that which is accord. to rule, and what J says is that which has been heard from the Arabs, as ISd has pointed out; (TA;) [and rule is not to be regarded when it is contr. to classical usage;] the meaning is, He vied with me, or strove to surpass me, in frequency of coming, and I surpassed him therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. OajaACahu He made him, or it, to come. (Kull p. 11.)
[Hence,] OajaOotuhu i. q. jiYotu bihi: see 1. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OajaOotuhu Uilayohi I compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or made him to want it, or be in need of it: (Ṣ:) in the dial. of Temeem, OaXaOotuhu. (TA in art. XyO.) It is said in a prov., Xar-N maA yujiyoWuka UilaI mux-api EuroquwbK [It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]; for, as Aṣ says, the Erqwb contains no marrow, and only he who cannot obtain any [other] thing is made to want it. (Ṣ.) And it is said in the Ḳur xix. 23, faOajaMCahaA AlmaxaADu UilaI jicoEi Aln-axolapi And the motion of the child in her womb compelled her to betake herself to the trunk of the palm-tree. (Bḍ.)
jiyoYapN [A coming;] a subst. from jaMCa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure fiEolapN, with kesr to the j. (Ṣ.)
jaYiYN and jaO-LCN: see what next follows.

jay-aMCN, (Ḳ,) mentioned by Sb as an extr. word, (TA,) [but regularly formed, of the measure faE-aAlN,] and jaO-LCN↓, also written jaO-aACN, (Ḳ,) with the I changed into hemzeh, (TA,) and jaYiYN↓, (Ḳ,) [originally jayiYN, of the measure faEilN, denoting intensiveness, in the CK written jaAyiYN,] mentioned by IJ as anomalous, A frequent comer. (TA.) One says, Uin-ahu lajay-aMCN bixayorK Verily he is a frequent bringer of good. (TA.)
[jaMCK, originally jaAyiYN, then jaAYiYN, then jaAYiIN, and then jaMCK, Coming; act. part. n. of 1.]
1. jaAba, aor. yajiybu: see 1 in art. jwb, in two places.
2. jy-b, inf. n. tajoyiybN: see 1 in art. jwb.

jayobN The Tawoq [or opening at the neck and bosom] (Ḳ) of a shirt (Ṣ, Ḳ) and the like; (Ḳ;) as, for instance, of a coat of mail: (TA:) or the opening of a shirt at the uppermost part of the breast: (Mṣb, MF:) or the opening in a garment for the head to be put through: or such an opening as a sleeve and a Tawoq: (MF:) pl. [of mult.] juyuwbN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) also pronounced jiyuwbN, (TA,) [like biyuwtN for buyuwtN,] and [of pauc.] OajoyaAbN: (Mṣb:) this is said to be its proper art., (Ḳ, TA,) not jwb, because its pl. is juyuwbN. (TA.) [The Arabs often carry things within the bosom of the shirt, &c.; and hence the word is now applied by them to A pocket.]

† The heart; the bosom. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, huwa naASiHu Aljayobi † [He is pure, or sincere, of heart or bosom]: (Ḳ:) or trusty, trustworthy, or faithful. (Ṣ. [See also art. nSH.]) A poet says,
waxaX-anota SadorFA jayobuhu laka naASiHu
† [And thou hast exasperated a bosom the heart of which was faithful to thee]. (TA.) You say also, huwa danisu Aljayobi † [He is a person of foul heart]. (A in art. dns.) And radaEa jayobahu Eanohu † He cleared his heart, or bosom, of it. (Ḳ in art. rdE q. v.)
