jayobu AlOaroDi † The place of entrance of the land, or country: (Ḳ:) pl. juyuwbN. (TA.)
jiybapN: see art. jwb.

yaAquwtN mujay-abN Hollowed [sapphires]: occurring in a trad. describing the banks of the river of Paradise: but accord. to one reading, it is luWoluWN mujaw-abN; accord. to another, mujay-abN or majaw-afN; and accord. to another, mujay-abN or mujaw-abN. (TA.)

1. jaAHati AlMfapu AlmaAla, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN, [perhaps a mistranscription for jaAYiHapN,] i. q. jaAHatohu of which the aor. is tajuwHuhu: see art. jwH. (Mṣb.) And jaAHahumu Qll-ehu, inf. n. jayoHN and jaAYiHapN, the latter an inf. n. like EaAfiyapN, God afflicted them with a calamity. (TA.)
majiyHN i. q. majuwHN: see art. jwH. (Mṣb.)

1. jayida, (Lḥ, L,) or jaAda, of the same class as taEiba, aor. yajaAdu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. jayadN, (Lḥ, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He had a long neck: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a long and beautiful neck: (Ṣ, L:) or a slender and long neck. (L, Ḳ.)

jiydN, of the measure fiEolN, (Sb, Akh,) or it may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (Sb, TA,) The neck: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) said by Sh to be used only in praise; and EunuqN, in dispraise; the use of the former in the Ḳur exi. being ironical; (TA;) but accord. to Esh-Shiháb, the contr. is often the case: (MF:) generally applied to that of a woman: (L:) or the part of the neck upon which the necklace lies: or its fore part: (L, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoyaAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] juyuwdN. (L, Ḳ.) lay-inapu AlOajoyaAdi means A female soft in respect of the neck; as though the term jiydN applied to each distinct part of the neck, and the pl. denoted the whole neck. (L.)
jayodaAnapN: see Oajoyadu.
jay-idN: see art. jwd.

Oajoyadu Having a long neck: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or having a long and beautiful neck: (Ṣ, L:) or having a slender and long neck: (L, Ḳ:) or it is not applied to a man: (T, TA:) fem. jayodaMCu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with which jayodaAnapN↓ is syn.; (Ḳ;) or this signifies having a beautiful neck: (L:) pl. juwdN [originally juyodN]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And EunuqN Oajoyadu A long and beautiful, or slender and long, neck. (L.)
2. jy-r He plastered a watering-trough or tank with jay-aAr. (TA.)

jayori, with kesr to the r, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ, &c.,) like Oamosi; (Mughnee;) and jayora, like Oayona; and sometimes jayorK; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) or this, where it occurs, is for jayori Uin-a, and is properly written jayorino, Uin-a in the sense of naEamo being a corroborative of jayori, and its hemzeh and sheddeh and final vowel being here suppressed: (Mughnee:) a form of oath, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or put in the place of an oath, (IAmb, TA,) meaning Verily, or truly; syn. Haq-FA: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a responsive particle, (Mughnee,) meaning yes; syn. naEamo [which is most approved as responsive to an interrogation], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) or Oajalo [which is most approved as responsive to an affirmation]; (Sharh et-Tesheel, Ḳ;) not a noun in the sense of Haq-FA, for were it so it would be an inf. n.; nor in the sense of OabadFA, for were it so it would be an adv. n. of time; and if it were a noun it would be decl., and would admit the article Al, and would not have Uin-a for a corroborative, nor have laA opposed to it, as it has in the saying,
UicaA taquwlu laA Qbonapu AlEujayori
taSoduqu laA UicaA taquwlu jayori
[When the daughter of El-ʼOjeyr says lA, she speaks truly: not when she says jyr]: (Mughnee:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I know; syn. OaEorifu; as is mentioned by Ibn-Abi-r-Rabeea, and by Er-Raḍee on the authority of ʼAbd-El-Káhir. (MF.) You say, jayori laA Mtiyka Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not come to thee. (Ṣ.) And jayori laA OafoEalu celika Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do that. (Ḳ,* TA.) And laA jayori laA OafoEalu No, verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do [that]. (Ḳ.)
jiyrN Gypsum; syn. jiS-N. (IAạr, TA.) [In modern Arabic, Lime: see also what next follows.]

hom.sense: jay-aArN Quick lime, and the mixtures thereof, with which are plastered watering-troughs or tanks, and baths; syn. SaAruwjN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) quick lime and gypsum mixed with ashes: (IAạr TA:) or quick lime alone. (TA. [See also jiyrN.])
[A limeburner: so in the present day: see OatuwnN.]

Heat in the chest, by reason of rage or hunger; as also jaAYirN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or cough, or the like. (Ḥam p. 56.) It is app. of the measure faE-aAlN; or it may be of the measure fayoEaAlN; or fawoEaAlN [originally jawoyaArN]. (IJ, TA.)
Strength, or vehemence. (TA.)

entry.sense: jaAYirN: see jay-aArN.
mujay-arN A watering-trough or tank made small: or made deep: or plastered with gypsum. (Ḳ.)

1. jaAXa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yajiyXu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. jayoXN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and jayaXaAnN (T, Ḳ) and juyuwXN, (Ḳ,) said of a cooking-pot (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ), &c., (T, A, Ḳ,) It boiled, or estuated: (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or began to do so, not yet boiling or estuating; this latter being said by some to be the correct meaning. (Ib, L, TA.)
‡ It (the sea) estuated (A,* Ḳ, TA) with the waves, (A, TA,) so that it was unnavigable. (TA.)
† It (a valley) flowed with much water, its water, or waves, rising high. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
† It (a water-spout, or pipe,) poured forth water: (TA:) and [in like manner] you say of the eye, jaAXato, meaning, † it flowed, or overflowed, with tears. (Ḳ.)
† He (a horse) reared, and became excited. (TA.)

jaAXa Sadoruhu ‡ His bosom boiled with wrath, or rage. (TA.) You say also, Sadoruhu yajiyXu EalaI-a biAlgil-i ‡ [His bosom boils against me with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or with latent rancour,, &c.]. (A.)
jaAXa Alham-u fiI AlS-adori Anxiety boiled in the bosom: and in like manner, jaAXati AlguS-apu fiI AlS-adori † [Choking wrath or rage boiled in the bosom]. (T, TA.)
jaAXat AlHarobu bayonahumo (A, L) ‡ War, or the war, [boiled, or raged, or] began to boil [or rage,] between them. (L, TA.)

In the following words of a poet, cited by IAạr,
qaAmato tabad-aI laka fiI jayoXaAnihaA
† [She arose, showing herself to thee] in her strength and youth, [tabad-aI being for tatabad-aI,] jyXAn, [the inf. n.,] meaning as rendered above, is with sukoon [to the I] by poetic license. (ISd, TA.)
2. jy-X, [from jayoXN,] He collected, or assembled, armies, or military forces. (Ṣ.) And jy-X jayoXFA [He collected, or assembled, an army, or a military force]. (A.)

hom.sense: 5. tjy-Xt nafosuhu: see 1.
[tjy-XwA, from jayoXN, They became collected, or assembled, as an army, or a military force: or they formed themselves into an army, or a military force.]

entry.sense: 10. AstjAX, [from jayoXN,] He demanded, or summoned, armies, or military forces, mino maHal-i kacaA from such a place. (A.) And AstjAXhu He demanded of him an army, or a military force. (Ṣ.)
jaAXN: see jaOoXN, in art. jOX, in two places; and see AljaAYiXapu, below.
jayoXN An army; a military force: (A, Ḳ:) or a body of men in war: (TA:) or men going to war or for some other purpose: (T, Ḳ, TA:) pl. juyuwXN. (Ṣ, A Mṣb, Ḳ.)
jayoXapN A single rising, or heaving, or the like: pl. jayoXaAtN: hence the phrase jayoXaAtu AlOabaATiyli [app. meaning The risings of false or vain things in the mind, or the like]. (TA.)
mirojalN jay-aAXN [A cooking-pot boiling, or boiling much]. (A.)
farasN jiy-aAXN † A horse that rears and is excited when thou puttest him in motion with thy heel. (Ḳ * TA.)
AljaAYiXapu The soul; syn. Aln-afosu; (Ḳ;) [as also AljaOoXu, sometimes written AljaAXu↓, without C;] mentioned by some in art. jOX. (TA.) Quasi
jayaAEaI and juy-aEN: see jaAYiEN, in art. jwE.

1. jaAfati Aljiyfapu, aor. tajiyfu; (Ḳ;) and jy-ft↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. tajoyiyfN; (Ṣ;) and AjtAft↓, (Ḳ,) [and tjy-ft↓, Golius, as from the Ḳ, but not found by me in any copy thereof,] and AnjAft↓; (TA;) The dead body stank, or became stinking. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)
2. jy-f He became a stinking dead body. (Mgh, KL.)
See also 1.
5: see 1.
7: see 1.
8: see 1.

jiyfapN [A carcass, or corpse, i. e.] a dead body [of a beast or a man], that has become stinking; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) or, as some say, in a general sense; [whether stinking or not:] (TA:) or, of beasts and cattle, an animal that has died a natural death, or been killed otherwise than in the manner prescribed by the law, and has become stinking: (Mṣb:) [and the corpse of a man: (see jay-aAfN:)] pl. [of mult.] jiyafN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OajoyaAfN. (Ṣ Ḳ.) [Hence,] jiyfapu layolK quTorubu nahaArK One who sleeps all the night, and labours all the day. (TA from a trad. [See also art. qTrb.]) IDrd mentions this word in art. jwf, holding the I to be originally w. (TA.)
jay-aAfN A rifler, or ransacker, of graves; (Ḳ, TA;) because he removes the [grave-] clothes from the corpses, and takes them; or, as some say, because of the stinking nature of his act. (TA.)

hom.sense: jiylN A nation, people, race, tribe, or family of mankind; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) such as the Turks, and the Greeks, (Ṣ. TA,) and the Chinese: (TA:) pl. OajoyaAlN (M, Mṣb, TA) and jiylaAnN. (M, TA.)
And A generation of men. (TA.)
See also juwlN.

entry.sense: jayalu: see jayoOalu, in art. jOl.

hom.sense: jayolaAnu AlHaSaI Small pebbles which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but this belongs to art. jwl. (TA.)
yawomN jayolaAnu: see Oajowalu, in art. jwl.

entry.sense: yawomN jayolaAniI-N: see Oajowalu, in art. jwl.
2. jy-m jiymFA He wrote a j. (Ḳ.)
jiymN The letter j: masc. and fem.: (T, Ḳ,* TA:) pl. OajoyaAmN and jiymaAtN. (TA.) Quasi
jiyhN: see juwhN, in art. jwh.
